description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA A+ 900 Series certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the two exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for entry level IT professionals with about a year of experience. Some of the exam objectives include hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, security, and troubleshooting, making it a valuable certification to have especially for one just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience.
descriptionMD: Those looking to complete the CompTIA A+ 900 Series certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the two exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for entry level IT professionals with about a year of experience. Some of the exam objectives include hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, security, and troubleshooting, making it a valuable certification to have especially for one just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience.__This course has been CAQC'd and qualifies for CEU credits. [Click here](https://itpro.tv/comptia-partnership) to get an exam voucher discount.__
name: CompTIA A+ (220-901)
subtitle: Vendor-neutral hardware and software technologies

episodes.description: Those looking to complete the CompTIA A+ 900 Series certification will find in this course an overview of the process in achieving the certification and details about the two exams required to pass in order to receive the certification. The certification is designed for entry level IT professionals with about a year of experience. Some of the exam objectives include hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, security, and troubleshooting, making it a valuable certification to have especially for one just getting in to the IT career field with no documented experience.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.048
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.048 --> 00:00:11.530
In this series, we're gonna be
looking at CompTIA's A+ 220-901 exam.

3
00:00:11.530 --> 00:00:16.780
We'd like to take a moment and
tell you, what is the A+ 220-901 exam?

4
00:00:16.780 --> 00:00:21.772
Who is this course for, what will be
covered and what are the exam details?

5
00:00:21.772 --> 00:00:26.647
What is A+ 220-901?

6
00:00:26.647 --> 00:00:31.051
Well, the A+ 220-901 is a vendor
neutral certification in

7
00:00:31.051 --> 00:00:35.842
the fact that you will be learning
a great many different technologies and

8
00:00:35.842 --> 00:00:39.350
not any one technology
from any specific vendor.

9
00:00:39.350 --> 00:00:41.520
It's also a worldwide accreditation.

10
00:00:41.520 --> 00:00:44.430
Which means that if you are here
in the United States and

11
00:00:44.430 --> 00:00:45.885
you earn a certification,

12
00:00:45.885 --> 00:00:50.330
your certification is just as valid as if
you earned it in Barcelona, Spain per se.

13
00:00:50.330 --> 00:00:56.274
Also understand that it is not
only a worldwide accreditation,

14
00:00:56.274 --> 00:01:01.447
it's also DOD compliant for
the 8140 objective and

15
00:01:01.447 --> 00:01:04.542
8570.01-mcompliant.

16
00:01:04.542 --> 00:01:06.230
Who is this course for?

17
00:01:06.230 --> 00:01:07.370
Well, this course is for

18
00:01:07.370 --> 00:01:13.010
any candidate that requires validation
of common hardware and software skills.

19
00:01:13.010 --> 00:01:16.465
It's also for the candidate
that needs an understanding of

20
00:01:16.465 --> 00:01:19.446
the basic concepts within
any IT infrastructure.

21
00:01:19.446 --> 00:01:24.711
Candidates that need to be able to
perform troubleshooting and networking,

22
00:01:24.711 --> 00:01:30.150
as well as basic IT security should
be seeking the 220-901 objectives.

23
00:01:30.150 --> 00:01:35.061
Candidates who are preparing
to take the current A+ exam.

24
00:01:37.090 --> 00:01:39.690
What are some of the things that'll
be covered inside of 220-901?

25
00:01:39.690 --> 00:01:45.117
Well we'll be looking specifically at
the objectives that are called out for

26
00:01:45.117 --> 00:01:49.135
CompTIA on their website for
exam code 220-901.

27
00:01:49.135 --> 00:01:51.943
We'll be looking at some of
the fundamental software and

28
00:01:51.943 --> 00:01:56.425
hardware concepts that you can expect to
see inside of your IT infrastructure.

29
00:01:56.425 --> 00:02:01.126
We'll also be looking at some of the basic
TCP/IP concepts that allow us to move

30
00:02:01.126 --> 00:02:05.491
communications across the most common
networking technologies today.

31
00:02:05.491 --> 00:02:08.805
And that being said,
even the fundamental networking and

32
00:02:08.805 --> 00:02:14.790
communication technologies will be
learned inside of the 220-901 objectives.

33
00:02:14.790 --> 00:02:18.331
We'll also be looking at some of
the fundamentals of troubleshooting common

34
00:02:18.331 --> 00:02:21.224
hardware that you'll see within
your computing units today.

35
00:02:23.711 --> 00:02:28.094
What are some of the exam details that
you can expect if you decide to sit

36
00:02:28.094 --> 00:02:30.337
the CompTIA 220-901 exam?

37
00:02:30.337 --> 00:02:34.287
Well you're gonna be looking
at 90 questions, 90 minutes.

38
00:02:34.287 --> 00:02:36.519
Keep in mind that these
are gonna be multiple choice and

39
00:02:36.519 --> 00:02:40.300
the fact that you'll have more than
one choice and only one right answer.

40
00:02:40.300 --> 00:02:44.990
Now, you could also find exam
questions that have multiple answers,

41
00:02:44.990 --> 00:02:49.330
in which they ask you to choose
more than just a single answer.

42
00:02:49.330 --> 00:02:54.210
And you might hear things like each
answer represents a complete solution.

43
00:02:54.210 --> 00:02:58.500
You'll also see additional questions
like drag and drops, diagrams,

44
00:02:58.500 --> 00:03:04.370
that'll make you determine which of the
answers should be placed within a diagram.

45
00:03:04.370 --> 00:03:08.678
As well as performance based questions,
such as simulations.

46
00:03:08.678 --> 00:03:13.646
On the 220-901 exam for
CompTIA's A+ certification,

47
00:03:13.646 --> 00:03:18.340
you'll be required to have a 675 for
your passing score.

48
00:03:18.340 --> 00:03:21.534
And that's out of a range from 100 to 900.

49
00:03:21.534 --> 00:03:27.590
Currently, here in US dollars,
the exam will cost you $205.

50
00:03:27.590 --> 00:03:32.700
Recommendations by CompTIA for
sitting the exam are 6 to 12 months,

51
00:03:32.700 --> 00:03:37.890
either within a lab environment or hands
on experience within the field itself.

52
00:03:38.960 --> 00:03:42.498
Keep in mind,
that if you would like to be A+ certified,

53
00:03:42.498 --> 00:03:46.794
you don't only take just the 220 exam,
or 220-901 exam.

54
00:03:46.794 --> 00:03:50.243
You also have to complete and
pass the 902.

55
00:03:50.243 --> 00:03:52.646
And again, that's the 220-902 exam.

56
00:03:52.646 --> 00:03:57.818
Both passes on the exam are required for
both 220-901 and

57
00:03:57.818 --> 00:04:02.815
220-902 in order to achieve
your A+ certification.

58
00:04:02.815 --> 00:04:08.480
If the A+ certification is something
that you want to attempt, well then,

59
00:04:08.480 --> 00:04:13.808
look forward to this course and
some of the topics you can see within it.

60
00:04:13.808 --> 00:04:18.452
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: Wes and Zach discuss using BIOS/UEFI tools on a PC, a history of BIOS & UEFI, overview of BIOS component information, BIOS configurations, how to set date & time, how to re-configure settings in BIOS, virtualization support, BIOS security, what LoJack is, monitoring, and built in diagnostics.
episodes.title: Configure BIOS and UEFI Settings
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:01.210
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.210 --> 00:00:02.177
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.177 --> 00:00:06.425
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.425 --> 00:00:08.287
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.287 --> 00:00:12.154
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.154 --> 00:00:14.782
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

7
00:00:14.782 --> 00:00:17.530
helping you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:17.530 --> 00:00:20.600
I'm your host, Zach Memos and
this is A+ 901.

9
00:00:20.600 --> 00:00:24.654
And this is exciting, and
we're diving into configure BIOS and

10
00:00:24.654 --> 00:00:28.895
UEFI settings with our very own Wes Bryan,
who knows more than me.

11
00:00:28.895 --> 00:00:30.050
>> [LAUGH] Hey Zach, how you doing?

12
00:00:30.050 --> 00:00:30.600
>> Doing well.

13
00:00:30.600 --> 00:00:34.320
>> That's right, we're gonna be looking
right at configuring our BIOS and

14
00:00:34.320 --> 00:00:36.390
UEFI settings, and
I know what you're probably saying.

15
00:00:36.390 --> 00:00:38.720
If you're getting into the A+ for
the first time,

16
00:00:38.720 --> 00:00:42.180
what is this alphabet soup that they are
feeding us right here at the beginning?

17
00:00:42.180 --> 00:00:45.670
But let's go ahead, and
let's define what BIOS and UEFI is.

18
00:00:45.670 --> 00:00:48.840
And then we'll take a look at some of
the settings that you can configure.

19
00:00:48.840 --> 00:00:51.740
Now BIOS is a Basic Input/Output System,
and

20
00:00:51.740 --> 00:00:54.810
UEFI is
the Unified Extensible Firmware Interface.

21
00:00:54.810 --> 00:00:57.240
Now, why would we need
something like BIOS?

22
00:00:57.240 --> 00:00:59.020
Well, in the earlier days of computing,

23
00:00:59.020 --> 00:01:04.750
going into probably the later 70s
when hobbyists were bring out of the,

24
00:01:04.750 --> 00:01:07.820
for instance universities and
these big like, Sun Microsystems.

25
00:01:07.820 --> 00:01:10.660
You wanted to be able to have
your own small computer.

26
00:01:10.660 --> 00:01:13.800
But the problem was in order
to make that computer work,

27
00:01:13.800 --> 00:01:15.410
you had to have programming, right?

28
00:01:15.410 --> 00:01:17.480
And the programmers when
they developed the software,

29
00:01:17.480 --> 00:01:21.430
they also had to have a good innate
understanding of what the hardware was.

30
00:01:21.430 --> 00:01:26.150
And they had to program each individual
little piece to allow their software

31
00:01:26.150 --> 00:01:29.310
to control their hardware,
cuz imagine what an operating system is.

32
00:01:29.310 --> 00:01:31.060
That's basically what it does.

33
00:01:31.060 --> 00:01:33.790
It allows us to control our hardware.

34
00:01:33.790 --> 00:01:38.540
Now, the problem with that is every system
that would come out, your programmers

35
00:01:38.540 --> 00:01:43.120
would have to know all about the hardware
in order to get the machine started in and

36
00:01:43.120 --> 00:01:44.400
brought up online.

37
00:01:44.400 --> 00:01:48.913
So what BIOS does is,
it allows us a system independent,

38
00:01:48.913 --> 00:01:52.588
if you will,
way to get our hardware started.

39
00:01:52.588 --> 00:01:56.044
Get it stabilized, so
that when the operating system loads,

40
00:01:56.044 --> 00:01:58.508
it doesn't have to worry
about any of that.

41
00:01:58.508 --> 00:02:03.236
The hardware is ready to go,
it's online, and then BIOS, or UEFI,

42
00:02:03.236 --> 00:02:08.660
they can transition and let the operating
system take over after that.

43
00:02:08.660 --> 00:02:12.090
It also means that the software
programmers who are designing

44
00:02:12.090 --> 00:02:14.360
the operating systems to
control the hardware,

45
00:02:14.360 --> 00:02:17.250
they don't have to know in
depth what the hardware is.

46
00:02:17.250 --> 00:02:20.650
What they have to do is, they have to make
sure that their operating system can take

47
00:02:20.650 --> 00:02:22.770
over, after BIOS does.

48
00:02:22.770 --> 00:02:26.290
And BIOS is something that's gonna
be controlled by the manufacturer

49
00:02:26.290 --> 00:02:27.140
of the hardware.

50
00:02:27.140 --> 00:02:28.440
So it makes it really good.

51
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:33.030
Hardware manufacturers can focus
on things like the BIOS and UEFI.

52
00:02:33.030 --> 00:02:36.670
And the operating system developers,
they can work on their operating system.

53
00:02:36.670 --> 00:02:40.700
So what's the difference between BIOS and
UEFI?

54
00:02:40.700 --> 00:02:42.200
Well, there's a lot of difference in them,

55
00:02:42.200 --> 00:02:44.340
but basically they're
doing the same thing.

56
00:02:44.340 --> 00:02:48.380
See, BIOS was written back in the late
70s, when we had 8-bit systems.

57
00:02:48.380 --> 00:02:52.620
It's really an outdated way
to start your hardware,

58
00:02:52.620 --> 00:02:55.130
bring it online, and get it stabilized.

59
00:02:55.130 --> 00:02:57.500
It also has some limitations, right?

60
00:02:57.500 --> 00:03:02.540
So later down the road,
Intel came out with what is known as EFI,

61
00:03:02.540 --> 00:03:04.880
the Extensible Firmware Interface.

62
00:03:04.880 --> 00:03:08.130
Well, Intel wanted this
to eventually become

63
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:10.800
a standard that everybody could use.

64
00:03:10.800 --> 00:03:14.310
So what they did is they tried
to distinguish their earlier

65
00:03:14.310 --> 00:03:16.510
EFI from something known as UEFI.

66
00:03:16.510 --> 00:03:19.960
They basically handed
the standard over to the public.

67
00:03:19.960 --> 00:03:23.429
And in order to differentiate
from the earlier Intel based EFI,

68
00:03:23.429 --> 00:03:26.849
they called it the Universal
Extensible Firmware Interface.

69
00:03:26.849 --> 00:03:30.690
Now, these interfaces,
they're doing the same thing.

70
00:03:30.690 --> 00:03:32.140
They're called firmware.

71
00:03:32.140 --> 00:03:35.450
And again,
basically understand that firmware

72
00:03:35.450 --> 00:03:38.920
is a way that we can bring
our hardware online.

73
00:03:38.920 --> 00:03:39.940
Get it stabilized,

74
00:03:39.940 --> 00:03:44.720
make sure that the checks are in place in
order to get the operating system loaded.

75
00:03:44.720 --> 00:03:47.500
And then the operating system
doesn't have to worry about that.

76
00:03:47.500 --> 00:03:51.560
So that's a little bit about our BIOS,
Basic Input/Output Systems.

77
00:03:51.560 --> 00:03:55.150
What happens is we send a little bit
of input to different components within

78
00:03:55.150 --> 00:03:57.220
the system unit.

79
00:03:57.220 --> 00:04:00.730
And if those components respond back,
we get a message back from them that

80
00:04:00.730 --> 00:04:03.350
we know that they're there,
present and ready to go.

81
00:04:03.350 --> 00:04:05.270
So that's a little bit about BIOS.

82
00:04:05.270 --> 00:04:06.282
And again, keep in mind,

83
00:04:06.282 --> 00:04:09.720
Unified Extensible Firmware Interface,
pretty much doing the same thing.

84
00:04:09.720 --> 00:04:13.940
But the difference is,
it's the more modern version of BIOS.

85
00:04:13.940 --> 00:04:17.580
>> So what is some of the information
that we can actually see in the BIOS?

86
00:04:17.580 --> 00:04:19.050
>> That's a good question.

87
00:04:19.050 --> 00:04:20.840
A lot of great information
that we can see.

88
00:04:20.840 --> 00:04:22.200
In fact, let's go ahead and check it out.

89
00:04:22.200 --> 00:04:26.330
I've got a BIOS pulled up here and
this is, you will see this is

90
00:04:26.330 --> 00:04:30.710
actually a Unified Extensible
Firmware Interface based system.

91
00:04:30.710 --> 00:04:32.190
However, don't let that bother you.

92
00:04:32.190 --> 00:04:34.660
Because every vendor's
a little bit different,

93
00:04:34.660 --> 00:04:39.290
but when it comes down to it, a lot of the
components that you see will look alike.

94
00:04:39.290 --> 00:04:42.570
The interface might change a little bit
in colors and how you interact with it.

95
00:04:42.570 --> 00:04:46.630
But for the most part, you're gonna
see just about the same information.

96
00:04:46.630 --> 00:04:49.490
Now, some of the basic component
information that we can look at

97
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:52.668
is under for instance, and
this BIOS is under general.

98
00:04:52.668 --> 00:04:55.370
You can see, that we see,
well, system information.

99
00:04:55.370 --> 00:04:57.140
Well, what is system information for us?

100
00:04:57.140 --> 00:04:58.080
Well if you notice,

101
00:04:58.080 --> 00:05:01.210
you can see things like the BIOS version,
that's gonna be important.

102
00:05:01.210 --> 00:05:02.510
Well, why is that important?

103
00:05:02.510 --> 00:05:06.070
Well you have what are known as firmware
updates, and when we update firmware,

104
00:05:06.070 --> 00:05:09.310
a lot of times what it does is it
fixes some kind of functionality flaw.

105
00:05:09.310 --> 00:05:11.870
We can sometimes even give
you more functionality by

106
00:05:11.870 --> 00:05:12.870
adding a couple of things.

107
00:05:12.870 --> 00:05:16.080
So, it is important to understand
what the version of the BIOS is.

108
00:05:16.080 --> 00:05:20.700
So as the manufacturer of the hardware
releases new firmware platforms or

109
00:05:20.700 --> 00:05:24.810
updates if you will, you can tell
whether you've got the most current.

110
00:05:24.810 --> 00:05:26.170
Now I do wanna warn you real quick.

111
00:05:26.170 --> 00:05:29.860
When we talk about the system components
and we talk about updating your firmware,

112
00:05:29.860 --> 00:05:32.190
it's also called flashing the BIOS.

113
00:05:32.190 --> 00:05:34.420
See, when you think about BIOS,

114
00:05:34.420 --> 00:05:38.650
BIOS is something that sits in a type
of memory that's non volatile.

115
00:05:38.650 --> 00:05:42.940
And if you're not familiar with
non volatile memory, go over and

116
00:05:42.940 --> 00:05:47.430
check out some of our memory issue,
or memory episodes if you will.

117
00:05:47.430 --> 00:05:50.740
Remember non-volatile memory just
means that I don't need an electrical

118
00:05:50.740 --> 00:05:54.980
current to keep refreshing
that information to retain it.

119
00:05:54.980 --> 00:05:57.506
It also means when I turn the power off,

120
00:05:57.506 --> 00:06:01.192
all of that data that's stored
in it is gonna stay there.

121
00:06:01.192 --> 00:06:03.880
It's not gonna be lost, all right.

122
00:06:03.880 --> 00:06:04.580
Now here's the thing.

123
00:06:04.580 --> 00:06:06.640
With flashing that non-volatile memory,

124
00:06:06.640 --> 00:06:09.340
you have to make sure that
it's never interrupted.

125
00:06:09.340 --> 00:06:12.460
Because, if there's let's
say an electrical storm,

126
00:06:12.460 --> 00:06:14.750
if you pull the power
during a firmware upgrade,

127
00:06:14.750 --> 00:06:19.030
you could cause irreversible damage that
could damage the unit so much that, well,

128
00:06:19.030 --> 00:06:21.510
unfortunately, you might have to
replace the entire motherboard.

129
00:06:21.510 --> 00:06:24.390
So, be careful when you're flashing BIOS.

130
00:06:24.390 --> 00:06:26.380
You can see other information here, too.

131
00:06:26.380 --> 00:06:28.430
You can see information for instance,

132
00:06:28.430 --> 00:06:31.510
about half way down,
you can see things like the RAM, right?

133
00:06:31.510 --> 00:06:34.180
Our Random Access Memory,
our system memory.

134
00:06:34.180 --> 00:06:38.600
And I can see for instance,
inside of this BIOS system information or

135
00:06:38.600 --> 00:06:42.950
UEFI system information,
I can see how much is installed.

136
00:06:42.950 --> 00:06:44.970
I can see what the bus speed is.

137
00:06:44.970 --> 00:06:46.680
You can see 1,600 megahertz.

138
00:06:46.680 --> 00:06:48.570
I can see what channel it is.

139
00:06:48.570 --> 00:06:50.680
I can also see what technology it is.

140
00:06:50.680 --> 00:06:53.810
This type of BIOS here gives
us a lot of good information.

141
00:06:53.810 --> 00:06:58.060
I could see that it's DDR3 RAM,
so it's relatively new.

142
00:06:58.060 --> 00:07:01.870
And even more so, I can see where
the RAM sticks are installed.

143
00:07:01.870 --> 00:07:05.440
I can see that I have for instance,
three and four on our motherboard.

144
00:07:05.440 --> 00:07:06.460
They're not even populated.

145
00:07:06.460 --> 00:07:08.780
They don't even have RAM sticks in them.

146
00:07:08.780 --> 00:07:10.340
So you can see things like that, right?

147
00:07:10.340 --> 00:07:15.260
We can see for instance, also things like,
for instance, hard drive information.

148
00:07:15.260 --> 00:07:18.590
You can see as well,
things like your expansion slots.

149
00:07:18.590 --> 00:07:22.400
But you could have the ability to control
other things, like optical drives, and

150
00:07:22.400 --> 00:07:24.160
even CPU information.

151
00:07:25.250 --> 00:07:29.640
Now, we've got some different things that
we can configure inside of our BIOS.

152
00:07:29.640 --> 00:07:32.860
Some of those things that we can
configure are things like, for instance,

153
00:07:32.860 --> 00:07:34.310
our boot sequence.

154
00:07:34.310 --> 00:07:36.190
Now, boot sequence is important, right?

155
00:07:36.190 --> 00:07:40.321
When we look at our boot sequence,
this says, where does BIOS look for

156

00:32:22.481 --> 00:32:25.102
What the core temperature not
the core temperature, but

606
00:32:25.102 --> 00:32:27.800
what the temperature of
the system unit is as well.

607
00:32:27.800 --> 00:32:32.840
Cuz keep in mind, as our CPU's heat up,

608
00:32:32.840 --> 00:32:37.010
right, the hotter they get, the more
likely they are to become damaged.

609
00:32:37.010 --> 00:32:38.830
And really when it comes
to thermal damage,

610
00:32:38.830 --> 00:32:41.040
a lot of times you don't actually see it.

611
00:32:41.040 --> 00:32:44.646
It usually manifest itself in
kinda erratic behavior and

612
00:32:44.646 --> 00:32:46.533
it can be very hard to detect.

613
00:32:46.533 --> 00:32:51.500
So that's why it's good to have some
kind of temperature monitoring system.

614
00:32:51.500 --> 00:32:54.760
Now, if you don't have that in your BIOS,
don't worry about that,

615
00:32:54.760 --> 00:32:58.340
because you do have software that you can
get and you can install on your machine

616
00:32:58.340 --> 00:33:02.340
that can do this from inside
of the operating system, too.

617
00:33:02.340 --> 00:33:03.264
Now the other thing is, fans.

618
00:33:03.264 --> 00:33:11.086
You have things like CPU fans that help to
actively cool the CPU if you are plugging,

619
00:33:11.086 --> 00:33:15.240
well CPU fans they plug
to the mother board.

620
00:33:15.240 --> 00:33:18.220
But sometimes, you have system fans as
well, that plug into the mother board.

621
00:33:18.220 --> 00:33:20.730
And one of the things that
you can do with monitoring,

622
00:33:20.730 --> 00:33:24.510
is you can actually monitor what
the fan speed is, how many RPMs it is.

623
00:33:24.510 --> 00:33:27.189
So for instance if you increase
the voltage to the CPU, and

624
00:33:27.189 --> 00:33:28.946
you increase the power to the system.

625
00:33:28.946 --> 00:33:33.270
A lot of times what you'll have is fans
that are controlled by the mother board.

626
00:33:33.270 --> 00:33:35.132
And they're variable speed fans and

627
00:33:35.132 --> 00:33:38.983
they'll put more electrical current
going into the fan to speed up the RPM.

628
00:33:38.983 --> 00:33:43.073
And that's why it's good in these
when you have monitoring like this,

629
00:33:43.073 --> 00:33:47.366
because you can see as the fans ramp
up is it bringing down the temperature,

630
00:33:47.366 --> 00:33:49.772
the internal temperature of the system.

631
00:33:49.772 --> 00:33:54.237
You might find that it's ramping
the system fans up to a high RPM and

632
00:33:54.237 --> 00:33:59.770
you're not noticing anything going down
in the temperature of the machine.

633
00:33:59.770 --> 00:34:03.580
That could be a telltale sign that
either your fan's failing or it

634
00:34:03.580 --> 00:34:06.510
could just be that the fan's not adequate
for the system and that does happen.

635
00:34:06.510 --> 00:34:10.284
And that's why I mentioned
earlier Zach that a caution,

636
00:34:10.284 --> 00:34:14.924
when you're increasing the CPU
voltage like that sometimes you might

637
00:34:14.924 --> 00:34:17.613
hear that called overclocking as well.

638
00:34:17.613 --> 00:34:19.693
Yes, you could get a better performance,
but

639
00:34:19.693 --> 00:34:23.230
you have to know that there are checks and
balances that you have to implement.

640
00:34:23.230 --> 00:34:25.460
If I increase voltage I increase power.

641
00:34:25.460 --> 00:34:27.620
If I increase both of those
I increase temperature.

642
00:34:27.620 --> 00:34:31.680
So I might have to increase the cooling
unit that we have inside of the system.

643
00:34:31.680 --> 00:34:34.020
And we'll talk about cooling
units in another episode.

644
00:34:34.020 --> 00:34:37.560
But however,
know what the basic output system is.

645
00:34:37.560 --> 00:34:40.270
Know that we go through things
like the power on self test,

646
00:34:40.270 --> 00:34:41.860
right, post as it's called.

647
00:34:41.860 --> 00:34:44.860
Send out a little electrical signals,
we check on those devices,

648
00:34:44.860 --> 00:34:46.160
make sure that they are present.

649
00:34:46.160 --> 00:34:50.352
BIOS helps us to finish the process
by stabilizing all of those devices.

650
00:34:50.352 --> 00:34:52.294
And then, finally looking for

651
00:34:52.294 --> 00:34:56.230
a master boot record to
bootstrap the operating system.

652
00:34:56.230 --> 00:34:59.998
Allow the operating system to take
over and in the end it's your hardware

653
00:34:59.998 --> 00:35:03.768
manufacturers that have to worry about
the basic input output system and

654
00:35:03.768 --> 00:35:05.709
not your operating system vendors.

655
00:35:05.709 --> 00:35:11.420
>> Fantastic job as usual Wes,
configure BIOS and UEFI settings.

656
00:35:11.420 --> 00:35:13.308
Marvelously done and 8 plus 901.

657
00:35:13.308 --> 00:35:15.310
There is more in this series.

658
00:35:16.682 --> 00:35:20.860
In ITProTV, we are committed to
helping you learn where ever you go.

659
00:35:20.860 --> 00:35:23.720
And a good ITPro is always learning.

660
00:35:23.720 --> 00:35:24.570
I'm Zach Memos.

661
00:35:24.570 --> 00:35:25.390
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

662
00:35:25.390 --> 00:35:30.294
>> And we'll see you soon.

663
00:35:30.294 --> 00:35:33.744
[MUSIC]

664
00:35:33.744 --> 00:35:36.750
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike begin their exploration of various components typically found on a motherboard. They talk about integrated versus non-integrated components, buses, the CMOS battery, expansion slots, and the Northbridge and Southbridge chipsets.
episodes.title: Motherboard Components
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:06.647
Welcome to IT Pro TV,
I'm your host, Don Preset.

2
00:00:06.647 --> 00:00:10.661
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

3
00:00:12.360 --> 00:00:15.080
>> Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:15.080 --> 00:00:18.810
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick, and
today we're doing our CompTIA A+ 901.

5
00:00:18.810 --> 00:00:22.160
And specifically in this episode,

6
00:00:22.160 --> 00:00:24.970
we're going to be taking in a look at
motherboards and their components.

7
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:26.980
And here to explain all those
intricate little parts and

8
00:00:26.980 --> 00:00:30.190
what the heck they do and
why we care, is Mr Wes Bryan.

9
00:00:30.190 --> 00:00:32.280
Welcome, Wes.
>> Hely, thanks for having me here, Mike.

10
00:00:32.280 --> 00:00:33.710
Pleasure to be here with ITPro.Tv.

11
00:00:33.710 --> 00:00:37.510
That is right, we are going to be looking
at, well, a bunch of goodies today.

12
00:00:37.510 --> 00:00:39.060
We're going to be looking
at a lot of hardware,

13
00:00:39.060 --> 00:00:42.380
we're going to be trying to let you
know a little bit about that hardware.

14
00:00:42.380 --> 00:00:44.790
And we're gonna dive into some things
that you need to know for the exam.

15
00:00:44.790 --> 00:00:48.420
Sometimes maybe not the fun stuff but
standardization and specification.

16
00:00:48.420 --> 00:00:50.980
So, that is what we are gonna
look at here in this episode.

17
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:54.045
One of the first things I'd like
to talk about is a motherboard.

18
00:00:54.045 --> 00:00:56.130
You heard Mike mentioned it,
what is a motherboard?

19
00:00:56.130 --> 00:00:56.990
Why do we even need it?

20
00:00:56.990 --> 00:00:58.620
Well, a motherboard,
if you think about it,

21
00:00:58.620 --> 00:01:02.170
if you looking at your computer right now,
you probably see this little box, right?

22
00:01:02.170 --> 00:01:04.500
Well, if we take that box apart,
we got a lot of components.

23
00:01:04.500 --> 00:01:07.020
The box itself is kind of
like an exoskeleton, and

24
00:01:07.020 --> 00:01:08.580
we've got a lot of components in there,
right?

25
00:01:08.580 --> 00:01:12.590
And we're gonna talk about all of these
components in other episodes as we proceed

26
00:01:12.590 --> 00:01:14.110
through this series here.

27
00:01:14.110 --> 00:01:15.590
But let's just kind of run down it, right?

28
00:01:15.590 --> 00:01:17.040
We've got a power supply, right?

29
00:01:17.040 --> 00:01:20.510
We've got a central processing unit that
is like the brains of the operation.

30
00:01:20.510 --> 00:01:23.010
We got some hard drives for
data storage in there.

31
00:01:23.010 --> 00:01:25.700
We've got random access memory or
system memory, right?

32
00:01:25.700 --> 00:01:29.450
A temporary storage unit for
our data so that we can work with it.

33
00:01:29.450 --> 00:01:32.420
Well, what is it that
ties everything together?

34
00:01:32.420 --> 00:01:33.730
Well, that's the motherboard.

35
00:01:33.730 --> 00:01:36.980
The motherboard is a circuit board
that essentially is like the backbone

36
00:01:36.980 --> 00:01:38.440
of the entire system unit.

37
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:42.505
And it's important to understand
what that component is doing for us.

38
00:01:42.505 --> 00:01:45.305
What it looks like and then some
of the pieces that you could find

39
00:01:45.305 --> 00:01:48.065
with the components within
the motherboard themselves.

40
00:01:48.065 --> 00:01:48.895
>> Very good.
So

41
00:01:48.895 --> 00:01:51.085
all computers that have
a motherboard inside them?

42
00:01:51.085 --> 00:01:54.825
>> Most definitely and it's one of
the components, doesn't matter how big or

43
00:01:54.825 --> 00:01:59.315
how small the computing system is,
most of them will

44
00:01:59.315 --> 00:02:03.555
have some type of printed circuit board
that ties these components together.

45
00:02:03.555 --> 00:02:06.810
Now, they could be different sizes,
they could be different shapes,

46
00:02:06.810 --> 00:02:08.930
they could have different arrangements,
but for

47
00:02:08.930 --> 00:02:12.700
the most part, like you said, we're gonna
find those in just about any system.

48
00:02:12.700 --> 00:02:16.350
So, let's go ahead and
let's talk about the motherboard itself.

49
00:02:16.350 --> 00:02:17.498
And in fact, I've got one here.

50
00:02:17.498 --> 00:02:20.680
We kinda actually got a few of them here
and if we could take a look at them,

51
00:02:20.680 --> 00:02:23.720
you're gonna see that these motherboards
have a lot of different components.

52
00:02:23.720 --> 00:02:26.845
Now, I wanna just talk briefly
about these components here.

53
00:02:26.845 --> 00:02:30.720
You'll notice that there are some
components that are built

54
00:02:30.720 --> 00:02:31.470
into the motherboard.

55
00:02:31.470 --> 00:02:34.570
If I was to turn this motherboard over,
you can see some of these components

56
00:02:34.570 --> 00:02:37.790
are soldered directly into
the motherboard themselves.

57
00:02:37.790 --> 00:02:39.600
That's what's known as
an integrated component.

58
00:02:39.600 --> 00:02:42.820
And we kinda understand that integrated
components aren't something that we

59
00:02:42.820 --> 00:02:45.910
can really change if something fails,
right.

60
00:02:45.910 --> 00:02:48.660
The benefit of the integrated
components is sometimes it can

61
00:02:48.660 --> 00:02:52.590
expand the functionality of
the motherboard without having to buy like

62
00:02:52.590 --> 00:02:55.560
third party accessories to
give you that functionality.

63
00:02:55.560 --> 00:02:58.760
Now we also have, as you can see here,
we've got some different slots and

64
00:02:58.760 --> 00:02:59.590
sockets here.

65
00:02:59.590 --> 00:03:02.768
Now, these are for what are known
as non-integrated components.

66
00:03:02.768 --> 00:03:05.760
And the non-integrated components
are things that can expand

67
00:03:05.760 --> 00:03:07.580
the functionality of the system.

68
00:03:07.580 --> 00:03:10.802
And one of the great things about
non-integrated components is,

69
00:03:10.802 --> 00:03:13.390
your manufacturers,
they can sell you a base model of

70
00:03:13.390 --> 00:03:17.357
a motherboard at a different price points
and if you wanna buy the Ferrari, well,

71
00:03:17.357 --> 00:03:19.507
you don't have to buy the Ferrari, right?

72
00:03:19.507 --> 00:03:22.364
You can, they can leave some of
these components out of it and

73
00:03:22.364 --> 00:03:26.120
then if you want you can get a reasonable
price you can always add those later.

74
00:03:26.120 --> 00:03:28.880
So one of the big things I want
you to keep in mind is that,

75
00:03:28.880 --> 00:03:32.470
when it comes to integrated components,
integrated components

76
00:03:32.470 --> 00:03:35.410
are those components that are soldered
directly to the motherboard.

77
00:03:35.410 --> 00:03:37.420
Now also keep in mind, like I said,

78
00:03:37.420 --> 00:03:41.820
that when integrated components fail,
hopefully, we have a workaround at.

79
00:03:41.820 --> 00:03:45.660
Sometimes integrated components fail,
and we can maybe put a non-integrated

80
00:03:45.660 --> 00:03:49.460
component in one of these sockets or
slots and bring that functionality back.

81
00:03:49.460 --> 00:03:52.450
However, there are times when integrated
components fail, and when they do,

82
00:03:52.450 --> 00:03:55.140
unfortunately, you have to
replace the entire motherboard.

83
00:03:55.140 --> 00:03:59.020
The benefit of the non-integrated
components is the fact that we can always

84
00:03:59.020 --> 00:04:00.740
expand the functionality later.

85
00:04:00.740 --> 00:04:05.870
And if those components fail, there's some
kinda power shortage or short circuiting.

86
00:04:05.870 --> 00:04:08.760
A lot of times all we have to
do is replace that component.

87
00:04:08.760 --> 00:04:10.590
>> So
are all these motherboards the same, and

88
00:04:10.590 --> 00:04:14.020
do they all have the same integrated
components in the same slots on them?

89
00:04:14.020 --> 00:04:16.530
>> No, they don't and actually that's
one of the great things is that there is

90
00:04:16.530 --> 00:04:18.000
a variety of them out there, right?

91
00:04:18.000 --> 00:04:20.930
You can get those entry level,
when manufacturers make them and

92
00:04:20.930 --> 00:04:23.010
you get those what we call
entry level motherboards.

93
00:04:23.010 --> 00:04:24.850
And again,
they give you the basic functionality,

94
00:04:24.850 --> 00:04:26.420
the basic computing experience.

95
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:29.530
But, if you're somebody that
needs a little bit more power,

96
00:04:29.530 --> 00:04:32.390
you need a little more juice, your
computing experience is one that kind of

97
00:04:32.390 --> 00:04:36.240
accelerates everybody else's,
you could always get that functionality.

98
00:04:36.240 --> 00:04:38.940
But again, remember that's also
gonna raise the price point, too.

99
00:04:38.940 --> 00:04:39.610
>> Gotcha, all right.

100
00:04:39.610 --> 00:04:41.860
So let's say we wanna go out and
get a motherboard.

101
00:04:41.860 --> 00:04:45.085
You said they come in and
there's no one size fits all thing,

102
00:04:45.085 --> 00:04:46.610
there's different sizes?

103
00:04:46.610 --> 00:04:47.120
>> There are.

104
00:04:47.120 --> 00:04:49.680
So for instance,
they have what is known as a form factor.

105
00:04:49.680 --> 00:04:51.490
When we talk about form factor,

106
00:04:51.490 --> 00:04:55.260
all right, form factor
describes not just size, right?

107
00:04:55.260 --> 00:04:58.980
Size is one of those things that form
factor describes but it also talks about

108
00:04:58.980 --> 00:05:02.290
the layout, all right, the arrangement
of the components within the motherboard

109
00:05:02.290 --> 00:05:07.370
themselves, the unique characteristics
of this type of motherboard.

110
00:05:07.370 --> 00:05:10.260
And we will, towards the end of this
episode, we're gonna talk about some

111
00:05:10.260 --> 00:05:13.910
different form factors that you're gonna
need to be aware of, for this exam.

112
00:05:13.910 --> 00:05:19.680
Now, I understand that when it comes down
to buying and purchasing a motherboard,

113
00:05:19.680 --> 00:05:22.780
you're gonna have to do your research,
out there in the real world.

114
00:05:22.780 --> 00:05:26.130
But for the A plus exam, you are gonna
have to know some of the specifications,

115
00:05:26.130 --> 00:05:30.790
because understand this, when you're
moving into an IT technician type role,

116
00:05:30.790 --> 00:05:32.159
you have to speak the lingo, right?

117
00:05:32.159 --> 00:05:35.800
We can't sit there and call,
I would never call myself a mechanic.

118
00:05:35.800 --> 00:05:36.931
In fact, Mike, you know that.

119
00:05:36.931 --> 00:05:38.543
>> [LAUGH]
>> I can break a car with

120
00:05:38.543 --> 00:05:39.361
the best of them.

121
00:05:39.361 --> 00:05:40.930
But if you wanna become a mechanic,

122
00:05:40.930 --> 00:05:43.730
you have to know what the different
parts of a combustible engine is.

123
00:05:43.730 --> 00:05:46.582
And the only thing I know is that
I can make it combust and go boom.

124
00:05:46.582 --> 00:05:47.094
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

125
00:05:47.094 --> 00:05:48.980
>> So, you have to remember that.

126
00:05:48.980 --> 00:05:52.310
You're gonna be learning a new language,
so that is important.

127
00:05:52.310 --> 00:05:56.200
Now, the next thing that I'd like to talk
about are how do the components interact

128
00:05:56.200 --> 00:05:58.280
with one another on a motherboard?

129
00:05:58.280 --> 00:06:02.695
All right, well, on a motherboard we
have what are known as buses and traces.

130
00:06:02.695 --> 00:06:05.670
I got a little diagram here and
If we look at it,

131
00:06:05.670 --> 00:06:10.290
we kinda got to zoom in and man,
this looks like a highway or

132
00:06:10.290 --> 00:06:14.090
a road map to downtown New York or
something like that, right?

133
00:06:14.090 --> 00:06:17.360
These are little electrical conductors,
right?

134
00:06:17.360 --> 00:06:19.450
You can hear them called traces, right?

135
00:06:19.450 --> 00:06:21.800
Copper conductors, and what do they do?

136
00:06:21.800 --> 00:06:25.190
Well, they take the data between between
these different components, right?

137
00:06:25.190 --> 00:06:30.540
And they feed them in and out of the CPU
to basically process and store your data.

138
00:06:30.540 --> 00:06:35.390
Not always only store data but it might do
things like showing video as well, right?

139
00:06:35.390 --> 00:06:38.390
It might,
you might type on the keyboard, right?

140
00:06:38.390 --> 00:06:42.080
And as you type on the keyboard that sends
in a little electrical signal in here and

141
00:06:42.080 --> 00:06:45.820
that little electrical signal
follows along these pathways,

142
00:06:45.820 --> 00:06:50.900
notice boxes again, between the different
components on the motherboard, right?.

143
00:06:50.900 --> 00:06:54.260
Now, I wanna take just a second here and
talk about when it comes to a motherboard,

144
00:06:54.260 --> 00:06:59.240
we have a very,
very important bus on the motherboard.

145
00:06:59.240 --> 00:07:02.170
And again, I want you to think
like a bus is kinda highway.

146
00:07:02.170 --> 00:07:04.820
And think about cars on a highway,
that's your data.

147
00:07:04.820 --> 00:07:07.680
Now, data has really nothing more
than a series of electrical impulses.

148
00:07:07.680 --> 00:07:10.360
In fact, Mike you had said this many
years ago when we first met that

149
00:07:10.360 --> 00:07:11.670
you couldn't believe that this is what?

150
00:07:11.670 --> 00:07:13.673
Just a series of electrical impulses?

151
00:07:13.673 --> 00:07:14.365
>> I did, that's all it is.

152
00:07:14.365 --> 00:07:17.800
Is that a crazy game that you're
playing with those high end graphics?

153
00:07:17.800 --> 00:07:20.014
Turns out it's all just ones and zeroes.

154
00:07:20.014 --> 00:07:22.450
>> And that's right and
it's amazing that we can have things,

155
00:07:22.450 --> 00:07:25.200
I think of video games out there
that you can play, and stuff, and

156
00:07:25.200 --> 00:07:28.280
you see all the crazy colors and
the fun that we can do.

157
00:07:28.280 --> 00:07:32.714
And all it is, just like Mike said,
a little electrical impulses travelling.

158
00:07:32.714 --> 00:07:33.224
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right.

159
00:07:33.224 --> 00:07:33.731
>> [LAUGH]

160
00:07:33.731 --> 00:07:34.700
>> Ones and zeroes.

161
00:07:34.700 --> 00:07:38.360
Now, I mentioned that there is a very
important bus that I want to talk about

162
00:07:38.360 --> 00:07:41.710
before we dive back into the motherboard
cuz buses are important.

163
00:07:41.710 --> 00:07:45.675
And this type of bus actually dictates the
overall performance that you're gonna see

164
00:07:45.675 --> 00:07:46.839
out of the motherboard.

165

contributing factors to a good board or

612
00:30:32.890 --> 00:30:35.490
a board that maybe doesn't
give you enough functionality.

613
00:30:35.490 --> 00:30:38.840
Just pay attention to the lay out of the
board and you'll get the right decision.

614
00:30:38.840 --> 00:30:40.180
>> All right, thanks for that Wes.

615
00:30:40.180 --> 00:30:42.049
I hope everybody out there
enjoyed watching this one.

616
00:30:42.049 --> 00:30:45.055
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

617
00:30:45.055 --> 00:30:45.884
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

618
00:30:45.884 --> 00:30:47.078
>> And we'll see you next time.

619
00:30:48.963 --> 00:30:54.215
[MUSIC]

620
00:30:54.215 --> 00:30:56.590
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike continue to look at common components of a motherboard. They discuss power connectors for the motherboard, storage, and the CPU. They also look at fan connectors, as well as front/top panel connectors.
episodes.title: Motherboard Components Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.115
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.115 --> 00:00:05.820
[CROSSTALK].

3
00:00:05.820 --> 00:00:08.170
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.170 --> 00:00:11.518
>> You're watching ITProTV
>> Hello,

5
00:00:11.518 --> 00:00:15.400
welcome to another exciting
episode here at ITProTV.

6
00:00:15.400 --> 00:00:21.310
I'm your host Mike Roderick, and
today we're doing our CompTIA A+ 901.

7
00:00:21.310 --> 00:00:25.340
And in this episode we're actually doing
a part two on motherboards and components.

8
00:00:25.340 --> 00:00:28.400
So if you missed part one,
make sure you go back and check that out.

9
00:00:28.400 --> 00:00:31.030
We're gonna dive right back in,
pick up where we left off, and

10
00:00:31.030 --> 00:00:33.760
here to do that with is Mr.
Wes Brian, welcome back Wes.

11
00:00:33.760 --> 00:00:35.086
>> Hey Mike, thanks for having me back.

12
00:00:35.086 --> 00:00:39.383
Yep, that's right, we have a lot of
components that we need to talk about.

13
00:00:39.383 --> 00:00:43.330
So like Mike said,
that's why we're in a part two.

14
00:00:43.330 --> 00:00:45.970
In the first part we talked about some
of the components that you can see on

15
00:00:45.970 --> 00:00:46.600
a motherboard.

16
00:00:46.600 --> 00:00:50.460
We talked a little bit about things
like your RAM slots, expansion slots.

17
00:00:50.460 --> 00:00:53.651
We talked about some of the chips,
if you will, the computer processors,

18
00:00:53.651 --> 00:00:56.402
if you will, that are on the motherboard,
called the chipset.

19
00:00:56.402 --> 00:01:00.096
And if any of this doesn't seem familiar
to you, like Mike said, go back and

20
00:01:00.096 --> 00:01:02.315
watch part one and
come back to part two here.

21
00:01:02.315 --> 00:01:05.186
>> All right Wes, we talked about
northbridge and southbridge, a couple of

22
00:01:05.186 --> 00:01:08.640
the chips, as you said, that are typically
integrated on that motherboard.

23
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:12.175
But there's one big chip on that mother
board that we haven't talked about yet.

24
00:01:12.175 --> 00:01:14.405
>> Yeah, that's the one that
you never wanna forget about.

25
00:01:14.405 --> 00:01:16.424
Apparently my memory needs upgrading.

26
00:01:16.424 --> 00:01:21.130
[LAUGH] But one of the things that we have
to also talk about is the CPU, all right?

27
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:24.930
The CPU is the central processing unit,
you might hear it called the processor,

28
00:01:24.930 --> 00:01:26.980
I've heard it microprocessor before.

29
00:01:26.980 --> 00:01:28.036
They don't really call,

30
00:01:28.036 --> 00:01:30.920
[LAUGH] I don't really hear it called
microprocessor too much anymore.

31
00:01:30.920 --> 00:01:33.507
That actually goes back to the earlier
days when a guy by the name of

32
00:01:33.507 --> 00:01:36.094
Gary Goodall went to Intel and
he said, these things are more than

33
00:01:36.094 --> 00:01:38.564
just controllers,
they can actually process information.

34
00:01:38.564 --> 00:01:41.830
So they called them microprocessors
in the earlier days.

35
00:01:41.830 --> 00:01:45.410
But what we wanna look at is the
connections specifically that they make to

36
00:01:45.410 --> 00:01:46.010
the motherboard.

37
00:01:46.010 --> 00:01:48.896
We'll talk a lot more about CPUs,
and dive into what they are and

38
00:01:48.896 --> 00:01:51.200
some of the different types and
characteristics.

39
00:01:51.200 --> 00:01:55.674
But for the motherboard itself, every
motherboard is going to have one of these

40
00:01:55.674 --> 00:01:59.570
sockets, where we install, really,
the brains of the operation.

41
00:01:59.570 --> 00:02:02.452
And so if we can take a look here, and
like you've seen in the first episode,

42
00:02:02.452 --> 00:02:03.994
we've got a few different boards here.

43
00:02:03.994 --> 00:02:07.730
Just so you guys can see that they come
in all different shapes and sizes.

44
00:02:07.730 --> 00:02:09.520
Well, one of the things that
you also have to keep in mind,

45
00:02:09.520 --> 00:02:12.180
is they could have different socket types.

46
00:02:12.180 --> 00:02:16.510
Now, what you don't see on
this one is the CPU socket,

47
00:02:16.510 --> 00:02:19.570
because we have a couple
of things attached to it.

48
00:02:19.570 --> 00:02:23.035
We have the processor that's set down on
it, we have this little metal fin type

49
00:02:23.035 --> 00:02:27.120
thing, kind of looks like a radiator,
it's called a heat sink, and then a fan.

50
00:02:27.120 --> 00:02:30.420
But below that,
we have these type of sockets.

51
00:02:30.420 --> 00:02:31.897
Now, Intel is a little bit different, and

52
00:02:31.897 --> 00:02:33.545
we'll get into the specifics
here in a second.

53
00:02:33.545 --> 00:02:39.960
But this is a CPU socket, and it's where
you install, if you will, the CPU itself.

54
00:02:39.960 --> 00:02:42.770
Now you're looking at
two of the same types.

55
00:02:42.770 --> 00:02:47.210
Let me go ahead and
put this board a little bit closer, here.

56
00:02:47.210 --> 00:02:49.580
You can see that there
are little openings, right here.

57
00:02:49.580 --> 00:02:54.020
And these are where the pins on the bottom
of a CPU are gonna make contact.

58
00:02:54.020 --> 00:02:56.870
And more importantly, when we install it,
it will make that electrical

59
00:02:56.870 --> 00:03:02.080
connection to the motherboard that allows
the processor to process that information.

60
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:05.380
Now, this is something that
is called a PGA socket.

61
00:03:05.380 --> 00:03:06.811
Now Mike I know you're a golfer, but

62
00:03:06.811 --> 00:03:10.289
unfortunately we're not talking about the
Professional Golf Association on this one.

63
00:03:10.289 --> 00:03:14.770
We're talking about something
known as a pin grid array.

64
00:03:14.770 --> 00:03:17.650
Now, pin grid array is a type
of socket that has well,

65
00:03:17.650 --> 00:03:19.890
the pins are on the bottom of the CPU.

66
00:03:19.890 --> 00:03:22.843
And the openings, if you will,
or the ports on the socket,

67
00:03:22.843 --> 00:03:25.399
are the openings that
the pins will be inserted to.

68
00:03:25.399 --> 00:03:29.210
Now you might notice that in this one
there's this little handle right here.

69
00:03:29.210 --> 00:03:32.619
And this little handle is
actually a really clever design.

70
00:03:32.619 --> 00:03:35.600
In the earlier days you
didn't have this handle.

71
00:03:35.600 --> 00:03:38.520
When I say early days, I'm really talking
about some of the very first PCs that

72
00:03:38.520 --> 00:03:40.082
were out there, they didn't have this.

73
00:03:40.082 --> 00:03:44.245
Well I want you to understand that when
you put an electrical current on a CPU,

74
00:03:44.245 --> 00:03:46.820
it's gonna get very, very hot.

75
00:03:46.820 --> 00:03:48.970
Well, what happens when you turn it off?

76
00:03:48.970 --> 00:03:50.520
Well, it's gonna cool down.

77
00:03:50.520 --> 00:03:54.401
So, you have this expansion and contract,
expand and contract, and expand and

78
00:03:54.401 --> 00:03:57.910
contract, because of the heating and
the cooling the CPU.

79
00:03:57.910 --> 00:04:01.150
Now, the problem in the early days is the
fact that that would cause something known

80
00:04:01.150 --> 00:04:02.380
as chip creep.

81
00:04:02.380 --> 00:04:06.454
Chip creep just basically means that quite
literally the CPU that was installed

82
00:04:06.454 --> 00:04:10.703
the socket could walk its way out, grow
legs, and, I don't know, take a break for

83
00:04:10.703 --> 00:04:11.515
the day [LAUGH].

84
00:04:11.515 --> 00:04:14.858
But it would cause problem, because it
would move it's way out of its socket, and

85
00:04:14.858 --> 00:04:17.152
then, again,
we're not making electrical contact.

86
00:04:17.152 --> 00:04:21.180
And all kinds of problems can happen,
short circuiting, even damaging the CPU.

87
00:04:21.180 --> 00:04:22.400
The other problem that you have,

88
00:04:22.400 --> 00:04:25.532
is if you look at the socket
itself here on this motherboard.

89
00:04:25.532 --> 00:04:30.580
These pins, well in this case,
the openings, are very, very small, and

90
00:04:30.580 --> 00:04:35.160
it's very easy that if you
were to install a CPU,

91
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:38.150
you could potentially bend the pins.

92
00:04:38.150 --> 00:04:41.470
So they came out with this unique
design that actually moves.

93
00:04:41.470 --> 00:04:44.370
I don't know if you can see in
relationship to my finger there,

94
00:04:44.370 --> 00:04:47.370
that the socket is actually
moving from side to side.

95
00:04:47.370 --> 00:04:50.904
And what it does is,
it opens up this socket, and

96
00:04:50.904 --> 00:04:56.957
it allows you to just drop the CPU, based
on a marking that;s on the socket itself.

97
00:04:56.957 --> 00:05:00.381
And it´s also a marking on the CPU,
tells you how to align it, so

98
00:05:00.381 --> 00:05:04.750
you don´t install it wrong, cuz that
would definitely cause pin bending.

99
00:05:04.750 --> 00:05:08.500
And you could literally just drop that in
there and just shimmy it a little bit, and

100
00:05:08.500 --> 00:05:10.280
you´ll feel it drop into place.

101
00:05:10.280 --> 00:05:13.730
And then you take this latch,
and you push it down.

102
00:05:13.730 --> 00:05:18.166
And you'll notice it moves it forward,
and those pins, they get grabbed onto.

103
00:05:18.166 --> 00:05:21.905
This is what's known as a ZIF socket,
and it's been what we've used for

104
00:05:21.905 --> 00:05:23.020
a very long time now.

105
00:05:23.020 --> 00:05:25.420
It's called zero insertion force socket.

106
00:05:25.420 --> 00:05:30.158
So I want you to know, the ZIF socket
is the one that essentially will

107
00:05:30.158 --> 00:05:33.080
protect you from things like chip creep.

108
00:05:33.080 --> 00:05:37.310
Again, basically,
the CPU walking out of its socket.

109
00:05:37.310 --> 00:05:40.090
And it also helps to prevent pen bending.

110
00:05:40.090 --> 00:05:43.510
Now, in the AMD world,
Advanced Micro Devices,

111
00:05:43.510 --> 00:05:48.070
AMD is the two major CPU manufacturers
right now, and have been for

112
00:05:48.070 --> 00:05:51.750
a long time,
they're the ones that adopted the PGA.

113
00:05:52.820 --> 00:05:56.840
But Intel, they went a different route,
they went with something known as an LGA,

114
00:05:56.840 --> 00:05:57.710
and they still do today.

115
00:05:57.710 --> 00:06:02.010
They have for a long time, gone with
what is known as a land grid array.

116
00:06:02.010 --> 00:06:06.170
Now, I've got a picture, because a land
grid array is considerably different here.

117
00:06:06.170 --> 00:06:10.530
In a land grid array you're gonna notice
that the electrical contacts that are in

118
00:06:10.530 --> 00:06:14.760
the socket, they're like a bed of nails.

119
00:06:14.760 --> 00:06:19.015
So it's the electrical contacts here are
actually kinda pins that are facing up.

120
00:06:19.015 --> 00:06:23.688
And what we do, is we essentially
still have that same little lever,

121
00:06:23.688 --> 00:06:25.550
you'll see it latch.

122
00:06:25.550 --> 00:06:30.370
And that latch folds down on top of
the CPU, and then you pull this lever.

123
00:06:30.370 --> 00:06:34.090
And what it does is,
it takes the surface of that latch,

124
00:06:34.090 --> 00:06:38.520
or the surface of the closing point there,
and it presses it down.

125
00:06:38.520 --> 00:06:42.104
Now on the bottom of an Intel based CPU,
you just have these flat contacts.

126
00:06:42.104 --> 00:06:46.737
And the electrical contact
is made with the pins,

127
00:06:46.737 --> 00:06:51.840
the grid array here that
is down in the CPU itself.

128
00:06:51.840 --> 00:06:54.760
A little bit more alphabet soup here,
but you want

129
00:06:54.760 --> 00:06:59.720
to know the two major types of CPU sockets
that you can find on motherboards, and

130
00:06:59.720 --> 00:07:01.330
they really are vendor specific.

131
00:07:01.330 --> 00:07:05.070
When we talk about CompTIA+ and
a lot of the other CompTIA exams,

132
00:07:05.070 --> 00:07:06.330
we talk about vendor neutrality.

133
00:07:06.330 --> 00:07:09.941
This is not a vendor neutrality, one went
one way, the other one went the other way.

134
00:07:09.941 --> 00:07:14.552
Intel, they stick with the land
grid array, the AMD sockets,

135
00:07:14.552 --> 00:07:17.170
they're gonna be the PGA sockets.

136
00:07:17.170 --> 00:07:20.910
So, know those two different types,
and know what their differences are.

137
00:07:20.910 --> 00:07:23.700
Cuz you don't know,
they might give you an exam question that

138
00:07:23.700 --> 00:07:26.810
maybe gives you a picture and
says, what type of socket is this?

139
00:07:26.810 --> 00:07:28.100
And you're gonna have to know that, and

140
00:07:28.100 --> 00:07:30.490
know that they're specific
to each manufacturer.

141
00:07:30.490 --> 00:07:33.851
>> Very good, but performance wise
there's no real big difference.

142
00:07:33.851 --> 00:07:37.930
It's just how does the processor actually
make contact with the motherboard.

143
00:07:37.930 --> 00:07:41.050
>> That's right, it's really how
the processor makes contact.

144
00:07:41.050 --> 00:07:43.845
And then we get into the whole
Intel versus AMD, and

145
00:07:43.845 --> 00:07:46.188
I don't know if we want
to go down that one.

146
00:07:46.188 --> 00:07:49.468
Because some people like and
are very product,

147
00:07:49.468 --> 00:07:53.661
I don't know, they like Intel and
some people swear by AMD.

148
00:07:53.661 --> 00:07:56.741
So ultimately Mike, I would say no,
it's not really a performance thing,

149
00:07:56.741 --> 00:07:59.818
it's like you said it, it's just how
they make the electrical contact with

150
00:07:59.818 --> 00:08:01.440
the motherboard and the CPU itself.

151
00:08:01.440 --> 00:08:02.720
Very good.

152
00:08:02.720 --> 00:08:05.860
All right now, the next thing I wanna talk
about is something that you don't really

153
00:08:05.860 --> 00:08:07.300
see on these boards at all.

154
00:08:07.300 --> 00:08:09.130
And that's something
known as a reset button.

155
00:08:09.130 --> 00:08:12.600
And a rest button,
you find it a lot on the newer boards.

156
00:08:12.600 --> 00:08:17.570
You can find too that this is also part of

157
00:08:17.570 --> 00:08:20.100
the case itself,
it depends on where it's located.

158
00:08:20.100 --> 00:08:22.650
A lot of the times you'll
have two of these switches.

159
00:08:22.650 --> 00:08:26.990
The ability to recycle the power all
the way, and restart the machine,

160
00:08:26.990 --> 00:08:29.790
without having to hardboot
the entire machine.

161
00:08:29.790 --> 00:08:31.600
And, that's something
known as the reset button.

162
00:08:31.600 --> 00:08:33.430
Sometimes you can push that
on the front of a case.

163
00:08:33.430 --> 00:08:35.560
You'll see a little,
small button that you can reset.

164
00:08:35.560 --> 00:08:38.900
But, a lot of these motherboards actually,
have a button right on the motherboard

165
00:08:38.900 --> 00:08:42.130
itself, that you can push and
it restarts the system.

166
00:08:42.130 --> 00:08:44.000
That's called the reset button.

167
00:08:44.000 --> 00:08:46.490
It might be something that
you have on the mother board.

168
00:08:46.490 --> 00:08:47.650
I know mine's got that.

169
00:08:47.650 --> 00:08:53.450
I've got a gigabyte ASUS, not ASUS but
a gigabyte type board and its got that.

170
00:08:53.450 --> 00:08:55.030
But these here, they don't.

171
00:08:55.030 --> 00:08:56.730
I can't actually show you that.

172
00:08:56.730 --> 00:08:58.870
Keep in mind,
it could also be on the case as well.

173
00:09:00.710 --> 00:09:04.260
So, what else do we have
connected to the motherboard?

174
00:09:04.260 --> 00:09:05.110
Well, we got a lot of stuff.

175
00:09:05.110 --> 00:09:07.220
The next thing that we're
gonna talk about, and

176
00:09:07.220 --> 00:09:10.850
they call out on the exam objectives,
are fan connectors.

177
00:09:10.850 --> 00:09:13.220
And there are a couple of different
types of fan connectors and

178
00:09:13.220 --> 00:09:14.610
I want to kind of mention them here.

179
00:09:14.610 --> 00:09:17.890
One that is on the motherboard,
one that is not.

180
00:09:17.890 --> 00:09:22.502
And I want you to know the difference in
why you might use one over the other.

181
00:09:22.502 --> 00:09:27.050
All right, I've got a couple of fans here
that we have set to the side here, and if

182
00:09:27.050 --> 00:09:30.860
we could take a look at them, you've got
a couple of different connectors, right?

183
00:09:30.860 --> 00:09:34.760
You'll see in our hard drive section that
we talk about the old traditional molex

184
00:09:34.760 --> 00:09:38.450
connectors, and these go back to
the days of like the early days,

185
00:09:38.450 --> 00:09:42.540
of like the parallel ATA connectors,
the old hard drives right?.

186
00:09:42.540 --> 00:09:45.564
Well, they're still used inside
of your computing environment,

187
00:09:45.564 --> 00:09:48.280
because what they do is,
they connect to these system fans.

188
00:09:48.280 --> 00:09:54.850
Now, the good thing about this is,
you can take a single power plug, coming

189
00:09:54.850 --> 00:09:59.540
off your power supply unit, and you can
daisy-chain a lot of these on there okay.

190
00:09:59.540 --> 00:10:01.900
But there's a limiting factor to these.

191
00:10:01.900 --> 00:10:04.670
A lot of times is what you don't
get is variable speed, and

192
00:10:04.670 --> 00:10:08.720
you don't get some of the monitoring,
and, not diagnostic.

193
00:10:08.720 --> 00:10:10.480
I guess more monitoring than anything.

194
00:10:10.480 --> 00:10:12.480
That we talked about in our bio section.

195
00:10:12.480 --> 00:10:15.020
To do that what you need
to have is one of these.

196
00:10:15.020 --> 00:10:17.650
They're still a Molex connector but
they've got a funny name.

197
00:10:17.650 --> 00:10:18.260
It's Molex KK.

198
00:10:18.260 --> 00:10:20.240
I don't want you to worry about that.

199
00:10:20.240 --> 00:10:22.370
It's just a family,
a style of connectors, and

200
00:10:22.370 --> 00:10:26.615
they can, now they can be all different
types of connectors but primarily what you

201
00:10:26.615 --> 00:10:30.205
see inside of your computing environment
is a three pin or a four pin.

202
00:10:30.205 --> 00:10:33.585
If it's a three pin then what it
means is you can't really monitor it.

203
00:10:33.585 --> 00:10:35.865
You'll have your positive,
you'll have your negative, and

204
00:10:35.865 --> 00:10:37.825
then I believe you'll
have your ground here.

205
00:10:37.825 --> 00:10:41.065
If you see a four pin,
then what that means, same thing,

206
00:10:41.065 --> 00:10:42.555
you've got your positive,
negative, and ground,

207
00:10:42.555 --> 00:10:45.565
but then you have a fourth pin for
things like monitoring.

208
00:10:45.565 --> 00:10:50.650
And they usually plug in you'll see, well
this one's completely different here, but

209
00:10:50.650 --> 00:10:55.660
you'll usually see a little header on the
motherboard that we can plug these into.

210
00:10:55.660 --> 00:11:00.600
Now it's important to understand
that when you plug the system fan,

211
00:11:00.600 --> 00:11:03.860
well this is the CPU fan,
these are called system fans.

212
00:11:03.860 --> 00:11:08.280
When you plug these into the motherboard,
this gives the motherboard the ability to

213
00:11:08.280 --> 00:11:13.050
say, okay, if I've got a thermal
temperature sensor that's basically

214
00:11:13.050 --> 00:11:15.190
telling you what the heat is,
detecting what the heat is.

215
00:11:15.190 --> 00:11:19.090
If I see that heat rise and
the temperatures start to go up, with that

216
00:11:19.090 --> 00:11:22.530
fourth pin, it can send a little bit more
electrical current, not only monitoring

217
00:11:22.530 --> 00:11:26.990
it, but send a little more electric
current to ramp up the RPMs on the CPU.

218
00:11:26.990 --> 00:11:29.840
And again,
you can find them all over the place.

219
00:11:29.840 --> 00:11:33.320
Let's see if I can find
one on this motherboard.

220
00:11:33.320 --> 00:11:34.720
Sometimes, they're hard to find.

221
00:11:34.720 --> 00:11:38.490
And you know what, I am not seeing one.

222
00:11:38.490 --> 00:11:42.240
There's a CPU fan and that's actually
you can see the four pin right there and

223
00:11:42.240 --> 00:11:43.770
that's kinda hard to see.

224
00:11:43.770 --> 00:11:47.250
But that's a little four
pin Molex connector.

225
00:11:47.250 --> 00:11:52.420
And again gives it the ability that if it
detects that there's a lot of heat and

226
00:11:52.420 --> 00:11:57.190
it maybe needs to increase the cooling,
if you will, it will ramp up

227
00:11:57.190 --> 00:12:01.720
the RPM's within the system unit itself,
basically assisting the cooling.

228
00:12:01.720 --> 00:12:04.700
There's one, here we go,
here's a system fan header right here.

229
00:12:04.700 --> 00:12:09.890
It's kinda hard to see but
you can see SYS_FAN there for

230
00:12:09.890 --> 00:12:13.820
system fan, so what we would do is
we would take one of these here and

231
00:12:13.820 --> 00:12:15.880
we would just plug it right into here.

232
00:12:17.680 --> 00:12:21.460
And there we go we've installed one of the
system fans and then what the system fan

233
00:12:21.460 --> 00:12:26.440
does is it typically sits in the case and
it pulls cool air inside of the case.

234
00:12:26.440 --> 00:12:27.920
Well, depending on how you
have your case set up.

235
00:12:27.920 --> 00:12:29.990
Something these can be a push mechanism.

236
00:12:29.990 --> 00:12:31.860
Sometimes they can be
an exhaust mechanism.

237
00:12:31.860 --> 00:12:35.610
So basically based on what
your case might support.

238
00:12:35.610 --> 00:12:39.850
So those are something to keep in mind as
well, again, if they're integrated into

239
00:12:39.850 --> 00:12:43.100
the motherboard the big thing with those
that I want you to take away from this is

240
00:12:43.100 --> 00:12:48.700
the fact that the motherboard itself,
it can detect the RPMs.

241
00:12:48.700 --> 00:12:51.166
You could even see in the monitoring
software in your bios,

242
00:12:51.166 --> 00:12:52.880
that it'll tell you
the RPM's it's running.

243
00:12:52.880 --> 00:12:58.100
I know mine does that it says okay well
my CPU fan is running at 2,900 RPM's and

244
00:12:58.100 --> 00:13:02.190
it sees the heat start to rise,
I've seen where I've gone in there and

245
00:13:02.190 --> 00:13:05.180
its like 4,0000 RPM's and I'm like well I
think it's time to blow the dust out of

246
00:13:05.180 --> 00:13:10.300
this case because the cooling system's
having to work really hard, so

247
00:13:10.300 --> 00:13:14.100
it does variable speed and it also gives
the motherboard a chance to give you

248
00:13:14.100 --> 00:13:19.530
a little bit information back on
the current status of that fan as well.

249
00:13:19.530 --> 00:13:22.360
The other thing that's
really great about these two

250
00:13:22.360 --> 00:13:23.643
is it detects system failure, right?

251
00:13:23.643 --> 00:13:27.000
Excuse me, fan failure.
You could see it a lot of times that it

00:13:27.000 --> 00:13:28.100
might even throw a warning.

253
00:13:28.100 --> 00:13:31.770
If in your BIOS,
sometimes BIOS or UEFI platforms,

254
00:13:31.770 --> 00:13:34.730
they support fan failure warnings.

255
00:13:34.730 --> 00:13:37.750
Be careful with that [LAUGH]
because when a fan fails,

256
00:13:37.750 --> 00:13:38.950
you're gonna get warned, all right.

257
00:13:38.950 --> 00:13:39.678
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

258
00:13:39.678 --> 00:13:41.433
>> Tell your neighbors next to you.

259
00:13:41.433 --> 00:13:44.201
It basically gives off
this high-pitched alarm.

260
00:13:44.201 --> 00:13:49.300
So [LAUGH] I made the mistake I have
quite a few system fan headers.

261
00:13:49.300 --> 00:13:51.080
You might call those,
the connectors on the motherboard,

262
00:13:51.080 --> 00:13:52.560
you might hear them called headers.

263
00:13:52.560 --> 00:13:56.650
And what I did is I turned the alarm on
but I didn't connect one of the fans.

264
00:13:56.650 --> 00:13:59.440
So it thought it was a failure and
the moment I turned the computer on.

265
00:13:59.440 --> 00:14:03.610
So, you might not wanna turn that
alarm on if you're not gonna populate.

266
00:14:03.610 --> 00:14:04.630
And what that means, again,

267
00:14:04.630 --> 00:14:08.900
jargon for installing all the system
fans across the motherboard itself.

268
00:14:08.900 --> 00:14:10.010
>> Very good.

269
00:14:10.010 --> 00:14:17.010
>> So the next thing, we've got
what are known as front panel and

270
00:14:17.010 --> 00:14:21.740
top panel connectors that we need to
look at inside of our motherboard.

271
00:14:21.740 --> 00:14:29.380
This is an interesting concept because
what is a front and top panel connector?

272
00:14:29.380 --> 00:14:30.300
Mike I don't know about you.

273
00:14:30.300 --> 00:14:32.090
Do you see any panels on
this motherboard anywhere?

274
00:14:32.090 --> 00:14:35.740
>> I was going to say, you know Wes,
my case at home has some connectors on

00:14:35.740 --> 00:14:39.640
the front, but I don't see how they're
going to get to the motherboard.

276
00:14:39.640 --> 00:14:40.800
>> That's right.

277
00:14:40.800 --> 00:14:44.320
The front panel and top panel,
I want you to think of, for instance.

278
00:14:44.320 --> 00:14:45.830
I want you to think of your case.

279
00:14:45.830 --> 00:14:50.570
This really relates to your case, and the
connections that your case, your tower,

280
00:14:50.570 --> 00:14:55.060
the exoskeleton of the system unit
make to the motherboard itself.

281
00:14:55.060 --> 00:14:58.980
And in fact let's see here, this one,
okay, we got this right here,

282
00:14:58.980 --> 00:15:02.740
let me turn this around a little bit,
did I get that in the camera there?

283
00:15:02.740 --> 00:15:04.880
It's over here, yeah.

284
00:15:04.880 --> 00:15:05.720
There we go.

285
00:15:05.720 --> 00:15:07.810
So it doesn't look that glorious, right,

286
00:15:07.810 --> 00:15:10.820
it's just a little small
connector right here, right.

287
00:15:10.820 --> 00:15:12.680
And you can see a series of pins.

288
00:15:12.680 --> 00:15:15.820
Now I will tell you that every
one of these are kind of

289
00:15:15.820 --> 00:15:18.440
unique to each case that you have.

290
00:15:18.440 --> 00:15:21.340
And on the front of your case you
might have seen things like a hard

291
00:15:21.340 --> 00:15:23.650
drive activity light, right?

292
00:15:23.650 --> 00:15:26.800
When you turn on your computer,
you see the little red or green or

293
00:15:26.800 --> 00:15:28.280
blue, whatever the color might be.

294
00:15:28.280 --> 00:15:32.580
And you can see that light flickering on
and off, that's a drive activity light

295
00:15:32.580 --> 00:15:36.080
indicator it lets you know that the hard
drive's running or maybe it's red and

296
00:15:36.080 --> 00:15:38.870
that tells you something's bad maybe
the hard drive isn't running you got more

297
00:15:38.870 --> 00:15:40.410
problems than you know.

298
00:15:40.410 --> 00:15:43.060
But it can also do things
like the power light.

299
00:15:43.060 --> 00:15:46.923
When you push the power on the front of
your computer that light a lot of times,

300
00:15:46.923 --> 00:15:49.896
you'll have a light in that
power button that comes on, and

301
00:15:49.896 --> 00:15:52.473
it lets you know,
hey we got power to the computer.

302
00:15:52.473 --> 00:15:56.359
It also connects to things like your
audio, and if you've got those little what

303
00:15:56.359 --> 00:16:00.187
are they the one-eighth inch 3.5 mm TRS
jacks, the audio jacks in the front

304
00:16:00.187 --> 00:16:03.530
of the case that I plug my headphones or
a microphone into.

305
00:16:03.530 --> 00:16:06.960
Well, that's where you connect
those connections from the case to

306
00:16:06.960 --> 00:16:11.350
the motherboard, and it allows you to use
those headphones and those microphones.

307
00:16:11.350 --> 00:16:13.200
Could be USB, all right?

308
00:16:13.200 --> 00:16:15.250
Now on the motherboard here itself,
let's be careful.

309
00:16:15.250 --> 00:16:17.330
Let me show you this
motherboard again down here.

310
00:16:17.330 --> 00:16:20.430
Notice that we have some USB connectors
that are on the back of this motherboard

311
00:16:20.430 --> 00:16:21.540
and a stack of them right here.

312
00:16:21.540 --> 00:16:22.840
Well those are integrated, right?

313
00:16:22.840 --> 00:16:24.120
That's the IO ports and

314
00:16:24.120 --> 00:16:27.210
they're integrated into the functionality
of the motherboard itself.

315
00:16:27.210 --> 00:16:30.870
However, a lot of times, and
most of the times your towers,

316
00:16:30.870 --> 00:16:34.790
your cases will have their
own USB ports in them.

317
00:16:34.790 --> 00:16:40.320
And if you look on the inside of that
case along with the front panel headers,

318
00:16:40.320 --> 00:16:42.690
typically this is a separate wire so
we have to be careful.

319
00:16:42.690 --> 00:16:45.520
A lot of times you might not even
see that in the front panel headers,

320
00:16:45.520 --> 00:16:47.370
that it's a completely separate cable.

321
00:16:47.370 --> 00:16:50.680
That same concept that basically
plugs into the motherboard and

322
00:16:50.680 --> 00:16:54.350
allows you to use the USB ports that
are integrated into the case versus

323
00:16:54.350 --> 00:16:56.970
the ones that are integrated
into the motherboard.

324
00:16:56.970 --> 00:17:00.200
All right, so let me see,
make sure I didn't miss anything here.

325
00:17:00.200 --> 00:17:02.604
USB, we've got the power button and
the power light,

326
00:17:02.604 --> 00:17:04.129
drive activity light indicator.

327
00:17:04.129 --> 00:17:08.012
And again it flickers on and off to let
you know the hard drives running or

328
00:17:08.012 --> 00:17:10.031
lack thereof, [LAUGH] as well as USB.

329
00:17:10.031 --> 00:17:12.908
So those are some of the things
that we really have to look at

330
00:17:12.908 --> 00:17:16.810
overall when it comes to the major
components within the motherboard itself.

331
00:17:18.662 --> 00:17:20.630
All right, now we got the fun stuff,
Mike, [LAUGH] all right?

332
00:17:20.630 --> 00:17:22.800
>> That's what I'm looking forward to.

333
00:17:22.800 --> 00:17:26.100
>> Yeah, so we've been talking
about a lot of the components and

334
00:17:26.100 --> 00:17:32.380
what we're trying to do is basically
show you what these components are.

335
00:17:32.380 --> 00:17:36.720
And really when it comes down to it, those
are the majority of the major components

336
00:17:36.720 --> 00:17:38.780
that you might interact
with on a motherboard.

337
00:17:38.780 --> 00:17:41.300
Some of the integrated components that
you can see, the little transistors and

338
00:17:41.300 --> 00:17:45.400
stuff, not really anything you have
to worry about for the A+ exam.

339
00:17:45.400 --> 00:17:49.180
However, there are some things that you
do have to worry about the A+ exam, and

340
00:17:49.180 --> 00:17:51.660
those are known as form factors.

341
00:17:51.660 --> 00:17:55.452
Now Mike, you asked the question earlier,
said form factors, you know we get size

00:17:55.452 --> 00:17:58.539
and shape, and we talked about
those being the characteristics and

343
00:17:58.539 --> 00:18:00.726
the arrangement of the mother boards,
right?

344
00:18:00.726 --> 00:18:02.806
This is about standardization, all right?

345
00:18:02.806 --> 00:18:05.321
In the earlier days of computing,
and networking, and

346
00:18:05.321 --> 00:18:07.195
I know you're a network administrator so

347
00:18:07.195 --> 00:18:11.160
I know you understand this well, everybody
wanted to do everything their own way.

348
00:18:11.160 --> 00:18:12.450
>> Right.
>> Everybody had the latest and

349
00:18:12.450 --> 00:18:13.310
greatest technology,

350
00:18:13.310 --> 00:18:16.730
but the problem is you would get into
something known as vendorlocked, right?

351
00:18:16.730 --> 00:18:19.050
Vendorlocked, it wasn't vendor
diversity that we have today.

352
00:18:19.050 --> 00:18:23.370
A lot of times if you're just getting into
computing you don't really realize this,

353
00:18:23.370 --> 00:18:26.492
but there was a point in time
that Atari was making computers.

354
00:18:26.492 --> 00:18:29.642
I think Toshiba was making computers,
Commodore, and, wow,

355
00:18:29.642 --> 00:18:30.935
that's an old one there.

356
00:18:30.935 --> 00:18:31.530
>> Yeah.

357
00:18:31.530 --> 00:18:33.200
>> But everybody was making computers, and

358
00:18:33.200 --> 00:18:35.210
they were all making it
a little bit different.

359
00:18:35.210 --> 00:18:37.820
And if you bought their computer,
guess what?

360
00:18:37.820 --> 00:18:39.470
You'd have to buy all
their components too.

361
00:18:39.470 --> 00:18:43.740
Because their components wouldn't fit
in another manufacturer's components.

362
00:18:43.740 --> 00:18:48.640
So IBM, and again, IBM has basically
led the way on a lot of things that

363
00:18:48.640 --> 00:18:51.440
have been standardized
later down the road, right?

364
00:18:51.440 --> 00:18:54.730
IBM said, okay, well we're gonna
release what's known as a standard or

365
00:18:54.730 --> 00:18:55.890
a specification.

366
00:18:55.890 --> 00:18:57.310
Why do we want standardization?

367
00:18:57.310 --> 00:19:00.250
Before we even get into
the forum factor sizes, right?

368
00:19:00.250 --> 00:19:03.160
Standardization provides consistency,
all right?

369
00:19:03.160 --> 00:19:06.028
Not only does it provide consistency,
it provides inter-operability.

370
00:19:06.028 --> 00:19:09.497
And one of the great things is
it allows you, as the consumer,

371
00:19:09.497 --> 00:19:13.200
to make a choice that says, hey,
I can get an ASUS motherboard.

372
00:19:13.200 --> 00:19:15.500
I can get a gigabyte motherboard.

373
00:19:15.500 --> 00:19:19.830
But then I can go to NVIDIA
if I want a video card or

374
00:19:19.830 --> 00:19:23.700
I could go to ATI and
I could get a video card.

375
00:19:23.700 --> 00:19:26.630
If I need a network adapter,
I could choose Intel, right?

376
00:19:26.630 --> 00:19:30.000
I might not even have an Intel board and
that's gonna throw you for a loop.

377
00:19:30.000 --> 00:19:34.280
I might have an AMD board that I can
put an Intel network adapter in.

378
00:19:34.280 --> 00:19:35.600
Maybe I don't like Intel.

379
00:19:35.600 --> 00:19:38.630
Well, that's okay,
I can get a Broadcom network adapter.

380
00:19:38.630 --> 00:19:41.440
You have choices and you have this
inter-operability and if they're

381
00:19:41.440 --> 00:19:45.320
following the standards you know what
to expect when you open the case.

382
00:19:45.320 --> 00:19:47.721
And that's one of the great
things about standardization and

383
00:19:47.721 --> 00:19:49.510
it's why it's important here on the exam.

384
00:19:49.510 --> 00:19:54.120
So we're gonna talk about some of
those form factors right here.

385
00:19:54.120 --> 00:19:55.810
>> Actually, Wes, we're not.

386
00:19:55.810 --> 00:19:56.350
No, I'm kidding.

387
00:19:56.350 --> 00:19:57.410
We are gonna go over them.

388
00:19:57.410 --> 00:20:00.705
But unfortunately, we are out of time for
this particular episode.

389
00:20:00.705 --> 00:20:02.060
So we're gonna leave
you with a cliffhanger.

390
00:20:02.060 --> 00:20:05.900
We're gonna talk about those
different form factors in part three.

391
00:20:05.900 --> 00:20:06.523
So thank you for that, Wes.

392
00:20:06.523 --> 00:20:09.120
Anything you want to add
