393
00:20:09.120 --> 00:20:09.847
>> No, access denied.

394
00:20:09.847 --> 00:20:11.493
>> [LAUGH]
>> Apparently,

395
00:20:11.493 --> 00:20:15.070
we gotta leave you with that cliffhanger,
but we will see you in that third part.

396
00:20:15.070 --> 00:20:15.610
>> I like it.

397
00:20:15.610 --> 00:20:16.990
All right,
well thanks everybody for joining,

398
00:20:16.990 --> 00:20:18.740
hope you enjoyed watching this one.

399
00:20:18.740 --> 00:20:21.510
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Mike Rodrick.

400
00:20:21.510 --> 00:20:23.160
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.
>> And we'll see you next time.

401
00:20:23.160 --> 00:20:30.477
[MUSIC]

402
00:20:30.477 --> 00:20:33.380
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode Wes and Mike break down the different form factors of motherboards. They discuss how size is not the only difference between the form-factors. They also look at the different expansion slots and their bandwidth.

you have choices as a consumer.

00:01:43.110 --> 00:01:46.920
And that's a great thing to have,
to be able to say,

Now I just have to figure out, who do I

But, there are some things that
the standards that we're gonna talk about,

00:02:01.761 --> 00:02:06.100

Form factor isn't just about

00:02:30.390 --> 00:02:32.350
it's a lot of things

00:03:07.100 --> 00:03:10.970
So for instance, I'll have an ATX case,

widely adopted motherboard form factor

00:03:58.350 --> 00:03:59.690
Now, when I say it's been around for

00:03:59.690 --> 00:04:03.798

00:04:03.798 --> 00:04:05.660

00:04:07.100 --> 00:04:10.230

see a little about the future and

00:04:21.054 --> 00:04:21.974

00:04:21.974 --> 00:04:26.480

00:04:53.390 --> 00:04:57.520
Now, with the AT boards, I want you to

00:05:04.500 --> 00:05:09.370
ATX is a 12 inch by 9.6 inch motherboard.

00:05:09.370 --> 00:05:13.370
And this is why you could probably

00:05:13.370 --> 00:05:15.860
Cuz if I have an ATX case,

00:05:46.870 --> 00:05:50.350

00:05:50.350 --> 00:05:54.750
one of the things that the ATX

00:05:54.750 --> 00:05:59.090
I guess divergence, from the earlier

104
00:05:59.090 --> 00:06:01.000
In the AT boards, in those days,

00:06:01.000 --> 00:06:06.580
in fact if we can take a look here at

106
00:06:06.580 --> 00:06:10.610
In the earlier AT boards,
you had a single keyboard connector, and

107
00:06:10.610 --> 00:06:12.140
that was called an AT dean.

108
00:06:12.140 --> 00:06:15.230
It was an AT DIN connector, in fact
we still use it today, it's used in

109
00:06:15.230 --> 00:06:19.410

used in input devices for keyboards.

110
00:06:19.410 --> 00:06:22.690
And if you had a mouse on that day,

111
00:06:22.690 --> 00:06:24.710
And you would plug it in this way.

00:06:24.710 --> 00:06:27.190
Well, that wasn't really convenient, so

00:06:27.190 --> 00:06:31.420
what the ATX standard
brought in is the PS2 port.

00:06:31.420 --> 00:06:34.780
Now, I know what you gamers are thinking

00:06:34.780 --> 00:06:36.060

00:06:36.060 --> 00:06:37.960
what we're talking about

00:06:39.280 --> 00:06:43.300
This replaced the earlier what would
be known as the AT DIN connector,

00:06:43.300 --> 00:06:44.970

00:06:44.970 --> 00:06:49.020
DIN just stands for the German Institute

00:06:49.020 --> 00:06:52.000

00:06:53.570 --> 00:06:59.110
This is called a six pin mini-din, and you

122
00:06:59.110 --> 00:07:03.420
Now, I will tell you that the colors,

00:07:03.420 --> 00:07:07.135
In fact, some days today, for

00:07:07.135 --> 00:07:08.855

00:07:08.855 --> 00:07:12.105
So keep in mind, the color codes
are really just for us to know, and

00:07:12.105 --> 00:07:16.705

facto than it did really a standard

00:07:16.705 --> 00:07:20.650
to color code them, just so you know which
one's keyboard and which one's mouse.

128
00:07:20.650 --> 00:07:23.360
That's one of the big things that I
want you to know when it comes to

129
00:07:23.360 --> 00:07:25.170
the ATX standard.

130
00:07:25.170 --> 00:07:30.030
Now the other thing that the ATX
standard did is it would rearrange,

131
00:07:30.030 --> 00:07:35.110
from the earlier AT days, it would
rearrange the CPU and rotate the whole

00:07:35.110 --> 00:07:39.790
board 90 degrees to put that CPU,
if you ever looked inside your case,

133
00:07:39.790 --> 00:07:41.650
the CPU is sitting right
under the power supply.

00:07:41.650 --> 00:07:44.300
And that's the fan of
the power supply can help

135
00:07:44.300 --> 00:07:49.340
assist the overall cooling system
within the machine itself.

136
00:07:49.340 --> 00:07:51.350
Now there's some other
great things that it did.

137
00:07:51.350 --> 00:07:54.864
In the earlier AT standard we
had what were known as a P8 and

00:07:54.864 --> 00:07:56.315
a P9 power connector.

139
00:07:56.315 --> 00:08:00.230
And there was a problem, well could be
a problem with these, they were identical.

00:08:01.520 --> 00:08:02.236
So how do you arrange it, right?

141
00:08:02.236 --> 00:08:04.299
>> [LAUGH]
>> You had to know that black and

00:08:04.299 --> 00:08:07.500
red together is how you would arrange

00:08:07.500 --> 00:08:10.490
And the thing about reversing
the polarity of your [LAUGH] power

144
00:08:10.490 --> 00:08:14.649
supply could cause all kinds of problems,
short circuits or damage, right?

145
00:08:14.649 --> 00:08:18.170
So they said, you know what,
we can't have that anymore.

146
00:08:18.170 --> 00:08:23.045
Let's make it a little bit more convenient

147
00:08:23.045 --> 00:08:27.550

00:08:27.550 --> 00:08:29.192
All right, so

00:08:29.192 --> 00:08:32.891
One of the other things that the ATX
standard brought in is this 20 pin

00:08:32.891 --> 00:08:34.000

00:08:34.000 --> 00:08:37.250
And I know its kinda hard to see, but Mike

00:08:37.250 --> 00:08:37.986

00:08:37.986 --> 00:08:39.310

00:08:39.310 --> 00:08:42.165
These specific shapes,
they call it notched keyed connector.

00:08:42.165 --> 00:08:46.185
And we would know exactly how to
put the clip from the power supply

156
00:08:46.185 --> 00:08:48.280
cuz it would have the notch on it.

157
00:08:48.280 --> 00:08:52.746
And then the power supply connector
actually matches the notches that are in

158
00:08:52.746 --> 00:08:54.670

159
00:08:54.670 --> 00:08:55.820
So I want you to know that.

00:08:55.820 --> 00:08:59.730
Now, the ATX standard has
gone through many revisions.

00:08:59.730 --> 00:09:03.605
Because in the earlier days, we didn't

not as much as we need today

00:09:06.540 --> 00:09:08.127
And a lot of other things

00:09:10.300 --> 00:09:13.250
So it has gone through its revisions,

00:09:13.250 --> 00:09:16.980
We'll definitely talk about some of these

00:09:16.980 --> 00:09:18.705
But that's the big thing

00:09:18.705 --> 00:09:22.510

00:09:22.510 --> 00:09:24.420
Now, that is one of the major things.

00:09:24.420 --> 00:09:28.877
And while we're still here with these
motherboards, the other thing I wanna tell

00:09:28.877 --> 00:09:33.204

00:09:33.204 --> 00:09:37.680

00:09:37.680 --> 00:09:42.530

In those days, you can get a card

00:09:45.717 --> 00:09:48.105

00:09:48.105 --> 00:09:51.670
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well, when the ATX standard came out,

00:09:51.670 --> 00:09:56.730
what they did is they integrated the IO

00:09:56.730 --> 00:09:58.620
>> Now Wes,
you got three motherboards there,

00:09:58.620 --> 00:10:01.120

00:10:01.120 --> 00:10:03.182
And we're saying it's a standard, yet

00:10:03.182 --> 00:10:05.920
they don't really look like

00:10:05.920 --> 00:10:06.860

00:10:06.860 --> 00:10:08.470
>> Well, that's kinda interesting here.

00:10:08.470 --> 00:10:11.000
What the ATX standard,
let me show you guys here.

185
00:10:11.000 --> 00:10:15.050
What the ATX standard calls out
is a rectangular pattern, right?

186
00:10:15.050 --> 00:10:17.100
The dimensions of a rectangle essentially.

187
00:10:17.100 --> 00:10:20.324
And if I put these two different
boards up here side by side,

00:10:20.324 --> 00:10:23.560
you'll notice that they're
almost the same width right?

189
00:10:23.560 --> 00:10:25.370
Length and height if you will.

00:10:25.370 --> 00:10:29.831
And that is because the ATX standard
integrates these components in and

00:10:29.831 --> 00:10:32.670
calls out the rectangular pattern, right?

192
00:10:32.670 --> 00:10:34.700
The dimensions of that rectangle.

00:10:34.700 --> 00:10:39.110
But what it doesn't call out Is what

00:10:39.110 --> 00:10:42.070
So what it does is it gives

00:10:42.070 --> 00:10:45.418
Not saying that hey, you have to

00:10:45.418 --> 00:10:48.910

And Mike you and I were talking

00:10:59.872 --> 00:11:02.881

And one of the great things is if you
an ATX standard, those blanking plates and

00:11:18.150 --> 00:11:20.939

00:11:20.939 --> 00:11:23.260

00:11:23.260 --> 00:11:26.510

00:11:26.510 --> 00:11:29.723

00:11:29.723 --> 00:11:30.503

00:11:30.503 --> 00:11:36.260

00:11:36.260 --> 00:11:39.390
Again, the I/Os,
they're integrated in the motherboard,

00:11:39.390 --> 00:11:40.580

00:11:41.600 --> 00:11:44.640
Now, I've also talked about the fact,

00:11:44.640 --> 00:11:48.170
we've got several different

The next one you're gonna

00:11:50.450 --> 00:11:56.180
Guys and gals, let me not confuse you

00:11:56.180 --> 00:11:57.583

00:12:02.765 --> 00:12:05.444
Now the Micro-ATX, everything's the same.

00:12:05.444 --> 00:12:10.576
Everything, as far as the arrangement, all

00:12:26.210 --> 00:12:31.260
So the Micro-ATX,
it would come out two years later, 1997.

00:12:31.260 --> 00:12:35.546
And its a nine by six,
actually nine by six, yeah,

00:12:35.546 --> 00:12:40.254
let me get this right,
9.6 inches by 9.6 inches.

00:12:40.254 --> 00:12:42.281

00:12:42.281 --> 00:12:45.169

00:12:45.169 --> 00:12:49.570

00:12:49.570 --> 00:12:53.660

but this is the Mini-ITX.

00:12:53.660 --> 00:12:55.440
That'll come up next.

00:12:55.440 --> 00:13:00.760
It was a 9.6 inch by 9.6 inch board,

00:13:00.760 --> 00:13:03.570
The power supplies are the same.

00:13:03.570 --> 00:13:06.450
I will tell you one of the micro

00:13:06.450 --> 00:13:10.530
ATX specifications is a maximum

00:13:10.530 --> 00:13:14.474
That's really the only difference is that

00:13:14.474 --> 00:13:18.372

00:13:18.372 --> 00:13:23.495
So, keep in mind that they're great for

00:13:44.350 --> 00:13:46.800
Now, on our diagram here,
we've got a couple more and

00:13:46.800 --> 00:13:49.120

00:13:49.120 --> 00:13:54.450
And I just want you to know that the ITX
standard, it's the basis for ITX.

253
00:13:54.450 --> 00:13:57.030
You're not gonna go out there and
find an ITX board, all right?

254
00:13:57.030 --> 00:14:01.190
It forms the basis for
all the other ITX standards, right?

255
00:14:01.190 --> 00:14:05.558
It's never formally released to the market
until we came up with Mini-ITX, right?

256
00:14:05.558 --> 00:14:09.609
There's Mini-ITX, there's Nano-ITX,
Pico, and even Mobile today.

257
00:14:09.609 --> 00:14:12.990
Mobile-ITX is like
a credit card sized board.

258
00:14:12.990 --> 00:14:15.568
So you could just see smaller,
smaller boards, right?

259
00:14:15.568 --> 00:14:20.605
Well the Mini-ITX board,
it came out in 2001.

260
00:14:20.605 --> 00:14:25.813
And that's the one that we have over here
that I kinda confuse with the Micro-ITX.

261
00:14:25.813 --> 00:14:30.762
The Mini-ITX is 6.7 inches by 6.7 inches,
right?

262
00:14:30.762 --> 00:14:33.889
The original design did
a passive cooling system,

263
00:14:33.889 --> 00:14:37.950
which means they were completely fanless,
and why is that?

264
00:14:37.950 --> 00:14:42.390
Because they were primarily
developed to have low powered,

265
00:14:42.390 --> 00:14:45.570
low heat CPUs in them, and
that's still the fact today.

266
00:14:45.570 --> 00:14:49.650
But with CPUs getting a lot more stronger,
we

267
00:14:49.650 --> 00:14:54.030
could still do a kind of a passive cooling
where you might have just a heat sink, and

268
00:14:54.030 --> 00:14:56.860
you could even sink fans in them today.

269
00:14:56.860 --> 00:15:01.510
Typically, with these you only
see a single expansion slot.

270
00:15:01.510 --> 00:15:04.712
A lot of times what you're gonna
see is that the I/O functionality,

271
00:15:04.712 --> 00:15:08.140
the input/output, will be integrated
directly in the motherboard itself.

272
00:15:08.140 --> 00:15:09.890
Let me show you what I mean here.

273
00:15:09.890 --> 00:15:15.120
You'll see that compared to
our more full-sized board,

274
00:15:15.120 --> 00:15:17.795
you have four RAM slots here.

275
00:15:17.795 --> 00:15:19.870
Notice that this one only has two.

276
00:15:19.870 --> 00:15:23.660
That's a commonality here,
all right, in these Mini-ITX boards.

277
00:15:23.660 --> 00:15:26.090
And you can see the square pattern here.

278
00:15:26.090 --> 00:15:28.520
You can see that we have our I/Os.

279
00:15:28.520 --> 00:15:31.735
And again, interestingly enough,
guess what, the ITX,

280
00:15:31.735 --> 00:15:34.772
Mini-ITX standard follows
the ATX standard, right?

281
00:15:34.772 --> 00:15:39.830
So for the most part, the ITX standard
isn't too far off the ATX standard.

282
00:15:39.830 --> 00:15:43.280
But the big thing here is it was for
low powered CPUs, right?

283
00:15:43.280 --> 00:15:48.370
In those home theater PC type builds,
very, very small footprint, right?

284
00:15:48.370 --> 00:15:51.099
Something that could fit in almost what
you would say is like a top set box for

285
00:15:51.099 --> 00:15:52.194
your cable company, right?

286
00:15:52.194 --> 00:15:53.200
>> Right.

287
00:15:53.200 --> 00:15:54.455
>> So very, very handy,

288
00:15:54.455 --> 00:15:57.703
that is another one that we
want you to be aware of, right?

289
00:15:57.703 --> 00:16:02.456
So those are some of the form factors when
it comes to the motherboards themselves.

290
00:16:02.456 --> 00:16:05.944
Remember, three form factors that
must match anytime you're gonna build

291
00:16:05.944 --> 00:16:06.503
a machine.

292
00:16:06.503 --> 00:16:08.920
It's gonna be your case, right?

293
00:16:08.920 --> 00:16:10.300
It's gonna be your motherboard.

294
00:16:10.300 --> 00:16:12.240
It's gonna be the power supply as well.

295
00:16:12.240 --> 00:16:13.775
>> All right, Wes, great stuff there.

296
00:16:13.775 --> 00:16:16.330
Just a wealth of knowledge when it
comes to the components we're gonna

297
00:16:16.330 --> 00:16:16.900
find in our PC.

298
00:16:16.900 --> 00:16:21.310
We've been focusing in on the motherboard,
the integrated components,

299
00:16:21.310 --> 00:16:23.412
the non-integrated components.

300
00:16:23.412 --> 00:16:24.325
And we kinda round things
up in this episode.

301
00:16:24.325 --> 00:16:26.278
Talking about the motherboard themselves.

302
00:16:26.278 --> 00:16:31.259
And the form factors and the standards
that we need to be aware of when we're

303
00:16:31.259 --> 00:16:36.100
building a PC, repairing a PC,
as well as passing that A+ 901 exam.

304
00:16:36.100 --> 00:16:37.520
So we thank you for that, Wes.

305
00:16:37.520 --> 00:16:38.955
Any parting words for our viewers?

306
00:16:38.955 --> 00:16:41.316
>> Well, I do have a few other
things that I wanna talk about.

307
00:16:41.316 --> 00:16:45.140
I do have something that they call out,
and this is kinda interesting.

308
00:16:45.140 --> 00:16:47.812
We've been talking about expansion
slots the whole entire time.

309
00:16:47.812 --> 00:16:52.047
But one of the things that we haven't
defined are those expansion slot

310
00:16:52.047 --> 00:16:54.110
specifications as well.

311
00:16:54.110 --> 00:16:59.360
So, that is something we kinda gotta cover
here, because you have to know, right?

312
00:16:59.360 --> 00:17:02.180
When we talk about expansion slots,
as you've seen, as Mike and I have talked,

313
00:17:02.180 --> 00:17:03.919
they're all different shapes and
sizes, right?

314
00:17:05.270 --> 00:17:07.289
So how do we know what one does what,
right?

315
00:17:07.289 --> 00:17:08.080
>> [LAUGH]
>> And

316
00:17:08.080 --> 00:17:10.680
that's why I wanna take just a few
more minutes here just to talk

317
00:17:10.680 --> 00:17:12.810
about these expansion
slots as we round up.

318
00:17:12.810 --> 00:17:15.445
And unfortunately,
we don't get out of specifications and

319
00:17:15.445 --> 00:17:16.795
standards quite that easily.

320
00:17:16.795 --> 00:17:18.388
>> [LAUGH] That's right,
that's right, ladies and gentlemen.

321
00:17:18.388 --> 00:17:21.066
>> [LAUGH] He tried to save
you a little bit of pain here.

322
00:17:21.066 --> 00:17:24.400
But we do have to talk a little
bit about these expansion slots.

323
00:17:24.400 --> 00:17:28.320
So on the exam,
they call out a series of these, right?

324
00:17:28.320 --> 00:17:31.010
And we've actually got these,
I've got a little diagram up here.

325
00:17:31.010 --> 00:17:34.900
So if we could kinda look at that,
we have PCI, and look at this,

326
00:17:34.900 --> 00:17:38.620
we just got a whole slew of
alphabet soup here, all right?

327
00:17:38.620 --> 00:17:42.220
Well, the expansion slot has what's known,
remember we talked about bus, right?

328
00:17:42.220 --> 00:17:43.960
Well, that's a bus architecture, right?

329
00:17:43.960 --> 00:17:46.850
The expansion slot sits
on those traces and

330
00:17:46.850 --> 00:17:48.850
that bus architecture's
gonna be important.

331
00:17:48.850 --> 00:17:51.800
Because remember,
we said interoperability,

332
00:17:51.800 --> 00:17:54.325
it's interoperability if you're
following the same standard.

333
00:17:54.325 --> 00:17:58.260
[LAUGH] So it is important to
understand these standards.

334
00:17:58.260 --> 00:18:01.450
Now the first one we have right here
is called the peripheral component

335
00:18:01.450 --> 00:18:01.990
interconnect.

336
00:18:01.990 --> 00:18:04.600
And this one's been around for
a very long time.

337
00:18:04.600 --> 00:18:06.650
It's almost considered legacy today.

338
00:18:06.650 --> 00:18:09.580
We still see it,
we still could potentially use it.

339
00:18:09.580 --> 00:18:12.970
And this was developed
back in 1992 by Intel and

340
00:18:12.970 --> 00:18:16.340
then later they handed this over
to what was known as PCI-Sig.

341
00:18:16.340 --> 00:18:19.995
That's a special interest group that
basically oversees the PCI standard.

342
00:18:19.995 --> 00:18:25.607
All right, this is a 32-bit bus.

343
00:18:25.607 --> 00:18:30.662
Or it could be 64-bit bus, which means
32 bits wide going into the CPU.

344
00:18:30.662 --> 00:18:36.226
I want you to remember that
each one of these 32-bit buses,

345
00:18:36.226 --> 00:18:41.797
again, you could have two
32-bit buses on a single board.

346
00:18:41.797 --> 00:18:45.984
And each one of those buses
could have five cards.

347
00:18:45.984 --> 00:18:49.873
So you can get a total, believe it or
not, maximum the standard support,

348
00:18:49.873 --> 00:18:51.470
is you can have ten PCI cards.

349
00:18:51.470 --> 00:18:55.680
If your board supported it, you can
expand out to ten cards, right, maximum.

350
00:18:55.680 --> 00:18:57.600
And I want you to remember the bits.

351
00:18:57.600 --> 00:18:59.831
It's the width of those traces, right,

352
00:18:59.831 --> 00:19:04.311
that pathway that we talked about that
goes into the CPU, it's 32 bits, right?

353
00:19:04.311 --> 00:19:09.085
Overall, it's really 64 bits, but there's
kind of like a dividing line, if you will,

354
00:19:09.085 --> 00:19:10.511
between the two 32 bits.

355
00:19:10.511 --> 00:19:14.853
And each of the five cards
sits on its own 32-bit bus.

356
00:19:14.853 --> 00:19:17.600
Now, there were some
limiting factors to this.

357
00:19:17.600 --> 00:19:20.150
It was what's known as
a parallel interface.

358
00:19:20.150 --> 00:19:25.320
And a parallel interface is one where we
have multiple adjacent copper conductors.

359
00:19:25.320 --> 00:19:28.647
And the problem with that is you
get what's known as crosstalk and

360
00:19:28.647 --> 00:19:30.108
electrical interference.

361
00:19:30.108 --> 00:19:34.428
Think about if I'm sending electrical
signal down one of those conductors and

362
00:19:34.428 --> 00:19:35.680
it kinda bleeds over.

363
00:19:35.680 --> 00:19:38.722
It interferes with the highway,
if you will, that's next to it, right?

364
00:19:38.722 --> 00:19:43.440
So there was only so much power
you could put over a PCI interface

365
00:19:43.440 --> 00:19:47.370
before it would cause crosstalk and
interference.

366
00:19:47.370 --> 00:19:49.330
So it was a little bit limiting.

367
00:19:49.330 --> 00:19:52.701
I want you to remember some
other specifics, all right?

368
00:19:52.701 --> 00:19:56.250
Standard configuration was 33 megahertz,
right?

369
00:19:56.250 --> 00:19:59.820
A hert, if you will,
is one clock cycle, if you will.

370
00:19:59.820 --> 00:20:02.660
And we measured in how many
clock cycles per second.

371
00:20:02.660 --> 00:20:05.679
So 33 clock cycles per second,
if you will.

372
00:20:05.679 --> 00:20:09.240
And again, I know a lot of standards guys,
but you can do this.

373
00:20:09.240 --> 00:20:11.881
The total speed was a 133 megabytes.

374
00:20:11.881 --> 00:20:17.710
Now that being said, remember I talked
about the PCI Special Interest Group?

375
00:20:17.710 --> 00:20:19.765
PCI Special Interest Group said,
you know what?

376
00:20:19.765 --> 00:20:21.601
This parallel interface,

377
00:20:21.601 --> 00:20:27.130
we're having kind of a problem with it
because it is a shared bus topology.

378
00:20:27.130 --> 00:20:28.760
And what that means is everyone,

379
00:20:28.760 --> 00:20:32.170
all of those ten cards,
were communicating across the same path.

380
00:20:32.170 --> 00:20:35.430
>> So to use the term you talked about
in one of our previous episodes,

381
00:20:35.430 --> 00:20:36.990
it starts becoming your bottleneck.

382
00:20:36.990 --> 00:20:38.077
>> It certainly does.

383
00:20:38.077 --> 00:20:40.190
It uses what's known as bus mastery,
right?

384
00:20:40.190 --> 00:20:45.820
Because think about maybe
a call that I'm on, right?

385
00:20:45.820 --> 00:20:47.639
If Mike and I are talking,

386
00:20:47.639 --> 00:20:52.606
rather than butt into the conversation,
only between our two phones,

387
00:20:52.606 --> 00:20:57.602
people can't really butt into that
call and just interrupt that call.

388
00:20:57.602 --> 00:21:00.485
So, what these cards would
do is use bus mastering,

389
00:21:00.485 --> 00:21:04.823
since they're all using the same highway,
I got ten cards who's gonna talk?

390
00:21:04.823 --> 00:21:06.108
Well, they would use bus mastering.

391
00:21:06.108 --> 00:21:10.550
And bus mastering just means that this
card would say, hey, I gotta talk.

392
00:21:10.550 --> 00:21:13.010
Everybody else, you gotta be quiet, right?

393
00:21:13.010 --> 00:21:14.450
So again, limiting, right?

394
00:21:14.450 --> 00:21:16.340
One card talks, everybody stops.

395
00:21:16.340 --> 00:21:17.880
The other card talks, everybody stops.

396
00:21:17.880 --> 00:21:21.830
So I also want you to know bus mastering
is the way that they would communicate.

397
00:21:21.830 --> 00:21:25.080
So PCI-SIG, the special interest group,
said, that's not even efficient.

398
00:21:25.080 --> 00:21:29.538
We need all cards running at all
times to get better performance.

399
00:21:29.538 --> 00:21:30.600
And later on,

400
00:21:30.600 --> 00:21:33.530
they would come up with another interface
that we're gonna talk about in a second.

401
00:21:34.570 --> 00:21:38.340
So what they tried to do is between
coming up with a new technology, PCI,

402
00:21:38.340 --> 00:21:41.400
they could see was coming to
the end of its efficiency.

403
00:21:41.400 --> 00:21:43.321
So they said, hey, you know what?

404
00:21:43.321 --> 00:21:48.990
How about we take the dividing line
out of those two 32-bit highways and

405
00:21:48.990 --> 00:21:51.740
we put them together one 64 bit.

406
00:21:51.740 --> 00:21:56.417
And we stick a single slot across that
entire 64 bit platform or trace, right?

407
00:21:56.417 --> 00:22:01.130
That would be what was known
as PCI extended, all right?

408
00:22:01.130 --> 00:22:02.997
That's really all I want you
to know about PCI extended.

409
00:22:02.997 --> 00:22:05.510
It wasn't highly adopted,
it was really expensive.

410
00:22:05.510 --> 00:22:08.262
We've seen in server technology and
it essentially says,

411
00:22:08.262 --> 00:22:11.687
let's take the dividing line out of
those two separate 32-bit buses.

412
00:22:11.687 --> 00:22:13.731
We'll slam them together with all 64 bits.

413
00:22:13.731 --> 00:22:15.988
And we'll put a card
across the top of it and

414
00:22:15.988 --> 00:22:20.548
we'll increase the speeds up to about
266 megabits per second, right?

415
00:22:20.548 --> 00:22:26.140
Again ,very expensive, only commonly
seen inside of your server environments,

416
00:22:26.140 --> 00:22:29.170
but even that was still using
the parallel interface.

417
00:22:29.170 --> 00:22:32.310
So what they did is they came out
with the next generation interface,

418
00:22:32.310 --> 00:22:35.640
which is really what we're using today,
and that's PCIE.

419
00:22:35.640 --> 00:22:39.160
PCIE is the peripheral component
interconnect express, and

420
00:22:39.160 --> 00:22:40.700
it uses a serial interface.

421
00:22:40.700 --> 00:22:44.270
And the serial interface
is a set of sequential

422
00:22:44.270 --> 00:22:47.790
information that's going back and
forth across that bus.

423
00:22:47.790 --> 00:22:50.560
And one of the great
things is it eliminates

424
00:22:50.560 --> 00:22:52.500
some of that crosstalk, if you will.

425
00:22:52.500 --> 00:22:55.160
And when we put a lot more voltage,
all we're doing

426
00:22:55.160 --> 00:22:57.490
is increasing the communication
across that single interface.

427
00:22:57.490 --> 00:23:03.040
So it's a serial interface and
it's a full point to point communication.

428
00:23:03.040 --> 00:23:07.833
Now, there are some of the PCIE standards
that I wanna just briefly talk about

429
00:23:07.833 --> 00:23:11.757
cuz it's gone through some
different revisions, all right?

430
00:23:11.757 --> 00:23:16.299
PCIe1 version one, and
let me just stop here for a second and

431
00:23:16.299 --> 00:23:18.360
let me say one other thing.

432
00:23:18.360 --> 00:23:23.977
One of the great things about PCIe is now
not only can you have a single interface,

433
00:23:23.977 --> 00:23:25.060
a single path.

434
00:23:25.060 --> 00:23:28.283
They made it to where you
can actually stagger and

435
00:23:28.283 --> 00:23:31.280
add individual sequential communication.

436
00:23:31.280 --> 00:23:34.679
So even though it's not a parallel
interface, you've essentially said,

437
00:23:34.679 --> 00:23:38.196
I got one pipeline, now I'm gonna add
another pipeline, another pipeline.

438
00:23:38.196 --> 00:23:40.767
And eventually,
all the way up to 16 of these, right?

439
00:23:40.767 --> 00:23:42.367
You might hear them called lanes, right?

440
00:23:42.367 --> 00:23:46.107
So you'll have one lane cards,
which is exactly like it sounds,

441
00:23:46.107 --> 00:23:49.470
just a single lane in and
out across the motherboard.

442
00:23:49.470 --> 00:23:50.710
You might have four.

443
00:23:50.710 --> 00:23:53.710
A four-lane card,
which is four of those lanes wide.

444
00:23:53.710 --> 00:23:55.622
Eight, all the way up to sixteen.

445
00:23:55.622 --> 00:23:59.242
>> All right, Wes, so really what we need
to know is the speed of a single lane and

446
00:23:59.242 --> 00:24:00.931
then we can just multiply that out?

447
00:24:00.931 --> 00:24:02.666
Makes it so much easier, doesn't it?

448
00:24:02.666 --> 00:24:03.202
>> Yeah.

449
00:24:03.202 --> 00:24:04.358
>> But that's absolutely the truth.

450
00:24:04.358 --> 00:24:08.670
Keep in mind, like we've said, you have
a single serial lane, and it's just great

451
00:24:08.670 --> 00:24:13.070
that they allow you, in the design, that
they attach multiple lanes, easiest way.

452
00:24:13.070 --> 00:24:16.670
So, let's look at, there's really three
PCIE standards that you have to know,

453
00:24:16.670 --> 00:24:18.400
and just make it easy.

454
00:24:18.400 --> 00:24:20.850
Version one, version two,
and version three.

455
00:24:20.850 --> 00:24:24.470
And let's kind of run through the speeds
that you can see on the different lanes.

456
00:24:24.470 --> 00:24:27.670
And really, when it comes down the exam,
remember what Mike said.

457
00:24:27.670 --> 00:24:30.730
That's gonna make it easier for you,
cuz if you can remember the single lanes,

458
00:24:30.730 --> 00:24:34.110
you don't have to remember four,
five, six different standards, right?

459
00:24:34.110 --> 00:24:37.130
So for instance, we have PCIE 1.0.

460
00:24:37.130 --> 00:24:41.200
Single lane transfer speed
is 250 megabytes per second.

461
00:24:41.200 --> 00:24:44.590
So that means if I have a four lane card,
multiply it times four.

462
00:24:44.590 --> 00:24:45.250
We've got a gigabit.

463
00:24:45.250 --> 00:24:49.670
If I have an eight lane card,
well we have two gigabytes, not gigabits,

464
00:24:49.670 --> 00:24:51.640
gigabytes, per second.

465
00:24:51.640 --> 00:24:56.400
And then if I have, finally, the 16 lane,
that's gonna be 250 megabytes times 16.

466
00:24:56.400 --> 00:24:59.290
That gives me four
gigabyte transfer speeds.

467
00:24:59.290 --> 00:25:02.370
So fairly easy once you know
that single lane speed.

468
00:25:02.370 --> 00:25:06.160
Now, when we move in to 2.0 everything,
the single lane's speeds double.

469
00:25:06.160 --> 00:25:09.957
And that's another thing that might make
it easier for the study and stand point.

470
00:25:09.957 --> 00:25:15.144
250 on a 1.0, we get into 2.0, single
lane speed's gonna be 500 megabytes,

471
00:25:15.144 --> 00:25:17.474
and then it's a multiplier after that.

472
00:25:17.474 --> 00:25:20.530
We have two gigabyte transfer speeds for
a four lane.

473
00:25:20.530 --> 00:25:22.310
We have four gigabytes for the eight lane.

474
00:25:22.310 --> 00:25:24.830
And in the 16 lane,
that's pretty impressive,

475
00:25:24.830 --> 00:25:26.865
brings it all the way up to 8 gigabytes.

476
00:25:26.865 --> 00:25:30.669
Eight gigabytes for those point to
point serial based connections.

477
00:25:30.669 --> 00:25:35.100
Then we also have 3.0 too, and
3.0 has been more of the common standard.

478
00:25:35.100 --> 00:25:37.851
Mike and I were talking about this,
cuz we're geeks.

479
00:25:37.851 --> 00:25:40.732
They got a four in draft right now,
and as of 2017,

480
00:25:40.732 --> 00:25:42.910
it should be released fairly soon.

481
00:25:42.910 --> 00:25:45.130
But I want you to know the 3.0.

482
00:25:45.130 --> 00:25:48.050
Single lane speed, four gigabytes.

483
00:25:48.050 --> 00:25:50.510
Now it's a little off then that,
it's 3.94, but

484
00:25:50.510 --> 00:25:52.425
you don't have to worry about that.

485
00:25:52.425 --> 00:25:55.000
In all the references that I've seen,
if you're not getting really,

486
00:25:55.000 --> 00:25:59.430
really specific on it,
no four gigabytes for the single lane.

487
00:25:59.430 --> 00:26:02.220
Multiply that, and
you know what, let me back up.

488
00:26:02.220 --> 00:26:03.430
It's actually a gigabyte.

489
00:26:03.430 --> 00:26:07.110
Because I said every one's a double,
and I'm gonna get my math wrong here.

490
00:26:07.110 --> 00:26:11.330
Again, the single lane
speed is a gigabyte.

491
00:26:11.330 --> 00:26:15.340
And then that means the four
lane is gonna be four gigabytes.

492
00:26:15.340 --> 00:26:18.395
Imagine what eight lane is gonna be,
eight gigabytes.

493
00:26:18.395 --> 00:26:21.131
And then the 16 lanes is
gonna be 16 gigabyte.

494
00:26:21.131 --> 00:26:26.091
So let me just recap the single lane
speeds for you guys one more time, so

495
00:26:26.091 --> 00:26:29.410
you guys can figure out
the other multipliers.

496
00:26:29.410 --> 00:26:33.220
Version 1.0 we've got 250
megabyte transfer speeds.

497
00:26:33.220 --> 00:26:37.320
Version 2.0 it doubles,
500 megabytes transfer speeds.

498
00:26:37.320 --> 00:26:38.908
Version 3.0, it doubles,

499
00:26:38.908 --> 00:26:43.400
yet again, we've got a gigabyte when it
comes to a single-lane transfer speed.

500
00:26:43.400 --> 00:26:45.097
>> I like that.
>> That makes it easy, and

501
00:26:45.097 --> 00:26:48.226
I can do that math, and
we can figure out if we've got four,

502
00:26:48.226 --> 00:26:50.380
as long as I know that single lane speed.

503
00:26:50.380 --> 00:26:53.390
Now, Wes, are there any other PCI
standards we need to be familiar with?

504
00:26:53.390 --> 00:26:55.310
>> You know?
There's one more that they call out, and

505
00:26:55.310 --> 00:26:58.230
it's kind of simplistic,
because it follows the same standards.

506
00:26:58.230 --> 00:27:02.185
It's called mini PCI, mini PCI is
what you would see inside a laptop.

507
00:27:02.185 --> 00:27:03.642
So as far as the standard goes,

508
00:27:03.642 --> 00:27:06.619
just know the PCI standards that
we've already talked about.

509
00:27:06.619 --> 00:27:09.206
However, there were three
different type cards, and

510
00:27:09.206 --> 00:27:11.748
these were really about
the connectors themselves.

511
00:27:11.748 --> 00:27:13.890
The standards the same,
so that's a great thing.

512
00:27:13.890 --> 00:27:17.325
You don't have to worry about it being
different than PCI all together.

513
00:27:17.325 --> 00:27:20.015
But we're talking about,
it's the same as the original PCI.

514
00:27:20.015 --> 00:27:23.740
They have a type 1 card,
which had 100 pin connector in it.

515
00:27:23.740 --> 00:27:27.930
A type 2 connector, or a type 2 card,
which, good thing here,

516
00:27:27.930 --> 00:27:29.232
also had a 100 pin connector.

517
00:27:29.232 --> 00:27:29.744
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

518
00:27:29.744 --> 00:27:31.424
>> And then they had a type three,

519
00:27:31.424 --> 00:27:33.684
that had slightly different connector,

520
00:27:33.684 --> 00:27:36.574
and that was a 124 pin connector.
And again, many PCI, as far

521
00:27:36.574 --> 00:27:40.044
as the standard goes, just a smaller form
factor that would be shoved inside of

522
00:27:40.044 --> 00:27:43.370
a laptop, because of the fact that we
don't have a lot of space within it.

523
00:27:43.370 --> 00:27:46.600
>> All right, Wes, so I'm gonna have
to ask the obvious question, type 1,

524
00:27:46.600 --> 00:27:50.669
100 pins, type 2, 100 pins, there has
to be a difference though, right?

525
00:27:50.669 --> 00:27:52.090
>> [LAUGH] There really is,

526
00:27:52.090 --> 00:27:56.930
what it came down to is what
the manufacturers implemented them for.

527
00:27:56.930 --> 00:27:59.030
The most common one was
really the type two,

528
00:27:59.030 --> 00:28:02.210
and this would add network functionality
to a laptop that didn't have it.

529
00:28:02.210 --> 00:28:06.190
So you'd put one of those type
2 cards in there, 100 pin card.

530
00:28:06.190 --> 00:28:08.540
And you'd have this little x
jack that would pop out, and

531
00:28:08.540 --> 00:28:11.260
you could put a modem-
>> I remember those, yes.

532
00:28:12.450 --> 00:28:16.810
>> RJ 11 jacks, or, as we progressed, you
could actually add Ethernet capabilities.

533
00:28:16.810 --> 00:28:20.010
Which we'll talk about
those PCI connections, or,

534
00:28:20.010 --> 00:28:23.010
excuse me, the Ethernet connections,
in another episode.

535
00:28:23.010 --> 00:28:27.000
The last one type three, which is
interesting, I've never actually seen one.

536
00:28:27.000 --> 00:28:30.220
And it was one that was actually used for
a hard drive.

537
00:28:30.220 --> 00:28:34.040
But for what ever reason, I've actually
never seen one of the type three cards.

538
00:28:34.040 --> 00:28:37.760
So type 2 was definitely one of the ones
that were more common until lake sorceress

539
00:28:37.760 --> 00:28:41.140
would come out, which we'll also talk
about later, known as the express card.

540
00:28:41.140 --> 00:28:43.640
>> All right, Wes,
just a ton of information there.

541
00:28:43.640 --> 00:28:47.555
In this particular episode, a lot of
information about the standards, and

542
00:28:47.555 --> 00:28:49.035
what we need to know to pass the exam.

543
00:28:49.035 --> 00:28:53.495
But over the last three episodes, we've
covered all the different components on

544
00:28:53.495 --> 00:28:55.415
that motherboard,
that we need to be familiar with.

545
00:28:55.415 --> 00:28:59.505
So we thank you for that, Wes, appreciate
it, any parting words for our viewers?

546
00:28:59.505 --> 00:29:02.545
>> No, just pay attention to your
standards, there's a reason we have them.

547
00:29:02.545 --> 00:29:06.555
And, as an A+ technician, it's gonna be up
to you to know what those standards are.

548
00:29:06.555 --> 00:29:08.250
>> All right,
well you heard it here folks.

549
00:29:08.250 --> 00:29:09.950
Hopefully you enjoyed watching this one.

550
00:29:09.950 --> 00:29:12.930
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host, Mike Rodrick.

551
00:29:12.930 --> 00:29:13.770
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

552
00:29:13.770 --> 00:29:15.905
>> And we'll see you next time.

553
00:29:15.905 --> 00:29:21.995
[MUSIC]

554
00:29:21.995 --> 00:29:25.097
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Wes and Zach compare and contrast various RAM types and their features, RAM vs. ROM defining what each are, ECC vs. non-ECC explaining what each are, Parity vs. non-Parity, what buffered & non-buffered mean, single channel vs. dual & triple channel, and RAM configurations.
episodes.title: RAM Types and Features
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:08.354
Welcome to ITProTV I am your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:08.354 --> 00:00:12.330
>> You are watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:12.330 --> 00:00:13.810
>> Hello again, and thank you for

4
00:00:13.810 --> 00:00:17.790
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:17.790 --> 00:00:22.590
I am your host Zach Memos as
we continue on with A+ 901.

6
00:00:22.590 --> 00:00:27.050
And today we're looking at RAM types and
features.

7
00:00:27.050 --> 00:00:29.780
And I know a guy who knows
more about this than me.

8
00:00:29.780 --> 00:00:31.900
And his name is Wes Bryan and
there he is right there.

9
00:00:31.900 --> 00:00:32.910
>> Hey, Zach, how you doing?

10
00:00:32.910 --> 00:00:33.660
It's great to be here.

11
00:00:33.660 --> 00:00:37.200
That's right, we're gonna be talking
about something I wish I had more of, and

12
00:00:37.200 --> 00:00:38.860
that is memory, right?

13
00:00:38.860 --> 00:00:41.220
You might be saying, well, you said RAM.

14
00:00:41.220 --> 00:00:43.050
Well, if you can't RAM it dodge it.

15
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:44.790
There's our little plug from Mopar for
the day.

16
00:00:44.790 --> 00:00:48.490
But we are gonna be talking about
something known as random access memory.

17
00:00:48.490 --> 00:00:52.970
And we're gonna go through
some of the objectives that

18
00:00:52.970 --> 00:00:57.570
you can expect to see within the 901 exam,
220-901 exam.

19
00:00:57.570 --> 00:01:00.870
I'll make sure I got the exam right there.

20
00:01:00.870 --> 00:01:04.330
But we're also gonna look at some of
the basics as well, maybe not some of

21
00:01:04.330 --> 00:01:07.130
the things that are specifically
called out by the objectives but

22
00:01:07.130 --> 00:01:10.310
we really want you to understand
this concept that we have of memory.

23
00:01:10.310 --> 00:01:14.420
So while the objectives are specifically
focused on random access memory,

24
00:01:14.420 --> 00:01:16.340
we're gonna talk about a few
different types of memory.

25
00:01:16.340 --> 00:01:19.240
So just as an A+ technician,
you'll be a little bit more

26
00:01:19.240 --> 00:01:21.670
aware of what you can expect
to see inside of the industry.

27
00:01:21.670 --> 00:01:26.010
Because when it comes to memory, there are
all different kinds, shapes and sizes and

28
00:01:26.010 --> 00:01:29.940
it's going to be important to be able
to distinguish them should you have to

29
00:01:29.940 --> 00:01:32.400
service a machine,
should you have to replace memory.

30
00:01:32.400 --> 00:01:35.510
So, lets go ahead and
we will dive right into that.

31
00:01:35.510 --> 00:01:38.160
>> Wes, what's volatile versus
nonvolatile, what is that?

32
00:01:38.160 --> 00:01:42.152
>> That's a great question, when it comes
to nonvolatile we have two, volatile or

33
00:01:42.152 --> 00:01:43.280
nonvolatile memory.

34
00:01:43.280 --> 00:01:47.376
We've got a little diagram here and
very kinda simplistic, all right?

35
00:01:47.376 --> 00:01:49.759
When we talk about random access memory.

36
00:01:49.759 --> 00:01:52.809
Random access memory is a type
of volatile memory, all right?

37
00:01:52.809 --> 00:01:55.387
And volatile memory
means that it needs and

38
00:01:55.387 --> 00:01:59.600
electrical current to keep the data
that's stored in it refreshed.

39
00:01:59.600 --> 00:02:04.000
And what I mean by that is any
of the data that the CPU is

40
00:02:04.000 --> 00:02:08.120
feeding into that memory
is going to dissipate.

41
00:02:08.120 --> 00:02:09.070
It's gonna disappear.

42
00:02:09.070 --> 00:02:13.200
So think about it as like an imprint and
then it starts to fade away.

43
00:02:13.200 --> 00:02:16.650
And then we hit it with a little bit of
electricity across the motherboard, and

44
00:02:16.650 --> 00:02:17.960
it refreshes that memory.

45
00:02:17.960 --> 00:02:20.453
And then it starts just a fade away.

46
00:02:20.453 --> 00:02:25.084
Now, the next type is non-volatile and
non-volatile memory is a type of

47
00:02:25.084 --> 00:02:29.490
memory that doesn't require
an electrical refresh, if you will, or

48
00:02:29.490 --> 00:02:33.466
electrical current to maintain
the data that's stored in it.

49
00:02:33.466 --> 00:02:41.070
Now, why we use one over the other, why is
system memory, today, RAM vs ROM, right?

50
00:02:41.070 --> 00:02:42.985
Well, it comes down to the sheer expense.

51
00:02:42.985 --> 00:02:46.860
Non-volatile memory is more expensive,

52
00:02:46.860 --> 00:02:49.480
especially more expensive
in larger quantities.

53
00:02:49.480 --> 00:02:54.080
And given today's RAM necessities,
or system memory necessities,

54
00:02:54.080 --> 00:02:58.930
it would be a little bit, for
as far as cost, it would be infeasible to

55
00:02:58.930 --> 00:03:04.040
have larger quantities of memory like
this for our average everyday computing.

56
00:03:04.040 --> 00:03:07.150
So when it comes down to it,
the RAM, if you will,

57
00:03:07.150 --> 00:03:10.590
the volatile memory is cheaper,
if you will.

58
00:03:10.590 --> 00:03:14.085
So we can get it in larger quantities and
it doesn't cost as much.

59
00:03:14.085 --> 00:03:18.180
Now, just when I say that, we have things
like our solid state drives out there.

60
00:03:18.180 --> 00:03:22.290
Solid state drives actually
use a non-volatile memory.

61
00:03:22.290 --> 00:03:24.020
That's why you can store information,

62
00:03:24.020 --> 00:03:26.480
just like the old traditional
mechanical hard drives, on it.

63
00:03:26.480 --> 00:03:30.150
Turn your computer off, and when you turn
your computer back on, well, guess what?

64
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:33.070
That data you can pull right
back off that solid state drive.

65
00:03:33.070 --> 00:03:35.590
You might have seen, too, if you've
been paying attention and if not,

66
00:03:35.590 --> 00:03:37.830
if you're new to this,
we'll kinda make you aware.

67
00:03:37.830 --> 00:03:41.630
That solid state drives,
up until recently, within the last five or

68
00:03:41.630 --> 00:03:45.770
six years, have been very,
very expensive per gigabyte.

69
00:03:45.770 --> 00:03:49.970
And that's due to the fact that they're
using non-volatile memory, again,

70
00:03:49.970 --> 00:03:54.010
we're starting to see that price
point come down as they find

71
00:03:54.010 --> 00:03:58.240
better ways to make it more cost
efficient, to make a larger capacities.

72
00:03:58.240 --> 00:04:01.790
But when you really look at it,
those are the two different things.

73
00:04:01.790 --> 00:04:07.790
Now, you might notice that here in my
diagram, I said RAM, random access memory.

74
00:04:07.790 --> 00:04:11.140
The forms of non-volatile
you'll see is ROM.

75
00:04:11.140 --> 00:04:16.760
That's, read-only memory,
is an example of that, right?

76
00:04:16.760 --> 00:04:19.260
So keep that in mind for your exam.

77
00:04:19.260 --> 00:04:21.780
>> Can you have RAM and
ROM in the same system?

78
00:04:21.780 --> 00:04:22.430
>> You typically do.

79
00:04:22.430 --> 00:04:26.280
And let me give you a basics here, and
we'll definitely come back to some of

80
00:04:26.280 --> 00:04:28.180
the ROMs, too,
towards the end of this episode.

81
00:04:28.180 --> 00:04:30.160
Even though it's not called
out on the objectives,

82
00:04:30.160 --> 00:04:32.400
we really want you to know
what's going on here.

83
00:04:32.400 --> 00:04:34.490
You typically have your
random access memory,

84
00:04:34.490 --> 00:04:36.200
is gonna be inside of your system memory,
right?

85
00:04:36.200 --> 00:04:40.530
That's that main memory, you might hear
it called, and a large quantity of it.

86
00:04:40.530 --> 00:04:45.090
You can replace that RAM,
if you will, through memory

87
00:04:45.090 --> 00:04:49.140
modules on the motherboard itself,
if you remember our motherboard episode.

88
00:04:49.140 --> 00:04:52.200
ROM, you have, that's where we
store our BIOS information.

89
00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:55.490
Remember, that in our BIOS episode, one
of the things we said is that we have our

90
00:04:55.490 --> 00:04:59.940
BIOS and that contains
the manufacturer's defined settings for

91
00:04:59.940 --> 00:05:02.350
basically bringing the hardware online,
right?

92
00:05:02.350 --> 00:05:05.950
Well, why is it that I can
turn my computer off, and

93
00:05:05.950 --> 00:05:10.440
when I turn my computer on, I can boot
into BIOS, and all the interface and

94
00:05:10.440 --> 00:05:13.340
everything, all the capabilities
are still there?

95
00:05:13.340 --> 00:05:17.580
Well, that's because that BIOS
information is stored in a ROM chip.

96
00:05:17.580 --> 00:05:20.720
And again, it's a non-volatile chip.

97
00:05:20.720 --> 00:05:23.940
So two very, very important concepts.

98
00:05:23.940 --> 00:05:25.295
>> I knew that I was just testing you.

99
00:05:25.295 --> 00:05:28.580
[LAUGH] But actually,
what I wanted to move on to is parity.

100
00:05:28.580 --> 00:05:31.016
Parity, I've heard that's about errors,
is that right?

101
00:05:31.016 --> 00:05:32.320
>> That is right, okay, and

102
00:05:32.320 --> 00:05:36.142
there are a couple different kinds
of parity types, if you will.

103
00:05:36.142 --> 00:05:40.490
Actually, there's parity and think of it
as more of an advanced parity, right?

104
00:05:40.490 --> 00:05:45.160
Parity is all about checking errors and
what it essentially means is that what we

105
00:05:45.160 --> 00:05:52.070
do is when you write data into memory,
you typically do it by basis.

106
00:05:52.070 --> 00:05:55.340
And what parity does is
it allows you to check

107
00:05:55.340 --> 00:05:57.460
whether there is an error
present in the data.

108
00:05:57.460 --> 00:06:00.530
In fact I've got a little diagram here,
let me show you here.

109
00:06:00.530 --> 00:06:03.850
We have what's known as even parity or
odd parity.

110
00:06:03.850 --> 00:06:06.700
Now very basically, guys,
take all the technical jargons out of it.

111
00:06:06.700 --> 00:06:09.388
What does it mean to be even parity or
odd parity?

112
00:06:09.388 --> 00:06:12.550
All right, well, it means that
all of the data that is sent into

113
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:16.590
RAM is going to be checked and
through a little manipulation of the data,

114
00:06:16.590 --> 00:06:21.140
we should always expect even values or
odd values, right?

115
00:06:21.140 --> 00:06:24.050
Le's just say that we expect even values.

116
00:06:24.050 --> 00:06:26.530
And, by the way, your even or odd parity

117
00:06:26.530 --> 00:06:30.620
is set at the time before you actually
start to even write information, right?

118
00:06:30.620 --> 00:06:32.780
So we don't pick and
choose on the fly, right?

119
00:06:32.780 --> 00:06:34.660
We say, okay, it's gonna be even parity.

120
00:06:34.660 --> 00:06:37.500
Then the components in the design
of the memory itself says,

121
00:06:37.500 --> 00:06:40.790
okay, at right time, we're gonna
set that it's gonna be even parity.

122
00:06:40.790 --> 00:06:43.500
You don't actually set this,
it's built into the design itself.

123
00:06:43.500 --> 00:06:47.980
Now what it does is it says for every byte
of data, we're gonna count things like,

124
00:06:47.980 --> 00:06:49.570
for instance, the one bit.

125
00:06:49.570 --> 00:06:52.963
So, for instance, in my example here you
can see that I have a byte of data and

126
00:06:52.963 --> 00:06:54.246
if I count the ones, right?

127
00:06:54.246 --> 00:06:56.074
I've got three ones, right?

128
00:06:56.074 --> 00:07:01.137
Well, we said we expected every time
we send that information into RAM,

129
00:07:01.137 --> 00:07:03.190
we expect an even value.

130
00:07:03.190 --> 00:07:07.460
So what parity does,
is it adds a ninth bit.

131
00:07:07.460 --> 00:07:10.860
So if 8 bits makes a byte, right?

132
00:07:10.860 --> 00:07:13.380
So if I'm gonna send a byte
of data into memory, and

133
00:07:13.380 --> 00:07:18.540
in my example,
that byte of data is an odd value.

134
00:07:18.540 --> 00:07:19.760
Well, we're gonna modify it.

135
00:07:19.760 --> 00:07:22.510
We're gonna add one extra bit, and
now you count them all up, they're even.

136
00:07:22.510 --> 00:07:25.120
And we're gonna send it into RAM.

137
00:07:25.120 --> 00:07:29.610
Then the RAM will be checked and
if the value is even it means that, well,

138
00:07:29.610 --> 00:07:33.320
passively we've detected that nothing's
really changed with the data and

139
00:07:33.320 --> 00:07:34.440
it's valid.

140
00:07:34.440 --> 00:07:38.750
However, if we send that information,
again, I've already denoted that it's

141
00:07:38.750 --> 00:07:42.760
even parity, we add the parity bit,
in this case to make it even.

142
00:07:42.760 --> 00:07:47.688
We send it into the RAM and
the memory controller checks it and

143

all of a quad channel board,

366
00:19:45.255 --> 00:19:49.959
but later on down the road you might say
now I wanna add those other four modules.

367
00:19:49.959 --> 00:19:54.570
And that's why it's important to make sure
that if you're gonna populate every single

368
00:19:54.570 --> 00:19:56.387
RAM slot, don't worry about it.

369
00:19:56.387 --> 00:20:00.155
You populated the whole thing,
you're using all the channels.

370
00:20:00.155 --> 00:20:03.781
But if you're not, if you aren't
gonna populate all of the channels,

371
00:20:03.781 --> 00:20:08.072
pay attention to the RAM configuration cuz
you can actually do yourself a disservice

372
00:20:08.072 --> 00:20:11.578
by having nice fast memory and
you installed it in a single channel and

373
00:20:11.578 --> 00:20:13.227
you never see the performance.

374
00:20:13.227 --> 00:20:16.228
So that is something that
is gonna be important.

375
00:20:16.228 --> 00:20:18.723
>> What about single sided, double sided?

376
00:20:18.723 --> 00:20:21.662
Is that inferring like a record?

377
00:20:21.662 --> 00:20:24.774
The old LP had two sides and
even the tape.

378
00:20:24.774 --> 00:20:27.271
You'd actually flip tapes around,
especially reel of reels.

379
00:20:27.271 --> 00:20:28.680
>> You know when I first.

380
00:20:28.680 --> 00:20:30.504
[LAUGH] That's a great question.

381
00:20:30.504 --> 00:20:34.240
And you guys might think that it's a joke,
but it really isn't.

382
00:20:34.240 --> 00:20:37.899
But when I first started studying A+,
way back when I first took my A+ exam,

383
00:20:37.899 --> 00:20:39.489
that's exactly what I thought.

384
00:20:39.489 --> 00:20:40.400
What does this mean?

385
00:20:40.400 --> 00:20:44.195
Does this mean that like dvds, tapes,
tape cassettes, record players,

386
00:20:44.195 --> 00:20:46.076
you're gonna flip and turn it over.

387
00:20:46.076 --> 00:20:47.042
It's not like that.

388
00:20:47.042 --> 00:20:48.496
It's not what it means, all right?

389
00:20:48.496 --> 00:20:52.918
What it means is that the electrical
contacts on the RAM module itself,

390
00:20:52.918 --> 00:20:55.655
you got electrical contacts on both sides.

391
00:20:55.655 --> 00:21:00.014
And essentially, I could show you here
where the contacts are on both sides.

392
00:21:00.014 --> 00:21:02.832
Now, when it comes down to it,
what does that mean for performance?

393
00:21:02.832 --> 00:21:06.793
Well, It really doesn't make
too much of a difference.

394
00:21:06.793 --> 00:21:11.850
It just means how much of the memory in
totality can the memory controller see,

395
00:21:11.850 --> 00:21:12.624
all right?

396
00:21:12.624 --> 00:21:13.847
If it's single sided,

397
00:21:13.847 --> 00:21:17.037
it means it could use and
address all of the memory at one time.

398
00:21:17.037 --> 00:21:19.770
It doesn't matter how much memory
you have, it could see all of it and

399
00:21:19.770 --> 00:21:20.962
address all of it at one time.

400
00:21:20.962 --> 00:21:25.586
If it's double sided memory, what it means
is that it's separated into memory banks.

401
00:21:25.586 --> 00:21:29.195
And memory bank must be initiated to
switch over to the second bank then

402
00:21:29.195 --> 00:21:31.903
to further address the memory and
send data into it.

403
00:21:31.903 --> 00:21:33.546
But as far as the performance hit is,

404
00:21:33.546 --> 00:21:36.196
it's not really something
you're gonna notice too much.

405
00:21:36.196 --> 00:21:42.811
Now there's always speculation on that,
and we can go down the route of memory,

406
00:21:42.811 --> 00:21:47.010
I don't know,
there are some speculations on it.

407
00:21:47.010 --> 00:21:50.619
But what it really boils down to is when
we say single sided and double sided, it

408
00:21:50.619 --> 00:21:54.300
means how much of the memory is accessible
by the memory controller at one time.

409
00:21:54.300 --> 00:21:57.391
Single sided means it can see the whole
thing, address the whole thing.

410
00:21:57.391 --> 00:22:00.729
When it comes to double-sided,
it means it's seen in rows and banks and

411
00:22:00.729 --> 00:22:04.298
their bank has to be initiated between
each of the sides of the memory module.

412
00:22:04.298 --> 00:22:07.345
>> Perfect,
now we've been talking a lot about theory.

413
00:22:07.345 --> 00:22:10.085
But are we gonna be getting
into specifications, Wes?

414
00:22:10.085 --> 00:22:14.017
>> Absolutely,
A+ wouldn't be A+ without some standards.

415
00:22:14.017 --> 00:22:17.059
See we want you to kinda
understand the concepts, guys and

416
00:22:17.059 --> 00:22:21.361
gals out there before we just bombard you
with specifications that a lot of times.

417
00:22:21.361 --> 00:22:25.286
Don't be intimidated by it, but sometimes
for the A+ exam, you have to prove that

418
00:22:25.286 --> 00:22:29.061
you understand the lingo, you have to
prove that you know the specifications.

419
00:22:29.061 --> 00:22:33.010
And a lot of times they're really
important on the exam to understand these,

420
00:22:33.010 --> 00:22:35.637
but it's also important
to understand concepts.

421
00:22:35.637 --> 00:22:38.976
So yeah, we do have to go in the
specification but Zack's giving me that

422
00:22:38.976 --> 00:22:42.160
evil eye over there and I know that
we are coming up on some time here.

423
00:22:42.160 --> 00:22:44.944
So let me go ahead and
tackle a couple of concepts there and

424
00:22:44.944 --> 00:22:47.910
we'll probably have to leave
them with a cliff hanger here.

425
00:22:47.910 --> 00:22:53.070
They call out what is known as
a buffered and unbuffered memory.

426
00:22:53.070 --> 00:22:56.563
All right, now buffered and
unbuffered have,

427
00:22:56.563 --> 00:23:01.283
sometimes they're confusing
because you learn one concept and

428
00:23:01.283 --> 00:23:05.579
then you learn it has 15
different synonyms if you will.

429
00:23:05.579 --> 00:23:07.729
So let me just see if I can
help you out with this.

430
00:23:07.729 --> 00:23:12.710
You might hear buffered and unbuffered,
but you also might hear registered and

431
00:23:12.710 --> 00:23:13.761
unregistered.

432
00:23:13.761 --> 00:23:15.075
They're the same, they're synonymous.

433
00:23:15.075 --> 00:23:16.251
Don't let that confuse you.

434
00:23:16.251 --> 00:23:19.366
So in the context here, you're gonna
hear me use them interchangeably.

435
00:23:19.366 --> 00:23:22.344
So that when you go out there and
study them, you'll know that you're not

436
00:23:22.344 --> 00:23:25.274
losing your mind trying to find out
what's going on when somebody says,

437
00:23:25.274 --> 00:23:28.033
I'm not talking about buffered,
I'm talking about registered.

438
00:23:28.033 --> 00:23:32.659
All right, so here we go with buffered,
also known as registered, all right?

439
00:23:32.659 --> 00:23:34.656
We talked about ECC memory, right?

440
00:23:34.656 --> 00:23:40.638
ECC memory, a lot of times,
is registered memory or buffered memory.

441
00:23:40.638 --> 00:23:44.966
Again, I'm gonna probably do you guys
some injustice out here, all right?

442
00:23:44.966 --> 00:23:49.613
Buffered memory just basically means
that it has a register that sits between

443
00:23:49.613 --> 00:23:54.342
the memory controller that accesses RAM,
and the module itself, all right?

444
00:23:54.342 --> 00:23:55.915
So what does that module do?

445
00:23:55.915 --> 00:23:58.735
Well, first of all, that register,
right, in the buffered memory,

446
00:23:58.735 --> 00:24:00.980
that's why ithey call
it registered memory.

447
00:24:00.980 --> 00:24:03.560
What it does is that it ensures that it

448
00:24:04.720 --> 00:24:08.000
basically it lessens
the electrical load on the memory.

449
00:24:08.000 --> 00:24:09.930
And any time you reduce
the electrical load,

450
00:24:09.930 --> 00:24:11.670
there's a couple of things that happen.

451
00:24:11.670 --> 00:24:14.550
You will reduce a little bit of
latency you'll introduce and

452
00:24:14.550 --> 00:24:17.630
you'll reduce a little bit of
the performance speeds that you'll get but

453
00:24:17.630 --> 00:24:20.470
you increase stability
reliability of the data.

454
00:24:20.470 --> 00:24:25.520
Which means that the data's
gonna be more expensive,

455
00:24:25.520 --> 00:24:28.780
but again,
it's gonna be more reliable, right?

456
00:24:28.780 --> 00:24:30.560
More resistant to corruption.

457
00:24:30.560 --> 00:24:32.650
And that's one of the great
things about registered memory,

458
00:24:32.650 --> 00:24:34.450
or buffered memory if you will.

459
00:24:35.550 --> 00:24:38.933
Most of your ECC memory is
going to be a buffered memory.

460
00:24:38.933 --> 00:24:42.050
And it's just that register that sits in
between the controller and the memory, and

461
00:24:42.050 --> 00:24:46.450
it helps to, basically lessen the
electrical load on the memory itself and

462
00:24:46.450 --> 00:24:51.190
provides you with some stability and the
reliability, if you will, of your data.

463
00:24:51.190 --> 00:24:55.050
Now unbuffered memory is what we
find in our non ECC memory, right?

464
00:24:55.050 --> 00:24:58.410
This is the most common conventional
memory that's out there that's in

465
00:24:58.410 --> 00:25:00.810
our laptops here, Zack and my laptops.

466
00:25:00.810 --> 00:25:04.310
Probably if you're at a laptop if
you will, or even a mobile device,

467
00:25:04.310 --> 00:25:06.590
you hear Zack say that
learning wherever you go.

468
00:25:06.590 --> 00:25:09.850
I mean you talk about your phone,
you talk about your tablets,

469
00:25:09.850 --> 00:25:12.330
they're unbuffered memory, unregistered.

470
00:25:12.330 --> 00:25:15.980
Well, just remember register lack thereof,
right?

471
00:25:15.980 --> 00:25:18.840
that's why it's called unregistered or
that's why it's called unbuffered.

472
00:25:18.840 --> 00:25:20.770
Now, what's the benefit?

473
00:25:20.770 --> 00:25:23.755
Well the benefit is it's less expensive
and that's always good especially if

474
00:25:23.755 --> 00:25:27.460
you're frugal like I am,
you know that it's less expensive.

475
00:25:27.460 --> 00:25:29.860
But the other thing is it

00:25:29.860 --> 00:25:31.970
Remember, when we talk

477
00:25:31.970 --> 00:25:36.090
work stations what we mean is we
don't need the expensive memory,

if you're gonna throw some expense at
your memory just get more of it, right?

479
00:25:39.455 --> 00:25:42.570
Cuz I don't worry about
the corruption of the information.

480
00:25:42.570 --> 00:25:45.320
Now that doesn't mean at the home
environment we don't care if your

481
00:25:45.320 --> 00:25:46.040
data corrupts.

482
00:25:46.040 --> 00:25:47.660
I mean obviously you do to a point but

483
00:25:47.660 --> 00:25:49.760
it's not mission critical
like it is in corporation.

484
00:25:49.760 --> 00:25:55.902
So an unbuffered or unregistered memory
module has direct memory access,

485
00:25:55.902 --> 00:25:59.805
I don't have middle man to go through,
right?

486
00:25:59.805 --> 00:26:01.126
If you will, pardon the pun here but

487
00:26:01.126 --> 00:26:02.946
I don't have a middle man to go through,
right?

488
00:26:02.946 --> 00:26:06.815
The memory controller talks to the
register, talks to the memory control or

489
00:26:06.815 --> 00:26:09.910
the memory itself inside of registered or
buffered memory.

490
00:26:11.030 --> 00:26:15.390
Unbuffered, if you will, or non registered
memory takes that whole thing out,

491
00:26:15.390 --> 00:26:17.620
lowers the price,
increases the performance.

492
00:26:17.620 --> 00:26:20.970
But anytime we talk about not
having that register in there,

493
00:26:20.970 --> 00:26:23.740
we also talk about you don't
have a stable memory and

494
00:26:23.740 --> 00:26:28.530
the memory itself might not be, it isn't
as reliable as the buffered memory.

495
00:26:28.530 --> 00:26:29.680
So keep those in mind,

496
00:26:29.680 --> 00:26:33.600
those are a couple of concepts that
you need to know for the exam.

But like I said,
Zack's giving that look and

Now, first of all, I got a little

00:24:15.322 --> 00:24:18.650
Read-only memory, right.

It's non-volatile, and

00:24:25.840 --> 00:24:29.250
In the old days, sometimes you could

00:24:29.250 --> 00:24:32.680
And some, this is going way back,

00:24:32.680 --> 00:24:35.090
But notice that these chips
are soldered into the motherboard and

00:24:35.090 --> 00:24:37.210
that's typically what they are today.

465
00:24:37.210 --> 00:24:40.030
However, ROM,
we have a few different kinds.

00:24:40.030 --> 00:24:42.250
We have what's known as the oldest kind,

467
00:24:42.250 --> 00:24:44.820
which was known as
programmable read-only memory.

468
00:24:44.820 --> 00:24:48.480
We have electrically, no,
I'm sorry, we have EPROM.

469
00:24:48.480 --> 00:24:51.660
EPROM was erasable
programmable read-only memory.

470
00:24:51.660 --> 00:24:53.380
And what we use today is EEPROM.

471
00:24:53.380 --> 00:24:57.260
That's electrically erasable
programmable read-only memory.

472
00:24:57.260 --> 00:24:59.120
Boy, a whole bunch of jargon,
what does that mean?

473
00:24:59.120 --> 00:25:00.450
All right, well, in the earlier days,

474
00:25:00.450 --> 00:25:02.710
remember what we said that
BIOS memory does, right?

475
00:25:02.710 --> 00:25:05.730
In that ROM chip, it retains
the manufacturer's defined settings for

476
00:25:05.730 --> 00:25:07.580

477
00:25:07.580 --> 00:25:11.440
You customize your settings and those
customized settings are stored in CMOS,

478
00:25:11.440 --> 00:25:13.760
which we have a little
battery that refreshes.

479
00:25:13.760 --> 00:25:16.766
Now, in those earlier days,
those PROM chips would come in and

480
00:25:16.766 --> 00:25:19.046
you couldn't do any programming,
all right?

481
00:25:19.046 --> 00:25:23.135
You couldn't do any programming because,
the way that they would program them,

482
00:25:23.135 --> 00:25:26.572
binary ones and zeros,
everything's ones and zeros in computing,

483
00:25:26.572 --> 00:25:30.150
is essentially what they do is
they burn a diode out, right?

484
00:25:30.150 --> 00:25:32.400
And they'd leave a diode, burn a diode,
and it would forms the ones and zeros.

485
00:25:32.400 --> 00:25:36.500
But it's kind of like, say I've got
a series of light bulbs, right?

486
00:25:36.500 --> 00:25:38.600
If I look at the light bulbs and
they're on, off, on and off,

487
00:25:38.600 --> 00:25:40.720
don't worry about the fact
that they're off.

488
00:25:40.720 --> 00:25:42.930
I break the light bulb, that's off, right.

489
00:25:42.930 --> 00:25:44.360
But I can't replace it.

490
00:25:44.360 --> 00:25:47.940
So they were programmable
once by the manufacturer.

491
00:25:47.940 --> 00:25:51.330
Well, what happens if you
needed an update, right.

492
00:25:51.330 --> 00:25:52.300
Well if you needed an update,

493
00:25:52.300 --> 00:25:54.830
a lot of times you'd have to send
it back to the manufacturer.

494
00:25:54.830 --> 00:26:01.190
And they could program it or you could
potentially just upgrade your motherboard.

495
00:26:01.190 --> 00:26:04.970
Down the way they found out that,
hey, how about we

496
00:26:04.970 --> 00:26:10.290
use ROM chips that
are sensitive to a UV light?

497
00:26:10.290 --> 00:26:13.510
And really what happened was it's
called the floating gate transistor.

498
00:26:13.510 --> 00:26:14.664
And don't even worry [LAUGH]
too much about this.

499
00:26:14.664 --> 00:26:15.706
>> [LAUGH]
>> It just means

500
00:26:15.706 --> 00:26:20.208
that we have a transistor that can move up
and down and it's reactive to UV light.

501
00:26:20.208 --> 00:26:24.372
So the erasable programmable read-only
memory chips were the ones that you could

502
00:26:24.372 --> 00:26:27.520
actually flash with a UV light
that have a little lens in them.

503
00:26:27.520 --> 00:26:30.330
And it would reset the ROM,
and it could be reprogrammed.

504
00:26:30.330 --> 00:26:33.460
That's why it's called erasable
programmable read-only memory.

505
00:26:33.460 --> 00:26:35.210
But even that wasn't efficient.

506
00:26:35.210 --> 00:26:39.950
And what we do today when we do firmware
updates, we call it flashing the BIOS.

507
00:26:39.950 --> 00:26:41.740
Why do we call it flashing the BIOS?

508
00:26:41.740 --> 00:26:44.750
Well, it kinda emanates from
that flashing the UV light.

509
00:26:44.750 --> 00:26:45.940
But the difference is,

510
00:26:45.940 --> 00:26:50.510
those floating gate transistors today
are reactive to electrical current.

511
00:26:50.510 --> 00:26:53.300
So rather than have to
flash them with a UV light,

512
00:26:53.300 --> 00:26:55.490
you can send an electrical current
on a trace on the motherboard,

513
00:26:55.490 --> 00:26:58.870
right across the motherboard,
and it programs it.

514
00:26:58.870 --> 00:27:02.010
And we don't have to remove our chips,
we don't have to worry about that.

515
00:27:02.010 --> 00:27:05.450
And I do want to make mention
that be careful, all right?

516
00:27:05.450 --> 00:27:08.712
Any time you upgrade BIOS,
you'll hear firmware updates, right?

517
00:27:08.712 --> 00:27:12.380
This is the flashing of that ROM chip.

518
00:27:12.380 --> 00:27:15.969
If you interrupt that
flashing of that memory,

519
00:27:15.969 --> 00:27:19.926
you might permanently ruin the device,
all right?

520
00:27:19.926 --> 00:27:23.020
So don't flash your BIOS, if you will.

521
00:27:23.020 --> 00:27:26.025
Don't reprogram with a firmware
update during things like

522
00:27:26.025 --> 00:27:28.010
a potential of an electrical storm.

523
00:27:28.010 --> 00:27:33.280
When your power supply isn't
plugged into the wall on a laptop.

524
00:27:33.280 --> 00:27:37.350
When you run the risk of losing power or
interrupting that process.

525
00:27:37.350 --> 00:27:40.380
That is something that is very,
very important.
