right?

533
00:27:56.868 --> 00:27:58.749
Let's get the pessimistic side out first.

534
00:27:58.749 --> 00:28:02.813
ECC memory and non-ECC memory,
like we talked about in the first episode,

535
00:28:02.813 --> 00:28:04.220
cannot be mixed, right?

536
00:28:04.220 --> 00:28:08.040
If you have an ECC motherboard that
recognizes error correcting code,

537
00:28:08.040 --> 00:28:09.945
it's going to have to have ECC memory.

538
00:28:09.945 --> 00:28:15.230
Non-ECC memory boards, expect to have
non-error correcting code memory.

539
00:28:15.230 --> 00:28:17.360
You cannot mix and match in these boards.

540
00:28:17.360 --> 00:28:19.596
So that's the no part.

541
00:28:19.596 --> 00:28:20.740
Standards, all right?

542
00:28:20.740 --> 00:28:26.640
DDR3 doesn't fit in a DDR2 board versus
the legacy DDR all the way back.

543
00:28:26.640 --> 00:28:28.940
Notches are in a different position,
different pin outages.

544
00:28:28.940 --> 00:28:31.430
I don't even care if you're
talking about DDR2 and DDR3,

545
00:28:31.430 --> 00:28:34.400
which both have 240 pins, all right?

546
00:28:34.400 --> 00:28:37.660
So that's the ugly, the bad and
the ugly, if you will.

547
00:28:37.660 --> 00:28:39.010
Let's get back to the good.

548
00:28:39.010 --> 00:28:40.930
Good is if you have a matching standard,
right?

549
00:28:40.930 --> 00:28:42.001
I have DDR3 memory.

550
00:28:42.001 --> 00:28:45.715
Let's say I have 1066 memory in there,
right, DDR3 1066.

551
00:28:45.715 --> 00:28:52.720
And I say, you know what, my friend just
gave me this good DDR3 2133 memory, right?

552
00:28:52.720 --> 00:28:59.560
Little bit higher of a megahertz,
a little bit faster.

553
00:28:59.560 --> 00:29:01.260
Yes, you can put that in the motherboard.

554
00:29:01.260 --> 00:29:02.160
You can mix and match.

555
00:29:02.160 --> 00:29:02.800
>> Wow.

556
00:29:02.800 --> 00:29:03.904
>> But there's a performance cost, right?

557
00:29:03.904 --> 00:29:07.252
There's always a pro and a con.

558
00:29:07.252 --> 00:29:10.170
The pro is that, hey,
I can populate and have more memory.

559
00:29:10.170 --> 00:29:15.610
The problem is that 2133 megahertz memory
is gonna run at the 1066 speed, okay?

560
00:29:15.610 --> 00:29:21.450
So it's like saying, okay, well, I have,
let's go the side of the tracks, right?

561
00:29:21.450 --> 00:29:25.997
Let's say we have three modules
that are 2133 megahertz,

562
00:29:25.997 --> 00:29:30.729
speed-wise, bus speed, and
we put a 1066 module in there.

563
00:29:30.729 --> 00:29:36.502
Now, every one of your 2133 modules have
now reverted back to the slowest speed,

564
00:29:36.502 --> 00:29:39.400
the bottleneck, so don't mix and match.

565
00:29:39.400 --> 00:29:41.690
Now, mix and match vendors if you want.

566
00:29:41.690 --> 00:29:44.980
If you like Kingston, you like Crucial,
you like Corsair, that's fine.

567
00:29:44.980 --> 00:29:47.803
You can mix and match vendors as long as
it's the same standard and same speed and

568
00:29:47.803 --> 00:29:49.039
you don't get a performance hit.

569
00:29:50.150 --> 00:29:52.700
When you talk about warranties,
though, you might have the blame game.

570
00:29:52.700 --> 00:29:55.252
Now that was their memory that caused
the problem, it wasn't our memory so.

571
00:29:55.252 --> 00:29:57.497
>> Yes.
>> When you're talking about warranty, or

572
00:29:57.497 --> 00:30:00.982
you're talking about sending
memory back to the manufacturer,

573
00:30:00.982 --> 00:30:04.484
that might cause a problem when
you mix and match manufacturers.

574
00:30:04.484 --> 00:30:07.940
But as long as you don't mix and match
speeds, they'll all run at the same speed.

575
00:30:07.940 --> 00:30:12.680
Again, you put a slower RAM module
in with a faster RAM module and

576
00:30:12.680 --> 00:30:15.000
everything is gonna bottleneck
to the slowest speed.

577
00:30:15.000 --> 00:30:18.522
So just like anything else in computing,
there's gonna pros and cons.

578
00:30:18.522 --> 00:30:21.980
Just make sure you pay attention to
the specifications of the motherboard, and

579
00:30:21.980 --> 00:30:24.524
the specifications of the memory
that you put in that motherboard.

580
00:30:24.524 --> 00:30:27.200
>> RAM types and features,
part two, excellent job, Wes.

581
00:30:27.200 --> 00:30:28.050
There is a part one.

582
00:30:28.050 --> 00:30:32.220
You can watch them as many times
as you want because it's on video,

583
00:30:32.220 --> 00:30:33.940
as we continue on with A+ 901.

584
00:30:33.940 --> 00:30:36.134
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

585
00:30:36.134 --> 00:30:38.860
Remember, a good IT Pro
is always learning.

586
00:30:38.860 --> 00:30:39.745
I am Zach Memos.

587
00:30:39.745 --> 00:30:41.705
>> And I'm Wes Bryan
>> We'll see you soon.

588
00:30:41.705 --> 00:30:48.800
[MUSIC]

589
00:30:48.800 --> 00:30:51.544
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Wes and Zach discuss what Expansion Cards are, where to install cards, integrated vs. non-integrated,  how to choose the correct cards for your device, sound & video cards, network cards, Firewire cards, what Thunderbolt cards are, storage cards, adding additional USB ports, USB-Type-A & USB-Type-C, what Riser Cards are, TV Tuner cards, Modem cards, Drivers, Motherboard considerations, case-tower considerations, and power supply considerations.
episodes.title: PC Expansion Cards
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.190 --> 00:00:05.133
Welcome to IT Pro TV,

2
00:00:05.133 --> 00:00:11.834
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

3
00:00:11.834 --> 00:00:14.741
>> Hello again, and
thank you for choosing IT Pro TV,

4
00:00:14.741 --> 00:00:16.778
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:16.778 --> 00:00:21.226
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with A+901, and

6
00:00:21.226 --> 00:00:24.340
right now we're looking
at expansion cards.

7
00:00:24.340 --> 00:00:27.410
What are expansion cards, and who's gonna
bring us that information but Wes Bryan,

8
00:00:27.410 --> 00:00:28.010
hey Wes.

9
00:00:28.010 --> 00:00:28.526
>> Hey there, sir.

10
00:00:28.526 --> 00:00:29.180
>> Hello, how are you?

11
00:00:29.180 --> 00:00:34.188
>> That's right, we're gonna be looking at
PC expansion cards, and these are, it's

12
00:00:34.188 --> 00:00:38.800
a good functionality, it's a good thing to
have inside of your computing environment.

13
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:41.410
So let's go ahead and
let's kinda just define,

14
00:00:41.410 --> 00:00:45.270
basically what an expansion
card really is, right?

15
00:00:45.270 --> 00:00:46.810
Well one of the things,

16
00:00:46.810 --> 00:00:51.240
if we take the expansion card,
we just put that on hold for a second.

17
00:00:51.240 --> 00:00:55.330
One of the great things about
motherboards, the way they're manufactured

18
00:00:55.330 --> 00:01:00.320
today is manufacturers, they vary the
price point of their computers that they

19
00:01:00.320 --> 00:01:03.160
deliver to you based on the level
of functionality that you need.

20
00:01:03.160 --> 00:01:06.840
All right, so if you're one that's maybe
sitting at home, and you just need to send

21
00:01:06.840 --> 00:01:10.490
an email, maybe browse the web once in
a while, maybe check into your Facebook,

22
00:01:10.490 --> 00:01:14.070
well do you really need that
$5,000- $8,000 gaming rig?

23
00:01:14.070 --> 00:01:17.050
>> Yes.
>> Well, Zach would say yes, sure, and

24
00:01:17.050 --> 00:01:19.390
many of you might even say,
well absolutely I need that,

25
00:01:19.390 --> 00:01:22.120
I need to be able to send
those emails very, very fast.

26
00:01:22.120 --> 00:01:28.100
Well, if you think about it, well for some
people a $300 computer might be feasible.

27
00:01:28.100 --> 00:01:33.190
However, what happens if you decide that
you need a little bit more functionality?

28
00:01:33.190 --> 00:01:37.680
Well, if you didn't have expansion cards,
you're gonna have to turn around, and

29
00:01:37.680 --> 00:01:40.780
you'd have to go out and
you'd have to buy a whole new computer.

30
00:01:40.780 --> 00:01:43.920
Or, based on your motherboard,
you might have to do that anyways, right?

31
00:01:43.920 --> 00:01:48.005
So, an expansion card, what it allows
you to do and the reason they call it

32
00:01:48.005 --> 00:01:51.180
an expansion card, it doesn't
stretch the computer out any more.

33
00:01:51.180 --> 00:01:54.820
It's not the blue handle
motherboard stretcher right next

34
00:01:54.820 --> 00:01:55.750
to the sky hook, right?

35
00:01:55.750 --> 00:01:59.890
This is essentially a way to
expand the functionality, and

36
00:01:59.890 --> 00:02:04.585
we do that by inserting different types
of cards into slots on the motherboard.

37
00:02:04.585 --> 00:02:06.145
In fact, we've got a motherboard here,
right here.

38
00:02:06.145 --> 00:02:08.105
And I can kind of show you that, right?

39
00:02:08.105 --> 00:02:12.145
You can see that there are some
unpopulated slots on this motherboard.

40
00:02:12.145 --> 00:02:14.405
Again, remember the jargon
I'm feeding you guys here.

41
00:02:14.405 --> 00:02:18.130
When I say unpopulated, it just means that
there isn't anything installed, right?

42
00:02:18.130 --> 00:02:21.270
You could say that these memory
modules are populating the RAM slots

43
00:02:21.270 --> 00:02:23.630
because they're there,
present and installed.

44
00:02:23.630 --> 00:02:28.410
But the great thing about this is,
this is a relatively low-end computer.

45
00:02:28.410 --> 00:02:30.990
And you didn't have to pay
a lot of money for it, because,

46
00:02:30.990 --> 00:02:32.450
if you needed basic functionality,

47
00:02:32.450 --> 00:02:36.800
well, this gives you everything you
need without some of the extras.

48
00:02:36.800 --> 00:02:41.770
However, if you want some of the extras,
maybe later down the road, you can always

49
00:02:41.770 --> 00:02:46.620
add additional functionality by
installing these cards, these

50
00:02:46.620 --> 00:02:51.550
PC expansion cards as you call them, into
the different slots on the motherboard.

51
00:02:51.550 --> 00:02:55.730
>> Well, you know that being said,
should you check to see if it says

52
00:02:55.730 --> 00:02:59.420
you can expand this, this is expandable,
there is that capability?

53
00:02:59.420 --> 00:03:00.740
>> That's a perfect question,

54
00:03:00.740 --> 00:03:04.740
the fact that it all depends
on what you need, right?

55
00:03:04.740 --> 00:03:09.370
So, to give you an example, where I've
done this in the past when I'm building

56
00:03:09.370 --> 00:03:13.280
computers is I always pay attention
to what the customer wants, right?

57
00:03:13.280 --> 00:03:15.995
Or pay attention, if it's a friend that
I happen to be doing this for and say,

58
00:03:15.995 --> 00:03:20.295
okay, what is the price point
that you have to spend right now?

59
00:03:20.295 --> 00:03:23.125
And where do you see yourself
going with this computer,

60
00:03:23.125 --> 00:03:25.055
let's say in six months or a year?

61
00:03:25.055 --> 00:03:26.365
And I know they're usually outdated.

62
00:03:26.365 --> 00:03:30.290
But a lot of times people hold
onto computers for a long time.

63
00:03:30.290 --> 00:03:32.790
So, when you're purchasing a system,

64
00:03:32.790 --> 00:03:35.810
you might wanna pay attention to
the motherboard specifications.

65
00:03:35.810 --> 00:03:37.500
Because the motherboard specifications,

66
00:03:37.500 --> 00:03:42.010
according to the manufacturer's details
about it, the manufacturer's specs

67
00:03:42.010 --> 00:03:46.020
tell you how many of these expansion
slots are available, right?

68
00:03:46.020 --> 00:03:49.640
And even if you aren't populating them
now, if you want to upgrade in the future,

69
00:03:49.640 --> 00:03:51.950
you have to make sure that those
slots are available, right?

70
00:03:51.950 --> 00:03:53.720
Because, if you don't have
those slots available,

71
00:03:53.720 --> 00:03:56.630
then you're not really going to expand
the functionality of the computer

72
00:03:56.630 --> 00:04:00.270
at all because of the fact that
there's no way to expand it.

73
00:04:00.270 --> 00:04:05.090
Now, why might you want to expand the
functionality of your computer, all right?

74
00:04:05.090 --> 00:04:08.514
Well, in an earlier episode we talked
about motherboards having integrated

75
00:04:08.514 --> 00:04:11.325
functionality and
non-integrated functionality, right?

76
00:04:11.325 --> 00:04:13.570
Non-integrated means it's
not present all right?

77
00:04:13.570 --> 00:04:16.310
In the fact I could say that I could
say that this motherboard that we just

78
00:04:16.310 --> 00:04:20.640
looked at here, doesn't have,
things like firewire capabilities, right?

79
00:04:20.640 --> 00:04:23.410
It's not present,
it's not integrated, all right?

80
00:04:23.410 --> 00:04:27.320
But some integrated functionalities,
all right, you have to keep in mind,

81
00:04:27.320 --> 00:04:31.290
don't perform as well as
dedicated functionality.

82
00:04:31.290 --> 00:04:34.760
And what I mean by that is if I
take a video that's integrated into

83
00:04:34.760 --> 00:04:37.640
the functionality of the motherboard
that chips up that we talked about,

84
00:04:37.640 --> 00:04:40.800
it understands the graphical rendering,
great.

85
00:04:40.800 --> 00:04:41.640
You don't even have to buy it.

86
00:04:41.640 --> 00:04:43.190
It keeps the price point down.

87
00:04:43.190 --> 00:04:44.480
You can watch your monitor.

88
00:04:44.480 --> 00:04:48.460
You can interact with your computer, but
you're probably not gonna play games,

89
00:04:48.460 --> 00:04:49.710
like video games,

90
00:04:49.710 --> 00:04:54.250
on a very high-level setting because
the integrated component doesn't do well.

91
00:04:54.250 --> 00:04:58.390
But if you get a dedicated card,
where all of that hardware is

92
00:04:58.390 --> 00:05:02.640
built in to the functionality of that
card, you put it on an expansion slot.

93
00:05:02.640 --> 00:05:05.260
Now you've really expanded
the functionality, right?

94
00:05:05.260 --> 00:05:08.270
So that might be a reason
that you might do that.

95
00:05:08.270 --> 00:05:11.410
Now, there are many,
many different cards out there, right?

96
00:05:11.410 --> 00:05:15.780
And I wanna kind of backtrack just
a little bit to our motherboard episode,

97
00:05:15.780 --> 00:05:19.540
because it is contingent
on the bus architecture.

98
00:05:19.540 --> 00:05:21.690
So if we could take a look at
this motherboard here real quick,

99
00:05:21.690 --> 00:05:24.432
I want you to see that there
are different types of slots

100
00:05:24.432 --> 00:05:25.000
here,
>> Hm-mm.

101
00:05:25.000 --> 00:05:26.950
>> And they are not the same.

102
00:05:26.950 --> 00:05:29.720
For instance,
this is the PCI slot here, right.

103
00:05:29.720 --> 00:05:33.880
This PCI slot and the PCI e-slot,
they're not compatible with each other.

104
00:05:33.880 --> 00:05:36.350
So you have to make sure
that you understand, again,

105
00:05:36.350 --> 00:05:38.700
according to the specifications
of the motherboard,

106
00:05:38.700 --> 00:05:42.880
what bus architecture you
have available to you.

107
00:05:42.880 --> 00:05:46.820
So, for instance,
this is a FireWire expansion card.

108
00:05:46.820 --> 00:05:47.550
Remember, I told you,

109
00:05:47.550 --> 00:05:50.980
I said, well this computer doesn't
have FireWire available to it.

110
00:05:50.980 --> 00:05:53.320
Well, now we've figured out that
we've got some kind of cameras.

111
00:05:53.320 --> 00:05:56.110
Zach, you were talking about some of
the cameras that you've seen on video

112
00:05:56.110 --> 00:05:57.620
systems in the past, have FireWire.

113
00:05:57.620 --> 00:06:00.280
And that's just because it's one
of the best interfaces well,

114
00:06:00.280 --> 00:06:01.170
up until we have things.

115
00:06:01.170 --> 00:06:04.140
We have newer technology like Thunderbolt,
which we'll talk about here, and

116
00:06:04.140 --> 00:06:05.890
it was very good at video, right?

117
00:06:05.890 --> 00:06:10.180
Not quite as good as like things like
our Integrated USB ports, right?

118
00:06:10.180 --> 00:06:14.340
Well I've got USB right here,
but I want Firewire.

119
00:06:14.340 --> 00:06:15.350
USB is not gonna,

120
00:06:15.350 --> 00:06:18.360
it isn't really gonna give me the best
performance that I need for the video.

121
00:06:18.360 --> 00:06:19.270
So what do I do?

122
00:06:19.270 --> 00:06:23.550
I expand the functionality of this
motherboard and the system unit

123
00:06:23.550 --> 00:06:28.820
collectively by taking this card and
we install it in the PCI slot.

124
00:06:28.820 --> 00:06:31.560
And again, this is a PCI Firewire card.

125
00:06:31.560 --> 00:06:33.550
And once you see me install it like this,

126
00:06:33.550 --> 00:06:36.690
you can now see that on
the back plan of that computer,

127
00:06:36.690 --> 00:06:41.000
on the back of the tower, I can now
plug in our six-pin FireWire connectors.

128
00:06:41.000 --> 00:06:44.480
Right now I have FireWire
400 functionality that

129
00:06:44.480 --> 00:06:45.920
I didn't have before, right?

130
00:06:45.920 --> 00:06:48.220
And that's one of the great
things about these.

131
00:06:48.220 --> 00:06:51.280
Now, the other thing that I might tell
you as well is, okay, so for instance,

132
00:06:51.280 --> 00:06:54.360
this is a PCI card, right, or PCIE card.

133
00:06:54.360 --> 00:06:56.850
And if I just take a second here,
and I'll pop this back out.

134
00:06:56.850 --> 00:06:58.440
Be very careful with these guys.

135
00:06:58.440 --> 00:07:02.300
You'll notice that we're
using anti-static bags here.

136
00:07:02.300 --> 00:07:02.970
>> Yeah, I was gonna say,

137
00:07:02.970 --> 00:07:06.100
is it good to use the anti-static
bags when you're actually doing this?

138
00:07:06.100 --> 00:07:09.010
>> Yeah, definitely, because you have
to worry about static electricity.

139
00:07:09.010 --> 00:07:10.110
And we'll talk, definitely,

140
00:07:10.110 --> 00:07:13.040
a lot more about that in our
electrical safety chapter.

141
00:07:13.040 --> 00:07:13.760
>> Wow.

142
00:07:13.760 --> 00:07:16.920
>> But notice that the pins
are completely different, right?

143
00:07:16.920 --> 00:07:18.740
Notice that they are not the same.

144
00:07:18.740 --> 00:07:23.080
These are different standards, different
architectures, and you have to follow.

145
00:07:23.080 --> 00:07:27.770
PCI doesn't work with PCIe, vice versa,
PCIe doesn't work with PCI.

146
00:07:27.770 --> 00:07:32.210
All right, so I could expand
the functionality by bringing

147
00:07:32.210 --> 00:07:35.810
the Firewire capabilities to this machine.

148
00:07:35.810 --> 00:07:38.320
Alright, now one of the things
I told you is that you can have

149
00:07:38.320 --> 00:07:40.550
integrated functionality
on the motherboard as well.

150
00:07:40.550 --> 00:07:44.640
The integrated functionality says
that the CPU mixed with the chip set

151
00:07:44.640 --> 00:07:47.220
understands how to do
graphical processing.

152
00:07:47.220 --> 00:07:51.790
The CPU or the motherboard and its chip
set are doing a lot of other things.

153
00:07:51.790 --> 00:07:54.491
So now it's collectively sharing its
performance with other devices, right.

154
00:07:54.491 --> 00:07:58.450
So how about getting dedicated
functionality by a non-integrated

155
00:07:58.450 --> 00:08:02.905
component, and this more so is It's
kinda old by today's standards here.

156
00:08:02.905 --> 00:08:07.430
But this is an older DVI
type Radeon graphics card.

157
00:08:07.430 --> 00:08:11.005
And what I can do is I can place this into

158
00:08:11.005 --> 00:08:16.170
the PCI-E slot and
now I have a different video quality.

159
00:08:16.170 --> 00:08:19.440
Notice that this is the old VGA
connector here but now I have DVI.

160
00:08:19.440 --> 00:08:22.050
And this goes even more farther today,
they have things like your

161
00:08:22.050 --> 00:08:25.050
thunderbolt cards out there,
which are absolutely amazing.

162
00:08:25.050 --> 00:08:29.550
And they will connect to your PC ie
slots and give you things like HDMI,

163
00:08:29.550 --> 00:08:32.130
display ports of very high resolutions.

It's kind of like the translator.

00:32:04.180 --> 00:32:08.275
Operating systems are programmed in
a high level programming language or

615
00:32:08.275 --> 00:32:12.763
coded, if you will, and our hardware runs
on a very low level like machine code,

616
00:32:12.763 --> 00:32:14.891
they don't speak the same language.

617
00:32:14.891 --> 00:32:18.494
So we download and update drivers and
they're the translator,

618
00:32:18.494 --> 00:32:22.833
they're the middleman between the high
level programming language and that

619
00:32:22.833 --> 00:32:27.524
machine code that allow our, basically
our hardware, to talk with our software.

620
00:32:27.524 --> 00:32:32.864
Drive adapters most often today
are plug-and-play compatible.

621
00:32:32.864 --> 00:32:37.580
And plug-and-play means the device can
be plugged in, the motherboard and

622
00:32:37.580 --> 00:32:42.060
the BIOS will communicate with
the resources, memory locations,

623
00:32:42.060 --> 00:32:48.810
the CPU if you will, and figure this out,
and basically you're ready to go.

624
00:32:48.810 --> 00:32:51.140
That doesn't mean that
you won't need a driver.

625
00:32:51.140 --> 00:32:53.750
You typically need drivers
especially with video cards.

626
00:32:53.750 --> 00:32:55.990
The other thing too is you sometimes and

627
00:32:55.990 --> 00:32:59.560
a lot of times need to update
drivers to your video cards as well.

628
00:32:59.560 --> 00:33:01.320
Because when you do an update to a driver,

629
00:33:01.320 --> 00:33:04.700
a lot of times it fixes known flaws or
bugs in the software or

630
00:33:04.700 --> 00:33:08.400
in the programming, and
sometimes expands the functionality.

631
00:33:08.400 --> 00:33:11.030
So yes, rely on plug-and-plays,
it's a great thing.

632
00:33:11.030 --> 00:33:12.160
You plug in the device.

633
00:33:12.160 --> 00:33:14.400
It allocates all the resources it needs.

634
00:33:14.400 --> 00:33:16.552
The operating system's communicating.

635
00:33:16.552 --> 00:33:20.468
A lot of times your operating systems
like Windows have built in drivers and

636
00:33:20.468 --> 00:33:22.592
it says, I know exactly what that is.

637
00:33:22.592 --> 00:33:25.950
But that doesn't mean you're gonna get
the full functionality of the device.

638
00:33:25.950 --> 00:33:29.090
Always check with
the manufacturer when you install

639
00:33:29.090 --> 00:33:32.890
some kind of expansion card into the
motherboard itself, because if you do not,

640
00:33:32.890 --> 00:33:36.790
you do run the chance of either
not communicating with it,

641
00:33:36.790 --> 00:33:41.830
reduced functionality, or
just instability and problems if you will.

642
00:33:41.830 --> 00:33:46.670
Bus architecture, PCI doesn't
work with PCIe, and vice versa.

643
00:33:46.670 --> 00:33:51.120
Motherboard considerations, pay attention
to the amount of expansion slots you have.

644
00:33:51.120 --> 00:33:54.230
The other thing to keep in mind is when
you put things like video cards in and

645
00:33:54.230 --> 00:33:56.880
especially when you start running them
side by side like I was telling you in

646
00:33:56.880 --> 00:34:01.190
tandem like that, and SLI and
Crossfire solution, Heat.

647
00:34:01.190 --> 00:34:05.079
You might have to increase the cooling
system because you're gonna generate a lot

648
00:34:05.079 --> 00:34:08.514
more heat and the normal system cooling
that came with it was adequate for

649
00:34:08.514 --> 00:34:10.033
what it was when you bought it but

650
00:34:10.033 --> 00:34:13.891
might not be adequate anymore because of
the fact that you've now increased it.

651
00:34:13.891 --> 00:34:18.672
The other thing is power considerations,
especially when you're talking about PCIe.

652
00:34:18.672 --> 00:34:24.613
PCIe is a power hungry boss by itself,
without even populating the cards,

653
00:34:24.613 --> 00:34:29.611
they had to invent a 24-pin
connector to give 4 extra pins to

654
00:34:29.611 --> 00:34:33.430
power the PCIe bus architecture alone.

655
00:34:33.430 --> 00:34:37.220
Your cards themselves might have
connectors that are on the back of them,

656
00:34:37.220 --> 00:34:40.790
so you also have to pay attention
to your power requirements,

657
00:34:40.790 --> 00:34:45.270
the available wattage you have in
the system as well as the connectors.

658
00:34:45.270 --> 00:34:49.120
Last, but not least, pay attention
to the case you have itself, right.

659
00:34:49.120 --> 00:34:52.320
Because the case itself,
your motherboard, ATX motherboard,

660
00:34:52.320 --> 00:34:57.410
remember we said form factor, case, power
supply and motherboard all have to match.

661
00:34:57.410 --> 00:35:00.245
But just because you have an ATX board and
an ATX case,

662
00:35:00.245 --> 00:35:04.088
if that case only has two available slots,
blanking plates on the back,

663
00:35:04.088 --> 00:35:08.003
you can't populate let's say if you
have four slots on the motherboard.

664
00:35:08.003 --> 00:35:08.871
You can't populate them.

665
00:35:08.871 --> 00:35:12.613
You gotta make sure that the case from
the back of the case that you have enough

666
00:35:12.613 --> 00:35:16.065
available openings on the back of
the case to utilize every one of those

667
00:35:16.065 --> 00:35:18.030
slots on the motherboard.

668
00:35:18.030 --> 00:35:20.603
>> Wonderful, as usual, thank you Wes.

669
00:35:20.603 --> 00:35:23.884
PC expansion cards A+ 901, thanks for

670
00:35:23.884 --> 00:35:27.445
watching that and
you're watching IT Pro TV.

671
00:35:27.445 --> 00:35:29.330
And thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

672
00:35:29.330 --> 00:35:31.820
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

673
00:35:31.820 --> 00:35:32.680
I'm Zach Memos.

674
00:35:32.680 --> 00:35:33.450
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

675
00:35:33.450 --> 00:35:35.746
>> We'll see you soon.

676
00:35:35.746 --> 00:35:41.661
[MUSIC]

677
00:35:41.661 --> 00:35:45.233
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: Wes and Zach begin the discussion of how to install and configure storage devices, use of appropriate media, optical drives, CD-ROM/CD-RW, DVD-ROM/DVD-RW/DVD-RW DL, DVDDL, Blu-Ray, BD-R, BD-RE, and file system for CDFS & UDF.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Storage Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.915
Welcome to ITPro.TV,

2
00:00:03.915 --> 00:00:08.296
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.296 --> 00:00:12.321
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

4
00:00:12.321 --> 00:00:17.840
>> Thank you again for choosing ITPro.TV,
where we help you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:17.840 --> 00:00:21.580
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with A+ 901.

6
00:00:21.580 --> 00:00:24.800
And today, or for
this episode we're gonna be installing and

7
00:00:24.800 --> 00:00:28.430
configuring storage
devices with Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:28.430 --> 00:00:29.460
>> Hey Zach, how you doing today?

9
00:00:29.460 --> 00:00:30.357
>> Good.
>> That's right.

10
00:00:30.357 --> 00:00:34.298
We're gonna be looking at, well, some of
the different technologies that you have

11
00:00:34.298 --> 00:00:37.571
to be familiar with if you are going
to make a decision on what to install.

12
00:00:37.571 --> 00:00:40.254
When it comes to different
storage mediums that we have.

13
00:00:40.254 --> 00:00:42.710
And we've got a whole
bunch of different types.

14
00:00:42.710 --> 00:00:44.330
But when it comes to storage medium,

15
00:00:44.330 --> 00:00:48.280
it really boils down to a couple basic
concepts that we want you to be aware of.

16
00:00:48.280 --> 00:00:52.079
So storage mediums, if you will,
the media if you will or

17
00:00:52.079 --> 00:00:54.863
the components within your system unit.

18
00:00:54.863 --> 00:00:58.820
That allow us to take our data,
stored on it, like the name implies.

19
00:00:58.820 --> 00:01:02.279
But more importantly, for
reusal at a later time.

20
00:01:02.279 --> 00:01:07.327
In past episodes we have talked about
our volatile memory, our system memory.

21
00:01:07.327 --> 00:01:10.438
And the fact that that's
a a temporary works bench.

22
00:01:10.438 --> 00:01:13.780
The bigger that work bench,
if you will, the more memory you have.

23
00:01:13.780 --> 00:01:17.980
Well, the more information you
could be working with at one time.

24
00:01:17.980 --> 00:01:22.760
But the problem here is, remember when we
said when you cut that electrical current,

25
00:01:22.760 --> 00:01:25.700
the power shuts off or
power the computer down.

26
00:01:25.700 --> 00:01:30.881
Anything that is stored within that
memory region is going to be lost.

27
00:01:30.881 --> 00:01:33.000
So if we wanna store our data, and

28
00:01:33.000 --> 00:01:37.173
we want to pull that data back into
the system unit at a later time.

29
00:01:37.173 --> 00:01:41.680
We have a few different types of storage
devices that we need to look at.

30
00:01:41.680 --> 00:01:44.077
Now, they really boil down to
two different types today,

31
00:01:44.077 --> 00:01:46.126
well actually three different types.

32
00:01:46.126 --> 00:01:48.929
They boil down to what is
known as magnetic media.

33
00:01:48.929 --> 00:01:51.866
Magnetic media has been around for
a very long time.

34
00:01:51.866 --> 00:01:55.550
And it really is one of
the oldest storage medium types.

35
00:01:55.550 --> 00:01:59.500
The second one is optical,
optical storage.

36
00:01:59.500 --> 00:02:03.850
And this is something as well that
has also been around for awhile.

37
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:08.030
The third one is, I don't wanna say
new by computing standards today.

38
00:02:08.030 --> 00:02:12.230
I guess if you look at a larger picture
of things, newer than the other two.

39
00:02:12.230 --> 00:02:15.250
And that's called electronic storage.

40
00:02:15.250 --> 00:02:19.260
Now, the other thing that we also have
to keep in mind is that sometimes

41
00:02:19.260 --> 00:02:21.670
devices are mechanical as well.

42
00:02:21.670 --> 00:02:25.690
Versus the electronic storage which
is a non-mechanical type of device,

43
00:02:25.690 --> 00:02:27.234
storage medium if you will.

44
00:02:27.234 --> 00:02:30.580
In which it just basically means
you don't have moving parts.

45
00:02:30.580 --> 00:02:32.460
We talked about mechanical drives.

46
00:02:32.460 --> 00:02:35.970
What we're talking about is you got
a lot of different pieces inside of them

47
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:37.380
that are moving.

48
00:02:37.380 --> 00:02:38.912
Let's go ahead and
take a couple steps back.

49
00:02:38.912 --> 00:02:41.220
And let's talk about magnetic media.

50
00:02:41.220 --> 00:02:45.550
When we talk about magnetic media,
we talk about basically a magnetic

51
00:02:45.550 --> 00:02:49.900
charge is put onto the storage medium
that essentially represents our data.

52
00:02:49.900 --> 00:02:51.510
We've got different types out there.

53
00:02:51.510 --> 00:02:55.250
We've got going back for
a long time if you will, and

54
00:02:55.250 --> 00:02:59.110
pretty much not used in today's industry,
not very commonly.

55
00:02:59.110 --> 00:03:01.908
And if it still is, you really need
to upgrade, are the floppy disks.

56
00:03:01.908 --> 00:03:04.694
The floppy disks were
a magnetic storage type.

57
00:03:04.694 --> 00:03:06.550
They're also mechanical drives,

58
00:03:06.550 --> 00:03:08.890
because they have got a lot of
little moving parts in there.

59
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:10.810
And it's also what's
known as removable media.

60
00:03:10.810 --> 00:03:13.120
Keep in mind that I should
probably mention that.

61
00:03:13.120 --> 00:03:14.880
We have what's known as removable media,
and

62
00:03:14.880 --> 00:03:17.530
sometimes we have what's
known as fixed media.

63
00:03:17.530 --> 00:03:20.690
Now, to give you an example of
a magnetic media that's fixed, we have

64
00:03:20.690 --> 00:03:24.460
what are known as our internal mechanical
hard drives, our hard disk drives.

65
00:03:24.460 --> 00:03:25.690
You might see the acronym.

66
00:03:25.690 --> 00:03:30.125
And again, just like A+, we're not shy
of any kind of alphabet soup here.

67
00:03:30.125 --> 00:03:32.830
The term HDD, and
that's a hard disk drive.

68
00:03:33.970 --> 00:03:38.920
And a hard disk drive is one that,
again, stores that data magnetically.

69
00:03:38.920 --> 00:03:42.220
Now the next one we talk about
again is the optical drives.

70
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:45.335
Optical drives are ones that use
some form of an optical laser.

71
00:03:45.335 --> 00:03:51.881
And what they do is they typically burn
recesses, these lowered pits if you will.

72
00:03:51.881 --> 00:03:54.727
Or these raised areas called lands..

73
00:03:54.727 --> 00:03:57.274
And they're basically burning the media.

74
00:03:57.274 --> 00:04:00.100
They're melting,
I think it's Mylar plastic.

75
00:04:00.100 --> 00:04:04.003
I might have that a little bit wrong but
it's a plastic removable media.

76
00:04:04.003 --> 00:04:08.931
We can take the optical discs out
of the mechanical optical drive,

77
00:04:08.931 --> 00:04:12.100
and we can use that data at a later date.

78
00:04:12.100 --> 00:04:14.450
>> Sorta like a laser disc for
your computer.

79
00:04:14.450 --> 00:04:15.600
>> That's exactly what it is.

80
00:04:15.600 --> 00:04:19.050
And really that's where the laser
discs that we see today,

81
00:04:19.050 --> 00:04:20.480
that's really where they started out.

82
00:04:20.480 --> 00:04:23.620
They started out in
the earlier days more for

83
00:04:23.620 --> 00:04:27.090
things like your industrial
based computing systems.

84
00:04:27.090 --> 00:04:28.900
Now we also have the electronic storage.

85
00:04:28.900 --> 00:04:31.630
And electronic storage is where we
get into things like flash drives,

86
00:04:31.630 --> 00:04:33.690
we get into things like
solid state drives.

87
00:04:33.690 --> 00:04:38.681
And this is where our data is stored
in non-volatile memory type chips.

88
00:04:38.681 --> 00:04:42.338
Remember and if you're not familiar with
that term, we'll recap it a little bit and

89
00:04:42.338 --> 00:04:44.000
go back and watch our memory section.

90
00:04:44.000 --> 00:04:46.930
Because we did talked about
non-volatile storage.

91
00:04:46.930 --> 00:04:50.030
And remember that is a way that we
can send an electrical current.

92
00:04:50.030 --> 00:04:53.120
And we can manipulate chips
that are within this component.

93
00:04:53.120 --> 00:04:56.000
That if we pull the power on
whatever the component is or

94
00:04:56.000 --> 00:04:59.460
the system unit collectively,
we don't lose that data.

95
00:04:59.460 --> 00:05:02.010
And these have their benefits
because of the fact that they're

96
00:05:02.010 --> 00:05:03.370
a non-mechanical drive.

97
00:05:03.370 --> 00:05:05.000
You get access times.

98
00:05:05.000 --> 00:05:09.012
Being able to grab that information and
store that information lightning fast,

99
00:05:09.012 --> 00:05:11.908
if you will,
compared to the mechanical drives.

100
00:05:11.908 --> 00:05:14.998
The mechanical drives have
a little bit of latency, guys, and

101
00:05:14.998 --> 00:05:18.690
a little jargon right off the top,
right at the beginning of this episode.

102
00:05:18.690 --> 00:05:21.790
When we talk about latency,
we're talking about delay.

103
00:05:21.790 --> 00:05:23.300
Delay, latency, the same thing.

104
00:05:23.300 --> 00:05:26.010
Because we have to wait
a little bit of time.

105
00:05:26.010 --> 00:05:27.090
Let me give you an example.

106
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:31.310
If you put a DVD into your DVD player and
you turn it on.

107
00:05:31.310 --> 00:05:34.640
And it takes a second for
the system to spin up.

108
00:05:34.640 --> 00:05:40.077
You typically get, I can move to
different tracks, are all on that DVD.

109
00:05:40.077 --> 00:05:41.677
Just by pushing a button, real quick,

110
00:05:41.677 --> 00:05:44.890
we can get to it versus
something like a record player.

111
00:05:44.890 --> 00:05:48.160
If you go with the old record players,
which are obviously still in use today.

112
00:05:48.160 --> 00:05:51.630
I have to move the needle or
I have to wait for the needle to come up.

113
00:05:51.630 --> 00:05:52.630
And it's got to seek.

114
00:05:52.630 --> 00:05:57.920
And then it's gotta come down and find
the track that's within the record itself.

115
00:05:57.920 --> 00:06:01.257
So, that's kind of like what we say when
we say mechanical versus electronic.

116
00:06:01.257 --> 00:06:04.090
Because I don't have to
wait on those moving parts.

117
00:06:04.090 --> 00:06:08.340
We get access times that are a lot faster
than the traditional mechanical drives.

118
00:06:08.340 --> 00:06:10.843
So those are some of the things that
we're gonna talk about in this episode.

119
00:06:10.843 --> 00:06:14.490
And we're going to look little bit
more in depth at each one of those.

120
00:06:14.490 --> 00:06:18.673
>> Question, do you have to install,
and then configure or

121
00:06:18.673 --> 00:06:20.686
configure and then install?

122
00:06:20.686 --> 00:06:21.966
>> When it comes to the drive types?

123
00:06:21.966 --> 00:06:23.980
>> Yeah.
>> Well, one of the great things we have

124
00:06:23.980 --> 00:06:26.220
today, Zach,
is something known as plug and play.

125
00:06:26.220 --> 00:06:28.403
Drivers are always important.

126
00:06:28.403 --> 00:06:31.641
And we talked more about drivers,
actually we'll be talking about drivers

127
00:06:31.641 --> 00:06:34.790
really through all the hardware and
definitely in our operating system.

128
00:06:34.790 --> 00:06:38.490
See, one of the things you have to
understand is that an operating system is

129
00:06:38.490 --> 00:06:40.130
a high level programming language.

130
00:06:40.130 --> 00:06:44.080
And your programmers, that program in
those languages don't necessarily know all

131
00:06:44.080 --> 00:06:45.770
the details of the hardware.

132
00:06:45.770 --> 00:06:46.450
And that's the benefit.

133
00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:47.410
They don't really have to.

134
00:06:47.410 --> 00:06:50.720
We leave the manufacturers of
the hardware to understand

135
00:06:50.720 --> 00:06:52.500
how to get the hardware online.

136
00:06:52.500 --> 00:06:56.085
So what you need is you need some
kind of middle man, if you will, or

137
00:06:56.085 --> 00:06:58.343
some kind of middle translator.

138
00:06:58.343 --> 00:07:03.550
So for instance, I'd love to learn, and
am still trying to learn to speak Spanish.

139
00:07:03.550 --> 00:07:05.160
But I don't really understand Spanish.

140
00:07:05.160 --> 00:07:08.329
So if I'm gonna speak to somebody
that is only fluent in Spanish but

141
00:07:08.329 --> 00:07:10.208
doesn't really understand English.

142
00:07:10.208 --> 00:07:13.236
Then what I need is somebody
that understands Spanish and

143
00:07:13.236 --> 00:07:14.634
English at the same time.

144
00:07:14.634 --> 00:07:18.289
And can sit between me and
my conversation with another person, and

145
00:07:18.289 --> 00:07:19.968
can translate for me.

146
00:07:19.968 --> 00:07:23.195
So to get to your question,
do we install and do we have to configure.

147
00:07:23.195 --> 00:07:26.570
When we rely on plug-and-play, a lot of
times what happens is your hardware and

148
00:07:26.570 --> 00:07:28.420
your software talk together.

149
00:07:28.420 --> 00:07:32.150
And they can figure out what translators
are needed, drivers if you will, and

150
00:07:32.150 --> 00:07:33.360
they can install them.

151
00:07:33.360 --> 00:07:35.870
But never underestimate the fact or

152
00:07:35.870 --> 00:07:40.500
never assume that a driver's gonna
be present through plug and play.

153
00:07:40.500 --> 00:07:43.748
You get your drivers for your hardware
devices directly from the manufacturer.

154
00:07:43.748 --> 00:07:46.285
And any time you're gonna install
a device in a system unit,

155
00:07:46.285 --> 00:07:48.840
you wanna make sure that you have
the most up to date drivers.

156
00:07:48.840 --> 00:07:51.923
Because a lot of times, for instance in
a Windows based system, those drivers for

157
00:07:51.923 --> 00:07:54.172
the hardware are gonna be built
into the operating system.

158
00:07:54.172 --> 00:07:57.500
But it might not be the latest and
greatest drivers.

159
00:07:57.500 --> 00:07:59.413
So you might lose a little
bit of functionality.

160
00:07:59.413 --> 00:08:03.500
So when you install these, always make
sure that you have those drivers present.

161
00:08:03.500 --> 00:08:05.539
Now that being said, let's go ahead.

162
00:08:05.539 --> 00:08:10.243
And what we're gonna do is we're
gonna take a look at our very first

163

find when you go to a store and

385
00:20:27.630 --> 00:20:32.200
you buy a DVD optical disk,
is you're gonna find for a single sided.

386
00:20:32.200 --> 00:20:33.370
And when we talk about single sided,

387
00:20:33.370 --> 00:20:35.874
it's kinda like we were talking about
with the memory with the record player.

388
00:20:35.874 --> 00:20:37.770
You can pull it out, turn it over,
and put it back in and

389
00:20:37.770 --> 00:20:39.290
it can read you the other side.

390
00:20:39.290 --> 00:20:42.420
If you talk about a single sided DVD,
you're

391
00:20:42.420 --> 00:20:46.910
talking 4.7 gigabytes of information
on a single DVD, one-sided, right?

392
00:20:46.910 --> 00:20:49.732
That's a lot more than just
a 700 megabyte, right?

393
00:20:49.732 --> 00:20:51.880
We're talking a lot of information.

394
00:20:51.880 --> 00:20:56.823
If you have one of the dual-sided,
right, or excuse me, single-sided,

395
00:20:56.823 --> 00:20:58.780
dual-layer, right?

396
00:20:58.780 --> 00:21:03.420
So now we just have a single side, but
there's multiple writing layers, right?

397
00:21:03.420 --> 00:21:07.699
That one's gonna be one that's
8.5 gigabytes of capacity.

398
00:21:08.790 --> 00:21:11.044
But now here it gets a little tricky.

399
00:21:11.044 --> 00:21:15.415
We have double-sided with single layers.

400
00:21:15.415 --> 00:21:18.792
And that just means I've got one
writing layer that I can write to, and

401
00:21:18.792 --> 00:21:19.887
that's 4.7 gigs.

402
00:21:19.887 --> 00:21:23.294
We can take that optical disk out and
turn it over.

403
00:21:23.294 --> 00:21:25.250
And we can write to the other side.

404
00:21:25.250 --> 00:21:27.054
Well, guess what, it just doubles it.

405
00:21:27.054 --> 00:21:29.062
It goes from 4.7 gigs to 9.4 gigs, right?

406
00:21:29.062 --> 00:21:31.490
It's 4.7 on each side.

407
00:21:31.490 --> 00:21:35.633
Now one of the ones that are very rare and
they're not really found in the market.

408
00:21:35.633 --> 00:21:39.644
You can see these a lot of times
coming from the manufacturer,

409
00:21:39.644 --> 00:21:42.150
are what are known as single-sided.

410
00:21:42.150 --> 00:21:45.260
And you'll see DL,
it might say dual layer or double layer.

411
00:21:45.260 --> 00:21:50.440
Not single-sided, excuse me,
double-sided, double layer or dual layer.

412
00:21:50.440 --> 00:21:55.860
These mean you have two of those
writing surfaces on each side.

413
00:21:55.860 --> 00:22:01.600
Those would go up to 17 gigabytes
of data on a single DVD.

414
00:22:01.600 --> 00:22:03.830
That's a lot of information
on one little optical disc.

415
00:22:03.830 --> 00:22:05.460
However, they're very rare.

416
00:22:05.460 --> 00:22:06.760
I only throw them out here for

417
00:22:06.760 --> 00:22:11.650
the exam purposes in case you come
across it on the exam, right?

418
00:22:11.650 --> 00:22:17.690
The most common ones that we find
are the single-sided, single layer,

419
00:22:17.690 --> 00:22:22.550
4.7 gigs, or single-layer,
double sided, right?

420
00:22:22.550 --> 00:22:27.840
4.7 gigs on each side, tally it up,
total it up, it is 9.4 gigabytes, right?

421
00:22:27.840 --> 00:22:30.915
So I definitely want
you to remember those.

422
00:22:30.915 --> 00:22:33.052
And to kinda give you an idea
about the wavelengths,

423
00:22:33.052 --> 00:22:35.622
you're gonna see that the wavelength
is shorter on this one.

424
00:22:35.622 --> 00:22:37.952
And, again, I don't want you to
worry about the wavelengths.

425
00:22:37.952 --> 00:22:40.528
Just for the concept and the theory.

426
00:22:40.528 --> 00:22:47.990
We go from 780 nanometers in a CD
down to 650 nanometers in a DVD.

427
00:22:47.990 --> 00:22:51.218
So you can see that the compression
of the information,

428
00:22:51.218 --> 00:22:53.218
the more you can compact, right?

429
00:22:53.218 --> 00:22:55.414
I want you to think of that
file cabinet that you open up.

430
00:22:55.414 --> 00:22:59.410
And it's got loose files in it,
right, being like the CD, right?

431
00:22:59.410 --> 00:23:02.811
If I take those files and
I push them all the way to the back,

432
00:23:02.811 --> 00:23:05.255
I now have a little bit more information.

433
00:23:05.255 --> 00:23:07.800
And I can put some more
files in that file cabinet.

434
00:23:07.800 --> 00:23:10.130
It's kind of like what's
going on with those lasers.

435
00:23:10.130 --> 00:23:11.600
The shorter the wavelength,

436
00:23:11.600 --> 00:23:14.330
think of it as data compression,
we're squeezing that data.

437
00:23:14.330 --> 00:23:17.580
And we can get a lot more
information on that optical disk.

438
00:23:17.580 --> 00:23:18.832
The last one is Blu-ray.

439
00:23:18.832 --> 00:23:22.976
And Blu-ray, just like I said,
again, it is a blue laser.

440
00:23:22.976 --> 00:23:27.194
These were originally before,
and I don't know the company,

441
00:23:27.194 --> 00:23:29.032
I think Sony was part of it.

442
00:23:29.032 --> 00:23:31.583
Phillips Magnavox might have been
another one that was part of it too.

443
00:23:31.583 --> 00:23:35.380
They're Sony-Philips today, but Sony was
definitely on the forefront of this.

444
00:23:35.380 --> 00:23:38.070
They called them high
density optical disks in

445
00:23:38.070 --> 00:23:41.300
the earlier days until they settled
on the marketing name if you will,

446
00:23:41.300 --> 00:23:44.880
Blue ray,
based on the blue laser that it is.

447
00:23:44.880 --> 00:23:47.041
These are also removable storage.

448
00:23:47.041 --> 00:23:49.340
They started somewhere
in the early 2000's.

449
00:23:49.340 --> 00:23:51.631
And they've been constantly
being optimized and

450
00:23:51.631 --> 00:23:53.984
they're increasing their
capacities every day.

451
00:23:53.984 --> 00:23:58.930
That wavelength is almost half Half of
what the original CDs were that were

452
00:23:58.930 --> 00:24:04.940
released in the 80s, we're talking 405
nanometers, ultra compact, all right?

453
00:24:04.940 --> 00:24:09.310
So because of that, they can compress a
lot information on a single Blu-ray disk.

454
00:24:09.310 --> 00:24:12.585
And they also have technologies,
through the encoding and how they

455
00:24:12.585 --> 00:24:16.616
write the information, it allows for
very crystal clear audio and video, right?

456
00:24:16.616 --> 00:24:22.260
So very, very good for our modern
high definition video that we watch.

457
00:24:22.260 --> 00:24:27.320
Now the way they work,
they work in multiple layers,

458
00:24:27.320 --> 00:24:30.330
kind of like that DVD does on one side.

459
00:24:30.330 --> 00:24:33.500
It can have multiple writing layers,
just in a single side.

460
00:24:33.500 --> 00:24:36.110
And they're single layer,
they're dual layer, and

461
00:24:36.110 --> 00:24:38.850
there's another one out
there that's called BDXL.

462
00:24:38.850 --> 00:24:42.400
And again, that's extra layer or
extra large, I think.

463
00:24:42.400 --> 00:24:44.670
But it's BDXL format.

464
00:24:44.670 --> 00:24:50.810
Every layer, this might help you
on the exam, a single sided, and

465
00:24:50.810 --> 00:24:56.370
excuse me single layer and a dual layer
are really just double of each other.

466
00:24:56.370 --> 00:25:03.280
If I have a single layer Blu-ray disk,
I get 25 gigabytes in a single layer.

467
00:25:03.280 --> 00:25:08.064
Versus the biggest DVD which you've never
really seen too much of that you can

468
00:25:08.064 --> 00:25:09.544
get 17 gigs, right?

469
00:25:09.544 --> 00:25:14.479
So you can see,
there was a big I guess you would say war

470
00:25:14.479 --> 00:25:17.790
if you will for the storage medium.

471
00:25:17.790 --> 00:25:20.269
The next greatest format that
was gonna win out, right?

472
00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:24.430
Maybe some of you guys are old enough
to remember, some of you might not be,

473
00:25:24.430 --> 00:25:27.270
that there was a Betamax VHS competition.

474
00:25:27.270 --> 00:25:28.080
>> The Betamax.

475
00:25:28.080 --> 00:25:29.360
My goodness, really?

476
00:25:29.360 --> 00:25:30.132
>> That's right.

477
00:25:30.132 --> 00:25:33.790
And Betamax kind of lost overnight and

478
00:25:33.790 --> 00:25:37.020
a lot of the people don't even
remember it because VHS won out.

479
00:25:37.020 --> 00:25:40.920
Well, towards the end of
DVDs being considered what

480
00:25:40.920 --> 00:25:44.880
was gonna be a continued thing for
high definition,

481
00:25:44.880 --> 00:25:48.840
they did briefly have what was
known as an HD DVD, right?

482
00:25:48.840 --> 00:25:51.780
And they, I don't know who it was,
Toshiba or

483
00:25:51.780 --> 00:25:53.720
somebody like that was
actually promoting that.

484
00:25:53.720 --> 00:25:58.900
And by the end of the year,
they were making products at the beginning

485
00:25:58.900 --> 00:26:01.460
of the year or the beginning of
the quarter and by the end of the quarter,

486
00:26:01.460 --> 00:26:03.780
they have completely abandoned it and
hopped off to Blu-ray.

487
00:26:03.780 --> 00:26:08.200
So it's again, just competing formats,
it is something I want you to remember.

488
00:26:08.200 --> 00:26:10.790
Now there are file systems.

489
00:26:10.790 --> 00:26:12.182
Now, what is a file system?

490
00:26:12.182 --> 00:26:15.290
All right, I want you to think of
a file system as a logical structure on

491
00:26:15.290 --> 00:26:17.122
how we can write and read the data.

492
00:26:17.122 --> 00:26:20.620
All right, think about it,
I don't care what language you are.

493
00:26:20.620 --> 00:26:24.240
I hope you are watching in English,
because that's what I'm speaking,

494
00:26:24.240 --> 00:26:26.940
but doesn't matter what
language you speak, right?

495
00:26:26.940 --> 00:26:29.830
You have a format, you have an alphabet,

496
00:26:29.830 --> 00:26:33.480
you have a structure to how
the language is written, right?

497
00:26:33.480 --> 00:26:36.453
Well it is the same thing
with these optical drives.

498
00:26:36.453 --> 00:26:42.480
They have a format of how the information
is written to and read from the media.

499
00:26:42.480 --> 00:26:45.278
And we have got some different formats
that I want you to be aware of.

500
00:26:45.278 --> 00:26:49.156
In the original ones for
CDs it was called CDFS.

501
00:26:49.156 --> 00:26:52.450
Yes I know another acronym, and
it is compact disk file system.

502
00:26:53.490 --> 00:26:57.780
Now compact disk file system was really
good for uncompressed audio, but

503
00:26:57.780 --> 00:26:59.080
it did have some limitations.

504
00:26:59.080 --> 00:27:03.690
So they came out with another format and
that's the universal disk format and

505
00:27:03.690 --> 00:27:08.410
from then on, most of all of
your optical drives support UDF.

506
00:27:10.270 --> 00:27:12.540
Same thing with DVD.

507
00:27:12.540 --> 00:27:16.000
DVD doesn't support CDFS, that was
something in the very early days just for

508
00:27:16.000 --> 00:27:17.210
CDs.

509
00:27:17.210 --> 00:27:20.120
It supports the universal disk format.

510
00:27:20.120 --> 00:27:20.925
Same thing with with Blu-ray.

511
00:27:20.925 --> 00:27:25.680
Blu-ray started out I wanna say UDF 2.5
is when Blu-ray kind of came on board and

512
00:27:25.680 --> 00:27:27.930
they still have UDF today as well.

513
00:27:27.930 --> 00:27:31.900
All right, these are just some of
the things that we have to understand,

514
00:27:31.900 --> 00:27:33.840
but Zach's giving me that eye over there.

515
00:27:33.840 --> 00:27:36.391
Boy I've talked a lot about
optical disks and lasers and

516
00:27:36.391 --> 00:27:38.779
we didn't even mention
a single Star Wars reference,

517
00:27:38.779 --> 00:27:41.288
but it does look like we might
have to go into a part two.

518
00:27:41.288 --> 00:27:44.392
>> I didn't have a chance
to get in there with that.

519
00:27:44.392 --> 00:27:48.483
But install and configure storage devices,
so this is part one and

520
00:27:48.483 --> 00:27:52.136
part two will be coming up very,
very soon in A+ 901.

521
00:27:52.136 --> 00:27:54.856
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

522
00:27:54.856 --> 00:27:57.920
Remember, a good IT pro
is always learning.

523
00:27:57.920 --> 00:27:58.740
I'm Zach Memos.

524
00:27:58.740 --> 00:27:59.430
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

525
00:27:59.430 --> 00:28:02.162
>> We'll see you real soon.

526
00:28:02.162 --> 00:28:08.135
[MUSIC]

527
00:28:08.135 --> 00:28:11.052
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Wes and Zach continue the discussion of how to install and configure storage devices, 'magnetic hard disk drives' & the various rpm (5400-7200-10,000), 'hot swapable drive' vs. a 'cold swappable drive' & 'warm swappable drive,' solid state/flash drives, compact flash types-SD, MicroSD, MiniSD, xD, SSD, Hybrid, eMMC, and what a tape drive is including LTO tape.
episodes.title: Install and Configure Storage Devices Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:02.196
Welcome to ITProTV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.196 --> 00:00:05.912
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:05.912 --> 00:00:08.233
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.233 --> 00:00:11.900
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.900 --> 00:00:16.600
>> Hello again and thank you for making
the intelligent choice to watch ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.600 --> 00:00:19.300
Helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:19.300 --> 00:00:22.430
I'm your host Zach Memos as
we continue on with A+ 901.

8
00:00:22.430 --> 00:00:25.425
Install and configure storage devices.

9
00:00:25.425 --> 00:00:26.368
This is part two.

10
00:00:26.368 --> 00:00:30.762
We had part one, and now we're gonna
pick it up right here with, probably,

11
00:00:30.762 --> 00:00:32.418
magnetic hard disk drives.

12
00:00:32.418 --> 00:00:35.770
And Wes Bryan is the man bringing you
all the information you need to know.

13
00:00:35.770 --> 00:00:38.062
>> Hey Zack, thanks for
having me back, that is right.

14
00:00:38.062 --> 00:00:42.331
We've got a lot of different
storage mediums to talk about.

15
00:00:42.331 --> 00:00:45.660
Like Zach said in the first episode we
talked a lot about the optical drives.

16
00:00:45.660 --> 00:00:48.750
Remember we have three
primary storage types that

17
00:00:48.750 --> 00:00:51.150
really are something that
you're gonna need to know.

18
00:00:51.150 --> 00:00:54.070
Not only in the real world but
also pass that A+ exam.

19
00:00:54.070 --> 00:00:56.310
Remember, we talked about
optical drives in the first one.

20
00:00:56.310 --> 00:00:59.510
We have a laser that is
writing to removable media to

21
00:00:59.510 --> 00:01:01.260
mechanical drive, right?

22
00:01:01.260 --> 00:01:06.400
We mentioned magnetic media and
again, that's a mechanical type drive

23
00:01:06.400 --> 00:01:11.807
that uses some kind of electromagnet
energy to store and read information.

24
00:01:11.807 --> 00:01:13.720
And then we also have electronic storage.

25
00:01:13.720 --> 00:01:16.990
So, what we're gonna dive into first,
again, like Zach said,

26
00:01:16.990 --> 00:01:18.100
is the magnetic media.

27
00:01:18.100 --> 00:01:20.198
So, let's go ahead and
let's dive right in there.

28
00:01:20.198 --> 00:01:20.823
>> Yay.

29
00:01:20.823 --> 00:01:22.659
>> Now, when we talk about magnet media,

30
00:01:22.659 --> 00:01:24.990
there are different
types of magnetic media.

31
00:01:24.990 --> 00:01:30.070
There are what originally we had very
early on when it came to removable media,

32
00:01:30.070 --> 00:01:32.160
which is actually the predecessor,
if you will,

33
00:01:32.160 --> 00:01:34.910
to the optical disk were what
were known as floppy disks.

34
00:01:34.910 --> 00:01:38.043
In the earlier days, these floppy disks
could be up to eight inches long,

35
00:01:38.043 --> 00:01:40.782
pretty much looks like you could
roof a house with them, right.

36
00:01:40.782 --> 00:01:44.138
They were very, very big, looks like
a shingle out there on your roof.

37
00:01:44.138 --> 00:01:47.660
As time progressed,
everything's getting smaller and smaller.

38
00:01:47.660 --> 00:01:52.990
You probably have maybe seen that over
the years, if you look at pictures

39
00:01:52.990 --> 00:01:57.140
out there on the internet of old computers
and stuff everything seems to get smaller.

40
00:01:57.140 --> 00:02:00.070
Then we would have the five and
a quarter inch floppy disc and

41
00:02:00.070 --> 00:02:05.380
then finally before they pretty much CD
marked the pretty much the death blow for

42
00:02:05.380 --> 00:02:07.965
the floppies three in a half inch.

43
00:02:07.965 --> 00:02:09.792
That's a magnetic type media.

44
00:02:09.792 --> 00:02:13.761
Now what we have for internal storage and
this is internal and external,

45
00:02:13.761 --> 00:02:17.470
external meaning that you can plug
it into an external system port or

46
00:02:17.470 --> 00:02:20.030
connection on the outside
of the system case.

47
00:02:20.030 --> 00:02:23.996
Internal meaning, it's plugged
directly into the motherboard,

48
00:02:23.996 --> 00:02:26.630
is what are known as hard disk drives.

49
00:02:26.630 --> 00:02:30.346
Now in this episode I want you to
understand that what we're gonna do

50
00:02:30.346 --> 00:02:34.323
is we're just really kind of letting
you know what the technology is more

51
00:02:34.323 --> 00:02:35.251
in theory type.

52
00:02:35.251 --> 00:02:39.350
We do have another episode where we're
gonna talk about the specifics of

53
00:02:39.350 --> 00:02:42.251
the different technologies for
hard disk drives.

54
00:02:42.251 --> 00:02:45.563
We just kinda want you to understand,
what kind of storage mediums we have,

55
00:02:45.563 --> 00:02:47.064
what kind of storage devices, and

56
00:02:47.064 --> 00:02:51.120
then we'll get a little more specific in a
later episode on those actual connections.

57
00:02:51.120 --> 00:02:54.160
So what is a hard disk drive?

58
00:02:54.160 --> 00:02:56.020
Magnetic media if you will.

59
00:02:56.020 --> 00:02:59.658
I've got a little picture here, and one of
the things that you can see is that these

60
00:02:59.658 --> 00:03:03.172
hard disc drives, right, little boxes
that you see inside of your computer.

61
00:03:03.172 --> 00:03:06.226
They're actually made up of
a series of platters, right,

62
00:03:06.226 --> 00:03:10.325
a lot like a record player was,
if you look at the record players, right.

63
00:03:10.325 --> 00:03:12.385
And it has this little actuator arm.

64
00:03:12.385 --> 00:03:15.390
And this actuator arm floats back and
forth, right.

65
00:03:15.390 --> 00:03:18.020
The actuator arm is actually
what is responsible for

66
00:03:18.020 --> 00:03:22.750
using electromagnetic energy to
basically put a charge if you will.

67
00:03:22.750 --> 00:03:26.030
A magnetic charge on
different locations and

68
00:03:26.030 --> 00:03:28.840
points across these what
are known as platters right?

69
00:03:28.840 --> 00:03:31.884
And these platters do spin,
just like a record player.

70
00:03:31.884 --> 00:03:35.225
And they either are putting
a charge onto that platter, or

71
00:03:35.225 --> 00:03:38.580
they're just reading the charge
that's there, right.

72
00:03:38.580 --> 00:03:42.620
That's how it distinguishes our
binary information, our binary bits,

73
00:03:42.620 --> 00:03:44.740
if you will, ones and zeros.

74
00:03:44.740 --> 00:03:47.700
Now, one of the things I want
you to keep in mind is this

75
00:03:47.700 --> 00:03:51.080
actuator arm that you see is a lot
like a record player needle.

76
00:03:51.080 --> 00:03:55.278
There's a slight difference in the fact
that it sits off of these platters,

77
00:03:55.278 --> 00:03:56.403
its in the microns.

78
00:03:56.403 --> 00:03:58.340
And micron is one millionth of a meter.

79
00:03:58.340 --> 00:04:03.768
And we say a micron, we're talking
about so close to those platters,

80
00:04:03.768 --> 00:04:07.908
essentially, that even
something as thin as an ash.

81
00:04:07.908 --> 00:04:11.866
Fitting in between there could actually
scratch the platters themselves.
