00:27:32.720 --> 00:27:36.460
that's important to understand is that
you know the data is red sequential.

538
00:27:36.460 --> 00:27:41.450
Again its a magnetic interface, they are
removable media used for backups today.

539
00:27:41.450 --> 00:27:44.030
And you can see capacities anywhere,

540
00:27:44.030 --> 00:27:49.370
it commonly anywhere from 100 gigs all the
way up to 12.8 terabytes of information.

541
00:27:49.370 --> 00:27:53.980
And what I want you to know for the exam
is not some of the formats like they have.

542
00:27:53.980 --> 00:27:57.670
The most common format, if you wanna go
out and look is the Ultrium 8 standard and

543
00:27:57.670 --> 00:27:58.980
it's called the LTO tape.

544
00:27:58.980 --> 00:28:00.620
That's a Linear Tape Open Standard.

545
00:28:02.340 --> 00:28:06.410
And just for the most part, know that tape
drives are there, know that we use them.

546
00:28:06.410 --> 00:28:07.740
They're very high speed.

547
00:28:07.740 --> 00:28:13.288
They have the speed that those
spinning wheels can spin just as fast.

548
00:28:13.288 --> 00:28:18.640
If not, in some cases faster than
the internal magnetic drives that we have.

549
00:28:18.640 --> 00:28:23.870
The LTO standard, I think,
does about 160 megabytes sequential reads.

550
00:28:23.870 --> 00:28:28.310
And that's what the very first serial
ATA standard support have more.

551
00:28:28.310 --> 00:28:30.860
The original serial ATA
standard that came out

552
00:28:30.860 --> 00:28:35.250
only supported 150 megabyte
transfer speeds so very, very fast.

553
00:28:35.250 --> 00:28:37.000
Again, they're expensive.

554
00:28:37.000 --> 00:28:40.329
But they're typically used inside of
enterprises that need to archive their

555
00:28:40.329 --> 00:28:42.730
information and
they can't afford to lose it.

556
00:28:42.730 --> 00:28:45.290
>> Well,
Wes because magnetite degrades over time.

557
00:28:45.290 --> 00:28:49.810
Do they take that information then and
then store that somewhere else?

558
00:28:49.810 --> 00:28:52.180
>> That is a great question, yes they do.

559
00:28:52.180 --> 00:28:56.320
Because it is no different than some
of the issues you would have back

560
00:28:56.320 --> 00:28:58.580
when we had tape cassettes were so common.

561
00:28:58.580 --> 00:29:00.376
I'm sure you probably did this,
I know I did this.

562
00:29:00.376 --> 00:29:02.070
>> No,
>> Especially here in Florida,

563
00:29:02.070 --> 00:29:06.700
you leave it on the dashboard, you come
back after a good afternoon of very,

564
00:29:06.700 --> 00:29:08.510
very hot weather and the tape is warped.

565
00:29:08.510 --> 00:29:13.250
So they definitely have to seal
these in climate controlled systems.

566
00:29:13.250 --> 00:29:16.788
You have entire robotic machinery too.

567
00:29:16.788 --> 00:29:21.972
If you've ever seen some of your SCi-Fi
movies where you have an arm that comes,

568
00:29:21.972 --> 00:29:27.020
pulls a tape, pulls it down, those are,
that's what that machine is doing.

569
00:29:27.020 --> 00:29:29.606
That machine is finding tape
data then it's moving it down.

570
00:29:29.606 --> 00:29:32.940
That is very, very expensive,
but you might be that robot.

571
00:29:32.940 --> 00:29:33.465
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

572
00:29:33.465 --> 00:29:35.370
>> And it might be part of your job as

573
00:29:35.370 --> 00:29:36.330
a backup operator.

574
00:29:36.330 --> 00:29:37.490
But it's a great question.

575
00:29:37.490 --> 00:29:42.358
And you do have to store these in
a climate-controlled and secure system,

576
00:29:42.358 --> 00:29:43.757
or secure location.

577
00:29:43.757 --> 00:29:46.430
To make sure that you don't
lose the information.

578
00:29:46.430 --> 00:29:50.940
Because like any other magnetic media you
do run the risk of what's known as dot, or

579
00:29:50.940 --> 00:29:51.590
bit rod,

580
00:29:51.590 --> 00:29:55.940
or data rod in the fact that the media
can start to lose its magnetic charge.

581
00:29:55.940 --> 00:29:58.285
And you certainly can't keep
them next to like magnets,

582
00:29:58.285 --> 00:29:59.950
because it can scramble the information.

583
00:29:59.950 --> 00:30:01.020
And so

584
00:30:01.020 --> 00:30:07.430
those are some of the considerations that
we have to just know about and consider.

585
00:30:07.430 --> 00:30:09.850
>> Wes, awesome job, thank you very much.

586
00:30:09.850 --> 00:30:14.736
And this is part two of installing
configure storage devices, A+901,

587
00:30:14.736 --> 00:30:17.515
and you wanna catch part one and
there'll be a part three.

588
00:30:17.515 --> 00:30:19.040
[LAUGH] And thank you for

589
00:30:19.040 --> 00:30:23.550
watching ITPro.TV, where we help you
learn wherever your go, I'm Zach Memos.

590
00:30:23.550 --> 00:30:24.450
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

591
00:30:24.450 --> 00:30:26.752
>> And we'll see you real soon.

592
00:30:26.752 --> 00:30:32.698
[MUSIC]

593
00:30:32.698 --> 00:30:35.717
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: Wes and Zach conclude the discussion of how to install and configure storage devices, more discussion on flash drives with an overview of what a 'Hybrid' drive is, what are RAID types- type 0 (block level striping), type 1 (mirror), type 5 (parody bit & redundancy with striping), and type 10 (nested raid).
episodes.title: Install and Configure Storage Devices Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:04.190
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Prizet.

2
00:00:04.190 --> 00:00:06.468
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.468 --> 00:00:08.358
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.358 --> 00:00:11.914
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.914 --> 00:00:14.704
>> Hello again and
thank you for choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:14.704 --> 00:00:16.754
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.754 --> 00:00:20.727
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with A+ 901, and

8
00:00:20.727 --> 00:00:23.121
we're talking about storage devices.

9
00:00:23.121 --> 00:00:28.350
This is actually part three of installing
configured storage devices and

10
00:00:28.350 --> 00:00:30.910
Wes Bryan is gonna help us out
again like he always does.

11
00:00:30.910 --> 00:00:33.524
>> Yeah, we're working on a little
mini series here before you know it.

12
00:00:33.524 --> 00:00:35.294
>> Yeah.
>> We'll be challenging Stephen King for

13
00:00:35.294 --> 00:00:37.330
the amount of papers that
he's fit in the book.

14
00:00:37.330 --> 00:00:38.941
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right, well,

15
00:00:38.941 --> 00:00:43.945
we have just a couple really things that
we wanna tie up here in this episode.

16
00:00:43.945 --> 00:00:47.730
And in the past episodes we've been
talking about all different types of

17
00:00:47.730 --> 00:00:50.470
storage media that we can
see inside of our systems.

18
00:00:50.470 --> 00:00:53.580
For instance, we've been talking
about optical drives, right.

19
00:00:53.580 --> 00:00:59.960
Optical laser writes to your, or
burns if you will, the media and it either

20
00:00:59.960 --> 00:01:04.740
is lands or pits, raised or lowered areas
if you will, I think I did that backwards.

21
00:01:04.740 --> 00:01:07.700
How about raised or
lower areas there [LAUGH] and

22
00:01:07.700 --> 00:01:09.890
that's how it reads the information.

23
00:01:09.890 --> 00:01:13.330
Magnetic media using electromagnetic
charge to either read or

24
00:01:13.330 --> 00:01:16.090
write the information if
you will to the disk.

25
00:01:16.090 --> 00:01:18.290
And then we also talked
about electronic storage.

26
00:01:18.290 --> 00:01:21.830
Now one of the things that I didn't
mention and I kinda wanna double back to,

27
00:01:21.830 --> 00:01:26.380
is that we do have a type that kind of
blends two different storage medium types.

28
00:01:26.380 --> 00:01:30.680
And it really combines magnetic
storage with your electronic storage.

29
00:01:30.680 --> 00:01:33.230
And that's something known as a hybrid,
all right.

30
00:01:33.230 --> 00:01:34.330
And when we talk about a hybrid,

31
00:01:34.330 --> 00:01:37.700
we're not talking about using
vegetable oil to power your car.

32
00:01:37.700 --> 00:01:39.240
That's not really what
we're talking about here.

33
00:01:39.240 --> 00:01:42.190
We're using, I guess you could say
electrical it's kinda like that right,

34
00:01:42.190 --> 00:01:44.260
well let's go ahead and
follow that train of thought.

35
00:01:44.260 --> 00:01:47.334
Right, if you have a hybrid car
you're using some kind of combustible

36
00:01:47.334 --> 00:01:48.020
fuel, right?

37
00:01:48.020 --> 00:01:50.690
But at the same time, you could plug
it in and use electricity, right.

38
00:01:50.690 --> 00:01:53.140
You get best of both, if you will.

39
00:01:53.140 --> 00:01:55.910
Now, so what does a hybrid mean
when we talk about storage mediums?

40
00:01:55.910 --> 00:01:59.250
Well, with storage mediums, what we're
talking about is taking magnetic media and

41
00:01:59.250 --> 00:02:04.060
putting some of those electronic chips
into the same case, if you will.

42
00:02:04.060 --> 00:02:06.270
Now, what does this do for us, right?

43
00:02:06.270 --> 00:02:09.830
Well, what this does is this says that
information that's gonna be stored and

44
00:02:09.830 --> 00:02:11.660
we're not currently using, right?

45
00:02:11.660 --> 00:02:15.060
We don't need high speed access
necessarily to that information, so

46
00:02:15.060 --> 00:02:18.790
we can put it on slower
traditional mechanical media.

47
00:02:18.790 --> 00:02:21.900
And again, remember when I say that
we're not talking two separate devices,

48
00:02:21.900 --> 00:02:24.630
all built into the same hard drive,
itself.

49
00:02:24.630 --> 00:02:26.770
But however,
we have frequently used data, right?

50
00:02:26.770 --> 00:02:30.230
We have information that we gonna get
access to on a regular basis we're gonna

51
00:02:30.230 --> 00:02:32.970
use more frequently than
the infrequent data, right?

52
00:02:32.970 --> 00:02:35.480
So, we want faster access
to that information.

53
00:02:35.480 --> 00:02:39.495
So, what they come up with
is a combination of the two.

54
00:02:39.495 --> 00:02:43.605
And pretty much for the purpose of
giving you some kind of performance

55
00:02:43.605 --> 00:02:46.555
of a solid state drive and
still kind of keeping the cost down.

56
00:02:46.555 --> 00:02:48.125
And that's what a hybrid does.

57
00:02:48.125 --> 00:02:52.655
Really, a hybrid is mechanical,
moving platters, inside of that drive, and

58
00:02:52.655 --> 00:02:55.325
some of those NAND flash memory chips
that are sitting on a circuit board.

59
00:02:55.325 --> 00:02:57.915
And it says,
all of the frequently used information

60
00:02:57.915 --> 00:03:00.970
is gonna go into the NAND flash memory,
so that we can get to it quicker.

61
00:03:00.970 --> 00:03:05.344
The information that's not used or
is used a little bit less infrequently, if

62
00:03:05.344 --> 00:03:10.130
you will, or less frequently excuse me, is
gonna be stored on the mechanical drive.

63
00:03:10.130 --> 00:03:11.792
So that's one that I kind of
wanted to double back on.

64
00:03:11.792 --> 00:03:13.510
We wanna make sure that you
have everything here and

65
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:14.990
I was looking at my list.

66
00:03:14.990 --> 00:03:17.670
So ,definitely know that it's
a blending between of the two.

67
00:03:17.670 --> 00:03:20.970
>> So now is the time to
jump into the RAID types?

68
00:03:20.970 --> 00:03:24.100
>> That's right and
you'll commonly hear this called RAID.

69
00:03:24.100 --> 00:03:27.200
And when talk about RAID is we are not
talking really about pest control here,

70
00:03:27.200 --> 00:03:29.830
but what we're talking about is
something known is an acronym, right?

71
00:03:29.830 --> 00:03:31.535
And it's an acronym that's been around for
a while and

72
00:03:31.535 --> 00:03:33.655
you will here a couple of different terms.

73
00:03:33.655 --> 00:03:38.120
You'll here redundant array
of independent disks.

74
00:03:38.120 --> 00:03:40.660
More often, that's the common
term that it's been called.

75
00:03:40.660 --> 00:03:44.762
It used to be called redundant
array of inexpensive disks.

76
00:03:44.762 --> 00:03:49.443
And what I mean by that is when
RAID technologies first started

77
00:03:49.443 --> 00:03:53.584
to come into play, and
we could see some of the earliest

78
00:03:53.584 --> 00:03:58.192
kind of technologies if you will
starting to go toward RAID.

79
00:03:58.192 --> 00:04:01.420
What we had is things
like your DEC equipments,

80
00:04:01.420 --> 00:04:05.780
DEC corporation excuse me,
Digital Equipment Corporation and

81
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:10.639
companies like IBM that would have very,
very expensive hard drives.

82
00:04:10.639 --> 00:04:14.362
And they're big mainframes,
big systems right, very expensive.

83
00:04:14.362 --> 00:04:19.579
So a lot of different engineers, it's not
any one person, many different companies,

84
00:04:19.579 --> 00:04:23.684
actually made different forms of
what would later be called RAID.

85
00:04:23.684 --> 00:04:27.441
Because they called them inexpensive,
because it was inexpensive compared

86
00:04:27.441 --> 00:04:31.150
to the expense of the massive hard drives
that these big systems would have.

87
00:04:31.150 --> 00:04:35.450
So in the earlier days, they called it
the redundant array of inexpensive disks.

88
00:04:35.450 --> 00:04:39.380
However, later on, they decided
to change the acronym around and

89
00:04:39.380 --> 00:04:42.070
call it redundant array
of independent disks.

90
00:04:42.070 --> 00:04:45.220
Now, I don't want you to
worry about the semantics.

91
00:04:45.220 --> 00:04:48.568
We've talked about and joked [LAUGH]
Zach you and I have off camera tomato,

92
00:04:48.568 --> 00:04:49.223
tomato here.

93
00:04:49.223 --> 00:04:50.056
>> [LAUGH]
>> Although,

94
00:04:50.056 --> 00:04:51.800
I haven't heard anybody call it tomato.

95
00:04:51.800 --> 00:04:55.350
But that's just a little bit of semantics.

96
00:04:55.350 --> 00:04:57.170
However, what does that mean?

97
00:04:57.170 --> 00:05:01.110
Well, if I have one hard drive,
let's say that I take one hard drive and

98
00:05:01.110 --> 00:05:02.458
we have a drive controller right?

99
00:05:02.458 --> 00:05:06.970
The drive controller's the littlest
circuitry on the drive itself that allows

100
00:05:06.970 --> 00:05:11.985
us access to the information or access to
the storage medium to write information,

101
00:05:11.985 --> 00:05:13.615
to store information.

102
00:05:13.615 --> 00:05:19.255
Now, I want you to think about, if I have
one of those drives, and more specifically

103
00:05:19.255 --> 00:05:22.955
think about the drive controller
that's embedded into that hard drive.

104
00:05:22.955 --> 00:05:25.715
It's gonna do the work of one drive.

105
00:05:25.715 --> 00:05:27.769
But what happens if I think or
if I decide,

106
00:05:27.769 --> 00:05:30.725
maybe I want a little
bit better performance?

107
00:05:30.725 --> 00:05:35.760
Wouldn't it is nice to take two of those
hard drives and put them together.

108
00:05:35.760 --> 00:05:37.379
And now what we have
is a multi task right?

109
00:05:37.379 --> 00:05:39.832
We have two drives working in tandem,

110
00:05:39.832 --> 00:05:44.978
two drive controllers giving us access
to two separate drives at the same time.

111
00:05:44.978 --> 00:05:48.830
And that's essentially what
they call a RAID array.

112
00:05:48.830 --> 00:05:52.400
Now a RAID array is just
a aggregation of multiple disks.

113
00:05:52.400 --> 00:05:54.257
And you do it for
a couple of different reasons.

114
00:05:54.257 --> 00:05:56.544
The name implies, redundancy.

115
00:05:56.544 --> 00:05:58.100
Well, what's redundancy?

116
00:05:58.100 --> 00:06:01.050
Redundancy is having
more of any one system.

117
00:06:01.050 --> 00:06:02.062
I don't care if it's a hard drive.

118
00:06:02.062 --> 00:06:06.094
I don't care if it's a telephone system,
if you get more than one phone, right,

119
00:06:06.094 --> 00:06:09.380
just in case one phone dies,
you have a redundant system, right-

120
00:06:09.380 --> 00:06:10.906
>> Back up of the back up of the back up.

121
00:06:10.906 --> 00:06:13.140
>> That's right, back up and
the back up and the back ups, right?

122
00:06:13.140 --> 00:06:14.220
So we have more than one system.

123
00:06:14.220 --> 00:06:16.060
So it's about redundancy.

124
00:06:16.060 --> 00:06:18.450
All right now, what does redundancy mean?

125
00:06:18.450 --> 00:06:21.580
Redundancy or why do we implement
redundancy, more than one.

126
00:06:21.580 --> 00:06:24.380
Well, we implement redundancy
to achieve something known as

127
00:06:24.380 --> 00:06:25.700
fault tolerance, all right?

128
00:06:25.700 --> 00:06:26.600
What's fault tolerance?

129
00:06:26.600 --> 00:06:29.870
Fault tolerance is being able to
withstand a foreseeable failure.

130
00:06:29.870 --> 00:06:31.845
It's not a matter of if something fails,

131
00:06:31.845 --> 00:06:33.770
it's a matter of when something fails,
right?

132
00:06:33.770 --> 00:06:35.563
Mechanical drives fail, all right.

133
00:06:35.563 --> 00:06:37.977
So that's one of the big
things about RAID,

134
00:06:37.977 --> 00:06:40.203
redundant array of independent disks.

135
00:06:40.203 --> 00:06:44.410
Now, as time progressed, we have
industry wide standards and definitions,

136
00:06:44.410 --> 00:06:46.893
or if you will,
RAID types as they call it, and

137
00:06:46.893 --> 00:06:49.900
more specifically what
they call it on the exam.

138
00:06:49.900 --> 00:06:51.930
And there's different RAID types.

139
00:06:51.930 --> 00:06:54.770
And each one of them have their pros and
cons, and

140
00:06:54.770 --> 00:06:59.430
each one of them have their utilization
inside of our computing industry today.

141
00:06:59.430 --> 00:07:01.430
And it really means that
you have to pick and

142
00:07:01.430 --> 00:07:05.440
choose which one you want based on
the goals that you have to achieve.

143
00:07:05.440 --> 00:07:08.002
Let me go in here a little bit
more in to depth what I mean here.

144
00:07:08.002 --> 00:07:09.522
I've got a couple of
different RAID types and

145
00:07:09.522 --> 00:07:11.530
there are all different types
of RAID types out there guys.

146
00:07:11.530 --> 00:07:16.057
The most common standard and I don't
even want to say common standards, but

147
00:07:16.057 --> 00:07:21.000
the RAID types that we had for a long
time were zero through six, all right?

148
00:07:21.000 --> 00:07:25.637
The ones that you see 0 through 5 here,
0, 1 and 5, these are the most common,

149
00:07:25.637 --> 00:07:29.243
industry wide standards that have
been adopted for a long time.

150
00:07:29.243 --> 00:07:35.457
Things like 2, 3 and 4, these weren't
used as common as 0, 1 and 5.

151
00:07:35.457 --> 00:07:38.861
And then when we have what
are called nested RAIDs, right,

152
00:07:38.861 --> 00:07:42.550
where we have things like RAID 10,
RAID 50 and RAID 100.

153
00:07:42.550 --> 00:07:46.101
Thank goodness you only have to worry
about RAID 10 for this exam, and

154
00:07:46.101 --> 00:07:47.588
we'll get into what we mean.

155
00:07:47.588 --> 00:07:51.500
Okay, so when I say a RAID type,
I have these to choose from and

156
00:07:51.500 --> 00:07:55.213
I have to understand why I would
choose one over the other.

157
00:07:55.213 --> 00:07:58.771
When it comes to implementing a RAID for
the specific system that I'm supporting.

158
00:07:58.771 --> 00:08:01.926
>> Now, before you do that,
where does the RAID live?

159
00:08:01.926 --> 00:08:05.740
Does it live inside our
systems,our laptops, our PC's?

160
00:08:05.740 --> 00:08:06.790
>> That's a great question.

161
00:08:06.790 --> 00:08:09.690
So, in our expansion card episode,

162
00:08:09.690 --> 00:08:12.460
we've talked about things like
integrated functionality and

163
00:08:12.460 --> 00:08:16.660
expandable functionality and you can see
these in two different locations, right?

164
00:08:16.660 --> 00:08:19.850
We can see these either integrated
into the logic of the motherboard,

165
00:08:19.850 --> 00:08:22.400
that chipset that we said
understands video, audio,

166
00:08:22.400 --> 00:08:26.150
if you will,
can move your data across the motherboard.

391
00:19:50.590 --> 00:19:53.110
the amount of storage cuz
you actually lose storage.

392
00:19:53.110 --> 00:19:56.781
You benefit in redundancy, you lose
a little bit of the write speeds, right,

393
00:19:56.781 --> 00:19:59.780
cuz you have to do things twice or
more than twice, right?

394
00:19:59.780 --> 00:20:03.830
But you also lose some of the overall
capacity of the drive as well.

395
00:20:03.830 --> 00:20:06.570
Now, the next one,
the next one's kinda interesting.

396
00:20:06.570 --> 00:20:09.961
I really like this one because
this one's called RAID 5.

397
00:20:09.961 --> 00:20:15.580
And RAID 5, understand right away,
takes a minimum of three disks, okay?

398
00:20:15.580 --> 00:20:18.572
Now, notice that there's a little
bit more information in here than

399
00:20:18.572 --> 00:20:21.340
just our standard blocks
that we've been writing.

400
00:20:21.340 --> 00:20:23.462
Notice that I write to one disk.

401
00:20:23.462 --> 00:20:27.500
Then I write to the second
disk the second write.

402
00:20:27.500 --> 00:20:29.160
So we've got a stripe going on, right?

403
00:20:29.160 --> 00:20:34.390
Notice that RAID 5 has a stripe going,
write to this drive, write to this drive.

404
00:20:34.390 --> 00:20:36.770
But notice what happens
to the third drive.

405
00:20:36.770 --> 00:20:40.061
The third drive is where we write
something known as a parity bit.

406
00:20:40.061 --> 00:20:43.328
And like we talked about
in our memory episode,

407
00:20:43.328 --> 00:20:47.360
parity is about error detection and
correction.

408
00:20:47.360 --> 00:20:50.329
See, RAID 5 is called block
level striping, again,

409
00:20:50.329 --> 00:20:54.537
cuz we're striping our information
across the three drives within the set.

410
00:20:54.537 --> 00:20:57.366
But then after the writes,

411
00:20:57.366 --> 00:21:03.300
we end up having a parity
bit that's added, all right?

412
00:21:03.300 --> 00:21:07.910
And the parity bit allows us to calculate
information when one of the drives fails

413
00:21:07.910 --> 00:21:09.770
to understand what's still going.

414
00:21:09.770 --> 00:21:13.360
And let me go into a little bit more about
this because when we talk about RAID 5,

415
00:21:13.360 --> 00:21:17.770
it's actually block level striping with
what's known as distributed parity.

416
00:21:17.770 --> 00:21:21.620
Because as you'll notice, the parity bit,
as they call it, the parity information

417
00:21:21.620 --> 00:21:26.540
is distributed across all three drives,
and that's important, right?

418
00:21:26.540 --> 00:21:30.130
Because what happens when
one of these drives fails

419
00:21:30.130 --> 00:21:34.730
is the fact that the drive controller
still knows what's going on.

420
00:21:34.730 --> 00:21:38.980
Can still figure out the data that's
been striped, which is interesting.

421
00:21:38.980 --> 00:21:41.630
Remember if I have a stripe by itself and
one of the drives fails,

422
00:21:41.630 --> 00:21:43.600
it doesn't know that
we've lost everything.

423
00:21:43.600 --> 00:21:47.860
But now in this instance of striping,

424
00:21:47.860 --> 00:21:50.560
because we've lost a drive and
we have distributed parity,

425
00:21:51.620 --> 00:21:54.350
the drive controller or
the RAID controller knows what's going on.

426
00:21:54.350 --> 00:21:57.870
It knows and can figure out
the information that's missing

427
00:21:57.870 --> 00:21:59.950
based on the distributed parity bit.

428
00:21:59.950 --> 00:22:01.240
And that's one of the great things.

429
00:22:01.240 --> 00:22:03.430
The other thing that's good is,
and in the first part of this,

430
00:22:03.430 --> 00:22:06.820
we talked about hot swappable, and
I mentioned, Zach, how if I come in and

431
00:22:06.820 --> 00:22:10.830
I've got a blinking red light,
I have to replace that drive.

432
00:22:10.830 --> 00:22:14.212
RAID 5 arrays are great because they're
hot swappable, and if I have a RAID 5

433
00:22:14.212 --> 00:22:17.130
array with multiple disks in it,
minimum of three, and I come in and

434
00:22:17.130 --> 00:22:20.280
one of those drives has failed,
I can pull it out with the power still on.

435
00:22:20.280 --> 00:22:24.876
I can replace the drive, and because of
that parity bit, the drive controllers and

436
00:22:24.876 --> 00:22:28.423
the RAID controller can rebuild
the entirety of that drive, and

437
00:22:28.423 --> 00:22:30.084
I don't have to do anything.

438
00:22:30.084 --> 00:22:30.990
>> Fantastic.

439
00:22:30.990 --> 00:22:32.140
>> And that's one of the great things.

440
00:22:32.140 --> 00:22:36.200
So it implements redundancy with striping.

441
00:22:36.200 --> 00:22:40.220
Now you might say, well, that's gotta be,
I got the best of both worlds.

442
00:22:40.220 --> 00:22:41.961
Well, yes and no.

443
00:22:41.961 --> 00:22:45.420
All right, here's where you take
a little bit of a hit, right?

444
00:22:45.420 --> 00:22:49.473
Yes, you do get a little
bit of a performance gain,

445
00:22:49.473 --> 00:22:52.688
especially when it comes to your reads.

446
00:22:52.688 --> 00:22:57.900
I guess your reads still do well.

447
00:22:57.900 --> 00:23:00.600
Your writes slow down a little bit
cuz you have to add extra data,

448
00:23:00.600 --> 00:23:02.480
you have to add parity information.

449
00:23:02.480 --> 00:23:04.530
But the other thing to
keep in mind is that

450
00:23:06.240 --> 00:23:09.780
the RAID controller has
to calculate parity.

451
00:23:09.780 --> 00:23:12.620
Any time you calculate parity,

452
00:23:12.620 --> 00:23:15.910
you get an overhead on your
processing from the RAID controller.

453
00:23:15.910 --> 00:23:21.190
So you take a performance drop,
because you have to calculate

454
00:23:21.190 --> 00:23:25.710
other stuff other than your
information inside of that array.

455
00:23:25.710 --> 00:23:28.690
So remember RAID 5,
minimum of three disks, right?

456
00:23:28.690 --> 00:23:32.050
I lose one of the disks,
the stripe is still functional.

457
00:23:32.050 --> 00:23:36.043
We're gonna lose performance, but
we're not out of the water, right?

458
00:23:36.043 --> 00:23:41.029
And also keep in mind that we do have
to consider a couple things, and

459
00:23:41.029 --> 00:23:45.226
another thing, I should say,
and that is the fact that,

460
00:23:45.226 --> 00:23:49.433
remember we talked about our
drive capacities, right?

461
00:23:49.433 --> 00:23:53.810
And one of the things that we had said
is figuring out, like for instance,

462
00:23:53.810 --> 00:23:58.398
in RAID 0 We mentioned the fact that you
have a total capacity of all the drives

463
00:23:58.398 --> 00:23:59.528
individually, or

464
00:23:59.528 --> 00:24:04.800
your total capacity as adding up all
the drive's capacity individually.

465
00:24:04.800 --> 00:24:09.450
And the mirror, you lose, you only have,
basically, the capacity of one drive.

466
00:24:09.450 --> 00:24:13.444
Well, with the RAID 5, let's go ahead and
go back to that and kinda think about

467
00:24:13.444 --> 00:24:17.610
what the, how would we configure,
how would we figure that capacity out?

468
00:24:17.610 --> 00:24:19.260
Well, this is very simple.

469
00:24:19.260 --> 00:24:23.840
Take one of the drives,
drive capacities, set it to the side.

470
00:24:23.840 --> 00:24:24.374
That's all you have to do.

471
00:24:24.374 --> 00:24:25.030
Why?

472
00:24:25.030 --> 00:24:30.770
Because the parity information is equal
to a single drive capacity in an array.

473
00:24:30.770 --> 00:24:33.890
So like I said, you wanna figure out
what the capacity is on the exam?

474
00:24:33.890 --> 00:24:34.710
They give you something and

475
00:24:34.710 --> 00:24:37.110
they'll probably give you numbers
a little bit bigger than this.

476
00:24:37.110 --> 00:24:37.980
It's easy enough.

477
00:24:37.980 --> 00:24:42.060
Just remove that one drive capacity.

478
00:24:42.060 --> 00:24:46.680
Now you can see I've got a 200
gigabyte RAID array, right?

479
00:24:46.680 --> 00:24:48.022
That's how big that array is.

480
00:24:48.022 --> 00:24:49.491
>> With the RAID 5.

481
00:24:49.491 --> 00:24:50.990
>> It's kinda easy to figure out.

482
00:24:50.990 --> 00:24:54.540
And you could put more drives in a RAID
5 configuration, you get six drives.

483
00:24:54.540 --> 00:24:55.540
Still easy to find out.

484
00:24:55.540 --> 00:24:58.870
Take one drive capacity, remove it,
and add up the other five drives and

485
00:24:58.870 --> 00:25:00.240
you got the total.

486
00:25:00.240 --> 00:25:03.200
Now because of the fact that it takes
a little bit of the computational power

487
00:25:03.200 --> 00:25:08.000
to calculate the parity bit,
this is especially with gamers, right?

488
00:25:08.000 --> 00:25:10.460
Gamers don't spend thousands of
dollars on their, well they do,

489
00:25:10.460 --> 00:25:12.050
but give me a second let
me finish this thought.

490
00:25:12.050 --> 00:25:16.010
They don't spend thousands of dollars on
their systems to get slow performance.

491
00:25:16.010 --> 00:25:19.720
So what happened is now we
want the best of both worlds.

492
00:25:19.720 --> 00:25:24.660
We want not only speed of striping,
but we also want the redundancy, and

493
00:25:24.660 --> 00:25:28.680
we don't wanna take the performance
hit that calculating parity does and

494
00:25:28.680 --> 00:25:30.370
that's where the very last one comes in.

495
00:25:30.370 --> 00:25:33.260
This is called sometimes you hear
it called a couple of things,

496
00:25:33.260 --> 00:25:34.929
the most common thing is a Nested RAID,

497
00:25:34.929 --> 00:25:39.190
where you take one RAID technology and
nest it in another one.

498
00:25:39.190 --> 00:25:42.690
You might even hear it called Hybrid RAID,
it's more commonly though it's nested.

499
00:25:42.690 --> 00:25:47.900
And Nested RAID is what we have
when we talk about RAID 10.

500
00:25:47.900 --> 00:25:51.435
All right, when we talk about RAID 10,
let's go ahead and look at that.

501
00:25:51.435 --> 00:25:57.788
What we end up having is we have a set
of drives that not only blends RAID 1,

502
00:25:57.788 --> 00:26:05.720
all right, the mirroring, notice I have
mirrored sets, and they're striped.

503
00:26:05.720 --> 00:26:08.640
All right, and
that's essentially what RAID 10 is.

504
00:26:08.640 --> 00:26:13.450
I have a few striped mirrors if you will.

505
00:26:13.450 --> 00:26:18.040
Notice that we have two hard
drives that are a RAID 1,

506
00:26:18.040 --> 00:26:21.740
then we have two hard drives
that are also a RAID 1.

507
00:26:21.740 --> 00:26:24.918
But notice what's happening
to the upper level RAID.

508
00:26:24.918 --> 00:26:29.300
Right, I guess I have a mirror, but
I also have the stripe going on and

509
00:26:29.300 --> 00:26:31.650
we do this across all four drives.

510
00:26:31.650 --> 00:26:33.140
Now what's the benefit of this?

511
00:26:33.140 --> 00:26:34.990
If you look at any one of these drives,

512
00:26:34.990 --> 00:26:39.150
if it fails,
I still have every bit of my data and

513
00:26:39.150 --> 00:26:43.170
the RAID array is still functional and
there's no calculation of the parity bit.

514
00:26:43.170 --> 00:26:45.660
So now I get speed, and

515
00:26:45.660 --> 00:26:48.980
I get the performance, if you will,
I get the fault tolerance.

516
00:26:48.980 --> 00:26:51.920
However, keep in mind this
is a very expensive setup.

517
00:26:51.920 --> 00:26:52.913
>> [LAUGH] I was just gonna ask that.

518
00:26:52.913 --> 00:26:54.550
>> Yeah.
>> It's probably pricier.

519
00:26:54.550 --> 00:26:57.470
>> Yeah, it is very pricey, and
you would be absolutely right.

520
00:26:57.470 --> 00:26:58.810
Can you tell me why?

521
00:26:58.810 --> 00:26:59.720
You think about that?

522
00:26:59.720 --> 00:27:02.630
>> Well, it's the number of disks,
it's the number of functions,

523
00:27:02.630 --> 00:27:04.700
it's functionality, it's the whole bit.

524
00:27:04.700 --> 00:27:06.808
>> It's the number of
disks that it requires.

525
00:27:06.808 --> 00:27:10.213
It requires a minimum of four drives, so
you're gonna have to have a minimum of

526
00:27:10.213 --> 00:27:12.385
four drives to support
a RAID 10 configuration.

527
00:27:12.385 --> 00:27:17.600
So again, pros and cons to everything but
keep in mind this is all about having both

528
00:27:17.600 --> 00:27:22.533
the ability to mirror the drives for
the fault tolerance as well as striping.

529
00:27:22.533 --> 00:27:27.300
So you get the performance gain with
an overall cost hit, if you will.

530
00:27:27.300 --> 00:27:30.050
Those are some of the different RAID
types that I would be familiar with on

531
00:27:30.050 --> 00:27:30.710
this exam.

532
00:27:30.710 --> 00:27:34.170
And please understand them,
cuz they very well could ask you

533
00:27:34.170 --> 00:27:38.530
not only what are the RAID types, but also
how to calculate what the size might be.

534
00:27:38.530 --> 00:27:42.694
>> Install and configure storage devices,
A+ 901 part three, and

535
00:27:42.694 --> 00:27:45.582
there's part two [LAUGH] and
there's part one.

536
00:27:45.582 --> 00:27:48.190
And you can watch them all whenever
you want, which is a wonderful thing.

537
00:27:48.190 --> 00:27:49.980
Wes, marvelous, good job.

538
00:27:51.220 --> 00:27:55.860
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV, remember,
a good IT pro is always learning.

539
00:27:55.860 --> 00:27:57.640
I know I am too.

540
00:27:57.640 --> 00:27:58.440
I'm Zach Memos.

541
00:27:58.440 --> 00:27:59.130
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

542
00:27:59.130 --> 00:28:02.980
>> And we'll see you soon.

543
00:28:02.980 --> 00:28:07.622
[MUSIC]

544
00:28:07.622 --> 00:28:09.814
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore installing various types of CPUs and apply the appropriate cooling methods. Specific topics covered here includes: CPU socket types and CPU characteristics like speeds, cores, cache, hyperthreading, virtualization support, and architecture.
episodes.title: CPUs and Appropriate Cooling
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.312
Welcome to IT Pro TV.

2
00:00:01.312 --> 00:00:06.407
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.407 --> 00:00:08.284
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.284 --> 00:00:12.032
>> You're watching IT Pro TV.

5
00:00:12.032 --> 00:00:13.400
>> All right, greetings, everyone.

6
00:00:13.400 --> 00:00:16.920
And welcome to another
great episode of IT Pro TV.

7
00:00:16.920 --> 00:00:18.010
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:18.010 --> 00:00:19.270
And in today's episode, well,

9
00:00:19.270 --> 00:00:24.180
we are moving on with more
of our A+ 220-901 series.

10
00:00:24.180 --> 00:00:25.482
What a fun, fun thing to say.

11
00:00:25.482 --> 00:00:28.940
And joining me in the studio is
our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:28.940 --> 00:00:30.110
Wes?
>> It's great to be here

13
00:00:30.110 --> 00:00:30.790
today, that's right.

14
00:00:30.790 --> 00:00:34.560
And we are going to be looking at, well,
the brains of the operation, right?

15
00:00:34.560 --> 00:00:37.860
In the past episodes we've been talking
about things like your motherboard, right?

16
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:41.440
The motherboard is really
the backbone of the entire

17
00:00:41.440 --> 00:00:44.030
system unit as we call it, right?

18
00:00:44.030 --> 00:00:47.650
The overall Tower,
motherboard if you will,

19
00:00:47.650 --> 00:00:51.040
storage drives, or
hard drives if you will, storage devices.

20
00:00:51.040 --> 00:00:55.450
So we need to look at what really gets
our information processed, right?

21
00:00:55.450 --> 00:00:59.400
What is responsible,
if you will, for calculating,

22
00:00:59.400 --> 00:01:03.740
making the critical calculations that
really run the entire computing industry.

23
00:01:03.740 --> 00:01:05.950
And that's something known as a CPU.

24
00:01:05.950 --> 00:01:10.800
And, of course, just like any other A+
series, we wouldn't be without acronyms,

25
00:01:10.800 --> 00:01:13.290
a little bit of theory,
and some specifications.

26
00:01:13.290 --> 00:01:17.830
So when we look at CPU, right,
what is a CPU responsible for?

27
00:01:17.830 --> 00:01:21.100
But it is what really just
does all the arithmetic,

28
00:01:21.100 --> 00:01:23.520
does the logical calculations,
if you will.

29
00:01:23.520 --> 00:01:25.990
When it comes to working
with applications,

30
00:01:25.990 --> 00:01:27.810
when it comes to working your data.

31
00:01:27.810 --> 00:01:31.490
It is really one of the major
components that we have inside of

32
00:01:31.490 --> 00:01:32.280
the system unit collectively.

33
00:01:32.280 --> 00:01:33.380
>> One of a big four they say.

34
00:01:33.380 --> 00:01:34.770
>> That's right, that's right.

35
00:01:34.770 --> 00:01:36.210
I always call them the four horsemen.

36
00:01:36.210 --> 00:01:37.290
>> Yeah!
>> You're talking about the CPU,

37
00:01:37.290 --> 00:01:38.690
you're talking about your networking,

38
00:01:38.690 --> 00:01:41.690
you're talking about your hard drive,
if you will.

39
00:01:41.690 --> 00:01:43.730
And RAM, right?

40
00:01:43.730 --> 00:01:46.950
Memory, so yes,
definitely one of the major components.

41
00:01:46.950 --> 00:01:50.000
And it's really important to understand,
when it comes to a CPU,

42
00:01:50.000 --> 00:01:52.850
some of the characteristics
that they call out on the exam.

43
00:01:52.850 --> 00:01:56.810
And not only just from a theory standpoint
or from a certification standpoint.

44
00:01:56.810 --> 00:01:59.750
But just basically to kind of
understand what's going on.

45
00:01:59.750 --> 00:02:03.380
Now, in the earlier days when we
talked about CPUs, CPUs were very,

46
00:02:03.380 --> 00:02:04.730
very large devices.

47
00:02:04.730 --> 00:02:09.160
And some of these devices had different
socket types we've talked about in past

48
00:02:09.160 --> 00:02:09.710
episodes.

49
00:02:09.710 --> 00:02:12.150
We've talked about the two
major different socket types.

50
00:02:12.150 --> 00:02:16.320
And remember the socket is what
really makes the connection to

51
00:02:16.320 --> 00:02:20.130
the motherboard between the CPU itself and
the motherboard.

52
00:02:20.130 --> 00:02:23.990
Now we also made a mention of a couple
different types of sockets, right?

53
00:02:23.990 --> 00:02:28.290
There are a few different types out there,
but largely today, the two big guys on

54
00:02:28.290 --> 00:02:33.400
the block, right, Intel and AMD have
really kind of parted ways, if you will.

55
00:02:33.400 --> 00:02:34.870
If they were ever together to begin with.

56
00:02:34.870 --> 00:02:35.870
They've kind of parted ways,

57
00:02:35.870 --> 00:02:40.150
and each different manufacturer has
kind of made its choice, right?

58
00:02:40.150 --> 00:02:42.050
They've crossed that line in the sand and

59
00:02:42.050 --> 00:02:44.610
they've got two different
socket types that they follow.

60
00:02:44.610 --> 00:02:46.450
In fact, I've got a little diagram here.

61
00:02:46.450 --> 00:02:48.060
Let's kinda talk about the CPU.

62
00:02:48.060 --> 00:02:50.220
This is what's knows as an LGA CPU.

63
00:02:50.220 --> 00:02:52.570
This is where Intel went.

64
00:02:52.570 --> 00:02:54.570
And if you know,
it's called LAN grid array.

65
00:02:54.570 --> 00:02:56.410
And when we look at the LANs here,
if you will,

66
00:02:56.410 --> 00:02:59.611
they're just little pieces of flat metal,
right?

67
00:02:59.611 --> 00:03:03.340
Flatt copper, if you will, gold,
probably a little gold in there as well.

68
00:03:03.340 --> 00:03:06.310
You can even find things like platinum
across your motherboards, too.

69
00:03:06.310 --> 00:03:09.880
And if you notice that they're
flat electrical contacts-

70
00:03:09.880 --> 00:03:11.260
>> Because back in the day they used to be

71
00:03:11.260 --> 00:03:12.650
like sharp little pins that stuck off.

72
00:03:12.650 --> 00:03:13.450
>> That's right.

73
00:03:13.450 --> 00:03:15.840
And let's go ahead and
let's follow that train of thought, too.

74
00:03:15.840 --> 00:03:19.250

memory controller hub,

00:14:35.500 --> 00:14:37.680
and we'll just sit it
right inside of the CPU.

298
00:14:37.680 --> 00:14:40.840
They also put USB controllers
inside the CPUs today,

299
00:14:40.840 --> 00:14:44.460
and even integrated
graphics processing units.

300
00:14:44.460 --> 00:14:49.020
That’s right, your CPUs understand,
with a little a bit of help, with a GPU

301
00:14:49.020 --> 00:14:52.800
that’s built into the processor,
how to do calculations on graphics.

302
00:14:52.800 --> 00:14:56.836
Which is kind of interesting,
because remember, we've mentioned in other

303
00:14:56.836 --> 00:15:00.325
episodes that fact that a CPU works
on sequential streams of data.

304
00:15:00.325 --> 00:15:05.382
A GPU does parallel computing, right,
parallelism, if I can say that right.

305
00:15:05.382 --> 00:15:07.440
>> [LAUGH]
>> Where it can take a single piece of

306
00:15:07.440 --> 00:15:10.785
graphic, and do five different
things to it at one time, right?

307
00:15:10.785 --> 00:15:14.890
Well, imagine not having to send that
information out on an external bus into

308
00:15:14.890 --> 00:15:19.390
the graphics card, wait for the graphics
card to perform whatever its function is.

309
00:15:19.390 --> 00:15:23.727
And then receive that information back,
if we can pack it right there in the CPU

310
00:15:23.727 --> 00:15:26.631
itself, so
you might hear integrated GPUs as well.

311
00:15:26.631 --> 00:15:30.794
Now, getting back to the caching type,
all right?

312
00:15:30.794 --> 00:15:34.375
We talked about L1 cache,
L1 cache is the most frequently-used,

313
00:15:34.375 --> 00:15:36.548
instructions are gonna be stored there.

314
00:15:36.548 --> 00:15:41.293
And then it's prioritized, L2,
it's tiered, if you will, and

315
00:15:41.293 --> 00:15:45.135
then L3,
L2 cache has less frequent instructions.

316
00:15:45.135 --> 00:15:50.688
Now, L3 can also be a bank of memory,
that could be on the motherboard itself.

317
00:15:50.688 --> 00:15:57.444
Again, L1 and L2 are typically
integrated into the CPUs themselves.

318
00:15:57.444 --> 00:16:00.775
Now the other thing that they
call it is hyperthreading.

319
00:16:00.775 --> 00:16:05.600
Now hyperthreading is Intel's form of
something known as multithreading.

320
00:16:05.600 --> 00:16:07.033
It's been around for a very long time.

321
00:16:07.033 --> 00:16:12.440
The IBM mainframes have been doing
it since the late 60s and 70s.

322
00:16:12.440 --> 00:16:16.905
But remember what I told you, I said that
processors work on sequential streams of

323
00:16:16.905 --> 00:16:19.115
data, they're called threads right.

324
00:16:19.115 --> 00:16:23.758
The fact that we have, for instance,
multiple processing units if I could only

325
00:16:23.758 --> 00:16:27.014
feed one stream of information
into that CPU at a time and

326
00:16:27.014 --> 00:16:31.866
it's not efficient why should we have
six other cores, eight cores, 16 cores,

327
00:16:31.866 --> 00:16:35.216
32 cores, if you will,
sitting there doing nothing?

328
00:16:35.216 --> 00:16:40.173
So what we can do, if you will, is we
can put in multiple streams of data into

329
00:16:40.173 --> 00:16:43.821
the same CPU, and
that's called hyper-threading.

330
00:16:43.821 --> 00:16:48.950
Now, hyper-threading is kind of
a numbers game, if you will.

331
00:16:48.950 --> 00:16:51.085
It's back to more numbers games.

332
00:16:51.085 --> 00:16:56.680
Hyper-threading is interesting because
the fact that the registers, the little,

333
00:16:56.680 --> 00:17:00.300
little, smallest pieces of storage unit
within a computer's called a register.

334
00:17:00.300 --> 00:17:03.630
It stores one bit of data and
it's located in the CPU.

335
00:17:03.630 --> 00:17:06.380
They started to learn that
because processors are so

336
00:17:06.380 --> 00:17:09.540
fast, those registers
weren't always getting used.

337
00:17:09.540 --> 00:17:13.110
So what they found is a way in software
that they can logically divide it up,

338
00:17:13.110 --> 00:17:14.754
and if the operating supports it,

339
00:17:14.754 --> 00:17:18.512
which most of your operating systems have
supported this for a very long time.

340
00:17:18.512 --> 00:17:21.607
They could see it as more
than one physical core.

341
00:17:21.607 --> 00:17:26.793
And understand that you can have four
physical cores on the chip but you could

342
00:17:26.793 --> 00:17:32.000
feed in eight individual threads,
all right and that's hyper threading.

343
00:17:32.000 --> 00:17:34.819
Again, it's a multithreading
technology that

344
00:17:34.819 --> 00:17:39.571
allows you to put more than one stream of
information into the CPU at the same time.

345
00:17:39.571 --> 00:17:43.030
Now sometimes it benefits you,
sometimes they say it doesn't.

346
00:17:43.030 --> 00:17:46.507
Again, we're not here to debate that
because we can go down that path and

347
00:17:46.507 --> 00:17:47.544
be here a whole week.

348
00:17:47.544 --> 00:17:52.301
But just remember, hyperthreading means
I can put more than one stream of

349
00:17:52.301 --> 00:17:56.675
information into the CPU at once and
the operating system will see,

350
00:17:56.675 --> 00:18:00.300
let's say four physical cores
as eight logical cores.

351
00:18:00.300 --> 00:18:04.901
Again, the difference between the physical
is the actual hardware on the chip itself.

352
00:18:04.901 --> 00:18:07.910
Logical means it's represented
inside of software.

353
00:18:07.910 --> 00:18:11.650
>> Now Wes, where would we see
this hyperthreading business?

354
00:18:11.650 --> 00:18:13.117
Where is it employed?

355
00:18:13.117 --> 00:18:16.350
>> Well,
it primarily Intel based chips, right?

356
00:18:16.350 --> 00:18:18.486
If you go into your
Task Manager inside of Windows,

357
00:18:18.486 --> 00:18:20.931
typically you can bring up
things like your Task Manager.

358
00:18:20.931 --> 00:18:25.703
You bring up your Task Manager, you might
see that you have four cores, right,

359
00:18:25.703 --> 00:18:30.264
individual threads but what you'll
notice inside of Task Manager as well is

360
00:18:30.264 --> 00:18:33.700
you'll see that it represents
it as 8 logical cores.

361
00:18:33.700 --> 00:18:37.490
And then you say well, Dan,
I know I just bought a 4-core processor.

362
00:18:37.490 --> 00:18:39.323
I just bought it, it said quad core.

363
00:18:39.323 --> 00:18:44.261
But when I look inside of the operating
system I actually see 8 individual meters

364
00:18:44.261 --> 00:18:45.070
if you will.

365
00:18:45.070 --> 00:18:49.300
And that's typically where you see, you
see an inside of Intel-based processors.

366
00:18:50.370 --> 00:18:55.120
Now, the other thing that we have
to also talk about is, that with

367
00:18:55.120 --> 00:19:00.070
modern processors today,
we also have the ability provided that

368
00:19:00.070 --> 00:19:05.790
the processor supports it,
what's known as virtualization.

369
00:19:05.790 --> 00:19:07.790
Now, virtualization is
a very cool technology,

370
00:19:07.790 --> 00:19:09.760
another one that's been around for
a very long time.

371
00:19:09.760 --> 00:19:13.560
But it's typically, I would say, within
the past ten years, or prior to that,

372
00:19:13.560 --> 00:19:17.640
it was typically something you would
see in the enterprise environments.

373
00:19:17.640 --> 00:19:18.820
However it's become more and

374
00:19:18.820 --> 00:19:22.940
more common in just about every CPU
that you have inside a desktop PC today.

375
00:19:22.940 --> 00:19:27.313
Whether it be Intel or AMD,
supports the ability to run

376
00:19:27.313 --> 00:19:31.696
more than one operating
system on a physical machine.

377
00:19:31.696 --> 00:19:32.670
And that's a great thing.

378
00:19:32.670 --> 00:19:34.860
And that's essentially
what virtualization does.

379
00:19:34.860 --> 00:19:39.590
It means that I can have more than one
operating system controlling the hardware

380
00:19:39.590 --> 00:19:40.730
at any given time.

381
00:19:40.730 --> 00:19:45.011
Now be careful because what we aren't
talking about is what is called dual-boot.

382
00:19:45.011 --> 00:19:49.630
Dual-boot when we talk about a dual-boot
situation you boot one operating system

383
00:19:49.630 --> 00:19:51.460
and it takes over the hardware and

384
00:19:51.460 --> 00:19:56.500
then when I wanna run the other operating
system I have to shut the first one down.

385
00:19:56.500 --> 00:19:59.468
And then I boot strapped
the second operating system.

386
00:19:59.468 --> 00:20:03.928
When we talk about virtualization here
what we are talking about is the ability

387
00:20:03.928 --> 00:20:08.744
to run multiple isolated instances of an
operating system on one physical machine.

388
00:20:08.744 --> 00:20:13.510
And that is a very very handy thing
to have in today's day and age.

389
00:20:13.510 --> 00:20:16.670
If you're talking about PC then we're
talking about the ability to run

390
00:20:16.670 --> 00:20:18.290
testing if you will.

391
00:20:18.290 --> 00:20:21.870
Without having to have multiple machines
I can take one physical machine,

392
00:20:21.870 --> 00:20:24.880
more than one operating system very,
very good for testing.

393
00:20:24.880 --> 00:20:30.147
It also means that we could save space in
our server closet if we're talking about

394
00:20:30.147 --> 00:20:35.880
things like enterprise level environments
where you have a single physical computer,

395
00:20:35.880 --> 00:20:38.281
and you're running 4 or 5, 10,

396
00:20:38.281 --> 00:20:43.171
15 logical computers if you will in
a single device so very, very handy.

397
00:20:43.171 --> 00:20:45.244
All right, what else do we got here too?

398
00:20:45.244 --> 00:20:48.251
32 bit versus 64 bit.

399
00:20:48.251 --> 00:20:53.486
Now when we talk about 32 bit
architecture versus 64 bit architecture,

400
00:20:53.486 --> 00:20:57.230
this is based on
the capabilities of the CPU.

401
00:20:57.230 --> 00:20:59.885
When it comes down to it,
32 bit architecture and

402
00:20:59.885 --> 00:21:04.208
64 bit architecture have to deal with not
only the fact that the CPU supports it but

403
00:21:04.208 --> 00:21:06.584
really how much memory
the CPU can work with.

404
00:21:06.584 --> 00:21:09.839
Right, in a 32 bit operating system,
you're typically,

405
00:21:09.839 --> 00:21:11.650
you are restricted to four gigs.

406
00:21:11.650 --> 00:21:18.160
And in a 64 bit operating system there's I
don't wanna say that you aren't limited.

407
00:21:18.160 --> 00:21:24.110
But the limit is so astronomically large
that we don't really have home PCs or

408
00:21:24.110 --> 00:21:26.630
desktops, laptops,
if you will, it support.

409
00:21:26.630 --> 00:21:27.720
I think it's something like,

410
00:21:27.720 --> 00:21:32.230
I heard it one time it just like
16 exabytes of memory, right?

411
00:21:32.230 --> 00:21:35.419
It just means we get past that
four gigabyte limitation.

412
00:21:35.419 --> 00:21:39.540
And that is something that's important
to keep in mind is architecture.

413
00:21:39.540 --> 00:21:42.480
It means that if you have a 32-bit CPU and

414
00:21:42.480 --> 00:21:46.800
a 32-bit piece of hardware,
you have to run a 32-bit operating system.

415
00:21:46.800 --> 00:21:49.442
You cannot run a 64-bit operating system.

416
00:21:49.442 --> 00:21:54.049
Now, the interesting thing
though is if you have a 64-bit

417
00:21:54.049 --> 00:21:58.850
operating system,
yes you can run obviously a 64-bit CPU.

418
00:21:58.850 --> 00:22:01.026
Yes, you can run a 64-bit
operating system, but

419
00:22:01.026 --> 00:22:02.617
here's what's kinda interesting.

420
00:22:02.617 --> 00:22:05.522
You can actually run a 32-bit
operating system too.

421
00:22:05.522 --> 00:22:08.709
It's not recommended because what you do
is you basically reduce the amount of

422
00:22:08.709 --> 00:22:09.900
memory that you can see.

423
00:22:09.900 --> 00:22:13.263
So kind of as a recap, I want you to
remember that if you have a 32-bit

424
00:22:13.263 --> 00:22:15.439
operating system,
you have to or excuse me.

425
00:22:15.439 --> 00:22:21.643
I keep saying that, 32-bit CPU You
have to run a 32-bit operating system.

426
00:22:21.643 --> 00:22:26.035
If you have a 64-bit CPU,
you can run a 64-bit operating system and

427
00:22:26.035 --> 00:22:28.420
have access to a lot of memory, right.

428
00:22:28.420 --> 00:22:32.647
There really isn't much of a limitation
inside of our home PCs today or

429
00:22:32.647 --> 00:22:37.610
really even in our servers today,
outside of the manufacturers' limitations.

430
00:22:37.610 --> 00:22:42.210
But you could also run
a 32-bit operating system.

431
00:22:42.210 --> 00:22:46.912
Again, when you do that it's not wise
because of the fact that when you run that

432
00:22:46.912 --> 00:22:51.618
32-bit operating system on a 64-bit
platform you basically restricted

433
00:22:51.618 --> 00:22:55.194
yourself back to 4 gigs, so
definitely not recommended.

434
00:22:55.194 --> 00:22:59.316
One of the last things I wanna talk about
when it comes to the characteristics of

435
00:22:59.316 --> 00:23:02.700
the CPU is something they call
the execution bit or execute bit.

436
00:23:02.700 --> 00:23:05.490
And this is called a couple of
different things depending on what

437
00:23:05.490 --> 00:23:06.700
technology you're looking at.

438
00:23:06.700 --> 00:23:09.223
You might hear Windows and
their operating systems,

00:23:09.223 --> 00:23:12.373
they call it something known as DEP,
data execution protection.

440
00:23:12.373 --> 00:23:17.150
As far as the hardware goes you might
hear it called NX and that's no execute.

441
00:23:17.150 --> 00:23:19.169
And no execute basically allows for

442
00:23:19.169 --> 00:23:22.271
a portion of memory to be
flagged as non-executable.

443
00:23:22.271 --> 00:23:26.997
And that means that if data goes into
that location it cannot be executed

444
00:23:26.997 --> 00:23:28.820
from those regions.

445
00:23:28.820 --> 00:23:33.272
These features are basically supported in

446
00:23:33.272 --> 00:23:38.349
what's known as x86 and x64 technologies.

447
00:23:38.349 --> 00:23:40.180
That's probably another
thing that I wanna mention.

00:23:40.180 --> 00:23:43.943
I was gonna save that for the operating

You might hear terms like x86,

definitely 64 bit-

interesting so and l know you're a ware

880 six process like very early on
When everything was 16 and 32-bit.

And x86 is a CPU instruction set and
that instruction set,

I don't care where you're from.

We're in the States here

It's an extension of

Again, really for the exam just know

if you will,

26
00:00:52.440 --> 00:00:57.500
it's how many calculations can
a CPU form in a given second.

27
00:00:57.500 --> 00:01:02.538
And it is measured in hertz, remember
if you have a 2.8 gigahertz processor,

28
00:01:02.538 --> 00:01:04.920
like Dan mentioned in the first part.

29
00:01:04.920 --> 00:01:09.618
That's 2.8 billion calculations in a given
second, which is absolutely crazy and

30
00:01:09.618 --> 00:01:10.680
mind-boggling.

31
00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:12.844
We also talked about
multi-core processing.

32
00:01:12.844 --> 00:01:15.925
Multi-core processors are because
of the fact that processors have

33
00:01:15.925 --> 00:01:18.221
gotten smaller and smaller and
smaller over time.

34
00:01:18.221 --> 00:01:22.916
So they found a way that they could put
more than just one processing unit in

35
00:01:22.916 --> 00:01:26.180
the center of that little
green wafer that you see.

36
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:28.420
That is known as our CPU.

37
00:01:28.420 --> 00:01:30.160
We also talked about the caching system.

38
00:01:30.160 --> 00:01:36.670
Remember, because the CPU is so darn fast,
faster than anything on the CPU.

39
00:01:36.670 --> 00:01:40.710
If we have a common set of instructions
that the CPU is always calculating.

40
00:01:40.710 --> 00:01:44.625
We put those in a non-volatile
region of memory called cache.

41
00:01:44.625 --> 00:01:47.650
I don't know if I mentioned this,
but let me go ahead and mention it.

42
00:01:47.650 --> 00:01:50.692
It's called SRAM,
that's static random-access memory.

43
00:01:50.692 --> 00:01:54.177
So when the power's lost those
instructions do stay behind for

44
00:01:54.177 --> 00:01:55.480
a period of time.

45
00:01:55.480 --> 00:01:57.307
Remember it's a hierarchy, L1, L2, L3.

46
00:01:57.307 --> 00:01:59.968
Most common instructions in L1, and

47
00:01:59.968 --> 00:02:05.230
then it prioritizes the lower
priority instructions in L2 and L3.

48
00:02:05.230 --> 00:02:09.630
Both L1 and L2 are inside of the CPU,
most likely today.

49
00:02:09.630 --> 00:02:13.350
You even have portions of the motherboard
that might have a dedicated

50
00:02:13.350 --> 00:02:16.740
SRAM bank called L3 cache.

51
00:02:16.740 --> 00:02:18.100
We also talked about hyper-threading.

52
00:02:18.100 --> 00:02:22.468
Remember, hyper-threading is a way to
feed more than one sequential stream of

53
00:02:22.468 --> 00:02:23.324
information.

54
00:02:23.324 --> 00:02:25.872
Basically allowing, for instance,

55
00:02:25.872 --> 00:02:30.380
two applications to have their
data processed at the same time.

56
00:02:30.380 --> 00:02:32.350
We also mentioned things
like virtualization.

57
00:02:32.350 --> 00:02:36.330
The ability for the CPU to have
more than one operating system

58
00:02:36.330 --> 00:02:39.430
running in any single physical device.

59
00:02:39.430 --> 00:02:40.790
So all great things.

60
00:02:40.790 --> 00:02:44.740
We also talked about the architecture,
32 bit versus 64 bit.

61
00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:48.298
Keep in mind when we talk about 32 bit
we're talking about a limitation of 4

62
00:02:48.298 --> 00:02:48.965
gigs of rams.

63
00:02:48.965 --> 00:02:51.732
64 bit, we don't have that limitation.

64
00:02:51.732 --> 00:02:55.310
And there were some other
things that we talked about.

65
00:02:55.310 --> 00:02:58.270
But those are some of the bigger things
that you definitely have to know.

66
00:02:58.270 --> 00:03:01.272
If that doesn't make sense then
jump back over and see part one.

67
00:03:01.272 --> 00:03:03.570
And we'll see you here in a little bit.

68
00:03:03.570 --> 00:03:06.400
Now what we're gonna do is
we're gonna dive into well,

69
00:03:06.400 --> 00:03:09.940
what do we use to keep those CPUs cool?

70
00:03:09.940 --> 00:03:14.190
One of the major concerns when it
comes to any kind of system unit is

71
00:03:14.190 --> 00:03:15.970
proper thermal management.

72
00:03:15.970 --> 00:03:18.370
And what we mean by thermal
management is the CPU,

73
00:03:18.370 --> 00:03:21.080
we have a lot of voltage
being pumped into these CPUs.

74
00:03:21.080 --> 00:03:24.850
Dan, I've seen some boards that
are the higher end Intel boards where they

75
00:03:24.850 --> 00:03:27.910
have a dedicated 600 watts,
just to the CPU alone.

76
00:03:27.910 --> 00:03:30.380
Let alone what else you got
going on inside of your machine.

77
00:03:30.380 --> 00:03:33.120
So, they get very, very hot.

78
00:03:33.120 --> 00:03:37.750
So it is important that we are aware
of the different components inside

79
00:03:37.750 --> 00:03:41.300
of the system that help to
dissipate some of that heat.

80
00:03:41.300 --> 00:03:44.740
Now, things that we do talk about in other
episodes, I wanna just kinda mention here.

81
00:03:44.740 --> 00:03:47.590
Because although it's not expressly
called out on the objectives,

82
00:03:47.590 --> 00:03:49.350
you should know as an IT tech.

83
00:03:49.350 --> 00:03:53.340
Inside of any kind of A+ situation and
on the exam.

84
00:03:53.340 --> 00:03:57.740
Remember one of the first starting points
of your cooling system is your case.

85
00:03:57.740 --> 00:04:02.862
You have strategically placed vents,
if you will, in the ATX motherboards.

86
00:04:02.862 --> 00:04:06.990
One of the things that standard
did is it kind of reversed

87
00:04:06.990 --> 00:04:08.900
the way the circulation would be done.

88
00:04:08.900 --> 00:04:14.520
What happens is it brings cool air in
combination with fans into the system.

89
00:04:14.520 --> 00:04:16.660
As the heat rises the fans exhaust,

90
00:04:16.660 --> 00:04:19.130
if you will,
the heat out of the back of the case.

91
00:04:19.130 --> 00:04:22.200
Keep in mind during normal operations

92
00:04:22.200 --> 00:04:26.380
your case within your system
unit needs to stay closed.

93
00:04:26.380 --> 00:04:28.390
Because it is part of the cooling unit.

94
00:04:28.390 --> 00:04:30.070
So, I do wanna make mention of that.

95
00:04:30.070 --> 00:04:32.730
It's not, again,
in the formal objectives here.

96
00:04:32.730 --> 00:04:35.180
There is one other thing that's
not in the objectives, here,

97
00:04:35.180 --> 00:04:38.360
either when it comes to cooling,
and that's also your power supply.

98
00:04:38.360 --> 00:04:40.120
The other thing with the ATX motherboard,

99
00:04:40.120 --> 00:04:43.340
that standard that's been around
since 1995 when Intel released it.

100
00:04:43.340 --> 00:04:47.608
Is it rotated the entire board and put the
CPU directly under the power supply fan.

101
00:04:47.608 --> 00:04:51.180
So that the power supply fan
could help to assist the cooling.

102
00:04:51.180 --> 00:04:52.590
So, a couple of things,

103
00:04:52.590 --> 00:04:55.430
like I said, that aren't here in
the objectives that we're talking about.

104
00:04:55.430 --> 00:04:59.375
But a major part of your
overall cooling system.

105
00:04:59.375 --> 00:05:02.490
Cuz, well, Dan you read off
the title here, Appropriate Cooling.

106
00:05:02.490 --> 00:05:05.530
And it's not just about what's
up with the objectives.

107
00:05:05.530 --> 00:05:08.742
So that being said,
let's go ahead and talk about,

108
00:05:08.742 --> 00:05:11.808
when it comes to the CPU itself,
one of our first,

109
00:05:11.808 --> 00:05:15.913
if you will, primary components
in this overall cooling system.

110
00:05:15.913 --> 00:05:19.270
And that's something known as a heat sink.

111
00:05:19.270 --> 00:05:21.073
And I've got a little bit
of a diagram here and

112
00:05:21.073 --> 00:05:23.272
we'll actually look at a heat sink,
too, coming up.

113
00:05:23.272 --> 00:05:28.810
I can almost guarantee you, this is
probably a diagram of some AMD socket.

114
00:05:28.810 --> 00:05:31.770
Because of that zero insertion
force socket that we talked about.

115
00:05:31.770 --> 00:05:33.960
The little handle we showed you in
the motherboard when I opened it up.

116
00:05:33.960 --> 00:05:35.640
It kinda pulls the socket back and

117
00:05:35.640 --> 00:05:38.520
releases those pins that
it's grabbing onto.

118
00:05:38.520 --> 00:05:42.140
Well, notice this little piece,
it almost looks like a radiator, right?

119
00:05:42.140 --> 00:05:45.090
This radiator is what's
known as the heat sink.

120
00:05:45.090 --> 00:05:48.420
And what the heat sink is is really
nothing more than a radiator that's

121
00:05:48.420 --> 00:05:50.350
a piece of metal, if you will.

122
00:05:50.350 --> 00:05:52.880
And what it does is it actually,
in theory,

123
00:05:52.880 --> 00:05:57.930
it increases the surface
area of the CPU drastically.

124
00:05:57.930 --> 00:06:00.150
And that's because if you
would take a hammer, right?

125
00:06:00.150 --> 00:06:02.970
And you were to mill this down
to a flat piece of metal.

126
00:06:02.970 --> 00:06:04.290
And I don't know what the percentage is,

127
00:06:04.290 --> 00:06:06.790
I've heard it before I can't think
of it at the top of my head.

128
00:06:06.790 --> 00:06:10.407
That it will be a big flat piece of
metal and that's what is supposed to do.

129
00:06:10.407 --> 00:06:13.960
It's supposed to increase
the surface area of the CPU.

130
00:06:13.960 --> 00:06:18.400
Now the other thing that it does is it
actually draws heat into these valleys

131
00:06:18.400 --> 00:06:20.590
right here, into the valleys between it.

132
00:06:20.590 --> 00:06:23.537
And what you'll see is that we have
something on top of it known as

133
00:06:23.537 --> 00:06:24.145
the CPU fan.

134
00:06:24.145 --> 00:06:28.887
And the CPU fan is responsible for
taking that air that's essentially

135
00:06:28.887 --> 00:06:33.370
heated up within those valleys and
it kind of dissipates it away.

136
00:06:33.370 --> 00:06:38.770
Blows it out of the heat sink itself,
so that it helps to assist the cooling.

137
00:06:38.770 --> 00:06:43.788
Now, more specifically, when you have
a fan like this with a heat sink,

138
00:06:43.788 --> 00:06:47.259
that is what is known as
an active cooling system.

139
00:06:47.259 --> 00:06:50.905
You also what are known as
passive cooling systems.

140
00:06:50.905 --> 00:06:54.401
And these passive cooling systems
are found in things like your very,

141
00:06:54.401 --> 00:06:56.770
very small form factor motherboards.

142
00:06:56.770 --> 00:07:02.780
Like the microATX, mini-ITX,
Pico-ITX boards that they have now.

143
00:07:02.780 --> 00:07:06.000
And that's because they use
very low power CPUs, so

144
00:07:06.000 --> 00:07:07.690
they don't generate a lot of heat.

145
00:07:07.690 --> 00:07:09.531
Low power CPUs don't
generate a lot of heat,

146
00:07:09.531 --> 00:07:11.135
we can just put the heat sink on itself.

147
00:07:11.135 --> 00:07:15.720
And it's doing its job passively,
that's a passive cooling system.

148
00:07:15.720 --> 00:07:20.450
Or sometimes called fanless,
if you will, really for obvious reasons.

149
00:07:20.450 --> 00:07:22.940
Now let's go ahead and
let's kinda look at this motherboard.

150
00:07:22.940 --> 00:07:27.149
We've got all different
kinds of cooling units here.

151
00:07:27.149 --> 00:07:29.069
And I was kinda joking around with Dan,
I said,

152
00:07:29.069 --> 00:07:29.850
look at the size-
>> [LAUGH]

153
00:07:29.850 --> 00:07:30.380
>> Of this heat sink, here.

154
00:07:30.380 --> 00:07:31.663
Talk about [CROSSTALK]
>> You'll notice

155
00:07:31.663 --> 00:07:32.896
it's the size of your hand.

156
00:07:32.896 --> 00:07:33.454
[LAUGH]
>> That's right.

157
00:07:33.454 --> 00:07:37.637
[LAUGH] Dan suggested that I wear
this as a hat as big this sucker is.

158
00:07:37.637 --> 00:07:38.942
>> [LAUGH]
>> Probably

159
00:07:38.942 --> 00:07:40.443
contact the mothership while I'm at it.

160
00:07:40.443 --> 00:07:41.012
>> Yes.

161
00:07:41.012 --> 00:07:42.525
>> But notice the flat surface, here.

162
00:07:42.525 --> 00:07:46.786
Well, I want you to understand, too, that
there are a couple of extra things that we

163
00:07:46.786 --> 00:07:49.078
have with the heat sink
that go along with it.

164
00:07:49.078 --> 00:07:51.403
It's not just the heat sink and
just the fan.

165
00:07:51.403 --> 00:07:55.130
But you can see that it's kinda
like a heat exchange system.

166
00:07:55.130 --> 00:07:58.608
System, right?
Where it pulls the heat away from the CPU.

167
00:07:58.608 --> 00:08:02.941
As the CPU heats up, it brings this
hot air, or the heat, into itself,

168
00:08:02.941 --> 00:08:06.080
and it dissipates it up
into the vents here.

169
00:08:06.080 --> 00:08:09.840
And then, if we have a fan on place,
I believe this fan,

170
00:08:09.840 --> 00:08:13.420
if I remember right, was side mounted
here, and it would blow it out the side.

171
00:08:13.420 --> 00:08:17.250
But keep in mind, you also have
top-mounted fans like you see here too.

172
00:08:17.250 --> 00:08:20.467
Now, if you're a little OCD,
you might notice something about this fan,

173
00:08:20.467 --> 00:08:21.550
is it's kinda twisted.

174
00:08:21.550 --> 00:08:24.600
I know one of our other host here
didn't like these, like man,

175
00:08:24.600 --> 00:08:28.070
I need to be asymmetrical or
symmetry, that's right, symmetrical.

176
00:08:28.070 --> 00:08:29.046
>> That's right, yeah.

177
00:08:29.046 --> 00:08:32.680
>> And don't worry about that, because
this one here, if I was to lift this up

178
00:08:32.680 --> 00:08:37.090
just a little bit, you'll see that this is
actually more of like a cylinder, right?

179
00:08:37.090 --> 00:08:38.607
But the principle is the same.

180
00:08:38.607 --> 00:08:44.220
And then what you have is you have a fan
that spins and it blows the hot air away.

181
00:08:44.220 --> 00:08:47.705
Keep in mind that it's typically
connected to the motherboard, and

182
00:08:47.705 --> 00:08:51.310
that's something that you want
because part of the chipset, really,

183
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:54.673
the BIOS or the UA FI system,
it can actually detect what the heat,

184
00:08:54.673 --> 00:08:58.580
the core temperature, core voltage,
core temperature of the CPU.

185
00:08:58.580 --> 00:09:02.780
And as that heat rises,
it can apply more voltage to this fan, and

186
00:09:02.780 --> 00:09:05.540
it can increase the RPMs within the fan.

187
00:09:05.540 --> 00:09:07.100
Now that's not the only thing we have,
too.

188
00:09:07.100 --> 00:09:12.168
Remember, I told you that the system
unit also has system fans as well.

189
00:09:12.168 --> 00:09:14.494
And we've got a few
different types back here,

190
00:09:14.494 --> 00:09:17.630
you can see that they are all
different shapes and sizes.

191
00:09:17.630 --> 00:09:22.122
And I wanna talk real briefly about the
different shapes or sizes that we have.

192
00:09:22.122 --> 00:09:25.960
Because there's some different
characteristics, and honestly ladies and

193
00:09:25.960 --> 00:09:31.100
gents, I don't know how specific they're
gonna be to the characteristics of a fan,

194
00:09:31.100 --> 00:09:32.210
but you should know this.

195
00:09:32.210 --> 00:09:35.020
We've kind of said throughout this
series that it's not just about

196
00:09:35.020 --> 00:09:37.920
what's on the certification,
objectives as well.

197
00:09:37.920 --> 00:09:40.320
But it's about making you trained
if you're gonna be an IT tech.

198
00:09:40.320 --> 00:09:42.060
It kind of gives you the information.

199
00:09:42.060 --> 00:09:47.140
This is what's known, if I remember right,
this is a 120 millimeter fan, I believe.

200
00:09:47.140 --> 00:09:50.300
They do have slightly bigger,
those not quite as common,

201
00:09:50.300 --> 00:09:54.430
unless you're talking about a gaming
rig and that's 240 millimeter fans.

202
00:09:54.430 --> 00:09:58.910
This is a common sized fan here,
in fact 120 millimeters, you'll find

203
00:09:58.910 --> 00:10:03.480
a lot of cases that have brackets here
that already line up to this type of fan.

204
00:10:03.480 --> 00:10:07.165
This is typically the fan that's
gonna be set on the front and

205
00:10:07.165 --> 00:10:08.580
on the rear of the case.

206
00:10:08.580 --> 00:10:11.020
And again, you'll have to pay attention.

207
00:10:11.020 --> 00:10:13.150
I don't know if this one has it on it.

00:10:13.150 --> 00:10:16.420
Usually what you can see
on the top somewhere.

209
00:10:16.420 --> 00:10:18.116
And yeah, I don't see it on this one.

00:10:18.116 --> 00:10:21.940
You'll have directions that
shows you which way this spins.

211
00:10:21.940 --> 00:10:25.104
And you've gotta keep in mind
that on the front of the case,

212
00:10:25.104 --> 00:10:27.590
due to the ATX standard,
it’s an intake fan.

213
00:10:27.590 --> 00:10:32.140
So it draws cool air and as the heat
rises, the rear fan is typically going

214
00:10:32.140 --> 00:10:36.010
to exhaust fan, so it’s a pull push
system, if I believe I said that right.

215
00:10:36.010 --> 00:10:40.590
And this is also got the little four-pin,
it's called a Molex KK connector.

216
00:10:40.590 --> 00:10:42.600
And again,
I don't know how specific they'll get.

217
00:10:42.600 --> 00:10:46.421
But just keep in mind that when you have
the fourth pin, what you do is you have

218
00:10:46.421 --> 00:10:50.723
your positive, you have your negative, you
have your ground, and then you also have

219
00:10:50.723 --> 00:10:55.245
a fourth pin that the BIOS can actually
control or the UEFI system can control.

220
00:10:55.245 --> 00:10:58.255
Doing things like detecting
the RPMs in the fan.

221
00:10:58.255 --> 00:11:02.565
If it's a variable speed fan, it can
apply more voltage and raise the RPMs.

222
00:11:02.565 --> 00:11:06.100
Now, remember that RPMs guys,
we're talking about no different than when

223
00:11:06.100 --> 00:11:07.860

anything else.

We're talking revolutions per minute.

225
00:11:09.790 --> 00:11:11.190
And that might be a contributing factor.

00:11:11.190 --> 00:11:15.930
Not only the size of the fan, common

00:11:15.930 --> 00:11:16.740
That's an 80 millimeter fan,

I've seen some gaming rigs

And it's all relative too, to where

00:11:35.610 --> 00:11:41.060
Now, they don't always have to follow a

234
00:11:41.060 --> 00:11:42.680
yeah, see this one doesn't.

You can see it's a slightly smaller, so to

I want to say this is the one

00:11:53.790 --> 00:11:56.413
That's not so important,

00:11:56.413 --> 00:11:58.650
But you also have bearings in there too.

240
00:11:58.650 --> 00:12:00.424
So the real takeaway from this,

00:12:00.424 --> 00:12:04.390
I want you to know about these

RPMs, the millimeters, again a 240, a 120,

and you have the 80
millimeter fans likewise.

244

RPMs, like I said.

And then theres another thing,
couple of other things believe it or

00:12:18.589 --> 00:12:24.320
not that are a factor when it comes to
the purchasing of fan, and those are CFMs.

247
00:12:24.320 --> 00:12:28.804
That's one of the first ones, and
that's the cubic feet per minute,

248
00:12:28.804 --> 00:12:31.870

00:24:15.040 --> 00:24:19.750
the bulldozer architecture, or typically
what's known as the FX series for

471
00:24:19.750 --> 00:24:24.140
a brief time and also supported
the Phenom 2, Athlon 2, and Sempron.

472
00:24:26.050 --> 00:24:32.580
Now, the last three here, these last three
are what are considered APU's and we

473
00:24:32.580 --> 00:24:37.180
haven't really talked about that and that
and that's Accelerated Processing Units.

474
00:24:37.180 --> 00:24:42.630
And they're lower powered and they also
support things like graphics as well.

475
00:24:42.630 --> 00:24:46.927
The FM1,
this was called the LANO processor, right?

476
00:24:46.927 --> 00:24:54.850
This was the LANO processor as well as
the Gen 2 Accelerated Processing Unit,

477
00:24:54.850 --> 00:24:59.640
make sure I get that acronym right, and
that was the AMD Trinity technology.

478
00:24:59.640 --> 00:25:04.707
Last one is the AM2+, and again, remember
these FMs, they're low powered, right?

479
00:25:04.707 --> 00:25:11.610
Again, low powered boards, they save you
money and also, they generate less heat.

480
00:25:11.610 --> 00:25:14.510
That's the FM2+, and
again, that APU is for

481
00:25:14.510 --> 00:25:19.660
the Kaveri and this last one almost sounds
like chocolate, and that's Godavari.

482
00:25:19.660 --> 00:25:21.500
Not Ghirardelli but Godavari.

483
00:25:21.500 --> 00:25:26.330
So, Aaain guys I know the last bit here,
man we threw a bunch of specifications.

484
00:25:26.330 --> 00:25:29.670
And guys like I've said,
many times throughout this series,

485
00:25:29.670 --> 00:25:32.470
it's like setups and you guys can
look at me know I hate setups.

486
00:25:32.470 --> 00:25:39.270
But, I want you to take Dan's advise get
out the flash cards, type the notes.

487
00:25:39.270 --> 00:25:43.190
I remember when was studying for
A+ I literally would write these down and

488
00:25:43.190 --> 00:25:44.810
I'd crumple up the paper and
throw it away.

489
00:25:44.810 --> 00:25:47.180
And then write them down,
crumple up the paper and throw them away.

490
00:25:47.180 --> 00:25:50.637
And then once I'd passed the exam,
I'd do exactly what Dan said,

491
00:25:50.637 --> 00:25:53.310
I'd Google it right and
add it to the motherboard.

492
00:25:53.310 --> 00:25:55.865
>> [LAUGH]
>> So a lot of specifications guys, but

493
00:25:55.865 --> 00:25:57.610
don't let it confuse you.

494
00:25:57.610 --> 00:26:00.890
Don't let it intimidate you,
just dig in, memorize it, and

495
00:26:00.890 --> 00:26:02.760
you can pass the A+ certification as well.

496
00:26:02.760 --> 00:26:05.560
>> That's right, well Wes says
talking about is that repetition,

497
00:26:05.560 --> 00:26:06.990
it breeds retention.

498
00:26:06.990 --> 00:26:08.840
Don't forget that, so go over and over and

499
00:26:08.840 --> 00:26:10.855
over and
over until it's like second nature to you.

500
00:26:10.855 --> 00:26:13.962
You're just got to sit in that testing
booth and you'll smoke this thing out.

501
00:26:13.962 --> 00:26:16.430
All right everyone, it looks like we've
come to the end of today's episode.

502
00:26:16.430 --> 00:26:17.110
We do thank you for

503
00:26:17.110 --> 00:26:20.350
watching, signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

504
00:26:20.350 --> 00:26:21.060
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

505
00:26:21.060 --> 00:26:22.191
>> And we'll see you next time.

506

[MUSIC]

507
