>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes begin the vast conversation that is PC connections and characteristics. Specific topics covered here includes: Universal Serial Bus(USB) and Firewire 1394.
episodes.title: PC Connections and Characteristics
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.180 --> 00:00:02.704
Welcome to IT Pro TV I'm
your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.704 --> 00:00:06.704
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.704 --> 00:00:08.319
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.319 --> 00:00:12.380
>> You're watching ITProv TV.

5
00:00:12.380 --> 00:00:16.287
>> All right greeting everyone and welcome
to another great episode of ITPro TV.

6
00:00:16.287 --> 00:00:20.891
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode well we are moving on,

7
00:00:20.891 --> 00:00:24.636
with more on our A+,
what is it, the 229-01 series.

8
00:00:24.636 --> 00:00:29.217
That's right, good stuff here, joining us
in the studio again is our good friend,

9
00:00:29.217 --> 00:00:30.140
Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:32.740
Wes, I'm so glad to have you in
the studio again, man, how's it going?

11
00:00:32.740 --> 00:00:36.360
>> Hey, man, it's going great, great to be
here as always with the ITPro TV crew, and

12
00:00:36.360 --> 00:00:40.990
that's right, like Dan says, we are moving
along in this journey that hopefully

13
00:00:40.990 --> 00:00:44.840
leads you to a passing score
on that A+ certification.

14
00:00:44.840 --> 00:00:46.550
And well, what are we talking about today?

15
00:00:46.550 --> 00:00:50.360
But, well, we're gonna be talking about
connections, all kinds of connections.

16
00:00:50.360 --> 00:00:54.470
If you've ever looked at any desktop
that's sitting on the ground,

17
00:00:54.470 --> 00:00:58.190
one of the things you've probably noticed
is that there is a lot of times a rat's

18
00:00:58.190 --> 00:00:59.735
nest hanging off the back of that.

19
00:00:59.735 --> 00:01:03.407
Well, we're gonna follow those
those wires to the ports and

20
00:01:03.407 --> 00:01:08.159
connections on the PC, and we're gonna
kinda give you some examples of some of

21
00:01:08.159 --> 00:01:11.700
the specifications that you
can expect to see on the exam.

22
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:13.820
Now, not only external
connections as well but

23
00:01:13.820 --> 00:01:16.576
we're gonna talk briefly about
some internal connections,

24
00:01:16.576 --> 00:01:20.190
because in past episodes we've talked
about things like magnetic hard drives.

25
00:01:20.190 --> 00:01:24.096
We've talked about solid state drives, and
we did say in those episodes that, hey,

26
00:01:24.096 --> 00:01:27.351
we are gonna tell you a little bit more
about the interfaces that we use to

27
00:01:27.351 --> 00:01:29.760
connect those storage
devices to the motherboard.

28
00:01:29.760 --> 00:01:32.750
So we are going to talk
about those as well, so

29
00:01:32.750 --> 00:01:35.390
let's go ahead and let's dive right in.

30
00:01:35.390 --> 00:01:36.702
Now, in our motherboard episode,

31
00:01:36.702 --> 00:01:39.119
one of the things that we talked
about is something known as a bus.

32
00:01:39.119 --> 00:01:43.233
All right, we talked about a bus really
being a collection of electrical

33
00:01:43.233 --> 00:01:44.532
conductors, right.

34
00:01:44.532 --> 00:01:46.680
They're kinda like data highways,
if you will,

35
00:01:46.680 --> 00:01:51.250
paths that lead interconnection between
components along the motherboard.

36
00:01:51.250 --> 00:01:53.924
But I want you to know not only
do we have internal buses, but

37
00:01:53.924 --> 00:01:55.650
we also have external buses,right.

38
00:01:55.650 --> 00:02:00.397
And an external bus again, is just
a connection, a cable, usually today,

39
00:02:00.397 --> 00:02:05.460
it's usually a serial type cable that
connects to the outside of your computer.

40
00:02:05.460 --> 00:02:09.277
And allows you to attach
multiple devices to the PC,

41
00:02:09.277 --> 00:02:13.613
there are a few different kinds
that we need to be aware of and

42
00:02:13.613 --> 00:02:19.290
one of the very early type of connectors
that is, bus is actually in its name.

43
00:02:19.290 --> 00:02:22.788
Is something known as USB,
that is the Universal Serial Bus.

44
00:02:22.788 --> 00:02:26.372
Universal Serial Bus is something
that came along and I wanna say, Dan,

45
00:02:26.372 --> 00:02:30.157
if I can remember some of my history
right, it was Microsoft, it was Intel.

46
00:02:30.157 --> 00:02:34.701
Intel was definitely a big factor
in this as a way to have external

47
00:02:34.701 --> 00:02:36.850
connections to a computer.

48
00:02:36.850 --> 00:02:40.848
You've probably seen it today,
in fact, today it's so

49
00:02:40.848 --> 00:02:46.011
common that it isn't uncommon,
I guess I should say, to see maybe 10,

50
00:02:46.011 --> 00:02:50.950
sometimes up to 15 of these USB ports
that on the outside of the case.

51
00:02:50.950 --> 00:02:52.830
Now, what is a port, all right?

52
00:02:52.830 --> 00:02:56.332
I want you to understand that port
is an opening, if you will, and

53
00:02:56.332 --> 00:03:00.345
on your motherboard, it could be on
your motherboard, or could be a part of

54
00:03:00.345 --> 00:03:04.702
the tower or the the chassis, if you will,
that holds the system unit together.

55
00:03:04.702 --> 00:03:09.256
And it allows us to make a connection with
some kind of, typically copper conductor,

56
00:03:09.256 --> 00:03:11.786
doesn't always have to
be a copper conductor,

57
00:03:11.786 --> 00:03:14.900
we do have some that make
optical connections too as well.

58
00:03:14.900 --> 00:03:18.255
So that's what we're gonna dive
into first, let's go ahead and

59
00:03:18.255 --> 00:03:20.024
let's dive into USB, all right.

60
00:03:20.024 --> 00:03:23.775
Universal Serial Bus has had some
different revisions over the years and

61
00:03:23.775 --> 00:03:26.542
a lot of times the revisions
have to do with the speed,

62
00:03:26.542 --> 00:03:28.038
the speed of the interface.

63
00:03:28.038 --> 00:03:31.734
And I've got a little bit of a diagram
here talking about some of the things that

64
00:03:31.734 --> 00:03:34.539
we need to be aware of when it
comes to Universal Serial Bus.

65
00:03:34.539 --> 00:03:38.628
Now, some of these concepts that we're
gonna talk about are kind of considered

66
00:03:38.628 --> 00:03:40.285
legacy by today's standards.

67
00:03:40.285 --> 00:03:44.421
And what I mean by that is legacy is just
something that's kinda out of date, and

68
00:03:44.421 --> 00:03:47.600
in the computing world,
out of date could be six months ago.

69
00:03:47.600 --> 00:03:51.995
Dan, I seen a commercial one time and
this guy, he was just happy,

70
00:03:51.995 --> 00:03:54.615
he had the latest, greatest,
brand new computer.

71
00:03:54.615 --> 00:03:56.738
In fact,
he was walking out of the store with it.

72
00:03:56.738 --> 00:03:57.415
>> I remember this commercial.
>> Do you remember that?

73
00:03:57.415 --> 00:03:58.955
>> Yes, I do.
>> And he turns around,

74
00:03:58.955 --> 00:04:01.885
looks up at the sign, and
they're actually taking the sign down for

75
00:04:01.885 --> 00:04:04.690
his brand new computer that he
hasn't even left the store with, and

76
00:04:04.690 --> 00:04:05.810
they're coming out with a new model.

77
00:04:05.810 --> 00:04:10.930
So, understand that legacy, I know
it really is a relative term because

78
00:04:10.930 --> 00:04:12.850
things move so fast in computing today.

79
00:04:12.850 --> 00:04:15.635
However, you're starting to
see some things slow down.

80
00:04:15.635 --> 00:04:20.530
We've finally come to a certain point
where what we're really doing is trying to

81
00:04:20.530 --> 00:04:25.480
update speed and really shrinking
everything down to smaller packages.

82
00:04:25.480 --> 00:04:28.516
Now let's go ahead and we're gonna jump
in our DeLorean here and we're gonna take

83
00:04:28.516 --> 00:04:31.655
a trip back through time and we're gonna
talk about the very first standard 1.1.

84
00:04:31.655 --> 00:04:35.442
Now you might say, well wait a second,
1.1, what happened to 1.0?

85
00:04:35.442 --> 00:04:40.100
Well, 1.0 wasn't really widely adopted
when the USB standard come out.

86
00:04:40.100 --> 00:04:46.020
And it wasn't until 1.1 that it really
started to take a foothold in PCs and

87
00:04:46.020 --> 00:04:47.430
become common.

88
00:04:47.430 --> 00:04:51.070
Universal Serial Bus, understand that it
is a serial interface, all right, and

89
00:04:51.070 --> 00:04:52.430
the difference between a serial and

90
00:04:52.430 --> 00:04:57.260
a parallel interface is a serial interface
means sequential ones and zeroes.

91
00:04:57.260 --> 00:05:01.650
And there can be a couple of ways
that a serial communication happens.

92
00:05:01.650 --> 00:05:04.240
There's what's known as synchronous
serial communications and

93
00:05:04.240 --> 00:05:06.270
asynchronous serial communications.

94
00:05:06.270 --> 00:05:09.260
When we talk about synchronous
serial communications guys,

95
00:05:09.260 --> 00:05:11.210
I want you to think about metronome,
right.

96
00:05:11.210 --> 00:05:15.340
Any of you guys out there in music, right
timing, a heartbeat, synchronous, right.

97
00:05:15.340 --> 00:05:18.300
Synchronous seems that there's some kind
of beat pattern, if you will, that say,

98
00:05:18.300 --> 00:05:21.930
hey this is the timing and this is how
we're gonna synchronize our information.

99
00:05:21.930 --> 00:05:24.866
Asynchronous, right, that comes from
a word, right, asynchronous, right,

100
00:05:24.866 --> 00:05:25.598
synchronization.

101
00:05:25.598 --> 00:05:29.697
A, meaning again, synchronous meaning
time, it means it isn't synchronized to

102
00:05:29.697 --> 00:05:33.560
a heartbeat, and how they synchronize
serial communications, if you will,

103
00:05:33.560 --> 00:05:37.480
over an asynchronous communication is that
I have a start bit that says hey Dan,

104
00:05:37.480 --> 00:05:39.559
we're gonna start recording right now.

105
00:05:39.559 --> 00:05:42.804
And then I say hey Nan, I'm gonna send you
another little bit of information that

106
00:05:42.804 --> 00:05:45.012
says okay, hey Dan,
we're done recording, right.

107
00:05:45.012 --> 00:05:47.951
So a start and
stop as they typically call it, so

108
00:05:47.951 --> 00:05:53.090
a little bit more about the serial
information or serial type communication.

109
00:05:53.090 --> 00:05:56.320
And I just wanna take a second and
contrast that to a parallel communication.

110
00:05:56.320 --> 00:05:59.430
Parallel communications do have some,
they're kinda problematic.

111
00:05:59.430 --> 00:06:02.270
Parallel communications are when
you have a series of copper

112
00:06:02.270 --> 00:06:05.954
conductors that are adjacent to each
other, they run parallel to each other.

113
00:06:05.954 --> 00:06:09.734
And the problem with those is they do, you
limit how much power you can put across

114
00:06:09.734 --> 00:06:12.783
them, and that's because any,
kinda communication that goes

115
00:06:12.783 --> 00:06:15.606
down a single copper conductor
can have a negative effect or

116
00:06:15.606 --> 00:06:18.959
adverse effect on the data that's
carried across the adjacent line.

117
00:06:18.959 --> 00:06:22.574
It's what they call crosstalk, guys,
you can think of it as electromagnetic

118
00:06:22.574 --> 00:06:25.202
interference, right,
we can only put so much power over

119
00:06:25.202 --> 00:06:29.580
parallel communication before we start
to get that bleed over, if you will.

120
00:06:29.580 --> 00:06:32.450
Now Universal Serial Bus again
serial communications 1.1,

121
00:06:32.450 --> 00:06:34.310
what do we need to know about that?

122
00:06:34.310 --> 00:06:38.372
Well, 1.1, well I tel you what,
before we actually talk about speeds,

123
00:06:38.372 --> 00:06:41.750
let's talk about the overall
basics of Universal Serial Bus.

124
00:06:41.750 --> 00:06:44.510
When we look at a Universal Serial Bus,
believe it or not,

125
00:06:44.510 --> 00:06:47.475
the ports that are on your computer,
you can get five volts of power, right.

126
00:06:47.475 --> 00:06:52.148
We talked about, in another episode, we
talked about some of the power voltages,

127
00:06:52.148 --> 00:06:55.234
excuse me,
that you have coming off the power supply.

128
00:06:55.234 --> 00:06:58.697
We talked about 3.3,
5 volts and 12 volts, well,

129
00:06:58.697 --> 00:07:01.453
a single USB port supports
5 volts of power.

130
00:07:01.453 --> 00:07:05.374
So if you have a device that connects
to it externally and is powered and

131
00:07:05.374 --> 00:07:08.770
only requires five volts of power,
then you're just fine.

132
00:07:08.770 --> 00:07:11.130
However, keep in mind,
some of these devices like external,

133
00:07:11.130 --> 00:07:15.050
these bigger external hard drives that
plug into USB ports require extra power so

134
00:07:15.050 --> 00:07:17.880
they usually have some kind
of externally AC adapter.

135
00:07:17.880 --> 00:07:22.230
Now, I said bus all right, so what is,
if you think about it, a bus in general?

136
00:07:22.230 --> 00:07:27.080
A bus also allows you to do what's known
as daisy chaining, which means we can take

137
00:07:27.080 --> 00:07:33.560
multiple devices and connect them in
series, if you will, to a single port.

138
00:07:33.560 --> 00:07:37.958
And USB is kinda interesting
because theoretically it

139
00:07:37.958 --> 00:07:41.406
supports 127 devices on a single port.

140
00:07:41.406 --> 00:07:44.674
And if any of you guys know a little bit
about your binary communications that

141
00:07:44.674 --> 00:07:48.196
we'll talk about a little bit later, like
when we get into networking and stuff,

142
00:07:48.196 --> 00:07:51.541
you might say, well, 127,
that really isn't a binary number, right.

143
00:07:51.541 --> 00:07:54.855
A binary number would be 128,
and that's because, remember,

144
00:07:54.855 --> 00:07:57.599
when we talk binary in computing,
zero always counts.

145
00:07:57.599 --> 00:08:00.598
One of those bits is actually reserved for
what's known as a host device.

146
00:08:00.598 --> 00:08:05.345
And the host device is basically
the primary device that controls.

147
00:08:05.345 --> 00:08:07.403
All the other devices
that are on the chain.

148
00:08:07.403 --> 00:08:09.437
So 127 devices, if you will,

149
00:08:09.437 --> 00:08:13.737
are the ones that are basically
subserving it to whatever the host is.

150
00:08:13.737 --> 00:08:17.640
And again, so
127 devices on a single port.

151
00:08:17.640 --> 00:08:22.179
Now, keep in mind that 127 devices
on a single port is a nightmare.

152
00:08:22.179 --> 00:08:23.449
It's not really something
that you wanna do.

153
00:08:23.449 --> 00:08:27.877
>> I can't imagine having 127 physical
devices in my office that's going to

154
00:08:27.877 --> 00:08:30.806
connect, let alone
daisy-chain itself around or

155
00:08:30.806 --> 00:08:34.007
have some sort of hub thing going on-
>> When we talk about a rat's nest,

156
00:08:34.007 --> 00:08:35.094
we're talking about a rats den.

157
00:08:35.094 --> 00:08:36.292
>> [LAUGH] I know, right.

158
00:08:36.292 --> 00:08:37.818
[CROSSTALK] There will be boats of rats.

159
00:08:37.818 --> 00:08:39.513
[LAUGH]
>> Right so, and

160
00:08:39.513 --> 00:08:41.951
not to mention the contention, right?

161
00:08:41.951 --> 00:08:44.423
We don't really think about
this in today's day and age,

162
00:08:44.423 --> 00:08:47.610
with things like Voice over IP,
we've got products out there like Skype.

163
00:08:47.610 --> 00:08:49.794
But back in the earlier days,
I say earlier days,

164
00:08:49.794 --> 00:08:52.566
back in the 80s you had what
was called party lines, right?

165
00:08:52.566 --> 00:08:54.353
>> Yeah.
>> Many people don't remember party lines

166
00:08:54.353 --> 00:08:58.310
today, by today's standards, but you have
multiple people on a single communication.

167
00:08:58.310 --> 00:09:03.280
Now I want you to think about having 127
people in a single room all talking at

168
00:09:03.280 --> 00:09:04.273
the same time.

169
00:09:04.273 --> 00:09:07.064
It does, it makes a little contention.

170
00:09:07.064 --> 00:09:08.670
>> And
it might sound a little noisy in there.

171
00:09:08.670 --> 00:09:09.270
>> Yeah, that's right.

172
00:09:09.270 --> 00:09:11.834
So even though there is theoreticals,
right?

173
00:09:11.834 --> 00:09:14.577
And that's what we are talking about, and
that's what you need to know on the exam.

174
00:09:14.577 --> 00:09:17.147
Understand that the feasibility,
the practicality of this,

175
00:09:17.147 --> 00:09:18.852
it really isn't practical, all right?

176
00:09:18.852 --> 00:09:23.061
So 127 devices on a single port, 5 volts
of power, that's some of the basics that

177
00:09:23.061 --> 00:09:26.300
you definitely need to know
about Universal Serial Bus.

178
00:09:26.300 --> 00:09:29.068
Now if we could take a look here
at the diagram here one more time,

179
00:09:29.068 --> 00:09:30.316
we got USB standard 1.1.

180
00:09:30.316 --> 00:09:33.182
The other thing we also have to
keep in mind when it comes to

181
00:09:33.182 --> 00:09:37.487
Universal Serial Bus, is the fact that we
have different transmission speeds that we

182
00:09:37.487 --> 00:09:39.255
want you to be aware of on the exam.

183
00:09:39.255 --> 00:09:43.751
1.1, stand back now, we're talking
about some high tech technology, right?

184
00:09:43.751 --> 00:09:44.800
That's redundant.

185
00:09:44.800 --> 00:09:47.972
We have 12 megabit transfer speeds.

186
00:09:47.972 --> 00:09:49.910
All right,
we talk about 12 megabit transfer speeds,

187
00:09:49.910 --> 00:09:53.030
that is essentially
what's called throughput.

188
00:09:53.030 --> 00:09:55.603
Throughput is the amount of information,

189
00:09:55.603 --> 00:10:00.040
the amount of bits that you can pass
across an interface in a given second.

190
00:10:00.040 --> 00:10:03.250
We're talking about 12
megabits per second.

191
00:10:03.250 --> 00:10:06.163
Now, the next one is 2.0, all right?

192
00:10:06.163 --> 00:10:10.507
And 2.0 actually kinda stood the test
of time, it's still out there, still.

193
00:10:10.507 --> 00:10:13.160
I've got it on some of the older
motherboards that I have too.

194
00:10:13.160 --> 00:10:17.594
I want you to keep in mind that 2.0,
it kinda shattered the record,

195
00:10:17.594 --> 00:10:21.126
if you will, or
shattered the earlier revision of USB,

196
00:10:21.126 --> 00:10:24.982
because we now jumped up to
480 megabit transfer speeds.

197
00:10:24.982 --> 00:10:28.773
And know that all the same characteristics
that I told you about USB still apply to

198
00:10:28.773 --> 00:10:30.180
these different revisions.

199
00:10:30.180 --> 00:10:35.284
What you're seeing is speeds,
speeds generally increase in 3.0.

200
00:10:35.284 --> 00:10:41.753
3.0 now, it's almost 10 times what
the speed is of the earlier 2.0.

201
00:10:41.753 --> 00:10:46.885
And that is just under around,
or just about, if you will,

202
00:10:46.885 --> 00:10:53.572
5000 megabits per second or what would
equate to 5 gigabits per second.

203
00:10:53.572 --> 00:10:56.500
Now, let me take a second, even though
we're talking about theoretical, right?

204
00:10:56.500 --> 00:11:00.130
Dan and I were just mentioning that you
couldn't imagine having 127 devices

205
00:11:00.130 --> 00:11:04.390
literally connected to a single port,
even though it is theoretically capable.

206
00:11:04.390 --> 00:11:06.600
I want you to understand that
these are theoretical numbers.

207
00:11:06.600 --> 00:11:11.800
When it comes down to actual application,
you'll be lucky to see more than

208
00:11:11.800 --> 00:11:15.400
like on a 2.0 device, I don't care if it
says it's 480 megabyte transfer speeds,

209
00:11:15.400 --> 00:11:17.790
which is what I want you to recognize for
the exam.

210
00:11:17.790 --> 00:11:19.570
Might be the question they ask you.

211
00:11:19.570 --> 00:11:23.800
In the field, you'd be lucky to see around
240 out of one of the best devices.

212
00:11:23.800 --> 00:11:26.620
And again,
that's just because manufacturers vary,

213
00:11:26.620 --> 00:11:30.526
and there's all different things that
you have to take into consideration.

214
00:11:30.526 --> 00:11:34.097
And that being said, I also want you to
understand that there are some connector

215
00:11:34.097 --> 00:11:35.866
types that we have to talk about, too.

216
00:11:35.866 --> 00:11:41.072
And that's the other column in
the diagram, you'll see that we have

217
00:11:41.072 --> 00:11:46.490
USB connector Type A, Type B,
we have mini, and we have micro.

218
00:11:46.490 --> 00:11:49.348
All right now, Type A, one of the most
common ports you'll see today.

219
00:11:49.348 --> 00:11:53.041
In fact, we've kinda got a picture here
to make it a little bit easier, so

220
00:11:53.041 --> 00:11:55.310
we don't have to be flying blind here.

221
00:11:55.310 --> 00:11:58.057
This is the type A connector and
I've got two different kinds.

222
00:11:58.057 --> 00:12:00.267
We've got what's known as
the male connector and

223
00:12:00.267 --> 00:12:03.960
the male connector has the post and the
female connector is the empty port, right?

224
00:12:03.960 --> 00:12:08.440
This is the A connector, it's one of the
most common USB ports that are out there.

225
00:12:08.440 --> 00:12:13.771
It is the same for 1.1, it is the same for
2.0, it's the same for 3.0.

226
00:12:13.771 --> 00:12:18.331
Now I will tell you 3.0 has an interesting
characteristic that you can usually tell

227
00:12:18.331 --> 00:12:19.861
it from the earlier legacy.

228
00:12:19.861 --> 00:12:24.775
And that's typically that it has
a blue blade right under here,

229
00:12:24.775 --> 00:12:28.802
under the four pins that
the USB standard requires.

230
00:12:28.802 --> 00:12:30.403
Now this other port right here,

231
00:12:30.403 --> 00:12:33.085
this is what's known as
a Full Size Type B Connector.

232
00:12:33.085 --> 00:12:36.980
Be careful on this one, because a lot
of people call it a printer port.

233
00:12:36.980 --> 00:12:39.708
And I know Dan, if you and I were
talking outside of a certification exam,

234
00:12:39.708 --> 00:12:42.085
I wouldn't correct anybody,
I'm sure you wouldn't either.

235
00:12:42.085 --> 00:12:43.215
We would say yeah, it's the printer port.

236
00:12:43.215 --> 00:12:44.140
Because why?

237
00:12:44.140 --> 00:12:46.311
[CROSSTALK] It's one of the most
common ports, right, for

238
00:12:46.311 --> 00:12:47.695
a wired USB connection on a printer.

239
00:12:47.695 --> 00:12:52.545
>> Printers, scanning devices, typically
any kind of imaging or printing device,

240
00:12:52.545 --> 00:12:54.498
you'll see this very commonly.

241
00:12:54.498 --> 00:12:58.210
I've also seen this a lot on
older external hard drives.

242
00:12:58.210 --> 00:12:58.710
>> That's right.

243
00:12:58.710 --> 00:12:59.970
>> But then they got away from that.

244
00:12:59.970 --> 00:13:02.480
>> And I know you're a big music fan.

245
00:13:02.480 --> 00:13:03.417
I know you're into music,

246
00:13:03.417 --> 00:13:05.508
the other thing I've seen it
into is audio boards, as well.

247
00:13:05.508 --> 00:13:07.361
>> Yes.
>> Like mixing boards, it just,

248
00:13:07.361 --> 00:13:09.330
there's something about it.

249
00:13:09.330 --> 00:13:10.950
>> It makes a really solid connection.

250
00:13:10.950 --> 00:13:11.477
>> It does.

251
00:13:11.477 --> 00:13:13.306
>> I think it's probably
why it's preferred,

252
00:13:13.306 --> 00:13:15.998
because when you plug that sucker in,
it's a nice fat connector,

253
00:13:15.998 --> 00:13:19.120
seats in very deeply and very nicely,
and you don't have to worry about it.

254
00:13:19.120 --> 00:13:21.340
You'll notice that the smaller
connectors over there,

255
00:13:21.340 --> 00:13:22.760
you might have some trouble with it.

256
00:13:22.760 --> 00:13:24.570
If you pull one way or the other,
they'll come right out.

257
00:13:24.570 --> 00:13:26.972
>> Most definitely, so
it's got many different applications.

258
00:13:26.972 --> 00:13:29.801
And like I said, guys and gals out there,
if we were out outside of a certification

259
00:13:29.801 --> 00:13:32.146
endeavor, I wouldn't correct you
if you say it's a printer port.

260
00:13:32.146 --> 00:13:35.816
Because it was for the longest time,
up until things like wireless today,

261
00:13:35.816 --> 00:13:38.919
the most common wired connection
you could have for a printer.

262
00:13:38.919 --> 00:13:42.433
Now, if we jump over to the other
side of the tracks here,

263
00:13:42.433 --> 00:13:46.975
moving over towards the left,
right next to the female Type A connector,

264
00:13:46.975 --> 00:13:50.359
you'll see what is known as
the mini Type A connector.

265
00:13:50.359 --> 00:13:51.640
>> Can you point to that with your mouse?

266
00:13:51.640 --> 00:13:53.064
>> Yes, absolutely.
>> Just because I have no idea

267
00:13:53.064 --> 00:13:53.842
which one that is.

268
00:13:53.842 --> 00:13:55.750
[LAUGH]
>> Okay, that's probably a good thing.

269
00:13:55.750 --> 00:13:57.112
That's this one right here.

270
00:13:57.112 --> 00:13:58.453
This one right here is
the Type A connector.

271
00:13:58.453 --> 00:13:59.927
>> There we go, okay.

272
00:13:59.927 --> 00:14:01.520
Cuz they always confused me.

273
00:14:01.520 --> 00:14:04.610
I never understood which one was which,

274
00:14:04.610 --> 00:14:05.750
I always get it wrong.

00:14:05.750 --> 00:14:06.718

Yeah, I do too, and

00:14:06.718 --> 00:14:09.887

277
00:14:09.887 --> 00:14:10.538
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, but

00:14:10.538 --> 00:14:12.589
in practicality If you're not studying for
this-

279
00:14:12.589 --> 00:14:13.393
>> It really is,

280
00:14:13.393 --> 00:14:16.012
you break out your
magnifying glass to see it.

281
00:14:16.012 --> 00:14:19.180
And this is another one
that's commonly used.

282
00:14:19.180 --> 00:14:21.860
But probably one, and
I'm gonna skip over this one here.

283
00:14:21.860 --> 00:14:25.690
This isn't a really common one here.

284
00:14:25.690 --> 00:14:28.030
So, I don't want you to worry
about this one for the exam.

285
00:14:28.030 --> 00:14:31.140
But the one that I do want you to
worry about, these one's your micro.

286
00:14:31.140 --> 00:14:33.730
Now micro, if you've got Android devices,

287
00:14:33.730 --> 00:14:37.190
it's probably one of the ones that you've

00:14:37.190 --> 00:14:41.250
when you plug that power adapter
into that little wall wart, right?

289
00:14:41.250 --> 00:14:44.310
You plug it into the bottom
of your Android based phones,

290
00:14:44.310 --> 00:14:47.800
that is the Micro Type A connector.

291
00:14:47.800 --> 00:14:52.240
So we definitely want you to know
those and understand what they are.

292
00:14:52.240 --> 00:14:54.219
So-
>> The mini one looks little top-hat.

293
00:14:54.219 --> 00:14:55.003
>> That's right.

294
00:14:55.003 --> 00:14:58.600
>> And the micro is just the wider,
looks like an angry face.

295
00:14:58.600 --> 00:15:00.460
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's right,

296
00:15:00.460 --> 00:15:01.540
that's a great way to say it.

297
00:15:01.540 --> 00:15:02.440
And you know what?

298
00:15:02.440 --> 00:15:04.729
That might sound,
it's actually really pretty funny.

299
00:15:04.729 --> 00:15:05.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> But

300
00:15:05.350 --> 00:15:09.085
that's what's gonna commit it to memory,
do things like that.

301
00:15:09.085 --> 00:15:12.200
That' s actually some of the things
that I train people to do too,

302
00:15:12.200 --> 00:15:14.761
cuz I've been teaching A+ now for

00:15:14.761 --> 00:15:17.105
And I tell you,
if you can remember jokes like that,

00:15:17.105 --> 00:15:19.087
it can help cement it in

305
00:15:19.087 --> 00:15:22.522
And when you go into the exam booth, if

306
00:15:22.522 --> 00:15:25.950

when you're like, what is that one?

307
00:15:25.950 --> 00:15:27.337
Know these for the exam.

308
00:15:27.337 --> 00:15:28.561
Now that being said,

309
00:15:28.561 --> 00:15:32.310
that isn't the only type of external
BUS type connector we have.

310
00:15:32.310 --> 00:15:36.740
We have to move into one that's also been
around for a while, and that is FireWire.

311
00:15:36.740 --> 00:15:37.659
All right, FireWire.

312
00:15:37.659 --> 00:15:40.663
Now, here's where we're gonna
get a little confusing on you,

313
00:15:40.663 --> 00:15:43.080
because FireWire has
a few different names.

314
00:15:43.080 --> 00:15:46.320
When FireWire first came out,
there were many different companies

315
00:15:46.320 --> 00:15:50.280
that were working with this
new connection, right?

316
00:15:50.280 --> 00:15:54.243
Apple happened to be one of them that
had some of the major contributions

317
00:15:54.243 --> 00:15:56.237
to the earlier FireWire standard.

318
00:15:56.237 --> 00:16:01.206
But it was also being
overseen by a collection of

319
00:16:01.206 --> 00:16:07.054
manufacturers under a standards
body called the IEEE.

320
00:16:07.054 --> 00:16:10.158
The Institute for Electronic and
Electrical Engineers.

321
00:16:10.158 --> 00:16:13.078
Or Electrical and
Electronic Engineers if you will, IEEE.

322
00:16:13.078 --> 00:16:16.037
And the IEEE actually calls it 1394.

323
00:16:16.037 --> 00:16:18.535
And I don't want you to confuse that or

324
00:16:18.535 --> 00:16:21.590
think that that's some
big different cable.

325
00:16:23.060 --> 00:16:26.680
FireWire, when it was released,
that was Apple's marketing name for it.

326
00:16:26.680 --> 00:16:29.045
When it formally got standardized,

327
00:16:29.045 --> 00:16:33.783
it was standardized as an industry-wide
standard under IEEE1394.

328
00:16:33.783 --> 00:16:37.788
Guys, we're talking about tomato tomato,
those are the same exact cables.

329
00:16:37.788 --> 00:16:41.560
Again, one's a marketing name,
one's a standards name.

330
00:16:41.560 --> 00:16:43.590
Now, let's talk a little
bit more about FireWire,

331
00:16:43.590 --> 00:16:46.860
we'll talk about some of the speeds
coming up but it's interesting because

332
00:16:46.860 --> 00:16:50.080
FireWire also allows you to do
something called daisychaining right.

333
00:16:50.080 --> 00:16:52.320
The fact that we can
take multiple devices and

334
00:16:52.320 --> 00:16:55.710
we can just basically chain them together.

335
00:16:55.710 --> 00:16:58.497
I can plug in one device to
another device, to another device,

336
00:16:58.497 --> 00:17:01.030
we do this a lot of the times
through what is known as a hub.

337
00:17:01.030 --> 00:17:02.214
A hub is a multi port device.

338
00:17:02.214 --> 00:17:04.994
They have USB hubs,
they have FireWire hubs and

339
00:17:04.994 --> 00:17:07.200
we can plug more than one device in.

340
00:17:07.200 --> 00:17:10.240
However, the standards
are different than USB.

341
00:17:10.240 --> 00:17:14.798
The standard inside of a FireWire is
going, I want you to keep in mind,

342
00:17:14.798 --> 00:17:18.370
is going to be 63 devices
connected to a single port.

343
00:17:18.370 --> 00:17:21.178
Here we go with some of those numbers
that it's like, well, wait a second, 63.

344
00:17:21.178 --> 00:17:24.509
And you guys as you go into your IT
career, especially guys that are moving

345
00:17:24.509 --> 00:17:27.210
onto network plus, might say,
well, wait a second 63?

346
00:17:27.210 --> 00:17:30.636
It shouldn't be 64 that's
a binary number right?

347
00:17:30.636 --> 00:17:35.166
And there again, zero counts because
the one bit is actually reserved for

348
00:17:35.166 --> 00:17:39.404
the device of the controller if you
will that controls all the devices

349
00:17:39.404 --> 00:17:41.390
along this type of BUS.

350
00:17:41.390 --> 00:17:43.650
Power, all right there's
a reason they call it FireWire.

351
00:17:43.650 --> 00:17:45.450
We're talking about a lot of power here.

352
00:17:45.450 --> 00:17:47.215
We're talking about 12 volts right?

353
00:17:47.215 --> 00:17:49.887
So remember when we were talking
about our power supply and

354
00:17:49.887 --> 00:17:53.170
those three main voltages, 3.3,
5 volts, and 12 volts right?

355
00:17:53.170 --> 00:17:56.030
Well USB uses 5 volts.

356
00:17:56.030 --> 00:17:57.710
FireWire actually uses 12 volts.

357
00:17:57.710 --> 00:18:01.960
So I want you to keep that in mind that
if you plug in to a powered port and

358
00:18:01.960 --> 00:18:02.940
there are some that are different.

359
00:18:02.940 --> 00:18:07.924
We'll show you those coming up here that
you're talking about 12 volts of power,

360
00:18:07.924 --> 00:18:11.586
all right now what is up with
this FireWire 400 and 800?

361
00:18:11.586 --> 00:18:15.170
I actually like the naming convention I
want you guys and gals out there to cement

362
00:18:15.170 --> 00:18:19.800
this to memory because 400 tells you what
the speeds are, 400 megabits per second.

363
00:18:19.800 --> 00:18:23.970
All right you also see FireWire 800
well guess what 800 megabits per second.

364
00:18:23.970 --> 00:18:27.510
And I really like that naming convention
because if you can remember the standard.

365
00:18:27.510 --> 00:18:31.120
The name and in the name,
you could also remember the speeds.

366
00:18:31.120 --> 00:18:32.112
It makes it a lot easier for

367
00:18:32.112 --> 00:18:34.470
some of this stuff that I realize
is just sheer memorization.

368
00:18:34.470 --> 00:18:38.010
So, FireWire 400, 400 megabits per second.

369
00:18:38.010 --> 00:18:42.891
If you are FireWire 800, I think I said
that right FireWire400 400 megabits and

370
00:18:42.891 --> 00:18:45.245
then FireWire800 is 800 megabits.

371
00:18:45.245 --> 00:18:46.196
>> They're giving you the answer.

372
00:18:46.196 --> 00:18:47.139
>> They really are.

373
00:18:47.139 --> 00:18:48.089
>> I love that about them.

374
00:18:48.089 --> 00:18:48.870
Thank you.

375
00:18:48.870 --> 00:18:49.700
>> Most definitely.

376
00:18:49.700 --> 00:18:52.099
And again you gotta thank
capital on that one.

377
00:18:52.099 --> 00:18:55.190
Steve Jobs defiantly
maybe had some foresight.

378
00:18:55.190 --> 00:18:58.821
Maybe he knew that A+ exam was coming out
before they even knew it was coming out.

379
00:18:58.821 --> 00:19:02.360
Now, we do have a series of connections
that I want you to be aware of here.

380
00:19:02.360 --> 00:19:05.400
We have a 4 pin connection,
we have a 6 pin connection, and

381
00:19:05.400 --> 00:19:06.820
we have a 9 pin connection.

382
00:19:06.820 --> 00:19:10.760
And there are differences not
only in the amount of pins but

383
00:19:10.760 --> 00:19:13.632
also the attributes of
the cables themselves.

384
00:19:13.632 --> 00:19:18.480
All right, Firewire400 uses the top
two connectors that we see, and

385
00:19:18.480 --> 00:19:20.280
I'll dive into them in a second.

386
00:19:20.280 --> 00:19:24.990
FireWire 800 uses the square box pattern
nine pin connector that you see here.

387
00:19:24.990 --> 00:19:29.670
Notice in the upper-left hand corner of
your screen, you have four, six, and nine.

388
00:19:29.670 --> 00:19:31.670
Four and
six are the two that you see at the top,

389
00:19:31.670 --> 00:19:34.190
nine is the box pattern
that you see in the bottom.

390
00:19:34.190 --> 00:19:37.144
The top one is FireWire 400,
the bottom one is FireWire 800.

391
00:19:37.144 --> 00:19:39.040
Now there are some characteristics.

392
00:19:39.040 --> 00:19:42.415
Dan, just like we were talking about with
USB that we kinda got to go over for

393
00:19:42.415 --> 00:19:43.284
FireWire 400.

394
00:19:43.284 --> 00:19:48.540
You'll see and when I was studying it,
they always had a square shape.

395
00:19:48.540 --> 00:19:50.807
It's got kind of this like-
>> Dent?

396
00:19:50.807 --> 00:19:53.390
>> Yeah, looks like somebody grabbed
it with a pair of pliers and broke it.

397
00:19:53.390 --> 00:19:56.480
But that's actually part
of the the connection tube.

398
00:19:56.480 --> 00:20:00.350
You can remember it on the exam
as the square type connector.

399
00:20:00.350 --> 00:20:04.300
It's a 4 pin connector, but
I want you to also know it's unpowered.

400
00:20:04.300 --> 00:20:07.855
This is an unpowered square
4 pin connector, and

401
00:20:07.855 --> 00:20:13.360
that's unlike one of the most common
FireWire connectors that you see.

402
00:20:13.360 --> 00:20:17.530
That is a 6 pin connector and
if you want to remember it on the exam,

403
00:20:17.530 --> 00:20:20.750
I always remember it as a bullet shaped
connector and a bullet has a lot of

404
00:20:20.750 --> 00:20:25.320
power behind it, right, so
power connector, a 6 pin power connector.

00:20:25.320 --> 00:20:27.796
800, thank goodness they made it easy.

406
00:20:27.796 --> 00:20:30.782
We just have a nine [CROSSTALK].

And this is actually a better
connector than both the other one.

00:20:34.749 --> 00:20:35.785
>> Yeah it looks like it
actually kinda clips in.

411
00:20:35.785 --> 00:20:38.260
>> That's exactly a good, good.

412
00:20:38.260 --> 00:20:40.379
Smart guy he got that
one right on the money.

413
00:20:40.379 --> 00:20:43.795
And that's exactly it just like you
were saying you know like the US

414
00:20:43.795 --> 00:20:47.638
type B connector, where it's not as,
it's a little bit more difficult,

415
00:20:47.638 --> 00:20:51.250
you could still pull it out fairly
easy if you actually yank on it.

416
00:20:51.250 --> 00:20:53.790
This one's a little bit more feral,
if you will.

417
00:20:53.790 --> 00:20:57.397
The fact that it's a little bit more
heavy-duty and it does stay locked in.

418
00:20:57.397 --> 00:21:02.123
So those are some of the things
that we need to keep in mind

419
00:21:02.123 --> 00:21:05.180
when it comes to FireWire and USB.

420
00:21:05.180 --> 00:21:07.550
Again guys,
these are some of the specifications,

421
00:21:07.550 --> 00:21:11.010
some of the characteristics,
we want you to be aware of them.

422
00:21:11.010 --> 00:21:14.585
Now, I wanna take a few more minutes and
I wanna kind of compare USB

00:21:14.585 --> 00:21:17.976
to FireWire because by the numbers
we've talked about this.

424
00:21:17.976 --> 00:21:21.104
And we were talking about
this in our CPU episodes,

425
00:21:21.104 --> 00:21:24.470
marketing is a lot of times
it's a numbers game right?

426
00:21:24.470 --> 00:21:28.230
If I tell you that you
have 300 of something or,

427
00:21:28.230 --> 00:21:32.900
how about this,
if I tell you you have 480 of something or

428
00:21:32.900 --> 00:21:37.020
I can give you 400 of something, don't
worry about what the something is, right?

429
00:21:37.020 --> 00:21:40.990
You're gonna probably say, hey I think I'm
gonna do better if I have the 480, right?

430
00:21:40.990 --> 00:21:44.340
Of something that you're
gonna give me $480, right?

431
00:21:44.340 --> 00:21:47.627
If I said I'm gonna give you $480
in one hand or you could $400.

432
00:21:47.627 --> 00:21:51.125
No curve balls here, this is what you get.

433
00:21:51.125 --> 00:21:55.112
Well you would automatically think in
a marketing sense that hey 480 is gonna be

434
00:21:55.112 --> 00:21:56.165
better than 400.

435
00:21:56.165 --> 00:21:58.825
Let's go ahead and
take that analogy out of dollars and

436
00:21:58.825 --> 00:22:03.015
let's talk about the bits that USB and
FireWire transfer across their cables.

437
00:22:03.015 --> 00:22:08.011
All right you'll see by the numbers
that USB 2.0 has 480 mb transfer speed.

438
00:22:08.011 --> 00:22:12.624
You will see FireWire 400
400 megabit transfer speeds.

439
00:22:12.624 --> 00:22:17.010
Do you get a benefit one over the other?

440
00:22:17.010 --> 00:22:18.580
Well it depends.

441
00:22:18.580 --> 00:22:22.440
USB, it does something
interesting to its data.

442
00:22:22.440 --> 00:22:25.430
It takes large files and
it breaks them up.

443
00:22:25.430 --> 00:22:27.730
It does what's known as segmentation.

444
00:22:27.730 --> 00:22:32.610
And it sends sequential information that's
been segmented across that serial bus.

445
00:22:32.610 --> 00:22:34.630
FireWire doesn't do that.

446
00:22:34.630 --> 00:22:37.970
FireWire can take the full five
gallon bucket and throw it at you.

447
00:22:37.970 --> 00:22:41.120
It doesn't have to pull it out in
little small glasses of water and

448
00:22:41.120 --> 00:22:44.160
then send it one cup at a time.

449
00:22:44.160 --> 00:22:46.240
And so what the heck does that even mean,
right?

450
00:22:46.240 --> 00:22:50.280
Well, it means that if I have
let's say a 4 GB file, right?

451
00:22:50.280 --> 00:22:53.584
By today's standards that's not really
big, back when this first came out that

452
00:22:53.584 --> 00:22:56.705
would have been a pretty big file and
it would have taken a while to transfer.

453
00:22:56.705 --> 00:23:01.391
But if I take a 4 GB file and I have 4
GB of individual small files, kilobytes,

454
00:23:01.391 --> 00:23:04.730
megabytes if you will, but
a whole bunch of them right?

455
00:23:04.730 --> 00:23:06.711
A whole bunch of,
a stack of papers if you will.

456
00:23:06.711 --> 00:23:10.260
USB will do pretty good at
that transfer rate, right?

457
00:23:10.260 --> 00:23:12.120
It'll do really good, all right.

458
00:23:12.120 --> 00:23:15.750
But you take that,
compared to FireWire if you will.

459
00:23:15.750 --> 00:23:20.566
You take that 4 gig file and
make it a video file and

460
00:23:20.566 --> 00:23:23.555
I love the, all pun intended.

461
00:23:23.555 --> 00:23:25.005
Here goes.

462
00:23:25.005 --> 00:23:26.739
>> [LAUGH]
>> USB doesn't hold a candle to

463
00:23:26.739 --> 00:23:27.550
FireWire all right?

464
00:23:27.550 --> 00:23:31.350
And that's because FireWire doesn't
have to break information down.

465
00:23:31.350 --> 00:23:35.339
It can send raw uncompressed information
across that wire and it can send it fast.

466
00:23:36.560 --> 00:23:40.354
That's one of the reasons it's used in
high definition videos up until some of

467
00:23:40.354 --> 00:23:43.631
the other connections that we'll
talk about during this episode or

468
00:23:43.631 --> 00:23:45.500
maybe in part two like thunder bolt.

469
00:23:45.500 --> 00:23:49.390
Thunder bolt is the successor, pretty much
kind of like the successor to FireWire.

470
00:23:49.390 --> 00:23:52.321
FireWire is for a long time been very,

471
00:23:52.321 --> 00:23:55.880
very good in things like high
definition video conferencing systems.

472
00:23:55.880 --> 00:23:59.350
A company I used to work for Dan,
had what was known as a life size system.

473
00:23:59.350 --> 00:24:02.340
In fact I think we still have some of
these systems here in the background when

474
00:24:02.340 --> 00:24:03.752
we're doing video conferencing.

475
00:24:03.752 --> 00:24:08.582
And one of the cameras they had was
eight grand, very high definition video,

476
00:24:08.582 --> 00:24:13.190
and they both had the whole system was
just littered with the six pin bullet

477
00:24:13.190 --> 00:24:17.676
shape FireWire connectors and
you know what the USB connector was for?

478
00:24:17.676 --> 00:24:21.037
Keyboard and mouse [CROSSTALK],
it wasn't for the video and so,

479
00:24:21.037 --> 00:24:22.354
there are differences.

480
00:24:22.354 --> 00:24:24.066
Don't let the numbers fool you and

481
00:24:24.066 --> 00:24:28.080
the other thing I say in reality a lot
of these numbers are theoretical.

482
00:24:28.080 --> 00:24:32.147
What you see in actual
speed is really relative

483
00:24:32.147 --> 00:24:36.848
to how well the manufacturer
implements the device.

484
00:24:36.848 --> 00:24:40.620
In another episode, we had a great comment
in the chatroom and Dan, I think you

485
00:24:40.620 --> 00:24:44.279
picked up on this, that says just because
you couldn't get in an adapter and

486

save money doesn't mean it's gonna give
you the performance that you need.

487
00:24:48.020 --> 00:24:49.560
Well, it's the same way.

488
00:24:49.560 --> 00:24:53.030
Manufacturers that put cheap
implementations in their hardware means

489
00:24:53.030 --> 00:24:56.580
that just because the theoretical pathway
is there, I can't turn around and

490
00:24:56.580 --> 00:25:01.810
take my old 84 Ford with a four-cylinder
and expect to outperform the Shelby Cobra.

491
00:25:01.810 --> 00:25:03.506
It just really depends on
how they're implemented.

492
00:25:03.506 --> 00:25:05.254
>> Well Wes Who knew that there were so

493

much to know all about these different
types of cables and connectors that we're

494

gonna be messing around with as
a plus technicians, but guess what?

495
00:25:12.874 --> 00:25:16.781
There is, there's a ton of information
because there's a ton of different types

496

of connections, and I know that we are not

497

we're gonna be looking at here.

498

So, looks like we're gonna have

Probably even farther [LAUGH].

>> [LAUGH]
>> And that being said,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes begin the vast conversation that is PC connections and characteristics. Specific topics covered here includes: Serial ATA(SATA), VGA, Digital Video Interface(DVI), High Definition Multi-Media Interface(HDMI), Tipped Ring Sleeve(TRS), Sony/Phillips Digital Interface(SPDIF), Display Port, and Thunderbolt.

In the first part,

29

Right?
Storage devices.

30
00:01:21.080 --> 00:01:24.160
And it doesn't matter if we're
talking about magnetic media, or

31
00:01:24.160 --> 00:01:26.480
we're talking about electronic storage.

32
00:01:26.480 --> 00:01:29.740
We are talking about hard drives or
solid state drives,

33
00:01:29.740 --> 00:01:32.450
and that's something known as serial ATA.

34
00:01:32.450 --> 00:01:40.165
Now, as you guys are probably familiar,
the A plus isn't as shy in any means.

35
00:01:40.165 --> 00:01:42.945
With acronyms,
you might hear it called SATA drive,

36
00:01:42.945 --> 00:01:45.625
you might hear it called serial ATA,

37
00:01:45.625 --> 00:01:50.245
all stemS back from the very earliest
drives that were called ATA drives.

38
00:01:50.245 --> 00:01:52.535
And actually it started out as IDE drives,
and

39
00:01:52.535 --> 00:01:57.160
then they were retro named ATA for
Advanced Technology Attachment.

40
00:01:57.160 --> 00:01:59.490
We talked about in our
motherboard episodes,

41
00:01:59.490 --> 00:02:03.850
ATX was Advanced Technology Extended,
well, this actually ATA

42
00:02:03.850 --> 00:02:08.810
precedes ATX, going back to the earlier
AT boards, hence the name ATA.

43
00:02:08.810 --> 00:02:12.630
There was an advanced technology
motherboard attachment.

44
00:02:12.630 --> 00:02:15.410
So we're talking about
drive interfaces here.

45
00:02:15.410 --> 00:02:19.790
And in the earlier days these IDE drives,
such as graded drive electronics,

46
00:02:19.790 --> 00:02:23.420
they started to call them that because
of the fact the drives themselves had

47
00:02:23.420 --> 00:02:27.390
integrated controllers on
the hard drives themselves.

48
00:02:27.390 --> 00:02:29.260
Well, that's kinda stuck around.

49
00:02:29.260 --> 00:02:30.590
That hasn't changed.

50
00:02:30.590 --> 00:02:32.770
In the earlier days on computing,

51
00:02:32.770 --> 00:02:36.200
if you were to get a hard drive that
was a whopping ten megs in size,

52
00:02:36.200 --> 00:02:40.020
the drive was probably the size of a small
refrigerator, and it had an expansion card

53
00:02:40.020 --> 00:02:43.320
that it would connect to, and
that was a controller card.

54
00:02:43.320 --> 00:02:46.390
Well, like all technology,
technology gets faster.

55
00:02:46.390 --> 00:02:49.950
We talked about it also getting smaller
in size, that makes it a little bit more

56
00:02:49.950 --> 00:02:52.760
efficient, we could pack a lot more
stuff inside of these system units.

57
00:02:52.760 --> 00:02:55.760
They said well you know what,
how about this,

58
00:02:55.760 --> 00:02:57.770
how about we take that drive controller,

59
00:02:57.770 --> 00:03:01.890
which is essentially what allows to access
information on and off the hard drive.

60
00:03:01.890 --> 00:03:05.390
And we'll take that controller and we'll
slap it right on the hard drive itself.

61
00:03:05.390 --> 00:03:08.890
You can see this in a lot of your serial
ATA drives that there's a little PCB,

62
00:03:08.890 --> 00:03:13.700
a little Green printed circuit board
with wires or traces along it,

63
00:03:13.700 --> 00:03:16.780
and it was what allows you to
read information from the drive,

64
00:03:16.780 --> 00:03:19.210
or write the information to the drive.

65
00:03:19.210 --> 00:03:22.450
Now let's talk a little bit about
the serial ATA standards, SATA standards.

66
00:03:22.450 --> 00:03:25.120
There are a few revisions.

67
00:03:25.120 --> 00:03:29.110
And I actually got a small little diagram
here of those revisions that we need to

68
00:03:29.110 --> 00:03:30.230
be aware of.

69
00:03:30.230 --> 00:03:32.060
Now we got serial ATA 1, 2, and 3.

70
00:03:32.060 --> 00:03:35.460
And we also got something known as eSATA.

71
00:03:35.460 --> 00:03:40.420
eSATA, the e there is for
external, external serial ATA,

72
00:03:40.420 --> 00:03:41.930
and we'll get to that too.

73
00:03:41.930 --> 00:03:45.070
Now, notice that I am saying Serial ATA.

74
00:03:45.070 --> 00:03:48.360
The earlier hard drives were
called Parallel ATA drives,

75
00:03:48.360 --> 00:03:49.820
PATA drives you might heard them called.

76
00:03:49.820 --> 00:03:54.500
And that was a parallel interface, and
they use these 20 pin or 20 conductor and

77
00:03:54.500 --> 00:03:57.260
40 conductor cables, I get ribbon cables.

78
00:03:57.260 --> 00:04:01.760
Had a very short length, I think 18
inches was the standard, the maximum, and

79
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:04.650
again parallel communications
have a lot of interference.

80
00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:08.340
So the next generation type
hard drive storage interface,

81
00:04:08.340 --> 00:04:11.540
connection if you will, to the motherboard
came out was a serial interface.

82
00:04:11.540 --> 00:04:14.430
And a serial interface is great,
because of the fact that

83
00:04:14.430 --> 00:04:18.450
it eliminates things like cross talk, so
that is why we call it serial ATA, right?

84
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:21.690
Earlier parallel interfaces
were just not as efficient.

85
00:04:21.690 --> 00:04:23.880
Now serial ATA one, when it came out,

86
00:04:23.880 --> 00:04:28.170
it was kind of Earth shattering
when we talk about speeds.

87
00:04:28.170 --> 00:04:31.680
The fastest of the parallel ATA devices

88
00:04:31.680 --> 00:04:34.930
was 133 megabyte transfer
speeds per second.

89
00:04:34.930 --> 00:04:37.330
You don't have to worry about parallel
ATA, at least I don't believe so,

90
00:04:37.330 --> 00:04:39.490
because formerly on the objectives
they don't call it out anymore.

91
00:04:39.490 --> 00:04:42.490
Which is good, because we really
don't use it anymore, for

92
00:04:42.490 --> 00:04:44.650
the most part it is a legacy technology.

93
00:04:44.650 --> 00:04:49.520
Serial ATA, the very first revision
that came out was 150 megabytes.

94
00:04:49.520 --> 00:04:52.200
So you could see right away
the very first standard,

95
00:04:52.200 --> 00:04:54.450
broke what the standards
were existing of the day.

96
00:04:54.450 --> 00:04:57.620
The other thing that was great about it,
is the serial ATA cable, and

97
00:04:57.620 --> 00:04:59.760
this is something that I want you
to know about the data cable.

98
00:04:59.760 --> 00:05:04.330
The data cable went from the parallel
ATA's limitation was 18 inches.

99
00:05:04.330 --> 00:05:06.180
Now, if any of you guys have
been in computing for a while,

100
00:05:06.180 --> 00:05:07.040
you're gonna come back and

101
00:05:07.040 --> 00:05:11.280
probably leave me a little nastygram
on our forums, just kidding, guys.

102
00:05:11.280 --> 00:05:15.210
That says, hey, I've seen 24 inch and
32 inch parallel ATA cables and

103
00:05:15.210 --> 00:05:17.150
I'll say, you will.

104
00:05:17.150 --> 00:05:20.540
The American National Standards Institute
never certified them, because of the fact

105
00:05:20.540 --> 00:05:24.220
that the longer a parallel cable, the more
likely it is to have signal attenuation,

106
00:05:24.220 --> 00:05:27.530
the progressive degradation of the signal
as it gets farther from its source, and

107
00:05:27.530 --> 00:05:29.510
increased crosstalk.

108
00:05:29.510 --> 00:05:34.630
But that being said, the serial ATA
cable has a 3.3 foot length, right, so

109
00:05:34.630 --> 00:05:39.780
we've got a lot more
length out of the cable.

110
00:05:39.780 --> 00:05:42.910
150 megabyte per second when it
comes to the transfer speeds, and

111
00:05:42.910 --> 00:05:45.850
that's why sometimes you'll
also hear it called SATA 150,

112
00:05:45.850 --> 00:05:48.670
you might even hear it called SATA 1.5.

113
00:05:48.670 --> 00:05:52.310
So don't let those naming
conventions confuse you.

114
00:05:52.310 --> 00:05:55.470
Now, if you can remember
the very first standard,

115
00:05:55.470 --> 00:05:57.800
it'll make it easy on the exam you guys.

116
00:05:57.800 --> 00:06:01.470
We've been talking about some memorization
techniques here, making it funny,

117
00:06:01.470 --> 00:06:03.940
making little jokes about it that
can help cement it in your mind.

118
00:06:03.940 --> 00:06:07.980
We talked about firewire 800 and 400,
the speed's right there in the name.

119
00:06:07.980 --> 00:06:13.320
If you can remember Serial ATA-1 as
being 150 megabyte transfer speeds,

120
00:06:13.320 --> 00:06:15.040
every standard after that doubles.

121

All right, so

341
00:18:35.740 --> 00:18:36.964
I'm pretty good with my acronyms.

342
00:18:36.964 --> 00:18:37.967
>> Yeah, you are.
>> But sometimes I

343
00:18:37.967 --> 00:18:41.800
definitely fall short of the runway,
[LAUGH] on this one.

344
00:18:41.800 --> 00:18:44.870
Now the next one that we
have again is now kinda

345
00:18:44.870 --> 00:18:48.260
being able to be used between analog and
your digital video.

346
00:18:48.260 --> 00:18:50.090
And that's the DVI-I.

347
00:18:50.090 --> 00:18:54.880
And that I just stands for integrated,
digital video interface integrated.

348
00:18:54.880 --> 00:19:00.030
And again, I want you to keep in mind that
this is an analog and a digital connector.

349
00:19:00.030 --> 00:19:01.600
And it is 22 pins.

350
00:19:01.600 --> 00:19:07.720
And there are a couple of different
types of DVI cables, if you will.

351
00:19:07.720 --> 00:19:11.340
We have what's known and single link and
we have what's known as dual link.

352
00:19:11.340 --> 00:19:15.064
Single link,
it produces lower resolutions.

353
00:19:15.064 --> 00:19:18.330
Dual link,
you can pump more information over it.

354
00:19:18.330 --> 00:19:23.310
So, dual link is, again,
your digital side of things.

355
00:19:23.310 --> 00:19:26.922
And you have a 22 pin with
a flat blade for single link.

356
00:19:26.922 --> 00:19:33.170
You also have 28 pin,
Flat blade for the dual link.

357
00:19:33.170 --> 00:19:35.517
And again, just think about digital video,

358
00:19:35.517 --> 00:19:39.296
higher resolutions that I can pump
across the dual link type interface.

359
00:19:39.296 --> 00:19:44.724
And that leaves me with one of the more
common ones that we see, as well.

360
00:19:44.724 --> 00:19:47.690
And that's the DVI-D, and
that's an all-digital.

361
00:19:47.690 --> 00:19:52.394
That's when we're talking about DVI being
truly digital, no analog support at all.

362
00:19:52.394 --> 00:19:56.570
And that is a 19 pin
connector with a flat blade.

363
00:19:56.570 --> 00:19:58.905
Now that brings me into all-digital.

364
00:19:58.905 --> 00:20:00.062
No analog, no food for you.

365
00:20:00.062 --> 00:20:02.502
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just kidding, no analog at all,

366
00:20:02.502 --> 00:20:04.800
all right, and that's the HDMI.

367
00:20:04.800 --> 00:20:06.632
HDMI is a proprietary interface.

368
00:20:06.632 --> 00:20:09.833
And what I mean by that is that,
believe it or not,

369
00:20:09.833 --> 00:20:15.046
every manufacturer that manufactures
an HDMI technology has to pay royalties.

370
00:20:15.046 --> 00:20:18.150
And I'm not exactly sure who
owns the royalties to it.

371
00:20:18.150 --> 00:20:19.604
>> I do.
>> You do, You do?

372
00:20:19.604 --> 00:20:20.612
Okay, so-
>> Make your

373
00:20:20.612 --> 00:20:21.130
checks out to Daniel, [LAUGH].

374
00:20:21.130 --> 00:20:22.076
>> Actually that's right,

375
00:20:22.076 --> 00:20:24.488
we're just gonna make Daniel's
wallet a little bit fatter here.

376
00:20:24.488 --> 00:20:25.850
And you can send all the hate mail to him.

377
00:20:25.850 --> 00:20:26.772
>> No, I'm just kidding, [LAUGH].

378
00:20:26.772 --> 00:20:27.842
That's all right,
it's all a joke, [LAUGH].

379
00:20:27.842 --> 00:20:31.800
>> So HDMI, that's
the High-Definition Multimedia Interface.

380
00:20:31.800 --> 00:20:34.042
Now this is a 19 pin connector.

381
00:20:34.042 --> 00:20:36.907
And if we could take a look at it here,
I do want you to know, again,

382
00:20:36.907 --> 00:20:37.948
some of the specifics.

383
00:20:37.948 --> 00:20:39.190
Know what it looks like.

384
00:20:39.190 --> 00:20:43.621
They might give you a question on the exam
that says, look at this exhibit and

385
00:20:43.621 --> 00:20:45.778
tell us what type of connector it is.

386
00:20:45.778 --> 00:20:47.830
And then you have
a multiple choice question.

387
00:20:47.830 --> 00:20:50.060
Again, I'm not sure if they will,
but they could.

388
00:20:50.060 --> 00:20:51.780
And I want you to be able to recognize it.

389
00:20:51.780 --> 00:20:54.320
Now, do I expect you to count 19 pins?

390
00:20:54.320 --> 00:20:56.383
Not on your life.
You don't have to count 19 pins at all,

391
00:20:56.383 --> 00:20:57.420
ladies and gentlemen.

392
00:20:57.420 --> 00:21:02.420
But you do have to potentially
have to know it for the exam.

393
00:21:02.420 --> 00:21:06.950
Now one of the great things about the HDMI
interface is that the cable itself

394
00:21:08.210 --> 00:21:14.650
does support not only all-digital video,
it also supports all digital audio.

395
00:21:14.650 --> 00:21:16.260
And it only takes a single cable.

396
00:21:16.260 --> 00:21:18.870
See, some of these other interfaces,
for instance like VGA,

397
00:21:18.870 --> 00:21:21.490
I have a VGA cable, that's my video.

398
00:21:21.490 --> 00:21:25.080
Guess what, I also have a sound card that
I use a one-eighth inch TRS jack to get

399
00:21:25.080 --> 00:21:26.612
sound across.

400
00:21:26.612 --> 00:21:30.532
And then same thing really
with digital video, that DVI.

401
00:21:30.532 --> 00:21:33.270
There's no audio that
goes over those cables.

402
00:21:33.270 --> 00:21:37.492
HDMI, on the other hand,
supports digital audio and video.

403
00:21:37.492 --> 00:21:41.540
And in the later standards also supports
ethernet network communications.

404
00:21:41.540 --> 00:21:45.587
So we're really talking bout a very,
very solid cable.

405
00:21:45.587 --> 00:21:49.192
It's got a lot of popularity,
very popular today in TV.

406
00:21:49.192 --> 00:21:53.410
As well as I couldn't count how many
HDMI cables we have around here and

407
00:21:53.410 --> 00:21:56.500
connected to the various
interfaces that we have.

408
00:21:56.500 --> 00:22:02.202
So not only in the computing industry in
general, but also in your video, as well.

409
00:22:02.202 --> 00:22:06.886
All right, so
next thing they call out again is audio.

410
00:22:06.886 --> 00:22:11.753
All right, now when we talked about audio,
there are a couple different types

411
00:22:11.753 --> 00:22:14.730
of connections that I
want you to be aware of.

412
00:22:14.730 --> 00:22:18.910
And when we talk about audio, really,
I'm talking about two different types.

413
00:22:18.910 --> 00:22:21.450
And again, we got analog, we got digital.

414
00:22:21.450 --> 00:22:24.034
One of the digital types of audio,
we've already mentioned as HDMI.

415
00:22:25.736 --> 00:22:30.570
But I've got a couple of pictures here,
and I've already mentioned one of these.

416
00:22:30.570 --> 00:22:34.497
One of them is the TRS jack, they call it.

417
00:22:34.497 --> 00:22:36.335
And that's because of
this little tip here.

418
00:22:36.335 --> 00:22:38.015
They call it tipped ring sleeve,
all right, so the TRS.

419
00:22:39.355 --> 00:22:41.045
And it might just be
called tipped sleeve too.

420
00:22:41.045 --> 00:22:43.270
I've also seen them called TS jacks.

421
00:22:43.270 --> 00:22:47.121
These are one-eight inch jacks.

422
00:22:47.121 --> 00:22:50.143
And guys and gals out there, I know some
of you are probably in Europe out there.

423
00:22:50.143 --> 00:22:52.431
And say, wait a second,
what is this one-eight?

424
00:22:52.431 --> 00:22:53.887
Well it's also 3.5 millimeter.

425
00:22:53.887 --> 00:22:57.023
I don't know which one they
might ask you on the exam.

426
00:22:57.023 --> 00:22:58.460
But either way you'll be prepared.

427
00:22:58.460 --> 00:23:04.940
So it's either one-eighth inch jack or
it is the 3.5 milimeter jack.

428
00:23:04.940 --> 00:23:08.236
You might see that they also have TRS
jacks in some of your audio connections

429
00:23:08.236 --> 00:23:10.922
that are quarter-inch, right,
the quarter-inch jack.

430
00:23:10.922 --> 00:23:13.010
This is one for your stereo headphones.

431
00:23:13.010 --> 00:23:14.848
A lot bigger, but
again the concept is the same.

432
00:23:14.848 --> 00:23:17.800
And that's where things
like adaptors come in.

433
00:23:17.800 --> 00:23:21.312
These are what connect to the integrated
ports on the back of your computer.

434
00:23:21.312 --> 00:23:25.574
Or if you've got like one of those
Audigy-type sound blaster cards right in

435
00:23:25.574 --> 00:23:29.040
your system,
this is what you'll connect to.

436
00:23:29.040 --> 00:23:33.860
Now remember, we kinda mentioned in
the first episode, just very briefly,

437
00:23:33.860 --> 00:23:37.728
that you could see even optical
cables connected to your PCs?

438
00:23:37.728 --> 00:23:41.976
Well, this is really one of those that,
it's out there.

439
00:23:41.976 --> 00:23:45.290
Again, this is an optical cable,
believe it or not.

440
00:23:45.290 --> 00:23:46.728
I remember it as S/PDIF, [LAUGH].

441
00:23:46.728 --> 00:23:49.205
But that's the Sony/Philips
digital interface.

442
00:23:49.205 --> 00:23:53.620
And again, it is a digital audio signal.

443
00:23:53.620 --> 00:23:58.262
One last one that I'd like to mention that
also supports digital audio is display

444
00:23:58.262 --> 00:24:00.036
port, and with display port,

445
00:24:00.036 --> 00:24:04.190
there are a few connections that
we'll talk about here as well.

446
00:24:04.190 --> 00:24:09.390
You'll see that this is a full sized
display port connection right here, and

447
00:24:09.390 --> 00:24:11.770
display port is a high resolution,

448
00:24:11.770 --> 00:24:16.810
supports very high resolution,
digital video and digital audio.

449
00:24:16.810 --> 00:24:20.960
Now one of the good things,
the difference between display port and

450
00:24:20.960 --> 00:24:23.470
HDMI is display port is royalty free.

451
00:24:23.470 --> 00:24:26.640
HDMI isn't royalty free and
every manufacturer's gotta pay,

452
00:24:26.640 --> 00:24:27.980
I don't know what the percentage is,

453
00:24:27.980 --> 00:24:30.570
a certain percentage to whoever
it is that owns the royalties.

454
00:24:30.570 --> 00:24:33.890
I should probably have that information,
but it's not relevant.

455
00:24:33.890 --> 00:24:36.190
Yeah it's not relevant to the exam at all.

456
00:24:36.190 --> 00:24:38.340
Now you also have Mini-DisplayPort too.

457
00:24:38.340 --> 00:24:42.496
In fact Mini-DisplayPort is
another common technology as well.

458
00:24:42.496 --> 00:24:46.555
Again characteristics of DisplayPort
are going to be the same,

459
00:24:46.555 --> 00:24:50.023
just keep in mind that it is
a digital video interface.

460
00:24:50.023 --> 00:24:54.039
And again, it supports very,
very high resolutions.

461
00:24:55.230 --> 00:24:58.310
Now the other thing that we have as well
that they call out is what's know as

462
00:24:58.310 --> 00:24:59.470
Thunderbolt.

463
00:24:59.470 --> 00:25:03.870
And I want you to really pay attention to
this Thunderbolt connection because, Dan,

464
00:25:03.870 --> 00:25:05.570
could you look at that connection.

465
00:25:05.570 --> 00:25:06.347
That's a Thunderbolt connection, right?

466
00:25:06.347 --> 00:25:07.612
>> That's a Thunderbolt connection, yeah.

467
00:25:07.612 --> 00:25:11.840
>> And the Mini-DisplayPort,
can you tell me any difference?

468
00:25:11.840 --> 00:25:13.920
>> They're almost identical.

469
00:25:13.920 --> 00:25:14.920
>> They're almost identical,

470
00:25:14.920 --> 00:25:18.970
the only difference I can tell is one has
a square, and one has a lightning bolt!

471
00:25:18.970 --> 00:25:19.555
>> Lightning bolt.

472
00:25:19.555 --> 00:25:23.160
>> [LAUGH] And that's because
when Thunderbolt first came out,

473
00:25:23.160 --> 00:25:26.720
Thunderbolt was invented by Apple and
Intel.

474
00:25:26.720 --> 00:25:27.630
When they first came out,

475
00:25:27.630 --> 00:25:32.300
it was called Light Peak technology,
and it blends portions of DisplayPort.

476
00:25:32.300 --> 00:25:38.319
In fact, Thunderbolt technologies
are actually a type of DisplayPort

477
00:25:38.319 --> 00:25:43.560
protocol and it also uses
the PCI Express 2.0 connection.

478
00:25:43.560 --> 00:25:46.730
Now, Thunderbolt's gone through some
different revisions, we have one, two and

479
00:25:46.730 --> 00:25:49.490
we're up to three now,
that I want you to keep in mind.

480
00:25:49.490 --> 00:25:54.240
And it also supports, kind of like we
talked about USB to be a daisy chaining.

481
00:25:54.240 --> 00:25:58.660
You can have up to six devices that
are connected to a Thunderbolt port.

482
00:25:58.660 --> 00:26:02.867
Again, the protocols that you
see are DisplayPort 1.1 and 2.0.

483
00:26:02.867 --> 00:26:06.570
When we talk about Thunderbolt
1.0 the very first revision.

484
00:26:06.570 --> 00:26:10.858
No one mentioned in standards, I don't
know if they're going to ask on the exam,

485
00:26:10.858 --> 00:26:14.670
but you will be thoroughly prepared
if you can remember those features.

486
00:26:14.670 --> 00:26:18.685
The other thing I want you to know is
that the very first Thunderbolt standard

487
00:26:18.685 --> 00:26:22.420
supported 10 gigabit transfer
speeds over a single cable.

488
00:26:22.420 --> 00:26:25.870
And that's one of the reasons I also said
that it's the successor to FireWire cuz

489
00:26:25.870 --> 00:26:29.010
FireWire's amazing, no doubt about it.

490
00:26:29.010 --> 00:26:31.260
And even USB has come up great.

491
00:26:31.260 --> 00:26:34.890
The USB 3.1, not on the exam,
but it's like 10 gigs.

492
00:26:34.890 --> 00:26:37.840
Thunderbolt's very first
standard supports 10 gigs.

493
00:26:37.840 --> 00:26:41.050
So it's a very,
very fast communication technology.

494
00:26:41.050 --> 00:26:45.690
Now, I also want you to know that we have
some different Thunderbolt revisions.

495
00:26:45.690 --> 00:26:47.880
I mentioned 1.1, we are up to 3.0 now.

496
00:26:47.880 --> 00:26:51.259
So, when we look at 2.0,
I want you to understand that 2.0,

497
00:26:51.259 --> 00:26:54.765
2.0 is a 20 gigabyte connection.

498
00:26:54.765 --> 00:26:59.985
All the characteristics, if you will,
are the same, supports up to six devices.

499
00:26:59.985 --> 00:27:05.594
And the difference here is that this
is based off of the PCI BCI Express

500
00:27:05.594 --> 00:27:09.764
2.0 Standard, as well as DisplayPort 1.2.

501
00:27:09.764 --> 00:27:12.557
All right, so you could see that it's
using both of those technologies.

502
00:27:12.557 --> 00:27:17.441
That's why in your expansion cards, we
talk about a Thunderbolt card connects to

503
00:27:17.441 --> 00:27:20.500
the PCI-E bus,
again because of its high speeds.

504
00:27:20.500 --> 00:27:25.790
And we're talking 20 gigabit transfer
speed, so very, very fast connection.

505
00:27:25.790 --> 00:27:27.910
And then, well, we don't stop there,

506
00:27:27.910 --> 00:27:33.030
we talk about Thunderbolt 3
that's out right now, and this is

507
00:27:33.030 --> 00:27:38.220
absolutely insane 40 gigabit transfer
speeds per second over single cable.

508
00:27:38.220 --> 00:27:39.360
So-
>> That's smoking Wes.

509
00:27:39.360 --> 00:27:40.040
>> Yeah, it really is.

510
00:27:40.040 --> 00:27:42.366
Cuz you think about, well why would
I need something that's so fast?

511
00:27:42.366 --> 00:27:42.925
>> Why wouldn't I?

512
00:27:42.925 --> 00:27:44.109
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, why wouldn't I?

513
00:27:44.109 --> 00:27:47.050
That's right.
Ludicrous speed, go.

514
00:27:47.050 --> 00:27:48.555
And here's the thing.

515
00:27:48.555 --> 00:27:54.838
4,000K TVs out there, 4,000K video, 4K
excuse me that would be really big right.

516
00:27:54.838 --> 00:27:58.611
4K resolution and
even 8K resolution out there and

517
00:27:58.611 --> 00:28:03.592
the fact that we've got a lot of
high definition, real beefy files.

518
00:28:03.592 --> 00:28:07.390
You can see that there's more of
a necessity to that not only can you pump

519
00:28:07.390 --> 00:28:11.020
that mount of resolution but
you get a very, very efficient speed.

520
00:28:11.020 --> 00:28:14.410
You get a very,
very good quality experience out of that,

521
00:28:14.410 --> 00:28:17.092
because yeah,
maybe I can support DisplayPort.

522
00:28:17.092 --> 00:28:21.930
DisplayPort supports a 4000k
resolution but it might stutter and

523
00:28:21.930 --> 00:28:25.456
[SOUND] sound like, so
you might see a break or a lag.

524
00:28:25.456 --> 00:28:29.309
Where something like this that just blows
the bandwidth wide open is gonna be

525
00:28:29.309 --> 00:28:32.610
something that supports it really,
really efficiently.

526
00:28:32.610 --> 00:28:34.510
So those are your Thunberbolt connections.

527
00:28:34.510 --> 00:28:37.270
Those are some of the connections that
we do want you to be aware of for

528
00:28:37.270 --> 00:28:39.430
the exam, but
Dan I know I've talked a lot here.

529
00:28:39.430 --> 00:28:42.108
It does look like we are going to work
on a small novel when it comes to PC

530
00:28:42.108 --> 00:28:42.724
connections.

531
00:28:42.724 --> 00:28:43.803
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

532
00:28:43.803 --> 00:28:44.460
>> That's right.

533
00:28:44.460 --> 00:28:48.289
It could definitely fill a little library
inside of your house if you were to print

534
00:28:48.289 --> 00:28:50.320
all this out and put it on a shelf.

535
00:28:50.320 --> 00:28:51.790
It would be massive volumes.

536
00:28:51.790 --> 00:28:54.323
So be prepared,
grab your pencil and paper or

537
00:28:54.323 --> 00:28:58.999
whatever note taking device you have in
front of you because we're continuing on.

538
00:28:58.999 --> 00:29:02.540
We're gonna have to make a part
three on more connection types.

539
00:29:02.540 --> 00:29:03.860
As for this episode, we do thank you for

540
00:29:03.860 --> 00:29:06.660
watching, hopefully you've enjoyed it and
are getting a lot out of it.

541
00:29:06.660 --> 00:29:08.830
As for this episode, though,
we need to sign off.

542
00:29:08.830 --> 00:29:11.300
For ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

543
00:29:11.300 --> 00:29:11.970
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

544
00:29:11.970 --> 00:29:13.679
>> And we'll see you next time.

545
00:29:13.679 --> 00:29:20.493
[MUSIC]

546
00:29:20.493 --> 00:29:23.756
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

Specific topics covered here includes: Composite/RCA, Component/RGB, Bluetooth, Infrared(IR), Near Field Communications(NFC), and Adapters like DVI-to-VGA, Thunderbolt-to-DVI, HDMI-to-VGA, etc.
