460
00:24:01.000 --> 00:24:04.400
But, that being said, whew,
right, we're done with those.

461
00:24:04.400 --> 00:24:05.440
We do thank you for watching.

462
00:24:05.440 --> 00:24:06.600
We're at the end of our episode.

463
00:24:06.600 --> 00:24:10.120
So, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

464
00:24:10.120 --> 00:24:10.870
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

465
00:24:10.870 --> 00:24:11.870
>> We'll see you next time.

466
00:24:11.870 --> 00:24:19.321
[MUSIC]

467
00:24:19.321 --> 00:24:20.929
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Wes explore installing a power supply based on given specifications. Specific topics covered include: Connector types and their voltages, Wattage, Form Factor, Molex types, voltage options, etc...
episodes.title: Power Supplies
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:01.425
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.425 --> 00:00:08.319
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.319 --> 00:00:11.870
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.870 --> 00:00:14.006
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.006 --> 00:00:15.791
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.791 --> 00:00:18.673
I'm your host Zach Memos for CompTIA A+.

7
00:00:18.673 --> 00:00:22.699
And we are gonna be looking at power
supplies today with our IT expert

8
00:00:22.699 --> 00:00:24.970
Wes Bryan, he's agreed to join us.

9
00:00:24.970 --> 00:00:26.180
Wes, good to see you, sir.

10
00:00:26.180 --> 00:00:27.600
>> Hey man, how you doing, Zach?

11
00:00:27.600 --> 00:00:29.041
>> Great, great.
>> It is great to be back here in

12
00:00:29.041 --> 00:00:29.640
the studios.

13
00:00:29.640 --> 00:00:30.309
That's right,

14
00:00:30.309 --> 00:00:33.430
we're gonna be looking at one of
the major system components today, right.

15
00:00:33.430 --> 00:00:36.470
We have the system unit and
we've got many different components.

16
00:00:36.470 --> 00:00:39.622
We talk about things like the motherboard
being really the spine of the whole

17
00:00:39.622 --> 00:00:41.650
operation that connects
everything together.

18
00:00:41.650 --> 00:00:45.639
We talk about the CPU, right, the CPU
being the brains of the operation and

19
00:00:45.639 --> 00:00:49.757
the hard drive being that container where
we store all of the information that

20
00:00:49.757 --> 00:00:50.980
we're working with.

21
00:00:50.980 --> 00:00:54.168
We talk about RAM being
the temporary workbench for

22
00:00:54.168 --> 00:00:58.230
your information that
you're currently using.

23
00:00:58.230 --> 00:01:01.626
But what is it that powers
the whole entire operation, so

24
00:01:01.626 --> 00:01:03.690
this is where power units come in.

25
00:01:03.690 --> 00:01:08.460
So let's go ahead and, A+ is never without
any acronyms, right, so let's go ahead and

26
00:01:08.460 --> 00:01:11.020
we'll feed you some
alphabet soup right away.

27
00:01:11.020 --> 00:01:15.020
PSU, that's the power supply unit, it's
a very, very important component, right,

28
00:01:15.020 --> 00:01:19.440
because it's really what
powers the whole operation.

29
00:01:19.440 --> 00:01:23.220
We can have all of these components but if
we don't have a power supply we don't have

30
00:01:23.220 --> 00:01:28.270
anything, so it is important that we
talk about the power supply in general.

31
00:01:28.270 --> 00:01:33.200
Now I wanna do a little bit of a recap
from an earlier episode that we had,

32
00:01:33.200 --> 00:01:34.950
right, we talked about form factor.

33
00:01:34.950 --> 00:01:39.133
And one of the things that we've mentioned
in a few different episode, right,

34
00:01:39.133 --> 00:01:42.201
we said three form factors have to match,
right, three.

35
00:01:42.201 --> 00:01:44.350
All right, well what is that,
what are those three?

36
00:01:44.350 --> 00:01:47.858
Well one of them is gonna be your case,
your tower, right, chassis,

37
00:01:47.858 --> 00:01:50.685
three different terms meaning
the same thing, right?

38
00:01:50.685 --> 00:01:53.400
>> Mm-hm.
>> It is the skin, if you will,

39
00:01:53.400 --> 00:01:57.280
that holds all of the system
unit components together.

40
00:01:57.280 --> 00:02:00.130
The next one is the motherboard,
right, again kinda like

41
00:02:00.130 --> 00:02:04.135
the backbone to the entire system unit,
right, ties everything together.

42
00:02:04.135 --> 00:02:07.990
And last but not least what we're gonna
talk about in this episode is the power

43
00:02:07.990 --> 00:02:11.860
supply unit, right, and that's important
to understand that the power supply unit,

44
00:02:11.860 --> 00:02:16.060
or PSU if you will,
that it also has a form factor.

45
00:02:16.060 --> 00:02:19.410
It's not just about the size and
the shape of the power supply,

46
00:02:19.410 --> 00:02:23.990
that certainly is a major consideration,
right, but

47
00:02:23.990 --> 00:02:28.750
it's also about things like the power
connections that you have available,

48
00:02:28.750 --> 00:02:30.960
right, that's why it's also important.

49
00:02:30.960 --> 00:02:34.452
If we take a trip back in time and
we go back to the AT standard,

50
00:02:34.452 --> 00:02:37.415
right, that was the predecessor
to the ATX board.

51
00:02:37.415 --> 00:02:41.935
Now the ATX form factor's been in place
for a long time, you guys as the taping of

52
00:02:41.935 --> 00:02:45.715
this you guys and gals out there probably
realize it's somewhere around 2017,

53
00:02:45.715 --> 00:02:49.355
maybe give or take a few months
depending on when you're watching this.

54
00:02:50.580 --> 00:02:55.439
Well the ATX standard came out in 1995,
so again we're talking before that,

55
00:02:55.439 --> 00:02:59.520
right, they had the AT standard and here's
where form factor also comes into play.

56
00:02:59.520 --> 00:03:02.080
In the AT days, right,
the AT motherboards,

57
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:06.767
they had two main power
connectors on the motherboard.

58
00:03:06.767 --> 00:03:10.110
They had what was known as a P8 and
a P9 connector, right, and

59
00:03:10.110 --> 00:03:13.980
they were identical and the problem with
that is that they could be reversed.

60
00:03:13.980 --> 00:03:17.890
And that's a really bad day at the office,
right, when you power up a power supply

61
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:21.180
where the main power connectors have
actually been flip-flopped, right, so

62
00:03:21.180 --> 00:03:24.290
you had to pay attention to
the coloring of the wires.

63
00:03:24.290 --> 00:03:27.475
And we're gonna talk a little bit about
some of the different voltages that you

64
00:03:27.475 --> 00:03:30.040
can find and the colors,
if you will, of some of these wires.

65
00:03:30.040 --> 00:03:34.430
Now I want you to understand that's one of
the main reasons you have to understand

66
00:03:34.430 --> 00:03:38.850
the form factor, right, not only just the
size and the characteristics, if you will,

67
00:03:38.850 --> 00:03:41.840
the arrangement of the components
within the system unit, but

68
00:03:41.840 --> 00:03:44.420
also because of the main power supply.

69
00:03:44.420 --> 00:03:49.054
See when the ATX standard first came
out we had a 20 pin power connector,

70
00:03:49.054 --> 00:03:53.313
right, we had a 20 pin power
connector that was a keyed or locked,

71
00:03:53.313 --> 00:03:58.140
locking connector, right, and I'll
show you what I mean here in a second.

72
00:03:58.140 --> 00:04:02.175
But it was different because they knew
the problems that the AT power supply had,

73
00:04:02.175 --> 00:04:05.210
right, and
really when it comes down to it it's

74
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:08.920
more the technicians than it
is the actual hardware itself.

75
00:04:08.920 --> 00:04:11.230
So they said you know what,
let's make it a little bit easier so

76
00:04:11.230 --> 00:04:16.846
you know exactly how to insert this
main power connector on the motherboard.

77
00:04:16.846 --> 00:04:20.550
So they made it a notched connector,
right, it has some shapes that it

78
00:04:20.550 --> 00:04:22.780
follows with the main power
connector on the motherboard and

79
00:04:22.780 --> 00:04:27.090
he main power plug itself that comes
off the back of the power supply.

80
00:04:27.090 --> 00:04:32.700
All right, as time progressed we needed
a little bit more power on the CPU so they

81
00:04:32.700 --> 00:04:37.490
came out with what was known as the 20+4
pin connector, right, and that extra four

82
00:04:37.490 --> 00:04:40.920
pins, if you will, would power the Pentium
processors that came out in the day.

83
00:04:40.920 --> 00:04:43.888
Because Pentium kind of shattered
everything when it comes

84
00:04:43.888 --> 00:04:47.151
to power requirements,
they're really power hungry, right,

85
00:04:47.151 --> 00:04:49.660
really powerful processors,
so we needed more.

86
00:04:49.660 --> 00:04:54.237
Today's standard follows what's known as,
again it's the ATX standard still but

87
00:04:54.237 --> 00:04:58.700
it's kind of gone through some revisions
and today is a solid 24 pin connector.

88
00:04:58.700 --> 00:05:02.210
All right, so understand that,
so what is the power supply?

89
00:05:02.210 --> 00:05:05.360
That's a little bit about the form factor
and we'll look at those connectors here

90
00:05:05.360 --> 00:05:07.350
because we can actually
kind of show you all three.

91
00:05:07.350 --> 00:05:12.410
Some of the power supply companies today
they're just really smart about how they

92
00:05:12.410 --> 00:05:16.080
put their power supplies together, and
they actually put some power supplies

93
00:05:16.080 --> 00:05:20.470
together so that it didn't matter if
you had which of the three revisions

94
00:05:20.470 --> 00:05:23.710
of ATX standard you had,
you'd get one power supply and

95
00:05:23.710 --> 00:05:27.810
it would support all three so
it's nice the way they put those together.

96
00:05:27.810 --> 00:05:29.580
So let's talk about some basics as well,

97
00:05:29.580 --> 00:05:33.310
not just form factor, remember form
factor's important, all right.

98
00:05:33.310 --> 00:05:37.240
The other thing that you have to keep in
mind is what is the power supply doing?

99
00:05:37.240 --> 00:05:40.198
Well you could say well, Wes,
you just told us, right, and

100
00:05:40.198 --> 00:05:42.006
it'd be a very short episode, too.

101
00:05:42.006 --> 00:05:43.270
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] It brings

102
00:05:43.270 --> 00:05:47.841
power into our devices or our components
within the system unit, it does, but

103
00:05:47.841 --> 00:05:52.622
what it's doing is it's actually taking
the alternating current that's coming

104
00:05:52.622 --> 00:05:56.580
from your AC outlet in the wall and
it's converting it.

105
00:05:56.580 --> 00:05:59.750
It's converting it from alternating
current into the direct

106
00:05:59.750 --> 00:06:03.220
current that our components need
to operate properly, right,

107
00:06:03.220 --> 00:06:05.800
they don't do well off
of frequency variations.

108
00:06:05.800 --> 00:06:08.790
So alternating current isn't what
your computer circuitry runs off of,

109
00:06:08.790 --> 00:06:13.730
it runs off a direct current, DC power,
so it takes the AC power from the wall,

110
00:06:13.730 --> 00:06:18.370
it converts it into DC, and
then it goes to power the devices.

111
00:06:18.370 --> 00:06:22.160
But it has to do something else, believe
it or not it also does what's known as

112
00:06:22.160 --> 00:06:25.150
power sequencing,
it's a stepping down of the voltages.

113
00:06:25.150 --> 00:06:29.910
Cuz if you think about it, right, the
voltages that we have coming from the wall

114
00:06:29.910 --> 00:06:33.040
how many volts do we have,
we have roughly 110 volts.

115
00:06:33.040 --> 00:06:37.252
So 110 volts, what do we need for
our computer circuitry, we need 12 volts,

116
00:06:37.252 --> 00:06:39.710
well that's a little bit of overkill,
right?

117
00:06:39.710 --> 00:06:41.853
[LAUGH] So-
>> So stepping down is important.

118
00:06:41.853 --> 00:06:43.410
>> That's right, that's exactly it.

119
00:06:43.410 --> 00:06:47.400
So what we need is that current comes in,
or I should say out,

120
00:06:47.400 --> 00:06:50.540
of the AC outlet, right,
goes into the power supply,

121
00:06:50.540 --> 00:06:52.970
the power supply converts
it to direct current.

122
00:06:52.970 --> 00:06:57.010
But then it goes through this process
of stepping down the voltages

123
00:06:57.010 --> 00:07:00.620
to the main three voltages that we
see inside of our computers, right,

124
00:07:00.620 --> 00:07:05.855
that's gonna be 12 volts, that's gonna be
5 volts, and it's going to be 3.3 volts.

125
00:07:05.855 --> 00:07:09.945
Now understand that your RAM, there's
also some other voltage regulation that

126
00:07:09.945 --> 00:07:13.545
goes on inside of the motherboard
because certain things like DDR3

127
00:07:13.545 --> 00:07:18.133
today are RAM that we talk about in
other episodes, is even lower than that.

128
00:07:18.133 --> 00:07:22.665
So there's more voltage regulation
that goes onto that, but before

129
00:07:22.665 --> 00:07:27.188
that happens those are the main three
voltages that we need to be aware of.

130
00:07:27.188 --> 00:07:29.870
Now I wanna talk a little bit about

131
00:07:29.870 --> 00:07:34.030
some of the two different types
of voltages you could see.

132
00:07:34.030 --> 00:07:36.792
You could see 110, I've talked about,
and that's common here in the States.

133
00:07:36.792 --> 00:07:41.295
However if you're in other nations,
things like Europe over there,

134
00:07:41.295 --> 00:07:43.813
you might have 220, all right, and

135
00:07:43.813 --> 00:07:48.466
the power supplies need to be set to
the right setting in order to, well,

136
00:07:48.466 --> 00:07:52.465
make sure that you don't underpower or
overpower a machine.

137
00:07:52.465 --> 00:07:55.494
Right, if you underpower it then
you just cause all kinds of havoc,

138
00:07:55.494 --> 00:07:58.114
you overpower it you can ruin
electrical damage, right?

139
00:07:58.114 --> 00:08:01.121
You could fry things in the mother
board quite literary, right?

140
00:08:01.121 --> 00:08:04.140
You never wanna smell a burning smell or
smoke, right?

141
00:08:04.140 --> 00:08:07.170
You definitely done some damage here.

142
00:08:07.170 --> 00:08:10.500
If we could take a look at the power
server, so we've got one here, right?

143
00:08:10.500 --> 00:08:12.340
And this power supply believe it or

144
00:08:12.340 --> 00:08:18.190
not is what is known as an auto
switching power supply, right?

145
00:08:18.190 --> 00:08:22.690
Because one of the things that I see here,
right, we have our 12 volt, right,

146
00:08:22.690 --> 00:08:25.530
AC adapter that goes into
the back of the power supply.

147
00:08:25.530 --> 00:08:27.600
We have an on off switch right?

148
00:08:27.600 --> 00:08:31.940
Not everyone of the power supplies is even
gonna have a manual on off switch right?

149
00:08:31.940 --> 00:08:34.514
But there's another switch that's
missing out here right, and

150
00:08:34.514 --> 00:08:35.979
that is the little selector switch.

151
00:08:35.979 --> 00:08:40.109
Sometimes on the back of the power
supply what you're gonna see is that

152
00:08:40.109 --> 00:08:44.519
there's this little red switch and
if you fix it to one side it says 110 or

153
00:08:44.519 --> 00:08:49.997
115 I think it says and then you fix it to
the other side, it says 220 or 225, right?

154
00:08:49.997 --> 00:08:55.121
That's letting you know that you're
either running if you're here this stage,

155
00:08:55.121 --> 00:08:59.350
you run 110 or
115 as it might say on the power supply.

156
00:08:59.350 --> 00:09:03.940
If you're over in the other like European
nations and stuff, you would fix it and

157
00:09:03.940 --> 00:09:09.330
switch it manually to the 225, that's
what not as a fixed input power supply.

158
00:09:09.330 --> 00:09:14.090
However, a lot of them today Zach are just
like we see here, I don't have anything

159
00:09:14.090 --> 00:09:18.260
other than the on off switch,
I don't have any manual switch here.

160
00:09:18.260 --> 00:09:22.390
And even if I turn this to the other side,
you'll see, well, it's pretty much blank,

161
00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:23.610
there's nothing there.

162
00:09:23.610 --> 00:09:26.630
And what that means is
this is auto switching.

163
00:09:26.630 --> 00:09:32.025
It means, the power supply can detect
what voltage you're suppose to be on,

164
00:09:32.025 --> 00:09:34.266
[CROSSTALK] That's exactly it,

165
00:09:34.266 --> 00:09:39.417
it automatically adjust to the proper
voltage coming from the AC outlet.

166
00:09:39.417 --> 00:09:43.417
Now, if you ever need to know a little
bit more about the voltages that you

167
00:09:43.417 --> 00:09:44.490
might see.

168
00:09:44.490 --> 00:09:47.740
You can actually and if we could zoom in
just a little bit here, you could see that

169
00:09:47.740 --> 00:09:51.530
there's a panel right here that kind
of tells us some information right?

170
00:09:51.530 --> 00:09:57.300
It says DC output, and I can see that
there's 3.3 volts, I can see 5 volts and

171
00:09:57.300 --> 00:10:01.850
I can see 12 volts, right, so
I know what I'm supposed to expect.

172
00:10:01.850 --> 00:10:05.310
I can also see the wattage here too and
this is a pretty beefy power supply,

173
00:10:05.310 --> 00:10:08.230
this is a kilowatt power supply,
it's 1000 watts, 1050 watts and

174
00:10:08.230 --> 00:10:12.260
I believe that's Might be match load,
yeah, match load here.

175
00:10:12.260 --> 00:10:15.950
So this is a pretty strong power supply,

176
00:10:15.950 --> 00:10:18.990
it's got a lot of get up and
go here, all right?

177
00:10:18.990 --> 00:10:22.690
So, that's some of the basics about your
power supplies that we want you to know.

178
00:10:22.690 --> 00:10:25.780
I want you to keep in mind
that when it comes down to it,

179
00:10:25.780 --> 00:10:29.450
if you don't see the selector switch
on the outside of the power supply, and

180
00:10:29.450 --> 00:10:32.770
I'm not talking about the on-off switch
cuz you can have a manual on-off switch.

181
00:10:32.770 --> 00:10:37.130
If you notice that some of them don't
have an on-off switch, what's that about?

182
00:10:37.130 --> 00:10:41.980
Well that means that because of
the advanced configuration power interface

183
00:10:41.980 --> 00:10:45.000
ACPI, believe Intel started it.

184
00:10:45.000 --> 00:10:47.660
There used to be a day, and
Zack maybe you remember this,

185
00:10:47.660 --> 00:10:49.550
back in the days of like Windows 95 and
98.

186
00:10:49.550 --> 00:10:53.970
Do you ever remember shutting your
computer off and then in the middle of

187
00:10:53.970 --> 00:10:57.920
the screen it would say,
it's now safe to shut down your computer.

188
00:10:57.920 --> 00:10:58.980
>> Yes.
>> Do you remember that?

189
00:10:58.980 --> 00:10:59.660
>> I still do.

190
00:10:59.660 --> 00:11:04.190
>> Now what was happening there was, that
was before the days when software could

191
00:11:04.190 --> 00:11:09.910
control the power right, to your hardware,
and so it's been a while, right?

192
00:11:09.910 --> 00:11:13.640
Today we have the advance
configuration power interface, ACPI,

193
00:11:13.640 --> 00:11:15.060
intel invented invented it.

194
00:11:15.060 --> 00:11:18.930
That means the software could send
a shutdown signal to the power supply, and

195
00:11:18.930 --> 00:11:22.810
that's why today, when you shut off your
operating systems everything shuts off,

196
00:11:22.810 --> 00:11:24.750
power supply turns off and
everything, right?

197
00:11:24.750 --> 00:11:26.520
So, understand that,

198
00:11:26.520 --> 00:11:30.660
that's why some of the power supplies
might not have an on/off switch.

199
00:11:30.660 --> 00:11:34.070
Some of them do so you can manually
turn it off after the fact.

200
00:11:34.070 --> 00:11:38.460
I wouldn't recommend ever
Just reaching over and

201
00:11:38.460 --> 00:11:42.140
doing a hard shutdown, right,
do a graceful shutdown, right?

202
00:11:42.140 --> 00:11:45.370
And that means the operating system
shuts itself down through that advanced

203
00:11:45.370 --> 00:11:46.680
configuration power interface.

204
00:11:46.680 --> 00:11:50.080
Because if you reach over and
you do a hard shutdown,

205
00:11:50.080 --> 00:11:53.770
you do run the risk of what's known as
a critical kernel power failure, and

206
00:11:53.770 --> 00:11:55.570
you could lose some of your data, right?

207
00:11:55.570 --> 00:12:00.740
Your computer could be right in the middle
of a write the read processes aren't so

208

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore building custom PCs as called out in the A+ 220-901 exam. Here they will walk you through choosing the correct CPU, Memory, Network adapter(s), and storage required for PC types like Graphics/CAD/CAM, Virtualization, Gaming, Home Server, and thick/thin client workstations.
episodes.title: Custom PCs

need something known as a TB tuner card.

587
00:29:02.710 --> 00:29:08.310
We have talked about those tuner
cards in a prior episode, but

588
00:29:08.310 --> 00:29:14.300
keep in mind what it does is it allows you
to stream, basically tune into television

589
00:29:14.300 --> 00:29:19.370
and you can stream at things like your
cable TV right into the home theater PC.

590
00:29:19.370 --> 00:29:22.920
It allows you to basically
take that information.

591
00:29:22.920 --> 00:29:26.840
You can even output it to high
definition monitors as well out to your

592
00:29:26.840 --> 00:29:29.350
big 55 inch TV if you end up having one.

593
00:29:29.350 --> 00:29:33.990
So those are a couple of things
in the home theater PC as well.

594
00:29:33.990 --> 00:29:37.650
I will tell you that there are couple
other things that they call out.

595
00:29:37.650 --> 00:29:39.950
They call out what are known
as standard thick clients and

596
00:29:39.950 --> 00:29:42.290
they call out what is
known as a thin client.

597
00:29:42.290 --> 00:29:43.675
Standard thick client, guys,

598
00:29:43.675 --> 00:29:46.199
gals out there,
I want you to know it's a basic computer.

599
00:29:46.199 --> 00:29:47.215
That's your workstation.

600
00:29:47.215 --> 00:29:51.965
Your average workstation, it basically
runs your desktop applications and

601
00:29:51.965 --> 00:29:56.057
it basically has to meet whatever
the minimum requirements are for

602
00:29:56.057 --> 00:29:58.115
the selected operating system.

603
00:29:58.115 --> 00:30:01.680
So if you're running Windows,
Windows has a very low requirement,

604
00:30:01.680 --> 00:30:04.400
minimum recommended requirement,
I think it's like one gig of RAM.

605
00:30:04.400 --> 00:30:06.520
However, just because you meet
the minimum requirements,

606
00:30:06.520 --> 00:30:10.160
the operating system doesn't mean you're
gonna get a good computing experience.

607
00:30:10.160 --> 00:30:14.480
So, also keep that in mind that just
because you meet the minimums doesn't mean

608
00:30:14.480 --> 00:30:16.350
you should stay with the minimums.

609
00:30:16.350 --> 00:30:20.090
Again, I typically recommend
today a minimum of four gigs,

610
00:30:20.090 --> 00:30:22.426
however with 64 bit being so prevalent,

611
00:30:22.426 --> 00:30:27.310
I mena, six, eight gigs is perfectly
fine for a standard thick client.

612
00:30:27.310 --> 00:30:30.115
And that is the opposite of what's
known as a thin client, all right.

613
00:30:30.115 --> 00:30:32.472
When we look at what's
know as a thin client,

614
00:30:32.472 --> 00:30:35.460
a thin client is a machine that
is very small form factor.

615
00:30:35.460 --> 00:30:38.229
In fact yeah, there we go,
we got a thin client right here.

616
00:30:38.229 --> 00:30:40.388
Actually they got kind of a lot
of power by today's means.

617
00:30:40.388 --> 00:30:43.230
I know you probably seen some of
the thin clients over the years.

618
00:30:43.230 --> 00:30:47.630
And a thin client is a very
streamlined machine.

619
00:30:47.630 --> 00:30:50.790
It has very limited resources and that's
kind of a [LAUGH] joke when you look at

620
00:30:50.790 --> 00:30:52.740
these thin clients,
cuz they actually have beefed them up.

621
00:30:52.740 --> 00:30:56.620
I've seen some that In the past it had
less than a gig of RAM quite literally.

622
00:30:56.620 --> 00:30:58.083
Because they're not running their own,

623
00:30:58.083 --> 00:30:59.893
they might be running their
own operating system.

624
00:30:59.893 --> 00:31:04.823
A very slimmed down highly optimized
operating system that runs with very

625
00:31:04.823 --> 00:31:08.170
limited memory, and
almost zero local storage.

626
00:31:08.170 --> 00:31:11.120
I've seen them even more with the
operating system is actually pulled down

627
00:31:11.120 --> 00:31:15.260
to the machine off of a server and loaded
at the time that you log into the device

628
00:31:15.260 --> 00:31:17.950
and then once you shut the device down,
the operating system is gone.

629
00:31:17.950 --> 00:31:22.810
So again thin clients, they meet
things like your basic applications,

630
00:31:22.810 --> 00:31:26.090
they talk about meets the minimum
requirements for the operating system.

631
00:31:26.090 --> 00:31:30.350
Again, it depends on what the thin
up OS the thin client is running.

632
00:31:30.350 --> 00:31:32.810
A lot of times these are specialized

633
00:31:32.810 --> 00:31:35.030
additions of your different
operating systems.

634
00:31:35.030 --> 00:31:38.930
Again, very,
very small footprint if you will.

635
00:31:38.930 --> 00:31:41.510
The other thing to keep in
mind too is that thin clients

636
00:31:41.510 --> 00:31:44.890
need good network connectivity, cuz a lot
of times that's what they are doing.

637
00:31:44.890 --> 00:31:47.750
They're connecting over the network to

638
00:31:47.750 --> 00:31:52.950
another massive computer that's actually
running the operating system for them.

639
00:31:52.950 --> 00:31:57.070
And I believe if we look,
I think this is a, yeah, so

640
00:31:57.070 --> 00:32:01.930
you can see that this has the RJ 45
jack and this is a gigabyte connection.

641
00:32:01.930 --> 00:32:03.060
If I remember seeing right.

642
00:32:03.060 --> 00:32:07.233
Yeah, so it's got Gigabit Ethernet,
not gigabyte, excuse me, Gigabit Ethernet.

643
00:32:07.233 --> 00:32:09.751
And notice that it says it's
running Windows 10 embedded, right.

644
00:32:09.751 --> 00:32:14.180
That's that slimline Windows 10 that's not
the full blown home edition if you will

645
00:32:14.180 --> 00:32:17.564
of Windows 10 certainly not pro
[CROSSTALK], that's right, so

646
00:32:17.564 --> 00:32:20.716
you're gonna have a little bit
of a limited functionality.

647
00:32:20.716 --> 00:32:23.224
Now, Dan I know we're running out of time,
but

648
00:32:23.224 --> 00:32:27.319
we do have one last one that we wanna
talk about and that's the home server PC.

649
00:32:27.319 --> 00:32:31.835
When we talk about the home
server PC just like the audio and

650
00:32:31.835 --> 00:32:36.168
video station, keep in mind,
that storage is a very big

651
00:32:36.168 --> 00:32:41.300
consideration with home media servers,
if you will.

652
00:32:41.300 --> 00:32:44.910
And basically a media server doesn't have
to be anything that's in a server closet.

653
00:32:44.910 --> 00:32:46.550
It could just be a normal workstation,

654
00:32:46.550 --> 00:32:48.760
but there are things that
are specific to it, right?

655
00:32:48.760 --> 00:32:50.550
It has to perform things
like media streaming.

656
00:32:50.550 --> 00:32:54.790
Could be a TV tuner card, you might have
things where its storing information like

657
00:32:54.790 --> 00:32:56.330
files, so you do file sharing.

658
00:32:56.330 --> 00:32:59.210
Share your photos over
the network if you will.

659
00:32:59.210 --> 00:33:01.140
As well as print sharing.

660
00:33:01.140 --> 00:33:03.910
You might have a printer in your house,

661
00:33:03.910 --> 00:33:07.640
and it's controlling what
print jobs go to the printer.

662
00:33:07.640 --> 00:33:10.180
So, that might be something that you need.

663
00:33:10.180 --> 00:33:13.490
Keep that in mind that if its a wired
connection you need your ethernet

664
00:33:13.490 --> 00:33:16.210
network jack in the PC itself.

665
00:33:16.210 --> 00:33:19.780
If it's a wireless connection then it has
to support the wireless functionality.

666
00:33:19.780 --> 00:33:22.970
Or you can add that functionality
by adding a wireless card

667
00:33:22.970 --> 00:33:24.910
to an expansion slot.

668
00:33:24.910 --> 00:33:28.410
Gigabit NIC as well, because there's gonna
be a lot of people, could be potential for

669
00:33:28.410 --> 00:33:29.950
a lot of people connecting to it.

670
00:33:29.950 --> 00:33:32.750
And more so today, because there's a lot
of high definition video out there,

671
00:33:32.750 --> 00:33:35.820
you need the gigabit NIC,
because it allows more information.

672
00:33:35.820 --> 00:33:38.820
Especially that high
definition streaming media

673
00:33:38.820 --> 00:33:41.950
to just give you a better performance.

674
00:33:41.950 --> 00:33:44.590
And it's the same thing with the audio and
video when it comes to storage.

675
00:33:44.590 --> 00:33:47.490
You need a large capacity
drive if you will,

676
00:33:47.490 --> 00:33:50.990
and this is where it differs a little bit.

677
00:33:50.990 --> 00:33:53.120
If you're talking about
an audio video station,

678
00:33:53.120 --> 00:33:55.700
then you want things like
a solid state drive drive,

679
00:33:55.700 --> 00:33:59.150
cuz you need not only a large drive,
you need a fast drive right to do.

680
00:33:59.150 --> 00:34:02.380
The processing, if you will, and
get to that information quicker.

681
00:34:02.380 --> 00:34:04.560
On the home PC, the home server PC,

682
00:34:04.560 --> 00:34:06.500
you don't necessarily
need a solid state drive.

683
00:34:06.500 --> 00:34:07.340
It's great to have.

684
00:34:07.340 --> 00:34:10.160
In fact, I kinda recommended it to one
of the other hosts here who's actually

685
00:34:10.160 --> 00:34:12.880
building a home media server right now.

686
00:34:12.880 --> 00:34:17.494
And again, because one of the two of
the main components that we need here is

687
00:34:17.494 --> 00:34:20.218
a fast network adapter, a fast hard drive.

688
00:34:20.218 --> 00:34:23.690
And the reason I say that is, because the
hard drive is what is storing your videos,

689
00:34:23.690 --> 00:34:26.816
and your photos, and when people
are connecting to it the faster that drive

690
00:34:26.816 --> 00:34:30.140
the faster they can get to it
the better experience they have.

691
00:34:30.140 --> 00:34:35.173
Last thing for the home server PC is
typically some kind of raid array.

692
00:34:35.173 --> 00:34:40.030
If you have all of your photos,
all of your movies if you will.

693
00:34:40.030 --> 00:34:42.220
Chances are you want a little
bit of fault tolerance, so

694
00:34:42.220 --> 00:34:47.680
that if one of the drives fails,
you still have access to your information.

695
00:34:47.680 --> 00:34:49.300
You don't lose all your information.

696
00:34:49.300 --> 00:34:54.390
Now, if the information that is on that
home server PC, maybe isn't important

697
00:34:54.390 --> 00:34:58.950
to you, then you can also do a RAID
zero where it's performance.

698
00:34:58.950 --> 00:35:03.167
That will be up to you and again keep
in mind the more drives that we add,

699
00:35:03.167 --> 00:35:05.669
the different rate arrays we can obtain,

700
00:35:05.669 --> 00:35:08.630
like a array ten also
brings the price point up.

701
00:35:08.630 --> 00:35:10.410
Do keep that in mind.

702
00:35:10.410 --> 00:35:13.010
Let me see if I forgot anything down here,
I know,

703
00:35:13.010 --> 00:35:16.230
we got a few things in maybe the audio and
video workstation.

704
00:35:16.230 --> 00:35:20.790
The last thing that I might mention is
dual monitors that's almost a must today.

705
00:35:20.790 --> 00:35:23.130
Dual monitors means,
more real estate in front of you,

706
00:35:23.130 --> 00:35:25.370
it means a little bit more productivity.

707
00:35:25.370 --> 00:35:30.090
And that really is just contingent not so
much on the monitors themselves,

708
00:35:30.090 --> 00:35:35.560
more as it is contingent on
the graphics card supporting it.

709
00:35:35.560 --> 00:35:39.530
And most of all your modern graphics
cards, even the integrated functionality

710
00:35:39.530 --> 00:35:43.730
of the motherboard will support
some kind of multi-monitor setup.

711
00:35:43.730 --> 00:35:44.770
>> Very cool stuff, Wes.

712
00:35:44.770 --> 00:35:49.340
We do thank you for showing us how to
build out a custom PC, and the different

713
00:35:49.340 --> 00:35:53.440
types of custom PCs that we might run
into out in the field as A+ technicians.

714
00:35:53.440 --> 00:35:55.350
That being said, it looks like
we're out of time for this episode.

715
00:35:55.350 --> 00:35:56.980
We do thank you for joining us.

716
00:35:56.980 --> 00:35:59.530
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

717
00:35:59.530 --> 00:36:00.480
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

718
00:36:00.480 --> 00:36:02.459
>> We'll see you next time.

719
00:36:02.459 --> 00:36:08.384
[MUSIC]

720
00:36:08.384 --> 00:36:10.490
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes compare and contrast types of display devices and their features. Specific topics covered includes: Cathode Ray Tube(CRT) monitors, Liquid Crystal Display(LCD), Refresh/Frame rates, screen resolutions, multi-monitor support, aspect ratios, and analog vs. digital.
episodes.title: Display Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.174
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.174 --> 00:00:06.150
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.150 --> 00:00:08.414
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.414 --> 00:00:12.192
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.192 --> 00:00:14.016
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:14.016 --> 00:00:16.470
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.470 --> 00:00:18.131
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.131 --> 00:00:21.298
in today's episode we are killing
it with more of our A+ series.

9
00:00:21.298 --> 00:00:24.196
Our 22901, that is,
if you're paying attention, and

10
00:00:24.196 --> 00:00:28.180
joining us in the studio to help us pay
attention, our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:28.180 --> 00:00:29.220
Wes it's good to have you again, man.

12
00:00:29.220 --> 00:00:32.262
>> And you are throwing a lot
on me to pay attention.

13
00:00:32.262 --> 00:00:34.303
That's right, I'm so
broke I can't even pay attention.

14
00:00:34.303 --> 00:00:37.198
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right, guys, welcome back, and

15
00:00:37.198 --> 00:00:40.570
we are continuing along,
just like Dan said, in our A+ series.

16
00:00:40.570 --> 00:00:44.040
And we are really focused in on
that first certification exam.

17
00:00:44.040 --> 00:00:47.931
We're gonna be continuing through, if you
are, like Dan said, following along with

18
00:00:47.931 --> 00:00:51.521
us, you've probably seen that we've
been spending a lot of time in hardware.

19
00:00:51.521 --> 00:00:55.510
Well, the first exam really has to
do a lot with the hardware itself.

20
00:00:55.510 --> 00:00:58.872
Doesn't mean you're not gonna see the
operating system, but for the most part,

21
00:00:58.872 --> 00:01:02.089
we're gonna be looking at those components
that overall make up our computing

22
00:01:02.089 --> 00:01:02.690
experience.

23
00:01:02.690 --> 00:01:06.897
And what we're gonna be diving in today
is how we really see what's going on in

24
00:01:06.897 --> 00:01:11.350
the computing experience, and
that's gonna be display devices.

25
00:01:11.350 --> 00:01:13.980
There are many different
types of displays out there,

26
00:01:13.980 --> 00:01:16.562
all different kinds of manufacturers,
if you will.

27
00:01:16.562 --> 00:01:20.880
And the technology has definitely changed
throughout the years, and we have to

28
00:01:20.880 --> 00:01:25.430
be aware of some of these components,
if you are gonna sit that exam.

29
00:01:25.430 --> 00:01:28.330
So one of the first ones
that we're gonna talk about,

30
00:01:28.330 --> 00:01:31.553
I am glad to see, is no longer
on the exam anymore [LAUGH], and

31
00:01:31.553 --> 00:01:34.473
that's something known as
the old cathode ray tube.

32
00:01:34.473 --> 00:01:38.830
These cathode ray tubes, also called
CRT monitors, these are the big,

33
00:01:38.830 --> 00:01:44.600
big monitors that were very, very heavy,
they weren't space savers, if you will.

34
00:01:44.600 --> 00:01:50.438
Thank goodness today, because they're
kind of a really old technology,

35
00:01:50.438 --> 00:01:53.135
they have ceased to be on our exam.

36
00:01:53.135 --> 00:01:56.588
But we just wanted to mention them here,
just briefly, so

37
00:01:56.588 --> 00:02:01.180
that you understand that at a certain
point, we moved into a couple of types.

38
00:02:01.180 --> 00:02:05.930
The types that are on the exam are gonna
be what is known as the LCD screen,

39
00:02:05.930 --> 00:02:07.360
and the LED screen.

40
00:02:07.360 --> 00:02:10.650
Dan, I don't even think I can get five
minutes into any episode with an A+,

41
00:02:10.650 --> 00:02:13.660
without a little bit of acronym and
alphabet soup.

42
00:02:13.660 --> 00:02:17.090
>> Yeah they definitely love
the acronyms in our line of biz, so

43
00:02:17.090 --> 00:02:20.735
if you don't like it,
that's a really tough thing to swallow.

44
00:02:20.735 --> 00:02:22.540
Because you're gonna
have to get used to it.

45
00:02:22.540 --> 00:02:24.891
>> And that's Dan's way of saying, tough.

46
00:02:24.891 --> 00:02:28.163
So guys, and again, just keep in mind,
learning the new lingo,

47
00:02:28.163 --> 00:02:31.390
just like any profession that
you might be striving to get in.

48
00:02:31.390 --> 00:02:35.807
So these acronyms will become
yesterday's news once you start to

49
00:02:35.807 --> 00:02:37.823
acclimate yourself to them.

50
00:02:37.823 --> 00:02:40.249
So what do we mean when we say LCD,

51
00:02:40.249 --> 00:02:45.728
what we're talking about is something
known as a liquid crystal display.

52
00:02:45.728 --> 00:02:49.304
And when we talk about LEDs,
we're talking about light emitting diodes.

53
00:02:49.304 --> 00:02:51.625
Light emitting diodes,
you've probably seen them before, in fact,

54
00:02:51.625 --> 00:02:53.182
they're kinda popular
today in flashlights.

55
00:02:53.182 --> 00:02:57.455
I know Dan and I were talking about
the old Maglites, real bright light today.

56
00:02:57.455 --> 00:03:01.734
But they're really moving
away from a traditional bulb,

57
00:03:01.734 --> 00:03:04.714
into these really ultra-bright LEDs.

58
00:03:04.714 --> 00:03:07.380
Well, that forms, really,
the basis for the LED monitors and

59
00:03:07.380 --> 00:03:09.195
how they're lit today.

60
00:03:09.195 --> 00:03:14.390
Now, when we talk about LCD screen, a
liquid crystal display, I want you to know

61
00:03:14.390 --> 00:03:17.890
that there are certain components within
it that you kinda wanna be aware of.

62
00:03:17.890 --> 00:03:20.682
In fact, I've got a little
bit of a diagram here, and

63
00:03:20.682 --> 00:03:24.667
what you have with liquid crystal
displays is, you have a series of layers.

64
00:03:24.667 --> 00:03:28.414
Now, I don't think that every individual
layer by any means is gonna be on

65
00:03:28.414 --> 00:03:28.966
the exam.

66
00:03:28.966 --> 00:03:30.331
But it is kinda of good to know,

67
00:03:30.331 --> 00:03:32.860
there'll be a couple of things
that we wanna be aware of.

68
00:03:32.860 --> 00:03:37.500
Like for instance, when you look at
these LCDs, and LED screens, for

69
00:03:37.500 --> 00:03:41.840
that matter, they have what's known as
an anti-reflective layer on the top.

70
00:03:41.840 --> 00:03:45.979
And I wanna take a second just to talk
about that anti-reflective layer,

71
00:03:45.979 --> 00:03:50.316
cuz we gotta be really, really careful on
how you clean the surface of an LCD or

72
00:03:50.316 --> 00:03:54.747
LED screen, because that anti-reflective
layer can actually get damaged.

73
00:03:54.747 --> 00:03:59.562
So you want to make sure that you
are using things like lint free cloths,

74
00:03:59.562 --> 00:04:00.452
if you will.

75
00:04:00.452 --> 00:04:03.767
They have pre-moistened wipes that
are out there, microfibers are very,

76
00:04:03.767 --> 00:04:06.690
very popular today, really,
really good way to clean these off.

77
00:04:06.690 --> 00:04:09.430
But keep in mind, be very, very careful.

78
00:04:09.430 --> 00:04:13.086
Now, as you go through the different
layers, you can see a polarizing layer.

79
00:04:13.086 --> 00:04:17.869
You can see a glass layer, color filters,
if you will, liquid crystal layer as well.

80
00:04:17.869 --> 00:04:23.737
And when we get down to these two layers,
and it's actually both in LEDs and LCDs.

81
00:04:23.737 --> 00:04:26.809
We'll talk about really what the
difference is between these two types here

82
00:04:26.809 --> 00:04:27.723
coming up in a second.

83
00:04:27.723 --> 00:04:31.762
You'll see TFT layer, there we go with
the acronyms again, what does that mean?

84
00:04:31.762 --> 00:04:35.433
Well, that's actually something
known as a thin film transistor, and

85
00:04:35.433 --> 00:04:38.392
it is something that’s specific

we don't overheat, keeping things cool.

310
00:16:02.329 --> 00:16:07.226
OLED screens can be very,
very small form factor, can have a really,

311
00:16:07.226 --> 00:16:12.040
really small real estate, if you will,
as far as the dimensions go,

312
00:16:12.040 --> 00:16:15.700
and produce an excellent
quality type of output.

313
00:16:15.700 --> 00:16:18.480
So those are some that you have, too.

314
00:16:18.480 --> 00:16:21.990
Now the other ones that they also talk
about, they talk about two types.

315
00:16:21.990 --> 00:16:23.815
They talk about a plasma screen.

316
00:16:23.815 --> 00:16:28.841
Plasma screens, they are out there,
they still sell them for sure.

317
00:16:28.841 --> 00:16:31.670
But there are some drawbacks
to a plasma screen.

318
00:16:31.670 --> 00:16:34.220
One, power.

319
00:16:34.220 --> 00:16:38.938
They are very,
very power hungry next to an LED screen.

320
00:16:38.938 --> 00:16:42.758
But they also have a very
wide viewing angle.

321
00:16:42.758 --> 00:16:46.074
They don't have quite the reflections
like an LCD screen would, so

322
00:16:46.074 --> 00:16:48.010
there all benefits to them.

323
00:16:48.010 --> 00:16:49.966
The other one is what is
known as a projector.

324
00:16:49.966 --> 00:16:53.594
And a projector is the one that uses
lenses, if you will, usually red,

325
00:16:53.594 --> 00:16:54.800
green and blue.

326
00:16:54.800 --> 00:16:57.660
And it projects against some
kind of back drop, right.

327
00:16:57.660 --> 00:17:00.450
That's really pretty much, I would say,
for the exam all you have to know

328
00:17:01.720 --> 00:17:06.550
when it comes to a projector,
knowing that type.

329
00:17:06.550 --> 00:17:07.880
All right, moving down on our list,

330
00:17:07.880 --> 00:17:09.665
we gotta talk about what's
known as refresh rate.

331
00:17:09.665 --> 00:17:13.100
And we have to know
what's called frame rate.

332
00:17:13.100 --> 00:17:14.601
And, yes, they are different.

333
00:17:14.601 --> 00:17:18.553
When we talk about refresh rate, it's
kinda interesting that the light sources

334
00:17:18.553 --> 00:17:22.360
that we see when we use artificial
lighting isn't a static light source.

335
00:17:22.360 --> 00:17:26.375
They're actually turning on and
off very, very fast.

336
00:17:26.375 --> 00:17:31.352
And refresh rate, if you will,
is how fast does the screen get repainted,

337
00:17:31.352 --> 00:17:33.580
basically turning on and off?

338
00:17:33.580 --> 00:17:35.631
Refresh rate is measured in hertz.

339
00:17:35.631 --> 00:17:39.701
And one of the things you'll have to keep
in mind is that typically 60 hertz and

340
00:17:39.701 --> 00:17:41.725
above, really, is what you'll see.

341
00:17:41.725 --> 00:17:43.160
And why is that?

342
00:17:43.160 --> 00:17:46.717
Well, a lot of times you can't
even adjust refresh rates anymore.

343
00:17:46.717 --> 00:17:50.233
One of the great things, or one of
the things to keep in mind about refresh

344
00:17:50.233 --> 00:17:53.866
rates, is that anything lower than
60 hertz, the optical nerves within

345
00:17:53.866 --> 00:17:57.860
your eyes actually pick up on the fact
that there's a flickering image.

346
00:17:57.860 --> 00:17:59.287
And it can give you headaches, right.

347
00:17:59.287 --> 00:18:01.172
We don't really modify these too much,
Dan.

348
00:18:01.172 --> 00:18:04.879
I don't know if you remember the old CRTs,
you definitely had to, because if you were

349
00:18:04.879 --> 00:18:08.115
staring at it too long, it could lead
to things like headaches and stuff.

350
00:18:08.115 --> 00:18:09.400
>> Yeah.

351
00:18:09.400 --> 00:18:11.150
>> All right, so that is, and

352
00:18:11.150 --> 00:18:13.800
frame rates, right,
we didn't talk about frame rate right.

353
00:18:13.800 --> 00:18:14.590
>> You mentioned it [LAUGH].

354
00:18:14.590 --> 00:18:17.530
>> I mentioned it [LAUGH],
that's right, I went there.

355
00:18:17.530 --> 00:18:20.670
So refresh rate is
a characteristic of the screen.

356
00:18:20.670 --> 00:18:23.820
Frame rate is a characteristic
of how fast the video's moving.

357
00:18:23.820 --> 00:18:26.268
So there's two different,
they're close, right.

358
00:18:26.268 --> 00:18:31.730
Frame rate is how fast you can get
individual pictures into the monitor.

359
00:18:31.730 --> 00:18:34.970
Where refresh rate is a characteristic
of the monitor, itself.

360
00:18:34.970 --> 00:18:38.690
And it could have an adverse effect
on refresh rate, if that makes sense.

361
00:18:38.690 --> 00:18:44.210
So do please keep that in mind.

362
00:18:44.210 --> 00:18:45.240
What else do we have?

00:18:45.240 --> 00:18:47.900
We gotta talk about
things like resolution.

00:18:47.900 --> 00:18:49.130
>> That could be important.

365
00:18:49.130 --> 00:18:50.387
>> Resolution is important, right [LAUGH].

366
00:18:50.387 --> 00:18:55.512
[LAUGH]
>> Resolution comes down to, basically,

367
00:18:55.512 --> 00:19:01.270
how many pixels does the surface

368
00:19:01.270 --> 00:19:03.460
In fact, I've got kind of a diagram here.

00:19:03.460 --> 00:19:05.866
You can kind of think of it this way,
right.

370
00:19:05.866 --> 00:19:09.540
On your monitors, you have
a horizontal axis, if you will, and

371
00:19:09.540 --> 00:19:11.798
then you have a vertical axis, right.

372
00:19:11.798 --> 00:19:16.814
When you look at something like 920
by 1080, it literally means you can

373
00:19:16.814 --> 00:19:22.840
fit 1,920 pixels in a single row, and
1,080, if you will, in the vertical.

374
00:19:22.840 --> 00:19:24.490
So please keep that in mind,

375
00:19:24.490 --> 00:19:29.450
that resolution is the overall amount
of pixels that the monitor supports.

376
00:19:29.450 --> 00:19:34.280
Now, one thing also to keep in
mind when we talk about LCDs and

377
00:19:34.280 --> 00:19:37.597
LEDs, unlike the earlier CRT monitors,

378
00:19:37.597 --> 00:19:42.831
I do want you to keep in mind that
you could adjust the resolution.

379
00:19:42.831 --> 00:19:45.785
All right, so you could potentially,
on the old CRT monitors,

380
00:19:45.785 --> 00:19:49.165
you can get a better resolution
because you could change it.

381
00:19:49.165 --> 00:19:50.845
LCD and LEDs don't do that.

382
00:19:50.845 --> 00:19:52.945
They have what's known
as a fixed resolution.

383
00:19:52.945 --> 00:19:56.345
On the exam, the objectives
call that a native resolution.

384
00:19:56.345 --> 00:20:01.325
Native resolution is the one resolution
that that monitor was made to support.

385
00:20:01.325 --> 00:20:06.123
Now, understand, I'm not saying that
you can't change the resolution.

386
00:20:06.123 --> 00:20:07.601
But in changing the resolution,

387
00:20:07.601 --> 00:20:11.208
a lot of times what you see is you just
kind of make icons bigger, like pixelated.

388
00:20:11.208 --> 00:20:15.090
It never improves the quality
of the image, itself.

389
00:20:15.090 --> 00:20:16.100
So that is important.

390
00:20:17.460 --> 00:20:21.210
All right, now we get to two really,
really confusing terms.

391
00:20:21.210 --> 00:20:25.110
One is subjective, objective,
I guess would be the opposite of that.

392
00:20:25.110 --> 00:20:25.781
>> Yes, objective is the opposite
of subjective [LAUGH].

393
00:20:25.781 --> 00:20:31.130
>> Yeah, right, so they talk about
brightness in lumens, all right.

394
00:20:31.130 --> 00:20:34.934
Brightness is kind of,
here we go with those number games, right,

395
00:20:34.934 --> 00:20:36.360
that's very bright.

396
00:20:36.360 --> 00:20:38.730
What does that mean, right?

397
00:20:38.730 --> 00:20:40.460
Well, that's perception, okay.

398
00:20:40.460 --> 00:20:41.610
Brightness, if you will,

00:20:41.610 --> 00:20:45.180
is a subjective term that describes
how bright the display is.

400
00:20:45.180 --> 00:20:48.030
The problem with it is
brightness isn't measurable.

401
00:20:48.030 --> 00:20:51.370
There's no measurable unit that says
I can measure the brightness, right.

402
00:20:51.370 --> 00:20:55.199
I can say right now, to Dan and I, we've
been standing in these studios for, Dan,

403
00:20:55.199 --> 00:20:57.850
you've been doing it for
two, three years now, right.

404
00:20:57.850 --> 00:21:00.070
And to us, yeah, it's bright,
but it's not that bad.

00:21:00.070 --> 00:21:02.320
However, we've had some people
that come in and go, wow,

406
00:21:02.320 --> 00:21:03.690
that's got a blinding bright.

407
00:21:03.690 --> 00:21:04.252
It's bright.

408
00:21:04.252 --> 00:21:07.160
It's a subjective term,
we can't really measure it.

409
00:21:07.160 --> 00:21:10.735
That's where the other part of
the measurable term comes in, and

410
00:21:10.735 --> 00:21:12.367
that's lumens, all right.

411
00:21:12.367 --> 00:21:16.289
So lumens is basically,
if you will, is luminance.

00:21:16.289 --> 00:21:19.623
And it is the intensity
of the light that's

413
00:21:19.623 --> 00:21:23.148
emitted on a surface per a unit area,
right.

414
00:21:23.148 --> 00:21:25.845
We can actually get
a measurement in lumens.

415
00:21:25.845 --> 00:21:29.590
Luminance, again,
can be measured, or luminance,

416
00:21:29.590 --> 00:21:33.990
if you will, can be measured in lumens.

417
00:21:35.060 --> 00:21:39.130
When we say increase the lumens,
again, you increase the brightness.

418
00:21:39.130 --> 00:21:44.150
Again, just remember brightness, again,
is just a subjective term, the amount of

419
00:21:44.150 --> 00:21:49.050
light output or the intensity of a light
that's produced by the display, itself.

00:21:50.610 --> 00:21:52.190
All right, Dan, moving down this list,

Anti-glare filters, yes,

It's the graphics system,

Across those multiple monitors.

00:28:04.640 --> 00:28:09.720
Now, there's one last thing that I
kinda wanna talk about when it comes

535
00:28:09.720 --> 00:28:11.950
to just video in general.

536
00:28:11.950 --> 00:28:15.930
In the past, with our earlier CRT
monitors, and this is really talking about

537
00:28:15.930 --> 00:28:19.210
the communication ports that we use,
as well as the technology.

538
00:28:19.210 --> 00:28:21.260
It's analog, video and digital video.

539
00:28:21.260 --> 00:28:27.240
When we talk about analog video,
it's really kind of outdated today.

540
00:28:27.240 --> 00:28:31.540
It's still there, we've talked about it in
other episodes like video graphics array.

541
00:28:31.540 --> 00:28:37.775
But more common today that you see is
at a minimum DVI, digital connections.

542
00:28:37.775 --> 00:28:40.875
We talked about this in some
of our PC connection episodes.

543
00:28:40.875 --> 00:28:43.095
Things like HDMI, very very prevalent.

544
00:28:43.095 --> 00:28:46.455
As well as display port and
even now we've had for a while.

545
00:28:46.455 --> 00:28:51.920
I say now Thunderbolt technology, so
understand the difference between the old

546
00:28:51.920 --> 00:28:57.750
analog like a sine wave if you will
versus a series of ones and zeros.

547
00:28:57.750 --> 00:29:01.980
And again,
the difference between analog and digital.

548
00:29:01.980 --> 00:29:05.950
So just a few of the display technologies
that you have to keep in mind and

549
00:29:05.950 --> 00:29:07.650
if you can get some of
these under your belt,

550
00:29:07.650 --> 00:29:11.050
you're going to be doing good when they
ask you these questions on your exam.

551
00:29:11.050 --> 00:29:12.250
>> All right Wes, thanks so much for

552
00:29:12.250 --> 00:29:16.000
explaining the different types of
displays that we might be working with.

553
00:29:16.000 --> 00:29:19.500
And their characteristics cuz we're gonna
need that like you say for that exam.

554
00:29:19.500 --> 00:29:21.200
That being said, looking at our clock.

555
00:29:21.200 --> 00:29:23.500
Wow the time,
we do thank you guys for watching.

556
00:29:23.500 --> 00:29:25.900
Signing off for ITPRO.TV I've
been your host Daniel Lowrie.

557
00:29:25.900 --> 00:29:26.640
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

558
00:29:26.640 --> 00:29:27.823
>> We'll see you next time.

559
00:29:29.112 --> 00:29:35.013
[MUSIC]

560
00:29:35.013 --> 00:29:37.651
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes install and configure common peripheral devices. Specific topics covered includes: Scanners, keyboards, mice, barcode scanners, biometric scanners, gamepads, motion scanners, touchpads, smartcard readers, digital cameras, web cam, printers, display devices, touchscreens, etc.
episodes.title: Common Peripheral Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:01.449
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.449 --> 00:00:02.927
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.927 --> 00:00:06.632
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.632 --> 00:00:08.287
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.287 --> 00:00:12.041
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.041 --> 00:00:14.005
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:14.005 --> 00:00:16.273
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.273 --> 00:00:18.898
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

9
00:00:18.898 --> 00:00:20.640
we are back with more in our A+ series.

10
00:00:20.640 --> 00:00:24.090
That's right, the good old, was it 220901?

11
00:00:24.090 --> 00:00:25.110
That's it.
There it is.

12
00:00:25.110 --> 00:00:26.650
There's the nomenclature for you.

13
00:00:26.650 --> 00:00:28.030
And joining us back in the studio yet

14
00:00:28.030 --> 00:00:32.440
again to lend his expertise on that
knowledge, our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

15
00:00:32.440 --> 00:00:33.470
Wes, welcome back, man.

16
00:00:33.470 --> 00:00:34.340
>> Hey, man, how's it going?

17
00:00:34.340 --> 00:00:37.565
Gotta give you props man, all the
different episodes you host around here.

18
00:00:37.565 --> 00:00:40.697
You happen to keep some of those
numbers rattling around in your brain.

19
00:00:40.697 --> 00:00:42.705
[LAUGH] And you give me credit for
acronyms, there.

20
00:00:42.705 --> 00:00:44.405
>> And they pass me around
to every different show.

21
00:00:44.405 --> 00:00:45.435
>> Yeah, definitely.

22
00:00:45.435 --> 00:00:46.755
So props to you there, bud.

23
00:00:46.755 --> 00:00:49.825
Absolutely, I'm doing great and
great to be here as always in the 220901,

24
00:00:49.825 --> 00:00:52.540
the one that Dan mentioned there.

25
00:00:52.540 --> 00:00:57.231
We're going to be looking at the some of
the peripherals that we can expand on our

26
00:00:57.231 --> 00:00:58.849
user experience, right?

27
00:00:58.849 --> 00:01:02.518
In past episodes we've talked about
the system unit and the motherboard and

28
00:01:02.518 --> 00:01:05.784
expanding the functionality of
the computer itself, if you will,

29
00:01:05.784 --> 00:01:07.580
by adding expansion cards, right?

30
00:01:07.580 --> 00:01:12.100
Well, we can also expand our computing
experience by making connections,

31
00:01:12.100 --> 00:01:14.690
external connections back
to the system unit and

32
00:01:14.690 --> 00:01:18.010
adding functionality that isn't
normally built into the computer.

33
00:01:18.010 --> 00:01:20.440
And some of these are actually
built in by today's standards.

34
00:01:20.440 --> 00:01:23.740
So let's go ahead and
were gonna go through

35
00:01:23.740 --> 00:01:26.770
really just a series of the different
types of peripherals, right, these

36
00:01:26.770 --> 00:01:30.790
external devices that make connections
through a port on your machine.

37
00:01:30.790 --> 00:01:34.790
Some of the first ones they call out,
and in fact, let me go ahead and

38
00:01:34.790 --> 00:01:38.010
kinda change gears here for
a second before we just dive right

39
00:01:38.010 --> 00:01:41.930
into talking about a whole bunch of
different type of peripherals, all right?

40
00:01:41.930 --> 00:01:44.520
One of the things I want you to
understand for the exams, or

41
00:01:44.520 --> 00:01:48.240
more of the specifics is what
the device is performing.

42
00:01:48.240 --> 00:01:50.825
And what I mean by that,
what functionalities is it performing.

43
00:01:50.825 --> 00:01:54.740
And more specifically,
is this an audio input type device, right?

44
00:01:54.740 --> 00:01:57.287
Is this an audio output device?

45
00:01:57.287 --> 00:02:01.085
Is this a video input or output device?

46
00:02:01.085 --> 00:02:04.535
Does this perform data
input versus data output?

47
00:02:04.535 --> 00:02:07.803
So also know the direction of
the communication as well,

48
00:02:07.803 --> 00:02:10.880
rather than just knowing
the device itself, right?

49
00:02:10.880 --> 00:02:15.010
So for instance if they ask you, what does
a printer do, right, versus a keyboard?

50
00:02:15.010 --> 00:02:18.318
If you think about it,
a keyboard is a data input device, right?

51
00:02:18.318 --> 00:02:23.900
It's how we interact with the computing
system by sending, typing in commands.

52
00:02:23.900 --> 00:02:27.352
And that inputs the data that controls
the computer essentially, right,

53
00:02:27.352 --> 00:02:28.760
versus a printer.

54
00:02:28.760 --> 00:02:32.231
A printer is a text or
image based output device, right?

55
00:02:32.231 --> 00:02:37.726
It's how we get data out of the machine
in some kind of printed media, right?

56
00:02:37.726 --> 00:02:40.666
So definitely pay attention to
that through the various devices

57
00:02:40.666 --> 00:02:42.090
that we're gonna talk about.

58
00:02:42.090 --> 00:02:44.150
And I'll also continue to mention them,

59
00:02:44.150 --> 00:02:48.570
if you will, as what kind of
functionality the device is doing.

60
00:02:48.570 --> 00:02:49.190
All right, well,

61
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:52.780
that lends us to the very first thing and
that is what is known as a mouse, right.

62
00:02:52.780 --> 00:02:56.320
Mouse, when we talk about mice,
I guess if you will say,

63
00:02:56.320 --> 00:02:59.680
they've been in a computing
environment for a very long time.

64
00:02:59.680 --> 00:03:04.470
In fact, I wanna say this goes back
to the 50s where some of the people,

65
00:03:04.470 --> 00:03:07.970
I wanna say, it was like DEC,
Digital Equipment Corporation.

66
00:03:07.970 --> 00:03:11.720
I might have that wrong, but
the original inventor of a mouse,

67
00:03:11.720 --> 00:03:16.740
basically, it was a wooden box with a
couple of metal gears in it, if you will.

68
00:03:16.740 --> 00:03:21.260
And it used plotter vector coordinates,
right, to position a cursor,

69
00:03:21.260 --> 00:03:22.710
if you will, on the screen, right?

70
00:03:22.710 --> 00:03:26.331
The cursor is the little logical
pointing device that we see,

71
00:03:26.331 --> 00:03:29.615
where the mouse itself is
the physical device, right?

72
00:03:29.615 --> 00:03:31.690
And there are a few different
kinds over the years.

73
00:03:31.690 --> 00:03:35.770
One that's kind of gone by
the wayside there is the mechanical

74
00:03:35.770 --> 00:03:37.000
mouse, if you will.

75
00:03:37.000 --> 00:03:39.550
And this is the one that would use
like a little rubber ball-bearing

76
00:03:39.550 --> 00:03:43.630
in the bottom of it to manipulate
some rotating gears inside of it and

77
00:03:43.630 --> 00:03:45.810
it would move up and down, left and right.

78
00:03:45.810 --> 00:03:49.700
And this is the one where you can actually
unscrew the bottom of the mouse itself,

79
00:03:49.700 --> 00:03:51.545
pull off a cover, pull the bearing out.

80
00:03:51.545 --> 00:03:52.550
And you'd have to get it in there and

81
00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:55.665
you'd have to clean those little
actuator motors with like a Q-tip and

82
00:03:55.665 --> 00:03:58.875
maybe a little bit of alcohol cuz
they collect dust, if you will.

83
00:03:58.875 --> 00:04:02.455
Thank goodness, we really don't use too
many of them because when it comes to

84
00:04:02.455 --> 00:04:06.635
positioning of the cursor,
they were good for the time, but

85
00:04:06.635 --> 00:04:11.085
we have more accurate ways of essentially
interacting with our computer,

86
00:04:11.085 --> 00:04:13.910
especially when it comes to the cursor
that you see on the screen.

87
00:04:13.910 --> 00:04:17.700
That being said, we're talking about,
for instance, optical mouse.

88
00:04:17.700 --> 00:04:21.380
An optical mouse is one that
uses an optical light source in

89
00:04:21.380 --> 00:04:22.770
order to track position.

90
00:04:22.770 --> 00:04:24.560
In fact, we've kinda got one here.

91
00:04:24.560 --> 00:04:26.930
And this is just a very basic mouse here.

92
00:04:26.930 --> 00:04:28.570
There's nothing fancy about it.

93
00:04:28.570 --> 00:04:31.240
I know some gamers would say no I
wouldn't be caught dead with that type

94
00:04:31.240 --> 00:04:31.760
of thing, right?

95
00:04:31.760 --> 00:04:34.450
Because you can get very,
very expensive mice here.

96
00:04:34.450 --> 00:04:37.810
But if you look, you can see that
there is an optical laser source.

97
00:04:37.810 --> 00:04:40.497
And I don't know if this
is gonna work on my Mac.

98
00:04:40.497 --> 00:04:42.710
Probably should have tested
this before we started here.

99
00:04:42.710 --> 00:04:44.740
But we'll give it a whirl and
see if it powers up here.

100
00:04:44.740 --> 00:04:45.350
Yeah, there we go.

101
00:04:45.350 --> 00:04:45.935
>> It blinded us all.

102
00:04:45.935 --> 00:04:47.815
>> All right, now, you know what they say.

103
00:04:47.815 --> 00:04:48.848
>> There's a warning right there.

104
00:04:48.848 --> 00:04:50.576
>> That's right,
you should always look in the laser, no.

105
00:04:50.576 --> 00:04:52.934
[CROSSTALK]
>> We were just kidding, right?

106
00:04:52.934 --> 00:04:54.809
But that's what's essentially happening,
right?

107
00:04:54.809 --> 00:04:58.014
The mouse itself is actually
manipulating the cursor here and

108
00:04:58.014 --> 00:04:59.620
it's tracking the position.

109
00:04:59.620 --> 00:05:03.205
And what's kinda cool is as I'm doing this
I can see my cursor over there on the Mac

110
00:05:03.205 --> 00:05:04.695
kinda going crazy on me, right?

111
00:05:04.695 --> 00:05:09.363
But then you typically have the little
center wheel there, and the roller wheel,

112
00:05:09.363 --> 00:05:12.555
if you will,
controls things like page up, page down.

113
00:05:12.555 --> 00:05:14.859
It's a scrolling wheel, if you will, and

114
00:05:14.859 --> 00:05:18.855
you typically have some kind of
left-click and you have a right-click.

115
00:05:18.855 --> 00:05:23.943
And depending on what you're doing
on your computer and how you have

116
00:05:23.943 --> 00:05:29.754
the logical side of this configured
will dictate which one these buttons do.

117
00:05:29.754 --> 00:05:35.150
The basic configuration we say, what is
it, left for select, right for effect.

118
00:05:35.150 --> 00:05:38.020
And that means basically right-click
gives you a series of options,

119
00:05:38.020 --> 00:05:40.940
a left-click typically selects
whatever the object is.

120
00:05:40.940 --> 00:05:42.320
And then you can move the mouse around.

121
00:05:42.320 --> 00:05:44.570
And again, remember,
the optical light source.

122
00:05:44.570 --> 00:05:48.960
You can kind of see it kind of light
up there, will control the position

123
00:05:48.960 --> 00:05:52.550
of the cursor on the screen
relative to how you're moving it.

124
00:05:52.550 --> 00:05:54.360
There are other types as well.

125
00:05:54.360 --> 00:05:59.720
There's a couple of different optical
light sources that they have today.

126
00:05:59.720 --> 00:06:03.174
They have what is known
as a blue track mouse.

127
00:06:03.174 --> 00:06:05.330
And I believe it was Microsoft
that first invented this.

128
00:06:05.330 --> 00:06:07.918
And all that's using is
a blue optical source.

129
00:06:07.918 --> 00:06:12.100
And the thought process behind this is
the fact that you have to be careful with

130
00:06:12.100 --> 00:06:15.250
an optical mouse because if
it's on a reflective surface,

131
00:06:15.250 --> 00:06:19.240
it can mess with the calculations,
right, the tracking of the system.

132
00:06:19.240 --> 00:06:21.991
Again, kind of like a mirror
reflecting the optical light source.

133
00:06:21.991 --> 00:06:24.747
It might be reflecting it right
back into the lens itself, and

134
00:06:24.747 --> 00:06:26.871
it can cause all kinds
of squirrelly problems.

135
00:06:26.871 --> 00:06:30.620
That's why we say that's the reason
you have a mouse pad, right?

136
00:06:30.620 --> 00:06:35.230
The mouse pad some people think, well, the
mouse pad is just made for the old roller

137
00:06:35.230 --> 00:06:39.180
ball mice because it would give a grip
on it, give you a little more traction.

138
00:06:39.180 --> 00:06:41.020
That really isn't the case.

139
00:06:41.020 --> 00:06:45.130
Keep in mind that it's more for,
today, for the reflective surface.

140
00:06:45.130 --> 00:06:47.149
Now I don't see this in the list.

141
00:06:47.149 --> 00:06:53.537
I do wanna mention another type
of mouse based type device.

142
00:06:53.537 --> 00:06:55.090
It's called a track ball.

143
00:06:55.090 --> 00:06:58.380
And a track ball essentially is
the old mechanical roller ball mouse

144
00:06:58.380 --> 00:06:59.810
turned upside down.

145
00:06:59.810 --> 00:07:02.000
Me personally, I can't stand them.

146
00:07:02.000 --> 00:07:06.080
And one of the great things about
them is you can leave the mouse,

147
00:07:06.080 --> 00:07:08.100
the base if you will,
in a single location and

148
00:07:08.100 --> 00:07:13.250
you just use the roller ball that's on top
of it to move the cursor back and forth.

149
00:07:13.250 --> 00:07:14.370
Some people swear by them.

150
00:07:14.370 --> 00:07:16.560
I know one of hosts,
Don, loves track balls.

151
00:07:16.560 --> 00:07:20.210
Our owner and CEO, well,
both our co-founder and

152
00:07:20.210 --> 00:07:22.520
founder there, love the track ball.

153
00:07:22.520 --> 00:07:24.510
Personally, I can't stand it.

154
00:07:24.510 --> 00:07:25.930
I've never been able to get used to them.

155
00:07:25.930 --> 00:07:28.680
If you ask me to work on your computer and
you have a track ball I'm gonna go

156
00:07:28.680 --> 00:07:31.550
find a mouse and plug it into your
computer so that I can work with it.

157
00:07:31.550 --> 00:07:34.190
However, they got a low latency.

158
00:07:34.190 --> 00:07:36.830
So they're very, very fast devices and
they have a real,

159
00:07:36.830 --> 00:07:43.500
real ultra fine precision when it comes
to real fine point placing the cursor.

160
00:07:43.500 --> 00:07:46.940
That being said, a few different types
of connections you have to keep in mind.

161
00:07:46.940 --> 00:07:50.284
What you've seen here was a USB.

162
00:07:50.284 --> 00:07:54.386
And when we talk about a USB mouse,
obviously making the USB base connection,

163
00:07:54.386 --> 00:07:57.632
although you also have some of
the earlier type connections.

164
00:07:57.632 --> 00:08:00.150
Those are the old PS2 ports or
the six pin mini DIN.

165
00:08:00.150 --> 00:08:02.769
And you can see those for
your keyboard, mouse, green, and blue.

166
00:08:02.769 --> 00:08:05.847
Purple, and also wireless communications.

167
00:08:05.847 --> 00:08:09.540
And keep in mind we've got two types of
wireless communications that they can use.

168
00:08:09.540 --> 00:08:12.720
They could use WiFi communications,
a lot of times they use bluetooth as well,

169
00:08:12.720 --> 00:08:14.770
and they'll go through
the pairing process.

170
00:08:14.770 --> 00:08:18.720
So also pay attention to
the connection types that you have.

171
00:08:18.720 --> 00:08:21.360
Now, the next thing that we
have are keyboards, all right.

172
00:08:21.360 --> 00:08:25.310
And keyboards when we look at them, they
come in all different shapes and sizes.

173
00:08:25.310 --> 00:08:28.340
And we gotta a couple of different kinds
here because we really wanna talk about

174
00:08:28.340 --> 00:08:31.625
again the connections that you
could see Videos on these.

175
00:08:31.625 --> 00:08:36.345
In fact, I've got a wired
keyboard here and we have, well,

176
00:08:36.345 --> 00:08:38.395
basically a wireless keyboard and

177
00:08:38.395 --> 00:08:42.855
you can see that this one is gonna be
using essentially the USB connection,

178
00:08:42.855 --> 00:08:46.050
where this one Well that's
completely unbounded, right?

179
00:08:46.050 --> 00:08:50.060
It doesn't have any kind of
tether type connection there.

180
00:08:50.060 --> 00:08:54.300
And you can see when it comes down to
it these keyboard they have different

181
00:08:54.300 --> 00:08:56.035
bells and whistles in them.

182
00:08:56.035 --> 00:09:00.280
One of the common functions that they
have a lot of times are the function keys

183
00:09:00.280 --> 00:09:01.940
across the top.

184
00:09:01.940 --> 00:09:06.420
And the numeric keypad, you can see
both of these have that function.

185
00:09:06.420 --> 00:09:08.180
That's actually a standard, believe it or

186
00:09:08.180 --> 00:09:12.850
not, that's kinda in our mindset gone by
the wayside because in the earlier days

187
00:09:12.850 --> 00:09:17.360
going all the way back to the AT boards,
that numerical keypad would have been

188
00:09:17.360 --> 00:09:21.610
directly connected right to the main
keys on the keyboard, right.

189
00:09:21.610 --> 00:09:26.590
And that's one of the things that what's
known as the AT enhanced standard came in

190
00:09:26.590 --> 00:09:29.790
later on as we progressed in technology.

191
00:09:29.790 --> 00:09:34.960
And that's typically where you can see
things like your home button here and

192
00:09:34.960 --> 00:09:37.070
page up, page down,
the directional keys and

193
00:09:37.070 --> 00:09:39.460
then the numeric keypad
separate from that.

194
00:09:39.460 --> 00:09:41.570
Again, I want you to know that for
the exam.

195
00:09:41.570 --> 00:09:44.660
I know that's a little bit of a, a little
technical specification there, but

196
00:09:44.660 --> 00:09:45.750
it could come up on the exam.

197
00:09:45.750 --> 00:09:47.710
What is the current standard
enhancement for a while?

198
00:09:49.330 --> 00:09:53.330
Now there are different types
of standards, even within that.

00:31:24.330 --> 00:31:24.851
>> We're musicians.

654
00:31:24.851 --> 00:31:25.998
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah very good.

655
00:31:25.998 --> 00:31:28.440
That's right.
[LAUGH] All right ladies and gentlemen,

656
00:31:28.440 --> 00:31:30.390
like I said, I know it's a laundry list.

657
00:31:30.390 --> 00:31:34.518
Dan's now broke with all the things we've
had to buy with his credit card here.

658
00:31:34.518 --> 00:31:36.211
>> [LAUGH] Hello?

659
00:31:36.211 --> 00:31:37.030
What?

660
00:31:37.030 --> 00:31:38.820
>> Should have told him
prior to us starting.

661
00:31:38.820 --> 00:31:41.730
So guys and gals again,
keep in mind input devices and

662
00:31:41.730 --> 00:31:44.630
output devices and then the handful
at the end that we mentioned.

663
00:31:44.630 --> 00:31:46.210
They kind of sit on both
sides of the tracks.

664
00:31:46.210 --> 00:31:49.503
They can be input and
output devices for your 901 exam.

665
00:31:49.503 --> 00:31:53.450
>> All right everyone, well it looks like
I've got some business to take care of.

666
00:31:53.450 --> 00:31:55.830
And some credit card
transactions to get rid of.

667
00:31:55.830 --> 00:31:58.520
But Wes, we thank you for
walking us through,

668
00:31:58.520 --> 00:32:02.430
there's a multitude of peripheral devices
that you might connect to your computer.

669
00:32:02.430 --> 00:32:05.230
We just want you to be familiar with
the most common that you might run into

670
00:32:05.230 --> 00:32:07.080
out there as an A+ technician.

671
00:32:07.080 --> 00:32:10.140
Understand how they connect,
what they do and how they work.

672
00:32:10.140 --> 00:32:12.530
That being said, looks like we
are out of time for this episode.

673
00:32:12.530 --> 00:32:16.390
We thank you for watching, signing off for
ITProTV, I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

674
00:32:16.390 --> 00:32:17.074
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

675
00:32:17.074 --> 00:32:19.367
We'll see you next time.

676
00:32:19.367 --> 00:32:25.354
[MUSIC]

677
00:32:25.354 --> 00:32:27.385
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the details about SOHO Multi-Function Devices(MFD) and Printers. Specific topics covered includes: printer drivers (PPD/PCL/UPD), configuration settings, device sharing using wired media, wireless (802.11x), ethernet, bluetooth, NFC, and Integrated Print Servers.
episodes.title: SOHO, MFDs and Printers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.074
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.074 --> 00:00:06.447
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.447 --> 00:00:08.357
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.357 --> 00:00:12.154
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.154 --> 00:00:14.239
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

6
00:00:14.239 --> 00:00:17.071
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.071 --> 00:00:20.147
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

8
00:00:20.147 --> 00:00:23.360
we are moving forward with
more in our A+ 22901 series.

9
00:00:23.360 --> 00:00:27.330
And joining us yet again in the studio,
our good friend and mentor, Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:27.330 --> 00:00:29.554
Wes, I'm so glad to have you again,
man, how's it going today?

11
00:00:29.554 --> 00:00:33.216
>> Man, it's going great,
really thrilled to be here, that's right,

12
00:00:33.216 --> 00:00:36.403
we're gonna be looking at the bane
of all IT existence today.

13
00:00:36.403 --> 00:00:40.297
Yeah, we're gonna be talking a little
bit about printers and their drivers,

14
00:00:40.297 --> 00:00:42.220
things that like to drive us mad.

15
00:00:42.220 --> 00:00:45.020
No, just kidding, guys, but
we do have to talk about printing.

16
00:00:45.020 --> 00:00:47.908
Remember, in your IT career,
the whole entire network and

17
00:00:47.908 --> 00:00:50.795
everything can fail, but
if one printer is still working,

18
00:00:50.795 --> 00:00:53.355
you can always print your
resume out the front door.

19
00:00:53.355 --> 00:00:58.052
[LAUGH] So we're gonna be looking at a
little bit of different technologies that

20
00:00:58.052 --> 00:01:01.183
do surround, specifically,
SOHOs, MFDs, yes,

21
00:01:01.183 --> 00:01:04.190
acronyms right out the gate here,
and printers.

22
00:01:04.190 --> 00:01:07.142
Now MFD, if you will, guys,
sorry for the alphabet soup, but

23
00:01:07.142 --> 00:01:09.005
that is a multi-functioning device.

24
00:01:09.005 --> 00:01:10.249
So let's go ahead and

25
