step back real quick before we get into
the specifics of this episode here.

26
00:01:14.614 --> 00:01:18.655
And let's talk about these acronyms
that we've kinda fed you right away.

27
00:01:18.655 --> 00:01:20.065
SOHO, what is that?

28
00:01:20.065 --> 00:01:22.475
Small office home office, right?

29
00:01:22.475 --> 00:01:25.260
It's not even an SMB, right,
small to medium business, right,

30
00:01:25.260 --> 00:01:27.324
we can have a couple hundred employees,
right?

31
00:01:27.324 --> 00:01:31.172
Can even be considered a small business,
small office, home office, a lot of times,

32
00:01:31.172 --> 00:01:34.408
what we're talking about is no more
than ten computers at best, right?

33
00:01:34.408 --> 00:01:38.862
So a very isolated type of
office environment, if you will.

34
00:01:38.862 --> 00:01:43.583
And isolated, I just mean very,
very limited in the overall expense,

35
00:01:43.583 --> 00:01:48.235
limited in the amount of devices and
people that you have inside of it.

36
00:01:48.235 --> 00:01:50.354
MFDs, well, what's an MFD?

37
00:01:50.354 --> 00:01:52.438
Well, that's a multi-functioning device.

38
00:01:52.438 --> 00:01:56.065
Well, I mean,
what is a multi-functioning device?

39
00:01:56.065 --> 00:01:58.275
Let's go ahead and
take a trip back in time, and

40
00:01:58.275 --> 00:02:01.280
let's talk about in the days when
you would, what would you do?

41
00:02:01.280 --> 00:02:06.635
You would buy a fax machine,
you'd buy a printer.

42
00:02:06.635 --> 00:02:08.680
You'd buy a copier, right,
what else would you do?

43
00:02:08.680 --> 00:02:09.880
>> Maybe a scanner.

44
00:02:09.880 --> 00:02:12.380
>> Yeah, very good,
the old flatbed scanners, right?

45
00:02:12.380 --> 00:02:14.440
And then what else would you have to do?

46
00:02:14.440 --> 00:02:20.031
You turn around and you would have to
buy furniture for your equipment, right?

47
00:02:20.031 --> 00:02:22.222
You have to buy a desk,
and even more so then,

48
00:02:22.222 --> 00:02:25.652
you would put the kids in a bunk bed and
you would move it into an office.

49
00:02:25.652 --> 00:02:27.650
>> [LAUGH]
>> So I want you to think about this.

50
00:02:27.650 --> 00:02:32.178
You just bought a whole bunch of inanimate
objects, not only their own furniture, but

51
00:02:32.178 --> 00:02:34.609
you put them up for
the night in their own room.

52
00:02:34.609 --> 00:02:36.785
So these devices, as time went on,

53
00:02:36.785 --> 00:02:40.935
a lot of the major manufacturers
out there said hey, you know what?

54
00:02:40.935 --> 00:02:45.280
Well, let's see if we can save some
space and also save some money here,

55
00:02:45.280 --> 00:02:48.359
if you will,
make it more economically feasible.

56
00:02:48.359 --> 00:02:51.943
We'll have all these devices, and
we'll just integrate them into one device.

57
00:02:51.943 --> 00:02:56.363
Now I do want you to keep in my mind when
you have a multi-functioning device,

58
00:02:56.363 --> 00:03:00.987
what you have is one single device that
is basically allocating its resources and

59
00:03:00.987 --> 00:03:04.598
functionality to different
types of functionality, right?

60
00:03:04.598 --> 00:03:10.151
So, that is going to be something that
can be a limitng factor with MFDs.

61
00:03:10.151 --> 00:03:14.177
Any time you've got one device that's
dedicated to a single functionality,

62
00:03:14.177 --> 00:03:17.959
its sole existence revolves around
that functionality, a lot of times,

63
00:03:17.959 --> 00:03:20.218
you get a really good
performance out of it.

64
00:03:20.218 --> 00:03:22.735
Versus one that kind of divides
the functionality between

65
00:03:22.735 --> 00:03:23.975
multiple different roles.

66
00:03:23.975 --> 00:03:30.470
However, they're cost effective, and
again, they do save you some space.

67
00:03:30.470 --> 00:03:32.650
So that's a little bit about the SOHO, and

68
00:03:32.650 --> 00:03:34.880
that is a little bit about
multi-functioning devices.

69
00:03:34.880 --> 00:03:39.036
And again, the objectives here, install
SOHO, multi-functioning device printers,

70
00:03:39.036 --> 00:03:42.439
and configure appropriate settings
are what we're gonna be looking at.

71
00:03:42.439 --> 00:03:46.420
And one of the first things that they
dive into is talking about configuring,

72
00:03:46.420 --> 00:03:48.573
using appropriate drivers, all right.

73
00:03:48.573 --> 00:03:52.320
When we talk about a driver, we've kind
of talked about, as we've mentioned,

74
00:03:52.320 --> 00:03:52.880
hardware.

75
00:03:52.880 --> 00:03:55.279
And as we'll mention,
when we get into our operating system,

76
00:03:55.279 --> 00:03:57.480
kind of looking at what
these little components are.

77
00:03:57.480 --> 00:04:00.890
It's really just a piece of software
that allows us to control our hardware.

78
00:04:00.890 --> 00:04:04.800
Right, our operating system
basically controls our hardware.

79
00:04:04.800 --> 00:04:08.020
But the only way you could control that
hardware or even be aware of what that

80
00:04:08.020 --> 00:04:12.600
hardware actually is, is through that
little translator that explains what it is

81
00:04:12.600 --> 00:04:15.660
and lets it talk to it,
the drivers themselves.

82
00:04:15.660 --> 00:04:19.930
Print drivers, they can be a nightmare,
all right, but

83
00:04:19.930 --> 00:04:23.190
if you're aware of the available drivers,
the type of drivers, and

84
00:04:23.190 --> 00:04:26.960
you know where to look for them, they
can also be very simplistic, all right?

85
00:04:26.960 --> 00:04:30.090
So I got a little list here of the print
drivers that I want you to be aware of

86
00:04:30.090 --> 00:04:31.630
on the exam, all right?

87
00:04:31.630 --> 00:04:35.980
Yes, you could see more acronyms,
right, we have PPD, PCL, and UPD.

88
00:04:35.980 --> 00:04:37.400
>> All right-
>> Thanks for clearing that up.

89
00:04:37.400 --> 00:04:38.073
>> That's right, okay.

90
00:04:38.073 --> 00:04:40.317
>> I appreciate it.
>> Yeah, moving on, [LAUGH] just kidding,

91
00:04:40.317 --> 00:04:43.884
the first one here, we've got what is
known as the post printer description,

92
00:04:43.884 --> 00:04:45.910
very common printer driver.

93
00:04:45.910 --> 00:04:50.110
The second one here, we have one that's
really been largely used in the HP world,

94
00:04:50.110 --> 00:04:51.130
the Hewlett Packard world, and

95
00:04:51.130 --> 00:04:55.200
that's the printer control language, as
well as the universal print driver, right?

96
00:04:55.200 --> 00:04:57.090
We've been talking about
MFDs just briefly, right?

97
00:04:57.090 --> 00:04:59.760
Well, a universal print driver is
good because well, think about it,

98
00:04:59.760 --> 00:05:01.400
universal print driver.

99
00:05:01.400 --> 00:05:06.605
It works very, very well for
MFD devices, if you will.

100
00:05:06.605 --> 00:05:09.154
I wanna just back up real quick and
mention in PCL,

101
00:05:09.154 --> 00:05:12.687
keep in mind there are different versions,
right, PCL 5, PCL 6.

102
00:05:12.687 --> 00:05:16.940
Pay attention to the manufacturer's
recommendations for these drivers.

103
00:05:16.940 --> 00:05:17.647
All right,

104
00:05:17.647 --> 00:05:22.244
you have to know that if I am going to
install a printer within my network, I'm

105
00:05:22.244 --> 00:05:26.942
gonna have to know what the manufacturer
requires when it comes to the driver.

106
00:05:26.942 --> 00:05:29.012
Now, there are other types of
drivers in here as well, too,

107
00:05:29.012 --> 00:05:31.220
you'll see Raster/Bitmap, and
you'll see Plotter Vector.

108
00:05:32.220 --> 00:05:32.910
Well, what do these mean?

109
00:05:32.910 --> 00:05:36.270
And in fact, I should probably put
a little forward slash there, there we go.

110
00:05:37.335 --> 00:05:39.614
What is Raster/Bitmap?

111
00:05:39.614 --> 00:05:43.596
Well, Raster/Bitmap is a driver,
essentially,

112
00:05:43.596 --> 00:05:48.035
that doesn't really scale to
very large type print jobs.

113
00:05:48.035 --> 00:05:52.055
Because the Raster/Bitmap kind of gets
pixellated the larger the print job, so

114
00:05:52.055 --> 00:05:54.196
there is a little bit
of a limiting factor.

115
00:05:54.196 --> 00:05:58.266
But it is pretty much supported just by
about almost every printer out there, so

116
00:05:58.266 --> 00:05:59.430
very common printer.

117
00:05:59.430 --> 00:06:02.507
However Plotter/Vector, right,
when we say Plotter/Vector, Dan,

118
00:06:02.507 --> 00:06:04.154
I know you were in the military before.

119
00:06:04.154 --> 00:06:05.946
You probably had to look at a map once or

120
00:06:05.946 --> 00:06:09.920
twice where you plot your vector on,
right, a series of x, y, z coordinates.

121
00:06:09.920 --> 00:06:14.033
And one of the great things about
Plotter/Vector drivers is because they use

122
00:06:14.033 --> 00:06:18.729
those x, y, z coordinates, they're perfect
for very large scale printing, right?

123
00:06:18.729 --> 00:06:22.790
>> I actually worked in sign shops as
a kid when I was in my teenage years.

124
00:06:22.790 --> 00:06:27.250
And we used plotters to
actually cut out vinyl

125
00:06:27.250 --> 00:06:30.910
signs to put on things like boats and
doors and things of that nature.

126
00:06:30.910 --> 00:06:31.947
>> So scalability was just great.

127
00:06:31.947 --> 00:06:36.379
>> Yeah, yeah, it basically looked like
a giant printer that you fed vinyl

128
00:06:36.379 --> 00:06:38.859
stickers into, giant vinyl stickers.

129
00:06:38.859 --> 00:06:42.699
And it would cut out whatever you want,
and you'd have it backed in masts.

130
00:06:42.699 --> 00:06:45.004
And you would take it to a glass door and
you put it on there and

131
00:06:45.004 --> 00:06:46.500
make sure it's straight.

132
00:06:46.500 --> 00:06:49.020
Wipe it on, pull the masking off,
and there's your sign.

133
00:06:49.020 --> 00:06:50.601
>> Perfect, so and you can see, well,

134
00:06:50.601 --> 00:06:53.312
I'm sure some of these signs can
get fairly huge as well, too.

135
00:06:53.312 --> 00:06:55.100
>> Yeah,
the ones on the boats got very large.

136
00:06:55.100 --> 00:06:57.640
Because you'd go off on these
multi-million dollar yachts, and

137
00:06:57.640 --> 00:07:00.450
they're putting queen's prize or
something.

138
00:07:00.450 --> 00:07:02.370
>> Sure.
>> And they're as big as me.

139
00:07:02.370 --> 00:07:03.613
>> Yeah, and
when they're spending that money,

140
00:07:03.613 --> 00:07:04.900
they don't want it to look pixellated,
right?

141
00:07:04.900 --> 00:07:05.892
>> No.

142
00:07:05.892 --> 00:07:08.912
>> Today, we look at things like
MineCraft, and we're like that's awesome,

143
00:07:08.912 --> 00:07:11.659
but I bet you back in the days,
they got a couple million dollar yacht.

144
00:07:11.659 --> 00:07:14.031
They wouldn't think that's Galaga, right?

145
00:07:14.031 --> 00:07:17.636
[LAUGH] So, well,
that's an Atari boat, but yeah, and

146
00:07:17.636 --> 00:07:22.710
that's some of the print drivers that
you have to be aware of on the exam.

147
00:07:22.710 --> 00:07:26.490
Know the names,
know the acronyms, if you will.

148
00:07:26.490 --> 00:07:29.900
Again, keep in mind things like your

149
00:07:29.900 --> 00:07:33.640
MFD devices work very well with
the universal print drivers.

150
00:07:33.640 --> 00:07:36.910
Now one of the great things about most of
these print drivers today is that they

151
00:07:36.910 --> 00:07:40.410
actually have a small portion of memory.

152
00:07:40.410 --> 00:07:44.280
Sometimes a non-volatile memory
where the driver's actually stored

153
00:07:44.280 --> 00:07:47.540
on the firmware within
the firmware itself,

154
00:07:47.540 --> 00:07:51.180
we've actually got something kinda cool
there in one of the printers that we have.

155
00:07:51.180 --> 00:07:55.980
The manufacturer actually include
a little USB device that you can just

156
00:07:55.980 --> 00:07:57.021
plug right in.

157
00:07:57.021 --> 00:07:58.124
So a lot of times,

158
00:07:58.124 --> 00:08:02.628
your manufacturers will include
the print drivers within the printer.

159
00:08:02.628 --> 00:08:05.556
So that, we'll talk about shared
printers here in a second, but

160
00:08:05.556 --> 00:08:08.100
when you connect to it,
the print driver's ready.

161
00:08:08.100 --> 00:08:11.800
It's ready to go, it's ready to install,
and it makes it really easy for you.

162
00:08:11.800 --> 00:08:15.180
However, one of the things I want you
to keep in mind about any driver,

163
00:08:15.180 --> 00:08:18.070
especially drivers that come on
an optical drive, come on a thumb drive,

164
00:08:18.070 --> 00:08:19.960
or come in the firmware itself.

165
00:08:19.960 --> 00:08:24.000
The printers can have a long shelf
life before you ever buy them.

166
00:08:24.000 --> 00:08:28.276
However, the drivers themselves, they
typically don't have a long shelf life.

167
00:08:28.276 --> 00:08:31.730
And manufacturers as they update their
products they update the, and do

168
00:08:31.730 --> 00:08:36.080
debug fixes, if you will inside of their
printer, inside of the logic, if you will.

169
00:08:36.080 --> 00:08:38.760
What happens is the drivers
need to update.

170
00:08:38.760 --> 00:08:42.540
So always check the manufacturer's website
to make sure that you have the most

171
00:08:42.540 --> 00:08:46.020
current driver when it comes
to supporting your printers.

172
00:08:46.020 --> 00:08:49.630
Now, next thing they talk
about is configuring settings.

173
00:08:49.630 --> 00:08:53.360
Some of the things that we can do,
let's talk about this a little bit, right?

174
00:08:53.360 --> 00:08:56.960
We have what is known as collating,
all right?

175
00:08:56.960 --> 00:08:59.150
Very first thing we'll
talk about is collating.

176
00:08:59.150 --> 00:09:04.110
Collate is a very interesting technique in
the way that you can make sure that your

177
00:09:04.110 --> 00:09:06.190
pages, when they're printed,
they're printed and

178
00:09:06.190 --> 00:09:09.270
the output is in a predetermined
arrangement, right?

179
00:09:09.270 --> 00:09:13.550
So let's say, for instance, like we print
our show notes here and I give Dan a copy

180
00:09:13.550 --> 00:09:17.430
of the show notes so he knows kinda
where we're going within this episode.

181
00:09:17.430 --> 00:09:20.350
Well, if you think about it,
if we got three pages, all right,

182
00:09:20.350 --> 00:09:25.560
for each collection of show notes, one for
me, one for him, that's six pages, right?

183
00:09:25.560 --> 00:09:29.790
And if you're not collating your output,

184
00:09:29.790 --> 00:09:34.230
it'll print one page and
it'll print another page one.

185
00:09:34.230 --> 00:09:37.700
Then page two, and then another page two,
and then a page three and

186
00:09:37.700 --> 00:09:38.390
another page three.

187
00:09:38.390 --> 00:09:42.280
If you do collate,
we can print it one, two, three, and

188
00:09:42.280 --> 00:09:44.370
again the next set one, two, three.

189
00:09:44.370 --> 00:09:47.080
So again,
collate's just a pre-determined output.

190
00:09:47.080 --> 00:09:49.940
How do you want the printed
output to be arranged?

191
00:09:49.940 --> 00:09:52.792
And that's pre-determined
by the collate settings.

192
00:09:52.792 --> 00:09:56.000
Other you have as well is orientation,
all right?

193
00:09:56.000 --> 00:09:58.560
Orientation is basically
the layout of the print, right?

194
00:09:58.560 --> 00:10:02.840
The paper itself, how are gonna print the

off on the industrial, scientific and

the relatively unused, I think it's
uniband 5 gigahertz frequency, right?

So, again, you get better bandwidth and-
>> Bluetooth has a shorter range,

as well, right?

So you get more range with wifi.

Now, there are some other technologies

really briefly.

There are things out there like for

So TCP/IP based printing again is

We talk about things like

We plug in, in a lot times,

you're gonna use a TCP/IP protocol stack,

Bonjour itself,
Bonjour's a really cool technology,

because we talked about things like,
for instance, drivers, right?

And services.

Well, one of the good things about Bonjour

the configuration.

that allows the communication between
network connected devices, applications,

00:23:09.774 --> 00:23:10.512
and services.

And it allows us zero
config based technology,

zero config is zero configuration if
you will, so another great technology.

And associated with that too is AirPrint,

00:23:21.713 --> 00:23:26.323
iOS devices,
Mac OS devices printing wirelessly via

the LAN without the necessity for

00:23:30.122 --> 00:23:31.712
That's gonna save you some time, right?

That's what we use here on our Macs,

00:23:34.235 --> 00:23:34.772
In fact,

you know what, let's go ahead while I've

Let me find,

00:23:45.057 --> 00:23:48.687
All of these printers that you see

00:23:49.812 --> 00:23:53.218
I believe we can see this.

00:23:53.218 --> 00:23:54.925
Down here I believe?

00:23:54.925 --> 00:24:00.570
Maybe its not in here, but

00:24:00.570 --> 00:24:04.602
If we want to find a printer, it'll go

00:24:07.880 --> 00:24:12.403
So great thing to have there

00:24:12.403 --> 00:24:16.626
So technology that they definitely call
out, let's see if I can cancel that and

00:24:16.626 --> 00:24:17.769

And so definitely be aware of that for

00:24:23.340 --> 00:24:27.171
The other thing I want you to keep in mind
that when we talk about different printing

00:24:27.171 --> 00:24:31.090
protocols out there you have what
are known as integrated print servers.

478
00:24:31.090 --> 00:24:34.560
All right integrated print server
basically is a device that

479
00:24:34.560 --> 00:24:37.210
centralizes the management of printing.

480
00:24:37.210 --> 00:24:41.617
And we can have multiple devices that are
printing to a network printer, right, and

481
00:24:41.617 --> 00:24:44.046
what happens is that you
end up having a queue.

482
00:24:44.046 --> 00:24:49.097
And a queue is the print job, essentially
what you're print that's stored in memory.

483
00:24:49.097 --> 00:24:52.774
And if everybody's printing any time they
want, well, it can become a little bit

484
00:24:52.774 --> 00:24:56.690
convoluted when it comes to the whole, you
know, management of that printer itself.

485
00:24:56.690 --> 00:25:00.588
So if you have an integrated print server,
what you can do is centrally manage of all

486
00:25:00.588 --> 00:25:04.059
of the print jobs, the print queue,
driver management is centralized.

487
00:25:04.059 --> 00:25:08.568
Centralized administration brings us
more of a least administrative effort.

488
00:25:08.568 --> 00:25:13.960
Print permissions, print times,
time of day printing.

489
00:25:13.960 --> 00:25:18.310
You're reducing the amount of
pages that can be printed out.

490
00:25:18.310 --> 00:25:20.200
If you want to control
things like black and white,

491
00:25:20.200 --> 00:25:23.600
because we don't want the company to get
charged more money because people are,

492
00:25:23.600 --> 00:25:28.322
just printed an 800 page color
document that basically drains all of

493
00:25:28.322 --> 00:25:34.270
the ink if you will or whatever,
if it's laser or toner that you're using.

494
00:25:34.270 --> 00:25:37.503
>> Listen I downloaded a PDF book and
I needed to print it out.

495
00:25:37.503 --> 00:25:38.314
>> [LAUGH] That's right, that's right.

496
00:25:38.314 --> 00:25:38.847
>> What is the problem?

497
00:25:38.847 --> 00:25:39.651
[LAUGH]
>> That will just be between

00:25:39.651 --> 00:25:40.151
me, you and Facebook.

499
00:25:40.151 --> 00:25:41.347
>> That's right.

500
00:25:41.347 --> 00:25:44.266
[LAUGH]
>> So again, it can, one of the things to

501
00:25:44.266 --> 00:25:48.871
keep in mind though is that a lot of your
devices, if they do have integrated print

502
00:25:48.871 --> 00:25:53.030
server, it could be built right into
the network based printer itself.

503
00:25:53.030 --> 00:25:54.880
It's really about
managing the print queue,

504
00:25:54.880 --> 00:25:56.787
that's one of the great
things that you can do.

505
00:25:56.787 --> 00:25:59.223
Some of the protocols I've
actually got in the list here and

00:25:59.223 --> 00:26:01.960
some of the protocols that you can
see that are used inside of this.

00:26:01.960 --> 00:26:05.904
You got for instance MNP, excuse me,
if I could say that right.

00:26:05.904 --> 00:26:06.427
>> LMNOP?

509
00:26:06.427 --> 00:26:07.891
[LAUGH]
>> That's right,

510
00:26:07.891 --> 00:26:11.760
that's Microsoft's network
printing protocol.

511
00:26:11.760 --> 00:26:14.190
IPP, if you will,
is the internet printing protocol.

512
00:26:14.190 --> 00:26:18.160
And the last one is common in your nix
based systems, Unix, Linux, if you will.

513
00:26:18.160 --> 00:26:20.560
That is the line printer daemon and

514
00:26:20.560 --> 00:26:26.120
it is a common protocol for
printing across the network.

515
00:26:26.120 --> 00:26:28.740
Now some of the other last things

00:26:28.740 --> 00:26:33.530
that we wanna talk about is a cloud

00:26:33.530 --> 00:26:37.000
And there are technologies out

One of the ones they specifically

00:26:40.552 --> 00:26:43.557
remote printing is what's

00:26:43.557 --> 00:26:46.848
I want you to think of

00:26:46.848 --> 00:26:49.456
is a software is a service, right?

522
00:26:49.456 --> 00:26:54.063
And basically being able to send
information up to the Cloud,

523
00:26:54.063 --> 00:26:56.642
if you will and print to a printer.

524
00:26:56.642 --> 00:26:59.870
There a lot of printers out there
that support Google Cloud Print.

525
00:26:59.870 --> 00:27:03.852
It basically means that they're
gonna manage your print job for you.

526
00:27:03.852 --> 00:27:08.634
I think it's Hewlett Packard I believe
that is their equivalent to it is

527
00:27:08.634 --> 00:27:09.761
called ePrint.

528
00:27:09.761 --> 00:27:13.362
So this is again cloud based printing, in
a way to connect your printer from home or

529
00:27:13.362 --> 00:27:14.680
work to the cloud if you will.

530
00:27:14.680 --> 00:27:18.030
The ability to print
across multiple devices.

531
00:27:18.030 --> 00:27:21.460
I have a mobile phone, maybe I'm not
connected to the wireless network, but

532
00:27:21.460 --> 00:27:22.620
I really have to print this job.

533
00:27:22.620 --> 00:27:25.116
Well, I could send it up to the cloud and
they,

534
00:27:25.116 --> 00:27:28.384
according to if you have
a cloud-based printing solution,

535
00:27:28.384 --> 00:27:32.625
your printer has that functionality
built into it, you do have that ability.

536
00:27:32.625 --> 00:27:35.974
One of the great things about cloud-based
printing is the fact that it eliminates

537
00:27:35.974 --> 00:27:38.360
the necessity for driver management, why?

538
00:27:38.360 --> 00:27:39.970
Because you're sending it to the Cloud and

539
00:27:39.970 --> 00:27:41.700
they managed the drivers
in the background.

540
00:27:41.700 --> 00:27:46.310
So the responsibility to manage the
physical printer by itself can essentially

541
00:27:46.310 --> 00:27:51.720
be allocated to a third party, some kind
of professional cloud-based solution.

542
00:27:51.720 --> 00:27:55.000
It reduces things like device
compatibility issues and

543
00:27:55.000 --> 00:28:00.220
the other thing that you also
get is access on demand.

544
00:28:00.220 --> 00:28:03.360
All right Dan we made it almost to the end
of the episode we do have one more

00:28:03.360 --> 00:28:06.110
thing when it comes to
the considerations of printing and

546
00:28:06.110 --> 00:28:08.830
that has to deal with data privacy.

547
00:28:08.830 --> 00:28:11.620
All right you have to be very careful
because if people can print to printers

548
00:28:11.620 --> 00:28:14.750
any time they want you might end up

549
00:28:14.750 --> 00:28:18.330
losing things like user

550
00:28:19.430 --> 00:28:22.820
Again this could cause problems,
especially if you're in an environment

551
00:28:22.820 --> 00:28:25.798
where maybe you're handling

552
00:28:25.798 --> 00:28:28.534
In the security world
they call that PCIDSS,

553
00:28:28.534 --> 00:28:31.705
payment card information
data security standard.

554
00:28:31.705 --> 00:28:34.959
And if you don't have authentication
that might violate some kind of standard

555
00:28:34.959 --> 00:28:35.800
like that.

556
00:28:35.800 --> 00:28:38.090
The other thing I want you to think of
that they call out on the exam, and

557
00:28:38.090 --> 00:28:41.330
this is something that's very important,
is hard drive caching.

558
00:28:41.330 --> 00:28:44.981
Your network based printers
are really self contained computers,

559
00:28:44.981 --> 00:28:46.782
amongst being a printer as well.

560
00:28:46.782 --> 00:28:49.801
And if I'm caching that information,

561
00:28:49.801 --> 00:28:54.655
then there's the ability to pull
that data out of the printer.

562
00:28:54.655 --> 00:28:57.480
You have a print job,
you essentially send it to the printer.

563
00:28:57.480 --> 00:29:00.845
The print job stays in a volatile
memory region called the queue, but

564
00:29:00.845 --> 00:29:03.977
to make sure that if the printer fails or
the printer shuts down,

565
00:29:03.977 --> 00:29:06.607
it's written to the hard drive,
well, guess what?

566
00:29:06.607 --> 00:29:09.798
Anytime something's written to the hard
drive it means you can do data recovery

567
00:29:09.798 --> 00:29:10.770
on it later.

568
00:29:10.770 --> 00:29:13.188
This could be a security problem, so

569
00:29:13.188 --> 00:29:16.629
do keep that in mind when
we talk about data privacy.

570
00:29:16.629 --> 00:29:20.597
If you are in a company that details with
credit cards, that deals with PII or

571
00:29:20.597 --> 00:29:24.135
[CROSSTALK] Personal Identifiable
Information, thank you there.

572
00:29:24.135 --> 00:29:26.968
PHI, Protected Healthcare Information,
just turn around and

573
00:29:26.968 --> 00:29:29.700
this could be a violation
of your security policy.

574
00:29:29.700 --> 00:29:32.040
Again the formal statement on what
security means to your company.

575
00:29:32.040 --> 00:29:35.030
So definitely keep those in mind but

576
00:29:35.030 --> 00:29:38.340
really like things like airprint because
it makes driver management so simple.

577
00:29:38.340 --> 00:29:42.310
Google Cloud print is another one
of those ones what we can say okay

578
00:29:42.310 --> 00:29:44.660
you guys go ahead and
handle the drives in the background and

579

all I have to worry about is what

>> Well, if you feel like this was

581

well guess what,

How they operate,

588

589
00:30:11.310 --> 00:30:13.460
Wes, you did a fantastic

00:30:13.460 --> 00:30:16.180
We do appreciate it,
we do appreciate you good folks watching,

591
00:30:16.180 --> 00:30:19.140

00:30:19.140 --> 00:30:20.200
So thanks for that anyway,

593
00:30:20.200 --> 00:30:22.980
signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

00:30:22.980 --> 00:30:23.845

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes walk you through each of the printer types found in the A+ 220-901 exam. Here you will learn about the components and printing processes of Laser printers, Inkjet printers, Thermal printers, Impact printers, and Virtual printers.

00:14:17.660 --> 00:14:19.170
Then we have charging.

275
00:14:19.170 --> 00:14:23.510
Now when we have charging, what we end up
having is a strong negative charge that's

276
00:14:23.510 --> 00:14:26.980
placed on the electrostatic or
the EP drum, the imaging drum.

277
00:14:26.980 --> 00:14:28.950
And so that's the next process right.

278
00:14:28.950 --> 00:14:32.630
Now you might hear this called charging,
you might hear it called conditioning.

279
00:14:32.630 --> 00:14:35.340
Conditioning is conditioning
the drum itself.

280
00:14:35.340 --> 00:14:37.610
Now we're putting a strong
charge on the drum itself.

281
00:14:38.730 --> 00:14:41.080
The next thing that you have
is what's known as exposing.

282
00:14:41.080 --> 00:14:42.360
Exposing, if you will,

283
00:14:42.360 --> 00:14:47.030
or writing, exposing is where the laser
is writing to the drum, right?

284
00:14:47.030 --> 00:14:50.100
It's exposing the image,
if you will, to the drum itself.

285
00:14:50.100 --> 00:14:54.100
Everywhere the laser writes to the drum it
actually reduces the charge a little bit.

286
00:14:54.100 --> 00:14:58.878
I remember some of the numbers,
it reduces it

287
00:14:58.878 --> 00:15:03.798
down to like 150 volts
if I remember right.

288
00:15:03.798 --> 00:15:11.030
So it's a 600 volt charge is placed on
the drum and it reduces it down to a 150.

289
00:15:11.030 --> 00:15:14.090
Again that's the writing phase or
the exposing phase if you will.

290
00:15:14.090 --> 00:15:18.880
Now the developing phase
is as that EP drum passes

291
00:15:18.880 --> 00:15:23.500
under the toner hopper, what happens is
the toner is attracted, it's pulled down.

292
00:15:23.500 --> 00:15:26.980
It is a loose transfer, it is pulled
down to the EP drum or the imaging drum.

293
00:15:26.980 --> 00:15:28.860
That is the developing phase.

294
00:15:28.860 --> 00:15:32.540
Developing is what I hear regardless
of the CompTIA version or

295
00:15:32.540 --> 00:15:35.190
their terminology or
just terminology out there.

296
00:15:35.190 --> 00:15:39.540
Again that is the toner its self
actually adhering to the EP drum.

297
00:15:39.540 --> 00:15:42.630
Transferring, well,
I'm glad they kept that one the same.

298
00:15:42.630 --> 00:15:44.793
Transferring is exactly
what it sounds like.

299
00:15:44.793 --> 00:15:48.128
Transferring's interesting because
what happens with transferring is,

300
00:15:48.128 --> 00:15:50.063
remember we talked about the corona wires?

301
00:15:50.063 --> 00:15:52.655
You have a set of corona
wires that charge the drum,

302
00:15:52.655 --> 00:15:56.454
but you also have a set of corona wires
That put a positive strong, positive

303
00:15:56.454 --> 00:16:00.760
charge on the paper and actually charges
the paper, right, and opposite attract.

304
00:16:00.760 --> 00:16:05.227
So as the EP drum rotates,
the toner that's adhered to the EP drum,

305
00:16:05.227 --> 00:16:10.080
the imaging drum, is actually pulled down
to the positive charge on the paper.

306
00:16:10.080 --> 00:16:12.820
Now, here's the problem with
the transferring phase.

307
00:16:12.820 --> 00:16:16.001
We're not completely done cuz we still
have what's known as the fusing phase, and

308
00:16:16.001 --> 00:16:17.145
this is where fusion goes on.

309
00:16:17.145 --> 00:16:22.558
And when we talk about fusing phase, the
paper that now has the media come right

310
00:16:22.558 --> 00:16:28.590

goes right through these fusing rollers.

311
00:16:28.590 --> 00:16:32.010
And these fusing rollers apply pressure,
and they apply heat.

312
00:16:33.080 --> 00:16:36.270
Inside of the toner, you have basically
a very fine metal powder, and

313
00:16:36.270 --> 00:16:38.100
you have plastics.

00:16:38.100 --> 00:16:42.200
The fusing rollers will heat up
to about 350 degrees or so, and

315
00:16:42.200 --> 00:16:47.040
they will literally melt the plastic,
if you will, right to the paper itself.

316
00:16:47.040 --> 00:16:49.831
This is one of the things
that you can keep in mind,

317
00:16:49.831 --> 00:16:53.488
that a fusing roller is dirty or
malfunctioning or overheated and

318
00:16:53.488 --> 00:16:56.361
got warped,
is when the printed output comes out.

00:16:56.361 --> 00:16:59.451
I don't know if you've ever done this,

00:16:59.451 --> 00:17:01.288

00:17:01.288 --> 00:17:03.581
>> Yeah.
>> You can actually do that too if you

00:17:03.581 --> 00:17:08.040

00:17:08.040 --> 00:17:09.380
And that, a lot of times,

324
00:17:09.380 --> 00:17:13.540
is a tell tale sign that the fusing
roller has overheated and warped itself.

325
00:17:13.540 --> 00:17:17.770
And rather than being, let's see here,
rather than being nice circles here, that

326
00:17:17.770 --> 00:17:22.013
are making contact with the paper roll

00:17:22.013 --> 00:17:27.370
And it misses some as it turns, it

00:17:27.370 --> 00:17:29.276
So do definitely keep that in mind.

329
00:17:29.276 --> 00:17:34.140
So the fusing, again, is the last
process in the laser print process, and

330
00:17:34.140 --> 00:17:37.820
that's that phase that
heats up the toner and

00:17:37.820 --> 00:17:42.050

00:26:26.370 --> 00:26:29.080
Printer maintenance inside of CompTIA A+.

537
00:26:29.080 --> 00:26:31.700
And make sure you see every
single episode of CompTIA A+.

538
00:26:31.700 --> 00:26:35.070
Go to our course library and
check out the hundreds of videos there,

539
00:26:35.070 --> 00:26:37.660
all designed to help you go further.

540
00:26:37.660 --> 00:26:41.190
And make sure you tell all your friends
about ITProTV, they'll be glad you did.

541
00:26:41.190 --> 00:26:42.560
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

542
00:26:42.560 --> 00:26:43.270
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

543
00:26:43.270 --> 00:26:46.228
>> And we'll see you again soon.

544
00:26:46.228 --> 00:26:52.018
[MUSIC]

545
00:26:52.018 --> 00:26:54.993
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes help you identify the various types of network cables and connectors specific to the A+ exam. Specific topics covered here includes: Fiber Optic media and connectors like Single-Mode and Multi-Mode, SC/ST/LC as well as Copper media and connectors like Twisted-Pair (UTP/STP), Plenum, CAT3/5/6/7, RJ-45, and Coax.
episodes.title: Network Cables and Connectors
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.350 --> 00:00:01.377
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.377 --> 00:00:02.853
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.853 --> 00:00:06.633
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.633 --> 00:00:08.367
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.367 --> 00:00:12.503
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.503 --> 00:00:14.357
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:14.357 --> 00:00:16.775
welcome to another great
episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.775 --> 00:00:18.005
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

9
00:00:18.005 --> 00:00:22.415
And in today's episode, I'm so glad to be
here because we're kicking off more of our

10
00:00:22.415 --> 00:00:25.620
A+ series going through
the 220-901 specifically.

11
00:00:25.620 --> 00:00:27.851
And of course joining us
back in the studio yet

12
00:00:27.851 --> 00:00:31.630
again, lending his expertise on that
topic, our good friend Mr Wes Bryan.

13
00:00:31.630 --> 00:00:32.580
Wes, welcome back, man.

14
00:00:32.580 --> 00:00:33.350
How's it going?

15
00:00:33.350 --> 00:00:35.057
>> Man, it's going great.

16
00:00:35.057 --> 00:00:38.062
Just when we thought we
were done with connections,

17
00:00:38.062 --> 00:00:41.424
we've got a few different types
that we gotta talk about.

18
00:00:41.424 --> 00:00:45.609
And that's really what we're gonna be
addressing in this issue, I don't know.

19
00:00:45.609 --> 00:00:46.194
>> Yeah.

20
00:00:46.194 --> 00:00:47.799
[LAUGH]
>> This issue of this magazine in

21
00:00:47.799 --> 00:00:48.427
this episode.

22
00:00:48.427 --> 00:00:49.729
>> That's right.
[LAUGH]

23
00:00:49.729 --> 00:00:50.872
>> In earlier episodes,

24
00:00:50.872 --> 00:00:53.338
we talked about things
like PC connections, and

25
00:00:53.338 --> 00:00:57.490
I really kept some of the connections
separate because, they fall under a class,

26
00:00:57.490 --> 00:00:59.793
we still make connections
to the computers.

27
00:00:59.793 --> 00:01:03.243
But, however, they're really
dealing with the network and

28
00:01:03.243 --> 00:01:05.245
network communications, right.

29
00:01:05.245 --> 00:01:09.446
When we talk about network communications,
essentially, what we are talking about is

30
00:01:09.446 --> 00:01:12.298
sending our data from internally
in the computer, right.

31
00:01:12.298 --> 00:01:16.100
Internally, we talk about communicating
across the motherboard, in and

32
00:01:16.100 --> 00:01:18.475
out of CPUs, memory, and storage devices.

33
00:01:18.475 --> 00:01:22.506
And now what we're doing is we're talking
about is sending that information

34
00:01:22.506 --> 00:01:26.724
externally, over some kind of media,
at the very least between two endpoints,

35
00:01:26.724 --> 00:01:28.655
a source and destination.

36
00:01:28.655 --> 00:01:31.975
And the types of connections we make
is gonna be important on the exam.

37
00:01:31.975 --> 00:01:34.062
You're gonna have to be aware of it.

38
00:01:34.062 --> 00:01:41.043
Now, there are a few different types of
communications that we can make, right?

39
00:01:41.043 --> 00:01:43.176
There's what's known as bounded media,
and and

40
00:01:43.176 --> 00:01:45.627
there's what's known as unbounded media,
all right.

41
00:01:45.627 --> 00:01:48.988
Let's go ahead, and I want to get
unbounded media out of the way here for

42
00:01:48.988 --> 00:01:49.716
just a second,

43
00:01:49.716 --> 00:01:53.600
because we're gonna talk about something
known as wireless in another episode.

44
00:01:53.600 --> 00:01:57.712
But when we talk about unbounded media,
we're talking about radiated connections,

45
00:01:57.712 --> 00:02:00.203
right, we're not talking
about physical cables.

46
00:02:00.203 --> 00:02:03.860
So in this episode, what we're
talking about is bounded medium.

47
00:02:03.860 --> 00:02:07.800
Talk about bounded medium,
we've got some kind of physical media,

48
00:02:07.800 --> 00:02:12.970
if you will, that makes a connection
between a two devices, right.

49
00:02:12.970 --> 00:02:17.185
Whether that be a network connectivity
device, whether that be a danum my laptop

50
00:02:17.185 --> 00:02:21.820
appear that is connected,
if you will to the network via a cable.

51
00:02:21.820 --> 00:02:23.480
Now when we talk about cable connections,

52
00:02:23.480 --> 00:02:27.920
there are typically two different mediums,
if you will.

53
00:02:27.920 --> 00:02:29.690
There's what's known as
copper bounded media,

54
00:02:29.690 --> 00:02:32.720
and there's what's known
as optical bounded media.

55
00:02:32.720 --> 00:02:36.318
Right, when we talk about copper based
media, what we're talking about is

56
00:02:36.318 --> 00:02:40.590
an electromagnetic energy is sent
across some kind of copper conductor.

57
00:02:40.590 --> 00:02:44.812
When we talk about an optical connection,
what we talk about is an optical light

58
00:02:44.812 --> 00:02:48.290
source for the data that is sent
over some kind of optical medium.

59
00:02:48.290 --> 00:02:51.260
We're gonna ahead and what we will do is,
we will dive into optical first.

60
00:02:51.260 --> 00:02:54.480
We're gonna to talk about what
is known as, well, fiber optics.

61
00:02:54.480 --> 00:02:57.850
Some of you, I'm sure,
already know what fiber optics are.

62
00:02:57.850 --> 00:03:01.410
You probably see it, whether it is
on the television out there, or

63
00:03:01.410 --> 00:03:03.010
whether you have been
surfing the Internet.

64
00:03:03.010 --> 00:03:07.230
You probably seen the concept
of fiber optics communication.

65
00:03:07.230 --> 00:03:09.370
Now, one of the great
things about fiber optics,

66
00:03:09.370 --> 00:03:11.970
well, there's a few things that
are good about fiber optics, all right.

67
00:03:11.970 --> 00:03:15.530
And then there's something that's not so
great about fiber optics, all right?

68
00:03:15.530 --> 00:03:18.360
Fiber optics, one of the great things is,
it's one of the fastest,

69
00:03:18.360 --> 00:03:23.430
is the fastest bounded transmission
media we have on the planet.

70
00:03:23.430 --> 00:03:25.183
>> It's quick
>> It's really quick and

71
00:03:25.183 --> 00:03:27.970
you, Dan, it's kind of interesting,
because it's so

72
00:03:27.970 --> 00:03:30.815
quick that even the devices
that send the communication,

73
00:03:30.815 --> 00:03:34.379
can't put all the data on a fiber
optic cable to completely saturate it.

74
00:03:34.379 --> 00:03:38.288
Now, when you multitudes of
computer can certainly do that.

75
00:03:38.288 --> 00:03:42.859
But, we still have a little bit
in the technology before we

76
00:03:42.859 --> 00:03:46.498
can really saturate
the amount of bandwidth,

77
00:03:46.498 --> 00:03:51.463
right, the capacity of that
transmission media completely.

78
00:03:51.463 --> 00:03:55.217
Now when we talk about fiber optic cables,
again,

79
00:03:55.217 --> 00:03:58.722
we're talking about
an optical light source.

80
00:03:58.722 --> 00:04:01.980
In some cases,
you could see LEDs were used.

81
00:04:01.980 --> 00:04:05.110
Again, fiber optics commonly
today are lasers are used, and

82
00:04:05.110 --> 00:04:09.090
lasers are used because they have
a very long transmission distance.

83
00:04:09.090 --> 00:04:12.370
Now I talked about transmission distances,
and when we look at transmission

84
00:04:12.370 --> 00:04:15.740
distances, it's really based on
the type of cable that you have.

85
00:04:15.740 --> 00:04:20.658
You have some cable types, if you will,
that support transmission distances up

86
00:04:20.658 --> 00:04:25.233
to 40 kilometers, right,
we're talking about 40,000 meters.

87
00:04:25.233 --> 00:04:30.157
So much so that they are what form
the basis for whats known as, for instance

88
00:04:30.157 --> 00:04:35.970
lets say, some of our Europeans SMEs that
come in here from across the pond, right.

89
00:04:35.970 --> 00:04:38.550
They actually connect continents together,
right,

90
00:04:38.550 --> 00:04:42.840
like the transatlantic cabling is
actually done with this type of medium.

91
00:04:42.840 --> 00:04:46.900
But there's also fiber optic
cables that are typically, again,

92
00:04:46.900 --> 00:04:51.200
still the same concept as in high band
width, but they're internal to a building.

93
00:04:51.200 --> 00:04:53.091
Let's go ahead and
talk about the different types.

94
00:04:53.091 --> 00:04:56.820
These are what are known as mode types,
and you have two different modes.

95
00:04:56.820 --> 00:05:00.387
You have what's known as single mode,
and you have what's known as multi-mode.

96
00:05:00.387 --> 00:05:02.080
Now, let's go ahead, and

97
00:05:02.080 --> 00:05:06.220
let's take a look at a diagram of
what multi-mode is, all right.

98
00:05:06.220 --> 00:05:09.944
When we talk about multi-mode
communications, I want you to know that

99
00:05:09.944 --> 00:05:13.497
the data is sent over the medium
in multiple light sources, right.

100
00:05:13.497 --> 00:05:17.540
You have multiple light sources
within the interior of the cable.

101
00:05:17.540 --> 00:05:20.210
Now the cable's interesting,
because it's made up of a few things.

102
00:05:20.210 --> 00:05:23.100
It's made up of typically a glass core,
right,

103
00:05:23.100 --> 00:05:27.170
and the core itself is what the light
source goes down, all right?

104
00:05:27.170 --> 00:05:32.930
Now in multi-mode cores, I want you to
know there's something specific to them,

105
00:05:32.930 --> 00:05:36.484
and that is that they are 50 or
62.5 microns.

106
00:05:36.484 --> 00:05:41.463
I had to be careful saying that, because
when I first started teaching this, I

107
00:05:41.463 --> 00:05:46.900
would say 50 to 62.5 microns in diameter,
and it's not an in between thing.

108
00:05:46.900 --> 00:05:50.096
You have 50, or you have 62.5.

109
00:05:50.096 --> 00:05:52.060
Now, what the heck is a micron?

110
00:05:52.060 --> 00:05:53.520
[LAUGH] A micron is
a millionth of a meter.

111
00:05:53.520 --> 00:05:55.919
So we're talking very small, all right.

112
00:05:55.919 --> 00:06:00.941
Now, the outer diameter of this cable,
which the outer diameter is

113
00:06:00.941 --> 00:06:07.656
the protective coating that's around the
outside, that is 125 microns in diameter.

114
00:06:07.656 --> 00:06:09.299
And the great thing to
understand about this,

115
00:06:09.299 --> 00:06:11.270
doesn't matter if it's single mode or
multi-mode.

116
00:06:11.270 --> 00:06:13.703
The diameter on the outside is the same.

117
00:06:13.703 --> 00:06:17.780
Now, around that core, you have
what's known as reflective cladding.

118
00:06:17.780 --> 00:06:21.890
All right, now reflective cladding is
what allows the cable to actually bounce

119
00:06:21.890 --> 00:06:26.660
the signal internally within the glass
core across the transmission medium.

120
00:06:26.660 --> 00:06:29.300
It uses something known as
total internal refraction.

121
00:06:29.300 --> 00:06:31.757
That's just a reflection bounces off,

122
00:06:31.757 --> 00:06:34.581
refraction keeps it
within the cable itself.

123
00:06:34.581 --> 00:06:38.392
And then around the reflective cladding,
you have strengthening fibers, all right.

124
00:06:38.392 --> 00:06:40.322
When we talk about strengthening fibers,

125
00:06:40.322 --> 00:06:44.345
they're important because of the fact that
the microns' diameters that we're talking

126
00:06:44.345 --> 00:06:46.830
about with that glass core
that's in the middle of it.

127
00:06:46.830 --> 00:06:50.682
Now the other thing I want you to keep in
mind, that with multi-mode communications,

128
00:06:50.682 --> 00:06:52.500
the distances are shorter, all right.

129
00:06:52.500 --> 00:06:54.320
Now, why are the distance is shorter?

130
00:06:54.320 --> 00:06:56.120
Well, I want you to think of
a garden hose, all right.

131
00:06:57.170 --> 00:07:01.585
If I have a garden hose that
is 3 inches in diameter, and

132
00:07:01.585 --> 00:07:04.580
I'm pumping water out of it, right, I have

133
00:07:04.580 --> 00:07:08.540
to put a lot of pressure in there to get
that water to come out really great.

134
00:07:08.540 --> 00:07:10.808
But If you take the same
amount of pressure, and

135
00:07:10.808 --> 00:07:14.039
you put that in a garden hose that
is a half inch in diameter, right,

136
00:07:14.039 --> 00:07:17.975
did you ever put your finger over the hose
when you where a kid and it sprays faster?

137
00:07:17.975 --> 00:07:19.434
That's kind of like a single mode.

138
00:07:19.434 --> 00:07:23.220
So there are some things to keep in
mind that because the core isn't

139
00:07:23.220 --> 00:07:26.860
ultra concentrated, like single motives
that we'll talk about in a second,

140
00:07:26.860 --> 00:07:30.920
the transmission distances
are a lot shorter, right.

141
00:07:30.920 --> 00:07:32.260
So, we have multi-mode.

142
00:07:32.260 --> 00:07:34.790
You could see multi-mode and
single mode within buildings, so

143
00:07:34.790 --> 00:07:35.610
don't let me fool you there.

144
00:07:35.610 --> 00:07:38.290
We have single mode cables
that we use in here as well.

145
00:07:38.290 --> 00:07:42.789
But as far as the overall range goes,
you're talking typically,

146
00:07:42.789 --> 00:07:45.531
no greater than 550 meters, right?

147
00:07:45.531 --> 00:07:49.450
Another common one is 330 meters,
I'm not sure exactly why.

148
00:07:49.450 --> 00:07:51.220
I'm sure there's some science behind it.

149
00:07:51.220 --> 00:07:53.575
Well beyond the scope of this exam and
my brain.

150
00:07:53.575 --> 00:07:59.695
[LAUGH] But I can shorter transition
distances is important to remember there.

151
00:07:59.695 --> 00:08:03.019
Now we also have what's
known as single mode.

152
00:08:03.019 --> 00:08:04.306
>> This is the big daddy.

153
00:08:04.306 --> 00:08:06.322
>> Yes, that's right.
That's going back to what we were talking

154
00:08:06.322 --> 00:08:08.113
about connecting continents-
>> Yes.

155
00:08:08.113 --> 00:08:11.539
>> Together, right?
We're talking up to 40 kilometers in

156
00:08:11.539 --> 00:08:12.804
a single cable.

157
00:08:12.804 --> 00:08:16.055
And then when you put repeaters
that can help extend the signal.

158
00:08:16.055 --> 00:08:20.859
I mean this is essentially what happens
when we have a network operation center

159
00:08:20.859 --> 00:08:23.208
down in Florida, down here in Miami.

160
00:08:23.208 --> 00:08:26.832
Or the ones that are like in New York
that literally tie the continents

161
00:08:26.832 --> 00:08:27.845
together, okay?

162
00:08:27.845 --> 00:08:30.173
Now when we say single mode,

163
00:08:30.173 --> 00:08:35.025
well let's go ahead and
let's look at the diameters here.

164
00:08:35.025 --> 00:08:39.825
Now, we're talking down to 9 microns,
9 millions of a meter in diameter.

165
00:08:39.825 --> 00:08:42.320
And again they call it singlemode
because its a single light source.

166
00:08:42.320 --> 00:08:46.524
Again its fired kinda like a rifle shot
and across here straight down that cable.

167
00:08:46.524 --> 00:08:51.174
And there really isn't any bouncing or
refraction like you see in multi-mode.

168
00:08:51.174 --> 00:08:57.153
All right, these are extremely
large long distance connections.

169
00:08:57.153 --> 00:09:00.214
And it really is one of the ones that's
about the fastest transmission speed that

170
00:09:00.214 --> 00:09:00.760
you'll see.

171
00:09:00.760 --> 00:09:04.409
In fact, they use these things
as you move into network plus,

172
00:09:04.409 --> 00:09:08.424
you'll learn about things like
synchronous optical networking.

173
00:09:08.424 --> 00:09:11.619
And that's how ISPs tie
their networks together and

174
00:09:11.619 --> 00:09:17.420
bring them into your house locally if you
will, for residential communications.

175
00:09:17.420 --> 00:09:21.620
Now I'd like to take a second, we've
actually got an example of some fiber

176
00:09:21.620 --> 00:09:25.369
optic cables here that I'd like
you guys to take a look at, right?

177
00:09:25.369 --> 00:09:28.388
One of the ones that I have here,
Dan I kinda broke this.

178
00:09:28.388 --> 00:09:29.773
Dan was like what are-
>> [LAUGH]

179
00:09:29.773 --> 00:09:30.439
>> These pieces here.

180
00:09:30.439 --> 00:09:33.803
And I decided to leave them up here
because what I was trying to do is

181
00:09:33.803 --> 00:09:35.895
show you the interior of the cable here.

182
00:09:35.895 --> 00:09:39.310
And there's not really much you
can see because of the fact that

183
00:09:39.310 --> 00:09:41.130
this is single mode cable.

184
00:09:41.130 --> 00:09:45.524
And that's why don't think we're
you won't find this inside of

185
00:09:45.524 --> 00:09:49.409
your communication networks or
closets within your system.

186
00:09:49.409 --> 00:09:54.346
In fact, this goes to one of the switches
we have inside of our closet too.

187
00:09:54.346 --> 00:09:55.885
Now-
>> Not anymore.

188
00:09:55.885 --> 00:09:57.056
[LAUGH]
>> Not anymore,

189
00:09:57.056 --> 00:09:57.946
that's right, that's funny.

190
00:09:57.946 --> 00:10:01.192
Because one of our other hosts that's
worked in networks for a very long time,

191
00:10:01.192 --> 00:10:01.692
Don Pezet.

192
00:10:01.692 --> 00:10:06.220
Actually, I was in a show with him when
he cut this, and when he cut this,

193
00:10:06.220 --> 00:10:08.166
I was like, did you just that?

194
00:10:08.166 --> 00:10:08.746
10 years ago,

195
00:10:08.746 --> 00:10:11.160
you wouldn't have cut a fiber optic
cable just in the sheer expense.

196
00:10:11.160 --> 00:10:15.100
And that's one of the drawbacks,
I said about the only drawback that you

197
00:10:15.100 --> 00:10:19.230
have that's not so good is that fiber
optics can be very expensive cables.

198
00:10:19.230 --> 00:10:22.650
This is single mode, and notice that
we have this protective coating, right?

199
00:10:22.650 --> 00:10:26.566
That's gonna be what has the 125
micron diameter on the outside of it.

200
00:10:26.566 --> 00:10:30.961
Then we have, you can't really see it,
there's a glass core in here.

201
00:10:30.961 --> 00:10:32.877
And like I said guys,
I tried to strip that off.

202
00:10:32.877 --> 00:10:35.359
You can see,
[LAUGH] I didn't do too good too well.

203
00:10:35.359 --> 00:10:36.120
>> It does look a little brittle.

204
00:10:36.120 --> 00:10:38.465
>> Yeah, that is very brittle,
you're absolutely correct.

205
00:10:38.465 --> 00:10:41.441
In fact you can kinda break it off,
you can feel it breaking there.

206
00:10:41.441 --> 00:10:43.848
So you wanna be very careful
with these cables for sure.

207
00:10:43.848 --> 00:10:46.215
That's not something you wanna
play tug of war on, right?

208
00:10:46.215 --> 00:10:48.005
We don't stretch these cables at all.

209
00:10:48.005 --> 00:10:50.246
But then notice that you also
have the strengthening fibers.

210
00:10:50.246 --> 00:10:55.203
Well this is just for
a single communication channel, right?

211
00:10:55.203 --> 00:10:59.081
This is what's known as a full duplex
communication in the fact that it sends

212
00:10:59.081 --> 00:11:00.670
signal down one fiber strand.

213
00:11:00.670 --> 00:11:05.519
And it receives communications

And when it comes to copper-based media,

319
00:16:14.100 --> 00:16:16.710
>> Yeah Wes, when I think of copper media,

00:16:16.710 --> 00:16:19.875
the first thing that pops from my mind,

00:16:19.875 --> 00:16:23.740
Just because of that thick copper wire

00:16:23.740 --> 00:16:24.635

00:16:24.635 --> 00:16:27.487
>> Yeah, that's right, it's interesting

00:16:27.487 --> 00:16:30.253
have to think about networking when

325
00:16:30.253 --> 00:16:34.300
Cuz, well, we've been using that for
cable television for a very long time.

326
00:16:34.300 --> 00:16:35.130
Now, in networking,

327
00:16:35.130 --> 00:16:40.160
one of the most popular copper-based
medias that we have is twisted pair.

328
00:16:40.160 --> 00:16:41.791
And twisted pair implementations,

329
00:16:41.791 --> 00:16:45.220
they have an interesting characteristic
that really is how it gets its name.

330
00:16:45.220 --> 00:16:47.165
In fact,
I got an example of one right here.

331
00:16:47.165 --> 00:16:49.360
And I went ahead and
tried to make it a little bit easier so

332
00:16:49.360 --> 00:16:51.600
you guys can see this a little
bit better out there.

333
00:16:51.600 --> 00:16:53.786
You can actually see, well,
you could see the twisted pairs.

334
00:16:53.786 --> 00:16:58.255
What we have, our eight conductors here,
straighten that out a little bit, and

335
00:16:58.255 --> 00:17:00.573
they are four individual twisted pairs.

336
00:17:00.573 --> 00:17:04.160
And why do we have twists in the pairs?

337
00:17:04.160 --> 00:17:08.955
Well, one of the things, unlike fiber
optics, which is pretty much immune to

338
00:17:08.955 --> 00:17:12.890
electromagnetic interference, cuz it's
an optical light source, is the fact that,

339
00:17:12.890 --> 00:17:15.560
well, copper-based media,
we do have to worry about interference.

340
00:17:15.560 --> 00:17:18.730
We have to worry about electromagnetic
energy actually getting into the cable.

341
00:17:18.730 --> 00:17:22.820
And the problem with that is, it does have
an adverse effect on the data that's being

342
00:17:22.820 --> 00:17:26.160
sent along it, so
the twists are important, right?

343
00:17:26.160 --> 00:17:28.760
They help to mitigate the risk, or

344
00:17:28.760 --> 00:17:33.240
just bring it down if you will, of EMI,
again, electromagnetic interference.

345
00:17:33.240 --> 00:17:37.050
Now, as you will see,
these cables increase with their quality,

346
00:17:37.050 --> 00:17:42.070
and when they do, what we have
is an increased twist per inch.

347
00:17:42.070 --> 00:17:44.855
And earlier cables,
which we'll talk about coming up,

348
00:17:44.855 --> 00:17:48.835
the types that we have, would be a little
bit more tolerant to untwisting,

349
00:17:48.835 --> 00:17:53.595
when you are putting, like for instance
the jack on it, called an RJ45 jack.

350
00:17:53.595 --> 00:17:56.260
Sometimes people just
call it an ethernet jack.

351
00:17:56.260 --> 00:18:00.920
And honestly guys, again if we're not in
an exam circumstance, I wouldn't correct

352
00:18:00.920 --> 00:18:05.380
you there, but that's typically,
that is the RJ45 jack that we have.

353
00:18:05.380 --> 00:18:11.260
And what you do, is you actually
untwist these pairs, all right?

354
00:18:11.260 --> 00:18:15.890
And you put each one of these pairs
in a certain arrangement in the back

355
00:18:15.890 --> 00:18:17.110
of the RJ45 jack, and

356
00:18:17.110 --> 00:18:20.810
you'll see there's eight copper conductors
right here, contacts, if you will.

357
00:18:20.810 --> 00:18:23.580
That's why sometimes,
the RJ45 jack is called and 8P8C, and

358
00:18:23.580 --> 00:18:28.140
it mean eight pins,
eight conductors, right?

359
00:18:28.140 --> 00:18:29.820
So this is twisted pair.

360
00:18:29.820 --> 00:18:34.640
Now, there are some things that could make
this cable a little bit more resistant,

361
00:18:34.640 --> 00:18:37.270
if you will,
to electromagnetic interference, and

362
00:18:37.270 --> 00:18:43.000
that's a type of twisted pair cable
called STP, shielded twisted pair.

363
00:18:43.000 --> 00:18:47.380
Because not only do they have the twists,
which all twisted pair have, but

364
00:18:47.380 --> 00:18:49.510
they also have a foil.

365
00:18:49.510 --> 00:18:54.040
Either a braided or
solid foil shielding around the outside,

366
00:18:54.040 --> 00:18:59.470
in between the outer insulated jacket and
the connectors themselves.

367
00:18:59.470 --> 00:19:05.090
And again, it helps to raise the immunity
to electromagnetic interference.

368
00:19:05.090 --> 00:19:07.554
Now, one of the things also to keep
in mind, is that these cables,

369
00:19:07.554 --> 00:19:09.175
there's also a few different types here.

370
00:19:09.175 --> 00:19:11.520
And when we talk about
a few different types,

371
00:19:11.520 --> 00:19:16.106
what we ended up talking about, is what's
known as plenum versus non-plenum.

372
00:19:16.106 --> 00:19:20.910
You'll see in the exam objectives,
they call it PVC versus plenum.

373
00:19:20.910 --> 00:19:23.973
They typically won't, on the side
of the box when you go to buy it,

374
00:19:23.973 --> 00:19:27.587
you're not gonna see non-plenum, or
you're not gonna see PVC, excuse me,

375
00:19:27.587 --> 00:19:29.544
you're gonna see non-plenum, right?

376
00:19:29.544 --> 00:19:31.924
Now, PVC, why am I worried about PVC?

377
00:19:31.924 --> 00:19:35.870
Well, polyvinyl chloride,
if I can say that right,

378
00:19:35.870 --> 00:19:40.380
polyvinyl chloride gives off
a toxic gas when it's burned.

379
00:19:40.380 --> 00:19:45.480
And so, according to fire code,
if you have cat cables or the twisted

380
00:19:45.480 --> 00:19:49.712
pair cables that are running through
fire breaks in your building structure,

381
00:19:49.712 --> 00:19:56.780
they could, again, give off a toxic gas
that is obviously poisonous to humans.

382
00:19:56.780 --> 00:20:01.033
The other thing about non-plenum cables or
PVC-based cables,

383
00:20:01.033 --> 00:20:05.660
is that that outer jacket, that actually
protects everything inside of the cable,

384
00:20:05.660 --> 00:20:10.710
isn't really tightly wrapped
around the interior of the cable.

385
00:20:10.710 --> 00:20:14.670
Which means that it also allows oxygen
to pass though, and well, guess what,

386
00:20:14.670 --> 00:20:15.830
fires love oxygen.

387
00:20:15.830 --> 00:20:20.190
So according to your fire code,
because of the toxicity, if you will.

388
00:20:20.190 --> 00:20:23.254
And because of the fact that there's
a little bit of an air gap in there,

389
00:20:23.254 --> 00:20:25.654
it not only could poison people
in the case of a fire, but

390
00:20:25.654 --> 00:20:28.697
it can also allow the fire to travel
right through the firebreak wall.

391
00:20:28.697 --> 00:20:30.606
That's where plenum comes in.

392
00:20:30.606 --> 00:20:34.046
Plenum isn't used in things
like your structural cabling.

393
00:20:34.046 --> 00:20:37.838
And what I mean by structural cabling,
I mean inside of your building versus

394
00:20:37.838 --> 00:20:42.220
something that's coming out of the wall,
going right into the back of your PC.

395
00:20:42.220 --> 00:20:43.810
That's gonna be non-plenum, right?

396
00:20:43.810 --> 00:20:46.710
Because plenum is very expensive,
but it's a necessity,

397
00:20:46.710 --> 00:20:50.830
because it doesn't give off a toxic fume,
if you will, when burned.

398
00:20:50.830 --> 00:20:55.427
And you can see plenum is a very very
stiff cable, because that outer jacket

399
00:20:55.427 --> 00:20:59.150
really wraps around the internal
copper conductors very very tightly.

400
00:20:59.150 --> 00:21:03.447
Again, preventing the ability for
fire to pass through it.

401
00:21:03.447 --> 00:21:04.910
>> That whole wick effect, right, yeah?

402
00:21:04.910 --> 00:21:07.610
That's exactly, and you know,
I've never even thought about it that way.

403
00:21:07.610 --> 00:21:09.010
That's a great way to think of it.

404
00:21:09.010 --> 00:21:11.171
Your cable ends up becoming
the candle wick, right?

405
00:21:11.171 --> 00:21:13.250
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So you have to be careful, or

406
00:21:13.250 --> 00:21:14.426
maybe a wick to dynamite.

407
00:21:14.426 --> 00:21:15.614
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

408
00:21:15.614 --> 00:21:17.950
>> So definitely be careful with that.

409
00:21:17.950 --> 00:21:19.920
So those are some of the things
that we have to talk about.

410
00:21:19.920 --> 00:21:24.310
One of the things I also wanna talk about
is just like we mentioned repeaters, for

411
00:21:24.310 --> 00:21:25.640
fiber optic communication.

412
00:21:25.640 --> 00:21:29.120
The ability to regenerate the signal as it

413
00:21:29.120 --> 00:21:33.400
hits the end of its maximum cable
distance, it hits a repeater.

414
00:21:33.400 --> 00:21:36.068
It regenerates the signal, boost it, and

415
00:21:36.068 --> 00:21:38.744
now you can go the length
of another cable.

416
00:21:38.744 --> 00:21:44.510
Well, you also have the ability to
do that inside a copper cabling.

417
00:21:44.510 --> 00:21:48.257
Because transmission distance maximums for

418
00:21:48.257 --> 00:21:52.198
your twisted pair implementations
are a 100 meters, right?

419
00:21:52.198 --> 00:21:53.780
Anything past a 100 meters,

420
00:21:53.780 --> 00:21:58.210
you run the risk of signal attenuation,
which essentially is just nothing more

421
00:21:58.210 --> 00:22:02.120
than a degradation of the signal as it
gets further from its transmission source.

422
00:22:02.120 --> 00:22:06.050
You also have the increased risk for
electromagnetic interference, or

423
00:22:06.050 --> 00:22:10.910
signal bleed, so you wanna know that
it's a maximum of a hundred meters.

424
00:22:10.910 --> 00:22:14.130
Now, that being said,
I've kind of slipped out with this one but

425
00:22:14.130 --> 00:22:18.780
I haven't really talked about it, is the
fact that there are different standards.

426
00:22:18.780 --> 00:22:21.800
There is a corporation,
or a standards body

427
00:22:21.800 --> 00:22:25.377
that is endorsed by the American National
Standards Institute, known as TIA/EIA.

428
00:22:25.377 --> 00:22:30.860
Telecommunication Industry
Alliance/Electronics Industry Association,

429
00:22:30.860 --> 00:22:31.820
I believe is what it is.

430
00:22:31.820 --> 00:22:33.670
I might have the As backwards in that,

431
00:22:33.670 --> 00:22:38.840
but they're a standards body that promotes
techno-electrical communications.

432
00:22:38.840 --> 00:22:44.410
And they came out with
a standardized way for

433
00:22:44.410 --> 00:22:48.400
manufacturers to make these cables,
and we have to be aware of them too.

434
00:22:48.400 --> 00:22:51.681
You might hear the term CAT cable,
and CAT cable,

435
00:22:51.681 --> 00:22:54.908
is abbreviated for a category of a cable.

436
00:22:54.908 --> 00:22:58.892
And the categories differ in their
transmission speeds really, cuz, again,

437
00:22:58.892 --> 00:23:01.515
twisted pair is gonna be
100 meters regardless.

So let's go ahead real quick, and let's

[LAUGH]

[LAUGH] So CAT cables, you might say,

But for the most part, they're kind of

We're in gigabit ethernet today,

100 megabit ethernet, and
gigabit ethernet, right?

Well, CAT3 cables are kinda outdated,

You also have CAT5 cables.

And a CAT3 that's just called Ethernet,

Dan, you mentioned this in many

>> Yeah.
>> The marketing game.

Well, when CAT5e came out they called

However, rated more common is gonna

you can obtain gigabyte speeds,

And that's one of the things that really

00:24:53.574 --> 00:24:57.421
CAT6, we have a sustained bits,
sustained speeds,

transmission speeds of the gigabyte,

00:25:02.720 --> 00:25:04.840
Now, with today's day and age.

We have ten gig networks and

Because when you have ten gigabit network,

So, the CAT6 cable wasn't adequate for

So, that's when they

Now, the CAT6a I put at a gigabit plus.

I don't know, what they're
gonna ask you on the exam, but

489
00:25:37.550 --> 00:25:43.130
the CAT6a cable can sustain a 10

00:25:43.130 --> 00:25:48.081
Not the whole 100 meters, but it can

00:25:48.081 --> 00:25:54.610
The CAT6a can sustain it at a full

Let's be careful with CAT, and

let me correct my acronym.

00:26:09.520 --> 00:26:11.880
>> I thought, it was an site [LAUGH].

Doesn't recognize a CAT7 cable,

But CAT7 is, again, true potential,

What you have is not only the shield

So, remember, CAT6, CAT6a, CAT7, we're

Doesn't matter what the twisted pair

Now, even though this

they also call out the RJ11 jack,

You've probably seen that,

The half size, it's half the size of the

Now, I also mentioned that RJ45 jack,

514
00:27:21.110 --> 00:27:22.100
Of that jack.

515
00:27:22.100 --> 00:27:25.530
So, for instance if we take

we do have a few different

We have what's known as 50 TEA,

00:27:33.067 --> 00:27:37.982

what it boils down to is how the copper

00:27:37.982 --> 00:27:42.475
conductors sit in the back

520
00:27:42.475 --> 00:27:45.005
And if you're talking about 568A,

522

And it typically goes your green,

00:27:57.389 --> 00:28:01.290

00:28:01.290 --> 00:28:06.390
Now, when you talk about cats, or excuse

What you end up having is you

00:28:09.430 --> 00:28:11.090
the orange and

528
00:28:11.090 --> 00:28:17.140
So, the orange cables become your transmit

529
00:28:17.140 --> 00:28:21.530
if you will, the green and it would go
orange, then it would go green, blue, and

530
00:28:21.530 --> 00:28:23.840
brown, or orange and then brown.

531
00:28:23.840 --> 00:28:27.760
And that's two different types of
wiring standards, and, in fact,

to make it a little easier to

00:28:29.770 --> 00:28:34.210

00:28:34.210 --> 00:28:37.850
All right, understand the dotted lines

535
00:28:37.850 --> 00:28:43.000
And this is how you would wire
a 568A type of connection.

536
00:28:43.000 --> 00:28:47.042
Notice that the green, we've got green
transmit for the pins one and two.

537
00:28:47.042 --> 00:28:49.321
And when I say pins one and two,

538
00:28:49.321 --> 00:28:54.324
that RJ45 jack connects the 8 pins

539
00:28:54.324 --> 00:28:59.412
Ethernet network adapter on the back
of your PC, as well as pins 3 and

540
00:28:59.412 --> 00:29:04.150
6 being your received pins and
you have your ground pins for 4,

541
00:29:04.150 --> 00:29:08.150
5, 7 and 8, but
notice that we also have 568B.

542
00:29:08.150 --> 00:29:12.130
And guys and gals out there,
make it easier on yourselves on the exam.

00:29:12.130 --> 00:29:16.150
Just realize that it's the orange and
green that are really just swapped, right?

544
00:29:16.150 --> 00:29:20.780
Now, notice, that the orange is for
your transmit pins,

545
00:29:20.780 --> 00:29:26.230
that's Tx, transmit pins, pins 1 and 2,
and pins 3 and 6 are now the green pins.

546
00:29:26.230 --> 00:29:28.820
All right, and again, 8P8C, or

547
00:29:28.820 --> 00:29:32.810
an RJ45 jack those are the pins
that make a connection into

548
00:29:32.810 --> 00:29:36.860
the Ethernet adaptor itself, or
the network adaptor on the machine.

549
00:29:36.860 --> 00:29:40.299
Now, it's interesting that the very first

Dan mentioned was coaxial,
and I was like, yeah, it's so

>> So, let's go in and double back to

Now, coaxial is used in

00:30:40.040 --> 00:30:44.540

British naval connectors the one that I've

yes, they are very good.

00:30:50.960 --> 00:30:54.909
You can see that it is a single

00:30:54.909 --> 00:30:58.120

00:30:58.120 --> 00:31:03.200
And what you end up having is you

00:31:03.200 --> 00:31:09.250

00:31:09.250 --> 00:31:12.490
And what's protecting
the central copper conductor

00:31:17.210 --> 00:31:19.140
So, that's the BNC.

579
00:31:19.140 --> 00:31:21.380
The other one they called out,

00:31:21.380 --> 00:31:25.390
That's the F connector,
that's another common type of connector.

This is our threaded type connector

00:31:29.270 --> 00:31:31.760
which actually a twist and

00:31:31.760 --> 00:31:35.340
In fact, I have an example of a B, or

What's different though if,

00:32:01.158 --> 00:32:04.027

This was what's known as an RG59.

00:32:19.458 --> 00:32:25.341
But you can see,

All right now,

One of the things that if you're

00:33:27.010 --> 00:33:30.680
And if I put a splitter on them right,

water going in one direction, half of

You can split coaxial communications, but

I've got a whole pie, if I cut in half,

00:33:51.890 --> 00:33:54.850
Because you can only split
a coaxial communication so

628
00:33:54.850 --> 00:33:58.560
much before it's gonna
start degrading the signal.

629
00:33:58.560 --> 00:33:59.900
In networking today, guys,

I wouldn't even worry about when it

But definitely know that for the most

A lot of different standards guys, I know.

A lot of different connections,

it's some of the first things we talk

Well it's just a lot of stuff.

And the answer is false.

00:23:01.530 --> 00:23:06.140
So if it's false, that means we're not

00:23:12.450 --> 00:23:18.580

within the octet across to the right.

00:23:18.580 --> 00:23:23.400
Okay, now notice I can subtract 2 from 2,
and that makes it true, right?

451
00:23:23.400 --> 00:23:24.560

452
00:23:24.560 --> 00:23:30.370
Now, notice that 2 from 2 leaves

453
00:23:30.370 --> 00:23:33.480
It's very, very easy that the process,

00:23:36.220 --> 00:23:41.900
And the answer is no, well, it's still

456
00:23:41.900 --> 00:23:46.765
That value is going to become

457
00:23:46.765 --> 00:23:51.060
So notice that we went through each

00:23:51.060 --> 00:23:55.680

459
00:23:55.680 --> 00:23:58.103

So 10 converted from the decimal
notation essentially

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the properties and characteristics of TCP/IP. Specific topics covered include: IPv4 vs. IPv6, Public vs. Private vs. APIPA, Static vs. Dynamic addressing, Client-side DNS settings, Client-side DHCP, Subnet Masks, CIDR, and Gateways.

communication coming up known as

520
00:28:59.080 --> 00:28:59.950

00:28:59.950 --> 00:29:05.180
Maybe not in this episode, but we'll
talk about a concept known as multicast.

00:29:05.180 --> 00:29:07.020
These are multicast addresses.

523
00:29:07.020 --> 00:29:10.040
Your computers use them kind

00:29:10.040 --> 00:29:14.980
which means my computer through a series

525
00:29:14.980 --> 00:29:18.670
processes, that are running on
the computer can assign it to themselves.

526
00:29:18.670 --> 00:29:22.790
They talk to a certain group of computers,
and then they don't use it anymore.

527
00:29:22.790 --> 00:29:24.230
And it will go through that process.

528
00:29:24.230 --> 00:29:27.180
So that's kind of automated
in the background for us.

529
00:29:27.180 --> 00:29:30.990
But I do want you to know for
the exam A, B and

00:29:30.990 --> 00:29:35.530
C that's a very,
very important for the exam.

00:29:37.060 --> 00:29:39.753
Remember what I said is that,

I told you that if you were going

Depending on how many computers
you need on the Internet,

535
00:29:51.830 --> 00:29:56.850
Well I want you to notice that there
is a series of default Subnet Masks.

00:29:56.850 --> 00:30:02.141
And I'll go ahead and mention them

537
00:30:02.141 --> 00:30:04.671

538
00:30:04.671 --> 00:30:09.450
So if you had a Class A address,
your Subnet Mask would be 255.0.0.0.

539
00:30:09.450 --> 00:30:15.979
Now remember what we said,
network portion versus the node portion.

540
00:30:15.979 --> 00:30:19.613
Well notice in the Subnet Mask where the
zeros are, we've kind of defined through

541
00:30:19.613 --> 00:30:22.310
that ending process that that
would be where your nodes are.

542
00:30:23.980 --> 00:30:27.014
That gives you 24 bits.

543
00:30:27.014 --> 00:30:30.230
24 individual bits for nodes.

544
00:30:30.230 --> 00:30:32.908
Remember everything's a power of two?

545
00:30:32.908 --> 00:30:38.350
Two to the power of 24,
that's a mind bogglingly large number.

546
00:30:38.350 --> 00:30:39.745
>> That's a lot of numbers.

547
00:30:39.745 --> 00:30:43.804
>> I think it's 16,777,216 possibilities,

we'll learn about that

549
00:30:48.180 --> 00:30:50.370
Notice that Class B.

So these are very large,
in fact Apple, Ford Dealership,

00:30:54.434 --> 00:30:59.739
big companies had these blocks, IP
addresses that would fall in this range.

552
00:30:59.739 --> 00:31:06.530
Class C, class C has a default
Subnet Mask of 255.255.0.0.

553
00:31:06.530 --> 00:31:09.808
Now, when we look at that,
notice that there are two octets.

554
00:31:09.808 --> 00:31:14.585
>> I think you're mistaken you're supposed

00:31:14.585 --> 00:31:16.519
[LAUGH]
>> I'm in class C you're confusing

00:31:16.519 --> 00:31:17.097

[LAUGH]
>> I'm on the side of the river.

I am, how about we get on

00:31:20.131 --> 00:31:21.637
>> Let's do that.

560
00:31:21.637 --> 00:31:23.787
>> Let's go to class B there.

561
00:31:23.787 --> 00:31:28.250
[LAUGH] If we look at

00:31:28.250 --> 00:31:33.678
So Class B if you will,
thank you Dan, is 255.255.0.0.

00:31:33.678 --> 00:31:37.470
Notice that we got one octet, binary one.

564
00:31:37.470 --> 00:31:41.030
So we go to Class B,
we've got two octets of binary ones.

565
00:31:41.030 --> 00:31:46.665
That leaves us 0's, two octet of 0's,
essentially a 16 bits of 0's,

566
00:31:46.665 --> 00:31:51.521
that's 16 bits for
your host to the power of 16 is 65,536

567
00:31:51.521 --> 00:31:55.960
technically 534 nodes,
that can be on a single network.

568
00:31:55.960 --> 00:32:02.100
Now, now that I'm in the right side here,

569
00:32:02.100 --> 00:32:04.972
Class C has the 255.

And you can probably see

00:32:06.342 --> 00:32:09.760
255, 255.0.

This is where they will have kinda small

574
00:32:17.760 --> 00:32:22.570

575

Those are default Subnet Masks.

576

I also want you to know that, and

577

Keep in mind A 255.0.0.0.

578

B it increases another octet of ones,

579
00:32:35.695 --> 00:32:39.039
Class C, increases it one more,
three octets of ones or

580
00:32:39.039 --> 00:32:41.730

581

And again when the Internet

This is where you would go

584

Essentially would dictate which one

586
00:33:05.203 --> 00:33:09.296

And these are the addressing

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the properties and characteristics of TCP/IP. Specific topics covered include: IPv4 vs. IPv6, Public vs. Private vs. APIPA, Static vs. Dynamic addressing, Client-side DNS settings, Client-side DHCP, Subnet Masks, CIDR, and Gateways.
episodes.title: TCP/IP Characteristics Part 3

Now, I kinda got this

But remember we have eight bits of ones.

Eight contiguous one bits.

And we write that out as,

00:03:31.091 --> 00:03:36.830
Well if you can just think about how

You can also think of it as

00:03:41.814 --> 00:03:43.245
And then we just kinda repeat the process.

This equals 8, equals 8, and

then obviously not talking down to

We have 0, 01 bits.

Now imagine if I could make this a little

And that's what we do when we have

For instance this IP address,

they'll do a slash, let's say in

00:04:22.300 --> 00:04:26.347
All right, you might even hear it

Well what's he talking about

Well, what he means by that

00:04:48.366 --> 00:04:55.880
192.168.10.24/24 I got an IP address.

Let me make that /5, wow that turned into-

And in fact, I'm just gonna go ahead and

192.168.10.5/24.

00:05:08.820 --> 00:05:11.699

00:05:14.560 --> 00:05:15.300
>> Yeah Dan, that's right.

Because they really didn't have

00:05:19.290 --> 00:05:21.800
They didn't think that the Internet

And so in the time, it wasn't really

cuz there weren't a lot of

So that's right, and as you can see,

I just want you to know for the exam that

If it's a slash 16, then what they mean is

255.255.0.0 right 16 one bits and

That's gonna be like your

00:05:58.858 --> 00:06:04.860
255.255.255.0 if you will, and just

121

And a lot easier really to denote how

122
00:06:10.180 --> 00:06:13.510
Now that being said, there's another

And the interesting thing is,

And because of the prevalence of so

In these classes of IP addresses,
what we're gonna go ahead and

a portion of each class that says,

00:06:46.450 --> 00:06:48.190
you know what,
you don't have to come to us.

00:06:48.190 --> 00:06:50.440
You don't have to come to us,
I know I can.

00:06:50.440 --> 00:06:55.410
And, allocate and we're gonna allocate

133
00:06:55.410 --> 00:06:56.560
But there's a catch, right?

00:06:56.560 --> 00:06:59.070
There's always a caveat.
Even though you don't have to come to us

00:06:59.070 --> 00:07:01.612

a con of that if you will,

00:07:01.612 --> 00:07:03.844
is you cannot use it

137
00:07:03.844 --> 00:07:07.753
in this case the only public network
we're talking about is the Internet.

138
00:07:07.753 --> 00:07:13.037
And what we mean by that, is the fact
