One of the last things I
wanna say is when we say

361
00:19:52.150 --> 00:19:55.585
that the pool of addresses is so large.

362
00:19:55.585 --> 00:19:59.041
We said 4.3 billion right,
it just makes it easier,

363
00:19:59.041 --> 00:20:02.245
again it's 4.294 billion and change.

364
00:20:02.245 --> 00:20:06.765
Some of the analogies that I've
heard in the past, from people that

365
00:20:06.765 --> 00:20:10.055
are well more brilliant with networking
than I am like network engineers.

366
00:20:10.055 --> 00:20:14.055
One said, if you were to take
an IPv4 address space and

367
00:20:14.055 --> 00:20:17.210
convert each one of the possibilities
into a grain of sand.

368
00:20:17.210 --> 00:20:20.660
That you would need a container that is
really the size of a very small moving

369
00:20:20.660 --> 00:20:24.080
truck to contain all that sand, and
you'd have a lot of space left over.

370
00:20:24.080 --> 00:20:28.860
If you were to take this same analogy and
apply it to the IPv6 address,

371
00:20:28.860 --> 00:20:33.010
space 2 to the power of 128,
then you would need a container that

372
00:20:33.010 --> 00:20:37.100
is 1.3 billion times the circumference
of our earth to contain all the sand.

373
00:20:37.100 --> 00:20:42.440
Again, the number is so mindbogglingly
large that I don't want to say never,

374
00:20:42.440 --> 00:20:47.470
but it's gonna be a very long time before
we ever see something like IPv7 or IPv8.

375
00:20:47.470 --> 00:20:50.730
Yeah cuz, well,
hopefully there will never be a need for

376
00:20:50.730 --> 00:20:53.650
it, that's a lot of numbers ladies and
gentlemen.

377
00:20:53.650 --> 00:20:57.220
And what's funny is we haven't
even gotten to how the heck do we

378
00:20:57.220 --> 00:20:59.720
get these numbers and
I'm looking at our clock there and

379
00:20:59.720 --> 00:21:02.400
I think we might be out of time for
that explanation Wesley.

380
00:21:02.400 --> 00:21:05.010
Yeah, most definitely we're definitely
going to have to go into another part of

381
00:21:05.010 --> 00:21:09.925
them because like Dan said, we haven't
talked about acquiring an IPv4 or

382
00:21:09.925 --> 00:21:10.985
IPv6 address.

383
00:21:10.985 --> 00:21:12.855
But I think we are going
to have to save that for

384
00:21:12.855 --> 00:21:14.725
a later time because I've
got a lot more to say.

385
00:21:14.725 --> 00:21:15.485
That's right.

386
00:21:15.485 --> 00:21:16.395
I look forward to it.

387
00:21:16.395 --> 00:21:18.055
Wes, it's been a fun conversation so far.

388
00:21:18.055 --> 00:21:21.725
Hopefully, you good folks out there
are learning a lot about networking and

389
00:21:21.725 --> 00:21:25.705
how these IP schemes and addresses
are working out inside your computers so

390
00:21:25.705 --> 00:21:27.385
we can have network communications.

391
00:21:27.385 --> 00:21:30.630
So join us back for,
what is this part four gonna be coming up?

392
00:21:30.630 --> 00:21:32.970
So, it's gonna be a lot of fun,
be there or be square.

393
00:21:32.970 --> 00:21:35.080
As for this episode,
it's time for us to sign off.

394
00:21:35.080 --> 00:21:37.610
For ITProTV I've been
your host Daniel Lowrie.

395
00:21:37.610 --> 00:21:38.320
And I'm We Bryan.

396
00:21:38.320 --> 00:21:40.043
And we'll see you next time.

397
00:21:40.043 --> 00:21:46.836
[MUSIC]

398
00:21:46.836 --> 00:21:49.842
Thank you for watching ITProTV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the properties and characteristics of TCP/IP. Specific topics covered include: IPv4 vs. IPv6, Public vs. Private vs. APIPA, Static vs. Dynamic addressing, Client-side DNS settings, Client-side DHCP, Subnet Masks, CIDR, and Gateways.
episodes.title: TCP/IP Characteristics Part 4
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:01.146
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.146 --> 00:00:02.720
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.720 --> 00:00:05.977
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:05.977 --> 00:00:08.340
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.340 --> 00:00:12.107
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.107 --> 00:00:13.393
>> All right, greetings, everyone.

7
00:00:13.393 --> 00:00:16.481
And welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.481 --> 00:00:18.222
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

9
00:00:18.222 --> 00:00:21.490
in today's episode we are going
forward with more in our A+ series.

10
00:00:21.490 --> 00:00:23.550
And of course,
joining us back in the studio,

11
00:00:23.550 --> 00:00:28.040
we're still working on
networking TCP/IP specifically.

12
00:00:28.040 --> 00:00:28.660
Our good friend, Mr.

13
00:00:28.660 --> 00:00:31.820
Wes Bryan, has continued to return and
teach us more on these things.

14
00:00:31.820 --> 00:00:33.564
Wes, welcome back, sir,
how is it going today?

15
00:00:33.564 --> 00:00:36.582
>> Man, it's going great,
we might be in this until,

16
00:00:36.582 --> 00:00:39.411
I don't know, IPv7 or
the new protocol stack.

17
00:00:39.411 --> 00:00:41.544
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] I remember back in those days.

18
00:00:41.544 --> 00:00:44.233
>> We only had 40 bazillion IP addresses.

19
00:00:44.233 --> 00:00:46.057
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's right,

20
00:00:46.057 --> 00:00:48.934
and as you guys can see, some of
the topics that we've been talking about,

21
00:00:48.934 --> 00:00:51.050
especially when you first
dive into them are complex.

22
00:00:51.050 --> 00:00:55.490
I remember when we got into things
like binary and IP addresses.

23
00:00:55.490 --> 00:00:56.640
My skin was crawling.

24
00:00:56.640 --> 00:00:58.780
I was like, my God,
what did I get myself into?

25
00:00:58.780 --> 00:01:03.770
But as you can see, hopefully you watched
the videos, the three that we've had

26
00:01:03.770 --> 00:01:09.270
before this, and definitely pause them and
go back over them, if you will.

27
00:01:09.270 --> 00:01:11.100
Remember that you can do this.

28
00:01:11.100 --> 00:01:13.280
There's a lot of different components and

29
00:01:13.280 --> 00:01:16.850
very important components when it
comes to even basic networking.

30
00:01:16.850 --> 00:01:19.628
And why we've been spending so
much time, like Dan said,

31
00:01:19.628 --> 00:01:21.690
through the past few episodes and myself.

32
00:01:21.690 --> 00:01:24.830
Networking really is
going to be a staple in

33
00:01:24.830 --> 00:01:28.507
your career even if you're just talking
about being a basic IT tech, right?

34
00:01:30.505 --> 00:01:33.460
I'll just recap what I said
in an earlier episode,

35
00:01:33.460 --> 00:01:38.410
that my instructor said that if
you're gonna be into computing and

36
00:01:38.410 --> 00:01:40.220
you don't really know
anything about networking,

37
00:01:40.220 --> 00:01:44.090
then a lot of times all you're going
to do is deliver the computer in a box.

38
00:01:44.090 --> 00:01:45.740
And you might not even set it up.

39
00:01:45.740 --> 00:01:48.910
Cuz even at the basic level, you'll have
to know how to make the connections to

40
00:01:48.910 --> 00:01:53.380
the network in order to give somebody
some kind of good computing experience.

41
00:01:53.380 --> 00:01:58.610
So moving on, we wanna talk, Dan,
we talked a lot about IP addresses.

42
00:01:58.610 --> 00:02:02.230
We've talked about the characteristics
of the IP address, the components.

43
00:02:02.230 --> 00:02:05.982
But one of the things that we
haven't really talked about is well,

44
00:02:05.982 --> 00:02:08.331
how do we get these IP addresses, right?

45
00:02:08.331 --> 00:02:13.239
And there are a few different methods
in which we can obtain an IP address.

46
00:02:13.239 --> 00:02:15.908
In fact, I'll tell you what.

47
00:02:15.908 --> 00:02:18.370
Let's go ahead and
we'll dive right into our diagram here.

48
00:02:18.370 --> 00:02:20.529
And we'll talk a little about
some of the concepts here.

49
00:02:20.529 --> 00:02:25.230
On the exam, they call out two
of the main methods when it

50
00:02:25.230 --> 00:02:28.140
comes to obtaining an IP address.

51
00:02:28.140 --> 00:02:30.480
Now we have what's known
as dynamic addressing and

52
00:02:30.480 --> 00:02:32.920
we have what's known as static addressing.

53
00:02:32.920 --> 00:02:36.163
I'm gonna add something to static
addressing because I think

54
00:02:36.163 --> 00:02:37.104
it helps people.

55
00:02:37.104 --> 00:02:39.975
If it's the first time they see it,
you think static, right?

56
00:02:39.975 --> 00:02:41.525
Well, what does static mean?

57
00:02:41.525 --> 00:02:45.149
I also want you to consider
it as manual addressing.

58
00:02:45.149 --> 00:02:48.600
Okay, so in your mind, even though it's
technically called static addressing,

59
00:02:48.600 --> 00:02:51.975
I want you to think of manual addressing
every time I say that word static, okay?

60
00:02:53.300 --> 00:02:56.010
Now we have what is known
as dynamic addressing.

61
00:02:56.010 --> 00:02:56.810
Let's go ahead and

62
00:02:56.810 --> 00:03:01.010
let's start there, and let's talk about
why we might want dynamic addressing.

63
00:03:01.010 --> 00:03:05.630
Well, in a home environment a lot
of times what you'll have is

64
00:03:05.630 --> 00:03:10.680
you'll have maybe a stationary desktop,
one that doesn't really move a lot.

65
00:03:10.680 --> 00:03:13.438
And you might have a lot of,
you might have laptops, right?

66
00:03:14.910 --> 00:03:16.910
You might have other devices
within your networks.

67
00:03:16.910 --> 00:03:18.250
Today we have the Internet of Things.

68
00:03:18.250 --> 00:03:21.965
We've got Rokus, we got streaming players,
we got Smart TVs.

69
00:03:21.965 --> 00:03:25.045
We've got mobile phones coming in and
off of your network.

70
00:03:25.045 --> 00:03:28.880
And we're really not talking about
connections to the cellular network.

71
00:03:28.880 --> 00:03:32.750
We're talking about literally
connecting to your wireless networks.

72
00:03:32.750 --> 00:03:34.760
And here's something to understand.

73
00:03:34.760 --> 00:03:39.350
When you talk about dynamic addressing,
you're talking about a service that allows

74
00:03:39.350 --> 00:03:42.220
your devices when they
connect to your networks,

75
00:03:42.220 --> 00:03:46.510
and again, not just home networks,
we're talking in corporate networks, too.

76
00:03:46.510 --> 00:03:51.400
To obtain the IP address by basically
communicating with the network

77
00:03:51.400 --> 00:03:55.420
over a series of services
and/or protocols.

78
00:03:55.420 --> 00:03:59.184
And what they can do, the devices,
when they connect to your network,

79
00:03:59.184 --> 00:04:02.760
they can essentially call out and
say, hey, out there somewhere,

80
00:04:02.760 --> 00:04:04.267
somewhere on this network,

81
00:04:04.267 --> 00:04:08.378
is there a device that can hand me
a certain amount of configuration, right?

82
00:04:08.378 --> 00:04:12.088
Now, when we talk about configuration, I
want you to understand it's not just about

83
00:04:12.088 --> 00:04:15.540
your IP address because, like we've
talked about in the first few parts here,

84
00:04:15.540 --> 00:04:18.245
remember we said an IP address
isn't the only thing you need.

85
00:04:18.245 --> 00:04:19.765
You also need a subnet mask, right?

86
00:04:19.765 --> 00:04:22.707
The subnet mask is what defines
what network you're on.

87
00:04:22.707 --> 00:04:26.420
The other thing you need is what's
known as a default gateway.

88
00:04:26.420 --> 00:04:27.490
And in fact, let's go ahead.

89
00:04:27.490 --> 00:04:31.530
I'm gonna switch over to my Windows
machine, guys and gals out there, and

90
00:04:31.530 --> 00:04:33.610
let me kind of show you what I mean.

91
00:04:33.610 --> 00:04:37.245
All right, now we're in our Network and
Sharing center inside of Windows.

92
00:04:37.245 --> 00:04:39.865
And if you can remember,
let's go ahead and recap how to get there.

93
00:04:39.865 --> 00:04:43.045
Now my head's always kind of covering
this one up because of the task bar on

94
00:04:43.045 --> 00:04:44.525
the lower right-hand side.

95
00:04:44.525 --> 00:04:46.050
We have this notification area.

96
00:04:46.050 --> 00:04:50.185
And remember we just right-click
on our network icon.

97
00:04:50.185 --> 00:04:52.795
And we can choose Network and
Sharing Center.

98
00:04:52.795 --> 00:04:57.425
Then we can go to our change adapter
settings, and in change adapter settings,

99
00:04:57.425 --> 00:04:59.440
you will see we have a path here.

100
00:04:59.440 --> 00:05:02.950
Control Panel is another way that you can
go, and we'll look at that more in our

101
00:05:02.950 --> 00:05:06.740
operating system episodes and
get you a little more familiar with that.

102
00:05:06.740 --> 00:05:08.410
Network Internet > Network Connections,
and

103
00:05:08.410 --> 00:05:10.530
inside of this we have
our network adapters.

104
00:05:10.530 --> 00:05:14.437
And remember, if we just right-click on
our network adapter and we choose status,

105
00:05:14.437 --> 00:05:17.643
then what we have are well,
some of the connection details, right?

106
00:05:17.643 --> 00:05:19.860
And we can see some very
basic information here.

107
00:05:19.860 --> 00:05:22.190
We can see that we have IPv4 connectivity,
so

108
00:05:22.190 --> 00:05:27.090
remember that tells me right away I've
got an IP address, I have a subnet mask.

109
00:05:27.090 --> 00:05:30.730
But I also wanna just briefly
mention another component here, and

110
00:05:30.730 --> 00:05:33.520
that is something known
as your default gateway.

111
00:05:33.520 --> 00:05:36.950
Your default gateway is essentially
what allows you to connect in context

112
00:05:36.950 --> 00:05:37.960
out to the Internet.

113
00:05:37.960 --> 00:05:39.350
Now you'll go on to Network+ and

114
00:05:39.350 --> 00:05:42.510
learn that your default gateway allows
you to connect to another remote network.

115
00:05:42.510 --> 00:05:45.000
Think of it as the doorway
out of your house, right?

116
00:05:45.000 --> 00:05:47.060
If I just brick off
the door into the house,

117
00:05:47.060 --> 00:05:51.080
you're gonna stay within the inside of
your house, and you're not gonna get out.

118
00:05:51.080 --> 00:05:53.044
We're not talking about
jumping out the window, right?

119
00:05:53.044 --> 00:05:56.649
[LAUGH] So imagine your default gateway is
the way that I can send information off of

120
00:05:56.649 --> 00:05:58.716
my home network and
get it out to the Internet or

121
00:05:58.716 --> 00:06:01.658
off of a corporate network and
get that out of the Internet, too.

122
00:06:01.658 --> 00:06:03.994
But notice there's a lot
of information here, right?

123
00:06:03.994 --> 00:06:08.145
There's a lot of configurations that are
going on and that's one of the things that

124
00:06:08.145 --> 00:06:11.064
the service that we're gonna
talk about allows you to do.

125
00:06:11.064 --> 00:06:14.937
It allows me to connect to a network,
call out to the network and say, hey,

126
00:06:14.937 --> 00:06:16.300
I need this information.

127
00:06:16.300 --> 00:06:18.140
I need this configuration.

128
00:06:18.140 --> 00:06:20.390
Now why would this service be beneficial?

129
00:06:20.390 --> 00:06:24.485
Well, there's a couple of reasons that we
kind of wanna keep in mind, all right?

130
00:06:24.485 --> 00:06:27.953
When you have multiple devices,
a multitude of devices that are maybe

131
00:06:27.953 --> 00:06:32.186
joining your network or maybe leaving your
network, and I quite literally mean maybe

132
00:06:32.186 --> 00:06:35.509
you got a tablet and a laptop and
you take it into your home network.

133
00:06:35.509 --> 00:06:37.457
And then you turn around and
you take it to work,

134
00:06:37.457 --> 00:06:40.149
maybe you take it on vacation with you,
maybe you travel with it.

135
00:06:41.350 --> 00:06:46.030
What you want is the ability to allow
that device, to configure that device to

136
00:06:46.030 --> 00:06:50.510
use that service to say, hey, just give
me that configuration information and

137
00:06:50.510 --> 00:06:53.280
I'll go ahead and take that
information and configure it for you.

138
00:06:53.280 --> 00:06:54.940
That's essentially what dynamic means,
right?

139
00:06:54.940 --> 00:06:57.700
Dynamic means let's let
the service do it for us and

140
00:06:57.700 --> 00:07:02.050
we don't have to sit there and enter
all of this information that we've seen

141
00:07:02.050 --> 00:07:04.740
in the TCP/IP properties
of the network adapter.

142
00:07:04.740 --> 00:07:06.062
It's easier to configure.

143
00:07:06.062 --> 00:07:08.520
It's also a little easier to reconfigure,
too, and

144
00:07:08.520 --> 00:07:10.430
we'll talk about that here in a second.

145
00:07:10.430 --> 00:07:14.145
It also gives you a consistent
configuration here because you guys and

146
00:07:14.145 --> 00:07:16.520
gals out there have seen
my typing abilities.

147
00:07:16.520 --> 00:07:20.340
You can see that sometimes I can't even
type an IP address to save my life.

148
00:07:20.340 --> 00:07:24.061
And that's where dynamic addressing
does come in handy, right?

149
00:07:24.061 --> 00:07:26.822
I could tell the service,
this is a series,

150
00:07:26.822 --> 00:07:31.301
this is a bank or a pool of IP addresses
that I want you to hand every device

151
00:07:31.301 --> 00:07:34.240
that calls out to the network and
asks for one.

152
00:07:34.240 --> 00:07:37.350
And then I walk away from it, and
I don't have to do anything after that.

153
00:07:37.350 --> 00:07:42.060
So I get a good consistency in all
of the configuration information.

154
00:07:42.060 --> 00:07:44.170
Now we'll talk about the service and

155
00:07:44.170 --> 00:07:48.680
the protocol down here in a bit that's
providing that dynamic addressing.

156
00:07:48.680 --> 00:07:49.970
Now here's another thing.

157
00:07:49.970 --> 00:07:51.386
We have static addressing.

158
00:07:51.386 --> 00:07:54.640
All right, now static or,
again, manual addressing.

159
00:07:54.640 --> 00:07:57.150
All right, well,
this is where I'm gonna go in.

160
00:07:57.150 --> 00:08:00.277
In fact,
I Kinda switch over to our machine here.

161
00:08:00.277 --> 00:08:03.360
This is where I'm gonna go into
the properties of the network adapter.

162
00:08:03.360 --> 00:08:06.200
And we're still in the same location,
but instead of choosing Details here,

163
00:08:06.200 --> 00:08:07.480
we go down to Properties.

164
00:08:07.480 --> 00:08:09.580
Now, I'm in a Windows specific device, so

165
00:08:09.580 --> 00:08:13.958
I want you to know that every
machine is gonna require these.

166
00:08:13.958 --> 00:08:16.536
If you wanna talk to the network,
you need an IP address,

167
00:08:16.536 --> 00:08:18.490
whether it's dynamic or static, right.

168
00:08:18.490 --> 00:08:21.940
Doesn't matter if you're in Windows,
it's nothing specific to Windows.

169
00:08:21.940 --> 00:08:25.810
Doesn't matter if you're on Unix system,
if you're on a Linux system, Mac system.

170
00:08:25.810 --> 00:08:28.160
If you're talking about a smart TV,

171
00:08:28.160 --> 00:08:31.260
a cell phone that connects
to your network or tablet.

172
00:08:31.260 --> 00:08:33.020
If you wanna communicate on the network,

173
00:08:33.020 --> 00:08:34.630
you need one of these
two addressing types.

174
00:08:34.630 --> 00:08:38.770
And this way, what I have to do is I
have to go with static addressing, and

175
00:08:38.770 --> 00:08:40.660
I have to configure this information.

176
00:08:40.660 --> 00:08:43.960
Which means, I also have to
remember what the configuration is.

177
00:08:43.960 --> 00:08:46.500
Notice that we have
the properties of TCP/IP here.

178
00:08:46.500 --> 00:08:48.033
Now, they spell it out fully, right?

179
00:08:48.033 --> 00:08:49.577
Internet Protocol Version 4.

180
00:08:49.577 --> 00:08:54.690
But if we go ahead and we select that,
we can choose Properties.

181
00:08:54.690 --> 00:08:56.900
Notice that we've got a couple of options.

182
00:08:56.900 --> 00:08:59.770
All right,
now obtain an IP address automatically.

183
00:08:59.770 --> 00:09:01.450
Let's be careful with
that term automatically,

184
00:09:01.450 --> 00:09:04.110
because we're gonna talk about another
concept that's a little bit more automatic

185
00:09:04.110 --> 00:09:04.680
than this, right?

186
00:09:04.680 --> 00:09:06.542
I still have to choose this option, right?

187

There are devices on your network that you

00:13:08.357 --> 00:13:09.370

00:13:09.370 --> 00:13:10.190

00:13:12.487 --> 00:13:16.544
you do want to have certain devices

00:13:16.544 --> 00:13:20.650
And you do have a series of devices

00:13:20.650 --> 00:13:21.670
Why?

00:13:21.670 --> 00:13:25.437
The difference is, with dynamic and

00:13:25.437 --> 00:13:28.785
And what that means is,
we usually have a listing in the device,

00:13:28.785 --> 00:13:30.774

00:13:30.774 --> 00:13:33.494
Think of it really as a file,

00:13:33.494 --> 00:13:35.093

00:13:35.093 --> 00:13:38.986
But the thing is, let's say you take your

00:13:38.986 --> 00:13:40.574

00:13:40.574 --> 00:13:43.861
All right, then you bring it back to your

00:13:46.157 --> 00:13:50.401
But then you bring it back to your home,

00:13:50.401 --> 00:13:52.790

00:13:52.790 --> 00:13:56.680
Well in that week, that list, there
could've been an IP address that it was

00:13:56.680 --> 00:13:59.140

device that connected to your network.

00:13:59.140 --> 00:14:01.130
That's why they call it dynamic,

00:14:01.130 --> 00:14:03.440
And that's really the dynamic part of it.

00:14:03.440 --> 00:14:08.520
Now you have devices on your network

00:14:08.520 --> 00:14:10.490

00:14:10.490 --> 00:14:11.661
That means-

00:14:11.661 --> 00:14:13.058
[LAUGH]
>> That's right, that's right,

00:14:13.058 --> 00:14:14.323
the sword in the stone, if you will.

00:14:14.323 --> 00:14:15.279
Don't move, and

00:14:15.279 --> 00:14:19.770
that's because, they might be expecting

00:14:19.770 --> 00:14:20.660
Let me give you an example.

00:14:20.660 --> 00:14:21.854

00:14:21.854 --> 00:14:24.482
And I know there are a lot

00:14:24.482 --> 00:14:26.708

00:14:26.708 --> 00:14:29.970

00:14:29.970 --> 00:14:33.150
But a lot of devices,

00:14:33.150 --> 00:14:35.610
Servers typically,
you don't want the IP address changing,

00:14:35.610 --> 00:14:38.055
cuz I want you to think of it

00:14:38.055 --> 00:14:40.264
Everyday, if you're getting snail mail,

00:14:40.264 --> 00:14:44.218

00:14:44.218 --> 00:14:49.220
All right, well,

00:14:49.220 --> 00:14:52.300
And right after you take the mail out of

00:14:52.300 --> 00:14:56.130

00:14:56.130 --> 00:14:59.290
Mail carrier says, well,
where's the mailbox?

00:14:59.290 --> 00:15:02.340
I can't deliver your mail,
I don't know where it's located.

311
00:15:02.340 --> 00:15:04.700
I don't know where
the location is to deliver it.

312
00:15:04.700 --> 00:15:08.320
And that's why there are certain devices
on your networks, like printers, right.

313
00:15:08.320 --> 00:15:10.341
Printers are a good example, right?

314
00:15:10.341 --> 00:15:12.906
I don't want,
if they're connected to the network,

315
00:15:12.906 --> 00:15:14.869
I don't want their IP address to change.

316
00:15:14.869 --> 00:15:18.995
So that all of our devices know

317
00:15:18.995 --> 00:15:22.735
And that’s where static assignment, like

318
00:15:22.735 --> 00:15:25.185
There are devices that we want
to know their IP address, and

00:15:25.185 --> 00:15:26.366
we don’t want it to change.

00:15:26.366 --> 00:15:29.174
>> Wes, going along with your
whole mailman situation or

00:15:29.174 --> 00:15:31.355
mail carrier situation.

00:15:31.355 --> 00:15:34.561
Think of it this way,
if you were moving once a week, right?

00:15:34.561 --> 00:15:37.219
You moved to a different house every week,
and

324
00:15:37.219 --> 00:15:39.820
the mailman's trying to deliver your mail.

00:15:39.820 --> 00:15:41.790
And it says Daniel Lowrie on it, right?

326
00:15:41.790 --> 00:15:46.240
If that's all it said, he's gonna be like,

327
00:15:46.240 --> 00:15:48.970
He was here last week, and
now apparently he's not there.

328
00:15:48.970 --> 00:15:49.648
Where did he go?

329
00:15:49.648 --> 00:15:52.350
If I'm a server,
I need to be in the same spot.

00:15:52.350 --> 00:15:54.661
I don't move, I need to be unchanging.

331
00:15:54.661 --> 00:15:57.730
So that mailman, all he has to do is say,

00:15:57.730 --> 00:15:58.990
That always goes here.

00:15:58.990 --> 00:16:01.708
That never goes anywhere else but here.

00:16:01.708 --> 00:16:03.228
Because if we start

00:16:03.228 --> 00:16:06.060
he's gonna be utterly confused and

336
00:16:06.060 --> 00:16:07.270
The service is gonna break down,

00:16:07.270 --> 00:16:09.500
the people that need that
service aren't gonna get it.

00:16:09.500 --> 00:16:13.110
Because it's been changing, so
that's why we need sometimes static, and

339
00:16:13.110 --> 00:16:14.154
sometimes dynamic.

00:16:14.154 --> 00:16:18.246
>> Absolutely, and that's a great classic

00:16:18.246 --> 00:16:19.990
we don't want things to change.

00:16:19.990 --> 00:16:21.610
>> [LAUGH] No,
we need them to stay the same.

00:16:21.610 --> 00:16:24.013

00:16:28.740 --> 00:16:33.080
So how do we get a dynamic IP address,

00:16:33.080 --> 00:16:34.920
We've been kinda, hinting at it.

00:16:34.920 --> 00:16:36.260
We've been talking about a service, so

00:16:36.260 --> 00:16:37.960

00:16:37.960 --> 00:16:40.430
In other episodes, we've talked

00:16:40.430 --> 00:16:46.250
one of those protocols, remember protocols
are the rules of communication for

00:16:46.250 --> 00:16:48.000
a specific type of service.

352
00:16:48.000 --> 00:16:50.290
That service is something known as DHCP.

353
00:16:50.290 --> 00:16:53.850
It's called
the Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

354
00:16:53.850 --> 00:16:57.270
It is responsible for

355
00:16:57.270 --> 00:17:01.930
Now I always try with A+
students because some people just

00:17:01.930 --> 00:17:05.760
focus on the fact that it
hands out IP addresses.

00:17:05.760 --> 00:17:08.250
I want you to break down the name.

00:17:08.250 --> 00:17:12.920
The acronym is one acronym that really
describes what it's doing, right?

359
00:17:12.920 --> 00:17:17.300
If I say serial ATA, we've hit you guys
with a lot of acronyms out there, that

360
00:17:17.300 --> 00:17:20.670
really doesn't tell me anything other than
maybe it tastes good with milk, right?

361
00:17:20.670 --> 00:17:24.540
Serial ATA makes no sense unless
you've studied it, right?

362
00:17:24.540 --> 00:17:30.183
If I say this is a dynamic, subject to
change, host configuration protocol,

363
00:17:30.183 --> 00:17:35.066
it means it's going to provide me

364
00:17:35.066 --> 00:17:38.422
And I want you to keep that in mind

00:17:38.422 --> 00:17:42.147

00:17:42.147 --> 00:17:45.934
the default gateway that you send
information out there to the internet or

00:17:45.934 --> 00:17:47.270
off of your network.

00:17:47.270 --> 00:17:50.710
As well as things like name servers

00:17:50.710 --> 00:17:52.744
We won't leave you hanging on that one,

370
00:17:52.744 --> 00:17:58.680
So it's called the Dynamic Host
Configuration Protocol, DHCP server.

371
00:17:58.680 --> 00:18:01.390
Now, when we talk about the DHCP server,

372
00:18:01.390 --> 00:18:06.630
I wanna just talk real briefly about the
process that your computer goes through.

373
00:18:06.630 --> 00:18:09.160
Remember we keep saying,
it calls out to the network.

00:18:09.160 --> 00:18:10.120
Well, what is it doing?

00:18:10.120 --> 00:18:14.190
Is it standing from the top of the roof

00:18:14.190 --> 00:18:15.460

377
00:18:15.460 --> 00:18:16.400
Is it doing a yodel?

00:18:16.400 --> 00:18:17.330
[LAUGH] No, not really.

379
00:18:17.330 --> 00:18:21.310
What's going on is there's
a four step process.

00:18:21.310 --> 00:18:25.000
And there is a little mnemonic I guess,
not really mnemonic,

381
00:18:25.000 --> 00:18:29.220
I guess it's more of just
an acronym that helps us remember.

382
00:18:29.220 --> 00:18:31.648
I know Dan, I know you've known this for
a very long time, and

00:18:31.648 --> 00:18:32.924
it's called DORA, all right?

384
00:18:32.924 --> 00:18:34.730
The DORA process, all right?

00:18:34.730 --> 00:18:39.770
Discover, Offer, Request,
Acknowledge, all right?

00:18:39.770 --> 00:18:42.360
Now Discover, what does that mean?

00:18:42.360 --> 00:18:45.948
All right, well Discover means I'm gonna
call out to the network and when I say I,

388
00:18:45.948 --> 00:18:48.600
I mean the network adapter
that's using this DHCP service.

389
00:18:48.600 --> 00:18:51.664
It's expecting to call out
to the network and say,

390
00:18:51.664 --> 00:18:53.930
anybody got an IP address out there?

391
00:18:53.930 --> 00:18:56.450
In fact, rather than just explain it,
let's kinda show you,

00:18:56.450 --> 00:18:58.600
I got a diagram here to kinda help out.

393
00:18:58.600 --> 00:19:03.180
So if my computer or any device that is
using that service, could be all kinds of

394
00:19:03.180 --> 00:19:06.760
devices that we could set for
Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol.

395
00:19:06.760 --> 00:19:10.390
What happens in the discovery process,
just think of it, ladies and gentlemen,

396
00:19:10.390 --> 00:19:14.240
real briefly it's just hey,
anybody out there got an IP address?

397
00:19:14.240 --> 00:19:15.730
I need one, right?

398
00:19:15.730 --> 00:19:19.800
And then the offer, an offer comes
back and this is the server.

399
00:19:19.800 --> 00:19:22.430
It doesn't necessarily have to
be a highly optimized computer,

400
00:19:22.430 --> 00:19:23.770
it could be your home access point.

401
00:19:23.770 --> 00:19:26.740
I've seen modems to this as well,
it's a service.

402
00:19:26.740 --> 00:19:32.500
And then the device that is providing
that service says, here's an IP address.

403
00:19:32.500 --> 00:19:35.690
I've got this IP,
consider it a configuration package.

404
00:19:35.690 --> 00:19:39.101
I've got this for you, it's gonna have
this IP address, subnet mask, and yeah,

405
00:19:39.101 --> 00:19:42.059
it could have your name server in there,
default gateway, all right?

406
00:19:42.059 --> 00:19:45.720
Then what happens is we make a request.

407
00:19:45.720 --> 00:19:50.400
Your device says back to that server yeah,
I'll take that information and

408
00:19:50.400 --> 00:19:52.430
then the last thing that
happens is an acknowledgment.

409
00:19:52.430 --> 00:19:58.330
Now I don't have any great cute little
explanation for the acknowledge but

410
00:19:58.330 --> 00:20:02.490
the acknowledge is the DHCP server saying,
kind of like if you rent a car.

411
00:20:02.490 --> 00:20:06.530
If you rent a car, you've got a certain
time that you can lease that car, right?

412
00:20:06.530 --> 00:20:07.690
And what do they do?

413
00:20:07.690 --> 00:20:10.370
They don't lease that car to somebody
else while you're in the middle of

414
00:20:10.370 --> 00:20:11.630
driving it, right?

415
00:20:11.630 --> 00:20:14.230
So what they do is they kind of
bookmark it in their notes or

416
00:20:14.230 --> 00:20:16.770
write in their database and they say,
yeah, you got that car for a week.

417
00:20:16.770 --> 00:20:18.417
Well, that's kind of
what happens with DHCP.

418
00:20:18.417 --> 00:20:20.945
It says, so
you're gonna take that IP address,

419
00:20:20.945 --> 00:20:24.823
I can't give that to anybody else, so I
acknowledge that you're gonna take it and

420
00:20:24.823 --> 00:20:27.145
I'm gonna mark it in the list as yours for
a week.

421
00:20:27.145 --> 00:20:29.508
Now if you don't communicate
back with me in a week,

422
00:20:29.508 --> 00:20:32.100
what's gonna happen is I'm
gonna take that IP address.

423
00:20:32.100 --> 00:20:34.390
I'm gonna put it back in the list and
sorry, no food for you,

424
00:20:34.390 --> 00:20:35.660
you don't get it, right?

425
00:20:35.660 --> 00:20:38.310
So that's the dynamic nature of it, right?

426
00:20:38.310 --> 00:20:42.370
And back to the analogy that we've kind
of been pushing here with the mailbox.

427
00:20:42.370 --> 00:20:45.210
You don't want your mailbox just
being thrown in the backyard, right?

428
00:20:45.210 --> 00:20:48.090
So you have services on your
network that sometimes,

429
00:20:48.090 --> 00:20:52.190
like the DHCP server, that you wanna
make that sure you can find them.

430
00:20:52.190 --> 00:20:53.560
Now, with a DHCP server,

431
00:20:53.560 --> 00:20:56.470
it is one that's kind of interesting
because you don't have an IP address.

432
00:20:56.470 --> 00:21:00.870
But typically the DHCP service is being
provided by things like your home router

433
00:21:00.870 --> 00:21:02.150
within your networks and

434
00:21:02.150 --> 00:21:05.130
we do have dedicated devices in
more corporate environments.

435
00:21:05.130 --> 00:21:12.300
So I want you to remember Discover, Offer,
Request, Acknowledge, the DORA process.

436
00:21:12.300 --> 00:21:17.520
It is the process that allows the DHCP
service to perform dynamic addressing.

437
00:21:17.520 --> 00:21:19.030
I also want you to remember,

438
00:21:19.030 --> 00:21:22.100
just like we've been talking about,
static addressing.

439
00:21:22.100 --> 00:21:25.370
Static addressing also has its purpose,
right?

440
00:21:25.370 --> 00:21:27.780
But let's get out of the home
network environment.

441
00:21:27.780 --> 00:21:30.190
Let's talk about a company
that Dan used to work for

442
00:21:30.190 --> 00:21:32.510
where there are thousands of devices.

443
00:21:32.510 --> 00:21:36.536
Hundreds and thousands if not thousands
and he can clarify if I'm wrong on that

444
00:21:36.536 --> 00:21:39.408
one, but definitely hundreds of devices,
all right?

445
00:21:39.408 --> 00:21:42.609
It is a very administrative
process to go through and

446
00:21:42.609 --> 00:21:47.269
manually configure an IP address,
manually configure a default gateway,

447
00:21:47.269 --> 00:21:51.003
[LAUGH] manually configure a subnet mask,
a name if you will.

448
00:21:51.003 --> 00:21:54.763
And tons of other things you can do
with DHCP, it's really flexible,

449
00:21:54.763 --> 00:21:56.239
500 to 1000 times.

450
00:21:56.239 --> 00:21:59.610
Let alone, like we've been talking
configuration errors, right?

451
00:21:59.610 --> 00:22:01.960
So in those aspects, those devices,

452
00:22:01.960 --> 00:22:06.510
you want to let a service provide
that functionality for you so

453
00:22:06.510 --> 00:22:10.655
you get consistency and
you get what Microsoft, in their mindset,

454
00:22:10.655 --> 00:22:15.510
calls a lot of times the least amount
of administrative effort, right?

455
00:22:15.510 --> 00:22:16.390
That's a good thing, right?

456
00:22:17.640 --> 00:22:19.810
Work smarter not harder, right?

457
00:22:19.810 --> 00:22:22.140
You've heard that before and
Dan, would you agree with that?

458
00:22:22.140 --> 00:22:24.480
I mean, in that company I know you,
that was a big company,

459
00:22:24.480 --> 00:22:26.840
I mean you had hundreds if not
thousands of computers, right?

460
00:22:26.840 --> 00:22:31.360
>> Yeah, we definitely did, not to
mention not just computers but printers,

461
00:22:31.360 --> 00:22:35.270
and switches and routers and things,
anything connected to the network

462
00:22:35.270 --> 00:22:38.180
requires an IP address so
they can communicate, right?

463
00:22:38.180 --> 00:22:42.620
And if I had to go through each
one of those things manually,

464
00:22:42.620 --> 00:22:45.850
specifically when it comes to things
like workstations, laptops, tablets,

465
00:22:45.850 --> 00:22:47.880
phones, that would be a nightmare.

466
00:22:47.880 --> 00:22:48.890
I would hate my life.

467
00:22:48.890 --> 00:22:51.260
I'd be looking for that,
where's that Truck Masters number?

468
00:22:51.260 --> 00:22:54.599
I'm gonna go drive a truck for
my life cuz this is a horrible job, right?

469
00:22:54.599 --> 00:22:55.864
It would not be fun.

470
00:22:55.864 --> 00:23:00.213
So we do use static IPs on things
like our servers and our gateways,

471
00:23:00.213 --> 00:23:01.774
things of that nature.

472
00:23:01.774 --> 00:23:05.338
But for the workstations, man,
let DHCP do the heavy lifting on that.

473
00:23:05.338 --> 00:23:07.171
You know it's gonna get
it right every time and

474
00:23:07.171 --> 00:23:09.270
if doesn't everybody's getting it wrong.

475
00:23:09.270 --> 00:23:11.590
You make your configuration
change at the server and

476
00:23:11.590 --> 00:23:15.860
then it goes out to everybody and then,
everyone's corrected from one change.

477
00:23:15.860 --> 00:23:20.560
So it's better to work, when it comes to
those types of things, with the DHCP.

478
00:23:20.560 --> 00:23:23.450
Let it do the heavy lifting and
then just leave the servers.

479
00:23:23.450 --> 00:23:27.320
That's going to be a much smaller pool of
resources that you have to administrate

480
00:23:27.320 --> 00:23:29.910
than working with a large
company with workstations.

481
00:23:29.910 --> 00:23:31.450
That would be be crazy.

482
00:23:31.450 --> 00:23:33.667
>> Yeah I guess if you're
getting paid hourly?

483
00:23:33.667 --> 00:23:38.270
I'm perfectly fine, I'll start today,
and if I'm done in a month,

484
00:23:38.270 --> 00:23:42.967
I'll be good but most people probably
won't get paid hourly that way.

485
00:23:42.967 --> 00:23:43.746
>> It'd be a never ending job.

486
00:23:43.746 --> 00:23:44.965
[LAUGH]
>> That's right, that's right.

487
00:23:44.965 --> 00:23:49.020
It's kind of like mowing a 500
acre property with a push mower.

488
00:23:49.020 --> 00:23:51.784
By the time you get done you
have to start over again.

489
00:23:51.784 --> 00:23:53.580
So very cyclic process.

490
00:23:53.580 --> 00:23:57.030
Now Dan, I'm kinda looking at the time and
I hate to say this but

491
00:23:57.030 --> 00:23:58.520
we might have to go into a part five.

492
00:23:58.520 --> 00:24:01.680
Because we wanna just, and we're gonna get
into a troubleshooting episode where we

493
00:24:01.680 --> 00:24:03.150
troubleshoot network connections.

494
00:24:03.150 --> 00:24:07.160
But I've kinda thrown around just
the graphical user interface and

495
00:24:07.160 --> 00:24:08.990
I wanna kinda go through
that a little bit more.

496
00:24:08.990 --> 00:24:12.910
Mention a couple of commands that you
could kinda see if you will the TCP/IP

497
00:24:12.910 --> 00:24:15.250
properties of your network adapters.

498
00:24:15.250 --> 00:24:19.460
And we still gotta talk about another
very important service out there

499
00:24:19.460 --> 00:24:23.800
that allows us to basically not
have to remember IP addresses, but

500
00:24:23.800 --> 00:24:26.620
still connect to devices over the network.

501
00:24:26.620 --> 00:24:27.990
Specifically, things like the internet.

502
00:24:27.990 --> 00:24:28.697
So, unfortunately,

503
00:24:28.697 --> 00:24:31.016
I think we're gonna have to leave them
with a little bit of a cliffhanger.

504
00:24:31.016 --> 00:24:33.460
>> Well,
sometimes that's the way it rolls.

505
00:24:33.460 --> 00:24:35.530
But, what are you gonna do, right?

506
00:24:35.530 --> 00:24:36.430
That's the way of life.

507
00:24:36.430 --> 00:24:37.520
Anyway, so thanks Wes.

508
00:24:37.520 --> 00:24:41.670
We look forward to seeing you and
that upcoming part five, but as for

509
00:24:41.670 --> 00:24:43.630
this episode, we're gonna go ahead and
shut it down.

510
00:24:43.630 --> 00:24:44.680
Thanks for watching everyone.

511
00:24:44.680 --> 00:24:45.975
We'll see you in that part five,
as well, hopefully.

512
00:24:45.975 --> 00:24:48.855
Signing off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

513
00:24:48.855 --> 00:24:49.715
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

514
00:24:49.715 --> 00:24:50.795
>> And we'll see you next time.

515
00:24:50.795 --> 00:24:58.319
[MUSIC]

516
00:24:58.319 --> 00:25:01.139
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain the properties and characteristics of TCP/IP. Specific topics covered include: IPv4 vs. IPv6, Public vs. Private vs. APIPA, Static vs. Dynamic addressing, Client-side DNS settings, Client-side DHCP, Subnet Masks, CIDR, and Gateways.
episodes.title: TCP/IP Characteristics Part 5
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:02.400
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:02.400 --> 00:00:06.774
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.774 --> 00:00:08.628
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.628 --> 00:00:12.265
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.265 --> 00:00:13.999
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

6
00:00:13.999 --> 00:00:16.197
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.197 --> 00:00:18.885
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

8
00:00:18.885 --> 00:00:20.243
it's more in our A+ series.

9
00:00:20.243 --> 00:00:22.237
Actually continuing on
with our conversation,

10
00:00:22.237 --> 00:00:24.384
hopefully even rounding it out today,
on TCP/IP.

11
00:00:24.384 --> 00:00:28.013
And, of course, joining us back in
the studio to actually lead us in said

12
00:00:28.013 --> 00:00:31.773
conversation, our good friend, Mr.
Wes Bryan, Wes, how's it going?

13
00:00:31.773 --> 00:00:34.340
>> Man, it's going great,
I'm hoping it is.

14
00:00:34.340 --> 00:00:38.712
It has definitely been a journey uphill,
we hit the top of the hill,

15
00:00:38.712 --> 00:00:41.258
and now hopefully we are over the hill.

16
00:00:41.258 --> 00:00:42.412
And by over the hill I mean Dan's old.

17
00:00:42.412 --> 00:00:44.996
>> [LAUGH]
>> Just kidding, that's right,

18
00:00:44.996 --> 00:00:47.615
we are on that downward slope,
and I don't mean in a bad way.

19
00:00:47.615 --> 00:00:50.919
So we do have some additional things
that we want to talk about, and

20
00:00:50.919 --> 00:00:54.880
I'm gonna throw one to Dan that I didn't
even let him know that we were gonna do.

21
00:00:54.880 --> 00:00:58.438
Because there is one last little address
type that I kinda wanna talk about,

22
00:00:58.438 --> 00:01:00.508
that we really haven't touched base with.

23
00:01:00.508 --> 00:01:03.300
And that is something known as
a media access control address.

24
00:01:03.300 --> 00:01:05.614
We've been talking a lot
about IP addresses, and

25
00:01:05.614 --> 00:01:08.049
talking about the properties
of a network adapter.

26
00:01:08.049 --> 00:01:11.669
But I just realized, quite literally
when they said, roll that footage,

27
00:01:11.669 --> 00:01:14.375
that we need to talk about
one last little address here.

28
00:01:14.375 --> 00:01:17.790
And let's go ahead and
talk about what a MAC address is.

29
00:01:17.790 --> 00:01:19.250
I don't really have a diagram,

30
00:01:19.250 --> 00:01:22.350
because really,
we're shooting from the hip on this one.

31
00:01:22.350 --> 00:01:25.030
So let me go ahead and
show you where you can find it,

32
00:01:25.030 --> 00:01:26.840
and then we'll talk about
it real briefly here.

33
00:01:26.840 --> 00:01:29.611
So I've got my Windows
machine here pulled up, and

34
00:01:29.611 --> 00:01:32.390
same thing that we've been in for
a while, right?

35
00:01:32.390 --> 00:01:36.965
We're in Network and Sharing Center,
like the last four episodes prior to this.

36
00:01:36.965 --> 00:01:42.008
And I'm gonna ahead and I'm gonna bring
up the properties of the network adapter,

37
00:01:42.008 --> 00:01:45.560
again, by choosing
Change Network Adapter Properties.

38
00:01:45.560 --> 00:01:51.090
I believe that's what it says, let's find
out again, yeah, change adapter settings.

39
00:01:51.090 --> 00:01:54.440
And we're gonna right click, and we're
gonna go ahead and choose Status, and

40
00:01:54.440 --> 00:01:56.250
then we're gonna choose Details again.

41
00:01:56.250 --> 00:01:58.773
And I do wanna just take a second here,
real briefly,

42
00:01:58.773 --> 00:02:02.432
cuz there is one address here that I
kind of think we have to, well, address.

43
00:02:02.432 --> 00:02:05.442
And that is something known
as the physical address, and

44
00:02:05.442 --> 00:02:08.780
it's also known as the MAC address,
that you might hear.

45
00:02:08.780 --> 00:02:11.768
That's called a media access
control address, right?

46
00:02:11.768 --> 00:02:15.318
IP addresses, they're what are known
as logical addresses, we can set and

47
00:02:15.318 --> 00:02:16.649
define these in software and

48
00:02:16.649 --> 00:02:20.269
it's the same concept that we've been
talking about in the prior episodes.

49
00:02:20.269 --> 00:02:24.574
But there is also an address that is
literally hard coded into the network

50
00:02:24.574 --> 00:02:28.610
adapter that identifies the adapter
at the physical level as well.

51
00:02:28.610 --> 00:02:32.165
And I mean as much so
as identifying the manufacturer,

52
00:02:32.165 --> 00:02:36.928
as well as uniquely identifying
the adapter within that manufacturer.

53
00:02:36.928 --> 00:02:39.420
And you can see right here,
we have that physical address, and

54
00:02:39.420 --> 00:02:43.570
like I said, this is what Microsoft calls
it, because it's physically burned in.

55
00:02:43.570 --> 00:02:48.330
You might hear it called it a BIA address,
or BIA, excuse me, burned in address.

56
00:02:48.330 --> 00:02:51.110
Now, you'll notice here that this address,
I'll click out of there so

57
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:52.770
you guys can see it right here.

58
00:02:52.770 --> 00:02:56.230
Notice that we have one,
two, three, four, five,

59
00:02:56.230 --> 00:02:59.720
six different individual blocks right?

60
00:02:59.720 --> 00:03:05.690
These individual blocks here are comprised
of two different components, right?

61
00:03:05.690 --> 00:03:10.217
These are actually six bytes or
48 bits individually, and

62
00:03:10.217 --> 00:03:15.274
the first three bytes that we have,
this is what's known as an OUI,

63
00:03:15.274 --> 00:03:18.489
an organizationally unique identifier.

64
00:03:18.489 --> 00:03:21.007
I want you to know OUI for
the exam, but let's

65
00:03:21.007 --> 00:03:25.590
make it a little bit more simplistic,
it doesn't have to be so highly technical.

66
00:03:25.590 --> 00:03:29.090
It's a vendor ID, essentially what
it does, you have a lot of different

67
00:03:29.090 --> 00:03:33.070
companies out there, I believe it's
Intel that makes this network adapter.

68
00:03:33.070 --> 00:03:35.712
And I'd almost be willing to bet that,
or you know what,

69
00:03:35.712 --> 00:03:37.373
I know who this network adapter is.

70
00:03:37.373 --> 00:03:41.340
This is actually a VM ware adapter,
so this is a VM ware OUI.

71
00:03:41.340 --> 00:03:45.775
And it just says, when I look at these
first three bytes of information expressed

72
00:03:45.775 --> 00:03:48.253
in a hexadecimal format,
it means that hey,

73
00:03:48.253 --> 00:03:50.944
we can identify that
that's the manufacturer.

74
00:03:50.944 --> 00:03:53.792
And they have to go to IANA or
ICANN, if you will,

75
00:03:53.792 --> 00:03:57.900
remember the Internet Assigned
Numbers Authority in the early days.

76
00:03:57.900 --> 00:04:01.440
Today, it's ICANN, Internet Corporation
for Assigned Names and Numbers.

77
00:04:01.440 --> 00:04:03.980
And if you're gonna manufacture
a network address that's gonna be

78
00:04:03.980 --> 00:04:07.090
put in a computer and connected to
a network, you have to register with them.

79
00:04:07.090 --> 00:04:09.689
And they give you an identifier,
that's the OUI.

80
00:04:09.689 --> 00:04:13.390
>> I did look it up on just a, you can
go to Google and type these things in.

81
00:04:13.390 --> 00:04:18.018
I just typed OUI, and
then those digits and letters, and

82
00:04:18.018 --> 00:04:20.533
it did come up with VMWare Inc.

83
00:04:20.533 --> 00:04:21.522
>> Okay, very good.

84
00:04:21.522 --> 00:04:23.336
>> If you're unsure, you're like,
who makes this board?

85
00:04:23.336 --> 00:04:26.849
You can just look at that MAC, if that's
all that you have maybe, or looking at

86
00:04:26.849 --> 00:04:30.980
a MAC address table inside of a switch or
something, you're like, what is that?

87
00:04:30.980 --> 00:04:34.642
You can verify that it is something that
your company has actually purchased, and

88
00:04:34.642 --> 00:04:36.834
not maybe a random
computer that's connected.

89
00:04:36.834 --> 00:04:39.816
>> And there's so many of them, I swear
I have every one of them in my brain.

90
00:04:39.816 --> 00:04:40.317
>> I'm sure you do.

91
00:04:40.317 --> 00:04:42.633
[LAUGH]
>> And that's because-

92
00:04:42.633 --> 00:04:43.748
>> No he don't.

93
00:04:43.748 --> 00:04:45.691
[LAUGH]
>> No, no, not even close.

94
00:04:45.691 --> 00:04:48.954
And that's just because we use
some components here quite a lot,

95
00:04:48.954 --> 00:04:50.450
so I've seen them a lot here.

96
00:04:50.450 --> 00:04:53.855
I certainly don't have them memorized,
and I do exactly what Dan did,

97
00:04:53.855 --> 00:04:55.916
I would do what's known as the OUI search.

98
00:04:55.916 --> 00:05:01.393
Now, if we go back to the screen here,
there's another set of three bytes,

99
00:05:01.393 --> 00:05:04.140
or the 24 bits here towards the end.

100
00:05:04.140 --> 00:05:09.400
Again, remember, expressed in hexadecimal
format, that are what are known as the,

101
00:05:09.400 --> 00:05:13.630
this is, this essentially
identifies the adapter itself.

102
00:05:13.630 --> 00:05:17.331
I've heard a crazy name
called the ULAN MAC, right.

103
00:05:17.331 --> 00:05:20.970
That's the Universal Local Area Network,
Media Access Control address.

104
00:05:20.970 --> 00:05:24.160
Don't even worry about that,
it identifies the network adapter.

105
00:05:24.160 --> 00:05:27.364
OUI, I definitely want you to know,
that could come up on the exam,

106
00:05:27.364 --> 00:05:28.445
know it as a vendor ID.

107
00:05:28.445 --> 00:05:32.272
But what happens is VMWare or
Intel out there, BroadCom,

108
00:05:32.272 --> 00:05:37.820
there's all kinds of manufacturers,
Gigabyte makes them and stuff as well.

109
00:05:37.820 --> 00:05:43.313
Believe it or not, Xerox,
because they have network based printers,

110
00:05:43.313 --> 00:05:45.519
they also have an OUI, IBM.

111
00:05:45.519 --> 00:05:49.250
If a company manufactures, let's say,
30,000 of these network adapters,

112
00:05:49.250 --> 00:05:52.650
you have to be able to uniquely identify
each one of those network adapters.

113
00:05:52.650 --> 00:05:57.140
And that's why this is unique
to the vendor itself, and

114
00:05:57.140 --> 00:06:00.220
that's because, remember,
we need unique identities for

115
00:06:00.220 --> 00:06:01.810
the devices that
are connected to the network.

When your computer does something known
as resolving names, all right, which

343
00:17:28.893 --> 00:17:33.666
is taking that name and mapping it to
an IP address, it goes through a process.

344
00:17:33.666 --> 00:17:37.702
Actually, backwards than what we read
unless you're talking about some of

345
00:17:37.702 --> 00:17:41.119
the Semitic languages or
Arabic where you do read right to left.

346
00:17:41.119 --> 00:17:43.164
So that might be a little bit different.

347
00:17:43.164 --> 00:17:47.585
But here in English, if you will,
we read left to right.

348
00:17:47.585 --> 00:17:50.773
Well, when names resolve,
they resolve from right to left.

349
00:17:50.773 --> 00:17:54.362
And believe it or not,
you have what's known,

350
00:17:54.362 --> 00:17:58.710
even though we don't type out,
www.microsoft.com.

351
00:17:58.710 --> 00:18:02.467
Technically, there is a dot just
after that last portion, right?

352
00:18:02.467 --> 00:18:04.894
And that dot is implied though.

353
00:18:04.894 --> 00:18:08.286
The web browsers, the client web
browser that's running on your machine,

354
00:18:08.286 --> 00:18:09.510
it knows that it's there.

355
00:18:09.510 --> 00:18:10.890
So what is that dot?

356
00:18:10.890 --> 00:18:14.680
Well, when we need to resolve a name,
you're gonna send a request to one of

357
00:18:14.680 --> 00:18:19.970
the configurations that we talked about to
a DHCP the IP address of that DNS server.

358
00:18:19.970 --> 00:18:25.370
And your computer is gonna say hey,
I need to know where www.microsoft.com is.

359
00:18:25.370 --> 00:18:30.135
I need to know where www.google.com is or
Facebook, all right?

360
00:18:30.135 --> 00:18:35.247
And the computer that you're
asking isn't in charge to put,

361
00:18:35.247 --> 00:18:38.730
technically, that location, right?

362
00:18:38.730 --> 00:18:40.650
Unless you're big company,
you might have your internal but

363
00:18:40.650 --> 00:18:41.660
it's not in charge of that.

364
00:18:41.660 --> 00:18:45.390
So it says yeah, I don't know where
this is, I can't really help you out.

365
00:18:45.390 --> 00:18:50.530
But I can start you along the path that
can help you find that information and

366
00:18:50.530 --> 00:18:52.320
it goes to that first part.

367
00:18:52.320 --> 00:18:56.020
It resolves the dot, it's called
a trailing dot that's at the end,

368
00:18:56.020 --> 00:18:57.490
that we don't even see.

369
00:18:57.490 --> 00:19:01.460
That dot is the highest part of the
hierarchy that is known as the domain name

370
00:19:01.460 --> 00:19:04.220
system and it's called root.

371
00:19:04.220 --> 00:19:09.160
We just call it root but
it's actually one of, I think,

372
00:19:09.160 --> 00:19:14.370
126 of them across the entire
globe that control DNS for us.

373
00:19:14.370 --> 00:19:15.720
And that's the first part.

374
00:19:15.720 --> 00:19:16.900
Now, what's root's job?

375
00:19:16.900 --> 00:19:20.390
Root's job isn't to tell you what an IP
address is, that's not what root does.

376
00:19:20.390 --> 00:19:25.360
That the root servers do is they say okay,
let me look at the portion

377
00:19:25.360 --> 00:19:30.520
just to the left of myself, the dot,
and let me see who are you asking for.

378
00:19:30.520 --> 00:19:34.061
All right, so we'll take the example
that it's microsoft.com,

379
00:19:34.061 --> 00:19:36.770
facebook.com, google.com.

380
00:19:36.770 --> 00:19:40.470
Well, I see you're looking for dot com.

381
00:19:40.470 --> 00:19:41.210
Guess what?

382
00:19:41.210 --> 00:19:42.820
I have in my listing,

383
00:19:42.820 --> 00:19:47.510
I'm in charge of what's known as
a top-level domain, TLD, all right?

384
00:19:47.510 --> 00:19:48.478
These are some of the examples.

385
00:19:48.478 --> 00:19:51.830
They're expanding every day just because
of the boom of the Internet, right?

386
00:19:51.830 --> 00:19:55.190
You might have heard of
the dot-com bubble if you will.

387
00:19:55.190 --> 00:19:59.500
It isn't the only one we have out there,
but this is a short list, right,

388
00:19:59.500 --> 00:20:01.870
cuz there's .mil for military if you will.

389
00:20:01.870 --> 00:20:05.556
But it says okay,
I see that you're looking for .com.

390
00:20:05.556 --> 00:20:07.498
I don't know who Microsoft is.

391
00:20:07.498 --> 00:20:12.230
So let me go ahead and I'll return you
the IP address of .com and that's we do.

392
00:20:12.230 --> 00:20:16.160
We move over to the next part of the
hierarchy known as the top-level domain

393
00:20:16.160 --> 00:20:18.608
and we go to one of the .com servers.

394
00:20:18.608 --> 00:20:25.280
And the .com server says you're
looking for www.microsoft.com?

395
00:20:25.280 --> 00:20:26.848
I don't know who WWW is.

396
00:20:26.848 --> 00:20:28.240
I don't have a clue.

397
00:20:28.240 --> 00:20:31.667
But I do know who Microsoft is,
because I .com and

398
00:20:31.667 --> 00:20:34.615
the authority over the Microsoft domain.

399
00:20:34.615 --> 00:20:36.603
At least,
publicly out there on the Internet,

400
00:20:36.603 --> 00:20:39.250
not necessarily Microsoft themselves.

401
00:20:39.250 --> 00:20:41.470
And it returns that answer
to your computer, right, or

402
00:20:41.470 --> 00:20:43.970
the computer that's asking on your behalf,
right?

403
00:20:43.970 --> 00:20:45.240
So what happens then?

404
00:20:45.240 --> 00:20:49.090
Well, we're gonna go to
Microsoft's DNS servers.

405
00:20:49.090 --> 00:20:53.305
And Microsoft is gonna say,
I know who WWW is.

406
00:20:53.305 --> 00:20:56.463
That's sitting behind this IP address
that you can't get to by the IP address

407
00:20:56.463 --> 00:20:57.410
[LAUGH] actually.

408
00:20:57.410 --> 00:20:59.306
That's sitting, I know where WWW is.

409
00:20:59.306 --> 00:21:05.440
In fact, here is the IP address for
WWW and that is a fully resolved name.

410
00:21:05.440 --> 00:21:06.861
In fact, it's fully revolving.

411
00:21:06.861 --> 00:21:09.060
Well, fully qualified domain name.

412
00:21:09.060 --> 00:21:12.477
That answer has returned from the DNS
server that you asked the question.

413
00:21:12.477 --> 00:21:16.715
The DNS server says here's your answer,
here's your IP address.

414
00:21:16.715 --> 00:21:19.687
And that gets us to these
different locations, right?

415
00:21:19.687 --> 00:21:22.926
These are what are known as second-level
domains and I've some examples here.

416
00:21:22.926 --> 00:21:28.280
And these are actually valid examples of
different, what are known as, SLDs, right?

417
00:21:28.280 --> 00:21:30.245
Top-level domains,
you have these right here.

418
00:21:30.245 --> 00:21:34.950
These are the .com, .org,
.tv, .net, .mil if you will.

419
00:21:34.950 --> 00:21:39.700
As well as second-level domains,
like .Microsoft, .Google, .Facebook.

420
00:21:39.700 --> 00:21:43.787
If you're in education, right, edu,
you're talking about Harvard, MIT,

421
00:21:43.787 --> 00:21:44.826
Berkeley, right?

422
00:21:44.826 --> 00:21:47.510
Or WordPress, Wikipedia, Mozilla.

423
00:21:47.510 --> 00:21:48.925
These are second-level domains.

424
00:21:48.925 --> 00:21:54.170
And they control the servers that host the
websites that you're trying to connect to.

425
00:21:54.170 --> 00:21:58.730
And more importantly, they are the
authority over the computer, hostname,

426
00:21:58.730 --> 00:22:00.440
that you're trying to resolve.

427
00:22:00.440 --> 00:22:05.570
So that's the process,
the process of DNS, Domain Name System.

428
00:22:05.570 --> 00:22:08.285
These DNS servers hold records.

429
00:22:08.285 --> 00:22:10.275
Just files is really all they are.

430
00:22:10.275 --> 00:22:14.083
And kinda like Daniel made the analogy
earlier of a phone book, right?

431
00:22:14.083 --> 00:22:17.712
Or not a phone book but a listing within
your phone that takes that name and

432
00:22:17.712 --> 00:22:19.947
it maps it to that phone number, right?

433
00:22:19.947 --> 00:22:23.047
Your phone stores a little file
in there that has those mappings.

434
00:22:23.047 --> 00:22:24.622
Well, DNS servers do the same thing.

435
00:22:24.622 --> 00:22:27.187
They got a little file in there,
it's just a little listing.

436
00:22:27.187 --> 00:22:31.917
And that DNS server is gonna say yeah, I
know where WWW is, that's in my database.

437
00:22:31.917 --> 00:22:35.283
Here's the IP address,
you can find it, go look here.

438
00:22:35.283 --> 00:22:38.053
And we work through this
process every time.

439
00:22:38.053 --> 00:22:40.326
Now, I know we got a few more minutes,
we're kind of running up on time here.

440
00:22:40.326 --> 00:22:42.998
But there's one last thing I wanna
talk a little bit about DNS on,

441
00:22:42.998 --> 00:22:45.065
because that's something
known as DNS caching.

442
00:22:45.065 --> 00:22:47.313
All right, when we talk about DNS caching,

443
00:22:47.313 --> 00:22:51.303
what we're talking about is
holding a piece of information

444
00:22:51.303 --> 00:22:55.050
to speed up the process next time

445
00:22:55.050 --> 00:22:58.689
Have you ever had somebody ask you
a question and then a few minutes later or

00:22:58.689 --> 00:23:01.154

they ask you the same question, and

00:23:01.154 --> 00:23:04.995
then they ask you the same question, and

00:23:04.995 --> 00:23:07.395
And how long does it take you before

449
00:23:07.395 --> 00:23:09.710
>> [LAUGH]
>> I don't wanna tell you anymore,

450
00:23:09.710 --> 00:23:11.000
write it down, all right?

451
00:23:11.000 --> 00:23:13.180
Well, that's kinda what DNS caching does.

452
00:23:13.180 --> 00:23:16.210
Every one of your systems
have a DNS cache.

453
00:23:16.210 --> 00:23:19.070
In fact, I could kinda show you
that here on our Windows machine.

454
00:23:19.070 --> 00:23:21.890
Now, guys, we're gonna talk a little bit
more about some of these commands coming

00:23:21.890 --> 00:23:26.820
up in troubleshooting but
we kinda wanna just show you briefly here.

456
00:23:26.820 --> 00:23:31.730
So if I wanna see what is the local cache,
all right, have I looked?

457
00:23:31.730 --> 00:23:33.990
And you guys can see we looked for
Microsoft earlier.

458
00:23:33.990 --> 00:23:36.160
Have I looked for names out there already?

459
00:23:36.160 --> 00:23:39.000
Because if I have,
I could have store them locally and

460
00:23:39.000 --> 00:23:42.100
I don't have to ask that question
again on the DNS service, right?

461
00:23:42.100 --> 00:23:44.171
I can just say I wrote that answer down.

462
00:23:44.171 --> 00:23:45.340
I don't have to ask anybody.

463
00:23:45.340 --> 00:23:47.910
I don't have to annoy the DNS server,
right?

464
00:23:47.910 --> 00:23:49.590
So let's go ahead and show you.

465
00:23:49.590 --> 00:23:53.290
ipconfig, inside of Windows,
that's Internet Protocol Configuration.

466
00:23:53.290 --> 00:23:57.020
It shows you the TCP/IP properties of
