00:23:57.020 --> 00:23:59.241
So when you run, in fact,
let me go ahead and clear the screen.

468
00:23:59.241 --> 00:24:02.341
Get this up to the top, make it
a little easier for you guys to see.

469
00:24:02.341 --> 00:24:06.225
You can run ipconfig/,
all one word displayDNS,

470
00:24:06.225 --> 00:24:09.483
and when you run that, here's the cache.

471
00:24:09.483 --> 00:24:14.690
This is the local cache, if you will,
of the questions you've asked.

472
00:24:14.690 --> 00:24:17.940
Now, I haven't use the web browser on
this machine, so you might say, well,

473
00:24:17.940 --> 00:24:19.080
wait a second, Wes.

474
00:24:19.080 --> 00:24:22.520
If you haven't browsed the web on there,
why are there records there?

475
00:24:22.520 --> 00:24:26.820
Well, web browsers aren't
the only thing that use DNS.

476
00:24:26.820 --> 00:24:30.450
In this case, what's going on is this
machine is running a Windows update.

477
00:24:30.450 --> 00:24:31.710
Well guess what?

478
00:24:31.710 --> 00:24:34.400
It's gonna use a name, and
it doesn't know the IP address, so

479
00:24:34.400 --> 00:24:35.590
guess what my computer does?

480
00:24:35.590 --> 00:24:39.238
It checks with a DNS server and it says,
hey, Windows, or hey, Microsoft,

481
00:24:39.238 --> 00:24:40.938
I need to find the updates, right?

482
00:24:40.938 --> 00:24:44.814
And the updates actually take you out to
another company that holds that closer to

483
00:24:44.814 --> 00:24:48.080
you so it's more efficient,
and it resolves those names.

484
00:24:48.080 --> 00:24:49.300
All right, they're called records.

485
00:24:49.300 --> 00:24:53.170
Basically taking a name and mapping it to
an IP address, is stored in a database,

486
00:24:53.170 --> 00:24:55.810
that database is an individual record,
right?

487
00:24:55.810 --> 00:24:57.460
And then we store it locally.

488
00:24:57.460 --> 00:25:00.563
So the next time in this case,
Windows needs to run its local updates,

489
00:25:00.563 --> 00:25:02.626
it doesn't have to go
back to the DNS process.

490
00:25:02.626 --> 00:25:04.920
It can say,
I already got that information.

491
00:25:04.920 --> 00:25:08.290
Let me go ahead, I've got the mapping,
I can talk right to the IP address,

492
00:25:08.290 --> 00:25:10.390
if you will, of that machine.

493
00:25:10.390 --> 00:25:13.040
In fact, we can kinda give
you an example here, too.

494
00:25:13.040 --> 00:25:17.113
So this is probably, the akadns.

495
00:25:17.113 --> 00:25:22.265
Well, that's easy, I think it's Akamai,
they're a content distribution network.

496
00:25:22.265 --> 00:25:25.794
They actually store your updates local, so
you don't have to go all the way across

497
00:25:25.794 --> 00:25:28.470
the internet over to Redmond and
then pull your updates back.

498
00:25:28.470 --> 00:25:29.839
It's closer to you, all right?

499
00:25:29.839 --> 00:25:33.889
So that's an example of basically
where you can see the local

500
00:25:33.889 --> 00:25:36.730
resolver cache as it's called.

501
00:25:36.730 --> 00:25:41.350
In DNS in general, this is what
you're gonna go through as well.

502
00:25:41.350 --> 00:25:45.360
Dan, I'm gonna pull a Columbo here on you,
just cuz there's just one more thing.

503
00:25:45.360 --> 00:25:46.309
And again, I told you that-
>> Just one more thing.

504
00:25:46.309 --> 00:25:48.360
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] Just one more thing.

505
00:25:48.360 --> 00:25:51.850
There is one more thing that I have
to talk about that I didn't mention.

506
00:25:51.850 --> 00:25:53.840
I mentioned a DHCP server, and

507
00:25:53.840 --> 00:25:57.820
right, I said that we get an IP
address through a DHCP server.

508
00:25:57.820 --> 00:26:01.233
Well what happens if
the DHCP server fails?

509
00:26:01.233 --> 00:26:04.310
Well you don't get an IP address, right?

510
00:26:04.310 --> 00:26:08.416
Well Windows has built into it
a technology that still allows you to

511
00:26:08.416 --> 00:26:12.524
maintain some kind of relative
communication with the network and

512
00:26:12.524 --> 00:26:15.626
that's one last thing that
we want to talk about.

513
00:26:15.626 --> 00:26:20.347
It really goes in line when you talk
about public and private IP addresses and

514
00:26:20.347 --> 00:26:22.579
that's something known as APIPA.

515
00:26:22.579 --> 00:26:26.909
APIPA stands for
the Automatic Private IP Address, and

516
00:26:26.909 --> 00:26:32.100
I've also heard it called
Automatic Private IP Addressing.

517
00:26:32.100 --> 00:26:37.090
And this is a situation where let's
say my rental car, all right,

518
00:26:37.090 --> 00:26:38.960
the lease is expired.

519
00:26:38.960 --> 00:26:41.280
I'm standing on the side of the road and
I need a rental car, right?

520
00:26:41.280 --> 00:26:43.790
But I don't have access
to a rental car agency.

521
00:26:43.790 --> 00:26:44.793
So what do I do?

522
00:26:44.793 --> 00:26:46.247
Let's say I call a cab, right?

523
00:26:46.247 --> 00:26:47.680
[LAUGH]
>> Wes steals a car.

524
00:26:47.680 --> 00:26:49.287
>> That's right.

525
00:26:49.287 --> 00:26:50.736
>> Throws a brick through a windshield.

526
00:26:50.736 --> 00:26:54.657
>> I was gonna say yeah, then we've
got some GTA going on right here.

527
00:26:54.657 --> 00:26:55.950
>> Exactly.

528
00:26:55.950 --> 00:26:58.450
>> Here comes Wes if he can get away.

529
00:26:58.450 --> 00:27:03.430
So they do have a technology that's kind
of like, it isn't really a one size fits

530
00:27:03.430 --> 00:27:07.551
all type solution, it's kind of
like a fall back on, if you will.

531
00:27:07.551 --> 00:27:11.638
And what we mean by Automatic Private IP
Addressing, if my computer calls out to

532
00:27:11.638 --> 00:27:15.729
the network and it says, hey, I need
an IP address out there, anybody got one?

533
00:27:15.729 --> 00:27:16.964
And it hears crickets.

534
00:27:16.964 --> 00:27:21.236
Well, it can actually automatically assign
its own IP address and that's why I said

535
00:27:21.236 --> 00:27:24.803
it, when we started talking about dynamic,
be very careful on that.

536
00:27:24.803 --> 00:27:27.295
Dynamic just means it can change,
it doesn't mean it's automatic,

537
00:27:27.295 --> 00:27:29.375
there's a certain level of
configuration you have to do.

538
00:27:29.375 --> 00:27:32.810
I don't have to do anything for
an IP address here, right?

539
00:27:32.810 --> 00:27:35.570
Automatic Private IP Addressing
is an example

540
00:27:35.570 --> 00:27:38.240
of what they call a zero
configuration technology.

541
00:27:38.240 --> 00:27:40.550
Kinda like plug and
play is, that zero config.

542
00:27:40.550 --> 00:27:43.410
I plug it in and it goes to work.

543
00:27:43.410 --> 00:27:44.910
This does that too.

544
00:27:44.910 --> 00:27:47.730
I want you to know that it
has a specific format though

545
00:27:47.730 --> 00:27:49.720
because not only knowing the concept,

546
00:27:49.720 --> 00:27:53.350
they could ask you on the exam,
what type of address is this, all right?

547
00:27:53.350 --> 00:27:55.950
And if you look here at
the little diagram, I have,

548
00:27:55.950 --> 00:27:59.710
notice that there's a 169.254,
why did I stop there?

549
00:27:59.710 --> 00:28:01.870
>> That's a dead give away
that that's an APIPA address.

550
00:28:01.870 --> 00:28:06.680
>> That's right, absolutely, because those
are the only two octets we care about.

551
00:28:06.680 --> 00:28:10.649
There's actually a wider range
here of APIPA addresses,

552
00:28:10.649 --> 00:28:13.403
but on the exam, in the RFC, request for

553
00:28:13.403 --> 00:28:17.786
comment specification,
they say it has to be 169.254.

554
00:28:17.786 --> 00:28:22.346
Your computer, zero config,
will automatically just generate,

555
00:28:22.346 --> 00:28:25.070
if you will, the last two octets.

556
00:28:25.070 --> 00:28:28.541
If there's ever a conflict, the other
computer that has that same APIPA address,

557
00:28:28.541 --> 00:28:33.200
it'll call out to the network and say,
no, no, no, no, no, no, no, that's mine.

558
00:28:33.200 --> 00:28:35.290
And your computer's saying, oops, my bad.

559
00:28:35.290 --> 00:28:38.264
Let me regenerate the last two octets,
until it comes up with a unique one.

560
00:28:38.264 --> 00:28:43.300
A lot of the times you have, gosh,
16 bits, you have 65,535 possibilities.

561
00:28:43.300 --> 00:28:44.190
It can happen.

562
00:28:44.190 --> 00:28:46.020
You never say never in computing.

563
00:28:46.020 --> 00:28:50.470
But it really is kinda highly unlikely,
especially in smaller networks.

564
00:28:50.470 --> 00:28:52.330
Now that's an IPv4 address.

565
00:28:52.330 --> 00:28:54.776
There is one last one that
you could also get, and

566
00:28:54.776 --> 00:28:56.693
that is something I can show you here.

567
00:28:56.693 --> 00:29:00.970
Going down to our
Internet Protocol Configuration Utility,

568
00:29:00.970 --> 00:29:05.492
if I type cmd, Charlie Mike Delta,
in our search, run line, and

569
00:29:05.492 --> 00:29:08.223
bring back up the Command Prompt here.

570
00:29:08.223 --> 00:29:12.723
One of the things you'll notice
here is that you also have,

571
00:29:12.723 --> 00:29:17.493
if I do an ipconfig /all, and
I look at all of the information,

572
00:29:17.493 --> 00:29:20.110
let's see if I can find it in here.

573
00:29:20.110 --> 00:29:22.600
Yes, yes,
I wanted to show you guys this last one.

574
00:29:23.790 --> 00:29:26.668
IPv6 has an automatic type of address.

575
00:29:26.668 --> 00:29:29.930
Remember I told you you can
use multiple IP addresses?

576
00:29:29.930 --> 00:29:35.277
And that is what's known as the link-local
address and it starts out with a prefix

577
00:29:35.277 --> 00:29:41.263
of fe80, just like APIPA has a 169.254,
I don't care what the last part of it is.

578
00:29:41.263 --> 00:29:43.201
Know that on the exam as well,

579
00:29:43.201 --> 00:29:46.858
that an fe80 is kinda like
an APIPA address for IPv6.

580
00:29:46.858 --> 00:29:50.858
But your computer can generate it and
then it can communicate on an IPv6 based

581
00:29:50.858 --> 00:29:53.330
network without you
doing any configuration.

582
00:29:53.330 --> 00:29:56.062
It's another one of those
zero config technologies.

583
00:29:56.062 --> 00:29:59.722
So a couple of last little stray shoelaces
we wanted to tie off, Dan, just so we

584
00:29:59.722 --> 00:30:03.667
are thorough on our objectives and you'll
be a little bit more prepared on the exam.

585
00:30:03.667 --> 00:30:06.238
Not only for the objectives,
these are important concepts,

586
00:30:06.238 --> 00:30:08.464
especially when it comes
into troubleshooting, but

587
00:30:08.464 --> 00:30:10.730
we're going to save that one for
another episode.

588
00:30:10.730 --> 00:30:13.750
>> Well there's definitely a lot
of going-ons when it comes to DNS.

589
00:30:13.750 --> 00:30:18.595
It's doing a lot of stuff for us, but it's
an extreme help to us as humans because of

590
00:30:18.595 --> 00:30:23.305
that whole, I don't remember IP addresses
very well, but I do remember names.

591
00:30:23.305 --> 00:30:24.953
They stick in my mind for
some strange reason.

592
00:30:24.953 --> 00:30:28.335
So that kinda does that translation for
us and it's

593
00:30:28.335 --> 00:30:32.495
a good thing it's around otherwise really
networking would not be where it's at.

594
00:30:32.495 --> 00:30:36.195
And I did just for
Wes's good pleasure here,

595
00:30:36.195 --> 00:30:39.905
I did try the Facebook nslookup trick and
it worked fine.

596
00:30:39.905 --> 00:30:42.650
So if you guys want to try that
yourselves, just do an nslookup for

597
00:30:42.650 --> 00:30:44.280
Facebook, take that IP address,

598
00:30:44.280 --> 00:30:46.790
slap it in your browser and
it will take you to Facebook.

599
00:30:46.790 --> 00:30:47.810
So, very cool stuff.

600
00:30:47.810 --> 00:30:50.373
Wes, thanks for joining us today and
teaching us about DNS.

601
00:30:50.373 --> 00:30:51.030
>> Absolutely.

602
00:30:51.030 --> 00:30:55.019
>> It's a very lengthy topic that we
barely even scratched the surface on, but

603
00:30:55.019 --> 00:30:57.050
we are definitely done with TCP/IP.

604
00:30:57.050 --> 00:30:59.450
We appreciate your walk through on that.

605
00:30:59.450 --> 00:31:02.486
Thank you all for watching,
hopefully you've enjoyed this episode and

606
00:31:02.486 --> 00:31:05.534
you got a lot out of our little series
as well as our A+ series in general.

607
00:31:05.534 --> 00:31:06.768
But it's time for us to sign off.

608
00:31:06.768 --> 00:31:09.940
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

609
00:31:09.940 --> 00:31:11.923
>> And I'm Wes IP Madness Bryan.

610
00:31:11.923 --> 00:31:14.257
>> [LAUGH] And we'll see you next time.

611
00:31:14.257 --> 00:31:20.161
[MUSIC]

612
00:31:20.161 --> 00:31:22.240
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain common TCP and UDP ports, protocols, and their purpose. Specific ports and protocols covered includes: FTP, SSH, TELNET, SMTP, DNS, HTTP(S), POP3, IMAP, RDP, NetBIOS, SMB/CIFS, SLP, AFP, DHCP, and LDAP.
episodes.title: Common Ports and Protocols
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.166 --> 00:00:01.540
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.540 --> 00:00:04.526
I'm your host Don-
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.526 --> 00:00:08.192
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.192 --> 00:00:10.880
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.880 --> 00:00:13.296
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

6
00:00:13.296 --> 00:00:16.362
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.362 --> 00:00:17.658
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:17.658 --> 00:00:21.550
And in today's episode, we are continuing
on with more of our A+ series.

9
00:00:21.550 --> 00:00:24.718
And joining us yet
again in the studio, you know him.

10
00:00:24.718 --> 00:00:27.280
The man, the myth, the legend,
that is Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:27.280 --> 00:00:28.158
Wes, we're glad to have you.

12
00:00:28.158 --> 00:00:29.039
How's it going today?

13
00:00:29.039 --> 00:00:29.854
>> Man, it's great to be here.

14
00:00:29.854 --> 00:00:30.878
Thanks for lifting the bar.

15
00:00:30.878 --> 00:00:33.152
Hope that you'll stick around and help
me hold that thing up, that's for sure.

16
00:00:33.152 --> 00:00:33.870
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's right,

17
00:00:33.870 --> 00:00:36.494
we're gonna be looking at more of
our network communications and

18
00:00:36.494 --> 00:00:37.650
networking technologies.

19
00:00:37.650 --> 00:00:41.927
And specifically what we're gonna be
talking about in this episode are ports

20
00:00:41.927 --> 00:00:43.518
and protocols, all right?

21
00:00:43.518 --> 00:00:46.713
And when I say ports,
I'm not talking about starboard versus,

22
00:00:46.713 --> 00:00:47.968
what's the other one?

23
00:00:47.968 --> 00:00:49.369
>> Yeah, port-
>> Yeah, portside.

24
00:00:49.369 --> 00:00:52.870
>> I guess it shows you that I've
never really been on a boat, right?

25
00:00:52.870 --> 00:00:53.710
>> You old sailor, you.
[LAUGH]

26
00:00:53.710 --> 00:00:55.690
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

27
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:58.511
So we're gonnatalk about something that
apparently, hopefully I do know about,

28
00:00:58.511 --> 00:00:59.046
unlike boats.

29
00:00:59.046 --> 00:01:02.890
So we're gonna talk about ports and
protocols, so let's go ahead.

30
00:01:02.890 --> 00:01:04.979
First of all, let's talk about
what a protocol is, right?

31
00:01:04.979 --> 00:01:08.295
When we talk about a protocol,
we have network communications.

32
00:01:08.295 --> 00:01:10.336
And when it comes to
network communications,

33
00:01:10.336 --> 00:01:12.651
we have a set of rules that
we have to follow, right?

34
00:01:12.651 --> 00:01:17.295
And if you have different protocols for
the different types of communications,

35
00:01:17.295 --> 00:01:21.403
different types of applications that
need to send their data, right?

36
00:01:21.403 --> 00:01:26.199
And it is important to understand that
if you are sending a certain type of

37
00:01:26.199 --> 00:01:30.692
data over a network that you are using
the same protocol on each end.

38
00:01:30.692 --> 00:01:32.920
Now we also have ports,
and what is a port for us?

39
00:01:32.920 --> 00:01:35.858
But a port is what they
call a logical identifier.

40
00:01:35.858 --> 00:01:40.196
Basically, it identifies the endpoint
of a connection and really identifies

41
00:01:40.196 --> 00:01:44.480
the service or the protocol, if you will,
that the port is associated with.

42
00:01:44.480 --> 00:01:47.870
So there are a few different ports
that we wanna make you aware of.

43
00:01:47.870 --> 00:01:51.030
They have a few different ranges.

44
00:01:51.030 --> 00:01:55.190
And when we talk about ports,
there are a set of standards, if you will,

45
00:01:55.190 --> 00:01:59.980
that a international standards
body set in place, INA.

46
00:01:59.980 --> 00:02:02.440
It started way back in the 70s,
late 70s, if you will.

47
00:02:02.440 --> 00:02:05.360
That's the International
Assigned Numbers Authority.

48
00:02:05.360 --> 00:02:06.580
They've kind of dissolved,

49
00:02:06.580 --> 00:02:10.890
even though their name is littered all
over the documentations and the standards.

50
00:02:10.890 --> 00:02:16.440
I think it's back in 2003ish that
the DOD contracts were basically run up.

51
00:02:16.440 --> 00:02:21.060
And a new body, if you will,
is doing the same and that's called ICANN.

52
00:02:21.060 --> 00:02:25.080
They're the Internet Corporation for
Assigned Names and Numbers.

53
00:02:25.080 --> 00:02:27.530
They help to oversee,

54
00:02:27.530 --> 00:02:30.980
not only things like these port
communications, network communications,

55
00:02:30.980 --> 00:02:34.892
but even what we talk about in other
episodes like IP address ranges.

56
00:02:34.892 --> 00:02:40.134
So do know that there are a certain
few different ranges of ports.

57
00:02:40.134 --> 00:02:41.542
We have what are known
as well-known ports.

58
00:02:41.542 --> 00:02:43.768
Well-known ports are common ports,
if you will.

59
00:02:43.768 --> 00:02:48.110
Typically identify all the common services
that we use when we communicate over

60
00:02:48.110 --> 00:02:50.910
what's known as a TCP/IP based network,
right?

61
00:02:50.910 --> 00:02:53.980
That's the Transmission Control
Protocol/nternet Protocol.

62
00:02:53.980 --> 00:02:58.566
It's a family or a suite of protocols that
allow us to communicate across the web.

63
00:02:58.566 --> 00:03:04.654
Now, in that well-known port range,
the ports that we have are zero,

64
00:03:04.654 --> 00:03:11.364
yes, zero always counts in computing,
keep that in mind, zero to 1023.

65
00:03:11.364 --> 00:03:13.994
Now outside of zero to 1023,
we have 1024 to 49151, right?

66
00:03:13.994 --> 00:03:18.580
That's really 49,151 and those
are what's known as registered ports.

67
00:03:18.580 --> 00:03:24.260
Now registered ports aren't necessarily
just completely overseen by manufacturers.

68
00:03:24.260 --> 00:03:27.872
But this allows software manufacturers
who want to use a certain port,

69
00:03:27.872 --> 00:03:30.111
they can use these ports
within that range.

70
00:03:30.111 --> 00:03:34.842
Then, step outside of that,
we have 49,152 to 65,535.

71
00:03:34.842 --> 00:03:38.431
And these are what are known as dynamic
ports or sometimes called private ports.

72
00:03:38.431 --> 00:03:40.960
And the reason we call them
dynamic is because your computers,

73
00:03:40.960 --> 00:03:42.678
your operating systems, your software,

74
00:03:42.678 --> 00:03:45.130
they'll assign these ports at
the time that they need them.

75
00:03:45.130 --> 00:03:46.788
And when they don't need them anymore,

76
00:03:46.788 --> 00:03:49.384
they'll go back into a pool that
they can reuse later, right?

77
00:03:49.384 --> 00:03:53.975
But there's no specific service associated
with that high level port, all right?

78
00:03:53.975 --> 00:03:58.980
Now, knowing those port ranges
is important on the exam.

79
00:03:58.980 --> 00:04:01.510
Let's go ahead and
let's talk about protocols that we have.

80
00:04:01.510 --> 00:04:04.650
Different types of communications that
communicate across these networks and

81
00:04:04.650 --> 00:04:06.600
the ports that are associated with them.

82
00:04:06.600 --> 00:04:09.590
One of the very first ones I wanna talk
about is actually a couple in the same

83
00:04:09.590 --> 00:04:10.260
diagram here.

84
00:04:10.260 --> 00:04:12.153
I've got a little diagram here, and

85
00:04:12.153 --> 00:04:14.666
we have a necessity to do remote logons,
right?

86
00:04:14.666 --> 00:04:17.075
Remote logon is when I'm
sitting at my computer, or

87
00:04:17.075 --> 00:04:19.977
Dan's sitting at his computer,
and we connect, let's say,

88
00:04:19.977 --> 00:04:22.745
over the network into a connectivity
device in the server.

89
00:04:22.745 --> 00:04:26.530
And we connect to this powerful
computer known as a server.

90
00:04:26.530 --> 00:04:28.160
And we want to manage it and

91
00:04:28.160 --> 00:04:32.471
not have to be in the same physical
location of that machine, right?

92
00:04:32.471 --> 00:04:36.000
It makes it very, very easy for
things like administration, right?

93
00:04:36.000 --> 00:04:39.668
I don't have to be in the same physical
location of the device that I'm gonna be

94
00:04:39.668 --> 00:04:40.794
configuring, right?

95
00:04:40.794 --> 00:04:44.945
Unlike sitting down at a PC and
working with your PC or Mac or

96
00:04:44.945 --> 00:04:46.567
a Linux based system.

97
00:04:46.567 --> 00:04:52.210
Now in the earlier days of communications,
we'll go back to the ARPANET, right?

98
00:04:52.210 --> 00:04:58.087
That's before we have what
the Internet would later be.

99
00:04:58.087 --> 00:05:00.720
Basically brought out
of the earlier ARPANET.

100
00:05:00.720 --> 00:05:02.631
>> It was like the proto Internet.

101
00:05:02.631 --> 00:05:05.940
>> Yeah, great way to put it,
it's the advanced research project agency.

102
00:05:05.940 --> 00:05:10.640
So what makes up our Internet today is
largely started by a few universities and

103
00:05:10.640 --> 00:05:13.420
our Department of Defense
here in the United States.

104
00:05:13.420 --> 00:05:17.200
Now in those days, we had five or
six entities [LAUGH] that were really

105
00:05:17.200 --> 00:05:20.730
connected to that network, and then they
started adding more, and more, and more.

106
00:05:20.730 --> 00:05:25.573
But keep in mind that, in those early
days, we didn't have the major concern for

107
00:05:25.573 --> 00:05:27.865
data privacy that that we have today.

108
00:05:27.865 --> 00:05:31.552
Right now, we have so many people
attached to public networks, and

109
00:05:31.552 --> 00:05:32.975
anybody can jump on them,

110
00:05:32.975 --> 00:05:37.390
that it was kinda difficult to connect
to those networks in the earlier days.

111
00:05:37.390 --> 00:05:41.695
Like I said, it would be schools,
it'd be military institutions, so

112
00:05:41.695 --> 00:05:43.579
privacy wasn't a major deal.

113
00:05:43.579 --> 00:05:47.176
So when I would make a remote logon
to connect to either a terminal,

114
00:05:47.176 --> 00:05:50.387
if you will, connect it to
a mainframe at a big computer, or

115
00:05:50.387 --> 00:05:54.370
if we were making a connection again,
essentially, to another device,

116
00:05:54.370 --> 00:05:58.190
everything can go across the network
in what's known as plaintext.

117
00:05:58.190 --> 00:05:59.139
Now what does plaintext mean?

118
00:05:59.139 --> 00:06:02.148
But that means the fact that if
somebody's out on that network,

119
00:06:02.148 --> 00:06:06.106
there are software programs out there that
can actually scrape that information and

120
00:06:06.106 --> 00:06:07.456
throw it into your display.

121
00:06:07.456 --> 00:06:10.710
And show you what the information
is inside of the text, right?

122
00:06:10.710 --> 00:06:14.060
That's called plaintext,
because you can read it.

123
00:06:14.060 --> 00:06:17.900
Now that doesn't provide
a confidentiality.

124
00:06:17.900 --> 00:06:21.350
And the first protocol, if we go back
to our slide here, is called Telnet.

125
00:06:21.350 --> 00:06:25.990
Telnet is a terminal emulation software
that said telecommunication networking,

126
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:27.180
I think it's what is short for.

127
00:06:27.180 --> 00:06:29.376
But it is a plaintext communication,

128
00:06:29.376 --> 00:06:32.540
it allows me to remotely
log on to another device.

129
00:06:32.540 --> 00:06:34.540
Again, I don't have to be in
the same physical location.

130
00:06:34.540 --> 00:06:39.161
In fact, if some of you guys are aware
of the co-founder of Apple out there,

131
00:06:39.161 --> 00:06:40.183
Steve Wozniak.

132
00:06:40.183 --> 00:06:40.683
Wozniak?
>> Wozniak.

133
00:06:40.683 --> 00:06:42.356
>> Yeah, [LAUGH] thank you, the Woz,

134
00:06:42.356 --> 00:06:45.699
I always remember it as the Woz.
He used to talk about when he was at

135
00:06:45.699 --> 00:06:49.687
university, he used to have fun logging
onto ARPANET back in those days and

136
00:06:49.687 --> 00:06:54.183
playing solitaire from California all the
way over to a computer that was, I think,

137
00:06:54.183 --> 00:06:56.463
it's somewhere out there, Berg Harbor,

138
00:06:56.463 --> 00:06:59.576
or something like that.
You notice the great

139
00:06:59.576 --> 00:07:01.320
long distances.
And

140
00:07:01.320 --> 00:07:04.110
in those days, it was just fine.
We didn't care about the privacy

141
00:07:04.110 --> 00:07:05.475
we do today.

142
00:07:05.475 --> 00:07:08.670
Plaintext communications,
when you talk about configuring and

143
00:07:08.670 --> 00:07:12.682
connecting to remote devices could
lead to a security vulnerability.

144
00:07:12.682 --> 00:07:16.293
And that's what gave rise to the next
protocol I'd like to talk about and

145
00:07:16.293 --> 00:07:17.425
that's known as SSH.

146
00:07:17.425 --> 00:07:20.484
SSH allows you to also
perform a remote logon so

147
00:07:20.484 --> 00:07:23.710
that you can configure
your different devices.

148
00:07:23.710 --> 00:07:26.947
You can connect to these devices,
utilize them again.

149
00:07:26.947 --> 00:07:29.338
And don't have to be in that
same physical location.

150
00:07:29.338 --> 00:07:35.340
Now there's a big difference between
secure shell as opposed to Telnet.

151
00:07:35.340 --> 00:07:39.430
Telnet, being a plaintext communication,
you can grab that information and

152
00:07:39.430 --> 00:07:42.450
potentially see what
is in the data itself.

153
00:07:42.450 --> 00:07:44.820
Secure Shell uses encryption.

154
00:07:44.820 --> 00:07:47.962
It takes that plaintext that
we've talked about, and

155
00:07:47.962 --> 00:07:52.141
it uses encryption algorithms to
provide what's known as cipher text.

156
00:07:52.141 --> 00:07:56.121
All right, cipher text is when
you have scrambled data that only

157
00:07:56.121 --> 00:08:00.099
the source where I'm logging into And
the device, if you will,

158
00:08:00.099 --> 00:08:05.708
the destination that I'm remotely logging
on to, understand the communication.

159
00:08:05.708 --> 00:08:08.790
It means, let's say Dan is communicating,
let's say,

160
00:08:08.790 --> 00:08:12.890
with one of the Cisco switches
inside of our server closet.

161
00:08:12.890 --> 00:08:17.317
I put my black hat on and I'm gonna decide
to attack the network and he's using SSH,

162
00:08:17.317 --> 00:08:18.214
I can't reach.

163
00:08:18.214 --> 00:08:20.325
I can grab that information but
when I look at it,

164
00:08:20.325 --> 00:08:22.990
it's gonna look like a bunch
of scrambled garbage, right?

165
00:08:22.990 --> 00:08:24.770
I won't be able to see the information,
and

166
00:08:24.770 --> 00:08:27.370
that's one of the benefits of using SSH.

167
00:08:27.370 --> 00:08:32.600
When we configure devices from a remote
location, you wanna make sure that people

168
00:08:32.600 --> 00:08:37.010
don't have access to that information,
cuz again, it can be used for war attacks.

169
00:08:37.010 --> 00:08:39.800
>> So sensitive information, we use SSH.

170
00:08:39.800 --> 00:08:43.340
Stuff that doesn't really matter,
you can use Telnet as a standard.

171
00:08:43.340 --> 00:08:45.841
We do see Telnet still
running around out there.

172
00:08:45.841 --> 00:08:51.653
Actually, if you wanna play with it, you
can open up a terminal that has Telnet or

173
00:08:51.653 --> 00:08:56.910
a Telnet client and you can connect
to rainmaker.wunderground.com.

174
00:08:56.910 --> 00:09:01.009
And that's the weather underground,
W-U-N-D-E-R ground, like that.

175
00:09:01.009 --> 00:09:03.865
And you can connect, and

The very first one, TCP,

00:32:20.590 --> 00:32:22.910

It means that when I communicate with

00:32:28.370 --> 00:32:30.210

00:32:30.210 --> 00:32:31.998

Because I wanna make sure that

00:32:37.560 --> 00:32:39.935
And if you tell me you didn't get it,

00:32:39.935 --> 00:32:41.485

00:32:41.485 --> 00:32:44.445

00:32:49.285 --> 00:32:50.890

UDP on the other hand,

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes compare and contrast the various WiFi networking standards and encryption types. Specific topics covered includes: 802.11 a/b/g/n/ac, Speeds, distances, and frequencies, WEP, WPA, WPA2, TKIP, and AES.
episodes.title: WiFi Standards and Encryption

00:31:58.636 --> 00:32:01.730
Signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

628
00:32:01.730 --> 00:32:03.510
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.
>> And we'll see you next time.

629
00:32:03.510 --> 00:32:10.986
[MUSIC]

630
00:32:10.986 --> 00:32:13.624
Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore the relevant information with regards to installing and configuring a SOHO wireless/wired router and applying appropriate settings. Specific topics discussed includes: Channels, Frequencies, Port Forwarding, Port Triggering, DCHP, DMZ, NAT/DNAT, QoS, Firmware, and UPnP.
episodes.title: Install SOHO Wireless/Wired Router
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:02.236
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.236 --> 00:00:08.237
[CROSSTALK]
[SOUND]

3
00:00:08.237 --> 00:00:11.929
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.929 --> 00:00:13.729
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:13.729 --> 00:00:16.155
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:16.155 --> 00:00:17.534
I'm you're host Daniel Lowrie, and

7
00:00:17.534 --> 00:00:19.397
in today's episode we do thank you for
joining us.

8
00:00:19.397 --> 00:00:22.257
Because we're kicking off
more in our A+ series.

9
00:00:22.257 --> 00:00:26.460
And of course, joining us back in studio,
when I say us, I mean you,

10
00:00:26.460 --> 00:00:28.136
myself and Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:28.136 --> 00:00:28.782
>> Hey, hey.

12
00:00:28.782 --> 00:00:29.792
>> Welcome back man, how's it going?

13
00:00:29.792 --> 00:00:31.483
>> Man, it's going great, Dan,
thanks for jumping in here.

14
00:00:31.483 --> 00:00:34.636
It is great to be here in studio two,
that's right,

15
00:00:34.636 --> 00:00:38.090
we just told you where we were,
in case you didn't know.

16
00:00:38.090 --> 00:00:40.746
We are moving along just
like Dan said with A+.

17
00:00:40.746 --> 00:00:45.837
And we've kinda moved a little bit out
of the the hardware side, if you will.

18
00:00:45.837 --> 00:00:48.566
We will be talking more about
networking components and

19
00:00:48.566 --> 00:00:52.640
some of the concepts behind networking,
if you've been following along with us.

20
00:00:52.640 --> 00:00:54.280
If you're just joining us now,
you might say, well,

21
00:00:54.280 --> 00:00:56.045
what is this hardware you speak of?

22
00:00:56.045 --> 00:00:58.725
Keep in mind we have quite a few
episodes when it comes to dealing with

23
00:00:58.725 --> 00:01:01.515
the different components that
are inside of your system unit.

24
00:01:01.515 --> 00:01:04.665
And make up the entire
computing experience for us.

25
00:01:04.665 --> 00:01:07.545
But now what we've been diving in
over the last couple episodes.

26
00:01:07.545 --> 00:01:12.450
We've really been talking about some of
the concepts behind how we communicate

27
00:01:12.450 --> 00:01:13.920
within networks today.

28
00:01:13.920 --> 00:01:17.380
Remember, very basically,
a network is really for two things, right?

29
00:01:17.380 --> 00:01:20.150
It's for sharing resources and
communication.

30
00:01:20.150 --> 00:01:22.132
Now there are all different
types of networks.

31
00:01:22.132 --> 00:01:26.740
And in later episodes, we're gonna
talk about geographical locations and

32
00:01:26.740 --> 00:01:30.052
the network classifications,
I guess you would say,

33
00:01:30.052 --> 00:01:33.560
related to how they're dispersed,
if you will.

34
00:01:33.560 --> 00:01:36.826
But, in this episode, what we're gonna
be talking about is the small office,

35
00:01:36.826 --> 00:01:38.696
home office, wireless, and wire routers.

36
00:01:38.696 --> 00:01:43.685
And we're gonna talk a little bit about
some of the concepts that these devices

37
00:01:43.685 --> 00:01:46.498
allow us to perform within these networks.

38
00:01:46.498 --> 00:01:50.040
Now remember, when we say SOHO network,
we're talking about a small office,

39
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:50.870
home office.

40
00:01:50.870 --> 00:01:53.616
You'll see that there are different
types of businesses that

41
00:01:53.616 --> 00:01:56.743
they classify when you start talking
about getting into networking.

42
00:01:56.743 --> 00:01:59.186
All right, the smallest one is the SOHO,
and then you move up from there.

43
00:01:59.186 --> 00:02:04.230
You might hear the term SMB,
which is small to medium business.

44
00:02:04.230 --> 00:02:06.430
And then you have enterprise
level networks, right?

45
00:02:06.430 --> 00:02:10.084
Enterprise level networks can have
thousands of employees, if you will,

46
00:02:10.084 --> 00:02:13.566
versus, again, small to medium and
then, last but not least, SOHO.

47
00:02:13.566 --> 00:02:17.280
Now, with the Soho environment, keep in
mind that we're typically talking no more

48
00:02:17.280 --> 00:02:19.130
than ten computers, ten computers max.

49
00:02:19.130 --> 00:02:22.310
If you've ever been to a doctor's office
before, and you've seen maybe, and

50
00:02:22.310 --> 00:02:25.900
when I say doctor's office, I'm certainly
not talking about a medical facility,

51
00:02:25.900 --> 00:02:27.890
just a normal doctor's office.

52
00:02:27.890 --> 00:02:28.890
You might see about, what?

53
00:02:28.890 --> 00:02:30.100
Maybe ten computers there?

54
00:02:30.100 --> 00:02:32.880
Maybe a couple of receptionists up front,
if you will, and

55
00:02:32.880 --> 00:02:35.940
some of the nurses log in
to different computers.

56
00:02:35.940 --> 00:02:39.170
Now, there are certain types of
devices that we have to be aware of

57
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:43.280
that help networks, if you will,
in general, function.

58
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:46.100
And we're gonna be talking
about wireless routers.

59
00:02:46.100 --> 00:02:48.510
And we're gonna talk a little
bit about wired routers too.

60
00:02:48.510 --> 00:02:52.370
And some of the configurations,
in technologies,

61
00:02:52.370 --> 00:02:54.910
that are really built into these devices.

62
00:02:54.910 --> 00:02:56.690
Now one of the first things
that they call out, and

63
00:02:56.690 --> 00:02:58.610
this is gonna be really specifically.

64
00:02:58.610 --> 00:03:00.400
This is gonna be more
on the wireless side.

65
00:03:00.400 --> 00:03:04.870
What we wanna do is we wanna
talk about wireless channels,

66
00:03:04.870 --> 00:03:06.210
wireless communication, all right?

67
00:03:06.210 --> 00:03:08.110
Now, when we talk about wireless,

68
00:03:08.110 --> 00:03:12.760
keep in mind that we're talking
about an unbounded communication.

69
00:03:12.760 --> 00:03:16.870
And wireless really has a lot of benefits.

70
00:03:16.870 --> 00:03:19.940
One of the things is, strategic
positioning can be a little bit better of

71
00:03:19.940 --> 00:03:21.500
your devices within your networks.

72
00:03:21.500 --> 00:03:25.570
If you have physical limitations, like
hey, I can't just go over to a wall and

73
00:03:25.570 --> 00:03:29.780
knock a wall down and then put down my CAT
cables that we've talked about before.

74
00:03:29.780 --> 00:03:31.280
So again, it does have its benefit.

75
00:03:31.280 --> 00:03:37.260
And the other thing is mobility, that's
one of the most prevalent technologies.

76
00:03:37.260 --> 00:03:38.035
We wanna be mobile, right?

77
00:03:38.035 --> 00:03:43.740
We don't wanna just necessarily be
locked down to a single location.

78
00:03:43.740 --> 00:03:46.900
So remember wireless is a very,
very common thing to have.

79
00:03:46.900 --> 00:03:49.130
Not only in SOHO,
small office home office,

80
00:03:49.130 --> 00:03:53.629
but even in things like relatively
short business type environments.

81
00:03:54.830 --> 00:03:58.889
Now, we should talk about radiated energy,
unbounded communications.

82
00:03:58.889 --> 00:04:02.680
And when we talk about that, we're really
talking about frequencies, all right?

83
00:04:02.680 --> 00:04:05.479
And there are a couple of different
types of frequencies that we really

84
00:04:05.479 --> 00:04:06.150
wanna call out.

85
00:04:06.150 --> 00:04:08.810
Now, on the exam they call out channels,
all right?

86
00:04:08.810 --> 00:04:11.600
But to understand channels,
you really have to understand

87
00:04:11.600 --> 00:04:15.420
the frequencies that these channels
operate on, if that makes sense, right?

88
00:04:15.420 --> 00:04:19.190
Because we have different channels for
different frequencies, right?

89
00:04:19.190 --> 00:04:23.230
We can't really just lump them all
together, and what you choose is

90
00:04:23.230 --> 00:04:26.850
based on compatibility, based on
the standard that you have, right?

91
00:04:26.850 --> 00:04:29.170
And you might choose one over the other,

92
00:04:29.170 --> 00:04:33.200
because there are standards out there
that support multiple frequencies.

93
00:04:33.200 --> 00:04:36.378
And what I mean by that is we have
what's known as the ISM band.

94
00:04:36.378 --> 00:04:37.858
And that's a band that's been around for

95
00:04:37.858 --> 00:04:39.723
a very long time, and
it's basically unlicensed.

96
00:04:39.723 --> 00:04:41.690
>> Flintstones, [LAUGH]
>> That's right, that's right,

97
00:04:41.690 --> 00:04:43.152
longer than the Flintstones even, right?

98
00:04:43.152 --> 00:04:46.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] The ISM band is an unlicensed

99
00:04:46.430 --> 00:04:46.975
band.

100
00:04:46.975 --> 00:04:50.009
Again, it was released to
the public by the FCC.

101
00:04:50.009 --> 00:04:52.924
And I honestly don't know the time frame,
I know it's been out there for a while.

102
00:04:52.924 --> 00:04:56.880
Because things like cellphones, the
cordless phones that you have out there,

103
00:04:56.880 --> 00:05:00.365
bluetooth, wireless communications
that we're gonna talk about,

104
00:05:00.365 --> 00:05:04.046
here, as well, all operate in what's
known as the 2.4 GHz spectrum.

105
00:05:04.046 --> 00:05:08.057
Now, when I say a spectrum, understand
what I'm talking about is not just

106
00:05:08.057 --> 00:05:11.381
a single frequency, but
in actually a range of frequencies.

107
00:05:11.381 --> 00:05:15.933
And when we talk about 2.4,
what we're talking about is there

108
00:05:15.933 --> 00:05:20.750
are different channels inside of
this larger domain, if you will.

109
00:05:20.750 --> 00:05:23.310
Again, commonly called a spectrum.

110
00:05:23.310 --> 00:05:29.398
Now let's go ahead and let's talk a little
bit about when it comes to those channels.

111
00:05:29.398 --> 00:05:34.160
Let's talk a little bit about
that 2.4 GHz spectrum, all right?

112
00:05:34.160 --> 00:05:36.920
And what we mean by that is,
when you have a wireless device,

113
00:05:36.920 --> 00:05:41.280
a mobile device or our laptops here that
Dan and I have, your tablets, if you will.

114
00:05:41.280 --> 00:05:45.852
And you connect to a wireless network, you
have the choice to either connect to a 2.4

115
00:05:45.852 --> 00:05:50.760
GHz network, and, more common today, also
a 5 GHz network and, well, sometimes both.

116
00:05:50.760 --> 00:05:52.862
So why would I choose one over the other?

117
00:05:52.862 --> 00:05:55.450
That's kinda one of the things that
we wanna alleviate here if you're

118
00:05:55.450 --> 00:05:56.700
a little bit confused about that.

119
00:05:56.700 --> 00:05:58.090
And if you've never heard about it at all,

120
00:05:58.090 --> 00:06:01.310
at least you just kinda
acclimate you to the technology.

121
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:04.190
So starting with 2.4 GHz,
I've got a little diagram here.

122
00:06:04.190 --> 00:06:08.000
And one of the great things is,
I don't know that you're gonna have to,

123
00:06:08.000 --> 00:06:10.590
on the A+ exam,
know the individual specifics.

124
00:06:10.590 --> 00:06:13.049
But we put them here anyways,
just so you guys could study it.

125
00:06:13.049 --> 00:06:15.784
And those of you that
are moving onto Network+,

126
00:06:15.784 --> 00:06:20.900
this information might be just as valuable
to you as well, so do keep that in mind.

127
00:06:20.900 --> 00:06:23.700
Now you'll see that these channels here,
and I'll explain kinda what's going on

128
00:06:23.700 --> 00:06:27.120
with this spaghetti that we
have up on the screen here.

129
00:06:27.120 --> 00:06:30.580
You'll notice that there are 11 channels,
and 11 channels, essentially,

130
00:06:30.580 --> 00:06:33.860
are individual frequencies that we have.

131
00:06:33.860 --> 00:06:38.676
So the 2.4 GHz spectrum,
it starts at 2.4 or 2.24,

132
00:06:38.676 --> 00:06:42.294
I'm gonna get this right now, 2412 MHz.

133
00:06:42.294 --> 00:06:46.660
So MHz in each channel bumps itself up.

134
00:06:46.660 --> 00:06:51.591
Like the next channel from channel one,
channel one starts out at 200,

135
00:06:51.591 --> 00:06:55.440
again, I'll get this right eventually,
2412 MHz.

136
00:06:55.440 --> 00:06:58.100
The second channel,
it's just a little bit higher than that.

137
00:06:58.100 --> 00:07:02.600
Still in that overall broad spectrum
of 2.4 GHz, if you will, but

138
00:07:02.600 --> 00:07:04.690
I believe it's 2.417.

139
00:07:04.690 --> 00:07:09.320
And you can see that every channel
just differs in its MHz just slightly.

140
00:07:10.360 --> 00:07:15.410
Now, inside of the 2.4 GHz spectrum,
I said there are 11 channels.

141
00:07:15.410 --> 00:07:16.860
Let me be a little bit more specific.

142
00:07:16.860 --> 00:07:20.718
There's actually 14 channels,
however, the FCC heavily regulates

143
00:07:20.718 --> 00:07:25.160
the amount of channels that we have
available to us here in the states.

144
00:07:25.160 --> 00:07:27.760
Other countries also use channels 12, 13,

145
00:07:27.760 --> 00:07:32.560
and I think Japan's the only one
that actually allocates 14 for use.

146
00:07:32.560 --> 00:07:35.054
In fact, I think it's one of the only
countries that uses channel 14.

147
00:07:35.054 --> 00:07:39.122
So we're not worried about those
channels 12 through 14 for the exam.

148
00:07:39.122 --> 00:07:45.046
And that's why, on this diagram right
here, I said outside of the US FCC, right?

149
00:07:45.046 --> 00:07:50.078
Our Federal Communications Commission that
actually overseas this unlicensed band and

150
00:07:50.078 --> 00:07:52.265
kinda dictates where we go with it.

151
00:07:52.265 --> 00:07:55.853
>> And Wes, what is the purpose of
having all these multiple channels?

152
00:07:55.853 --> 00:07:59.631
>> That's a great question, because
when you have wireless communications,

153
00:07:59.631 --> 00:08:03.597
I want you to think of the old Party
lines, right, or a conference call, right?

154
00:08:03.597 --> 00:08:05.545
If you have too many people
on a single channel,

155
00:08:05.545 --> 00:08:08.530
what happens is you get what's known
as signal congestion, all right.

156
00:08:08.530 --> 00:08:13.310
And signal congestion just means that hey,
we got too many people on one pipeline and

157
00:08:13.310 --> 00:08:14.690
that pipeline's getting full, right?

158
00:08:14.690 --> 00:08:19.176
And then you have things like radio
frequency interference that also comes

159
00:08:19.176 --> 00:08:19.895
into play.

160
00:08:19.895 --> 00:08:24.040
So to answer your question there,
Dan, you can use multiple channels.

161
00:08:24.040 --> 00:08:27.860
However, there are some recommendations
when it comes to which channels you use.

162
00:08:27.860 --> 00:08:30.300
Notice that there are some
green channels here.

163
00:08:30.300 --> 00:08:33.510
And I just did this to kinda make
them stand out from the rest of them.

164
00:08:33.510 --> 00:08:35.951
Well, what are we talking about
when we say there's green channels?

165
00:08:35.951 --> 00:08:41.862
Well, inside of the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum
there are three non-overlapping channels,

166
00:08:41.862 --> 00:08:42.625
all right?

167
00:08:42.625 --> 00:08:44.570
Well, what do I mean by that?

168
00:08:44.570 --> 00:08:47.411
Well, let's say that's
somebody is on channel 1 and

169
00:08:47.411 --> 00:08:49.088
then somebody is on channel 2.

170
00:08:49.088 --> 00:08:52.176
Notice that the bandwidth,
they kinda overlap with each other.

171
00:08:52.176 --> 00:08:55.849
And like I said, that can lead to things
like radio frequency interference,

172
00:08:55.849 --> 00:08:59.126
congestion, and you could start
see the degradation of the signal,

173
00:08:59.126 --> 00:09:01.170
the performance, if you will.

174
00:09:01.170 --> 00:09:06.980
So what they recommend is to
set your device on a channel

175
00:09:06.980 --> 00:09:11.239
that doesn't overlap with an adjacent
channel, right, for the purposes

176
00:09:11.239 --> 00:09:15.780
of getting a little bit better
performance within your communications.

177
00:09:15.780 --> 00:09:20.441
All right, so I want you to remember that
the three non-overlapping channels that

178
00:09:20.441 --> 00:09:24.580
you have within our spectrum here in
the United States is 1, 6 and 11.

179
00:09:24.580 --> 00:09:27.697
And that's because I believe that
the channels are 22 megahertz wide,

180
00:09:27.697 --> 00:09:28.960
I believe is what they are.

181
00:09:28.960 --> 00:09:32.880
And with that, that full 22 megahertz,

182
00:09:32.880 --> 00:09:36.610
what you'll see is that 1 and
6 do not overlap with each other.

183
00:09:36.610 --> 00:09:39.210
Now do you have to set
this on your access point?

184
00:09:39.210 --> 00:09:41.070
A lot of times you don't,
and let me tell you why.

185
00:09:41.070 --> 00:09:44.648
Because your access points support
what's known as autoswitching.

186
00:09:44.648 --> 00:09:46.720
They can actually sense it,
they can detect it.

187
00:09:46.720 --> 00:09:48.115
And if they say, wait a second here,

188
00:09:48.115 --> 00:09:51.540
we're getting a lot of congestion,
they can flip over to an adjacent channel.

189
00:09:51.540 --> 00:09:54.945
So sometimes you'll see that it does
kinda like a frequency hopping,

190
00:09:54.945 --> 00:09:58.582
even though it's not technically
frequency hopping, spread spectrum,

191
00:09:58.582 --> 00:10:00.677
which is another technology altogether.

192
00:10:00.677 --> 00:10:05.050
It does have the ability to
move between those frequencies.

193
00:10:05.050 --> 00:10:07.880
And that's something
important to remember.

194
00:10:07.880 --> 00:10:11.390
Now there is a benefit to
the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

195
00:10:11.390 --> 00:10:14.176
And just like anything that we've been
talking down through this entire episode,

196
00:10:14.176 --> 00:10:16.103
there's always gonna be some
kind of drawback, right?

197
00:10:16.103 --> 00:10:16.887
>> Always gives and takes, right?

198
00:10:16.887 --> 00:10:18.086
Pros and cons, as they say.

199
00:10:18.086 --> 00:10:19.373
>> Yeah, most definitely.

200
00:10:19.373 --> 00:10:22.658
And one of those pros is the fact
that 2.4 gigahertz spectrum,

201
00:10:22.658 --> 00:10:24.280
it's got a wide range, right?

202
00:10:24.280 --> 00:10:27.070
It's a very, very wide range, all right.

203
00:10:27.070 --> 00:10:29.860
And that's kind of one of the things
that you have to remember in wireless.

204
00:10:29.860 --> 00:10:33.130
The more powerful your signal,
the shorter the range.

205
00:10:33.130 --> 00:10:35.040
Lower the power a little bit,
you get a farther range.

206
00:10:35.040 --> 00:10:36.870
And I know that sounds kind of,
well, wait a second,

207
00:10:36.870 --> 00:10:38.610
that sounds kinda counterintuitive.

208
00:10:38.610 --> 00:10:41.670
But you gotta keep in mind, just because
you put more electrical energy into

209
00:10:41.670 --> 00:10:44.352
something doesn't necessarily mean
you're gonna get a clearer signal.

210
00:10:44.352 --> 00:10:45.790
Just means you're gonna
put more power in it.

211
00:10:45.790 --> 00:10:47.380
And when you put more power, guess what?

212
00:10:47.380 --> 00:10:50.780
You also have the chance for increased
radio frequency interference, so again,

213
00:10:50.780 --> 00:10:52.023
it's always a give and take.

214
00:10:52.023 --> 00:10:54.888
And thank goodness,
this isn't an electrical science class,

215
00:10:54.888 --> 00:10:56.595
because it's well beyond me, guys.

216
00:10:56.595 --> 00:10:58.255
But just kinda understand that.

217
00:10:58.255 --> 00:11:01.195
All right, now, here's the thing.

218
00:11:01.195 --> 00:11:05.665
Even though the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum
has a wide range, it's heavily congested.

219
00:11:05.665 --> 00:11:06.695
And why is that?

220
00:11:06.695 --> 00:11:08.895
Well, because it's on license,
all your manufacturers,

221
00:11:08.895 --> 00:11:11.655
microwaves operate in
the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

222
00:11:11.655 --> 00:11:14.755
Cell phones operate, sometimes,
in the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

223
00:11:14.755 --> 00:11:21.012
Bluetooth that we've talked about
operates in the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

224
00:11:21.012 --> 00:11:24.580
So you're gonna see heavily congested and
you could, because of that,

225
00:11:24.580 --> 00:11:25.870
get lower performance, right?

226
00:11:25.870 --> 00:11:30.133
Because you have more tendency to
get radio frequency interference.

227
00:11:30.133 --> 00:11:35.157
So that's one of the frequencies
I want you to be aware of.

228
00:11:35.157 --> 00:11:39.854
Now when we talk about channels, all
right, well, again, we're not done with

229
00:11:39.854 --> 00:11:44.296
channels because we also have another
spectrum, if you will, that we use.

230
00:11:44.296 --> 00:11:49.209
And this has become more and more popular
as we've gone through the different 802.11

231
00:11:49.209 --> 00:11:51.460
wireless local area network standards.

232
00:11:51.460 --> 00:11:55.540
We're gonna talk about the WLAN

00:11:55.540 --> 00:11:59.080

00:11:59.080 --> 00:12:02.926

00:12:02.926 --> 00:12:03.502
for that.

236
00:12:03.502 --> 00:12:08.207
In the earliest days, one of the very
first standards that came out actually

237
00:12:08.207 --> 00:12:11.320
was implemented over
the 5 gigahertz spectrum.

238
00:12:11.320 --> 00:12:15.726
Now the 5 gigahertz spectrum's a little
bit different than 2.4 gigahertz, and

239
00:12:15.726 --> 00:12:18.344
it's not just because
[LAUGH] of the frequencies.

240
00:12:18.344 --> 00:12:24.224
I mean, that would be kind of axiomatic
there, but this is more about, today it's

241
00:12:24.224 --> 00:12:30.030
relatively unused in comparison to
the long running 2.4 gigahertz spectrum.

242
00:12:30.030 --> 00:12:31.370
So it does have its benefits.

243
00:12:31.370 --> 00:12:33.570
Now, I got a little example here.

244
00:12:33.570 --> 00:12:37.530
There's some other benefits
to the 5 gigahertz spectrum.

245
00:12:37.530 --> 00:12:42.709
Dan, we said three of these
non-overlapping channels for 2.4.

246
00:12:42.709 --> 00:12:47.094
5 gigahertz has 23
non-overlapping channels, 23.

247
00:12:47.094 --> 00:12:48.461
So you've got a lot more choices, right?

248
00:12:48.461 --> 00:12:51.740
>> Yeah, a lot less, what you call
channel congestion, I'm assuming.

249
00:12:51.740 --> 00:12:54.540
>> Absolutely, which equates to
a little bit better performance, right?

250
00:12:54.540 --> 00:12:58.761
And the fact that it's not as widely
used as 2.4 gigahertz just adds to that,

251
00:12:58.761 --> 00:13:00.022
kinda compounds on it.

252
00:13:00.022 --> 00:13:01.706
So there's a plus to that.

253
00:13:01.706 --> 00:13:04.666
Now, this isn't the ISM band.

254
00:13:04.666 --> 00:13:07.546
This is actually kind of
a heavily regulated band.

255
00:13:07.546 --> 00:13:11.048
It's actually called the Unlicensed
National Information Infrastructure.

256
00:13:11.048 --> 00:13:15.410
I always remember it as UNI-II,
right U-N-I- I-I.

257
00:13:15.410 --> 00:13:18.530
Not really something that you have
to understand on the exam, but

258
00:13:18.530 --> 00:13:21.324
it is good information just for
your benefit regardless.

259
00:13:21.324 --> 00:13:24.324
Now, just like 2.4 gigahertz,

260
00:13:24.324 --> 00:13:29.730
this is gonna have a benefit,
and a drawback likewise, right?

261
00:13:29.730 --> 00:13:30.540
And what is that?

262
00:13:30.540 --> 00:13:35.250
Well, the benefit is the fact that
you get a lot better performance.

263
00:13:35.250 --> 00:13:38.010
The drawback is it's shorter distances,
shorter ranges, right?

264
00:13:38.010 --> 00:13:40.680
You have to be closer to
the wireless access point to get

265
00:13:41.950 --> 00:13:43.840
really good strong signal.

266
00:13:43.840 --> 00:13:46.870
Now as you'll learn, if you get
into wireless communications and

267
00:13:46.870 --> 00:13:49.790
you start supporting it, you'll see
that they also implement additional

268
00:13:49.790 --> 00:13:52.960
technologies that are really
beneficial for 5 gigahertz as well.

269
00:13:52.960 --> 00:13:54.880
They've got antennas today,
smart antennas,

270
00:13:54.880 --> 00:13:57.270
that do really cool
things like beam forming.

271
00:13:57.270 --> 00:14:00.038
And, yeah, that's kinda like
a sci-fi War of the Worlds.

272
00:14:00.038 --> 00:14:02.318
>> [LAUGH]
>> We're talking literally focusing in on

273
00:14:02.318 --> 00:14:06.750
your direction versus just increasing
the power to everybody within the network.

274
00:14:06.750 --> 00:14:11.020
We're talking literally channeling
down on a single device.

275
00:14:11.020 --> 00:14:17.808
Now the other thing that's really good
about the 5 gigahertz spectrum there

276
00:14:17.808 --> 00:14:22.830
is the fact that it also
supports something known as DFS.

277
00:14:22.830 --> 00:14:25.390
And this is dynamic frequency selection.

278
00:14:25.390 --> 00:14:28.670
And that's kind of really
cool because we talked

279
00:14:28.670 --> 00:14:32.360
about the autoswitching
inside of 2.4 gigahertz.

280
00:14:32.360 --> 00:14:37.790
This means that if it detects that
you're on a frequency that is actually

281
00:14:37.790 --> 00:14:43.368
congested in a way, it does give
you the ability to switch over.

282
00:14:43.368 --> 00:14:48.858
All right, now as a real small recap
from our wireless 802.11 standards,

283
00:14:48.858 --> 00:14:53.556
I want you to remember that
802.11a operates in 5 gigahertz.

284
00:14:53.556 --> 00:14:58.002
The B, G, and N, well,
B and G, if you will,

285
00:14:58.002 --> 00:15:03.400
they also operate in 2.4 gigahertz,
both of them.

286
00:15:03.400 --> 00:15:07.187
And then the N standard, 802.11n,
it is a dual band standard.

287
00:15:07.187 --> 00:15:11.098
And the fact that it operates in
2.4 gigahertz and 5 gigahertz so

288
00:15:11.098 --> 00:15:14.664
that N devices could support
all the earlier legacy devices,

289
00:15:14.664 --> 00:15:19.720
currently what we have today, what's kind
of really popular is the AC standard.

290
00:15:19.720 --> 00:15:23.816
And the AC standard, you'll see a lot of
them implement the 2.4 gigahertz as dual

291
00:15:23.816 --> 00:15:27.710
band, kind of like what N does with
the specification 5 gigahertz.

292
00:15:27.710 --> 00:15:29.740
And you get a lot of better performance.

293
00:15:29.740 --> 00:15:31.610
The channels, if you will,

294
00:15:31.610 --> 00:15:36.610
can be aggregated together to make a
larger pipeline to send information over.

295
00:15:36.610 --> 00:15:39.370
All right, so Dan, that's a little bit
about the channels that we have but

296
00:15:39.370 --> 00:15:42.570
there are other technologies that
we kind of gotta talk about too,

297
00:15:42.570 --> 00:15:46.780
and they mention things like port
forwarding and port triggering.

298
00:15:46.780 --> 00:15:50.766
All right, and these are very,
very beneficial, all right?

299
00:15:50.766 --> 00:15:55.538
And one of the things to keep in mind
is that when communications come

300
00:15:55.538 --> 00:16:00.059
into your wireless device, or
even your wired router, I mean,

301
00:16:00.059 --> 00:16:02.421
both wired and wireless do this.

302
00:16:02.421 --> 00:16:07.922
When you have information coming across
the Internet going into your network,

303
00:16:07.922 --> 00:16:11.781
You might want a specific type
of traffic to be basically

304
00:16:11.781 --> 00:16:16.730
directed to a single end point or
a single device within your networks.

305
00:16:16.730 --> 00:16:21.500
So, what port forwarding allows you to do
is to say when that information comes in

306
00:16:21.500 --> 00:16:24.020
Into your network,
send it to this computer.

307
00:16:24.020 --> 00:16:25.380
Let me give you a couple of examples or

308
00:16:25.380 --> 00:16:27.600
scenarios where that's
very beneficial; right?

309
00:16:27.600 --> 00:16:29.340
If you're a gamer, right?

310
00:16:29.340 --> 00:16:32.300
The gamers use this a lot, and
one of the great things about it is,

311
00:16:32.300 --> 00:16:36.050
let's say you have a game that you're
playing online, and you want to make sure

312
00:16:36.050 --> 00:16:39.500
that when that information comes in
it goes directly to your gaming PC.

313
00:16:39.500 --> 00:16:42.110
Well, that's where port
forwarding comes in.

314
00:16:42.110 --> 00:16:46.180
Port forwarding will tell the wireless
router, access point, if you will, or

315
00:16:46.180 --> 00:16:49.046
even the wired router that,
again, this is not a wireless,

316
00:16:49.046 --> 00:16:54.170
wired standard, it tells the device okay,
I see that gaming traffic.

317
00:16:54.170 --> 00:16:56.000
Send it that direction.

318
00:16:56.000 --> 00:16:58.690
Another way we use this too, Dan,
I don't know if you've ever done this.

319
00:16:58.690 --> 00:17:01.900
Maybe connected from your work at one
place, the various places you've worked,

320
00:17:01.900 --> 00:17:05.011
back to your computer at home
over like an RDP connection or

321
00:17:05.011 --> 00:17:06.920
a remote desktop protocol connection.

322
00:17:06.920 --> 00:17:10.660
Well, if I've got five Windows
devices within my network and

323
00:17:10.660 --> 00:17:15.090
my router, wireless or wired,
says, I see RDP traffic.

324
00:17:15.090 --> 00:17:16.770
We've got ten Windows devices here.

325
00:17:16.770 --> 00:17:18.525
>> [LAUGH] Which one do you want, right?

326
00:17:18.525 --> 00:17:19.780
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, so.

327
00:17:19.780 --> 00:17:22.980
What port forwarding does is it says,
okay send it to this device.

328
00:17:22.980 --> 00:17:26.620
And yeah that's common to be
able to connect from work

329
00:17:26.620 --> 00:17:31.010
over the public network like the Internet
back and to your internal network.

330
00:17:31.010 --> 00:17:33.720
The other thing I mentioned
was port triggering

331
00:17:33.720 --> 00:17:36.690
one of the things I want you to keep in
mind is when it comes to port triggering,

332
00:17:36.690 --> 00:17:39.820
a little bit different here
concept is close to the same.

333
00:17:39.820 --> 00:17:42.670
And when we say port triggering,
what's the difference?

334
00:17:42.670 --> 00:17:47.120
Well, port forwarding understand
leaves that rule open all right?

335
00:17:47.120 --> 00:17:50.892
I want you to think of it as punching
a hole in the side of the pool, all right?

336
00:17:50.892 --> 00:17:53.920
And water can leak out, but
you're not fixing it, okay?

337
00:17:53.920 --> 00:17:56.690
I want you to think of port
triggering as the same thing,

338
00:17:56.690 --> 00:18:01.650
only you got the ability to put a plug,
put a cork in the hole in the pool.

339
00:18:01.650 --> 00:18:02.790
So you're saying wait a second.

340
00:18:02.790 --> 00:18:04.440
What the heck does that mean, all right?

341
00:18:04.440 --> 00:18:07.680
Well, port triggering is a way to
do the same thing, port forwarding.

342
00:18:07.680 --> 00:18:09.570
It's when I see this traffic,

343
00:18:09.570 --> 00:18:12.890
send it to a certain destination
within inside of my network.

344
00:18:12.890 --> 00:18:15.960
But after you're done, close it down.

345
00:18:15.960 --> 00:18:20.900
I don't want that hole always
open allowing communications

346
00:18:20.900 --> 00:18:22.240
permanently in my network.

347
00:18:22.240 --> 00:18:25.310
So port triggering is
dynamic port forwarding.

348
00:18:25.310 --> 00:18:29.080
In the fact that it opens the port, sends
the information where it needs to go, and

349
00:18:29.080 --> 00:18:30.570
then it closes that port down.

350
00:18:30.570 --> 00:18:32.930
And again, a great thing to have and

351
00:18:32.930 --> 00:18:36.580
you can set them up, there are rules
you can set up in order to do this.

352
00:18:36.580 --> 00:18:39.240
All right, so that's port forwarding.

353
00:18:39.240 --> 00:18:42.230
Now, in another episode we talked
about what the DHCP protocol is?

354
00:18:42.230 --> 00:18:44.375
And I know, it's kind of redundant here.

355
00:18:44.375 --> 00:18:45.900
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the dynamic host

356
00:18:45.900 --> 00:18:47.530
configuration protocol?

357
00:18:47.530 --> 00:18:50.210
Remember if you've got a lot of
mobile devices in your SOHOs.

358
00:18:50.210 --> 00:18:53.740
You got a lot of laptops that
are coming in and out of your network.

359
00:18:53.740 --> 00:18:56.460
Maybe you don't want to statically assign,

360
00:18:56.460 --> 00:19:00.550
manually assign every IP address
subnet mask default gateway.

361
00:19:00.550 --> 00:19:04.190
For the TCPIP properties of every
single device within your network.

362
00:19:04.190 --> 00:19:06.140
In fact, some people do.

363
00:19:06.140 --> 00:19:08.310
I know I've got quite a few
that I do this myself.

364
00:19:08.310 --> 00:19:09.850
And I believe you've got a media server.

365
00:19:09.850 --> 00:19:11.100
Does that have a static IP address?

366
00:19:11.100 --> 00:19:12.860
>> It does not have a static IP address.

367
00:19:12.860 --> 00:19:14.552
>> It does not, alright,
he's living on the wild side.

368
00:19:14.552 --> 00:19:15.386
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

369
00:19:15.386 --> 00:19:16.106
>> And some people do,

370
00:19:16.106 --> 00:19:20.036
they've got a specific device, that they
always wanna have the same IP address,

371
00:19:20.036 --> 00:19:23.156
right?
Well that would again get a little

372
00:19:23.156 --> 00:19:26.350
bit complicated if you're doing that
to every single device on your network.

373
00:19:26.350 --> 00:19:29.900
All right, so you have the ability to
dynamically assign the IP address.

374
00:19:29.900 --> 00:19:33.230
When the computer or the device connects
to your network it calls out to

375
00:19:33.230 --> 00:19:37.430
the network, like we've talked about with
DHCP and says hey, I need an IP address.

376
00:19:37.430 --> 00:19:38.350
Can you give me one?

377
00:19:38.350 --> 00:19:41.820
And your devices can provide
that configuration information.

378
00:19:41.820 --> 00:19:43.850
DHCP can be turned on, can be turned off.

379
00:19:43.850 --> 00:19:45.920
It's really up to you.

380
00:19:47.050 --> 00:19:49.820
Just remember that you have that ability,
okay?

381
00:19:49.820 --> 00:19:51.400
Sometimes you have to
actually turn it off.

382
00:19:51.400 --> 00:19:53.300
Sometimes your modems will do this for

383
00:19:53.300 --> 00:19:57.370
And understand that your modem is
the first connection from your cable

384
00:19:57.370 --> 00:19:59.620
company into your network.

385
00:19:59.620 --> 00:20:01.920
And then behind that a lot of
time sits your router, right?

386
00:20:01.920 --> 00:20:03.150
Your wireless access point.

387
00:20:03.150 --> 00:20:08.940
So if the modem is doing DHCP,
you might turn it off on the access point.

388
00:20:08.940 --> 00:20:13.590
Vice versa, a lot of times you have
the ability to log into a modem.

389
00:20:13.590 --> 00:20:17.630
Turn the DHCP off and say I want to do it
on the router because I wanna control it.

390
00:20:17.630 --> 00:20:21.460
So it's a level of control that you
can choose or not to choose to use.

391
00:20:21.460 --> 00:20:24.270
>> Yeah, what I typically do is,
because I have cable, right?

392
00:20:24.270 --> 00:20:29.520
So my cable modem is doing DHCP, and I'm
getting an IP address from my ISP, right?

393
00:20:29.520 --> 00:20:31.400
They're giving me one of their own.

394
00:20:31.400 --> 00:20:37.830
So when I hook up my wireless router,
it's giving it a DHCP address, right?

395
00:20:37.830 --> 00:20:40.200
But it also has DHCP installed.

396
00:20:40.200 --> 00:20:44.680
Now, I can either try to get my
DHCP server to work well with my

397
00:20:44.680 --> 00:20:46.110
cable modem's DHCP server.

398
00:20:46.110 --> 00:20:48.990
But typically what I do is just make
sure they are in different ranges, and

399
00:20:48.990 --> 00:20:51.300
then allow the two to talk together and

400
00:20:51.300 --> 00:20:54.160
then basically separating the networks
using my wireless access point.

401
00:20:54.160 --> 00:20:57.250
>> That's a really good design,
saying hey we're gonna hand out

402
00:20:57.250 --> 00:21:01.595
this stack of cards or
IP addresses to a certain many devices.

403
00:21:01.595 --> 00:21:02.930
>> Right.
>> This stack of cards or

404
00:21:02.930 --> 00:21:04.750
stack of IP addresses will be handed out.

405
00:21:04.750 --> 00:21:07.710
It's a really good configuration
that you've got there.

406
00:21:07.710 --> 00:21:11.120
Now, some of the other things that we
wanna talk about when we say SOHOs.

407
00:21:11.120 --> 00:21:13.270
SOHO wireless or wired,

408
00:21:13.270 --> 00:21:16.035
again now understand some of the concepts
that we're talking about here.

409
00:21:16.035 --> 00:21:17.845
The channels are specific to wireless.

410
00:21:17.845 --> 00:21:21.705
Everything else that we've talked
about could be wired or wireless.

411
00:21:21.705 --> 00:21:23.595
So, they talk about what's known as a DMZ.

412
00:21:24.885 --> 00:21:29.650
The level in which you can do this,
is really contingent on how good,

413
00:21:29.650 --> 00:21:32.710
the wireless or wired router is.

414
00:21:32.710 --> 00:21:35.670
Some basic home routers
allow you to do this.

415
00:21:35.670 --> 00:21:38.410
Sometimes you do have to get
a higher-priced router just because it's

416
00:21:38.410 --> 00:21:40.410
more of a business class functionality.

417
00:21:40.410 --> 00:21:43.060
And that's something known again
as the demilitarized zone.

418
00:21:43.060 --> 00:21:44.780
So DMZ, what does that mean?

419
00:21:44.780 --> 00:21:46.330
All right,
well I got a little diagram here and

420
00:21:46.330 --> 00:21:48.880
a lot of times in the SOHO
environments what happens is,

421
00:21:48.880 --> 00:21:51.880
that we do this a little bit different
in the Enterprise Networks, for

422
00:21:51.880 --> 00:21:55.815
the reasons that we do this, but If you
will the concepts are still the same.

423
00:21:55.815 --> 00:22:00.925
A DMZ what it does is it takes and
it creates this logical, so in software,

424
00:22:00.925 --> 00:22:05.435
this logical perimeter
network if you will.

425
00:22:05.435 --> 00:22:08.222
A network outside of your network.

426
00:22:08.222 --> 00:22:09.662
Well why would you want to do that?

427
00:22:09.662 --> 00:22:11.392
Well if I'm out there on the Internet,
right?

428
00:22:11.392 --> 00:22:12.962
If this young lady is out
there on the Internet,

429
00:22:12.962 --> 00:22:17.072
maybe she's hosting a web
server in her internal network.

430
00:22:17.072 --> 00:22:20.542
And she wants to gain public
access to that one device.

431
00:22:21.582 --> 00:22:23.902
Well, in order to do that right?

432
00:22:23.902 --> 00:22:28.302
Public access she might have
to do port forwarding, right?

433
00:22:28.302 --> 00:22:31.790
But what if she wants a few other
people to have access to it as well.

434
00:22:31.790 --> 00:22:35.340
Well, you don't want people to have
access to your internal network.

435
00:22:35.340 --> 00:22:39.410
So what a DMZ does is it essentially
creates two firewalls, right?

436
00:22:39.410 --> 00:22:41.090
A firewall is something that allows or

437
00:22:41.090 --> 00:22:44.350
denies traffic based on rules,
a security implementation.

438
00:22:44.350 --> 00:22:48.550
Well this kind of logically
creates an external firewall and

439
00:22:48.550 --> 00:22:49.680
an internal firewall.

440
00:22:49.680 --> 00:22:54.050
Think of the two brick walls and then
in the middle of that you put a single

441
00:22:54.050 --> 00:22:56.830
computer that you want to expose
the access to the Internet, right?

442
00:22:56.830 --> 00:22:59.110
Without exposing the rest of your network,

00:23:56.463 --> 00:24:00.927

00:24:12.006 --> 00:24:13.951
However, that would be very expensive,

00:24:13.951 --> 00:24:16.350
if we were to try to do that

00:24:16.350 --> 00:24:20.637
So what we use is a technology

00:24:20.637 --> 00:24:23.220

00:24:23.220 --> 00:24:25.867

00:24:40.900 --> 00:24:44.290
