00:33:46.820 --> 00:33:50.770
Before anybody,
before I'm even, realize it.

667
00:33:50.770 --> 00:33:53.818
Don't worry about any of these settings,
you wanna know acknowledgement there,

668
00:33:53.818 --> 00:33:56.220
that just means,
did you receive the information?

669
00:33:56.220 --> 00:33:57.970
No, I didn't receive the information but

670
00:33:57.970 --> 00:34:01.720
those are essentially some of the things
you can see inside your wireless routers.

671
00:34:01.720 --> 00:34:03.921
And keep in mind that, your wired routers,

672
00:34:03.921 --> 00:34:06.670
a lot of times have these
same types of interfaces.

673
00:34:06.670 --> 00:34:09.168
You know what, let me do one more thing,
speaking of wireless,

674
00:34:09.168 --> 00:34:10.850
I didn't even show you guys the wireless.

675
00:34:10.850 --> 00:34:14.940
So let me just show you this real quick,
here's the wireless section and

676
00:34:14.940 --> 00:34:17.419
if I change it to manual
notice that we have,

677
00:34:17.419 --> 00:34:20.430
you can see the five
gigahertz spectrum here.

678
00:34:20.430 --> 00:34:25.700
And I told you Auto (DFS), that's dynamic
frequency selection, and channel-width.

679
00:34:25.700 --> 00:34:29.360
You can do and yeah,
let's change this to Auto, here we go.

680
00:34:29.360 --> 00:34:32.530
Now you can see some of the channels
that are available here

681
00:34:32.530 --> 00:34:34.750
inside of the access point.

682
00:34:34.750 --> 00:34:38.810
Same thing with the 2.4
GHz wireless settings.

683
00:34:38.810 --> 00:34:42.450
Notice that I can also do Auto here,
and if I scroll down,

684
00:34:42.450 --> 00:34:45.140
there are those 11
different channels there.

685
00:34:45.140 --> 00:34:48.425
Dan that we were talking about remember
if you do this manually 1, 6, 11.

686
00:34:48.425 --> 00:34:51.626
And a lot of times what we do
is we just leave it to auto.

687
00:34:51.626 --> 00:34:55.410
The device is smart enough to know hey,
I'm a little bogged down here.

688
00:34:55.410 --> 00:34:56.694
Chances are I'm gonna have to flip over.

689
00:34:56.694 --> 00:35:00.914
So all great stuff to have guys if
you have wireless access point.

690
00:35:00.914 --> 00:35:04.460
Don't hesitate to jump in there and
kinda look at the settings.

691
00:35:04.460 --> 00:35:05.169
Check your manufacturers.

692
00:35:05.169 --> 00:35:06.644
Dan that was a great piece of advice,

693
00:35:06.644 --> 00:35:10.080
check your manufacturer's defined settings
as well as what the recommendation is.

694
00:35:10.080 --> 00:35:13.130
A lot of the manufacturers will give
you some good advice on how to peak and

695
00:35:13.130 --> 00:35:15.830
tweak that Soho router so
you get the best experience possible.

696
00:35:15.830 --> 00:35:19.173
>> All right, well that wraps
up working with a Soho type

697
00:35:19.173 --> 00:35:22.232
wireless router device very,
very cool stuff.

698
00:35:22.232 --> 00:35:25.458
And the good news is it's probably not
something that's Super unfamiliar to

699
00:35:25.458 --> 00:35:26.060
you, right?

700
00:35:26.060 --> 00:35:28.200
Wireless is very ubiquitous today, so

701
00:35:28.200 --> 00:35:30.170
you've probably had at
least some experience.

702
00:35:30.170 --> 00:35:31.980
If you haven't, do what Wes said.

703
00:35:31.980 --> 00:35:32.600
Go grab you one.

704
00:35:32.600 --> 00:35:33.460
They're relatively cheap.

705
00:35:33.460 --> 00:35:37.270
Buy one on Ebay or Craigslist or something
that you can destroy and play with and

706
00:35:37.270 --> 00:35:37.910
do whatever you want.

707
00:35:37.910 --> 00:35:40.410
And start learning the technology
with some of that hands on.

708
00:35:40.410 --> 00:35:42.780
That's what's really gonna
benefit you in the long run.

709
00:35:42.780 --> 00:35:45.311
All right Wes thanks for joining us today
and we do thank our audience for watching.

710
00:35:45.311 --> 00:35:49.460
But it is that time for us to sign off for
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

711
00:35:49.460 --> 00:35:50.443
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

712
00:35:50.443 --> 00:35:51.619
>> And we'll see you next time.

713
00:35:51.619 --> 00:35:58.987
[MUSIC]

714
00:35:58.987 --> 00:36:01.344
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes compare and contrast different internet connection types, network types, and their features. Specific types covered here includes: Cable, DSL, Dial-up, Fiber, Satellite, ISDN, Cellular, Tethering, Mobile Hotspots, Line-of-Sight, LANs, WANs, PANs, and MANs.
episodes.title: Internet Connections and Network Types
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.220
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.220 --> 00:00:04.440
I am your host Don Pezet.

3
00:00:04.440 --> 00:00:06.487
>> Coming to you live from [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.487 --> 00:00:08.229
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.229 --> 00:00:11.911
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.911 --> 00:00:12.543
>> All right.

7
00:00:12.543 --> 00:00:15.900
Greetings everyone and welcome to
another great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:15.900 --> 00:00:17.730
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and

9
00:00:17.730 --> 00:00:21.400
in today's episode it's more in our
A+ Series of thread to get old.

10
00:00:21.400 --> 00:00:24.220
22901 for those of you keeping score.

11
00:00:24.220 --> 00:00:28.470
And joining us in the studio, yet again
today our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:28.470 --> 00:00:30.400
Wes, glad to have you again,
man how's it going?

13
00:00:30.400 --> 00:00:33.110
>> Man, it's going great,
feeling good here glad to be here and

14
00:00:33.110 --> 00:00:34.240
we are moving along.

15
00:00:34.240 --> 00:00:38.000
In fact we're, I would say if I'm keeping
score you guys are keeping track out here.

16
00:00:38.000 --> 00:00:41.518
I think we're in, just about one of
the last networking episodes that we gotta

17
00:00:41.518 --> 00:00:42.760
cover for the 901 exam.

18
00:00:42.760 --> 00:00:44.896
And well,
what are we gonna be talking about today?

19
00:00:44.896 --> 00:00:47.126
But we're gonna be taking
about some of the connections.

20
00:00:47.126 --> 00:00:50.935
And the connections I mean are the
services that are provided out there along

21
00:00:50.935 --> 00:00:51.980
the Internet.

22
00:00:51.980 --> 00:00:54.922
We're gonna talk a little bit about
the different types of connections

23
00:00:54.922 --> 00:00:55.467
you can see.

24
00:00:55.467 --> 00:00:57.591
And we're also gonna
talk about network types.

25
00:00:57.591 --> 00:01:01.071
Dan and I we've mentioned some acronyms,
boy have we mentioned some acronyms,

26
00:01:01.071 --> 00:01:02.823
as you guys and gals out there have seen.

27
00:01:02.823 --> 00:01:05.817
And there are some geographical
locations if you will,

28
00:01:05.817 --> 00:01:08.309
that really define
different network types.

29
00:01:08.309 --> 00:01:12.095
And that'd be one of the things that will
be looking at right towards the end of

30
00:01:12.095 --> 00:01:12.860
this episode.

31
00:01:12.860 --> 00:01:15.496
So, let's go ahead and
let's dive right in.

32
00:01:15.496 --> 00:01:17.955
And when we talk about internet
connection types well,

33
00:01:17.955 --> 00:01:20.430
where are our Internet
connections coming from?

34
00:01:20.430 --> 00:01:22.070
Well they're coming from
a service provider.

35
00:01:22.070 --> 00:01:24.050
Maybe you've heard the term ISP.

36
00:01:24.050 --> 00:01:27.440
If you haven't heard of the term ISP,
well maybe you're not paying the bill.

37
00:01:27.440 --> 00:01:30.310
[LAUGH] ISP is
the Internet Service Provider and

38
00:01:30.310 --> 00:01:33.630
they are the ones, they
are the companies out there if you will,

39
00:01:33.630 --> 00:01:36.510
that really give you
the connection to the Internet.

40
00:01:36.510 --> 00:01:39.400
Now I want you to know that the Internet
really is a hierarchical design

41
00:01:39.400 --> 00:01:41.200
when we talk about Internet
service providers.

42
00:01:41.200 --> 00:01:45.147
In fact, you go all the way to
the top part of the hierarchy.

43
00:01:45.147 --> 00:01:47.328
And you have a lot of standards bodies,

44
00:01:47.328 --> 00:01:50.810
regulatory bodies if
you will that oversee.

45
00:01:50.810 --> 00:01:55.200
And design specifications for
what we know as the Internet today.

46
00:01:55.200 --> 00:01:56.310
The Internet, if you will,

47
00:01:56.310 --> 00:02:01.870
actually started out as
a military/educational type network.

48
00:02:01.870 --> 00:02:05.050
And when I say educational type network,
we're not talking about PBS or

49
00:02:05.050 --> 00:02:05.750
Sesame Street here.

50
00:02:05.750 --> 00:02:10.510
But what we're talking about is was
really just about the military's use of

51
00:02:10.510 --> 00:02:14.440
network communications as well
as different universities.

52
00:02:14.440 --> 00:02:17.990
And that's really all that was
connected to in those days.

53
00:02:17.990 --> 00:02:19.812
In fact, in the early days,
it was called ARPANET.

54
00:02:19.812 --> 00:02:24.275
And ARPANET was the Advanced
Research Project Agency's Network.

55
00:02:24.275 --> 00:02:27.353
And they got into, I guess you'd say,
a coalition if you will,

56
00:02:27.353 --> 00:02:31.001
with a lot of the brilliant minds in
different universities like Stanford,

57
00:02:31.001 --> 00:02:32.150
Berkley, if you will.

58
00:02:32.150 --> 00:02:38.640
And essentially, formed and developed
what would later be called the Internet.

59
00:02:38.640 --> 00:02:39.770
So what happened?

60
00:02:39.770 --> 00:02:43.140
Why this transformation for
ARPANET to the Internet?

61
00:02:43.140 --> 00:02:47.130
Well, at a certain time, the ARPANET
became yesterdays technology, and

62
00:02:47.130 --> 00:02:50.450
the military said, okay,
hey as things have advanced.

63
00:02:50.450 --> 00:02:52.960
We need a little bit more
protection within our networks.

64
00:02:52.960 --> 00:02:54.680
And the ARPANET really
isn't giving us that,

65
00:02:54.680 --> 00:02:58.130
because we just started having more and
more people connecting to it.

66
00:02:58.130 --> 00:03:00.730
So eventually what would
happen is the government,

67
00:03:00.730 --> 00:03:02.570
our Department of Defense
here in the United States,

68
00:03:02.570 --> 00:03:06.970
would basically allocate what would
become the Internet, the ARPANET.

69
00:03:06.970 --> 00:03:09.910
Over to the public domain and
then it would be from there on out,

70
00:03:09.910 --> 00:03:13.850
it would be overseen by bodies that pretty
much were overseeing it to begin with.

71
00:03:13.850 --> 00:03:14.600
IANA, if you will.

72
00:03:14.600 --> 00:03:17.250
We've kind of talked about them throughout
the series when we talked about

73
00:03:17.250 --> 00:03:17.760
networking.

74
00:03:17.760 --> 00:03:22.060
The Internet Assign Numbers Authority and
then in 2003 formally,

75
00:03:22.060 --> 00:03:26.260
their defense contracts expired and
another company,

76
00:03:26.260 --> 00:03:29.800
a corporation if you will, took over
what we see today, and that's ICANN.

77
00:03:29.800 --> 00:03:33.140
That s the Internet Corporation for
Assigned Names and Numbers.

78
00:03:33.140 --> 00:03:36.090
And military essentially did a split,
right?

79
00:03:36.090 --> 00:03:37.560
They have the MILNET today and

80
00:03:37.560 --> 00:03:41.320
that's highly locked down,
that's the private military network.

81
00:03:41.320 --> 00:03:42.930
And then we have the public Internet.

82
00:03:42.930 --> 00:03:46.410
So that's a little bit about the history
behind the Internet, if you will.

83
00:03:46.410 --> 00:03:49.566
I also wanna talk about a couple of
different types of connections you can see

84
00:03:49.566 --> 00:03:51.104
out there as well, very basically.

85
00:03:51.104 --> 00:03:55.490
You have two different types
of means of communication.

86
00:03:55.490 --> 00:03:57.400
Actually, three different types really.

87
00:03:57.400 --> 00:04:00.490
One of the most prevalent types is what's
known as a packet switching network.

88
00:04:00.490 --> 00:04:04.040
And when we talk about a packet switching
network, we're talking about packets,

89
00:04:04.040 --> 00:04:04.630
if you will.

90
00:04:04.630 --> 00:04:07.791
Your data can be broken down into
these data units called packets.

91
00:04:07.791 --> 00:04:11.061
And they can route their
way across the Internet.

92
00:04:11.061 --> 00:04:15.392
And essentially, can be rebuilt and
find their way to the destination, and

93
00:04:15.392 --> 00:04:18.650
not necessarily does every
packet follow the same path.

94
00:04:18.650 --> 00:04:21.250
In fact, a lot of times,
rarely do they ever.

95
00:04:21.250 --> 00:04:23.160
And the thought process was, and

96
00:04:23.160 --> 00:04:25.320
I know there's a little conjecture
on the history behind this.

97
00:04:25.320 --> 00:04:27.690
But the thought process was,
is back in the days when the military,

98
00:04:27.690 --> 00:04:28.900
the Department of Defense, had it.

99
00:04:28.900 --> 00:04:32.170
What would happen during war times,
if a large portion of the network

100
00:04:32.170 --> 00:04:36.515
was eradicated or
just completely annihilated in war, right?

101
00:04:36.515 --> 00:04:40.360
It's the fact that the not so much self
healing, but that the data would have to

102
00:04:40.360 --> 00:04:44.390
find it's way around those broken portions
of network and still get to the end point.

103
00:04:44.390 --> 00:04:45.940
So it's a very common technology.

104
00:04:45.940 --> 00:04:49.632
In fact, Ethernet,
that we have in our local area networks,

105
00:04:49.632 --> 00:04:52.829
is the dominant local area
network communications.

106
00:04:52.829 --> 00:04:55.650
That's the network types that
we'll talk about coming up.

107
00:04:55.650 --> 00:04:58.230
Now you also have other types
of communications as well,

108
00:04:58.230 --> 00:04:59.060
we have two other ones.

109
00:04:59.060 --> 00:05:01.140
The other one is called
Circuit Switching Network.

110
00:05:01.140 --> 00:05:04.310
And these are going to be some of the
first type of connections we talk about.

111
00:05:04.310 --> 00:05:07.250
Circuit Switching is,
think about your telephones.

112
00:05:07.250 --> 00:05:09.751
Your telephone communication
is a circuit switch network.

113
00:05:09.751 --> 00:05:13.913
And that's because you have some kind of
either physical dedicated connection.

114
00:05:13.913 --> 00:05:17.626
That is established, maintained for
the duration of the communication.

115
00:05:17.626 --> 00:05:21.670
And that communication goes
across that dedicated connection.

116
00:05:21.670 --> 00:05:25.049
And then once you no longer need
that connection, what happens is,

117
00:05:25.049 --> 00:05:26.249
the circuit is broken.

118
00:05:26.249 --> 00:05:30.260
And those resources go back over in to
the pool of resources that additional

119
00:05:30.260 --> 00:05:31.670
communications can use.

120
00:05:31.670 --> 00:05:33.911
Now, I say physical connections,
keep in mind, today,

121
00:05:33.911 --> 00:05:36.399
there's also logical connections
that do circuit switching.

122
00:05:36.399 --> 00:05:39.164
And that's where you have
some kind of logical path,

123
00:05:39.164 --> 00:05:41.570
sort of virtual circuit
that is established.

124
00:05:41.570 --> 00:05:46.080
And it appears to us, if you will, in
software's being a dedicated connection.

125
00:05:46.080 --> 00:05:50.090
And again, if you will, once that
communication is no longer needed.

126
00:05:50.090 --> 00:05:55.496
Then what happens is that pool,
if you will, of resources, goes back into,

127
00:05:55.496 --> 00:06:00.145
collectively, the network for
additional connections, communications.

128
00:06:01.185 --> 00:06:05.665
Now, so the last one here, you'll learn
more about Network Plus, I just want

129
00:06:05.665 --> 00:06:08.385
to brief mention on this one and that's
also called a Cell Switching Network.

130
00:06:08.385 --> 00:06:12.080
Don't think cellular communications,
but we talk about a cellular network.

131
00:06:12.080 --> 00:06:16.740
We talk about a fixed length data
size versus a packet switching,

132
00:06:16.740 --> 00:06:21.490
which every individual data unit called
a packet can actually be varying sizes.

133
00:06:21.490 --> 00:06:25.770
Unlike a cell switching network,
in a cell switching network if you will,

134
00:06:25.770 --> 00:06:30.680
every single data unit is going
to be the same, the same size.

135
00:06:30.680 --> 00:06:35.350
And if it isn't the same size, then we put
a little padding or filler data in there.

136
00:06:35.350 --> 00:06:37.786
All right, so just kinda getting that
out of the way before we dive into our

137
00:06:37.786 --> 00:06:38.585
Internet connection.

138
00:06:38.585 --> 00:06:42.586
Just some of the different kinda
technologies that you might hear,

139
00:06:42.586 --> 00:06:44.359
could hear, on the A+ exam.

140
00:06:44.359 --> 00:06:47.200
And again,
really brief they might mention that.

141
00:06:47.200 --> 00:06:49.920
But you'll definitely hear
about it in the NETPLUS.

142
00:06:49.920 --> 00:06:52.550
So, that form in the basis for
the Internet connections.

143
00:06:52.550 --> 00:06:55.150
When we talk about Internet connections,
keep in mind that essentially,

144
00:06:55.150 --> 00:06:59.380
the Internet is nothing but a bunch of
small networks that are inter-networked

145
00:06:59.380 --> 00:07:02.720
together and controlled by these
Internet service providers.

146
00:07:02.720 --> 00:07:05.170
As we come down the hierarchy,

147
00:07:05.170 --> 00:07:09.200
I want you to understand that we have what
are known as Internet backbone providers.

148
00:07:09.200 --> 00:07:14.460
Internet backbone providers, these are the
companies that lay the cables that form

149
00:07:14.460 --> 00:07:15.670
the Internet as we know it today.

150
00:07:16.930 --> 00:07:17.780
They're called the IVP.

151
00:07:17.780 --> 00:07:19.970
There's a,
think like nine of them world wide,

152
00:07:19.970 --> 00:07:22.598
you don't have to know this but
people like Verizon, AT&T,

153
00:07:22.598 --> 00:07:26.560
well course AT&T's been in communication
since communication started, right?

154
00:07:26.560 --> 00:07:29.390
>> Definitely one of
the major players in this

155
00:07:29.390 --> 00:07:31.820
telecom world of which we're diving into.

156
00:07:31.820 --> 00:07:32.970
>> Yeah, definitely.

157
00:07:32.970 --> 00:07:35.371
And then as you go down,
you have things like regional ISPs.

158
00:07:35.371 --> 00:07:39.410
And they literally, like it says,
they control major regions.

159
00:07:39.410 --> 00:07:41.660
And then you have your local ISPs.

160
00:07:41.660 --> 00:07:44.800
We'll give you an example here Dan and
I Live in the Gainesville area,

161
00:07:44.800 --> 00:07:48.230
we have GRUCom, which is G-R-U,
Gainesville Regional Units.

162
00:07:48.230 --> 00:07:51.832
And then, maybe you guys have heard
of them out there, Cox Communication.

163
00:07:51.832 --> 00:07:57.154
Some of you might come from where maybe
you have, Brighthouse is one of them.

164
00:07:57.154 --> 00:07:59.044
Some of them kind of crossed the line and

165
00:07:59.044 --> 00:08:01.290
there just dominate all
over the place AT&T.

166
00:08:01.290 --> 00:08:03.712
>> AT&T [LAUGH]
>> Like Dan here has mentioned [LAUGH],

167
00:08:03.712 --> 00:08:04.870
its been around for along time.

168
00:08:04.870 --> 00:08:09.034
They're an Internet Service Provider or
backbone provider, they're a regional

169
00:08:09.034 --> 00:08:12.550
provider and they're a local provider,
Verizon being the same way.

170
00:08:12.550 --> 00:08:17.590
So keep in mind, when you get
a service from the Internet, right?

171
00:08:17.590 --> 00:08:21.370
The Internet Service Provider, I don't
care who it is if its local if you will,

172
00:08:21.370 --> 00:08:25.010
understand that your local
service provider doesn't give you

173
00:08:25.010 --> 00:08:28.560
access to the backbone of the Internet,
right, cuz they don't own it.

174
00:08:28.560 --> 00:08:29.680
Those are the IBPs.

175
00:08:29.680 --> 00:08:32.421
They're the ones that have
access to these large,

176
00:08:32.421 --> 00:08:34.788
massive communication channels, right?

177
00:08:34.788 --> 00:08:37.486
And essentially what they do
is they lease a connection to

178

the old timers out there that say,

400
00:19:56.756 --> 00:19:59.381
hey I remember when we had 28.8, right?

401
00:19:59.381 --> 00:20:05.325
And when I got a 56k modem, my gosh,
we're talking about double the speeds.

402
00:20:05.325 --> 00:20:06.519
>> I remember 14.4.

403
00:20:06.519 --> 00:20:07.846
>> Yeah, absolutely.

404
00:20:07.846 --> 00:20:08.588
>> I had 14.4.

405
00:20:08.588 --> 00:20:12.503
>> And what's kinda interesting about
that Dan, is when you say 14.4,

406
00:20:12.503 --> 00:20:15.534
28.8, 56k,
you could kinda see it doubling, and

407
00:20:15.534 --> 00:20:19.030
ISDN was one of those that
would double it yet again.

408
00:20:19.030 --> 00:20:22.190
So know the Basic Rate Interface,
again kinda know the speeds,

409
00:20:22.190 --> 00:20:23.720
128 kilobits per second.

410
00:20:23.720 --> 00:20:27.070
As you go into Network+,
we'll get a little bit more in depth.

411
00:20:27.070 --> 00:20:30.190
We'll talk about things like bear
channels and delta channels.

412
00:20:30.190 --> 00:20:33.170
I think that's beyond the scope
of this exam right here.

413
00:20:33.170 --> 00:20:35.870
All right, now that being said,
here's one that you probably have seen and

414
00:20:35.870 --> 00:20:39.540
is still heavily used as well, and
that's the last one in our list here.

415
00:20:39.540 --> 00:20:43.240
So far we've talked about dial-up,
ISDN and that is DSL,

416
00:20:43.240 --> 00:20:45.613
that is the Digital Subscriber Line.

417
00:20:45.613 --> 00:20:49.834
We talk about Digital Subscriber Line,
keep in mind, this is also another

418
00:20:49.834 --> 00:20:53.930
form of those digital communications
that we have to be aware of.

419
00:20:53.930 --> 00:20:55.787
There's a couple of different kinds of,

420
00:20:55.787 --> 00:20:58.440
actually there's quite a few
different kinds out there but

421
00:20:58.440 --> 00:21:01.955
there are, really there's one that we
used more than all, and that's ADSL.

422
00:21:01.955 --> 00:21:05.021
You'll see there's all kind, VDSL,
there's very high speed DSL.

423
00:21:05.021 --> 00:21:07.790
Actually, I think it might even be VHDSL.

424
00:21:07.790 --> 00:21:09.914
Right, the ones that we're looking at,
again,

425
00:21:09.914 --> 00:21:12.100
with the Digital Subscriber Line
is gonna be ADSL.

426
00:21:12.100 --> 00:21:15.021
This is the one that's kinda common
inside of residential areas.

427
00:21:15.021 --> 00:21:16.966
And what do we mean by ADSL?

428
00:21:16.966 --> 00:21:19.990
We're talking about asymmetric
digital subscriber line.

429
00:21:19.990 --> 00:21:24.630
And the asymmetric nature of it
which means, that your downloads and

430
00:21:24.630 --> 00:21:29.922
your uploads are different bandwidth,
they're different speeds, right?

431
00:21:29.922 --> 00:21:36.744
You might hear something called
upstream versus downstream, all right?

432
00:21:36.744 --> 00:21:38.267
If we say downstream,

433
00:21:38.267 --> 00:21:43.280
what we're talking about is from
our computer out to the Internet.

434
00:21:43.280 --> 00:21:47.250
Right, and what that would be is
a digital to analog conversion.

435
00:21:47.250 --> 00:21:49.120
We talk about those modems,
that's downstream,

436
00:21:49.120 --> 00:21:52.010
that's from let's say Dan's
computer out there to the Internet.

437
00:21:52.010 --> 00:21:55.962
Upstream means, it's coming from
the provider into your network, right.

438
00:21:55.962 --> 00:21:58.538
And that is over the analog base network,

439
00:21:58.538 --> 00:22:03.380
basically converting it through
the DSL modem into the digital signal.

440
00:22:03.380 --> 00:22:09.030
The other thing I might mention too about
your DSL, Digital Subscriber Line is,

441
00:22:09.030 --> 00:22:13.740
unlike things like cable television,
and your dial-up,

442
00:22:13.740 --> 00:22:18.000
it actually has a splitter that splits
your signal, your digital signal,

443
00:22:18.000 --> 00:22:23.890
if you will, going into your computer
versus your telephone signal there.

444
00:22:23.890 --> 00:22:27.204
Let's see, anything else that
I think we might have to use.

445
00:22:27.204 --> 00:22:31.530
Use the PTSN, the pots lines,
keep in mind, that there's a relatively,

446
00:22:31.530 --> 00:22:33.932
of all the DSL types you'll learn about,

447
00:22:33.932 --> 00:22:38.549
it's definitely one of the shortest ones
when it comes to the communications.

448
00:22:39.610 --> 00:22:42.217
All right, so those are the three,
Dan, like I said,

449
00:22:42.217 --> 00:22:45.964
we got kinda since it's digital,
analog all going over the same technology,

450
00:22:45.964 --> 00:22:48.443
it kinda took care of that
one all in the same slide.

451
00:22:48.443 --> 00:22:52.354
Cuz to me, it kinda makes sense that
if there's a commonality behind them,

452
00:22:52.354 --> 00:22:55.690
then it makes a little bit more
sense to put them all in one.

453
00:22:55.690 --> 00:22:58.600
However, I'm looking at the time clock,
and we got a lot more to go but

454
00:22:58.600 --> 00:23:01.670
I'm not sure that we have
the availability in this episode.

455
00:23:01.670 --> 00:23:04.600
>> All right, Wes, definitely,
we can definitely do a part two,

456
00:23:04.600 --> 00:23:06.710
that's not a problem
around here at ITProTV.

457
00:23:06.710 --> 00:23:09.580
We would love to do those, and I know I
like doing these because it is all about

458
00:23:09.580 --> 00:23:11.660
networking and
its my wheelhouse, I enjoy it.

459
00:23:11.660 --> 00:23:15.130
Hopefully, you are as well, but like the
man has been alluding too, it is time for

460
00:23:15.130 --> 00:23:16.120
us to sign off.

461
00:23:16.120 --> 00:23:18.210
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

462
00:23:18.210 --> 00:23:19.250
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

463
00:23:19.250 --> 00:23:20.257
>> We'll see you next time.

464
00:23:20.257 --> 00:23:27.265
[MUSIC]

465
00:23:27.265 --> 00:23:30.621
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes compare and contrast different internet connection types, network types, and their features. Specific types covered here includes: Cable, DSL, Dial-up, Fiber, Satellite, ISDN, Cellular, Tethering, Mobile Hotspots, Line-of-Sight, LANs, WANs, PANs, and MANs.
episodes.title: Internet Connections and Network Types Part 2

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV,

2

3

4

>> All right, greetings, everyone and

00:00:15.914 --> 00:00:17.557
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

continuing on with more A+ series,

And joining us in the studio for those

12
00:00:28.930 --> 00:00:30.138
Wes, welcome back, sir how's it going?

13
00:00:30.138 --> 00:00:31.190
>> Man, it's going good.

14
00:00:31.190 --> 00:00:34.520
Good to be back here again, because I
certainly talked a lot in the first one,

15
00:00:34.520 --> 00:00:35.220
that's for sure.

16
00:00:35.220 --> 00:00:37.008
And-
>> You bumping your gums.

17
00:00:37.008 --> 00:00:37.640
>> Absolutely.

18
00:00:37.640 --> 00:00:39.540
And the first thing I
wanna kinda talk about,

19
00:00:39.540 --> 00:00:42.350
just a quick little recap on what
we talked about in the first part.

20
00:00:42.350 --> 00:00:45.080
Remember we were kinda letting you
know what you could expect behind

21
00:00:45.080 --> 00:00:46.800
the scenes when it comes to the Internet.

22
00:00:46.800 --> 00:00:48.540
I was telling Dan this before we started.

23
00:00:48.540 --> 00:00:52.475
I remember coming out of A+ thinking
that this Internet service provider,

24
00:00:52.475 --> 00:00:56.656
there's one person out there and they're
providing service to everybody and,

25
00:00:56.656 --> 00:01:00.550
I've gotta have access to the backbone
of the Internet only to learn that.

26
00:01:00.550 --> 00:01:02.377
Well, it's really divided
up in a hierarchy, and

27
00:01:02.377 --> 00:01:04.070
that there are different connection types.

28
00:01:04.070 --> 00:01:07.226
We talked about the difference between
circuit switching and packet switching.

29
00:01:07.226 --> 00:01:08.845
Briefly mentioned cell switching,

30
00:01:08.845 --> 00:01:11.618
you'll definitely learn more of
that if you get into Net Plus.

31
00:01:11.618 --> 00:01:15.071
And then we talked about,
if we can look here at the diagram,

32
00:01:15.071 --> 00:01:19.407
remember we talked about three primary or
three of these I guess you would say

33
00:01:19.407 --> 00:01:24.240
circuit switching type communications that
really are a digital to analog signal.

34
00:01:24.240 --> 00:01:25.172
Remember dial-up?

35
00:01:25.172 --> 00:01:27.560
ISDN and DSL all right?

36
00:01:27.560 --> 00:01:30.082
And if any of these don't sound
familiar to you, ladies and

37
00:01:30.082 --> 00:01:32.907
gentleman out there, go ahead and
go back to the first part here and

38
00:01:32.907 --> 00:01:34.689
then we'll see you back in part two here.

39
00:01:34.689 --> 00:01:37.962
Now, moving on we gotta talk
about another type of connection,

40
00:01:37.962 --> 00:01:41.160
internet connection out there and
that is fiber.

41
00:01:41.160 --> 00:01:47.812
And sometimes you can see today you can
see fiber connected straight to your home.

42
00:01:47.812 --> 00:01:52.690
For the longest time, the fiber optic
communications have been something that's

43
00:01:52.690 --> 00:01:54.460
really just seen in the ISP.

44
00:01:54.460 --> 00:01:57.327
So for instance here, SONET,
that we have on our screen,

45
00:01:57.327 --> 00:02:01.776
it's the Synchronous Optical Networking if
you will, and that's what it's called here

46
00:02:01.776 --> 00:02:05.756
in the States by the American National
Standards Institute the ones they oversee

47
00:02:05.756 --> 00:02:07.067
the standard if you will.

48
00:02:07.067 --> 00:02:09.934
In our European countries out
there we have what's known

49
00:02:09.934 --> 00:02:12.393
the International
Telecommunications Union.

50
00:02:12.393 --> 00:02:15.607
And what they call it is
the plesiochronous digital hierarchy,

51
00:02:15.607 --> 00:02:16.490
all right.

52
00:02:16.490 --> 00:02:21.051
So again kind of synonymous terms
there When it comes to our digital or

53
00:02:21.051 --> 00:02:23.109
fiber optic communications.

54
00:02:23.109 --> 00:02:27.464
But Dan, like I said, for a long time this
is the only place you would really find

55
00:02:27.464 --> 00:02:30.080
this is well,
really just inside of your ISPs.

56
00:02:30.080 --> 00:02:31.870
Why?
Well, let's go ahead and

57
00:02:31.870 --> 00:02:35.360
kind of go back to briefly a topic that we
talked about when we were talking about

58
00:02:35.360 --> 00:02:37.220
media types in another episode, right.

59
00:02:37.220 --> 00:02:39.966
We had mentioned Single-mode fiber,
multi-mode fiber.

60
00:02:39.966 --> 00:02:44.620
If you guys aren't aware of the specifics
definitely go back and check that out,

61
00:02:44.620 --> 00:02:45.647
but keep in mind,

62
00:02:45.647 --> 00:02:49.959
it really comes down to the overall
distances on which fiber mode you choose

63
00:02:49.959 --> 00:02:54.150
and how they transmit the communications
across the cabling all right.

64
00:02:54.150 --> 00:02:58.125
Now, when we look at internet connection
types, right, we're talking about,

65
00:02:58.125 --> 00:03:01.988
primarily, you're talking about single
mode communications just because of

66
00:03:01.988 --> 00:03:03.793
the long transmissions distances.

67
00:03:03.793 --> 00:03:07.850
Remember that one of the big differences
between multi mode fiber, and

68
00:03:07.850 --> 00:03:12.583
the single mode fiber is really that the
transmission, or the length I should say,

69
00:03:12.583 --> 00:03:17.198
of the cable, and it's potential for
high amounts of bandwidth.

70
00:03:17.198 --> 00:03:22.066
Your single most fire bursts could reach
cabling distances up to 40 kilometers on

71
00:03:22.066 --> 00:03:23.048
a single cable.

72
00:03:23.048 --> 00:03:27.169
That's 40,000 meters, that's a pretty good
stretch when you consider without having

73
00:03:27.169 --> 00:03:28.360
to use repeaters, right?

74
00:03:28.360 --> 00:03:30.960
And a repeater is nothing more than
something that receives a signal,

75
00:03:30.960 --> 00:03:33.990
doesn't matter if it's an electromagnetic
energy through a copper based media or

76
00:03:33.990 --> 00:03:36.610
it's an optical light source
through a fiber optic media.

77
00:03:36.610 --> 00:03:41.520
It regenerates the signal and
it allows it to extend that signal or

78
00:03:41.520 --> 00:03:46.070
that transmission across the full length
of an additional form of whatever your

79
00:03:46.070 --> 00:03:48.900
media is, whether it's copper based or
whether it's fiber optic based.

80
00:03:48.900 --> 00:03:53.310
So that's one of the reasons you see that
single mode cabling, a lot of times,

81
00:03:53.310 --> 00:03:57.480
is, and we have some in our server closets
as well, so don't let me confuse you.

82
00:03:57.480 --> 00:03:59.686
When you have what's known as
the demarcation point, and

83
00:03:59.686 --> 00:04:02.207
that's probably something we
should just briefly mention here,

84
00:04:02.207 --> 00:04:04.157
when we talk about Internet connections,
right.

85
00:04:04.157 --> 00:04:07.180
Because we have the ISP side,
your carrier,

86
00:04:07.180 --> 00:04:10.772
the telecommunications provider,
their network.

87
00:04:10.772 --> 00:04:15.720
You're not required to service you
shouldn't have access to, legally.

88
00:04:15.720 --> 00:04:19.210
And where that comes into your network and

89
00:04:19.210 --> 00:04:23.940
makes a connection to your network, that's
called a demarc, or the demarcation point.

90
00:04:23.940 --> 00:04:26.031
It really divides up
the point of responsibility.

91
00:04:26.031 --> 00:04:31.050
To the Telcos provider side,
they're responsible for that network.

92
00:04:31.050 --> 00:04:34.450
If a cable's dug up they
have to come out and fix it.

93
00:04:34.450 --> 00:04:40.008
However, on your business or
residential side of the demarcation point,

94
00:04:40.008 --> 00:04:44.155
anything that happens on that side,
you're digging or

95
00:04:44.155 --> 00:04:47.259
knocking a wall down and you cut the wire.

96
00:04:47.259 --> 00:04:51.709
That's gonna be you that's responsible for
it, so I don't want you to

97
00:04:51.709 --> 00:04:56.383
think that we don't have single-mode
fiber inside of our networks here,

98
00:04:56.383 --> 00:04:58.625
on that side of demarkation point.

99
00:04:58.625 --> 00:05:00.979
But primarily because
the transmission distance,

100
00:05:00.979 --> 00:05:04.140
is single mode is what's
gonna be used by your ISPs.

101
00:05:04.140 --> 00:05:06.990
Now again, I mentioned a little
bit about SONET, right?

102
00:05:06.990 --> 00:05:11.460
If we can go back to our diagram here I
do wanna just kinda talk about what kinda

103
00:05:11.460 --> 00:05:14.580
topology you're seeing here,
more of the specifics.

104
00:05:14.580 --> 00:05:17.189
Again, we'll get into the inside of Net+.

105
00:05:17.189 --> 00:05:20.905
Keep in mind that Sonet is
a very high speed network,

106
00:05:20.905 --> 00:05:24.207
we're talking past 10 gigabit per second.

107
00:05:24.207 --> 00:05:28.120
And again because of the larger bandwidth,
it gives the ability for

108
00:05:28.120 --> 00:05:32.515
the ISPs to take multitudes of these
cables, aggregate them together, and

109
00:05:32.515 --> 00:05:36.610
we're talking terabits of data
which is mind boggling, right?

110
00:05:36.610 --> 00:05:40.009
In its capacity to send
information across of it.

111
00:05:40.009 --> 00:05:44.055
SONET is also a dual ring topology it's
one of the great things about in the fact

112
00:05:44.055 --> 00:05:47.480
that you have a primary and
you have a secondary ring.

113
00:05:47.480 --> 00:05:51.060
And that allows for
a self healing fault tolerance.

114
00:05:51.060 --> 00:05:56.545
Fault tolerance, remember, is a way
that we can essentially continue to

115
00:05:56.545 --> 00:06:01.774
function when there's a foreseeable
Failure that happens, right?

116
00:06:01.774 --> 00:06:03.611
If we have two of something and one fails,

117
00:06:03.611 --> 00:06:06.310
the other one can take up
where the last one left off.

118
00:06:06.310 --> 00:06:09.260
And that's what you see in
your synchronous digital or

119
00:06:09.260 --> 00:06:10.990
synchronous optical networking.

120
00:06:10.990 --> 00:06:14.240
Keep in mind it is a fiber
optic based communication.

121
00:06:14.240 --> 00:06:17.280
Now the other thing that you're also
seeing in fiber optic communications is

122
00:06:17.280 --> 00:06:18.450
things like FiOS.

123
00:06:18.450 --> 00:06:23.341
I think Verizon has FiOS and that's a
residential fiber optics that can give you

124
00:06:23.341 --> 00:06:25.830
a potential for a great amount of speed.

125
00:06:25.830 --> 00:06:27.330
Google was another one.

126
00:06:27.330 --> 00:06:31.040
Here in Gainesville,
I wanna say it's about six years ago,

127
00:06:31.040 --> 00:06:35.431
they did a survey to see if people
would be on board with gigabit speeds.

128
00:06:35.431 --> 00:06:40.077
Again, sustained gigabit speeds over fiber
optic communications for whatever reason,

129
00:06:40.077 --> 00:06:43.190
whatever bureaucracy or
legality it didn't happen.

130
00:06:43.190 --> 00:06:47.204
And it's definitely in other cities too
where Google is literally becoming the ISP

131
00:06:47.204 --> 00:06:50.480
and bringing fiber optic communications
right to your residence.

132
00:06:50.480 --> 00:06:54.491
And again Verizon has things like FiOS
again which is a fiber optic service that

133
00:06:54.491 --> 00:06:56.450
they're providing too.

134
00:06:56.450 --> 00:07:01.863
At this point I wanna say on June of 2017,
here's a the little asterisk,

135
00:07:01.863 --> 00:07:06.443
the fine print, is that you really
have to check your community,

136
00:07:06.443 --> 00:07:08.544
your neighborhood, right?

137
00:07:08.544 --> 00:07:12.200
Your region, and to see if it's
something that is available.

138
00:07:12.200 --> 00:07:15.098
Typically fiber optic communications
are gonna be expensive, right?

139
00:07:15.098 --> 00:07:16.937
You're gonna have an expense,

140
00:07:16.937 --> 00:07:20.710
it's gonna be a lot more expense
over a copper based media.

141
00:07:20.710 --> 00:07:25.230
Copper based media copper based devices
they're typically less expensive than

142
00:07:25.230 --> 00:07:26.710
their fiber optic counterparts.

143
00:07:26.710 --> 00:07:29.060
However, there's also pros and cons.

144
00:07:29.060 --> 00:07:31.880
You talk about ISDN you talk about
DSL you talk about cable TV,

145
00:07:31.880 --> 00:07:34.934
even dial up you're talking about
a copper based communication.

146
00:07:34.934 --> 00:07:38.988
They're susceptible to things like
electromagnetic interference which also

147
00:07:38.988 --> 00:07:43.560
reduces the quality of the feed,
the quality of the communication as well.

148
00:07:43.560 --> 00:07:45.800
And it reduces Is the price point too.

149
00:07:45.800 --> 00:07:47.870
However fiber optic media, again,

150
00:07:47.870 --> 00:07:52.478
that the counter to that is the fact that
it isn't susceptible to electromagnetic

151
00:07:52.478 --> 00:07:55.548
interference and
it can give you a lot more bandwidth,

152
00:07:55.548 --> 00:08:00.052
a lot more speed, potential for better
performance if you will in the long run.

153
00:08:00.052 --> 00:08:03.851
But it usually comes at
a significant price point.

154
00:08:03.851 --> 00:08:05.982
So you are saying if it's available and
you have the means,

155
00:08:05.982 --> 00:08:07.184
it's definitely the way to fly?

156
00:08:07.184 --> 00:08:08.705
>> Most definitely,

another great episode.

622
00:30:20.770 --> 00:30:23.630
Hopefully you feel that way and
you come back for

623
00:30:23.630 --> 00:30:25.490
more because we have more A+ coming.

624
00:30:25.490 --> 00:30:27.630
But, let's go ahead and
sign off for ITProTV,

625
00:30:27.630 --> 00:30:29.370
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

626
00:30:29.370 --> 00:30:30.686
>> And I'm Wes Bryant.

627
00:30:30.686 --> 00:30:31.290
>> We'll see you next time.

628
00:30:31.290 --> 00:30:38.004
[MUSIC]

629
00:30:38.004 --> 00:30:40.219
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes compare and contrast network architecture devices as well as their functions and features. Specific topics covered include: Hubs, Switches, Routers, Access Points(APs), Bridges, Modems, Firewalls, Patch Panels, Repeaters/Extenders, Ethernet over Power(EoP), and Power over Ethernet(PoE).
episodes.title: Network Architecture Devices
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV,

2

3

4
00:00:08.308 --> 00:00:11.996
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:11.996 --> 00:00:13.916
>> All right, greetings everyone and

welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.290 --> 00:00:19.140
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

we're back with more in our A+ series.

9
00:00:21.090 --> 00:00:24.440
So glad to have you guys joining
us in the studio again today.

And joining us is our good friend Mr.
Wes Bryan.

Wes, glad to have you as well.

12
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:29.030
How's it going, Sir?

13
00:00:29.030 --> 00:00:30.200
>> Man, it's going great.

14
00:00:30.200 --> 00:00:33.450
We've been moving through some of our
networking concepts, and you know,

15
00:00:33.450 --> 00:00:36.040
we've been talking about all
different types of things, right?

16
00:00:36.040 --> 00:00:39.990
We've been talking about
a lot of the software side

17
00:00:39.990 --> 00:00:44.390
aspects of things like the services,
ports, protocols if you will.

18
00:00:44.390 --> 00:00:45.370
We've been talking about,

19
00:00:45.370 --> 00:00:49.175
hey networks allow us to pass
information between each other.

20
00:00:49.175 --> 00:00:52.090
Well, we haven't really talked
about is the middle man,

21
00:00:52.090 --> 00:00:55.030
the devices that
are actually responsible for

22
00:00:55.030 --> 00:00:57.980
potentially making decisions on
where to send the information.

23
00:00:57.980 --> 00:01:02.516
So we are going to be looking at, I know
it says network architecture devices.

24
00:01:02.516 --> 00:01:05.585
Well, we really could just take
architecture out of this and

25
00:01:05.585 --> 00:01:09.437
just think about as we're gonna look at
some of the devices that are actually

26
00:01:09.437 --> 00:01:13.190
helping us to share resources and
essentially perform communications.

27
00:01:13.190 --> 00:01:16.393
Cuz that's what network is about, right.

28
00:01:16.393 --> 00:01:20.965
If we think about it very basically,
I think about in the earlier days when I

29
00:01:20.965 --> 00:01:25.753
wanted to play a video game with a friend
of mine, I had to get up from my couch and

30
00:01:25.753 --> 00:01:27.810

31

And I had to play essentially on

32

And it certainly isn't that way today,

33
00:01:34.790 --> 00:01:39.440
because now we can have communications
between different locations.

34
00:01:39.440 --> 00:01:43.310
We wanna talk more, spend some time

what device you may or may not use.

36
00:01:45.550 --> 00:01:49.350
Maybe you choose one,
is really gonna be contingent on

37
00:01:49.350 --> 00:01:52.830
what type of communication and
really what functionality do you need.

38
00:01:52.830 --> 00:01:55.940
So let's go ahead, that's what we're
gonna talk about in this episode and

39
00:01:55.940 --> 00:01:59.430
let's go ahead and talk about one that's
been around for a very long time, but

40
00:01:59.430 --> 00:02:05.070
we're starting to see less and less of it,
at least from a networking perspective.

41
00:02:05.070 --> 00:02:08.250
And that is what is known
as the good old hub.

42
00:02:08.250 --> 00:02:10.350
All right, now hubs have been around for
a long time and

43
00:02:10.350 --> 00:02:13.300
I want you to understand that when
I say that we're seeing less and

44
00:02:13.300 --> 00:02:17.080
less of them in networking you might
say well I got six of them over here.

45
00:02:17.080 --> 00:02:20.670
If you've been around the industry for
a little bit or know about computers,

46
00:02:20.670 --> 00:02:25.130
I'm not necessarily talking about USB
based hubs or FireWire based hubs.

47
00:02:25.130 --> 00:02:26.510
We'll mention those in context.

48
00:02:26.510 --> 00:02:29.005
But I'm talking about
the earlier days of networking.

49
00:02:29.005 --> 00:02:32.545
If you need a communication, what you
would do is you would take a cable,

50
00:02:32.545 --> 00:02:35.745
a network cable, and you'd plug it

51
00:02:35.745 --> 00:02:38.705
All right, so I've got kind of
an example of a hub right here.

52
00:02:38.705 --> 00:02:40.575
And again, just a real basic diagram.

53
00:02:40.575 --> 00:02:44.535
But what we wanna understand about a hub
is that a hub doesn't really have any

54
00:02:44.535 --> 00:02:45.205
logic in it.

55
00:02:45.205 --> 00:02:47.085
It doesn't really make any decisions.

56
00:02:47.085 --> 00:02:50.160
So when we talk about potentially pass and

57
00:02:50.160 --> 00:02:52.860
making the decision on where
to send the information.

58
00:02:52.860 --> 00:02:53.780
The hub doesn't do that.

59
00:02:53.780 --> 00:02:58.885
Believe it or not a hub is hardwired to
receive an electrical communication and

60

re-send it if you will, out all of

61
00:03:05.400 --> 00:03:07.630
Let's talk real briefly

62
00:03:07.630 --> 00:03:08.850
All right, because we've been talking,

63
00:03:08.850 --> 00:03:11.290
we've talked in the past
episodes about a port, right?

64
00:03:11.290 --> 00:03:15.070
And what we mean by a port there is really
a logical identifier that's inside of

65
00:03:15.070 --> 00:03:18.570
software that you're operating system
uses to identify the service that it's

66
00:03:18.570 --> 00:03:19.490
using, right?

67
00:03:19.490 --> 00:03:22.340
For instance, FTP,
we're gonna be using things like port 20.

68
00:03:22.340 --> 00:03:23.670
We're talking Telnet.

69
00:03:23.670 --> 00:03:26.520
We're identifying that services
running on port 23, right.

70
00:03:26.520 --> 00:03:31.770
It is the way software recognizes
this is the service I'm using.

71
00:03:31.770 --> 00:03:35.850
When we talk about a port inside of
a connectivity device, we're talking about

72
00:03:35.850 --> 00:03:40.300
a lot of the same concept when we look
at the motherboard and our chassis.

73
00:03:40.300 --> 00:03:45.730
This electrical connection that you make
by plugging some kind of fiber optic or

74
00:03:45.730 --> 00:03:50.250
copper based media plugging it
into a opening on the device.

75
00:03:50.250 --> 00:03:53.610
>> So an actual physical
port versus a software port.

76
00:03:53.610 --> 00:03:54.150
>> Most of it.
>> And

77
00:03:54.150 --> 00:03:55.960
we gotta get the two correct, right?

78
00:03:55.960 --> 00:03:58.650
>> Yes, absolutely, and
it's a physical connection, right?

79
00:03:58.650 --> 00:04:01.530
You might hear it called
an interface guys, gals.

80
00:04:01.530 --> 00:04:03.210
Don't let that confuse you.

81
00:04:03.210 --> 00:04:06.320
Any type of interface is
a point of interaction.

82
00:04:06.320 --> 00:04:07.840
Right, that's really what an interface is.

83
00:04:07.840 --> 00:04:12.110
You have software interfaces which says
hey, this program, talks to this program.

84
00:04:12.110 --> 00:04:14.500
It's that, if you will,
that communication point.

85
00:04:14.500 --> 00:04:18.220
When we talk about a physical interface,
we're talking about that interaction

86
00:04:18.220 --> 00:04:21.790
point between the copper or the optical
cable plugging into the device itself.

87
00:04:21.790 --> 00:04:23.380
>> To the extra connection
point at that point.

88
00:04:23.380 --> 00:04:24.290
>> The connection point,

89
00:04:24.290 --> 00:04:27.549
yeah, that's right, and,
they have different shapes and sizes.

90
00:04:28.680 --> 00:04:32.356
Now, when we talk about a hub I said that
it doesn't make any decisions on where

91
00:04:32.356 --> 00:04:34.882
to send information because
it really is hardwired.

92
00:04:34.882 --> 00:04:39.045
It's through electrical circuitry
with very little if any really,

93
00:04:39.045 --> 00:04:41.520
software on the device.

94
00:04:41.520 --> 00:04:45.670
So, this has it's benefit and
the fact that they're relatively cheap and

95
00:04:45.670 --> 00:04:48.560
by days means of standards they are very,
very cheap.

96
00:04:48.560 --> 00:04:50.480
But it also has a drawback, all right.

97
00:04:50.480 --> 00:04:52.535
And that means when we use hubs and
networking,

98
00:04:52.535 --> 00:04:56.820
if this computer sends information to
this computer, the hub doesn't make any

99
00:04:56.820 --> 00:05:00.980
decision that hey I shouldn't send this
information to this computer, right?

100
00:05:00.980 --> 00:05:03.680
What happens is electrical
communication goes into the hub and

101
00:05:03.680 --> 00:05:07.360
then what the hub does is it turns around
and through its wires that are physically

102
00:05:07.360 --> 00:05:10.700
soldered into the motherboard and
the trace is on the PCB as it

103
00:05:10.700 --> 00:05:13.620
It reboosts the signal and
just sends it out on all ports.

104
00:05:13.620 --> 00:05:15.160
Now, I want you to think about that.

105
00:05:15.160 --> 00:05:18.670
If I need a communication that this needs
to happen between me and Dan, or Dan and

106
00:05:18.670 --> 00:05:20.510
I, excuse me, I was trying
a little better English there.

107
00:05:20.510 --> 00:05:24.080
All right, between Dan and I, there's no
reason for me to walk out the door and

108
00:05:24.080 --> 00:05:27.510
tell every one of our producers that are
sitting in our command center helping us

109
00:05:27.510 --> 00:05:31.640
make, just basically,
produce our episodes, right?

110
00:05:31.640 --> 00:05:33.170
It's a lot of waste of communication, and

111
00:05:33.170 --> 00:05:34.780
it's certainly not talking down to them,
but

112
00:05:34.780 --> 00:05:38.410
they've got better things to be doing and
busy things that they're concentrating on.

113
00:05:38.410 --> 00:05:40.210
So, it creates this contention, right?

114
00:05:40.210 --> 00:05:43.470
It creates this contention in the fact
that were actually disturbing

115
00:05:44.480 --> 00:05:47.910
the other people within that conversation
because they don't really need to hear it.

116
00:05:47.910 --> 00:05:51.630
I also want you think about the fact
that it is basically adding

117
00:05:51.630 --> 00:05:56.310
more information on a network
that really needs to be.

118
00:05:56.310 --> 00:06:00.090
And that's one of the reasons that we
don't really use them too much inside of

119
00:06:00.090 --> 00:06:04.340
a networking communication technologies
today because, they put unnecessary

120
00:06:04.340 --> 00:06:09.120
communications across the network,
creates contention, creates congestion.

121
00:06:09.120 --> 00:06:10.890
All right,
when we say congestion, imagine,

122
00:06:10.890 --> 00:06:14.030
I don't need more electrical signals
if I only need sent to one computer.

123
00:06:14.030 --> 00:06:15.450
So I want you to remember
that about the hub.

124
00:06:15.450 --> 00:06:20.210
Now that being said, I don't want you to
also to think that we don't use hubs.

125
00:06:20.210 --> 00:06:23.030
Because we've talked about the theory
behind things like the universal

126
00:06:23.030 --> 00:06:26.510
serial bus, we've talked about FireWire,
we've talked about things like

127
00:06:26.510 --> 00:06:30.270
Thunderbolt in which you can daisy
chain up to six devices, primarily for

128
00:06:30.270 --> 00:06:32.310
high definition video and sound today.

129
00:06:32.310 --> 00:06:33.730
Those are hubs as well.

130
00:06:33.730 --> 00:06:37.310
That essentially is two devices that
are connected and they're communicating.

131
00:06:37.310 --> 00:06:41.000
So, technically,
that's a network, all right?

132
00:06:41.000 --> 00:06:45.440
So again, let me just be very careful
in how I say that we don't use hubs,

133
00:06:45.440 --> 00:06:48.730
cuz I'd hate for you guys to get into
the industries and say, I see an HDMI hub,

134
00:06:48.730 --> 00:06:51.960
a Thunderbolt hub, a USB hub, and
say, what is Wes talking about?

135
00:06:51.960 --> 00:06:54.900
But I mean, quite literally, for
a network communications and

136
00:06:54.900 --> 00:06:57.060
things like your communication closets,
right?

137
00:06:57.060 --> 00:07:00.319
We're seeing less and less of these hubs,
if any, today at all.

138
00:07:00.319 --> 00:07:05.731
>> Right, and even if you can't have, you
can grab that USB hub, and you can plug

139
00:07:05.731 --> 00:07:11.220
in USB 3 network dongles, that have
RJ-45 connectors built into them.

140
00:07:11.220 --> 00:07:12.030
Plug into that.

141
00:07:12.030 --> 00:07:15.840
That is not a networking hub,
even though it is doing the same job.

142
00:07:15.840 --> 00:07:19.080
What we're talking about here is
a networking hub properly, right?

143
00:07:19.080 --> 00:07:23.050
Its job is to connect computers
through Ethernet standards or

144
00:07:23.050 --> 00:07:24.020
maybe something else.

145
00:07:24.020 --> 00:07:27.900
But for networking standards,
not necessarily USB per se.

146
00:07:27.900 --> 00:07:29.490
All right, so just keep that in mind.

147
00:07:29.490 --> 00:07:32.320
>> Definitely, because there's some
translation that has to go between those

148
00:07:32.320 --> 00:07:35.070
similar protocols, so
it is slightly different.

149
00:07:35.070 --> 00:07:40.380
Now, as technology progressed,
they do find that it became more efficient

150
00:07:40.380 --> 00:07:43.530
to have a device that would actually have
a little bit of logic built in to it and

151
00:07:43.530 --> 00:07:47.020
can start to make decisions
on where to send information.

152
00:07:47.020 --> 00:07:49.738
All right, and what we mean by that
is a device known as a switch.

153
00:07:49.738 --> 00:07:53.283
And we do use these pretty heavily
in just about every internal

154
00:07:53.283 --> 00:07:56.979
local area network and
even on the backbone of the Internet too.

155
00:07:56.979 --> 00:08:00.096
And we'll talk about some of the
differences between some of the devices

156
00:08:00.096 --> 00:08:02.050
as well as we continue
through this episode.

157
00:08:02.050 --> 00:08:04.369
Now the next device when
we talk about a switch.

158
00:08:04.369 --> 00:08:05.421
Let's go ahead and

159
00:08:05.421 --> 00:08:09.574
I've gotta a little simplistic diagram
here of a diagram here of a switch.

160
00:08:09.574 --> 00:08:14.206
Now, switch just looks like, in this case,
it's got more connections than a hub so

161
00:08:14.206 --> 00:08:15.920
what is the difference?

162
00:08:15.920 --> 00:08:20.933
Well, a switch does make a logical
decision on where to send the information.

163
00:08:20.933 --> 00:08:24.173
Now a switch does something kinda
interesting because just like a hub,

164
00:08:24.173 --> 00:08:28.061
we have a physical connection that is made
through a copper-based cable, or it could

165
00:08:28.061 --> 00:08:32.452
be optical light source depending on how
expensive it is and they get expensive.

166
00:08:32.452 --> 00:08:35.887
All right, notice that the connections
aren't going to be looking pretty much in

167
00:08:35.887 --> 00:08:37.401
the diagram no different, right?

168
00:08:37.401 --> 00:08:38.931
So what is the difference?

169
00:08:38.931 --> 00:08:42.128
Well internally in that device
in a switch it actually looks,

170
00:08:42.128 --> 00:08:45.202
it starts to look at addressing
information all right, and

171
00:08:45.202 --> 00:08:48.105
remember why we talked about
addressing information.

172
00:08:48.105 --> 00:08:48.819
What do we use it for?

173
00:08:48.819 --> 00:08:54.259
Well, just like source, excuse me, mailing
address, and the return mailing address.

174
00:08:54.259 --> 00:08:58.632
You're postal carriers use it to say, hey,
I know where this information's going to.

175
00:08:58.632 --> 00:09:02.179
And really more importantly inside of
communications a lot of times we focus on

176
00:09:02.179 --> 00:09:03.370
what the destination is.

177
00:09:03.370 --> 00:09:05.990
So if I'm communicating
I know where it goes.

178
00:09:05.990 --> 00:09:09.844
Well it's interesting because a switch has
inside of it, has this little database,

179
00:09:09.844 --> 00:09:10.390
all right?

180
00:09:10.390 --> 00:09:14.306
A little database that is
made up of the devices that

181
00:09:14.306 --> 00:09:18.790
are connected to its ports and
their physical addresses.

182
00:09:18.790 --> 00:09:20.150
And its something I want you to know.

183
00:09:20.150 --> 00:09:23.953
A switch operates on what's
known as a MAC address.

184
00:09:23.953 --> 00:09:27.094
Now when we talked about some
of our TCP/IP characteristics,

185
00:09:27.094 --> 00:09:30.234
one of the things that we mentioned
in that series of episodes,

186
00:09:30.234 --> 00:09:34.770
we have multiple parts in there, we talked
about the media access control address.

187
00:09:34.770 --> 00:09:38.840
The MAC address,
that 48 bit 6 byte identifier,

188
00:09:38.840 --> 00:09:42.300
uniquely identifies the network
adapter that is in the PC.

189
00:09:42.300 --> 00:09:47.562
Well, your switches, understand,
have PCs that are connected to them.

190
00:09:47.562 --> 00:09:52.572
Now guys,
let me be very careful when I say PC,

191
00:09:52.572 --> 00:09:55.780
I'm not excluding Mac.

192
00:09:55.780 --> 00:10:00.662
Again, I'm also talking Linux, Nix base
systems, any operating system that is

193
00:10:00.662 --> 00:10:05.120
a network-based operating system which
primarily all of them are today,

194
00:10:05.120 --> 00:10:05.842
all right?

195
00:10:05.842 --> 00:10:08.747
Is going to have if they
connect to a network,

196
00:10:08.747 --> 00:10:11.660
they're gonna have a MAC
address all right.

197
00:10:11.660 --> 00:10:15.770
So if you have a device that is connected
through a physical cable to a switch,

198
00:10:15.770 --> 00:10:19.880
then it is going to make a decision when
it receives the information that comes

199
00:10:19.880 --> 00:10:23.130
in one of it's ports it's going
to reference this listing.

200
00:10:23.130 --> 00:10:24.670
It's called a MAC table,
if you will, guys.

201
00:10:24.670 --> 00:10:28.310
But it's gonna recognize that hey,
I see on port two,

202
00:10:28.310 --> 00:10:33.420
I see that computer two actually
has this MAC address, all right?

203
00:10:33.420 --> 00:10:37.425
And I see that on port 2,
if you will, Client01, and

204
00:10:37.425 --> 00:10:39.822
let me make sure I get that right.

205
00:10:39.822 --> 00:10:46.358
Client01 has this MAC address and
it needs to send information to Client05.

206
00:10:46.358 --> 00:10:49.539
All right, well let me go ahead and
look at my table and

207
00:10:49.539 --> 00:10:53.852
I'll figure out that client05 has
a MAC address that is connected to,

208
00:10:53.852 --> 00:10:57.548
I'm gonna just say switch here back and
forth here port 15.

209
00:10:57.548 --> 00:11:01.759
So, it make a decision,
it says okay, I see the information,

210
00:11:01.759 --> 00:11:04.703
I recognize that addressing information.

211
00:11:04.703 --> 00:11:09.152
And I'll make a decision that says I'm
going to forward that right over to

212
00:11:09.152 --> 00:11:10.960
client05.

213
00:11:10.960 --> 00:11:14.467
Now unlike the hub, we don't have
a lot of ways to communications and

214
00:11:14.467 --> 00:11:17.795
the fact that I don't have to
worry about client02, 03, and

directly to the device and

essentially that's what a switch is today.

00:22:46.351 --> 00:22:49.172
However, there are bridges

00:22:49.172 --> 00:22:52.590
I'm not talking about the ones

00:22:52.590 --> 00:22:56.567
What we're talking about a lot of times,

And sometimes, you might need

there's a physical limitation on media,

455
00:23:01.550 --> 00:23:02.460
I can't lay cable.

00:23:02.460 --> 00:23:05.948
So you do have the ability to

457
00:23:05.948 --> 00:23:09.136
And I have a wired network on one side and

00:23:09.136 --> 00:23:12.728
Maybe you've got a situation where

00:23:15.049 --> 00:23:16.326

00:23:16.326 --> 00:23:20.130

00:23:20.130 --> 00:23:24.145
I can't put a copper cable across a public

Alright and if lightning hits that cable

465

466
00:23:30.750 --> 00:23:33.776
But what I can do is use radiated

00:23:33.776 --> 00:23:38.658
We put an access point essentially on both

468
00:23:38.658 --> 00:23:42.060

communication across them.

469
00:23:42.060 --> 00:23:45.164
That would be considered something

470
00:23:45.164 --> 00:23:47.520
Bridging two dissimilar networks.

00:23:47.520 --> 00:23:52.601
And that's what the earlier bridges

Modem is actually a combination of two

Well when I say modulate, demodulate,

00:24:46.420 --> 00:24:49.960
Our computers don't speak in analog

491
00:24:49.960 --> 00:24:53.373
However, we have old telephone lines

00:24:53.373 --> 00:24:57.019
Networks, or sometimes called plain

00:24:57.019 --> 00:24:58.578
>> Telephone [LAUGH]
>> Telephone service, right?

494
00:24:58.578 --> 00:25:00.140
POTS lines, too.

495
00:25:00.140 --> 00:25:03.720
Well, if we have a digital communication,

496
00:25:03.720 --> 00:25:08.200
that we need to send along an analog
signal or an analog system, which your

497
00:25:08.200 --> 00:25:13.130

a way to kind of convert that signal,

498
00:25:13.130 --> 00:25:17.120
if you will, to allow those two dissimilar
systems to communicate between each other.

499
00:25:17.120 --> 00:25:19.080
And that's where the modem
comes into play.

500
00:25:19.080 --> 00:25:21.750
That's why they say modulation,
demodulation.

501
00:25:21.750 --> 00:25:24.820
We use modulation schemes that you'll
learn a little bit more about in net

00:25:24.820 --> 00:25:29.280
plus like phase-shift keying and stuff,

503
00:25:29.280 --> 00:25:32.202
but it's essentially taking the digital
signal and converting it to analog.

504
00:25:32.202 --> 00:25:36.630
And then the recipient signal is analog
over the Public Switch Telephone Networks,

505
00:25:36.630 --> 00:25:39.070
and then is turned back

00:25:39.070 --> 00:25:41.220

>> Cuz it's been around for

It's the small old man essentially.

>> [LAUGH]
>> And you might say well dial up,

we don't use dial up today,

Well, yes, you do use dial-up,

Because when your ethernet,

A lot of times it's your dial-up, right?

We have a lot of access to telephone
lines when we do have geographical

Now, that does happen even

Another situation that one of our other

In fact, I think the company

Because we live in a modern age, this

Hence the name, right,

00:28:16.160 --> 00:28:18.720
A few more things that

00:28:18.720 --> 00:28:21.090
We've got what's known as a firewall.

00:28:21.090 --> 00:28:23.120
And I do wanna talk just

565
00:28:23.120 --> 00:28:26.695
Maybe some of you are aware of a firewall,
and maybe you're not, all right.

566
00:28:26.695 --> 00:28:27.875
I've got a little diagram here, and

567
00:28:27.875 --> 00:28:29.785
let's talk a little bit about firewalls,
all right?

568
00:28:29.785 --> 00:28:31.805
We've got a few different
types of firewalls.

569
00:28:31.805 --> 00:28:33.545
Well, what does a firewall do?

570
00:28:33.545 --> 00:28:36.485
All right,
a firewall basically is what allows or

571
00:28:36.485 --> 00:28:38.445
denies communication types, right?

572
00:28:38.445 --> 00:28:42.790
If I wanna talk to you over a network I
have a security-based device that says,

573
00:28:42.790 --> 00:28:48.070
yeah, you can communicate with me or no,
you can't communicate with me, right?

574
00:28:48.070 --> 00:28:53.340
So, basically a firewall will
allow communications or it

575
00:28:53.340 --> 00:28:57.440
will block communications, and there's all
different types of ways that this happens.

576
00:28:57.440 --> 00:29:00.875
One of the most common ones is through
something known as an access control list

577
00:29:00.875 --> 00:29:02.395
which, really has a set of rules.

578
00:29:02.395 --> 00:29:04.677
It says if it is this
type of communication,

579
00:29:04.677 --> 00:29:07.150
allow it through the firewall.

580
00:29:07.150 --> 00:29:10.110
Now, I want you to know even though
that we're not really talking

581
00:29:10.110 --> 00:29:13.590
about security in this episode,
I do want you to know very basically,

582
00:29:13.590 --> 00:29:19.060
firewalls operate on
an implicit deny configuration.

583
00:29:19.060 --> 00:29:24.238
What we mean by that is any communication
that comes into the firewall is typically

584
00:29:24.238 --> 00:29:29.202
blocked unless it's explicitly allowed,
and that's for your protection.

585
00:29:29.202 --> 00:29:30.650
It's a security device.

586
00:29:30.650 --> 00:29:34.030
It says, if I didn't ask for
that communication and

587
00:29:34.030 --> 00:29:37.390
you didn't tell me it's allowed,
it's going to be denied, right?

588
00:29:37.390 --> 00:29:40.310
It's the difference between having
a reservation and being on the list and

589
00:29:40.310 --> 00:29:43.870
then showing up at the restaurant
without reservations and they say,

590
00:29:43.870 --> 00:29:45.807
I don't see you on the list,
you're not gonna eat, right?

591
00:29:47.470 --> 00:29:50.800
Outbound communications,
my communication from me to Dan.

592
00:29:50.800 --> 00:29:52.730
Doesn't mean Dan's computer's
gonna allow me, right?

593
00:29:52.730 --> 00:29:55.080
It's gonna be blocked unless
it's expressly allowed.

594
00:29:55.080 --> 00:29:58.650
But my outbound, my communication
to Dan is gonna be allowed.

595
00:29:58.650 --> 00:30:01.680
So communications that come
into firewalls without

596
00:30:01.680 --> 00:30:04.270
prior configuration are typically blocked.

597
00:30:04.270 --> 00:30:07.690
Any communication that goes from
your computer to another source

598
00:30:07.690 --> 00:30:09.120
is going to be allowed.

599
00:30:09.120 --> 00:30:10.240
Again, on the recipient end,

600
00:30:10.240 --> 00:30:14.410
it doesn't mean that it's gonna be allowed
except if you explicitly allow it.

601
00:30:14.410 --> 00:30:15.480
That's called an implicit deny.

602
00:30:16.580 --> 00:30:18.120
Last thing I wanna mention on firewalls,

603
00:30:18.120 --> 00:30:23.031
two primary different types network-based
firewall versus a host-based firewall.

604
00:30:23.031 --> 00:30:26.700
Host-based firewall is like what you
see inside of things like Windows.

605
00:30:26.700 --> 00:30:30.430
That is a software-based firewall and
it is screening traffic coming to and

606
00:30:30.430 --> 00:30:33.130
from the device that it's running on,
all right?

607
00:30:33.130 --> 00:30:35.270
It's a software-based firewall.

608
00:30:35.270 --> 00:30:36.810
Network based firewalls,

609
00:30:36.810 --> 00:30:40.120
I put them in relationship to
the architecture within the network.

610
00:30:40.120 --> 00:30:45.230
They screen all information coming
into your network from another network

611
00:30:45.230 --> 00:30:47.160
before it goes to any device.

612
00:30:47.160 --> 00:30:49.110
All devices within your network.

613
00:30:49.110 --> 00:30:52.570
Likewise they also screen all
traffic that is sent from

614
00:30:52.570 --> 00:30:55.320
every device within your
network off of your network.

615
00:30:55.320 --> 00:30:58.520
In this case, we used the example
of the Internet, all right?

616
00:30:58.520 --> 00:31:00.670
So do know about those firewalls.

617
00:31:00.670 --> 00:31:03.740
Again, couple other things
that we wanna mention.

618
00:31:03.740 --> 00:31:05.600
They also mention patch panels.

00:31:05.600 --> 00:31:09.542
All right, when we talk about patch
panels, what we're talking about is

00:31:09.542 --> 00:31:13.356
what every wired connection,
if you will, well, wired connection to

621
00:31:13.356 --> 00:31:17.999
your network essentially goes up through
the structural wiring within the building,

622
00:31:17.999 --> 00:31:21.074
comes down into a closet
called a communication closet.

623
00:31:21.074 --> 00:31:23.120
A lot of times we call
these server closets.

624
00:31:23.120 --> 00:31:26.210
And they connect to a central point,
that's the patch panel.

625
00:31:26.210 --> 00:31:27.690
We got an example of one right here.

626
00:31:27.690 --> 00:31:30.440
You can see all of these
different wired connections.

627
00:31:30.440 --> 00:31:32.400
Again If you were to lay this out and

628
00:31:32.400 --> 00:31:35.820
you were to look at it from a top down
view it'd look like a bunch of spaghetti.

629
00:31:35.820 --> 00:31:39.760
But they go through the structural wiring
within your building, down into a single

630
00:31:39.760 --> 00:31:44.530
point, and they plug in, essentially
connecting a pair of ports together.

631
00:31:44.530 --> 00:31:47.410
We also have repeaters and extenders.

632
00:31:47.410 --> 00:31:50.006
Hubs could be a form of a repeater or
extender.

633
00:31:50.006 --> 00:31:52.094
Any kind of repeater extender, guys,

634
00:31:52.094 --> 00:31:55.782
says that there's a maximum
transmission distance on that medium.

635
00:31:55.782 --> 00:31:59.609
Once you get to that maximum transmission
distance, if you go past it, and

636
00:31:59.609 --> 00:32:03.739
let's say we're making our own cables,
you run the risk of two things, right,

637
00:32:03.739 --> 00:32:06.020
signal loss as well as signal degradation.

638
00:32:06.020 --> 00:32:07.810
It's called signal attenuation.

639
00:32:07.810 --> 00:32:10.540
That's the progressive degradation
of a signal as it goes

640
00:32:10.540 --> 00:32:14.910
past whatever the standard length is for
that type of media.

641
00:32:14.910 --> 00:32:20.500
If it hits a repeater or an extender,
if you will, that device

642
00:32:20.500 --> 00:32:26.120
regenerates the signal back into
its original strength, if you will.

643
00:32:26.120 --> 00:32:31.039
And can extend or repeat it to another
certain amount of length, right?

644
00:32:32.425 --> 00:32:35.590
There's also what's known as
Ethernet over power, okay?

645
00:32:35.590 --> 00:32:38.280
And there's also what's known
as power over Ethernet.

646
00:32:38.280 --> 00:32:40.880
What the heck are we talking about there,
all right?

647
00:32:40.880 --> 00:32:44.990
So let's start with something
known as POE, Power Over Ethernet.

648
00:32:44.990 --> 00:32:46.040
See these cables right here.

649
00:32:46.040 --> 00:32:49.170
These are Ethernet based cables or
copper based media.

650
00:32:49.170 --> 00:32:51.960
And a lot of times all they have
running across them is data.

651
00:32:51.960 --> 00:32:56.090
But there are times when it's not feasible
to run an AC adapter to it from a device

652
00:32:56.090 --> 00:32:58.340
to an electrical location.

653
00:32:58.340 --> 00:32:59.360
So guess what?

654
00:32:59.360 --> 00:33:01.020
Not only, it's copper-based media.

655
00:33:01.020 --> 00:33:03.115
Guess what electrical wires are made of?

656
00:33:03.115 --> 00:33:03.615
Copper.
>> Copper.

657
00:33:03.615 --> 00:33:04.115
>> Right, so

658
00:33:04.115 --> 00:33:07.195
how convenient that we can-
>> I hear that they conduct electricity

659
00:33:07.195 --> 00:33:08.625
pretty well.
>> Pretty well, right?

660
00:33:08.625 --> 00:33:11.405
So how convenient is it that
we can have a device that

661
00:33:11.405 --> 00:33:15.965
literally injects an electrical
current into that data cable.

662
00:33:15.965 --> 00:33:17.275
That's power over Ethernet,

663
00:33:17.275 --> 00:33:21.565
it allows us to power devices that
otherwise we wouldn't be able to run

664
00:33:21.565 --> 00:33:25.430
because we don't have an AC adapter
to plug them into the wall.

665
00:33:25.430 --> 00:33:29.700
Now the other flip side to that is,
we also have power and guess what?

666
00:33:29.700 --> 00:33:31.180
Power cables use copper.

667
00:33:31.180 --> 00:33:32.560
Well guess what your data cables use too?

668
00:33:32.560 --> 00:33:34.090
Daniel, can you help me out with that?

669
00:33:34.090 --> 00:33:35.230
>> I'm gonna go with copper.

670
00:33:35.230 --> 00:33:36.105
>> Hey, that's right.

671
00:33:36.105 --> 00:33:37.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> Dan for the win on that one and

672
00:33:37.490 --> 00:33:38.180
that's right.

673
00:33:38.180 --> 00:33:40.250
We joke around, but it's true, right?

674
00:33:40.250 --> 00:33:44.250
So we already have power cables and
they have come up with technologies, and

675
00:33:44.250 --> 00:33:47.200
these could be considered things
like range extenders as well.

676
00:33:47.200 --> 00:33:51.440
Where I can actually plug a device right

677
00:33:52.450 --> 00:33:56.500
Put an Ethernet cable into it, put
a copper cable into it, and now I'm gonna

678
00:33:56.500 --> 00:34:01.602
send my data signal across the electrical
infrastructure inside of the building.

679
00:34:01.602 --> 00:34:03.970
>> It's gonna be a lot of money in
having to wire the entire building for

680
00:34:03.970 --> 00:34:04.550
Ethernet, right?

681
00:34:04.550 --> 00:34:05.480
>> It really does.

682
00:34:05.480 --> 00:34:08.370
We talk about using wireless,
more so because we have

683
00:34:08.370 --> 00:34:12.770
that limitation of physical cabling, well
if you do, now you have options right?

684
00:34:12.770 --> 00:34:14.790
You don't have to necessarily go wireless.

685
00:34:14.790 --> 00:34:17.980
You can extend your wired communications

686
00:34:17.980 --> 00:34:21.340
by essentially sending it through
your power-based infrastructure.

687
00:34:21.340 --> 00:34:24.250
So guys and gals out there,
a lot of difference technologies.

688
00:34:24.250 --> 00:34:26.210
We hope we've made them
a little bit clearer for you.

689
00:34:26.210 --> 00:34:29.960
Know where you would see some of these
devices and also know some of, we talked

690
00:34:29.960 --> 00:34:33.070
a little bit about some of the logic
behind them and what they're looking at.

691
00:34:33.070 --> 00:34:35.840
You'll learn a lot more
about this is Network+,

692
00:34:35.840 --> 00:34:38.050
but this should really be good for
the A+ exam.

693
00:34:38.050 --> 00:34:39.740
Keep in mind the functionality,

694
00:34:39.740 --> 00:34:42.040
where you would see these
devices within your networks and

695
00:34:42.040 --> 00:34:45.600
what their general use will be and
you should be doing for your A+ exam.

696
00:34:45.600 --> 00:34:48.607
>> All right, Wes,
great stuff, love networking.

697
00:34:48.607 --> 00:34:51.550
It's where I cut my teeth, it's how I
got into the biz cuz I love networking.

698
00:34:51.550 --> 00:34:52.660
I think it's a lot of fun.

699
00:34:52.660 --> 00:34:56.160
Hopefully you guys found this episode
enlightening and entertaining as well,

700
00:34:56.160 --> 00:34:57.180
I know I sure did.

701
00:34:57.180 --> 00:34:59.820
We thank you Wes for dropping by and
we thank our audience for watching.

702
00:34:59.820 --> 00:35:03.873
But, yep, it's that time for
us to sign off for ITProTV.

703
00:35:03.873 --> 00:35:05.200
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

704
00:35:05.200 --> 00:35:06.140
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

705
00:35:06.140 --> 00:35:08.307
>> We'll see you next time.

706
00:35:08.307 --> 00:35:14.225
[MUSIC]

707
00:35:14.225 --> 00:35:17.350
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look over, install, and configure the common hardware and expansion components found in laptop computers. Here specifically they explore: battery life, thermal management, expansion options (like ports, cards, and dongles), internal storage types,
episodes.title: Laptop Hardware and Components
episodes.transcript:

1

I keep thinking maybe I'm on the wrong

Okay I got it the dash is somewhere else.

But other than that guys that's

16

And like Dan says well,
we're gonna be looking at laptops today.

And we're gonna be looking at some of the

And boy have they changed over the years.

19
00:00:53.940 --> 00:00:55.860
One of the great things though is for

the most part a computer is
a computer is a computer, right?

It just really depends on how much
money you have to spend on one and

really what the functionality is,
the the role if you will,

of a computer within our networks, right?

24

We have from the smallest computers today,

Internet of Things where the computer is
a really just an RM-based processor and

they call it a SOC, system on a chip.

Everything's built into the PC or

Then we get a little bit bigger here, and

we can have things like the TV top boxes,

30

31

>> Set top boxes.

32

33

[LAUGH] And
they're a little big bigger and

their functionality is a lot of times

And allowing you to tune in and

36

You got tablets and
don't forget cell phones, right?

37

But really when you look at it,
all the way up to the work station or

38

even the servers that we talk about that

39

generate a lot of heat and very powerful,

40

Now, one of the things that differentiates

to consider when it comes to laptops

The main thing is battery life, right?

43

I mean, when we talk about mobility, it's

over the years, they've definitely gone so

46

Dan I can think about some of
the earlier NiCad batteries where you'd

you might even get 45 minutes use.

48
00:02:23.110 --> 00:02:24.158
You remember some of those?

49

>> Yeah, those things were the, you think,
well it's rechargeable so not a huge deal.

50

Except it's a huge deal,
it was a pain [LAUGH].

51

>> That's right, and then they would
suffer from things like the memory effect,

52
00:02:34.197 --> 00:02:37.739
where you would charge it, and
you would charge it for five hours, and

53
00:02:37.739 --> 00:02:40.450
it'd only give you half the actual charge.

54
00:02:40.450 --> 00:02:44.720
They had a memory retention, and for the
most part, I gotta be careful saying this.

55
00:02:44.720 --> 00:02:48.520
Cuz you never say never, but
we use lithium ion batteries more.

56
00:02:48.520 --> 00:02:51.860
Most popular battery today is
the lithium ion type battery.

57
00:02:51.860 --> 00:02:54.640
And that battery really doesn't
suffer from the memory effect.

58
00:02:54.640 --> 00:02:58.954
But again, it has a certain life
span that you have to keep in mind,

59
00:02:58.954 --> 00:03:01.205
that over time it's a cell right?

60
00:03:01.205 --> 00:03:04.810
And what are you doing, you're putting
a charge in the cell and you're removing

61
00:03:04.810 --> 00:03:09.300
that charge in the cell, and over a period
of time the cell just can't hold charges.

62
00:03:09.300 --> 00:03:14.120
So battery life back to the point here
before I get too far off the beaten track.

63
00:03:14.120 --> 00:03:17.490
Battery life is definitely
something that is a major concern.

64
00:03:17.490 --> 00:03:21.140
How long does the battery last,
how long could I go without

65

66

The next thing, if battery life
is one of the most crucial,

67
