is proper thermal management, heating.

68
00:03:31.640 --> 00:03:35.740
We really have to worry about heating,
or overheating I should say, inside of

69
00:03:35.740 --> 00:03:40.070
a laptop because of the fact that well,
they're fairly small form factors.

70
00:03:40.070 --> 00:03:43.045
In fact, we've got a laptop,
if we could look at the SkyCam here,

71
00:03:43.045 --> 00:03:44.386
this is a more modern laptop.

72
00:03:44.386 --> 00:03:47.656
And we've got another old one here

73
00:03:47.656 --> 00:03:49.810
tear apart and
show you guys some of the pieces.

74
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:53.280
Because again, for the most part,
the components really haven't changed.

75
00:03:53.280 --> 00:03:57.210
It's just everything gets smaller,
right, and faster.

76
00:03:57.210 --> 00:04:00.220
But if you look at that,
we don't have a lot of space, right?

77
00:04:00.220 --> 00:04:02.100
And it's not like our desktops, and

78
00:04:02.100 --> 00:04:04.510
our gaming desktops where we
have a big case there and

79
00:04:04.510 --> 00:04:09.730
we can put 42 fans in it, and we can just
pull in cool air and exhaust the hot air.

80
00:04:09.730 --> 00:04:13.610
I don't really have too much space here
and in fact it's kinda hard to see.

81
00:04:13.610 --> 00:04:17.890
But that's the exhaust on this Mac that's
actually the exhaust vent right there, and

82
00:04:17.890 --> 00:04:21.920
you can see that if I would stack up,
I don't know if I took a guess about four

83
00:04:21.920 --> 00:04:25.270
quarters it would be about
four quarters in height.

84
00:04:25.270 --> 00:04:26.470
There's not a lot of space.

85
00:04:26.470 --> 00:04:30.318
So when we look at that, keep in mind that
not only do we worry about the battery

86
00:04:30.318 --> 00:04:33.478
life, but we are also worry
about proper thermal management.

87
00:04:33.478 --> 00:04:36.592
Those are the two major contributing
factors when it comes to laptops and

88
00:04:36.592 --> 00:04:39.144
it's really something that you
have to be concerned with,

89
00:04:39.144 --> 00:04:42.021
when you talk about being an A +
technicians of some sort, right?

90
00:04:42.021 --> 00:04:45.654
Because the other thing is, with thermal
management, if we don't have, and

91
00:04:45.654 --> 00:04:48.750
I'm talking heat guys,
let's take the jargon out of it, right.

92
00:04:48.750 --> 00:04:50.650
We don't want things overheating, right?

93
00:04:50.650 --> 00:04:52.740
If we don't have proper
thermal management,

94
00:04:52.740 --> 00:04:56.380
proper cooling within a system,
it could be very problematic.

95
00:04:56.380 --> 00:04:58.210
We're gonna have problems, right?

96
00:04:58.210 --> 00:05:00.767
One of the obvious things
that you can see is,

97
00:05:00.767 --> 00:05:05.696
when your computer starts shutting down,
random reboots, that's a telltale sign.

98
00:05:05.696 --> 00:05:07.451
It could be memory for sure, but

99
00:05:07.451 --> 00:05:11.490
it's a telltale sign that you've got
some kind of overheating going on.

100
00:05:11.490 --> 00:05:14.910
In fact most of the modern CPUs,
and again,

101
00:05:14.910 --> 00:05:18.870
I don't care what the platform is, they
have these thermal temperature sensors

102
00:05:18.870 --> 00:05:21.030
that are built into the CPU itself.

103
00:05:21.030 --> 00:05:24.370
And what it can do is go into
a thermal shutdown right?

104
00:05:24.370 --> 00:05:26.010
And if that happens,

105
00:05:26.010 --> 00:05:30.560
again that's a telltale sign that your
computer isn't cooling itself properly.

106
00:05:30.560 --> 00:05:32.280
And what's happening is it's overheating.

107
00:05:32.280 --> 00:05:35.591
So those are some of the things that
I kinda wanna set the stage for

108
00:05:35.591 --> 00:05:38.912
when it comes to what you
are considering with laptops, right?

109
00:05:38.912 --> 00:05:41.931
Now we've got plenty of different
components inside of these devices, and

110
00:05:41.931 --> 00:05:44.400
like l said for the most part,
they really haven't changed.

111
00:05:44.400 --> 00:05:47.930
There are some things that have gone by
the way side, because well as technology

112
00:05:47.930 --> 00:05:51.524
moves on, some of the things that we used
to use, that we kinda laughed at today.

113
00:05:51.524 --> 00:05:54.650
And say well, you're really only gonna see
those in a museum more than you're gonna

114
00:05:54.650 --> 00:05:55.940
actually see them in the devices.

115
00:05:55.940 --> 00:06:00.100
But there are still a few of these things
that you have to know for the A+ exam.

116
00:06:00.100 --> 00:06:03.550
All right, some of the technologies,
again you might say,

117
00:06:03.550 --> 00:06:05.300
I've never seen one of those in my life.

118
00:06:05.300 --> 00:06:09.220
Well never say never because again, you
could see some of these components right?

119

We have things like storage devices,
now the storage devices really aren't any

our modern computers today,

121
00:06:16.140 --> 00:06:17.660
you know full size computers.

122
00:06:17.660 --> 00:06:20.101
But again, they're smaller,
we have the serial ATA, and

123
00:06:20.101 --> 00:06:24.310

spinning platters inside of them.

124
00:06:24.310 --> 00:06:26.629
We have, more common today,

125
00:06:26.629 --> 00:06:29.791
And these drives, again,
they're gonna look just like the same but

126
00:06:29.791 --> 00:06:32.120
the form factor's a little bit different.

127
00:06:32.120 --> 00:06:35.570
We talk about form factor of a hard drive,
we're talking about two and

128
00:06:35.570 --> 00:06:40.570
a half-inch form factor vs
the three-inch form factor of your full

129
00:06:40.570 --> 00:06:44.780
size desktop PCs or
even really server and storage devices.

130
00:06:44.780 --> 00:06:46.610
In fact, we've got a couple

131
00:06:46.610 --> 00:06:48.540
If we could pull them up from the Sky Cam,

132
00:06:48.540 --> 00:06:50.370
you'll see that I've got a couple of them,

133
00:06:50.370 --> 00:06:52.740
Now, this is a traditional
mechanical drive, right?

134
00:06:52.740 --> 00:06:56.968
And if I turn it over, you can see
that here's the controller board.

135
00:06:56.968 --> 00:07:01.870
This is a serial ATA interface, and
you can see we've got right here

136
00:07:01.870 --> 00:07:06.435
we've got our 15 pin serial
ATA L-shaped power connector.

137
00:07:06.435 --> 00:07:11.250
And we've got the seven-pin data
connector, the seven-pin data cable.

138
00:07:11.250 --> 00:07:12.890
Now one of the great
things about these and

139

we're gonna take a look at here at

140
00:07:16.650 --> 00:07:19.890
It is the fact that
a lot of these kinda fit

141
00:07:19.890 --> 00:07:22.190

don't really need the cables.

142
00:07:22.190 --> 00:07:23.900
So and that's because the data cable and

143
00:07:23.900 --> 00:07:28.390
the power is integrated directly into
the motherboard itself, or it's a separate

144
00:07:28.390 --> 00:07:34.170
little assembly that plugs on the back
side, plugs into the motherboard itself.

145
00:07:34.170 --> 00:07:38.410
But again you can see that these are
really no different than what you'd see in

146
00:07:38.410 --> 00:07:40.180
our full size drives.

147
00:07:40.180 --> 00:07:42.220
Again, the three and
a half inch form factor.

148
00:07:42.220 --> 00:07:45.240
And again, this one has spinning
platters that are inside of it, right?

149
00:07:45.240 --> 00:07:49.068
Now one of the things that is kinda
interesting about this is the platters on

150
00:07:49.068 --> 00:07:51.033
these, Dan, can actually be glass.

151
00:07:51.033 --> 00:07:54.464
I've actually taken a couple of these
older drives apart just to kinda see

152
00:07:54.464 --> 00:07:55.633
what's inside of them.

153
00:07:55.633 --> 00:08:00.202
And they really do look Much the same, but
the difference is, when you try to remove

154
00:08:00.202 --> 00:08:03.810
one of the platters, you really
have to be careful, not so much.

155
00:08:03.810 --> 00:08:07.930
I mean, if you open these drives guys,
you're pretty much ruined, am I right?

156
00:08:07.930 --> 00:08:10.100
And that's because the platters
have positioning and

157
00:08:10.100 --> 00:08:13.690
balancing that goes on them and
it's always unique to the drive itself.

158
00:08:13.690 --> 00:08:16.370
I could have five of the same exact drive,

159
00:08:16.370 --> 00:08:20.930
same model, same manufacturer and the
balancing can be a little bit different.

160
00:08:20.930 --> 00:08:23.230
They have very, very fine tolerances.

161
00:08:23.230 --> 00:08:25.890
Dan I know you're into engines and
stuff, and

162
00:08:25.890 --> 00:08:27.370
timing is everything right, in an engine?

163
00:08:27.370 --> 00:08:29.910
What happens if your timing gets
off just slightly in an engine?

164
00:08:29.910 --> 00:08:33.524
>> Yeah, well when you get the timing
off in an engine you have what's called

165
00:08:33.524 --> 00:08:37.098
pre-ignition which causes bad things
inside of a combustion chamber.

166
00:08:37.098 --> 00:08:37.760
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

167
00:08:37.760 --> 00:08:40.955
>> Which can,
it's small explosions at the wrong time.

168
00:08:40.955 --> 00:08:41.910
[LAUGH]
>> Right, and

169
00:08:41.910 --> 00:08:45.040
if we take that back to a hard drive, if
your timing is off just a little bit then

170
00:08:45.040 --> 00:08:48.460
the read write heads don't position
themselves inside of the drive.

171
00:08:48.460 --> 00:08:50.640
Essentially what you get is
data corruption or data loss.

172
00:08:50.640 --> 00:08:53.440
So understand when I tell you guys,
I've taken these apart.

173
00:08:53.440 --> 00:08:56.650
Well I know Dan, I know you've
busted a couple of these open too.

174
00:08:56.650 --> 00:08:58.100
We're doing it for curiosity.

175
00:08:58.100 --> 00:09:00.710
And it's usually because
like this drive here,

176
00:09:00.710 --> 00:09:02.960
we're gonna open this one
up here in the show and

177
00:09:02.960 --> 00:09:06.148
show you what it looks like here when we
get into actually looking at the pieces.

178
00:09:06.148 --> 00:09:09.640
You're not gonna be able to put it back
together and read the information.

179
00:09:09.640 --> 00:09:12.410
However, I will tell you,
on these devices,

180
00:09:12.410 --> 00:09:15.270
these drives here,
when you open them, be very careful.

181
00:09:15.270 --> 00:09:18.228
Because I've actually tried
taking all the screws out,

182
00:09:18.228 --> 00:09:22.240
and when you go try to remove the platter
it shatters into many, many pieces.

183
00:09:22.240 --> 00:09:24.190
And the pieces are glass.

184
00:09:24.190 --> 00:09:27.360
So you can only imagine taking some
kind of glass bottle and throwing it on

185
00:09:27.360 --> 00:09:31.170
the floor, and all the little shards
that can definitely get into your hand.

186
00:09:31.170 --> 00:09:32.890
So, be very careful when I say that.

187
00:09:32.890 --> 00:09:37.050
Now, this other one here you'll see,
it doesn't really look too much different.

188
00:09:37.050 --> 00:09:38.960

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look over, install, and configure the common hardware and expansion components found in laptop computers. Here specifically they explore: special function keys (fn keys), docking stations, physical and cable locks, and screens.
episodes.title: Laptop Hardware and Components Part 2

00:21:14.405 --> 00:21:19.320

00:21:21.786 --> 00:21:26.797

00:21:43.700 --> 00:21:46.290

00:22:13.490 --> 00:22:18.770
the inverter, all right,

415
00:22:18.770 --> 00:22:22.010
And it's also responsible for

00:22:22.010 --> 00:22:23.880
Hence the term backlight inverter.

00:22:23.880 --> 00:22:26.900
Backlighting, lighting the LCD, right?

00:22:28.580 --> 00:22:32.830
Inverter, in the fact that it's inverting
the direct current on the motherboard

00:29:57.130 --> 00:30:01.300
the side of one of those jacks that no
longer exist on certain Apple devices.

598
00:30:01.300 --> 00:30:03.650
It allows you to swipe your credit card,
right?

599
00:30:03.650 --> 00:30:06.470
Just a little thin device that usually
plugs into some kind of external

600
00:30:06.470 --> 00:30:07.880
connection.

601
00:30:07.880 --> 00:30:11.410
And potentially for
the expansion of your local storage,

602
00:30:11.410 --> 00:30:15.510
you could have memory cards or,
if you will, the micro SD cards.

603
00:30:15.510 --> 00:30:20.130
Pay attention because I don't have that,
for instance, on my cell phone.

604
00:30:20.130 --> 00:30:24.480
The pixel does not come, doesn't come
with an external memory card slot.

605
00:30:24.480 --> 00:30:26.659
I basically back up to the cloud.

606
00:30:26.659 --> 00:30:27.433
>> Mine does.
[LAUGH]

607
00:30:27.433 --> 00:30:28.165
>> Yours does,

608
00:30:28.165 --> 00:30:31.570
another reason I'm gonna go to that phone,
that's right.

609
00:30:31.570 --> 00:30:35.490
So, after this episode is done,
which is coming to the end, Dan and

610
00:30:35.490 --> 00:30:37.492
I are gonna have a UFC fight, right?

611
00:30:37.492 --> 00:30:41.195
[LAUGH] We'll end up seeing
whose phone is better.

612
00:30:41.195 --> 00:30:42.230
His is gonna win though.

613
00:30:42.230 --> 00:30:45.540
But Dan I know there's a lot of different
topics that we've talked about but

614
00:30:45.540 --> 00:30:47.640
I think we got it all in this episode.

615
00:30:47.640 --> 00:30:50.560
>> All right, well Wes, great job giving
us a great overview of what we can

616
00:30:50.560 --> 00:30:55.510
expect inside of mobile devices as A+
technicians, things that we might need to

617
00:30:55.510 --> 00:30:58.670
be able to support and understand about
them, and especially when it comes to

618
00:30:58.670 --> 00:31:02.900
the exam they're gonna ask up maybe a
question or two about said mobile devices.

619
00:31:02.900 --> 00:31:06.670
Given you a great 30,000 foot view of the
different types that you might encounter.

620
00:31:06.670 --> 00:31:08.980
That being said, Wes,
we do thank you for joining us.

621
00:31:08.980 --> 00:31:11.840
But it does look like it is that time for
us tosign off.

622
00:31:11.840 --> 00:31:14.811
For itpro.tv,
I've been your host Daniel Lowery.

623
00:31:14.811 --> 00:31:15.845
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.
>> We'll see you next time.

624
00:31:15.845 --> 00:31:23.077
[MUSIC]

625
00:31:23.077 --> 00:31:25.553
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Wes troubleshoot common problems related to motherboards, RAM, CPU, and power with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here includes: motherboard malfunction symptoms like burning smells, smoke, unexpected shutdowns, system lockups, and POST beeps.
episodes.title: Common Mobo, RAM, CPU and Power Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.006 --> 00:00:00.841
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:00.841 --> 00:00:02.878
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.878 --> 00:00:06.727
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.727 --> 00:00:08.128
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.128 --> 00:00:11.094
>> You are watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:11.094 --> 00:00:12.514
>> Hello and thank you for

7
00:00:12.514 --> 00:00:16.036
choosing ITProTV,
helping you learn wherever you go.

8
00:00:16.036 --> 00:00:20.440
I'm your host Zach Memos for
another episode of CompTIA A+.

9
00:00:20.440 --> 00:00:26.400
And in this episode, it's all about
common Mobo, RAM, CPU, and power issues.

10
00:00:26.400 --> 00:00:30.600
And once again, our IT expert for
all of this is Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:30.600 --> 00:00:31.750
Hey, Wes, good to see you, sir.

12
00:00:31.750 --> 00:00:33.690
>> Hey, Zach, thanks for having me back.

13
00:00:33.690 --> 00:00:35.500
That's right and I have props to you, man.

14
00:00:35.500 --> 00:00:38.660
They put a doctoral dissertation
in some of these episode titles.

15
00:00:38.660 --> 00:00:39.872
You did a great job, man.

16
00:00:39.872 --> 00:00:40.376
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

17
00:00:40.376 --> 00:00:41.260
>> That's right ,well,

18
00:00:41.260 --> 00:00:44.650
Zach's pretty much told us [LAUGH]
just about every component that

19
00:00:44.650 --> 00:00:46.430
we're really gonna be talking
about troubleshooting.

20
00:00:46.430 --> 00:00:48.505
And it's gonna be the major
system components, right,

21
00:00:48.505 --> 00:00:50.245
that you see inside of the system unit,
right.

22
00:00:50.245 --> 00:00:52.334
We have our motherboard, right,

23
00:00:52.334 --> 00:00:56.519
motherboard can cause all kinds of
havoc [LAUGH] when things go wrong.

24
00:00:56.519 --> 00:01:01.366
We're gonna talk about our memory, CPU,
as well as some of the power issues that

25
00:01:01.366 --> 00:01:05.670
we might face when it comes to
common symptoms for the A+ exam.

26
00:01:05.670 --> 00:01:09.080
Now, I would recognize some of
the scenarios that we're gonna talk about.

27
00:01:09.080 --> 00:01:12.140
And also do your research because we're
gonna talk about common symptoms.

28
00:01:12.140 --> 00:01:14.340
But keep in mind,
that when it comes to the computing world,

29
00:01:14.340 --> 00:01:19.040
you can find there are many more than just
some of the ones that we talk about here.

30
00:01:19.040 --> 00:01:23.212
Suffice it to say that these will be some
of the major ones that CompTIA is gonna

31
00:01:23.212 --> 00:01:25.729
want you to know when
you sit that 901 exam.

32
00:01:25.729 --> 00:01:29.090
So let's go ahead and let's talk
about just to start our list out.

33
00:01:29.090 --> 00:01:32.108
All right, we'll talk some of
the common symptoms that they

34
00:01:32.108 --> 00:01:34.685
talk about are things like
unexpected shutdowns.

35
00:01:34.685 --> 00:01:39.045
Now, believe it or not, unexpected
shutdowns could actually run hand in hand

36
00:01:39.045 --> 00:01:42.096
with some of the other common
systems we have, right.

37
00:01:42.096 --> 00:01:43.585
Unexpected shutdown, what happens?

38
00:01:43.585 --> 00:01:45.653
You're in the middle of doing something,

39
00:01:45.653 --> 00:01:49.454
maybe watching your favorite YouTube
video, hopefully not at work, right.

40
00:01:49.454 --> 00:01:50.310
>> Not at work.

41
00:01:51.440 --> 00:01:54.567
>> Right, maybe you're using your
line of business software, right,

42
00:01:54.567 --> 00:01:57.705
you're doing something and
all of a sudden your computer shuts down.

43
00:01:57.705 --> 00:01:59.470
So what could the issue be?

44
00:01:59.470 --> 00:02:03.460
Well, the issue could be quite simply, and
I've said this before in other episodes,

45
00:02:03.460 --> 00:02:06.150
it could be the fact that you accidentally
turned off the power to the power

46
00:02:06.150 --> 00:02:07.670
strip, right?

47
00:02:07.670 --> 00:02:08.990
Simple, fix this first.

48
00:02:08.990 --> 00:02:12.320
Unexpected shutdown could be the fact that
the power cable was just pulled out of

49
00:02:12.320 --> 00:02:16.960
the back of the machine or the AC
outlet or the power strip was shutdown.

50
00:02:16.960 --> 00:02:18.650
But the fact that you've
lost power in the building.

51
00:02:18.650 --> 00:02:21.600
But remember, when it comes to your
troubleshooting methods, right,

52
00:02:21.600 --> 00:02:23.830
we talk about narrowing
down the playing field.

53
00:02:23.830 --> 00:02:25.680
Narrowing down the scope, right?

54
00:02:25.680 --> 00:02:28.090
If it happens to be a power
issue inside of your building,

55
00:02:28.090 --> 00:02:31.140
chances are you're not the only one
that's gonna be affected by it, right?

56
00:02:31.140 --> 00:02:32.880
So that one might be
a little bit more obvious.

57
00:02:32.880 --> 00:02:37.538
However, if you can't isolate it down to
the fact that it's happening to everybody,

58
00:02:37.538 --> 00:02:39.360
and it's just happening to you,

59
00:02:39.360 --> 00:02:43.655
what might some of the issues be when
it comes to these unexpected shutdowns?

60
00:02:43.655 --> 00:02:47.195
Right, well there's another one in our
list that actually could be doing this and

61
00:02:47.195 --> 00:02:48.801
that's overheating, right?

62
00:02:48.801 --> 00:02:51.030
>> Yeah.
>> Unexpected shutdowns can happen when

63
00:02:51.030 --> 00:02:56.030
your system heats up so much that things
like the thermal temperature sensors that

64
00:02:56.030 --> 00:02:58.890
are built into, for
instance like our CPUs,

65
00:02:58.890 --> 00:03:02.430
they try to protect themselves from damage
and they shut themselves down, right.

66
00:03:02.430 --> 00:03:05.360
They do that to make sure that they
try to protect themselves from

67
00:03:05.360 --> 00:03:06.270
thermal damage, right.

68
00:03:06.270 --> 00:03:09.390
See, when a CPU gets overheated,
thermal damage is very,

69
00:03:09.390 --> 00:03:13.230
very hard to tell if it's happened
just by the average person, right.

70
00:03:13.230 --> 00:03:16.895
I'm sure that if you sent the CPU back
to the manufacturer if it happened to be

71
00:03:16.895 --> 00:03:21.333
under warranty, trust me, they're gonna be
able to see that it's overheating, right?

72
00:03:21.333 --> 00:03:25.180
But one of the telltale scientist
is an unexpected shutdown, right?

73
00:03:25.180 --> 00:03:28.930
This could be due to things like
inadequate cooling inside of the system,

74
00:03:28.930 --> 00:03:30.980
may be you had adequate cooling, right?

75
00:03:30.980 --> 00:03:34.879
Because remember, overheating and
unexpected shutdown it means,

76
00:03:34.879 --> 00:03:38.170
everything was running good,
and then all of the sudden,

77
00:03:38.170 --> 00:03:41.210
it steered away from what
the normality was, right?

78
00:03:41.210 --> 00:03:45.700
And it just automatically or suddenly
happened not automatically, right?

79
00:03:45.700 --> 00:03:47.720
Well, this could be things like dust and
debris, right?

80
00:03:47.720 --> 00:03:49.485
Yes, it could be
inadequate cooling system.

81
00:03:49.485 --> 00:03:53.035
But if it's happening suddenly, what can
happen is if you have an adequate cooling

82
00:03:53.035 --> 00:03:56.975
system, your system fans, you've got
a heat sink, you've got a system fan.

83
00:03:56.975 --> 00:04:01.415
Passive or active cooling on your CPU
where there's a system fan in there.

84
00:04:01.415 --> 00:04:03.595
The system fan might have failed, right?

85
00:04:03.595 --> 00:04:06.815
If that system fan fails for
whatever reason,

86
00:04:06.815 --> 00:04:12.430
then the temperature inside of the system
case, the tower is gonna start to heat up.

87
00:04:12.430 --> 00:04:15.520
The core temperature of the CPU
is gonna start to rise, and

88
00:04:15.520 --> 00:04:20.240
what happens is over a period of time,
everything is running right.

89
00:04:20.240 --> 00:04:23.570
It hits that whatever that spot is and

90
00:04:23.570 --> 00:04:28.860
I'm not sure exactly what it might be but
it hits a certain temperature level,

91
00:04:28.860 --> 00:04:31.120
and everything shuts down,
so it could be overheating.

92
00:04:31.120 --> 00:04:33.750
It could be debris or
dust inside of your case as well,

93
00:04:33.750 --> 00:04:37.570
so be mindful of
the location of your tower.

94
00:04:37.570 --> 00:04:42.086
Right, if your tower happens to be inside
a computing desk slid up against the back

95
00:04:42.086 --> 00:04:44.508
of the computing desk or
the computer desk,

96
00:04:44.508 --> 00:04:47.649
and it's basically blocking
off the rear exhaust vent,

97
00:04:47.649 --> 00:04:52.382
you're crippling your cooling system,
even if you have adequate cooling, right.

98
00:04:52.382 --> 00:04:55.744
If you happen to be a tech, and
you put things back together, but

99
00:04:55.744 --> 00:04:58.340
maybe you forgot one of the system fans,
right.

100
00:04:58.340 --> 00:05:02.410
That could cause an over-heating issue,
and the over-heating issue could lead to

101
00:05:02.410 --> 00:05:04.570
again, things like those
unexpected shutdowns.

102
00:05:04.570 --> 00:05:06.430
>> And
you shouldn't put it near a cat box.

103
00:05:06.430 --> 00:05:08.760
>> Yeah, definitely not, definitely not.

104
00:05:08.760 --> 00:05:09.285
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

105
00:05:09.285 --> 00:05:11.349
>> Not with the cat hair, right?

106
00:05:11.349 --> 00:05:13.087
You'll definitely get dust bunnies,

107
00:05:13.087 --> 00:05:14.113
for sure.
All right,

108
00:05:14.113 --> 00:05:17.535
the other things that could happen too,
they talk about system lockups.

109
00:05:17.535 --> 00:05:19.480
Now system lockups,

110
00:05:19.480 --> 00:05:20.850
some of these are intermittent issues.

111
00:05:20.850 --> 00:05:25.130
And some of the intermittent issues
are very, very hard to tackle, right.

112
00:05:25.130 --> 00:05:27.930
Because what happens one day
doesn't happen the next day,

113
00:05:27.930 --> 00:05:30.640
it never has a consistent pattern.

114
00:05:30.640 --> 00:05:34.750
System lockups could be software,
right, it could be a file corruption,

115
00:05:34.750 --> 00:05:37.420
it could be a virus,
we talked about malware, right.

116
00:05:37.420 --> 00:05:38.659
Could be failing hard drive,

117
00:05:38.659 --> 00:05:41.291
even though we're not really
talking about hard drives here.

118
00:05:41.291 --> 00:05:44.396
We've got an episode where we talk about
troubleshooting things like hard drives

119
00:05:44.396 --> 00:05:45.580
and radar rays.

120
00:05:45.580 --> 00:05:46.860
Could be file corruption, right?

121
00:05:46.860 --> 00:05:49.517
File corruption can cause things
like blue screens, right?

122
00:05:49.517 --> 00:05:53.870
The proprietary crash screens
like blue screens of death.

123
00:05:53.870 --> 00:05:56.020
Pinwheel, if you're talking about Macs.

124
00:05:56.020 --> 00:06:00.040
But, what ends up happening in a system
lockup, could be the memory, rIght.

125
00:06:00.040 --> 00:06:01.840
It could be the fact that
your memory is failing.

126
00:06:01.840 --> 00:06:05.850
And if the memory's failing, well that
can also cause unexpected shutdowns.

127
00:06:05.850 --> 00:06:09.150
See a lot a times [COUGH]
the reason unexpected shutdowns and

128
00:06:09.150 --> 00:06:12.210
these intermittent problems become
very hard to troubleshoot is

129
00:06:12.210 --> 00:06:14.510
it could be a number of things, right?

130
00:06:14.510 --> 00:06:17.059
So definitely keep that in mind,
all right?

131
00:06:17.059 --> 00:06:21.390
Other things that you could see,
blank screen on boot up, on start up.

132
00:06:21.390 --> 00:06:24.600
Now if it's a blank screen on start up,
that could be again,

133
00:06:24.600 --> 00:06:25.740
well, it could be a couple of things.

134
00:06:25.740 --> 00:06:28.162
Could be the fact that your
monitor isn't plugged in.

135
00:06:28.162 --> 00:06:32.010
[LAUGH] But
it could be another memory issue.

136
00:06:32.010 --> 00:06:35.651
Blank screen on start up might be the fact
that you can't load the operating system

137
00:06:35.651 --> 00:06:38.304
in the memory at the time
the operating system bootstraps.

138
00:06:38.304 --> 00:06:40.740
And again,
you don't have an image on the screen.

139
00:06:40.740 --> 00:06:43.220
Right, could the fact that
your video adapter has failed.

140
00:06:43.220 --> 00:06:46.364
Right, it could be the fact that if you
have an integrated video card, right,

141
00:06:46.364 --> 00:06:48.093
integrated video graphics, if you will.

142
00:06:48.093 --> 00:06:49.892
Could be a part of the motherboard, right,

143
00:06:49.892 --> 00:06:52.170
could be part of
the chipset that's failing.

144
00:06:52.170 --> 00:06:57.390
And some of these could be very, very hard
to diagnose what exactly the problem is.

145
00:06:57.390 --> 00:06:59.590
That's why you have to go through
your troubleshooting procedures and

146
00:06:59.590 --> 00:07:04.250
you have to make sure that you
try more than one theory, right.

147
00:07:04.250 --> 00:07:07.305
Don't just stop with one theory
because if it's not the solution,

148
00:07:07.305 --> 00:07:08.980
then you have to go back
to the drawing board.

149
00:07:08.980 --> 00:07:10.930
You have to start
the troubleshooting process over.

150
00:07:10.930 --> 00:07:15.379
So, get into troubleshooting table
with more than one theory, right?

151
00:07:15.379 --> 00:07:17.330
>> Right.
>> Some things though,

152
00:07:17.330 --> 00:07:23.460
they give you some kind of indication of
not only that something's going wrong,

153
00:07:23.460 --> 00:07:26.590
they also give you an indication of
what the problem might be, right.

154
00:07:26.590 --> 00:07:29.080
Or the component that
might be having a problem.

155
00:07:29.080 --> 00:07:33.822
In fact, well, let's go ahead and talk
about things like POST beep codes, right.

156
00:07:33.822 --> 00:07:37.025
POST beep codes are great because of the
fact, remember on the power-on self-test,

157
00:07:37.025 --> 00:07:40.450
right, part of POST is the fact
that we're sending signals.

158
00:07:40.450 --> 00:07:45.180
When the BIOS runs that self-diagnostic
called the power-on self-test,

159
00:07:45.180 --> 00:07:48.290
it's sending out a little electrical
signals to the major components within

160
00:07:48.290 --> 00:07:49.680
the system unit.

161
00:07:49.680 --> 00:07:51.773
And it's expecting to get a response back.

162
00:07:51.773 --> 00:07:55.520
When it gets a response back, it says,
okay, I recognize CPU, that you're there,

163
00:07:55.520 --> 00:07:57.410
memory, I recognize that you're there.

164
00:07:57.410 --> 00:08:01.662
Hard drive, you're there,
video, all of that, RAM.

165
00:08:01.662 --> 00:08:03.710
Again, I recognize these
components are there.

166
00:08:03.710 --> 00:08:05.000
I probably said a couple of those twice.

167
00:08:05.000 --> 00:08:05.805
>> That's okay.

168
00:08:05.805 --> 00:08:07.030
>> I recognize you're there.

169
00:08:07.030 --> 00:08:07.990
We're ready to go.

170
00:08:07.990 --> 00:08:12.009
We can now look for the boot code to
bootstrap the operating system and

171
00:08:12.009 --> 00:08:14.026
get the operating system online.

172
00:08:14.026 --> 00:08:18.110
But if something does go wrong,
if post runs and there's an issue,

173
00:08:18.110 --> 00:08:20.265
you'll get an audible beep.

174
00:08:20.265 --> 00:08:25.140
And why would you get an audible beep
rather than some kinda system log?

175
00:08:25.140 --> 00:08:27.910
You might get that too in BIOS as well.

176
00:08:27.910 --> 00:08:30.801
That's because your video sub
system might not load, and

177
00:08:30.801 --> 00:08:34.638
if your video sub system doesn't load,
there's no way to see blank screen,

178
00:08:34.638 --> 00:08:36.661
basically blank no image on the screen.

179
00:08:36.661 --> 00:08:39.802
It's a blank screen on start up,
I've got nothing to see.

180
00:08:39.802 --> 00:08:43.632
So giving me some kind of visual display
or visual indication isn't gonna help me.

181
00:08:43.632 --> 00:08:48.520
And that's why all of your motherboards
typically had a small built in speaker

182
00:08:48.520 --> 00:08:51.790
mounted soldered in SMD,
surface mounted device.

183
00:08:51.790 --> 00:08:52.321
>> It can be audible.

184
00:08:52.321 --> 00:08:55.696
>> That's right,
soldered right onto the motherboard so

185
00:08:55.696 --> 00:08:59.155
that in that very first early
stages of the boot process.

186
00:08:59.155 --> 00:09:02.340
If there's something wrong,
you'll be made aware of it.

187
00:09:02.340 --> 00:09:05.470
Not visually cuz the video subsystem
might be causing the problem, right?

188
00:09:05.470 --> 00:09:07.020
>> Yeah.
>> But audibly you'll be able to hear it.

189
00:09:07.020 --> 00:09:08.350
In fact, let's go ahead and do this.

190
00:09:08.350 --> 00:09:10.030
We've got a computer right here.

191
00:09:10.030 --> 00:09:12.660
And what I'll go ahead and
do, well, let's go ahead and

192
00:09:12.660 --> 00:09:14.090
see if there is any problems here.

193
00:09:14.090 --> 00:09:16.970
I'm gonna reach over here and I'm gonna
go ahead and start this computer up and

194
00:09:16.970 --> 00:09:18.280
let's see if we have any issues.

195

00:27:33.400 --> 00:27:38.210

00:27:43.260 --> 00:27:46.220

00:29:02.314 --> 00:29:05.681
they talk about attempts to

00:29:05.681 --> 00:29:09.612
This can happen when you've left

00:29:09.612 --> 00:29:14.450

00:29:14.450 --> 00:29:17.700
A lot of times your

00:29:17.700 --> 00:29:19.730

However, I have found where

the CMOS battery there in one

00:29:27.990 --> 00:29:32.820
Where if you put a USB device in

00:29:32.820 --> 00:29:37.980
the BIOS was set to look at USB,
it would find the USB device and if

00:29:42.770 --> 00:29:46.080

00:29:46.080 --> 00:29:50.540
And you'd literally have to remove the USB

00:29:50.540 --> 00:29:51.150

606
00:29:51.150 --> 00:29:57.705
So check your boot order and also
check for non-bootable devices, right?

00:29:57.705 --> 00:29:58.905
Being plugged into the machine.

00:29:58.905 --> 00:30:00.625

00:30:00.625 --> 00:30:05.245
Some of the other things that they talk

00:30:05.245 --> 00:30:07.335
If this happens it could be a shorting.

00:30:07.335 --> 00:30:09.702
Something's grounding out
pay attention to your case.

00:30:09.702 --> 00:30:12.822
Pay attention to wires,

00:30:12.822 --> 00:30:14.942

00:30:14.942 --> 00:30:16.842

00:30:16.842 --> 00:30:18.712
We kinda talked about
the power in general.

00:30:18.712 --> 00:30:23.432
If there's no power to other devices,

00:30:23.432 --> 00:30:27.222

00:30:27.222 --> 00:30:28.422
That can happen too.

I've seen that where and

00:30:33.620 --> 00:30:39.370

00:30:39.370 --> 00:30:43.510
Because it's got an L pattern on it, you
might see that they don't fully sit and

00:30:43.510 --> 00:30:46.568

00:30:46.568 --> 00:30:49.130
If the fan spin and

00:30:49.130 --> 00:30:53.050
nothing else is happening,
pay attention to your post codes, right?

00:30:53.050 --> 00:30:55.040
Your post codes could be an indicator.

Like for instance, when we had the post

00:30:58.186 --> 00:30:59.900

628
00:30:59.900 --> 00:31:01.580
Nothing else was happening, right?

629
00:31:01.580 --> 00:31:03.640
So pay attention to that, too.

630
00:31:03.640 --> 00:31:06.620
Let's see, a couple of other things,
indicator lights.

631
00:31:06.620 --> 00:31:08.570
You could have proprietary
indicator lights.

632
00:31:08.570 --> 00:31:10.400
You have the front panel.

00:31:10.400 --> 00:31:14.320
Indicator lights that tell
you have drive activity,

634
00:31:14.320 --> 00:31:17.290
pay attention if there's a drive
problem it could show you that.

635
00:31:17.290 --> 00:31:21.780
The power light itself could be an
indicator light that it's supposed to go

636
00:31:21.780 --> 00:31:26.040
maybe green or blue and it goes to
an amber color and it stays that way.

637
00:31:26.040 --> 00:31:30.220
That could be a sign indicating that
there's a problem with the machine, you

638
00:31:30.220 --> 00:31:33.840
might have a numerical readout actually
on the front built into the machine too.

639
00:31:33.840 --> 00:31:35.844
Pay attention to your vendors, right?

640
00:31:35.844 --> 00:31:39.037
Go to your vendor's website,
the manufacturer's website, and

641
00:31:39.037 --> 00:31:42.400
pay attention to what some of
the indicator lights are cuz they're not

642
00:31:42.400 --> 00:31:44.470
consistent across all manufacturers.

643
00:31:44.470 --> 00:31:49.040
I've even seen them with in a family
of products that are made by the same

644
00:31:49.040 --> 00:31:52.620
manufacturer where they're just slightly
different between the different models.

645
00:31:52.620 --> 00:31:54.950
So do pay attention to that.

646
00:31:54.950 --> 00:31:58.850
Couple of the big ones here guys and
gals out there to worry about smoke and

647
00:31:58.850 --> 00:31:59.920
a burning smell, all right.

648
00:31:59.920 --> 00:32:02.030
If we talk about smoke,

649
00:32:02.030 --> 00:32:04.730
that's an indication that something
is burning obviously, right?

650
00:32:04.730 --> 00:32:06.000
It is not good.

651
00:32:06.000 --> 00:32:09.160
Make sure that you disconnect the power
from the system even if you have to shut

652
00:32:09.160 --> 00:32:11.280
off the power strip or

653
00:32:11.280 --> 00:32:14.290
unplug from the AC outlet if you
happen to have a power strip.

654
00:32:15.760 --> 00:32:18.390
Be safe, fire safety on that one,

655
00:32:18.390 --> 00:32:22.370
because again it could actually be
a fire that's inside of the machine.

656
00:32:22.370 --> 00:32:24.370
If you're smelling something burnt,

657
00:32:24.370 --> 00:32:27.410
you've already got burnt
metal in the device itself,

658
00:32:27.410 --> 00:32:30.920
it's gonna be a process of elimination
of which device might have failed.

659
00:32:30.920 --> 00:32:32.700
If it happens to be a motherboard,
unfortunately,

660
00:32:32.700 --> 00:32:34.500
you're gonna to replace
the whole entire motherboard.

661
00:32:34.500 --> 00:32:37.020
If it happens to be an adapter card,

662
00:32:37.020 --> 00:32:40.090
you might have the ability to
pull the adapter card out, right?

663
00:32:40.090 --> 00:32:43.740
If it happens to be the CPU,
maybe you can replace the CPU, but

664
00:32:43.740 --> 00:32:47.670
you gotta to be careful because
if the CPU does overheat.

665
00:32:47.670 --> 00:32:50.580
Because of the fact that there is
plastics around that CPU where it

666
00:32:50.580 --> 00:32:52.890
sits in the socket in the motherboard,

667
00:32:52.890 --> 00:32:54.970
you might have melted a portion
of the motherboard too.

668
00:32:54.970 --> 00:32:59.570
So you do have to keep in mind that
usually when you smell smoke or see smoke,

669
00:32:59.570 --> 00:33:01.330
definitely you have to worry about that.

670
00:33:01.330 --> 00:33:02.960
But if you smell a burning smell,

671
00:33:02.960 --> 00:33:05.660
a lot of times it means the components
are just going to have to be replaced.

672
00:33:05.660 --> 00:33:09.680
But, more than anything,
keep yourselves safe out there.

673
00:33:09.680 --> 00:33:10.830
>> Yes.
>> Remember electrical safety,

674
00:33:10.830 --> 00:33:12.440
remember your troubleshooting theory, and

675
00:33:12.440 --> 00:33:15.240
if you don't feel you have
adequate training for

676
00:33:15.240 --> 00:33:18.440
whatever's being presented to you,
then escalate it to somebody who does.

677
00:33:18.440 --> 00:33:22.550
There's no, you know,
don't let egos get involved.

678
00:33:22.550 --> 00:33:26.630
Remember there's no problem saying I
don't know and I need help with that.

679
00:33:26.630 --> 00:33:29.880
Memorize some of these scenarios, and
be familiar with some of the scenarios and

680
00:33:29.880 --> 00:33:33.070
symptoms that we've talked about in this
episode, and you should be doing well for

681
00:33:33.070 --> 00:33:34.230
your A plus exam.

682
00:33:34.230 --> 00:33:35.582
>> Awesome as usual, Wes.

683
00:33:35.582 --> 00:33:39.450
Common Mobo, RAM, CPU, and
power issues, wonderful episode.

684
00:33:39.450 --> 00:33:41.330
Rewatching a few times,
it will be good for you.

685
00:33:41.330 --> 00:33:43.000
And also, why don't you do this?

686
00:33:43.000 --> 00:33:47.600
See every episode of the CompTIA plus
series and visit our course library.

687
00:33:47.600 --> 00:33:51.200
There's hundreds of videos right
there to help you go further and

688
00:33:51.200 --> 00:33:54.349
don't forget to tell a friend or
friends about ITProTV.

689
00:33:54.349 --> 00:33:55.400
They'll be glad you did.

690
00:33:55.400 --> 00:33:56.100
Thanks for watching.

691
00:33:56.100 --> 00:33:56.870
I'm Zach Memos.

692
00:33:56.870 --> 00:33:57.640
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

693
00:33:57.640 --> 00:34:00.104
>> And we'll see you again soon

694
00:34:00.104 --> 00:34:06.066
[MUSIC]

695
00:34:06.066 --> 00:34:09.647
Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes troubleshoot common problems related to motherboards, RAM, CPU, and power with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here includes: POST beeps, BIOS settings and/or time resets, trying to boot to incorrect device, no power to system or devices, noises, indicator lights, and proprietary screen crashes (e.g. BSOD).
episodes.title: Motherboard, RAM, CPU and Power Issues Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.290 --> 00:00:02.820
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.820 --> 00:00:06.253
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.253 --> 00:00:08.165
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.165 --> 00:00:10.720
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.280 --> 00:00:14.080
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:14.080 --> 00:00:16.662
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.662 --> 00:00:19.590
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

8
00:00:19.590 --> 00:00:23.510
we are continuing in A+ series and
we're glad your joining us again today.

9
00:00:23.510 --> 00:00:26.790
And joining us as well again today
is our good friend, Mr Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:26.790 --> 00:00:28.710
Wes, glad to have you again,
how's it going today, man?

11
00:00:28.710 --> 00:00:29.740
>> Man, it's going great.

12
00:00:29.740 --> 00:00:32.332
Looking through a plethora of different
things we have to worry about.

13
00:00:32.332 --> 00:00:33.270
>> A plethora.

14
00:00:33.270 --> 00:00:34.220
>> Yeah.
>> It's a nice word.

15
00:00:34.220 --> 00:00:35.130
>> It is, it is.

16
00:00:35.130 --> 00:00:36.491
>> That calendar's really working out for
you.

17
00:00:36.491 --> 00:00:38.474
[LAUGH]
>> Man, I have no clue what it means, but

18
00:00:38.474 --> 00:00:39.522
when you get one word a day.

19
00:00:39.522 --> 00:00:40.453
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

20
00:00:40.453 --> 00:00:42.383
>> [LAUGH] That's right, so we have to,

21
00:00:42.383 --> 00:00:43.640
what are we doing here?

22
00:00:43.640 --> 00:00:47.970
We're continuing on when it comes to
troubleshooting motherboards, RAM,

23
00:00:47.970 --> 00:00:50.000
CPU, and power issues.

24
00:00:50.000 --> 00:00:51.180
And we talked in the first part,

25
00:00:51.180 --> 00:00:53.970
we talked about some of the different
things that you could see.

26
00:00:53.970 --> 00:00:58.366
Unexpected shut down, system locks, and
we'll talked a little bit more about

27
00:00:58.366 --> 00:01:01.660
things like for
instance your post-error codes, right.

28
00:01:01.660 --> 00:01:05.325
So we talk about post-code beeps.

29
00:01:05.325 --> 00:01:09.502
Remember ladies and gentlemen, there
are so many different types out there

30
00:01:09.502 --> 00:01:13.938
that you really just, I think for the A+
exam what you have to know is that, hey,

31
00:01:13.938 --> 00:01:18.575
if I hear an audible beep, it's gonna
be some kind of post beep that happens.

32
00:01:18.575 --> 00:01:22.425
It's gonna be the power on self test run,
discovered a problem with some of

33
00:01:22.425 --> 00:01:27.395
the hardware, so BIOS couldn't initialize
it, and we get some kind of stop.

34
00:01:27.395 --> 00:01:32.318
Sometimes you'll get for instance, the
whole entire computer will just stop and

35
00:01:32.318 --> 00:01:36.455
you'll have a low resolution,
very pixelated test on the screen and

36
00:01:36.455 --> 00:01:38.117
some kind of information.

37
00:01:38.117 --> 00:01:41.230
However, it could be
just the audible beeps.

38
00:01:41.230 --> 00:01:43.890
And the reason I say that, one of the
things I didn't mention in the last part

39
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:48.930
is, well, you have to understand that
when post runs your video subsystem

40
00:01:48.930 --> 00:01:52.315
hasn't even initialized yet, so
that's why we have the audible beeps.

41
00:01:52.315 --> 00:01:55.790
Right,it's not even part of your
sound card, believe it or not.

42
00:01:55.790 --> 00:02:00.770
It's actually an external speaker that
takes very little to bring online,

43
00:02:00.770 --> 00:02:05.970
if you will, and that's just in
the firmware of your BIOS ROM chip.

44
00:02:05.970 --> 00:02:08.230
So those are some of the things we
talked about in the first part.

45
00:02:08.230 --> 00:02:12.635
If, that isn't making sense to you,
you're like, hm, I don't remember that.

46
00:02:12.635 --> 00:02:15.086
Make sure you go back and watch that part,
and then come back here and

47
00:02:15.086 --> 00:02:15.826
join us in part two.

48
00:02:15.826 --> 00:02:18.485
Now, speaking of part two,
what are we going into now?

49
00:02:18.485 --> 00:02:21.055
Well, we're gonna continue on in
the list here of our objectives.

50
00:02:21.055 --> 00:02:25.241
Given a scenario troubleshoot common
problems related to motherboards, RAM,

51
00:02:25.241 --> 00:02:26.543
CPU, and power issues.

52
00:02:26.543 --> 00:02:30.080
And then troubleshooting those
with the appropriate tools.

53
00:02:30.080 --> 00:02:33.410
All right so,
moving on down the list here, we talk,

54
00:02:33.410 --> 00:02:35.970
they mentioned blank screen at boot up.

55
00:02:35.970 --> 00:02:39.170
All right, blank screen at boot up,
well this could be a memory issue and

56
00:02:39.170 --> 00:02:40.050
sometimes it is.

57
00:02:41.430 --> 00:02:45.810
Remember, it might be video but
however, I have to keep in mind that,

58
00:02:45.810 --> 00:02:49.030
you remember the video subsystem
is gonna be checked during post.

59
00:02:49.030 --> 00:02:52.620
So, this could be some kind
of error within the memory,

60
00:02:52.620 --> 00:02:54.340
the memory module is failing.

61
00:02:54.340 --> 00:02:56.600
Keep in mind that you also
have sub-BIOS routines.

62
00:02:56.600 --> 00:02:59.011
And we really haven't talked
about those too much.

63
00:02:59.011 --> 00:03:01.300
I don't think it's something
that's gonna come up on the exam.

64
00:03:01.300 --> 00:03:04.060
But you also have sub-BIOS routines,
like for instance,

65
00:03:04.060 --> 00:03:06.380
when your graphics card comes online.

66
00:03:06.380 --> 00:03:07.760
It has all the hardware and

67
00:03:07.760 --> 00:03:11.500
firmware built in the graphics card
that it runs its own diagnostic check.

68
00:03:11.500 --> 00:03:15.840
And what it does is, the main bios says,
okay, I see you there video card,

69
00:03:15.840 --> 00:03:20.990
you have your own BIOS, you can run
your own little post diagnostic,

70
00:03:20.990 --> 00:03:25.190
I'll just hold back and you can just
report back to me that everything is okay.

71
00:03:25.190 --> 00:03:29.629
Now, if there is an integrated video,
then that's gonna be

72
00:03:29.629 --> 00:03:34.777
diagnosed during post and it should
come back with some kind of error.

73
00:03:34.777 --> 00:03:38.403
So, don't necessarily think that
the screen is blank on boot up,

74
00:03:38.403 --> 00:03:42.936
could be your video card, could be memory
issues, but here's the other thing that

75
00:03:42.936 --> 00:03:47.320
you got to always remember too, and I want
you to remember this for the A+ exam.

76
00:03:47.320 --> 00:03:50.507
We have stressed over and over through
the 901, that simple fix is first.

77
00:03:50.507 --> 00:03:53.965
Right, when we talked about networking,
we went into our networking episodes,

78
00:03:53.965 --> 00:03:56.419
we talked about, well,
if I don't have a link light, and

79
00:03:56.419 --> 00:03:59.950
I don't have a network connection, what
is the first thing I should test, right?

80
00:03:59.950 --> 00:04:00.960
I should check my cables.

81
00:04:00.960 --> 00:04:04.836
Right, I should make sure that the cable
is plugged in, I should make sure that

82
00:04:04.836 --> 00:04:08.870
the router is turned on, right, so
again, very simple fixes, right?

83
00:04:08.870 --> 00:04:11.080
Make sure that you have drivers
present in your network adapter.

84
00:04:11.080 --> 00:04:15.510
Well, if there isn't any screen, if you
don't have anything on the screen, and

85
00:04:15.510 --> 00:04:20.100
it's blank during boot up, you might wanna
find out if the monitor's even plugged in.

86
00:04:20.100 --> 00:04:23.300
And as simple as that sounds in me, you
might say, hey, well that's so trivial,

87
00:04:23.300 --> 00:04:25.290
how could that be on the exam?

88
00:04:25.290 --> 00:04:26.730
It very well could be on the exam.

89
00:04:26.730 --> 00:04:29.150
Now I can't tell you what
questions are on the exam.

90
00:04:29.150 --> 00:04:33.570
Well, that first of all, would be
cheating, but the questions that you get

91
00:04:33.570 --> 00:04:35.760
might not necessarily be
the questions somebody else gets.

92
00:04:35.760 --> 00:04:39.100
So if anybody tells you, well,
I didn't get that question on my exam,

93
00:04:39.100 --> 00:04:40.390
well it's probably right.

94
00:04:40.390 --> 00:04:42.010
Remember they do change it up a lot.

95
00:04:42.010 --> 00:04:43.810
So check your monitor connections, right?

96
00:04:43.810 --> 00:04:46.510
Check connections to
the video card itself.

97
00:04:46.510 --> 00:04:50.660
The other thing that you might keep
in mind too is in your BIOS settings.

98
00:04:50.660 --> 00:04:56.620
That if you do have an integrated video
adapter, and you have installed a graphics

99
00:04:56.620 --> 00:04:59.700
card, make sure that the configurations
and the BIOS are correct as well.

100
00:04:59.700 --> 00:05:03.721
So just a couple of side things
that you might need to consider and

101
00:05:03.721 --> 00:05:06.328
when it comes to the BIOS configuration,

102
00:05:06.328 --> 00:05:10.440
that's more related to your
motherboard versus a memory issue.

103
00:05:10.440 --> 00:05:14.777
All right, some of the other things
that they always also mention here.

104
00:05:14.777 --> 00:05:17.820
They talk about BIOS and setting resets.

105
00:05:17.820 --> 00:05:21.650
BIOS time and setting resets.

106
00:05:21.650 --> 00:05:24.180
Now this can happen for,
well, a couple of reasons.

107
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:27.280
One of the most common reasons,
which is really what we're looking for

108
00:05:27.280 --> 00:05:28.780
is the commonality here.

109
00:05:28.780 --> 00:05:33.661
One of the most common reasons that this
can happen is because, well, your little,

110
00:05:33.661 --> 00:05:37.923
I think it's a 2332, I don't know
exactly what the BiOS battery is,

111
00:05:37.923 --> 00:05:39.398
let me check it out here.

112
00:05:39.398 --> 00:05:43.580
But that little BiOS battery,
or CMOS battery, excuse me,

113
00:05:43.580 --> 00:05:47.526
the complementary metal
oxide semiconductor battery.

114
00:05:47.526 --> 00:05:52.299
It's a little CR2032 battery,
and it's responsible for

115
00:05:52.299 --> 00:05:56.360
holding the real-time clock
inside of your system.

116
00:05:56.360 --> 00:05:59.190
Keep in mind that we have
across the motherboard,

117
00:05:59.190 --> 00:06:02.840
we talk about bus speeds,
we talk about timing.

118
00:06:02.840 --> 00:06:06.200
Right, asynchronous and
synchronous communications and

119
00:06:06.200 --> 00:06:09.840
when we talk about synchronizing
communications across the motherboard,

120
00:06:09.840 --> 00:06:11.830
you need some kinda heartbeat, all right?

121
00:06:11.830 --> 00:06:14.950
And again, kinda like, and Dan,
I know you're into music heavily, right?

122
00:06:14.950 --> 00:06:15.630
Metronome, right?

123
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:18.280
What does a metronome do for
you as a guitarist?

124
00:06:18.280 --> 00:06:19.490
>> Yeah, just keeps your time, right?

125
00:06:19.490 --> 00:06:21.504
You set it to a certain beats per minute,
and

126
00:06:21.504 --> 00:06:23.747
that way you know you're
on the beat every time.

127
00:06:23.747 --> 00:06:27.820
It's a way for your gauge whether
your timing is the right timing.

128
00:06:27.820 --> 00:06:30.850
>> And most definitely, and that's
what a real time clock essentially is.

129
00:06:30.850 --> 00:06:31.980
If you want an analogy,

130
00:06:31.980 --> 00:06:36.770
that's analogous to what our real
time clock is inside of our machine.

131
00:06:36.770 --> 00:06:40.310
Now that real time clock, once it's set,

132
00:06:40.310 --> 00:06:45.364
those settings are retained in the
Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor

133
00:06:45.364 --> 00:06:47.810
settings, the CMoss settings.

134
00:06:47.810 --> 00:06:51.110
Remember, the BIOS itself
has a hard coded time.

135
00:06:51.110 --> 00:06:54.510
Right, and the hard coded time,
it could be set a couple different ways.

136
00:06:54.510 --> 00:06:57.819
It could be when the computer is actually
released from the manufacture, or

137
00:06:57.819 --> 00:07:01.360
more specifically, the motherboard
that's within the computer.

138
00:07:01.360 --> 00:07:06.010
When that motherboard is released,
it has an initial set of firmware in it.

139
00:07:06.010 --> 00:07:10.470
In that firmware, when it was released
they had a hard coded time, all right?

140
00:07:10.470 --> 00:07:12.940
It is one that will always be there.

141
00:07:12.940 --> 00:07:15.420
With one exception,
if you flash the firmware,

142
00:07:15.420 --> 00:07:18.962
if you update firmware, every time you
update the firmware, that little hard

143
00:07:18.962 --> 00:07:24.550
coded time is going to be basically, reset
to the moment that you flash the firmware.

144
00:07:24.550 --> 00:07:28.920
However, that doesn't set the real
time clock that has to stay up

145
00:07:28.920 --> 00:07:30.460
to date in the computer.

146
00:07:30.460 --> 00:07:35.190
That is a user defined setting
that is retained through the 2032,

147
00:07:35.190 --> 00:07:38.210
CR2032 CMOS,
a little three hole watch battery.

148
00:07:38.210 --> 00:07:44.600
When that battery fails, all right,
your computer fails to keep its time.

149
00:07:44.600 --> 00:07:48.237
Now I know they call it BIOS time, I'm not
trying to confuse you guys here, gals,

150
00:07:48.237 --> 00:07:48.890
by any means.

151
00:07:48.890 --> 00:07:50.566
Just keep in mind that,
that setting can change.

152
00:07:50.566 --> 00:07:55.398
And if that time changes,
what happens is Remember that the settings

153
00:07:55.398 --> 00:08:00.395
that are stored in CMOS are volatile
which means if I lose power to them,

154
00:08:00.395 --> 00:08:04.003
I no longer have those settings retained,
right.

155
00:08:04.003 --> 00:08:07.730
It just basically dissipates away and
we lose it.

156
00:08:07.730 --> 00:08:10.550
The other thing, too, is when you
have manufacturer defined settings,

157
00:08:10.550 --> 00:08:12.750
those are retained in the EEPROM chip.

158
00:08:12.750 --> 00:08:16.730
All right so for instance when I first got
the computer, it only had a single hard

159
00:08:16.730 --> 00:08:20.080
drive in it but the motherboard
supports eight hookups, right?

160
00:08:20.080 --> 00:08:24.720
So I populated every one of those drives,
got a massive fiber ray in there, right?

161
00:08:24.720 --> 00:08:27.511
Well I had to configure those and
I had to turn those interfaces on, right.

162
00:08:27.511 --> 00:08:30.298
You've seen in our BIOS setting
where we've gone into the BIOS and

163
00:08:30.298 --> 00:08:33.300
we turned on and
enabled a hard drive interface, right?

164
00:08:33.300 --> 00:08:37.471
Well, the fact that that is enabled is
retained in user defined settings that is

165
00:08:37.471 --> 00:08:39.229
stored in CMOS battery.

166
00:08:39.229 --> 00:08:43.811
All right when that battery is lost,
or the voltage if you will, changes or

167
00:08:43.811 --> 00:08:48.000
is reduced,
those settings are completely discarded.

168
00:08:48.000 --> 00:08:52.137
So, one of the telltale signs you can
see that your CMOS battery needs to be

169
00:08:52.137 --> 00:08:56.573
replaced It's when you reboot the computer
and the time is it isn't the same.

170
00:08:56.573 --> 00:09:00.086
It's usually several years earlier
depending on how long you've had

171
00:09:00.086 --> 00:09:02.800
the computer, several months earlier.

172
00:09:02.800 --> 00:09:07.060
So you go in there and you set the time
right, and while the computer's on, guess

173
00:09:07.060 --> 00:09:11.960
what, you have power you have voltage
going into it that time stays the same.

00:09:11.960 --> 00:09:15.240
The moment you reboot the computer,
remember volatile memory?

00:09:15.240 --> 00:09:18.950
Break the current,
settings are essentially lost.

00:11:17.090 --> 00:11:21.545

00:11:29.870 --> 00:11:33.780

00:11:33.780 --> 00:11:38.180

00:11:48.588 --> 00:11:51.830

00:11:51.830 --> 00:11:54.720
Well one of the things that might need to

223
00:11:54.720 --> 00:11:57.650
The biggest system, and it's not really
a system fan, it's called CPU fan.

224
00:11:57.650 --> 00:12:00.910
So let me be very clear on this one
because sometimes we genericize when

225
00:12:00.910 --> 00:12:03.640

00:12:03.640 --> 00:12:09.065
The CPU fan, if it fails, again,

227
00:12:09.065 --> 00:12:11.883
But as you start to use the machine,
it starts to ramp up the voltage,

228
00:12:11.883 --> 00:12:13.592

229
00:12:13.592 --> 00:12:16.736
We have stepping technologies that step

230
00:12:16.736 --> 00:12:19.145

when you don't need it.

231
00:12:19.145 --> 00:12:22.845
But as that voltage steps up, remember
the more electrical current that is passed

232
00:12:22.845 --> 00:12:25.325

the hotter it's gonna get.

233
00:12:25.325 --> 00:12:29.866
And that at a certain point, the thermal
temperature sensor in that triggers and

234
00:12:29.866 --> 00:12:32.100

235
00:12:32.100 --> 00:12:36.651
Now, once the cpu is heated up enough
it will continuously reboot the machine

236
00:12:36.651 --> 00:12:38.971
because when it shuts down it boots up.

237
00:12:38.971 --> 00:12:42.877
And then the thermal temperature center
says, I'm still hot, shuts down and

238
00:12:42.877 --> 00:12:45.120
you go through this horrible process.

00:12:45.120 --> 00:12:46.789

00:23:33.290 --> 00:23:35.330

that could be a sign that

00:23:39.310 --> 00:23:39.867
All right?

Power supplies itself,
if the fan is spinning and

00:23:48.689 --> 00:23:53.369

00:23:53.369 --> 00:23:54.669

00:23:54.669 --> 00:23:56.611
Essentially what this means is that,

00:24:10.574 --> 00:24:14.404

other devices connected, all right?

00:25:07.730 --> 00:25:12.630

00:25:12.630 --> 00:25:18.500

00:31:44.373 --> 00:31:48.626
we look forward to seeing the culmination
of this particular domain.

625
00:31:48.626 --> 00:31:52.025
Thanks for joining us everyone, signing
off for ITProTV, I've been your host,

626
00:31:52.025 --> 00:31:52.750
Daniel Lowrie.

627
00:31:52.750 --> 00:31:53.897
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.
>> And we'll see you next time.

628
00:31:53.897 --> 00:32:01.817
[MUSIC]

629
00:32:01.817 --> 00:32:04.364
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes troubleshoot common problems related to motherboards, RAM, CPU, and power with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here includes: demonstration of dead CMOS battery, POST Card demo, and testing for a bad power supply.
episodes.title: Motherboard, RAM, CPU and Power Issues Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.342
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.342 --> 00:00:04.326
I'm your host [INAUDIBLE]

3
00:00:04.326 --> 00:00:07.581
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:07.581 --> 00:00:10.639
You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.639 --> 00:00:13.245
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

6
00:00:13.245 --> 00:00:17.390
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.390 --> 00:00:21.280
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and today's
episode, it's all about the A+ series,

8
00:00:21.280 --> 00:00:25.440
that's right, always back for the good
old 22901, don't you just love it?

9
00:00:25.440 --> 00:00:27.198
Let's just ruminate in it.

10
00:00:27.198 --> 00:00:31.228
And here to help us [LAUGH] stew in that
juice is our good friend Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:31.228 --> 00:00:32.732
Wes, we're glad to have you back today,
and how's it going?

12
00:00:32.732 --> 00:00:33.940
>> Well, now you're making me hungry.

13
00:00:33.940 --> 00:00:35.173
>> [LAUGH]
>> Now I'm thinking stew, that's for sure.

14
00:00:35.173 --> 00:00:37.072
>> I gotta have food.

15
00:00:37.072 --> 00:00:38.478
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's right-

16
00:00:38.478 --> 00:00:39.746
>> Cut the camera!

17
00:00:39.746 --> 00:00:40.530
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] We're gonna

18
00:00:40.530 --> 00:00:42.009
>> We're gonna move into part three,

19
00:00:42.009 --> 00:00:42.854
as you can see here.

20
00:00:42.854 --> 00:00:47.505
And we've been talking about some
different issues that you can face with

21
00:00:47.505 --> 00:00:50.620
your motherboards, and CPUs, and RAM.

22
00:00:50.620 --> 00:00:53.692
And we've shown some stuff,
but we really wanna kinda,

23
00:00:53.692 --> 00:00:56.572
in this last part,
kinda show you some of the things,

24
00:00:56.572 --> 00:01:00.020
the physical hands-on parts
that you might end up seeing.

25
00:01:00.020 --> 00:01:02.614
When it comes to being
some kinda A+ technician,

26
00:01:02.614 --> 00:01:05.780
or if you're working the tech bench or
maybe even help desk.

27
00:01:05.780 --> 00:01:10.340
So that's really what we're gonna
take care of here in this last part,

28
00:01:10.340 --> 00:01:13.230
guys and gals, cuz we've been saying that.

29
00:01:13.230 --> 00:01:17.860
And well, we've just been, the
cliffhangers right there towards the end.

30
00:01:17.860 --> 00:01:19.920
So-
>> We keep promising and not delivering.

31
00:01:19.920 --> 00:01:21.906
>> That's right.
>> Today's the day, this is the show.

32
00:01:21.906 --> 00:01:25.510
>> We're gonna make like Cliff
the mailman and delivery has arrived.

33
00:01:25.510 --> 00:01:26.222
>> That's right.

34
00:01:26.222 --> 00:01:26.868
[LAUGH]
>> So,

35
00:01:26.868 --> 00:01:29.475
yeah, some of you guys
might understand that.

36
00:01:29.475 --> 00:01:30.740
Some of you, it's like, Cliff, who's he?

37
00:01:30.740 --> 00:01:32.255
But go check it out for sure.

38
00:01:32.255 --> 00:01:33.045
>> Cliff Clavin.

39
00:01:33.045 --> 00:01:35.055
>> Google will be your friend on that one,
for sure.

40
00:01:35.055 --> 00:01:36.015
>> Google Cliff Clavin.

41
00:01:36.015 --> 00:01:38.365
>> So when we talk about some
of the issues that you can face,

42
00:01:38.365 --> 00:01:40.395
some of the things that you could see.

43
00:01:40.395 --> 00:01:43.745
One of the things that we had talked
about in the previous episodes

44
00:01:43.745 --> 00:01:48.740
was your BIOS time and settings are reset.

45
00:01:48.740 --> 00:01:52.760
Right now,
don't let that term BIOS time confuse you.

46
00:01:52.760 --> 00:01:54.729
Because I also said CMOS settings.

47
00:01:54.729 --> 00:01:57.150
So what are we talking about?

48
00:01:57.150 --> 00:01:59.130
Just remember that when
they say BIOS time,

49
00:01:59.130 --> 00:02:02.360
generically you might even
hear the term BIOS CMOS, and

50
00:02:02.360 --> 00:02:05.500
those are just because they use
them interchangeably today, right?

51
00:02:05.500 --> 00:02:09.959
And that's just the fact that that
complementary metal oxide semiconductor is

52
00:02:09.959 --> 00:02:13.564
what really is helping you to
retain the user defined settings.

53
00:02:13.564 --> 00:02:18.729
And in the BIOS ROM chip, read only
memory, you've electrically flashed or

54
00:02:18.729 --> 00:02:23.980
electrically programmed the EEPROM chip
to retain those firmware settings.

55
00:02:23.980 --> 00:02:26.470
So again,
kinda using them interchangeably.

56
00:02:26.470 --> 00:02:32.402
Keep in mind that it is the CMOS battery
that is what provides the voltage for

57
00:02:32.402 --> 00:02:33.823
those settings.

58
00:02:33.823 --> 00:02:37.701
Now one of the things that we went ahead
and did is we've got a computer up here.

59
00:02:37.701 --> 00:02:39.213
And if we could take a look at it,

60
00:02:39.213 --> 00:02:42.810
you could see that we've got kind of
like the side already taken apart here.

61
00:02:42.810 --> 00:02:45.774
And we're gonna show you some of the
tools, because that's one of the things

62
00:02:45.774 --> 00:02:48.337
they talk about in the objectives
is using the appropriate tools.

63
00:02:48.337 --> 00:02:52.250
Well one of the tools that we have is
what is known as the power on self test.

64
00:02:52.250 --> 00:02:55.289
So we're gonna go ahead and
kinda show you what you would see.

65
00:02:55.289 --> 00:03:00.180
Let's say, for instance, if you were
first of all maybe replacing one of these

66
00:03:00.180 --> 00:03:04.560
batteries for the very first time or
the battery had outright failed and

67
00:03:04.560 --> 00:03:06.243
then you had to replace it.

68
00:03:06.243 --> 00:03:07.647
So we're gonna go ahead and

69
00:03:07.647 --> 00:03:11.750
we're gonna start up this machine and what
we want you to see is the post screen.

70
00:03:11.750 --> 00:03:14.537
Now you'll notice if we bring
up that post screen, right,

71
00:03:14.537 --> 00:03:17.792
well, you know the computer screen,
it's gonna be blank, right?

72
00:03:17.792 --> 00:03:21.357
It's going to be pretty much all blank,
we're not gonna see anything,

73
00:03:21.357 --> 00:03:24.830
what we're gonna end up seeing is
really just a black screen, right?

74
00:03:24.830 --> 00:03:27.420
And that's okay, because
the machine doesn't have any power.

75
00:03:27.420 --> 00:03:31.260
But let's go ahead and
let's look at the power screen.

76
00:03:31.260 --> 00:03:31.810
All right, Dan,

77
00:03:31.810 --> 00:03:34.252
this is what we should be seeing if we
don't have any power on the machine here.

78
00:03:34.252 --> 00:03:39.709
So what we're gonna go ahead and
do is we will power this machine up and

79
00:03:39.709 --> 00:03:44.050
we should see some kind of
BIOS screen come up, right?

80
00:03:44.050 --> 00:03:45.375
So we'll go ahead and we'll press power.

81
00:03:45.375 --> 00:03:49.745
And sometimes it takes a little bit to
see the screen depending on what kind of

82
00:03:49.745 --> 00:03:52.010
firmware that you have in the machine.

83
00:03:52.010 --> 00:03:55.415
Sometimes you might have a dual
firmware and if it's in the process of

84
00:03:55.415 --> 00:03:58.644
rebuilding one of the BIOS,
if they ended up getting corrupted,

85
00:03:58.644 --> 00:04:00.896
it could take a good bit
to even see anything.

86
00:04:00.896 --> 00:04:06.385
Now you can see that it is trying to
go through its basic boot, right.

87
00:04:06.385 --> 00:04:10.030
And notice right away, this is something
that we kinda wanted you to see.

88
00:04:10.030 --> 00:04:14.290
Notice it says performing
automatic IDE configuration.

89
00:04:14.290 --> 00:04:18.372
Now, why is it performing some
kind of automatic configuration?

90
00:04:18.372 --> 00:04:22.730
Well, it should already have
configurations stored, right?

91
00:04:22.730 --> 00:04:27.560
And now it's trying to check hard drives,
and notice we get a failure here.

92
00:04:27.560 --> 00:04:31.111
And if we look at what that failure says,
time-of-day not set,

93
00:04:31.111 --> 00:04:32.880
please run the SETUP program.

94
00:04:32.880 --> 00:04:35.317
Notice that it also says Invalid
configuration information, and

95
00:04:35.317 --> 00:04:37.065
again you guys can read
along with me out there.

96
00:04:37.065 --> 00:04:39.310
Please run the SETUP program.

97
00:04:39.310 --> 00:04:43.490
And then again in that next sentence it
says system management hardware requires

98
00:04:43.490 --> 00:04:44.640
a reset, right?

99
00:04:44.640 --> 00:04:49.490
System set up configuration and date and
time require attention after the reset.

100
00:04:49.490 --> 00:04:50.635
So what's going on here, all right?

101
00:04:50.635 --> 00:04:55.409
Well, what's going on is this little
battery that we have inside of

102
00:04:55.409 --> 00:04:59.450
the motherboard has failed to do its job,
right?

103
00:04:59.450 --> 00:05:02.819
And this is indicative of some
kind of CMOS battery failure.

104
00:05:02.819 --> 00:05:04.320
Now what battery do I mean?

105
00:05:04.320 --> 00:05:06.521
Well, I've actually got one
right here in my hands, right?

106
00:05:06.521 --> 00:05:07.920
This is it, right?

107
00:05:07.920 --> 00:05:12.270
It's a little CR I believe CR 2032
three volt watch battery, right?

108
00:05:12.270 --> 00:05:15.420
There's nothing really special about it.

109
00:05:15.420 --> 00:05:18.460
Except for in your computer,
there's something very special about it.

110
00:05:18.460 --> 00:05:23.120
It's holding all of these configurations,
and now that we don't have power

111
00:05:23.120 --> 00:05:26.620
to those configurations, volatile memory,
right, even if it's low voltage.

112
00:05:26.620 --> 00:05:31.180
If it's volatile memory,
no voltage means no configuration.

113
00:05:31.180 --> 00:05:36.290
So this is what you can see if you have
the BIOS settings are reset like they say,

114
00:05:36.290 --> 00:05:38.795
the BIOS time and settings keep resetting,

115
00:05:38.795 --> 00:05:43.050
that basically means this is the problem,
this is the little battery, right?

116
00:05:43.050 --> 00:05:46.470
And one of the things that you also
wanna keep in mind is that in the home

117
00:05:46.470 --> 00:05:47.860
environment, again,

118
00:05:47.860 --> 00:05:50.320
sometimes I've seen where where we
haven't ever changed these at all.

119
00:05:51.350 --> 00:05:54.380
But in a production environment, that's
not something you wanna risk, right?

120
00:05:54.380 --> 00:05:56.430
Especially when we're talking
about server closets, right?

121
00:05:56.430 --> 00:05:59.090
And we're talking about server closets
where you have a potential of thousands of

122
00:05:59.090 --> 00:06:00.410
servers.

123
00:06:00.410 --> 00:06:03.331
If even one of those servers goes
offline and you don't have some kind of

124
00:06:03.331 --> 00:06:06.544
redundancy, not likely that you wouldn't
have some kind of redundancy, but

125
00:06:06.544 --> 00:06:08.602
it could cause a very,
very bad day at the office.

126
00:06:08.602 --> 00:06:12.530
Not for just you as a tech, but
also for the company, right?

127
00:06:12.530 --> 00:06:16.420
As you guys go on to additional
training here at the CompTIA level,

128
00:06:16.420 --> 00:06:19.640
you'll progress through Net+ and
Security+.

129
00:06:19.640 --> 00:06:22.230
You'll learn about business continuity,
right?

130
00:06:22.230 --> 00:06:24.780
Well, your business can't continue
if we have issues like that.

131
00:06:24.780 --> 00:06:27.860
So, that's one of things that we
can hear in the post error code.

132
00:06:27.860 --> 00:06:28.660
You heard the little beep right there.

133
00:06:28.660 --> 00:06:32.400
It's giving me,
telling me something is wrong.

134
00:06:32.400 --> 00:06:34.245
And that's some of the things
that you could see.

135
00:06:34.245 --> 00:06:36.540
So, keep in mind that you
have those audible beeps.

136
00:06:36.540 --> 00:06:38.210
Now that's not the only audible
beep that you could hear too.

137
00:06:38.210 --> 00:06:41.438
What if you end up having memory issues?

138
00:06:41.438 --> 00:06:43.145
All right, well if you have memory issues,

139
00:06:43.145 --> 00:06:45.140
those will give you certain
types of beeps as well.

140
00:06:45.140 --> 00:06:48.270
And like Dan and
I have already stated, keep in mind,

141
00:06:48.270 --> 00:06:52.270
there is a consistency in inconsistency,
if that makes sense.

142
00:06:52.270 --> 00:06:56.018
Between the manufacturers on what kind
of codes, error codes you'll hear.

143
00:06:56.018 --> 00:07:02.120
For instance, Dell,
they're basically like an IBM PC BIOS.

144
00:07:02.120 --> 00:07:06.996
They still have the traditional PC BIOS,
but they have their own dedicated codes.

145
00:07:06.996 --> 00:07:09.760
HP's one that's got a very limited,
you know, amount.

146
00:07:09.760 --> 00:07:11.506
So again, pay attention to that.

147
00:07:11.506 --> 00:07:14.674
So let's go ahead, and what we're gonna
do next is we're gonna figure out,

148
00:07:14.674 --> 00:07:16.937
what happens if something
goes wrong with our memory?

149
00:07:16.937 --> 00:07:19.250
Do we get some kind of
post audible beep there?

150
00:07:19.250 --> 00:07:22.174
Is it something we can tell when
it runs that self diagnostic?

151
00:07:22.174 --> 00:07:24.530
So we'll go ahead and
take a look at that next.

152
00:07:24.530 --> 00:07:28.521
All right, Dan, so I think what I'm
gonna do is simulate a failure that

153
00:07:28.521 --> 00:07:31.446
can kind of happen if a tech
gets into kind of a hurry,

154
00:07:31.446 --> 00:07:34.593
if they're replacing a motherboard,
replacing RAM.

155
00:07:34.593 --> 00:07:37.359
So you'll notice if we
look right down in here,

156
00:07:37.359 --> 00:07:42.281
I've actually removed the RAM altogether,
we don't have a memory module in here.

157
00:07:42.281 --> 00:07:46.181
And what we're doing here is we're
simulating when somebody goes to install

158
00:07:46.181 --> 00:07:48.530
RAM and
they don't properly seat it, right.

159
00:07:48.530 --> 00:07:50.646
It doesn't make an electrical
contact with the motherboard.

160
00:07:50.646 --> 00:07:52.690
It's gonna cause some kind of issue.

161
00:07:52.690 --> 00:07:53.464
Perfect.
Look at that.

162
00:07:53.464 --> 00:07:54.489
Thank you, there, Dan.

163
00:07:54.489 --> 00:07:56.001
>> Coming in with the spotlight.

164
00:07:56.001 --> 00:07:59.945
>> So, the interesting thing about this
is, With the Dell machines here, they

165
00:07:59.945 --> 00:08:04.130
kinda have a post before you even hit the
power button so you're gonna notice that I

166
00:08:04.130 --> 00:08:08.095
don't even have to reach out here and
hit the power button like we did before.

167
00:08:08.095 --> 00:08:09.407
I'm just going to plug the machine in.

168
00:08:09.407 --> 00:08:14.494
[SOUND]
>> It gets real angry.

169
00:08:14.494 --> 00:08:15.776
>> It does, doesn't it?

170
00:08:15.776 --> 00:08:18.192
It's not too happy at me, Dan, right now.

171
00:08:18.192 --> 00:08:23.136
Did you notice that it had some
specific timings of that beep, right?

172
00:08:23.136 --> 00:08:26.896
That isn't like a metronome to
your favorite blues song here.

173
00:08:26.896 --> 00:08:29.957
Let's go ahead and
we're gonna unplug that one more time, and

174
00:08:29.957 --> 00:08:33.887
I'm gonna dissipate all the electrical
current out of here by pressing the power

175
00:08:33.887 --> 00:08:35.182
button and holding it in.

176
00:08:35.182 --> 00:08:38.177
And notice that little light there, just
behind where Dan's shining that light,

177
00:08:38.177 --> 00:08:39.646
notice how it dissipated, it went out.

178
00:08:39.646 --> 00:08:43.934
That lets me know there's not any residual
electrical power on the motherboard.

179
00:08:43.934 --> 00:08:45.326
And we'll do this one more time.

180
00:08:47.358 --> 00:08:48.972
[SOUND] Yep.

181
00:08:48.972 --> 00:08:55.406
[SOUND] All right, so it's letting me
know that there's something wrong.

182
00:08:55.406 --> 00:08:59.696
And that is, that would be something here
where we wanna actually have to go to

183
00:08:59.696 --> 00:09:01.214
Dell's website, right?

184
00:09:01.214 --> 00:09:03.812
I don't know what those codes are,
[LAUGH] we kind of joked around and

185
00:09:03.812 --> 00:09:06.192
I showed you all the different
pages that we had of codes here.

186
00:09:06.192 --> 00:09:07.167
I did that just for

187
00:09:07.167 --> 00:09:11.472
the purposes of showing you guys that
there's a lot of them out there, right?

188
00:09:11.472 --> 00:09:15.193
So at this point, and I've had to do this
too, I've done Dell warranty calls and

189
00:09:15.193 --> 00:09:16.960
stuff and had to talk to technicians.

190
00:09:16.960 --> 00:09:20.036
And they go through a process where
they say, well, did you check this,

191
00:09:20.036 --> 00:09:21.758
did you check this, did you check this?

192
00:09:21.758 --> 00:09:23.774
And then at the end they say, well have
you heard any kind of error codes?

193
00:09:23.774 --> 00:09:24.766
And you say, yeah.

194
00:09:24.766 --> 00:09:26.094
Well, what's the error code?

195
00:09:26.094 --> 00:09:31.134
You try to tell them and they've got
a great customer service base, too.

196
00:09:31.134 --> 00:09:35.232
And you can even kinda hold the phone over
and the tech can listen and say, okay.

197
00:09:35.232 --> 00:09:38.899
I know what that is let me look through my
manual real quick and I'll tell you some

198
00:09:38.899 --> 00:09:42.814
of the steps that we can go through before
we just, let's say ship you out new parts.

199
00:09:42.814 --> 00:09:44.480
So what do we have to do here?

200
00:09:44.480 --> 00:09:48.622
Well, what we end up having to do is we
have to reinstall the memory correctly.

201
00:09:48.622 --> 00:09:51.052
So let's go ahead and let's do that.

202
00:09:51.052 --> 00:09:54.590
Let's take a look at the machine here and
what I'm gonna do, I'm gonna do the same

203
00:09:54.590 --> 00:09:57.894
thing here, ladies and gentlemen,
I'm gonna pull the power, all right?

204
00:09:57.894 --> 00:09:58.886
It's important.

205
00:09:58.886 --> 00:09:59.789
Press the power button, and

206
00:09:59.789 --> 00:10:01.638
that's what I'm doing here on
the front side of the case.

207
00:10:01.638 --> 00:10:03.542
So we'll just hold this power button in.

208
00:10:03.542 --> 00:10:06.873
And it's really important then the reason
we didn't show you the front is all I'm

209
00:10:06.873 --> 00:10:08.330
doing is holding the power button.

210
00:10:08.330 --> 00:10:12.280
I just wanted to see that light just
kind of gently, just fade away.

211
00:10:12.280 --> 00:10:15.338
And again it let's me know that there
isn't any residual power in here.

212
00:10:15.338 --> 00:10:19.850
Now you might be asking yourself, Wes,
where's your ESD wrist strap, right?

213
00:10:19.850 --> 00:10:24.272
Yes, memory, we realize memory is very,
very sensitive to electrostatic discharge.

214
00:10:24.272 --> 00:10:28.840
But keep in mind I am dissipating
any electrical current in my body to

215
00:10:28.840 --> 00:10:32.860
the case right here just by
touching the inside of the case.

216
00:10:32.860 --> 00:10:37.497
And both Dan and I are actually standing
