440
00:21:47.714 --> 00:21:51.213
do is we're going to set up showing
you how you can potentially diagnose,

441
00:21:51.213 --> 00:21:54.960
if you have things like issues with,
for instance the power supply.

442
00:21:54.960 --> 00:21:56.457
So that´s the next thing
we´re going to look at.

443
00:21:56.457 --> 00:21:58.804
Today, yeah,
we were talking about power issues and

444
00:21:58.804 --> 00:22:01.264
some times things don´t
really manifest themselves.

445
00:22:01.264 --> 00:22:05.137
If you know that it´s a power issue,
I can give you one example of where it is.

446
00:22:05.137 --> 00:22:08.766
So for instance, let´s say that
your CPU isn't receiving power,

447
00:22:08.766 --> 00:22:12.470
whether it happens to be a rail coming
off of the power supply itself.

448
00:22:12.470 --> 00:22:18.665
Or it could actually be the connector,
whether it's the 8 pin EPS connector,

449
00:22:18.665 --> 00:22:24.040
or whether it's like the old P4 ATX
connector, if that's failed.

450
00:22:24.040 --> 00:22:27.038
So what I went ahead and
did is I went ahead and pulled,

451
00:22:27.038 --> 00:22:30.050
if you will,
the P4 connector off of the board here.

452
00:22:30.050 --> 00:22:33.942
And it would be no different than if this
failed off of the back of the power supply

453
00:22:33.942 --> 00:22:37.646
or if that port itself you know the
connector on the motherboard had fried.

454
00:22:37.646 --> 00:22:39.163
[CROSSTALK]
>> You're just simulating that failure?

455
00:22:39.163 --> 00:22:40.642
>> Yeah, that absolutely, yeah yeah.

456
00:22:40.642 --> 00:22:43.763
So if we plug this in, this is
an interesting one because remember one of

457
00:22:43.763 --> 00:22:46.728
the things that the objectives have
called that we've called out is

458
00:22:46.728 --> 00:22:49.240
the fact that the fans spin and
nothing happens, right.

459
00:22:49.240 --> 00:22:50.507
So let me show you here.

460
00:22:50.507 --> 00:22:53.119
Notice that the fans are spinning.

461
00:22:53.119 --> 00:22:58.350
Both the system fan and the CPU fan, and
wow, they just instantly turn right off.

462
00:22:58.350 --> 00:23:02.970
So what it did is it noticed that hey,
I notice that I have power to

463
00:23:02.970 --> 00:23:07.936
the three pin and four pin molex KK
connectors on the motherboard that

464
00:23:07.936 --> 00:23:12.408
control the power to the fans but
I've got nothing on the CPU.

465
00:23:12.408 --> 00:23:16.227
So to protect itself,
the mother board said no food for you, and

466
00:23:16.227 --> 00:23:18.150
it shut itself down right away.

467
00:23:18.150 --> 00:23:22.427
So that's actually a good protection
mechanism letting you know that if

468
00:23:22.427 --> 00:23:24.402
the power supply goes like this.

469
00:23:24.402 --> 00:23:26.502
And it isn't giving you any power at all,

470
00:23:26.502 --> 00:23:28.970
you don't have to worry
about damage to the CPU.

471
00:23:28.970 --> 00:23:32.627
Now that's not necessarily the case
if the power itself is lost or

472
00:23:32.627 --> 00:23:36.030
if something's wrong with that
little four pin connector.

473
00:23:36.030 --> 00:23:38.537
So, what would we do, right.

474
00:23:38.537 --> 00:23:40.268
Well, we're gonna go ahead and

475
00:23:40.268 --> 00:23:44.575
do is we're going to kind of show you how
you could test the power supply itself.

476
00:23:44.575 --> 00:23:46.297
So that'll be the next thing
we're going to look at.

477
00:23:46.297 --> 00:23:48.107
So Dan, I guess if we're
going to talk about power,

478
00:23:48.107 --> 00:23:50.512
the first thing we have to do is
a little disclaimer warning, right.

479
00:23:50.512 --> 00:23:54.352
So be very, very careful when you
are testing any kind of power supply,

480
00:23:54.352 --> 00:23:58.512
like we said throughout the last few
parts here that we've been in hardware,

481
00:23:58.512 --> 00:23:59.993
never open a power supply.

482
00:23:59.993 --> 00:24:03.792
Keep in mind that it does have capacitors
in it that can retain their charge

483
00:24:03.792 --> 00:24:07.732
just like the old CRT monitors that,
just on contact could stop your heart.

484
00:24:07.732 --> 00:24:10.601
It isn't something you
want to take very lightly.

485
00:24:10.601 --> 00:24:15.530
If you feel uncomfortable dealing with
any kind of electrical power then by all

486
00:24:15.530 --> 00:24:18.963
means leave it the people,
electrical engineers, or

487
00:24:18.963 --> 00:24:22.190
people that do have
the qualifications to test it.

488
00:24:22.190 --> 00:24:25.460
Now that being said there are some basic
tests that you can run on your power

489
00:24:25.460 --> 00:24:30.590
supplies if you do feel like maybe the
fans are spinning like we've shown you and

490
00:24:30.590 --> 00:24:34.330
we're not getting power to the machine
you can pull out your multimeter.

491
00:24:34.330 --> 00:24:36.500
We've got a power supply already set up.

492
00:24:36.500 --> 00:24:38.500
So here's a power supply
here that we have.

493
00:24:38.500 --> 00:24:42.470
Again this is about 1,100 watt power
supply here and what we're gonna do is

494
00:24:42.470 --> 00:24:45.640
we'll go ahead and we'll turn it
on here and let it start up again.

495
00:24:45.640 --> 00:24:48.600
You can see if something like this
happened where the fan is actually

496
00:24:48.600 --> 00:24:50.780
spinning and you have no power,
then that's pretty,

497
00:24:50.780 --> 00:24:55.270
a good tell tale sign that something
has failed on the power supply.

498
00:24:55.270 --> 00:24:58.890
Now what we have here are the P4
Connectors that I was talking about.

499
00:24:58.890 --> 00:25:02.080
One of the ways that you can test these,
keep in mind our multimeter.

500
00:25:02.080 --> 00:25:03.840
So if we look at our multimeter here.

501
00:25:03.840 --> 00:25:05.370
Notice that what you want to do,

502
00:25:05.370 --> 00:25:09.290
is you want to kind of keep it to the
setting there on the multimeter that is

503
00:25:09.290 --> 00:25:13.200
closest to one of the voltage
of which you're testing.

504
00:25:13.200 --> 00:25:15.660
If we can zoom into the multimeter there,

505
00:25:17.020 --> 00:25:19.330
we will see here that we
got it set on the 20 volts.

506
00:25:19.330 --> 00:25:21.360
And that's as close to what
we are going to be testing,

507
00:25:21.360 --> 00:25:25.320
because what we're gonna be testing
is the 12 volt circuit, if you will.

508
00:25:25.320 --> 00:25:29.260
So I'm going to go ahead, and
what I'll do is I'll touch this negative

509
00:25:30.800 --> 00:25:32.670
probe here to the negative side, and

510
00:25:32.670 --> 00:25:38.440
then what we will do is we'll touch
this to the hot wire if you will and

511
00:25:38.440 --> 00:25:43.560
you'll notice the voltmeter is letting
us know that it is in the 12 volt range.

512
00:25:43.560 --> 00:25:46.990
You can see right here that
it's within its tolerance.

513
00:25:46.990 --> 00:25:49.400
Keep in mind that it may not be exact.

514
00:25:49.400 --> 00:25:53.880
And if it was just a little bit under
you know that might cause a problem but

515
00:25:53.880 --> 00:25:56.930
if you're a little bit over remember
the device can only pull the amount of

516
00:25:56.930 --> 00:26:00.000
power that it's you know
capable of pulling.

517
00:26:00.000 --> 00:26:02.950
Now we could go a little further in than
this and then what I could do is I could

518
00:26:02.950 --> 00:26:05.210
pull over like one of these
Molex connectors here and

519
00:26:05.210 --> 00:26:08.200
we can show you you know again
one of the other voltages and

520
00:26:08.200 --> 00:26:11.280
this ones kind of a little
easier to test out.

521
00:26:11.280 --> 00:26:15.570
Because you can take your negative,
your black is your ground here and

522
00:26:15.570 --> 00:26:19.640
we could test again
the same thing just putting

523
00:26:19.640 --> 00:26:24.340
the black probe here into the ground and
then we can test for

524
00:26:24.340 --> 00:26:28.820
instance the yellow wire here, and
you´ll notice that same thing.

525
00:26:28.820 --> 00:26:29.750
We get our 12 volts.

526
00:26:29.750 --> 00:26:32.070
So you can see that from
two different rails here,

527
00:26:32.070 --> 00:26:34.280
we´re getting 12 volts off of each rail.

528
00:26:34.280 --> 00:26:37.510
I´m going to move this over a little
bit so we don´t arch out here.

529
00:26:37.510 --> 00:26:40.040
And we can test, again, the red.

530
00:26:40.040 --> 00:26:44.840
The red is the five volt,
or should be five volts.

531
00:26:44.840 --> 00:26:47.180
And you can see here too,
we're right in the way,

532
00:26:47.180 --> 00:26:51.040
in a good tolerance so I can tell
that this power supply is giving off

533
00:26:51.040 --> 00:26:54.550
the appropriate voltages that it needs to
be and I'll go ahead and turn this off.

534
00:26:54.550 --> 00:26:56.250
But that's something that you can see,

535
00:26:56.250 --> 00:27:00.670
again keep in mind that when it
comes to testing the power supply.

536
00:27:00.670 --> 00:27:04.150
If Dan or I were, if we were sitting
here and we were working on one of these

537
00:27:04.150 --> 00:27:07.340
machines, we could say, you know what,
we know that the power supply is good.

538
00:27:07.340 --> 00:27:08.480
We put the multimeter on it.

539
00:27:08.480 --> 00:27:11.870
It seems to check out, so
then what would the other thing be?

540
00:27:11.870 --> 00:27:15.710
Well it could be
the motherboard that's failing.

541
00:27:15.710 --> 00:27:17.410
Right?
If you're not getting any

542
00:27:18.590 --> 00:27:20.510
computation out of the CPU.

543
00:27:20.510 --> 00:27:22.140
Could be the fact that the CPU´s failed.

544
00:27:22.140 --> 00:27:25.260
Remember to use your tools that you have.

545
00:27:25.260 --> 00:27:27.890
We´ve kind of shown you in the background
some of the tools that we´ve had up here

546
00:27:27.890 --> 00:27:29.470
on the desk since we´ve started.

547
00:27:29.470 --> 00:27:33.820
You know, your chip inserters,
you have things like your thermal paste.

548
00:27:33.820 --> 00:27:37.060
Remember, that´s the other thing
they did mention overheating.

549
00:27:37.060 --> 00:27:39.380
If you forget to put thermal paste.

550
00:27:39.380 --> 00:27:41.890
And it can happen if
people get in a hurry.

551
00:27:41.890 --> 00:27:44.480
They don't put the thermal paste on,
don't spread it out right.

552
00:27:44.480 --> 00:27:49.110
Remember, what that does is that leaves
a metal on metal contact with the CPU.

553
00:27:49.110 --> 00:27:51.400
Actually, it leaves
a really small air gap, and

554
00:27:51.400 --> 00:27:54.360
that air gap turns into an insulator,
right.

555
00:27:54.360 --> 00:27:56.860
As it heats up it just stays right there,
and

556
00:27:56.860 --> 00:27:59.070
it actually can completely melt the CPU.

557
00:27:59.070 --> 00:28:02.280
So you wanna make sure for instance,
when you're using a thermal compound and

558
00:28:02.280 --> 00:28:04.110
you replacing a CPU or

559
00:28:04.110 --> 00:28:07.600
maybe installing a heat sink to make sure
you have that thermal compound on there.

560
00:28:07.600 --> 00:28:09.180
So, those are a few of the things,

561
00:28:09.180 --> 00:28:14.290
like we say anytime you're dealing
with any product that could have

562
00:28:14.290 --> 00:28:19.150
potential for damage due to static
discharge, electrostatic discharge.

563
00:28:19.150 --> 00:28:21.080
Remember wear your wrist straps or

564
00:28:21.080 --> 00:28:23.800
do what we're doing stand on
electrically resistive maps and

565
00:28:23.800 --> 00:28:27.550
ground out to the case to make sure
that you're dissipating that energy,

566
00:28:27.550 --> 00:28:31.110
that electricity somewhere else other than
the components that you're working on.

567
00:28:31.110 --> 00:28:33.680
Just again I cannot stress enough.

568
00:28:33.680 --> 00:28:36.390
And it comes to this electrical
equipment make sure you're dissipating

569
00:28:36.390 --> 00:28:38.580
all the excess electricity or

570
00:28:38.580 --> 00:28:41.660
discharging any excess electricity
when you pull the power on it.

571
00:28:41.660 --> 00:28:43.870
When you're replacing parts,
push the power button and

572
00:28:43.870 --> 00:28:45.880
let it, you hold it in for
a little bit, right?

573
00:28:45.880 --> 00:28:50.820
And that will make sure that any residual
electrical current that is left inside

574
00:28:50.820 --> 00:28:52.385
of the system is dissipated.

575
00:28:52.385 --> 00:28:55.656
And be very careful if you
don't feel comfortable doing,

576
00:28:55.656 --> 00:28:59.410
what it is that they're asking
you to do well, then escalate it.

577
00:28:59.410 --> 00:29:01.670
That's the reason you have
escalating processes,

578
00:29:01.670 --> 00:29:06.020
escalation processes within
the company that you're working for.

579
00:29:06.020 --> 00:29:08.030
Maybe you're tier one,
you wanna deal with the software,

580
00:29:08.030 --> 00:29:10.440
you don't wanna deal with the hardware,
or vice versa.

581
00:29:10.440 --> 00:29:14.190
Only do that work that
you're qualified for.

582
00:29:14.190 --> 00:29:16.980
And remember some of the things that
we've shown you in this episode or

583
00:29:16.980 --> 00:29:19.280
this mini series we've been doing, so

584
00:29:19.280 --> 00:29:22.780
that if they ask you on the A+ exam,
you'll be able to pass it.

585
00:29:22.780 --> 00:29:25.650
>> Well Wes, thank you so much for
those cool troubleshooting demonstrations,

586
00:29:25.650 --> 00:29:28.740
very good for us to not only
understand the theory behind it but

587
00:29:28.740 --> 00:29:30.440
to see it in practical application.

588
00:29:30.440 --> 00:29:32.560
So hopefully that helped
you guys out there as well.

589
00:29:32.560 --> 00:29:36.150
We work really hard to bring that kind
of content to you people but guess what?

590
00:29:36.150 --> 00:29:38.730
I'm looking at the clock and
we've run out of time for this episode.

591
00:29:38.730 --> 00:29:41.260
We do thank you so much for
watching though signing off for

592
00:29:41.260 --> 00:29:43.340
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

593
00:29:43.340 --> 00:29:44.160
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

594
00:29:44.160 --> 00:29:46.698
>> And we'll see you next time.

595
00:29:46.698 --> 00:29:52.571
[MUSIC]

596
00:29:52.571 --> 00:29:54.590
Thank you for watching IT ProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look at troubleshooting hard drives and RAID arrays with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here includes: Read/Write failures, Slow Performance, CHKDSK, Disk Defrag, and Loud Clicking noises.

As we move out our hardware, we've talked

there, some of the different types of

We talked about all kinds of things,

We talked about things

Different kinds of networking,

28
00:01:04.950 --> 00:01:08.630
Well, in this episode this is where we
start to move into the troubleshooting

29
00:01:08.630 --> 00:01:11.320
side, because we have our hardware.

30

It's important to understand what
the hardware is, what it does,

31
00:01:13.970 --> 00:01:14.630

But it's also important to understand,

33
00:01:16.860 --> 00:01:20.850
especially when it comes to support on

34

And then not only things
that could go wrong, but

35
00:01:23.430 --> 00:01:26.450
some of the symptoms of
a problem that might occur.

36
00:01:26.450 --> 00:01:29.370
And then as well,
well what are some of the remedies, right?

37
00:01:29.370 --> 00:01:33.540
What are some of the things that we can
do in order to diagnose a problem, right?

38

So you gotta recognize, first of all,
there is a problem, right?

39

You need to diagnose that problem,

40

And kind of like you might

we don't wanna just treat the symptoms,

We wanna find out what the cause is.

The symptoms tell us
that there is a problem.

We can find out what the root cause is.

45

And then some of the things that we
can do to maybe repair the problem.

46
00:01:56.400 --> 00:01:59.120
Sometimes it's just a piece

47

get the bugs out.

48

And we're not talking malware,
but who knows, maybe we are.

49
00:02:06.340 --> 00:02:10.670
As well as sometimes, there's just things

50
00:02:10.670 --> 00:02:13.700
failure, component failure,
that you just can't recover from, right?

51

And it might be time and in that case

53

But that's some of the things that

And specifically we're gonna be looking

We're gonna be looking at RAID arrays,

We talk about a way to aggregate,

a couple different reasons.

59
00:02:38.400 --> 00:02:39.780
Either performance, if you will.

60
00:02:39.780 --> 00:02:43.810
We wanna speed up things, or

If one drive happens to fail,

00:02:45.130 --> 00:02:48.670

63

So we might not have access to it

64
00:02:51.930 --> 00:02:54.240

00:13:56.380 --> 00:14:00.910

00:14:00.910 --> 00:14:02.740

00:14:02.740 --> 00:14:05.240

00:14:17.950 --> 00:14:19.600

00:14:19.600 --> 00:14:21.870

00:14:21.870 --> 00:14:24.390

00:14:24.390 --> 00:14:25.740
The cylinder in the middle of it.

00:14:25.740 --> 00:14:27.970
And it just keeps bouncing off of it.

00:14:27.970 --> 00:14:29.160
That's the click of death, right?

00:14:29.160 --> 00:14:30.150
That's a clicking noise.

00:14:30.150 --> 00:14:33.800

00:14:33.800 --> 00:14:37.670

00:14:37.670 --> 00:14:41.720
That is the actuator arm laying

321
00:14:43.162 --> 00:14:48.685
To understand again about the hard drives,
understand that that head actually sits

322
00:14:48.685 --> 00:14:55.035
around five, point zero five microns,
from the, or five microns, I think.

323
00:14:55.035 --> 00:14:56.715
It's five millionths of a meter, right?

00:14:56.715 --> 00:15:00.925
It's so thin in between there,

00:15:00.925 --> 00:15:04.835

00:15:04.835 --> 00:15:07.665

00:15:07.665 --> 00:15:10.170
Remember, that an actuator had,

00:15:10.170 --> 00:15:13.280
the RAID write head doesn't make

00:15:13.280 --> 00:15:16.680
It uses electromagnetic energy to read and

00:15:16.680 --> 00:15:21.017
when it makes that scrapping
sound typically what's

00:15:21.017 --> 00:15:24.220

00:15:24.220 --> 00:15:27.120
Again, it's a moving part and

00:15:28.530 --> 00:15:31.690

00:15:46.960 --> 00:15:50.442
Now that is a telltale sign that

00:15:50.442 --> 00:15:53.901

00:16:10.200 --> 00:16:14.930
Again, it's another tell tale sign

[SOUND] Dan and

00:16:55.410 --> 00:16:56.092

00:16:56.092 --> 00:16:58.241

00:16:58.241 --> 00:17:01.712

00:17:01.712 --> 00:17:03.460

00:17:03.460 --> 00:17:07.430
And, again, this could be could

368
00:17:07.430 --> 00:17:11.430
Notice that we have, these are called,
you know when IDE first came out,

369
00:17:11.430 --> 00:17:14.950
the old parallel drives they called
them integrated drive electronics,

370
00:17:14.950 --> 00:17:17.820
and that's because prior
to IDE drives you'd have

371
00:17:17.820 --> 00:17:20.700
a big expansion card that would
sit in expansion slot, and

00:17:20.700 --> 00:17:24.670
that's how you'd make a connection to the
hard disk, that was the controller, right?

373
00:17:24.670 --> 00:17:27.230
Time passed and they said, well,
let's go ahead and save some space and

374
00:17:27.230 --> 00:17:30.210
let's just take that circuitry, and
as things get smaller, embed it

375
00:17:30.210 --> 00:17:34.290
right into the drive itself, hence the

376
00:17:34.290 --> 00:17:38.190
And you can see it's still trying to,

00:17:38.190 --> 00:17:39.918

00:17:39.918 --> 00:17:40.840
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

00:17:40.840 --> 00:17:43.440

00:17:43.440 --> 00:17:46.380
The controller could fail too, right?

00:17:46.380 --> 00:17:50.890
If the controller has failed, then you

00:17:50.890 --> 00:17:54.630

00:17:54.630 --> 00:17:57.120

00:17:57.120 --> 00:17:59.950
Now, there's other things

00:17:59.950 --> 00:18:01.440
Again, it's a magnetic drive.

00:18:01.440 --> 00:18:04.640
If you place this near

387
00:18:04.640 --> 00:18:09.700
the platters are so

388
00:18:09.700 --> 00:18:14.400
that you could offset that balance,
that could give you a read write failure.

389
00:18:14.400 --> 00:18:16.550
So, for instance,
let me give you an example.

390
00:18:16.550 --> 00:18:20.330
When they do drive recovery, data

00:18:20.330 --> 00:18:22.830

company that Dan used to work for.

392
00:18:22.830 --> 00:18:25.360
This could have very,
very valuable information and

00:18:25.360 --> 00:18:26.910

394
00:18:26.910 --> 00:18:30.880
So they can justify the cost to take
this to a data recovery agent, right?

395
00:18:30.880 --> 00:18:33.610
That would try to remove
the information off of it and

396
00:18:33.610 --> 00:18:36.600
give it back to the organization
that's paying for the service.

397
00:18:36.600 --> 00:18:39.890
They have to so
delicately align those platters back

398
00:18:39.890 --> 00:18:43.440
that they like to take the whole
mechanism right out of the drive.

399
00:18:43.440 --> 00:18:46.550
Not the individual platters, but
literally the whole mechanism, so

400
00:18:46.550 --> 00:18:48.970
that the balance stays correct.

401
00:18:48.970 --> 00:18:51.360
Sometimes, not all the times,

402
00:18:51.360 --> 00:18:55.260
you can replace the drive controller
if you have an identical drive.

00:18:55.260 --> 00:18:57.800
However, keep in mind that

00:18:57.800 --> 00:18:58.570
Let me tell you why.

00:18:58.570 --> 00:19:02.570
The drive controller has obviously
a logic board that's built into it, and

406
00:19:02.570 --> 00:19:05.760
it actually writes to
the platters a little identifier.

407
00:19:05.760 --> 00:19:07.910
And if there's an identifier mismatch,
it says,

00:19:07.910 --> 00:19:09.450
I don't know what the heck
you're talking about.

00:19:09.450 --> 00:19:11.040

00:19:11.040 --> 00:19:14.670
So sometimes you can replace

411
00:19:14.670 --> 00:19:16.830
I go back to what we initially said.

00:19:16.830 --> 00:19:21.330
Back up your information before

00:19:21.330 --> 00:19:24.670
If you start to see that

00:19:24.670 --> 00:19:27.340
you're getting intermittent
failures within your drives.

415
00:19:27.340 --> 00:19:31.320
Make sure again that you

00:19:31.320 --> 00:19:35.640
It is important, in fact, I'm going to
be fixing a computer later on today that

417
00:19:35.640 --> 00:19:40.450
had a Seagate, 7,200 RPM Seagate,

00:19:40.450 --> 00:19:43.840

00:19:43.840 --> 00:19:48.940
he said, I got my data off already the

00:19:48.940 --> 00:19:52.290
I didn't back the machine up or anything,

421
00:19:52.290 --> 00:19:53.700
I moved it to an external drive.

422
00:19:53.700 --> 00:19:56.630
And later, what we're going to try to do,

00:19:56.630 --> 00:20:00.130
is gonna work, is we're going to try to

424
00:20:00.130 --> 00:20:04.640
which means a bit-by-bit replication,
so that when we put the new

00:20:04.640 --> 00:20:09.600
drive in we can just apply that bit by bit
image back to the new drive and hopefully

426
00:20:09.600 --> 00:20:12.880
all the applications are there and

00:20:12.880 --> 00:20:17.800
his information and it's on an external
and now we can do some data recovery.

00:20:17.800 --> 00:20:20.110
All we have to do is reinstall

00:20:20.110 --> 00:20:23.150
pull that information back down
to the machine and luckily for

00:20:23.150 --> 00:20:25.970
him, he should be good and
not dead in the water, right?

431
00:20:25.970 --> 00:20:29.960
>> Yeah, now Wes, is there where we would

00:20:29.960 --> 00:20:33.220
obviously, and I'm kind of setting you

I'm sure,
that our viewers out there have heard of.

You've got to defrag your drive.

00:20:37.590 --> 00:20:40.360
You start having drive problems,

Is that still a viable solution nowadays?

I'll say the only place that that's really

00:20:47.380 --> 00:20:49.850
drives, that it's just because they

00:20:49.850 --> 00:20:51.010

But on these mechanical drives,

00:20:53.420 --> 00:20:56.980
One of the things you might notice

Now slow performance can happen for

00:21:00.020 --> 00:21:03.770
Slow performance quite literally could be

00:21:03.770 --> 00:21:07.370
A lot times slow performance can

00:21:07.370 --> 00:21:11.330
One of the reason could be we like to

00:21:11.330 --> 00:21:15.771

00:21:15.771 --> 00:21:16.278

00:21:16.278 --> 00:21:16.850

00:21:16.850 --> 00:21:20.100
If you get something like a worm

00:21:20.100 --> 00:21:21.460

00:21:21.460 --> 00:21:24.600
It replicates it's self all over,

00:21:24.600 --> 00:21:28.080

The other thing too,

00:21:30.730 --> 00:21:35.158
As you fill up a drive, right,

00:21:35.158 --> 00:21:37.917

00:21:37.917 --> 00:21:41.269

00:21:41.269 --> 00:21:45.927
Dan, you asked about defragmentation, what
ends up happening within your drive is

00:21:45.927 --> 00:21:50.058
when you remove a file or you delete
a file, understand that at the physical

00:21:50.058 --> 00:21:54.452
level, and I mean literally the magnetic
locations, right, that that data is

00:21:54.452 --> 00:21:58.942
physically stored on the drives,
it doesn't remove the information, right?

462
00:21:58.942 --> 00:21:59.670
This is why, and

00:21:59.670 --> 00:22:02.894
I know you've been in many of the forensic
shows that we have around here,

464
00:22:02.894 --> 00:22:06.014
this is why they can do forensics on

00:22:06.014 --> 00:22:10.050
whether it's a criminal investigation,

466
00:22:10.050 --> 00:22:11.530
So what happens, all right?

467
00:22:11.530 --> 00:22:15.690
Well, when you delete a file from
your hard drive, you're essentially

00:22:15.690 --> 00:22:18.870
turning the blind eye in the operating
system to where it is, right?

469
00:22:18.870 --> 00:22:20.500
You have a master file table.

00:22:20.500 --> 00:22:24.040
That's a logical thing,
where it's the software itself

471
00:22:24.040 --> 00:22:27.650
that applies a logical blueprint over

472
00:22:27.650 --> 00:22:31.060
Well, what you're doing is you're taking
an erases in the operating system, for

473
00:22:31.060 --> 00:22:34.520
lack of a better term, and
you're deleting the pointer to that file.

474
00:22:34.520 --> 00:22:38.250
At the physical level, you did nothing
to that data, that data is still there.

475
00:22:38.250 --> 00:22:42.210
Well here's the problem, over the course
of time, what you're doing when you're

00:22:42.210 --> 00:22:47.045
deleting files, you're moving files,
you're leaving these spaces that that,

00:22:47.045 --> 00:22:51.625
essentially, might still have data in

478
00:22:51.625 --> 00:22:56.775
Keep in mind that our goal is to

00:22:56.775 --> 00:23:00.195
And I quite literally mean,
think of a walkway.

00:23:00.195 --> 00:23:04.134
If I have a walkway, let's say going out

00:23:04.134 --> 00:23:08.010
right, and I've got nice even walkway
with blocks one after the other,

482
00:23:08.010 --> 00:23:10.800
I could stride right on out of there,
no problem, right?

483
00:23:10.800 --> 00:23:13.220
But if I start taking
a couple of blocks here and

484
00:23:13.220 --> 00:23:16.600
there, out of the walkway,
now I got to work harder, I might have to,

485
00:23:16.600 --> 00:23:19.980
at certain point, hop over one of
the steps to get to the next one.

486
00:23:19.980 --> 00:23:22.710
Understand that your drive controller
in your operating system have to do

487
00:23:22.710 --> 00:23:23.660
the same thing.

488
00:23:23.660 --> 00:23:26.760
When you start deleting files,
and you rewrite or

489
00:23:26.760 --> 00:23:30.020
add to the same file,
that maybe you're adding to a file and

00:23:30.020 --> 00:23:34.780
making it bigger, it doesn't line

00:23:34.780 --> 00:23:37.690
It puts it at the end of the walkway,

00:23:37.690 --> 00:23:40.160
And that's really not convenient

493
00:23:40.160 --> 00:23:42.480
that's not going to help me get

494
00:23:42.480 --> 00:23:43.670
So what happens, right?

495
00:23:43.670 --> 00:23:46.708
That's file fragmentation,
so when we do a defrag,

496
00:23:46.708 --> 00:23:50.151
what we're doing is we're really
realigning the bricks and

497
00:23:50.151 --> 00:23:54.217
the walkway to be nice and contiguous so

498
00:23:54.217 --> 00:23:59.682
So slow performance could be because,

00:23:59.682 --> 00:24:04.502
because of the fact that you
might have File fragmentation.

have it go from green to red.

00:24:43.240 --> 00:24:45.120
This is something that you also have.

514
00:24:45.120 --> 00:24:48.205
You have the ability to see if you've got
a graphical user interface inside of your

515
00:24:48.205 --> 00:24:52.110
Linux-based systems and your Mac-based
systems, you can see these as well too.

516
00:24:52.110 --> 00:24:54.040
Just happen to be in
a Windows-based machine, so

517
00:24:54.040 --> 00:24:55.680
you can see that it's right here.

518
00:24:55.680 --> 00:24:59.409
All right, typically, when you right-click
on the drive here, on Windows,

519
00:24:59.409 --> 00:25:02.205
you'll see that we have a series
of right-click options.

520
00:25:02.205 --> 00:25:06.124
And the one that I'm really looking for
is this Properties option, right here.

521
00:25:06.124 --> 00:25:10.240
And if I select Properties, you'll notice
that I can get a lot more information

522
00:25:10.240 --> 00:25:14.100
about the used space and the free space,
and that's, really, what we need.

523
00:25:14.100 --> 00:25:17.890
Now notice that I have this little
button here that says Disk Cleanup.

524
00:25:17.890 --> 00:25:21.090
Now Disk Cleanup isn't a defragmenter,

525
00:25:21.090 --> 00:25:22.600
all right,
we're gonna get to that here in a second.

526
00:25:22.600 --> 00:25:26.250
But one of the things that I can
do is always do a Disk Cleanup.

527
00:25:26.250 --> 00:25:28.570
And as it calculates
the information right here,

528
00:25:28.570 --> 00:25:31.860
what it's gonna do is it's gonna say,
hey, you got some temporary files.

529
00:25:31.860 --> 00:25:34.870
We've seen some log files here,
maybe some internet files.

530
00:25:34.870 --> 00:25:38.360
And there's a way that if you run this in
an administrative mode, it also says, hey,

531
00:25:38.360 --> 00:25:40.370
we've got some system log files and

532
00:25:40.370 --> 00:25:43.970
some system temporary files
that we can clean up, right?

533
00:25:43.970 --> 00:25:48.230
We can run this utility, once it gets done
scanning we can select exactly what it

534
00:25:48.230 --> 00:25:50.450
is that we wanna remove from the drive.

535
00:25:50.450 --> 00:25:51.930
Let's see if it gave me any information.

536
00:25:51.930 --> 00:25:52.850
There we go, Dan.

537
00:25:52.850 --> 00:25:54.460
Looks like it didn't take too long there.

538
00:25:54.460 --> 00:25:57.500
And you can see these are some of
the files that you just really

539
00:25:57.500 --> 00:25:59.040
might not need, right?

540
00:25:59.040 --> 00:26:00.830
And I could sit here and
I could come through here and

541
00:26:00.830 --> 00:26:03.980
I could select each one of these,
if I wanted, in turn.

542
00:26:03.980 --> 00:26:07.240
And I could say, you know what,
go ahead and clean these up.

543
00:26:07.240 --> 00:26:09.014
Now to save a little bit of time here,

544
00:26:09.014 --> 00:26:11.770
what I'm not going to do is
run the administrative one.

545
00:26:11.770 --> 00:26:14.450
Understand that the administrative
one puts a few more entries in there.

546
00:26:14.450 --> 00:26:18.000
It puts things like your system
logs that maybe you wanna delete.

547
00:26:18.000 --> 00:26:19.500
You do have to be an Administrator.

548
00:26:19.500 --> 00:26:23.962
A standard user can perform this
without having to have Administrator

549
00:26:23.962 --> 00:26:25.910
permissions or privileges.

550
00:26:25.910 --> 00:26:27.600
And then I can turn around and
I can say Okay.

551
00:26:27.600 --> 00:26:30.924
And then it asks me one more time,
do I wanna delete those files,

552
00:26:30.924 --> 00:26:35.520
and if I want to I can let it go through
the process of deleting those files.

553
00:26:35.520 --> 00:26:39.008
Now, while that's running in the
background, shouldn't take too long there.

554
00:26:39.008 --> 00:26:41.177
Actually it's kinda moving
along quick there and

555
00:26:41.177 --> 00:26:43.100
I don't think it showed
me any any results.

556
00:26:43.100 --> 00:26:47.322
I could probably go in Event Viewer and
see some of the results of what happened.

557
00:26:47.322 --> 00:26:49.360
Notice here you also have Tools here.

558
00:26:49.360 --> 00:26:52.935
Tools is important too and
notice this is what's known as Check Disk.

559
00:26:52.935 --> 00:26:57.280
C-H-K-D-S-K if you are in Command Prompt.

560
00:26:57.280 --> 00:26:58.110
Let me go ahead and

561
00:26:58.110 --> 00:27:02.830
show you that you also have a graphical
user interface version of this.

562
00:27:02.830 --> 00:27:08.250
You also have the CLI, the Command Prompt
if you will, inside of Windows.

563
00:27:08.250 --> 00:27:11.343
And if you ever wanna find out
what are the options there,

564
00:27:11.343 --> 00:27:14.643
you can do a C-H-K-D-S-K
forward slash question mark.

565
00:27:14.643 --> 00:27:17.980
And you can see we have a whole lot
of different options that we can run.

566
00:27:17.980 --> 00:27:21.391
You get a lot more flexibility here in
the command line and as you guys go on,

567
00:27:21.391 --> 00:27:24.170
especially you guys that maybe
go out of Windows into Linux.

568
00:27:24.170 --> 00:27:26.920
You'll understand there's a lot
more power down in the terminal or

569
00:27:26.920 --> 00:27:30.238
command line than there typically
is in a graphical user interface.

570
00:27:30.238 --> 00:27:33.715
And that's because if they don't code in
the graphical user interface a little

571
00:27:33.715 --> 00:27:35.920
clickety button,
you don't get the functionality.

572
00:27:35.920 --> 00:27:39.820
But it is good that you can do this right
here and I'll go ahead and run this, and

573
00:27:39.820 --> 00:27:42.450
it's gonna prompt me with
the user account control.

574
00:27:42.450 --> 00:27:42.970
Remember guys,

575
00:27:42.970 --> 00:27:47.360
we're gonna get in our operating system
a lot more inside of the 902 series.

576
00:27:47.360 --> 00:27:51.827
Keep in mind that what we wanna do here
is just kinda show you what's going on,

577
00:27:51.827 --> 00:27:52.530
all right?

578
00:27:52.530 --> 00:27:53.182
Notice it says,

579
00:27:53.182 --> 00:27:55.890
it tells us right away this is
actively happening in the background.

580
00:27:55.890 --> 00:27:58.930
It says we haven't found any errors,
but you can scan it if you wanted to.

581
00:27:58.930 --> 00:28:00.760
I'm gonna go ahead and cancel this.

582
00:28:00.760 --> 00:28:03.802
And then one of the the last things
Dan mentioned about defragmentation,

583
00:28:03.802 --> 00:28:06.959
I know it's a long scenic approach to
get back to your question there, bud.

584
00:28:06.959 --> 00:28:09.141
>> [LAUGH]
>> But this is the one, optimize and

585
00:28:09.141 --> 00:28:13.750
defragment a drive And you can see, it's
called the Drive Optimizer today, guys.

586
00:28:13.750 --> 00:28:17.010
For the longest time,
it's been Disk Defragmenter.

587
00:28:17.010 --> 00:28:18.707
It's the same thing, guys.

588
00:28:18.707 --> 00:28:24.100
And because these are solid state drives,
never run optimization is not available.

589
00:28:24.100 --> 00:28:26.420
They don't want you to run
the solid state drives.

590
00:28:26.420 --> 00:28:29.700
But if this was a mechanical drive,
I could do analyze and

591
00:28:29.700 --> 00:28:32.300
find out if it recommends a defragmenter.

592
00:28:32.300 --> 00:28:35.760
That takes almost just as long as the
defragmentation, so I just go ahead and

593
00:28:35.760 --> 00:28:39.910
I say defragment it anyways, it's kind
of just that preventative maintenance.

594
00:28:39.910 --> 00:28:42.610
So, you do have the ability to do that.

595
00:28:42.610 --> 00:28:46.180
One of the last things that I might
mention is, you also have, and I'm not

596
00:28:46.180 --> 00:28:51.840
sure if they're gonna ask you this on the
exam, but you do have the ability to do.

597
00:28:51.840 --> 00:28:54.610
It's kind of easy inside
of the Command Prompt.

598
00:28:54.610 --> 00:28:57.640
Let's see, it's easy if Wes can spell.

599
00:28:57.640 --> 00:29:01.670
Defrag and it's .exe but
the exe is implied.

600
00:29:01.670 --> 00:29:04.270
You don't actually have to put exe.

601
00:29:04.270 --> 00:29:08.110
But you can see that it performs,
again, analysis on the volumes as well.

602
00:29:08.110 --> 00:29:11.683
So a few of the different things you can
see when you come across the fact that

603
00:29:11.683 --> 00:29:14.730
maybe you have slow performance
inside of your machines.

604
00:29:14.730 --> 00:29:17.019
You can run these utilities,
know some of the symptoms,

605
00:29:17.019 --> 00:29:20.400
know some of the things to check, know
some of the software that you can have.

606
00:29:20.400 --> 00:29:23.840
And at the end of the day, Dan, you might
just have to replace the drive, right?

607
00:29:23.840 --> 00:29:27.304
It might be dead duck in the water and
rather than sit there and watch it float,

608
00:29:27.304 --> 00:29:29.040
just go ahead, throw it away.

609
00:29:29.040 --> 00:29:31.649
If you can't get your
information off of it,

610
00:29:31.649 --> 00:29:36.054
go out to one of your favorite hardware
stores and I mean computer hardware.

611
00:29:36.054 --> 00:29:36.796
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

612
00:29:36.796 --> 00:29:37.444
>> Hammer might help too.

613
00:29:37.444 --> 00:29:44.220
[LAUGH] [CROSSTALK] So just a couple
of the things you need to keep in mind.

614
00:29:44.220 --> 00:29:47.842
But certainly isn't
the end of the list here.

615
00:29:47.842 --> 00:29:51.380
But Dan's showing me that we might
have to put a comma in this episode.

616
00:29:51.380 --> 00:29:55.540
>> That's right, and we're gonna have to
take a little siesta, and come back and

617
00:29:55.540 --> 00:29:57.950
do another episode,
because we are out of time for this one.

618
00:29:57.950 --> 00:30:00.450
But, we did get to cover
some of the most common and

619
00:30:00.450 --> 00:30:02.300
major malfunctions that could occur.

620
00:30:02.300 --> 00:30:05.800
And even got into some of the tools that
can help us to try to check these things,

621
00:30:05.800 --> 00:30:07.840
and see if something
is actually a problem,

622
00:30:07.840 --> 00:30:09.980
maybe even fix the thing, who knows.

623
00:30:09.980 --> 00:30:12.790
That being said, it looks like we are,
like I said, out of time for this episode.

624
00:30:12.790 --> 00:30:16.357
Definitely come back for part two,
as for this one goes, signing off for

625
00:30:16.357 --> 00:30:18.597
ITProTV I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

626
00:30:18.597 --> 00:30:19.558
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

627
00:30:19.558 --> 00:30:21.107
>> We'll see you next time.

628
00:30:21.107 --> 00:30:27.808
[MUSIC]

629
00:30:27.808 --> 00:30:29.840
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look at troubleshooting hard drives and RAID arrays with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here includes: Fail to boot, OS not found, FixMBR, FixBoot, BootRec utility, bcdedit, Drive not recognized, and SMART errors.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Hard Drives and RAID Arrays Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:02.568
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host Don.

2
00:00:02.568 --> 00:00:06.056
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.056 --> 00:00:08.063
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.063 --> 00:00:11.939
>> You're watching ITPROV.

5
00:00:11.939 --> 00:00:13.812
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:13.812 --> 00:00:16.338
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:16.338 --> 00:00:18.008
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and

8
00:00:18.008 --> 00:00:21.983
in today's episode it's more in our A+
series, we're actually continuing our

9
00:00:21.983 --> 00:00:25.280
conversation on common problems
with hard drives and RAID arrays.

10
00:00:25.280 --> 00:00:28.310
And joining us back in the studio
to continue that very conversation,

11
00:00:28.310 --> 00:00:30.140
our good friend, Mr Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:30.140 --> 00:00:31.840
Wes, how's it going today, man?

13
00:00:31.840 --> 00:00:34.090
>> Man, it is going great,
good to be here.

14
00:00:34.090 --> 00:00:37.880
I am just so psyched that we
survived the first episode.

15
00:00:37.880 --> 00:00:38.860
>> We did.
>> Because we were

16
00:00:38.860 --> 00:00:40.750
playing with electricity, right?, [LAUGH].

17
00:00:40.750 --> 00:00:42.160
So, great to be here.

18
00:00:42.160 --> 00:00:45.010
That's right, we're gonna move
along in our troubleshooting hard

19
00:00:45.010 --> 00:00:48.930
drives as well as communicating a little
bit more on things like RAID arrays.

20
00:00:48.930 --> 00:00:53.210
I know it's in the title, guys, I swear it
is coming up, but as we go through this

21
00:00:53.210 --> 00:00:57.260
list we also have to check out some of
the individual hard drives as well.

22
00:00:57.260 --> 00:01:00.500
Moving on in the list that we have here,
we're going to talk about failure to boot,

23
00:01:00.500 --> 00:01:04.550
and I'm going to go ahead and do a couple
of these in the same demonstration,

24
00:01:04.550 --> 00:01:07.490
because they can manifest
themselves in a lot of ways.

25
00:01:07.490 --> 00:01:09.040
Failure to boot, right?

26
00:01:09.040 --> 00:01:12.065
Failure to boot quite literally could be
some of the things that we talked about,

27
00:01:12.065 --> 00:01:12.990
read/write failures.

28
00:01:12.990 --> 00:01:17.180
One of the things you have to do is
the operating system is located on that

29
00:01:17.180 --> 00:01:18.040
hard drive.

30
00:01:18.040 --> 00:01:19.880
And it's gonna be pulled
off of the hard drive.

31
00:01:19.880 --> 00:01:23.590
It's gonna be thrown into the volatile
memory source that is RAM.

32
00:01:23.590 --> 00:01:27.040
And then,
from there it bootstraps the hardware,

33
00:01:27.040 --> 00:01:30.550
starts to take over the control of
the hardware, right?, and then, we get

34
00:01:30.550 --> 00:01:34.000
to hopefully the ability to log into
the machine and start using the computer.

35
00:01:34.000 --> 00:01:37.610
All right, well,
read/write failures happen, right?

36
00:01:37.610 --> 00:01:38.460
Well, that's gonna happen.

37
00:01:38.460 --> 00:01:41.380
If you hear that click of death right
that loud clicking noise, well,

38
00:01:41.380 --> 00:01:44.780
that's also gonna cause a failure
to boot the operating system.

39
00:01:44.780 --> 00:01:48.480
And in that case you might have to use
some kind of file recovery software

40
00:01:48.480 --> 00:01:49.890
if you can.

41
00:01:49.890 --> 00:01:51.190
Sometimes you can't even do that.

42
00:01:51.190 --> 00:01:53.960
Sometimes you can use
an external enclosure.

43
00:01:53.960 --> 00:01:57.550
You might hear the term, Drive Sled,
and again, this just little box,

44
00:01:57.550 --> 00:02:01.400
if you will, that you can pull
the drive out of the machine.

45
00:02:01.400 --> 00:02:06.350
And basically, plug it into this external
enclosure and then typically through USB,

46
00:02:06.350 --> 00:02:10.150
you just plug it right back into the
computer, another computer I should say.

47
00:02:10.150 --> 00:02:12.601
And then,
hopefully you can gain access to that.

48
00:02:12.601 --> 00:02:14.820
You can actually couple the two as well.

49
00:02:14.820 --> 00:02:17.700
You can do file recovery software
with an external enclosure.

50
00:02:17.700 --> 00:02:22.500
Because sometimes, you know,
you're gonna need a little bit more power,

51
00:02:22.500 --> 00:02:26.050
if you will, and it's just not as
simple as just taking the drive out,

52
00:02:26.050 --> 00:02:28.270
and plugging it into another one.

53
00:02:28.270 --> 00:02:30.980
All right, so
that is some of the things that we do.

54
00:02:30.980 --> 00:02:33.200
Failure to boot might be
an all out mechanical failure.

55
00:02:33.200 --> 00:02:35.730
If it's a mechanical failure, you're gonna
have to use some of the other techniques

56
00:02:35.730 --> 00:02:39.310
that we've already discussed in the first
part of this episode, or this series,

57
00:02:39.310 --> 00:02:41.660
if you will,
[LAUGH] that we're working on.

58
00:02:41.660 --> 00:02:44.740
Now, there's other things that could
cause a failure to boot, right?

59
00:02:44.740 --> 00:02:47.410
As we move into our
operating system portions,

60
00:02:47.410 --> 00:02:51.980
really in the 902 exam,
we'll talk a lot more about the OS.

61
00:02:51.980 --> 00:02:54.940
But there are some things, very basically
when it comes to storage devices,

62
00:02:54.940 --> 00:02:59.040
that you have to know about the software,
the operating system, more specifically.

63
00:02:59.040 --> 00:03:02.080
When it goes to bootstrap the hardware.

64
00:03:02.080 --> 00:03:03.960
So, what are we talking about?

65
00:03:03.960 --> 00:03:08.870
Well, inside of your operating system, we
have what's known as a master boot record.

66
00:03:08.870 --> 00:03:13.650
If you're talking about traditional bios
it uses an MBR a master boot record.

67
00:03:13.650 --> 00:03:16.540
If you're talking about the unified
extensible firmware interface right

68
00:03:16.540 --> 00:03:19.370
the later successor to bios,
Both are still used today.

69
00:03:19.370 --> 00:03:20.590
One's considered legacy.

70
00:03:20.590 --> 00:03:22.760
One's considered more modern.

71
00:03:22.760 --> 00:03:26.720
The UEFI uses something that's akin
to a master boot wrecker, right?

72
00:03:26.720 --> 00:03:28.580
It helps to bootstrap
the operating system.

73
00:03:28.580 --> 00:03:31.560
That's called GPT, or
the GUI partition table.

74
00:03:31.560 --> 00:03:37.020
Now, keep in mind that if we
can't access that information,

75
00:03:37.020 --> 00:03:39.530
then we can't start the computer, right?

76
00:03:39.530 --> 00:03:42.430
And that could cause a failure to boot.

77
00:03:42.430 --> 00:03:47.330
Know that you could really find that
out very early on in the start up

78
00:03:47.330 --> 00:03:51.210
process when you reach over and you push
power on the computer, and here's why.

79
00:03:51.210 --> 00:03:54.110
We talked about the basic input
output system pretty extensively in

80
00:03:54.110 --> 00:03:54.870
another episode.

81
00:03:54.870 --> 00:03:57.987
We talked about how it to sends
a little electrical signals out, and

82
00:03:57.987 --> 00:04:00.298
it really starts your hardware,
stabilizes it.

83
00:04:00.298 --> 00:04:03.941
And then, one of the last things that
BIOS does is looks for that boot record,

84
00:04:03.941 --> 00:04:07.250
that boot code that helps
the operating system come online.

85
00:04:07.250 --> 00:04:11.185
Well, even before that BIOS has stored in
it what's known as the power on self test,

86
00:04:11.185 --> 00:04:12.325
right, it's called post.

87
00:04:12.325 --> 00:04:17.125
Every machine that has a logic board in
it, a lot of times is gonna run post.

88
00:04:17.125 --> 00:04:20.535
Believe it, or not, your cars out there
today, with all the computing systems that

89
00:04:20.535 --> 00:04:25.375
they have in them, run through a potential
of hundreds of power-on self tests

90
00:04:25.375 --> 00:04:28.375
quite literally when you turn
the key in the ignition, all right?

91
00:04:28.375 --> 00:04:29.845
And what is power-on self test?

92
00:04:29.845 --> 00:04:32.540
Again, post this is the BIOS saying,

93
00:04:32.540 --> 00:04:35.150
okay, I'm gonna send
an electrical signal to the CPU.

94
00:04:35.150 --> 00:04:39.540
I'm gonna send an electrical signal to the
RAM, to the Video Sub-system if you will,

95
00:04:39.540 --> 00:04:40.870
and as well the hard drive.

96
00:04:40.870 --> 00:04:43.410
I'm gonna see if I can start
the hard drive up, right?

97
00:04:43.410 --> 00:04:46.080
And if it receives a signal back
that says, hey, we're here,

98
00:04:46.080 --> 00:04:49.010
it's kinda like a built
in self-diagnostic.

99
00:04:49.010 --> 00:04:52.870
Now, one of the last portions that
happens in that post process, and

100
00:04:52.870 --> 00:04:56.950
it's the BIOS as well, is that it looks
and tries to read that boot code.

101
00:04:56.950 --> 00:05:00.670
That boot code is loaded in the memory,
and it's what allows bi ops to

102
00:05:00.670 --> 00:05:04.390
transfer control of the hardware over
to the operating system, and ladies and

103
00:05:04.390 --> 00:05:06.580
gentlemen, out there I don't care if
you're running a windows machine.

104
00:05:06.580 --> 00:05:10.630
I don't care if you're a Newnex machine,
a Linux machine, a Mac.

105
00:05:10.630 --> 00:05:15.300
Everyone of those systems is going
to go through a power on sub test.

106
00:05:15.300 --> 00:05:18.290
Now, if it can't find that
boot record what happens?

107
00:05:18.290 --> 00:05:21.430
Fails to bootstrap the operating system,
the operating system doesn't allow you to

108
00:05:21.430 --> 00:05:25.030
log in, and a lot of times you will have
what is known as a POST error that will

109
00:05:25.030 --> 00:05:29.670
happen in a low resolution on the screen,
and it might say, failure to boot.

110
00:05:29.670 --> 00:05:32.599
The other thing that might happen
is it might say, OS not found.

111
00:05:32.599 --> 00:05:36.480
Now, there's a couple of things
that the OS not found might happen.

112
00:05:36.480 --> 00:05:37.520
Let me tell you why.

113
00:05:37.520 --> 00:05:40.880
Because inside of your BIOS you have
what's known as a boot sequence.

114
00:05:40.880 --> 00:05:44.270
And the boot sequence says, where does
the BIOS look for that boot code.

115
00:05:44.270 --> 00:05:47.190
And there's a few different locations
that it can actually find that boot code.

116
00:05:47.190 --> 00:05:49.940
One of the locations it can
find it is the hard drive.

117
00:05:49.940 --> 00:05:55.040
Now, I want you to understand in the boot
sequence, a lot of times not all the time,

118
00:05:55.040 --> 00:05:58.650
you have to pay attention to your BIOS and
how it's configure, or UAI file.

119
00:05:58.650 --> 00:06:01.620
Use them interchangeably, cuz essentially
their firmware starting hardware.

120
00:06:02.860 --> 00:06:06.180
What happens is,
the hard drive is set last.

121
00:06:06.180 --> 00:06:08.310
All right, and
there's a good reason for that, right?

122
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:11.180
If I need to run some kind
of recovery software,

123
00:06:11.180 --> 00:06:15.290
file recovery software, let's say, we
work for the United States government, or

124
00:06:15.290 --> 00:06:18.860
maybe your over there in Europe, right?,
and you have some data standards that you

125
00:06:18.860 --> 00:06:23.910
need to follow, and we need to make
sure that we securely erase information.

126
00:06:23.910 --> 00:06:27.290
Well, if we're always booting to
the hard drive we don't get a chance to

127
00:06:27.290 --> 00:06:30.890
run that software prior to
the operation system coming online.

128
00:06:30.890 --> 00:06:31.960
So, what do we do?

129
00:06:31.960 --> 00:06:35.460
We look for the boot code, typically in
places like the optical drive, right?

130
00:06:35.460 --> 00:06:37.300
Allows me to install my operating system.

131
00:06:37.300 --> 00:06:40.480
Could be a USB drive
that we made bootable,

132
00:06:40.480 --> 00:06:43.440
and we've actually got some boot code in
there, and there's an operating system,

133
00:06:43.440 --> 00:06:45.530
or at least an operating system installer.

134
00:06:45.530 --> 00:06:48.370
We plug it into the computer in
the USB port and we tell it, hey,

135
00:06:48.370 --> 00:06:51.730
BIOS go on ahead and look there, so
those are a couple of locations.

136
00:06:51.730 --> 00:06:53.880
The other real cool location
is a network adaptor.

137
00:06:53.880 --> 00:06:57.640
Believe it, or not your network adaptor
has a small bit of firmware in it that can

138
00:06:57.640 --> 00:07:04.720
load a very slimline highly optimized
portion of the TCIP protocol stack.

139
00:07:04.720 --> 00:07:06.050
And it can call up to the network and say,

140
00:07:06.050 --> 00:07:08.360
hey, you got an operating
system out there?

141
00:07:08.360 --> 00:07:10.130
I could really use one.

142
00:07:10.130 --> 00:07:14.120
Standard clients do this when we're trying
to deploy operating systems to multiple

143
00:07:14.120 --> 00:07:16.960
machines rather than going computer,
to computer,

144
00:07:16.960 --> 00:07:20.680
to computer installing optical disks,
right, or USB drives.

145
00:07:20.680 --> 00:07:22.910
The other thing that happens is
thin clients do this as well.

146
00:07:22.910 --> 00:07:25.570
Right, we talked about in another
episode the custom PC types.

147
00:07:25.570 --> 00:07:28.030
Thin clients a lot of times don't
even have their operating system

148
00:07:28.030 --> 00:07:29.540
installed locally.

149
00:07:29.540 --> 00:07:31.573
What they do is they call out
to the network and they say,

150
00:07:31.573 --> 00:07:34.345
hey, anybody out there got an operating
system, because you know what?,

151
00:07:34.345 --> 00:07:36.064
I'm not going to run if
you don't give me one.

152
00:07:36.064 --> 00:07:40.667
And a lot of times there's a server out
there that uploads, or over the network

153
00:07:40.667 --> 00:07:45.230
downloads a small highly optimized
operating system that's stored in RAM.

154
00:07:45.230 --> 00:07:48.073
So, those are the locations we
can find in the boot sequence.

155
00:07:48.073 --> 00:07:53.194
And then, if the master boot record,
or the unified GPT as it's called.

156
00:07:53.194 --> 00:07:57.571
The GUID Partition Table is what
UEFI uses, if it doesn't find that,

157
00:07:57.571 --> 00:07:58.917
it halts the system.

158
00:07:58.917 --> 00:08:02.490
We get an operating system not found and
failure to boot as well okay?

Well if it's corruption that's also gonna

00:08:12.670 --> 00:08:14.430

00:27:42.260 --> 00:27:43.900
a SMART Error provides.

546
00:27:43.900 --> 00:27:47.080
Sometimes its so difficult to
understand even what's going on,

547
00:27:47.080 --> 00:27:49.072
that you can't even
interpret the information.

548
00:27:49.072 --> 00:27:52.570
Sometimes you have a software,
right, that you can see and

549
00:27:52.570 --> 00:27:56.470
it can interpret that information.It can
load the SMART area into the software,

550
00:27:56.470 --> 00:27:59.160
gives you a nice little
graphical user interface,

551
00:27:59.160 --> 00:28:03.140
that you can kind of diagnose
what the problem might be.

552
00:28:03.140 --> 00:28:03.845
Keep in mind,

553
00:28:03.845 --> 00:28:08.210
that if your drives are under warranty,
you might be able to return them.

554
00:28:08.210 --> 00:28:08.970
All right?

555
00:28:08.970 --> 00:28:14.510
The main thing to keep in mind though
is that if you have the chance,

556
00:28:14.510 --> 00:28:17.240
all right, and
you really don't have an excuse,

557
00:28:17.240 --> 00:28:20.984
if you are under normal operations
you should be running back ups.

558
00:28:20.984 --> 00:28:21.630
Right?

559
00:28:21.630 --> 00:28:25.720
Because these problems
will manifest themselves.

560
00:28:25.720 --> 00:28:29.820
Understand it's not a matter of if,
a component's gonna fail,

561
00:28:29.820 --> 00:28:30.575
it's a matter of when.

562
00:28:30.575 --> 00:28:31.080
Right?

563
00:28:31.080 --> 00:28:33.260
There's a certain lifetime,
they call it a,

564
00:28:33.260 --> 00:28:36.660
what is it, a meantime between failure,
I believe it is, MTTF.

565
00:28:36.660 --> 00:28:40.931
And it just says, how many
operations are we gonna get, right,

566
00:28:40.931 --> 00:28:43.500
read-write operations,
are we gonna get within this drive or

567
00:28:43.500 --> 00:28:45.960
this storage device
before it finally fails?

568
00:28:45.960 --> 00:28:49.990
So again, keep in mind, it's not
a matter of if it's going to fail,

569
00:28:49.990 --> 00:28:51.390
it's a matter of when it's gonna fail.

570
00:28:51.390 --> 00:28:56.260
Your drives, believe it or not, are
failing on a daily basis, but they have

571
00:28:56.260 --> 00:29:00.650
software, they have logic built into them,
that allows the drive controller to kind

572
00:29:00.650 --> 00:29:05.750
of do on the fly diagnostics and
repair itself or move, if you will,

573
00:29:05.750 --> 00:29:10.015
information around failed sectors within
the drive and you're not even aware of it.

574
00:29:10.015 --> 00:29:10.660
Right?

575
00:29:10.660 --> 00:29:13.670
When we use some of these utilities
we have, we're forcing it to do it,

576
00:29:13.670 --> 00:29:16.080
we're telling it, do that now.

577
00:29:16.080 --> 00:29:17.250
Right?
But believe it or not,

578
00:29:17.250 --> 00:29:19.910
it's doing it on a daily basis,
cuz again, it's a magnetic,

579
00:29:19.910 --> 00:29:25.820
mechanical device that is constantly
failing overall in its overall life cycle.

580
00:29:25.820 --> 00:29:29.670
The problem is, some of the failures is so
great, that we do need these third party

581
00:29:29.670 --> 00:29:34.300
software or software that's built in
the operating system, in order to fix or

582
00:29:34.300 --> 00:29:36.460
diagnose these problems or both.

583
00:29:36.460 --> 00:29:39.140
All right?
Backups, run your backups,

584
00:29:39.140 --> 00:29:40.380
that is important.

585
00:29:40.380 --> 00:29:43.800
Now, we do have a few more things
that we kind of wanna round off,

586
00:29:43.800 --> 00:29:45.300
we still wanna look at RAID.

587
00:29:45.300 --> 00:29:48.690
We've been talking this whole entire
time and in the title is RAID arrays and

588
00:29:48.690 --> 00:29:50.160
we haven´t talked about those yet.

589
00:29:50.160 --> 00:29:53.990
But, Dan's over here telling me that
we might have to save that one for

590

a third part.

591

>> Yeah, I don´t think we have quite

592

but that's not a problem,
we'll make a part three.

593

So definitely join us for

594

to, we are out of time for this episode.

595
00:30:06.340 --> 00:30:09.610
So, signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

00:30:09.610 --> 00:30:10.400
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look at troubleshooting hard drives and RAID arrays with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here includes: RAID not found, RAID stops working, screwdrivers,

38

41

42

Tries to give you the best of

that striped thing with
distributed parity.

45
00:01:56.610 --> 00:02:00.745
So that if one of the drives fails your
still operational unlike mirror if one of

46
00:02:00.745 --> 00:02:04.330
the drives fails well you're out of the,
your out of luck, right?

47
00:02:04.330 --> 00:02:06.890
But you still have access to your data.

48

Now, that being said,
we will talk about full tolerance, right?

49
00:02:10.560 --> 00:02:12.010
Or, we will talk about failure.

That's loaded into the RAM, to even

I had to have a-
>> Seems like a problem, [LAUGH]

And that's why I had to have a little USB

I could say hey, Windows, that's okay,

that what you're seeing are drive sleds.

387
00:19:21.140 --> 00:19:23.576
Right, you have these rails
that attach to the drive, and

388
00:19:23.576 --> 00:19:25.525
you basically they're tool-less, right?

389
00:19:25.525 --> 00:19:29.480
You could slide the drives in the bay and
they lock in place.

390
00:19:29.480 --> 00:19:32.240
And if you need to take the drives
out you just pinch them and

391
00:19:32.240 --> 00:19:34.600
pull the drive right out of its bay.

392
00:19:34.600 --> 00:19:38.040
That is more common today, it makes
it tool-less it makes it very easy.

393
00:19:38.040 --> 00:19:39.960
About the only thing you
really need a tool for

394
00:19:39.960 --> 00:19:41.860
anymore Dan is removing the motherboards,
right?

395
00:19:41.860 --> 00:19:45.489
Because they have to be bolted down cuz
you don't want vibration and certainly you

396
00:19:45.489 --> 00:19:50.030
don't want them making a contact, if you
will, to any electrical component because

397
00:19:50.030 --> 00:19:53.390
of the traces on them could basically
electrically arc out the system.

398
00:19:53.390 --> 00:19:59.050
So, I know guys and gals, this is has
been a long journey here, but hopefully

399
00:19:59.050 --> 00:20:03.300
we've given you some of the ideas and
really the hands-on on some of the things

400
00:20:03.300 --> 00:20:07.340
you can see inside of troubleshooting your
hard drives as well as your RAID arrays.

401
00:20:07.340 --> 00:20:08.100
>> All right, Wes.

402
00:20:08.100 --> 00:20:11.250
Thanks for walking us down that road,
and holding our little hands so

403
00:20:11.250 --> 00:20:13.860
that we don't feel like lost
little lambs in the woods.

404
00:20:13.860 --> 00:20:16.260
But, like you said,
we are at the end of that episode.

405
00:20:16.260 --> 00:20:17.320
Thanks for watching everyone.

406
00:20:17.320 --> 00:20:18.530
Signing off, for ITProTV.

407
00:20:18.530 --> 00:20:19.830
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

408
00:20:19.830 --> 00:20:20.530
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

409
00:20:20.530 --> 00:20:21.261
>> And we'll see you next time.

410
00:20:21.261 --> 00:20:28.762
[MUSIC]

411
00:20:28.762 --> 00:20:31.659
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes troubleshoot common video, projector, and display issues. Specific topics covered here includes: VGA mode, no image, overheat shutdown, dead pixels, artifacts, incorrect color patterns, dim images, flickering image, distorted image, burn-in, and oversized images/icons.
episodes.title: Common Video, Projector and Display Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:06.410
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.410 --> 00:00:08.110
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.110 --> 00:00:12.374
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

4
00:00:12.374 --> 00:00:14.181
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

5
00:00:14.181 --> 00:00:17.480
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:17.480 --> 00:00:21.374
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and in
today's episode we are continuing on our

7
00:00:21.374 --> 00:00:24.440
A Plus series,
the good old 901 or 220, 901.

8
00:00:24.440 --> 00:00:26.300
Gotta get the numbers in
the right spot there.

9
00:00:26.300 --> 00:00:29.040
Joining us in the studio yet again,
the Linux expertise on that topic,

10
00:00:29.040 --> 00:00:31.160
our good friend Mr. Wes Bryan.

11
00:00:31.160 --> 00:00:32.568
Wes, welcome back man, how's it going?

12
00:00:32.568 --> 00:00:33.400
>> Man, it's going great.

13
00:00:33.400 --> 00:00:37.225
And Dan, I gotta give you props again and
as always with all these different exam

14
00:00:37.225 --> 00:00:40.264
numbers that you jump in and
host, you´re doing pretty good.

15
00:00:40.264 --> 00:00:41.982
>> Forget the Microsoft stuff
cuz that´s insane [LAUGH].

16
00:00:41.982 --> 00:00:43.021
>> Yeah, [INAUDIBLE] literally.

17
00:00:43.021 --> 00:00:47.106
So that´s right, well, you heard what
Dan said, we´re doing CompTIAs one, two,

18
00:00:47.106 --> 00:00:48.483
three, four, five, six.

19
00:00:48.483 --> 00:00:49.883
>> [LAUGH]
>> Or better known as 220-901.

20
00:00:49.883 --> 00:00:51.330
>> [CROSSTALK] That would be awesome.

21
00:00:51.330 --> 00:00:54.050
>> And we´re going to be looking at
a little bit more troubleshooting here.

22
00:00:54.050 --> 00:00:57.780
We´ve gone through some different
troubleshooting of things like hardware,

23
00:00:57.780 --> 00:00:59.720
things like networks, if you will.

24
00:00:59.720 --> 00:01:03.330
Even talk briefly about troubleshooting
in mobile devices, right?

25
00:01:03.330 --> 00:01:06.790
We're gonna be looking at some
of the video projector and

26
00:01:06.790 --> 00:01:08.160
display issues that you could see.

27
00:01:08.160 --> 00:01:11.263
So this might be a little
bit shorter of an episode.

28
00:01:11.263 --> 00:01:15.024
And what I mean by that are there's
some things that are pretty standard and

29
00:01:15.024 --> 00:01:19.201
common across all these different issues
that they call out right in the objectives

30
00:01:19.201 --> 00:01:19.870
for 901.

31
00:01:19.870 --> 00:01:23.730
But let's go ahead and
without further ado let's dive right in.

32
00:01:23.730 --> 00:01:26.045
So one of the things
that I wanna talk about,

33
00:01:26.045 --> 00:01:30.313
the very first common symptoms that they
mention is something known as VGA mode.

34
00:01:30.313 --> 00:01:34.665
All right now, VGA mode, we're gonna see
it in action a little bit more in 902

35
00:01:34.665 --> 00:01:36.850
when we dive into our operating system.

36
00:01:36.850 --> 00:01:40.630
And I wanna let you know that
it is inside of Windows.

37
00:01:40.630 --> 00:01:43.900
It is called,
I think they call it VGA Mode, but today

38
00:01:43.900 --> 00:01:48.240
they really call it low resolution mode
because when you say VGA some people don't

39
00:01:48.240 --> 00:01:52.260
even know what VGA is anymore in a high
definition society that we are today so.

40
00:01:53.550 --> 00:01:55.260
I agree with Microsoft's renaming on this.

41
00:01:55.260 --> 00:01:59.170
Sometimes Microsoft will rename a product
and they'll release it as a new technology

42
00:01:59.170 --> 00:02:02.420
when it's really the same technology
with a new coat of paint,

43
00:02:02.420 --> 00:02:06.200
however I understand why they've
done that right VGA mode.

44
00:02:06.200 --> 00:02:09.430
Many people probably don't even know
what the Video Graphics Array is.

45
00:02:09.430 --> 00:02:10.550
In fact it's kind of interesting.

46
00:02:10.550 --> 00:02:11.580
I was looking at feed that or

47
00:02:11.580 --> 00:02:14.900
something that come across
my news feed earlier today.

48
00:02:14.900 --> 00:02:19.551
They were talking about the old
Atari 520 ST computer, and

49
00:02:19.551 --> 00:02:25.902
it was an advertisement for it when it
came out in 1990 or 1985 I think it was,

50
00:02:25.902 --> 00:02:30.476
and it said your new monochrome display,
640 by 480.

51
00:02:30.476 --> 00:02:32.530
Extremely sharp resolution.

52
00:02:33.560 --> 00:02:36.220
That is actually the GA mode, right?

53
00:02:36.220 --> 00:02:38.440
That is your videographics array, right?

54
00:02:38.440 --> 00:02:41.290
It is the 640 by 480 resolution.

55
00:02:41.290 --> 00:02:45.360
So, again what you'll see is when you're
trouble shooting inside of the operating

56
00:02:45.360 --> 00:02:47.450
system and
when we get into our operating systems,

57
00:02:47.450 --> 00:02:49.140
we'll definitely show you
a little bit more about this.

58
00:02:49.140 --> 00:02:52.910
You'll see that it has been renamed
low resolution mode, right.

59
00:02:52.910 --> 00:02:55.770
Because understand right away that if
I'm having a problem with my monitor,

60
00:02:55.770 --> 00:02:57.790
I understand what low resolution is but

61
00:02:57.790 --> 00:03:01.370
I might not really understand
what the heck VGA is, okay.

62
00:03:01.370 --> 00:03:05.100
So VGA mode is still what they
call it out on the exam objective.

63
00:03:05.100 --> 00:03:07.780
So let's see if we can clarify
this a little bit, all right.

64
00:03:07.780 --> 00:03:09.590
So what is VGA mode?

65
00:03:09.590 --> 00:03:14.530
What you need to understand, all right
is a little bit more about how Windows,

66
00:03:14.530 --> 00:03:16.590
this is more of a Windows
thing if you will.

67
00:03:16.590 --> 00:03:21.870
How windows when it boots in, and it
starts to take control over the hardware.

68
00:03:21.870 --> 00:03:23.290
What its going to do, all right?

69
00:03:23.290 --> 00:03:27.150
So when we go through post,
we go through BIOS right?

70
00:03:27.150 --> 00:03:29.298
We have our basic input-output system.

71
00:03:29.298 --> 00:03:33.470
And whether you're using the BIOS or
using UEFI right, we look for

72
00:03:33.470 --> 00:03:38.140
some boot code, and the boot code is
what bootstraps the operating system and

73
00:03:38.140 --> 00:03:41.760
then hands over the hardware
to the operating system right?

74
00:03:42.770 --> 00:03:45.750
Every machine does this that
isn't Windows specific.

75
00:03:45.750 --> 00:03:49.180
However, here is where a little
bit more specifics come in to it.

76
00:03:49.180 --> 00:03:54.580
When Windows goes to basically
take over the video card and

77
00:03:54.580 --> 00:03:57.540
I guess this could be a Linux thing
it could be a Mac thing as well.

78
00:03:57.540 --> 00:04:00.938
You have a driver within the operating
system that's gonna load and

79
00:04:00.938 --> 00:04:04.765
its going to allow the operating system
to communicate with the video card.

80
00:04:04.765 --> 00:04:09.230
Now, I should clarify that
that's every operating system.

81
00:04:09.230 --> 00:04:12.506
However, here's something
interesting that Windows does,

82
00:04:12.506 --> 00:04:15.162
if there's a problem with the driver and
the driver

83
00:04:15.162 --> 00:04:19.442
can't allow the communication between
the operating system and the video card.

84
00:04:19.442 --> 00:04:23.158
Then what Windows does is
kind of like it's It's own

85
00:04:23.158 --> 00:04:27.296
way to not really diagnose itself but
to keep you booting so

86
00:04:27.296 --> 00:04:32.785
that you can troubleshoot the problem as
it says let me take a generic driver,

87
00:04:32.785 --> 00:04:38.131
one that all video cards understand and
it's not specific to any adapter.

88
00:04:38.131 --> 00:04:40.113
And I'll allow you boot to that driver,

89
00:04:40.113 --> 00:04:44.230
I'll let that driver allow you to
communicate with the graphics card, right?

90
00:04:44.230 --> 00:04:45.030
So there's a problem,

91
00:04:45.030 --> 00:04:48.260
understand that's why we call this trouble
shooting section, there's a problem.

92
00:04:48.260 --> 00:04:51.200
It means that Windows cannot communicate

93
00:04:51.200 --> 00:04:55.550
via the install driver that's
specific to the manufacturer, right?

94
00:04:55.550 --> 00:04:58.860
Remember, manufacturer drivers allow
you the full functionality of whatever

95
00:04:58.860 --> 00:05:02.150
the hardware device is, and
that again it's not specific to Windows,

96
00:05:02.150 --> 00:05:05.770
doesn't matter if you're in a Nix-based
system, Unix, Linux, Mac right.

97
00:05:06.820 --> 00:05:08.040
You have manufactured drivers.

98
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:11.210
Manufactured drivers allow because the
manufacturer is the one that's creating

99
00:05:11.210 --> 00:05:11.920
those drivers.

100
00:05:11.920 --> 00:05:13.360
Allow you the full functionality.

101
00:05:13.360 --> 00:05:17.680
However, if you install a driver in
Windows and it becomes problematic.

102
00:05:17.680 --> 00:05:19.736
Which if you've been around
any Windows machine.

103
00:05:19.736 --> 00:05:21.510
It's a commonality [LAUGH] right.

104
00:05:21.510 --> 00:05:26.954
How do I diagnosis something if I can't
interact with the operating system?

105
00:05:26.954 --> 00:05:29.940
>> So Wes would you say this
is a very good alternative?

106
00:05:29.940 --> 00:05:32.860
>> I would say its
an alternative in Windows, why?

107
00:05:32.860 --> 00:05:37.592
Because Linux if you can't interact
with a GUI, most people don't care.

108
00:05:37.592 --> 00:05:39.650
In fact I know Dan you're one of these.

109
00:05:39.650 --> 00:05:42.630
That says, hey if I'm in a server,
I don't want a GUI, right?

110
00:05:42.630 --> 00:05:44.690
I don't want all the problems
that those drivers can give.

111
00:05:44.690 --> 00:05:48.070
Just give me the command line,
that's my territory anyways.

112
00:05:48.070 --> 00:05:52.060
Windows, unfortunately, we don't
have a lot of those power users, and

113
00:05:52.060 --> 00:05:54.190
they need a graphical user interface.

114
00:05:54.190 --> 00:05:55.480
I just happen to be one of them, right?

115
00:05:55.480 --> 00:05:59.631
I'm a lot more familiar with a graphical
user interface than I am any kind

116
00:05:59.631 --> 00:06:00.797
of terminal right?

117
00:06:00.797 --> 00:06:01.793
>> Lightweight.

118
00:06:01.793 --> 00:06:02.485
>> What's that?
>> Lightweight.

119
00:06:02.485 --> 00:06:03.709
>> I know right.

120
00:06:03.709 --> 00:06:04.519
>> Come on son.

121
00:06:04.519 --> 00:06:07.820
>> I've got my training wheels on for
sure, right?

122
00:06:07.820 --> 00:06:10.110
Training wheel administration 101.

123
00:06:10.110 --> 00:06:12.850
So, this at least gives you the ability.

124
00:06:12.850 --> 00:06:15.692
If they say, you know what,
we're going to give a generic driver.

125
00:06:15.692 --> 00:06:19.224
Just common generic VGA
driver allows any video card,

126
00:06:19.224 --> 00:06:23.753
provided it's not the video card,
let's be a little more specific,

127
00:06:23.753 --> 00:06:29.049
because if it boots into VGA mode and you
still don't get anything on the monitor,

128
00:06:29.049 --> 00:06:31.551
chances are the video card's fried.

129
00:06:31.551 --> 00:06:36.876
There's something maybe it needs to be
reseated, maybe the GPU's overheated,

130
00:06:36.876 --> 00:06:40.886
the memory's gone, but
the point being is now I can at least,

131
00:06:40.886 --> 00:06:46.100
in a very low resolution environment
uninstall the problematic driver.

132
00:06:46.100 --> 00:06:50.020
Maybe I've got a thumb drive and
I plug in the thumb drive and I install

133
00:06:50.020 --> 00:06:54.750
a non-corrupted or updated driver, or
the correct driver for that matter.

134
00:06:54.750 --> 00:06:55.520
So understand,

135
00:06:56.540 --> 00:07:00.320
low resolution mode according to
the objective is also called VGA mode.

136
00:07:00.320 --> 00:07:02.300
Understand there's really no difference.

137
00:07:02.300 --> 00:07:06.930
And the reason I say this is because as
you will see, one of the things I really

138
00:07:06.930 --> 00:07:12.090
like about CompTIA's A+ is they
got out of just requiring Windows.

139
00:07:12.090 --> 00:07:14.010
And they want you to know
a little bit about Linux.

140
00:07:14.010 --> 00:07:15.880
They want you to know
a little bit about Mac.

141
00:07:15.880 --> 00:07:19.760
And in all honesty you should,
if you're going to be a tech,

142
00:07:19.760 --> 00:07:23.120
because not every body's going to bring
you just a Window's device right?

143
00:07:23.120 --> 00:07:26.240
However, know that all right?

144
00:07:26.240 --> 00:07:32.180
Now the next thing that we get
into is no image on the screen.

145
00:07:32.180 --> 00:07:33.540
Now let's step back.

146
00:07:33.540 --> 00:07:36.580
One of the things that we've talked about
in troubleshooting for the purposes of

147
00:07:36.580 --> 00:07:40.360
this exam and really in real life,
we've always stressed simple fixes first.

148
00:07:41.390 --> 00:07:42.653
When it comes to your monitor,

149
00:07:42.653 --> 00:07:45.582
first thing I want you to do is pay
attention to the light on the monitor.

150
00:07:45.582 --> 00:07:48.072
>> Completely rebuild the graphics
card from the ground up.

151
00:07:48.072 --> 00:07:49.023
>> That's right, that's right.

152
00:07:49.023 --> 00:07:51.411
Know the inner workings,
have the schematics, have the drivers.

153
00:07:51.411 --> 00:07:53.861
>> That would be the Ronnie Wong,
starting position [CROSSTALK].

154
00:07:53.861 --> 00:07:56.708
>> That's right, he's like,
I'll tell the IEEE what to do [LAUGH].

155
00:07:56.708 --> 00:07:58.968
Right, electrical engineering, right?

156
00:07:58.968 --> 00:08:03.745
Joking aside, though, pay attention
to what the monitor light is doing.

157
00:08:03.745 --> 00:08:04.680
Right, what do I mean by that?

158
00:08:04.680 --> 00:08:08.260
Well, you have a few different
colors that are potential, right?

159
00:08:08.260 --> 00:08:11.100
And I'll mention the most common ones.

160
00:08:11.100 --> 00:08:15.710
Green and blue and
sometimes monitor manufacturers,

161
00:08:15.710 --> 00:08:19.510
display manufacturers will use a blue
light or they'll use a green light, right?

162
00:08:19.510 --> 00:08:21.261
And either one of those
typically mean power, right?

163
00:08:21.261 --> 00:08:22.650
You've got power to the monitor.

164
00:08:23.750 --> 00:08:26.900
What is another one that's kind
of consistent is an amber light.

165
00:08:26.900 --> 00:08:28.216
And you can say orange and amber.

166
00:08:28.216 --> 00:08:32.781
I got in the habit of saying amber and the
reason I say that because the first time I

167
00:08:32.781 --> 00:08:37.211
saw a question across the A + exam,
I didn't know what the color amber was and

168
00:08:37.211 --> 00:08:42.010
I'd never apparently paid attention to
Jurassic Park and the little fly in amber.

169
00:08:43.270 --> 00:08:45.740
Now I know and that's why I use that term.

170
00:08:45.740 --> 00:08:50.069
So they could say orange, they could say
amber so just understand that when you see

171
00:08:50.069 --> 00:08:52.905
an amber light there's a few
things that can happen.

172
00:08:52.905 --> 00:08:57.647
That's the big, big thing to keep in mind
on the exam right, pay attention to what

173
00:08:57.647 --> 00:09:01.936
they are giving you in context of
the question the light is doing, right?

174
00:09:01.936 --> 00:09:04.168
So let's go ahead and
let's get a little bit more pacific,

175
00:09:04.168 --> 00:09:06.053
as a friend of mine would say,
specific, right?

176
00:09:06.053 --> 00:09:07.140
>> [LAUGH] Pacific.

177
00:09:07.140 --> 00:09:09.478
>> Pay attention to the power
indicator light, all right?

178
00:09:09.478 --> 00:09:10.334
If it's green or

179
00:09:10.334 --> 00:09:15.590
a blue light, then it typically means that
the monitor is receiving power, all right?

180
00:09:15.590 --> 00:09:17.290
But what if you have no
image on the screen and

181
00:09:17.290 --> 00:09:18.279
you've got a green or blue light?

182
00:09:19.360 --> 00:09:21.785
Well, here's another thing that
I want you to pay attention to,

183
00:09:21.785 --> 00:09:22.810
something known as an OSD.

184
00:09:22.810 --> 00:09:26.581
Yes, we're never shy of acronyms
here at the A+ level, right?

185
00:09:26.581 --> 00:09:28.300
The onscreen display.

186
00:09:28.300 --> 00:09:32.550
And what I mean by that is if you have a
little display that's kinda just traveling

187
00:09:32.550 --> 00:09:36.866
across your monitor in electrical limbo,
looks like it doesn't know where it's

188
00:09:36.866 --> 00:09:39.757
going, and
that means that the monitor's just fine.

189
00:09:39.757 --> 00:09:43.518
The on screen display says the monitor and
me the monitor,

190
00:09:43.518 --> 00:09:45.753
I'm doing what I should, right?

191
00:09:45.753 --> 00:09:50.078
>> And the good thing is, typically they
say something like, no input detected.

192
00:09:50.078 --> 00:09:52.920
They try to be a little informational and
not just go hi,

193
00:09:52.920 --> 00:09:55.590
this is a bouncing ball
running across your screen.

194
00:09:55.590 --> 00:09:59.520
They're saying, I don't detect that
there's anything coming toward me that I

195
00:09:59.520 --> 00:10:02.315
should be displaying, so
I'm just gonna give you this.

196
00:10:02.315 --> 00:10:05.214
>> And that is a great
progression of the technology.

197
00:10:05.214 --> 00:10:07.947
Cuz you're absolutely right Dan, and
sometimes they get real specific.

198
00:10:07.947 --> 00:10:09.901
>> Yeah.

00:18:51.180 --> 00:18:53.850

one that you cannot fix.

00:18:53.850 --> 00:18:55.890
