00:18:55.890 --> 00:18:59.490
A dead pixel basically is
where the pixel itself

378
00:18:59.490 --> 00:19:01.450
especially in thin film transistors.

379
00:19:01.450 --> 00:19:02.810
Let's understand that.

380
00:19:02.810 --> 00:19:07.580
In the older passive matrix, what you
would end up having is columns of these

381
00:19:07.580 --> 00:19:11.700
pixels that would be illuminated with the
transistor a little metal conductor and

382
00:19:11.700 --> 00:19:15.200
then what happened when adjacent columns
would rely on the ambient lighting.

383
00:19:15.200 --> 00:19:17.700
That's what I call
a passive matrix strain.

384
00:19:17.700 --> 00:19:23.040
In the active matrix strains that we have
today using TFT thin film transistors,

385
00:19:23.040 --> 00:19:26.320
every individual pixel
has its own transistor.

386
00:19:26.320 --> 00:19:30.840
In the olden days, what would happen
is if one of those conductors or

387
00:19:30.840 --> 00:19:33.950
a pixel went bad and the series that has
the conductor through it, guess what?

388
00:19:33.950 --> 00:19:36.280
You get a line right
down through the screen.

389
00:19:36.280 --> 00:19:41.980
Today, a single pixel, you're not gonna be
able to fix it because of the TFT screen,

390
00:19:41.980 --> 00:19:44.590
that pixel has its own transistor and
the transistor has failed.

391
00:19:44.590 --> 00:19:48.870
So there's just really nothing
that you can do for it.

00:20:46.860 --> 00:20:50.710
Now what's the different between that and

410
00:20:51.720 --> 00:20:54.233
A stuck pixel is not necessarily
one that's failing and

411
00:20:54.233 --> 00:20:57.170

412
00:20:57.170 --> 00:21:00.560

00:21:02.890 --> 00:21:04.930

00:21:04.930 --> 00:21:10.800
It retains the color illumination of
the previous image that it was displaying.

00:21:10.800 --> 00:21:15.060
Now there's a lot of software out

00:21:15.060 --> 00:21:18.420
So what it does is it sits there and
it goes to every single pixel and

424
00:21:32.440 --> 00:21:33.860
It's gonna write different colors,

425
00:21:33.860 --> 00:21:38.585
RGB to every single entire pixel
within the entirety of the monitor.

426
00:21:38.585 --> 00:21:40.780
Trying to kind of wake it up if you will.

427
00:21:40.780 --> 00:21:45.920
Trying to get it past
that stuck resolution.

428
00:21:45.920 --> 00:21:47.040
Here's another thing that you can do.

429
00:21:48.810 --> 00:21:54.500
What you can do is you can take
a little warm, I use a lint free cloth.

430
00:21:54.500 --> 00:21:56.842
And just heat it up just ever so slightly.

431
00:21:56.842 --> 00:21:58.620
Not hot.

432
00:21:58.620 --> 00:22:01.080
And then press it,
right there on the image,

433
00:22:01.080 --> 00:22:04.280
just press it barely just lightly and
sometimes that'll work.

434
00:22:04.280 --> 00:22:07.325
Other people have actually recommended
taking a pencil eraser at the end of

435
00:22:07.325 --> 00:22:09.563
a pencil and
kinda just massage the pixel a little bit.

436
00:22:09.563 --> 00:22:10.283
And again,

437
00:22:10.283 --> 00:22:15.193
what that does is it's gonna kinda get it
a little bit different colors for a bit.

438
00:22:15.193 --> 00:22:18.106
>> [CROSSTALK]
>> If you've had a rough day at work,

439
00:22:18.106 --> 00:22:19.570
you just wanna massage it.

440
00:22:19.570 --> 00:22:21.170
And say, you know,
just let that melt away.

441
00:22:21.170 --> 00:22:21.950
>> That's right, you're giving.

442
00:22:21.950 --> 00:22:22.910
>> And come back to working.

443
00:22:22.910 --> 00:22:24.700
>> You're giving your pixel
a little bit of Fen Shui.

444
00:22:24.700 --> 00:22:25.491
>> Yeah.
That's right.

445
00:22:25.491 --> 00:22:26.104
>> [LAUGH] For sure.

446
00:22:26.104 --> 00:22:26.908
Fen Shui for your monitor.

447
00:22:26.908 --> 00:22:27.483
>> A shiatzu massage.

448
00:22:27.483 --> 00:22:28.980
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

449
00:22:28.980 --> 00:22:32.610
So keep in mind, that's one of
the good things is that a stuck pixel,

450
00:22:32.610 --> 00:22:35.010
they don't call it out, but you should
know about it, because it could happen.

451
00:22:36.270 --> 00:22:38.880
All right we've got a few more things
that we wanna kinda talk about here.

452
00:22:38.880 --> 00:22:40.480
And we got artifacts.

453
00:22:40.480 --> 00:22:43.050
Artifacts a lot of times can
be a video format issue.

454
00:22:43.050 --> 00:22:47.615
Could be something kinda compression
issue where you've changed video formats.

455
00:22:47.615 --> 00:22:51.935
And you get these little strange
artifacts across the screen.

456
00:22:51.935 --> 00:22:53.745
The video card could overheat.

457
00:22:53.745 --> 00:22:56.395
When it starts to overheat,
a lot of times GPUs,

458
00:22:56.395 --> 00:23:00.825
just like CPUs, will go into a thermal
shutdown to protect themselves.

459
00:23:00.825 --> 00:23:04.795
However, sometimes it'll happen where it's
ambient heat, and be careful with this,

460
00:23:04.795 --> 00:23:10.490
when you have multiple expansion cards
that are populated across the motherboard.

461
00:23:10.490 --> 00:23:11.470
One card.

462
00:23:11.470 --> 00:23:13.110
It's heat that it's exhausted.

463
00:23:13.110 --> 00:23:16.980
Typically exhausts off
the back side of the card.

464
00:23:16.980 --> 00:23:21.580
If you have improper air flow,
you could be heating the PCB

465
00:23:21.580 --> 00:23:26.130
up on the card that's adjacent to it.

466
00:23:26.130 --> 00:23:30.150
Check to make sure the GPU fan on
the video card is actually working.

467
00:23:30.150 --> 00:23:33.530
Sometimes these get dusty and
sometimes the bearings seize up on them.

468
00:23:33.530 --> 00:23:35.160
It does happen.

469
00:23:35.160 --> 00:23:38.850
The other thing with artifacts too is if
you've got a PCIE card, a lot of these

470
00:23:38.850 --> 00:23:43.160
PCIE cards, PCIE by itself is so power
hungry that they needed to put additional

471
00:23:43.160 --> 00:23:48.370
four pins within the ATX main power
connector just to power the PCIE bus.

472
00:23:48.370 --> 00:23:50.070
And then on top of it, guess what?

473
00:23:50.070 --> 00:23:55.451
You have six and eight pin PCIE connectors
come off supply to connect the video card.

474
00:23:55.451 --> 00:23:57.795
If this is improperly seen and

475
00:23:57.795 --> 00:24:03.248
you might not be powering the card
correctly Could be a driver issue.

476
00:24:03.248 --> 00:24:04.640
Any time drivers get corrupted,

477
00:24:04.640 --> 00:24:08.150
we get all kind of things that go
screw your haywire in a machine.

478
00:24:08.150 --> 00:24:12.130
Could be an application is expecting
a certain amount of functionality and

479
00:24:12.130 --> 00:24:14.400
performance and it doesn't happen.

480
00:24:14.400 --> 00:24:16.810
You gamers out there that
are maybe watching this and

481
00:24:16.810 --> 00:24:20.520
pursuing a certification probably
know what it was like a few years ago

482
00:24:20.520 --> 00:24:22.800
if you were to put Crisis
on the highest settings and

483
00:24:22.800 --> 00:24:25.800
your graphics card didn't even
support the lowest settings, right?

484
00:24:25.800 --> 00:24:27.920
You can get these artifacts too.

485
00:24:29.410 --> 00:24:33.470
Color patterns are incorrect, again, this
could be where the application itself is

486
00:24:33.470 --> 00:24:36.190
expecting a certain level
of graphics memory,

487
00:24:36.190 --> 00:24:38.930
a certain level of processing
power within the GPU.

488
00:24:40.040 --> 00:24:43.410
And the poor car just doesn't
have those capabilities, right?

489
00:24:43.410 --> 00:24:46.640
So that might be something that you
have to upgrade the graphics card or

490
00:24:46.640 --> 00:24:48.970
it could be damaged or defective.

491
00:24:48.970 --> 00:24:50.280
Dim image, all right.

492
00:24:50.280 --> 00:24:53.180
Dan and I actually mentioned, in fact,
Danny it was you that mentioned this

493
00:24:53.180 --> 00:24:56.580
in the laptop episodes that
we were doing that dim image.

494
00:24:56.580 --> 00:25:00.400
Back light inverter could have
failed on whatever the device is,

495
00:25:00.400 --> 00:25:01.960
could be a power setting.

496
00:25:01.960 --> 00:25:03.930
It could be like a performance setting,
if you will.

497
00:25:03.930 --> 00:25:08.970
If you've got it for power saving,
remember your monitor can go at

498
00:25:08.970 --> 00:25:14.380
a power saving type situation where it
dims the image to preserve battery life.

499
00:25:14.380 --> 00:25:17.140
However, could be the fact
that the battery or

500
00:25:17.140 --> 00:25:20.250
the backlight inverter has failed, right?

501
00:25:20.250 --> 00:25:24.230
That's where the temporary workaround
is to extend the monitor out to a TV,

502
00:25:24.230 --> 00:25:25.605
like you were mentioning Dan, or

503
00:25:25.605 --> 00:25:29.390
out to a third or
second monitor until you can get it fixed.

504
00:25:29.390 --> 00:25:33.240
Flickering image, more often than not,
a flickering image is gonna be a loose

505
00:25:33.240 --> 00:25:37.540
connection, be a loose connection on
your power or on your cable itself.

506
00:25:37.540 --> 00:25:40.390
Could be a damaged connection port or
a damaged cable as well.

507
00:25:41.620 --> 00:25:45.940
Distorted image, again,
distorted image could be driver issue,

508
00:25:45.940 --> 00:25:48.370
could be resolution configuration, right?

509
00:25:48.370 --> 00:25:49.850
Distorted images can happen.

510
00:25:49.850 --> 00:25:53.880
Remember that LCDs, LEDs, and
OLEDs have what's known as a fixed or

511
00:25:53.880 --> 00:25:58.050
native resolution,
that's the resolution they operate in.

512
00:25:58.050 --> 00:26:04.350
If you get a 1920x1200 monitor,
that's its fixed resolution.

513
00:26:04.350 --> 00:26:07.680
When you change the resolution, just like
we have to do here to our MacBooks so

514
00:26:07.680 --> 00:26:09.060
that you guys can see it better,

515
00:26:09.060 --> 00:26:14.580
we do that because it brings up
the size of the icons, right?

516
00:26:14.580 --> 00:26:19.760
It can distort the image if you set
an incorrect monitor resolution, right?

517
00:26:19.760 --> 00:26:23.112
We've done this before where we've changed
the resolutions, we look at it, and we're

518
00:26:23.112 --> 00:26:26.362
like, wow, nobody would have wanna look
and stare at that for 30 minutes, right?

519
00:26:26.362 --> 00:26:26.874
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

520
00:26:26.874 --> 00:26:28.361
>> So again, it could be a resolution

521
00:26:28.361 --> 00:26:30.526
configuration that you
have to pay attention to.

522
00:26:30.526 --> 00:26:33.237
Distorted images could be driver

523
00:26:33.237 --> 00:26:36.845
issues as well.
Distorted geometry a lot of times that's

524
00:26:36.845 --> 00:26:41.599
gonna be an incorrect resolution setting
as well where you'll notice, for instance,

525
00:26:41.599 --> 00:26:45.389
after you're done watching this or
pause the video, if you change and

526
00:26:45.389 --> 00:26:48.729
turn your resolution,
like there's a knob on the computer,

527
00:26:48.729 --> 00:26:52.458
if you change your resolution and
the screen resolution settings and

528
00:26:52.458 --> 00:26:57.021
you notice the E across your task bar and
Windows, it's like it doesn't really look

529
00:26:57.021 --> 00:27:00.624
symmetrical in any way.
It's cuz it's resolution setting.

530
00:27:00.624 --> 00:27:02.064
It used to happen in the old CRTs,

531
00:27:02.064 --> 00:27:02.674
thank Goodness,

532
00:27:02.674 --> 00:27:08.550
they don't call out CRTs anymore on
the exam because it could be magnetized.

533
00:27:09.810 --> 00:27:14.160
Any magnet that's sat next to it
would distort the image, right?

534
00:27:14.160 --> 00:27:17.180
You'd have to do degaussing but
I wouldn't worry about that on the exam.

535
00:27:17.180 --> 00:27:19.320
>> Learned that lesson the hard way,
I was like, I don't know, ten,

536
00:27:19.320 --> 00:27:21.790
I took a magnet up to the TV,
I was like, that's cool.

537
00:27:21.790 --> 00:27:23.210
>> Yeah.
>> And then it didn't go away.

538
00:27:23.210 --> 00:27:23.972
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

539
00:27:23.972 --> 00:27:24.904
>> And mom and dad come out and

540
00:27:24.904 --> 00:27:26.060
I'm like they're real happy.

541
00:27:26.060 --> 00:27:29.134
>> What did you just do to my TV,
I'm gonna be missing Wapner?

542
00:27:29.134 --> 00:27:29.888
>> Yeah.
[LAUGH]

543
00:27:29.888 --> 00:27:30.609
>> That's right.

544
00:27:30.609 --> 00:27:34.530
So, again, we don't really have to
worry about that too much here cuz

545
00:27:34.530 --> 00:27:38.190
as far as the CRTs and the LCDs,

546
00:27:38.190 --> 00:27:43.690
you don't have a magnetic image spreader
like you did in the earlier CRT monitors.

547
00:27:43.690 --> 00:27:44.437
What else there Dan?

548
00:27:44.437 --> 00:27:48.558
Burned in image, we kinda talked
about that, some people say LCDs,

549
00:27:48.558 --> 00:27:53.830
LEDs aren't really susceptible to that,
yes, they are, we've got machines here.

550
00:27:53.830 --> 00:27:59.580
I had just a recent XPS and I know Ronny

551
00:27:59.580 --> 00:28:05.010
had this problem too in one of his
episodes where it was power hour and

552
00:28:05.010 --> 00:28:11.300
he did quite a few episodes and shurn off
when he took down his simple diagram.

553
00:28:11.300 --> 00:28:12.720
The diagram software that he had,

554
00:28:12.720 --> 00:28:15.170
you could still see the diagram
right across the image.

555
00:28:15.170 --> 00:28:16.990
So yes, it does happen, just keep in mind.

556
00:28:16.990 --> 00:28:21.290
You keep any image painted on
a screen statically for too long,

557
00:28:21.290 --> 00:28:24.143
you could have the remnants stay behind.

558
00:28:24.143 --> 00:28:28.417
Oversized images and icons, just like we
talked about with distorted images as

559
00:28:28.417 --> 00:28:30.724
well, keep in mind, lower resolutions.

560
00:28:30.724 --> 00:28:35.764
If you set a machine or a monitor or
even a projector, if you will for

561
00:28:35.764 --> 00:28:40.624
that matter, or any display really,
to a resolution lower than

562
00:28:40.624 --> 00:28:45.670
what it's expecting,
you get all kinds of crazy things, right?

563
00:28:45.670 --> 00:28:51.540
You're increasing the size of the icons
but you're not increasing the resolution.

564
00:28:51.540 --> 00:28:53.830
You could be decreasing it and
making it worse.

565
00:28:53.830 --> 00:28:57.530
So, again,
remember with your TFT screens or

566
00:28:57.530 --> 00:29:02.870
your LCD and LED screens,
remember native fixed resolution, right?

567
00:29:02.870 --> 00:29:06.780
Now, I'm saying native fixed like
they're two completely separate things,

568
00:29:06.780 --> 00:29:08.400
they're synonymous terms, right?

569
00:29:08.400 --> 00:29:11.301
A native resolution is the one
that that monitors supports,

570
00:29:11.301 --> 00:29:15.430
that's what they call it, fixed,
because you can change the resolution but

571
00:29:15.430 --> 00:29:18.270
it doesn't mean you're gonna improve the
picture quality and a lot of times you're

572
00:29:18.270 --> 00:29:21.130
gonna do the opposite, you're gonna
make the quality a little bit less.

573
00:29:21.130 --> 00:29:24.480
So quite a few different things
there that you gotta keep in mind.

574
00:29:24.480 --> 00:29:27.740
Dan [INAUDIBLE]
>> Yeah, this isn't on your notes or

575
00:29:27.740 --> 00:29:30.690
anything, but
as a guy who's been in the trenches, and

576
00:29:30.690 --> 00:29:36.100
thought I had seen all display issues,
I have come across at least one very,

577
00:29:36.100 --> 00:29:39.150
very strange one which is
inside of Windows specifically.

578
00:29:39.150 --> 00:29:43.540
They have the ability to increase
font sizes or readability,

579
00:29:43.540 --> 00:29:48.250
and it can kinda mess up
third party software.

580
00:29:48.250 --> 00:29:52.661
It will work great for the operating
system, but you look at [INAUDIBLE], and

581
00:29:52.661 --> 00:29:56.810
your like, why is this over scanning or
things aren't going in their proper spot?

582
00:29:56.810 --> 00:29:59.480
And I've had users say,
this isn't looking correct.

583
00:29:59.480 --> 00:30:03.080
I'm increasing the font size,
I'm decreasing the font size, resolution.

584
00:30:03.080 --> 00:30:03.600
>> Scaling.

585
00:30:03.600 --> 00:30:04.780
>> Changing things, right.

586
00:30:04.780 --> 00:30:09.000
It's the scaling feature inside of the
operating system that they had changed and

587
00:30:09.000 --> 00:30:13.970
it was modifying how a third
party software was acting.

588
00:30:13.970 --> 00:30:18.238
So don't think that wouldn't also be the
cause of maybe some display issues that

589
00:30:18.238 --> 00:30:19.925
you might be running into.

590
00:30:19.925 --> 00:30:24.180
But Wes, other than that, you've gone
through a great litany of I would say

591
00:30:24.180 --> 00:30:27.760
the vast majority if not all the rest of
the display issues I've ever encountered.

592
00:30:27.760 --> 00:30:29.350
Anything else that we need to be aware of?

593
00:30:29.350 --> 00:30:30.520
>> I was just gonna tell you,

594
00:30:30.520 --> 00:30:33.910
one of the telltale signs at scaling set
off is when you look at your common web

595
00:30:33.910 --> 00:30:38.040
browsers and you have a normal
zoom size and it still looks off.

596
00:30:38.040 --> 00:30:40.950
That's one of the first ways because,
like you said, some applications,

597
00:30:40.950 --> 00:30:42.090
they don't like it at all.

598
00:30:42.090 --> 00:30:44.061
>> No, they dont.
>> That's one of the telltale signs

599
00:30:44.061 --> 00:30:47.950
that font size and scaling size have
been kind of set incorrectly is when you

600
00:30:47.950 --> 00:30:52.145
open that web browser and you're like,
wow, half of that webpage is missing and

601
00:30:52.145 --> 00:30:54.018
when I look at the zoom it says 0%.

602
00:30:54.018 --> 00:30:54.660
Right?
So

603
00:30:54.660 --> 00:30:57.940
I was just gonna mention
to kinda expand on that.

604
00:30:57.940 --> 00:31:00.916
That's one of the first signs that
I've had to tell people, hey okay, so

605
00:31:00.916 --> 00:31:04.420
what's your zoom set to and they say,
well, I haven't zoomed in at all.

606
00:31:04.420 --> 00:31:07.123
And they're still getting
that kind of distorted image.

607
00:31:07.123 --> 00:31:09.221
>> I spent weeks on that by the way.

608
00:31:09.221 --> 00:31:12.198
I say weeks, it was like two days but,
Wes, thanks so much for

609
00:31:12.198 --> 00:31:14.395
explaining the different displays issues.

610
00:31:14.395 --> 00:31:15.134
>> Sure.

611
00:31:15.134 --> 00:31:18.254
>> That we're gonna be
encountering as A+ technicians and

612
00:31:18.254 --> 00:31:21.030
as someone who is preparing for
the A+ exam.

613
00:31:21.030 --> 00:31:22.990
But it does look like we are out
of time for this episode.

614
00:31:22.990 --> 00:31:25.270
We do thank you for joining us,
hopefully you've enjoyed it.

615
00:31:25.270 --> 00:31:27.100
We sure try hard that you do.

616
00:31:27.100 --> 00:31:29.840
Signing off for ITPro.TV,
I've been your host, Daniel Lowrie.

617
00:31:29.840 --> 00:31:30.690
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

618
00:31:30.690 --> 00:31:32.954
>> We'll see you next time.

619
00:31:32.954 --> 00:31:38.945
[MUSIC]

620
00:31:38.945 --> 00:31:42.584
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes troubleshoot both wired and wireless networks with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here include: Connectivity issues, disconnected cables, dead ports, dead devices, power loss, misconfiguration, incorrect cable standards, and device drivers.
episodes.title: Common Wired/Wireless Network Issues
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.003 --> 00:00:04.502
>> Welcome to ITPRO.TV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet-

2
00:00:04.502 --> 00:00:06.327
>> [CROSSTALK] [INAUDIBLE]

3
00:00:06.327 --> 00:00:08.270
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.270 --> 00:00:13.270
>> Youre watching ITPRO.TV.
>> All right, greetings everyone.

5
00:00:13.270 --> 00:00:16.570
Welcome back to another
great episode of ITPRO TV.

6
00:00:16.570 --> 00:00:21.276
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and today's
episode is more NRA plus series and

7
00:00:21.276 --> 00:00:23.290
good old 29 01, to be exact.

8
00:00:23.290 --> 00:00:24.590
And joining us in the studio yet

9
00:00:24.590 --> 00:00:27.910
again, lending his expertise on the topic,
our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

10
00:00:27.910 --> 00:00:29.280
Wes, how's it going today, my man?

11
00:00:29.280 --> 00:00:31.120
>> Man, it's going great,
great to be here.

12
00:00:31.120 --> 00:00:35.000
That's right, we are moving through
our troubleshooting sections, right?

13
00:00:35.000 --> 00:00:37.390
In a previous episode,
we showed you a little bit on how to,

14
00:00:37.390 --> 00:00:40.250
well, troubleshoot things like your
hard drives and your RAID arrays.

15
00:00:40.250 --> 00:00:44.270
Well, In 901, we've also talked about some
of the hardware that tallow us to move

16
00:00:44.270 --> 00:00:48.830
communications across the network, between
a few end points, a couple end points.

17
00:00:48.830 --> 00:00:52.200
So, that is what we're gonna dive
in today is troubleshooting some

18
00:00:52.200 --> 00:00:54.240
of our network communications.

19
00:00:54.240 --> 00:00:58.372
It is important to understand that when
it comes to network communications,

20
00:00:58.372 --> 00:01:02.005
we have wired devices, and
we have wireless devices, if you will.

21
00:01:02.005 --> 00:01:05.469
And, when we look at the two
different communication types,

22
00:01:05.469 --> 00:01:07.610
the communication media if you will.

23
00:01:07.610 --> 00:01:11.670
Some of them can have very
similar issues if you will.

24
00:01:11.670 --> 00:01:15.460
And then some of them can have some
distinct issues that you might have to

25
00:01:15.460 --> 00:01:20.710
recognize if you will diagnose,
resolve and/or remediate.

26
00:01:20.710 --> 00:01:23.340
So we're gonna dive into
both the wired side,

27
00:01:23.340 --> 00:01:26.500
as well as the wireless side, all right?

So the official objectives here,

00:24:09.105 --> 00:24:11.590
So, that could cause no
connectivity as well.

471
00:24:11.590 --> 00:24:14.730
And then, what you're gonna wanna
do is if you have any issue,

472
00:24:14.730 --> 00:24:16.000
if you think it's a driver issue,

473
00:24:16.000 --> 00:24:21.070
you can always right click on the network
adapter here, you can choose properties.

474
00:24:21.070 --> 00:24:24.330
Inside of the properties,
you'll notice that we do have this

475
00:24:24.330 --> 00:24:27.620
driver tab right here, and
that driver tab is very important.

476
00:24:27.620 --> 00:24:30.940
Notice, that it also tells us,
in this case, whether it's working or not.

477
00:24:30.940 --> 00:24:35.990
Absolutely love that, too,
as a way to do a quick diagnosis.

478
00:24:35.990 --> 00:24:40.320
Notice that you can find out what
the driver is to the device,

479
00:24:40.320 --> 00:24:43.980
you can see the driver details,
we could update the driver.

480
00:24:43.980 --> 00:24:46.440
The device might even be disabled, right?

481
00:24:46.440 --> 00:24:48.890
Let me show you here,
if you just actually disable the device,

482
00:24:48.890 --> 00:24:51.870
it's going to warn you saying, hey,
it'll cause it to stop working.

483
00:24:51.870 --> 00:24:54.770
And if I choose OK, to this,
you're going to notice that,

484
00:24:54.770 --> 00:24:58.660
now I do have an icon that is
present in device manager, right?

485
00:24:58.660 --> 00:25:04.540
And it's letting me know, hey, you're not
gonna be able to use your network adapter.

486
00:25:04.540 --> 00:25:07.530
So, again,
keep that in mind that that is there too.

487
00:25:07.530 --> 00:25:10.580
Let's see what it looks like
in the background here.

488
00:25:10.580 --> 00:25:13.855
Yep, so
you can see that it is a disabled device.

489
00:25:13.855 --> 00:25:15.425
That would cause no connectivity.

490
00:25:15.425 --> 00:25:18.645
The good thing is it's kind of obvious
because it does tell you that it is

491
00:25:18.645 --> 00:25:19.765
disconnected.

492
00:25:19.765 --> 00:25:21.105
And one of the great things is,

493
00:25:21.105 --> 00:25:23.745
we can actually just right-click on
it right here, just choose enable,

494
00:25:23.745 --> 00:25:26.840
so a few different things
that you got to keep in mind.

495
00:25:26.840 --> 00:25:29.680
I know we're running short on time,
on this one here.

496
00:25:29.680 --> 00:25:32.010
Some of the other things that you
might have to worry about, right?

497
00:25:32.010 --> 00:25:33.970
If you have no connectivity,

498
00:25:33.970 --> 00:25:36.390
like an internet connection,
did you pay the bill, right?

499
00:25:36.390 --> 00:25:38.481
I mean, we've talked about simple fixes,

500
00:25:38.481 --> 00:25:42.790
probably one of the most simplistic
fixes is if you haven't paid the bill.

501
00:25:42.790 --> 00:25:47.830
Now, with wire connections, we do want
to mention things like, for instance,

502
00:25:47.830 --> 00:25:52.700
are your cables crimped, and, what I mean
by that, is not installing an RJ 45 jack.

503
00:25:52.700 --> 00:25:56.270
I mean, literally,
have they sustained some damage.

504
00:25:56.270 --> 00:25:59.210
Remember, simple fixes first,
look at the link lights.

505
00:25:59.210 --> 00:26:04.300
Inspect the cable if you need to, the
other thing to keep in mind is that if you

506
00:26:04.300 --> 00:26:07.110
have somebody that's wired
up that cable themselves and

507
00:26:07.110 --> 00:26:12.160
they've put the TEF568A
wiring scheme on one side and

508
00:26:12.160 --> 00:26:15.470
the 568B on another side that actually
forms what's known as a crossover cable.

509
00:26:15.470 --> 00:26:20.170
And in administration we use this to
communicate with things like access points

510
00:26:20.170 --> 00:26:24.025
directly, if you will, or
connectivity devices or to make a direct

511
00:26:24.025 --> 00:26:27.980
point-to-point communication without
going through the connectivity device.

512
00:26:27.980 --> 00:26:32.980
And the problem is if that's plugged into
one of these APs or even a wired router,

513
00:26:32.980 --> 00:26:35.400
it isn't going to allow
you to communicate.

514
00:26:35.400 --> 00:26:37.440
Doesn't it matter if you
have an IP address or not.

515
00:26:37.440 --> 00:26:39.270
Doesn't matter if it's statically set.

516
00:26:39.270 --> 00:26:40.490
It could cause problems.

517
00:26:40.490 --> 00:26:46.000
So also pay attention to the standards
like that when we talk about 568A and

518
00:26:46.000 --> 00:26:48.000
568B, you just have to make sure.

519
00:26:48.000 --> 00:26:51.660
Pay attention to the cable, and it's
whatever standard it is on both sides.

520
00:26:51.660 --> 00:26:54.400
Commonly today it's gonna be 568B.

521
00:26:54.400 --> 00:26:58.880
So configuration, drivers, adapter issues,
all things that can manifest themselves.

522
00:26:58.880 --> 00:27:02.970
There are things that are specific to
the wireless access point as well.

523
00:27:02.970 --> 00:27:08.220
If you have no connectivity, are you
within the proximity of the access point?

524
00:27:08.220 --> 00:27:10.830
You might be too far away
from the access point, right,

525
00:27:10.830 --> 00:27:13.460
that you're not getting that connectivity.

526
00:27:13.460 --> 00:27:17.370
The devices could be turned off themselves
just like the network adapters we showed

527
00:27:17.370 --> 00:27:19.700
you disabling them and turning them off.

528
00:27:19.700 --> 00:27:22.830
If you have no power on the device,
you're not gonna have any connectivity.

529
00:27:22.830 --> 00:27:25.740
>> All right, lots of different
things that could be causing issues

530
00:27:25.740 --> 00:27:27.480
when it comes to network connectivity.

531
00:27:27.480 --> 00:27:30.050
We've really just scratched
the surface on things we can do and

532
00:27:30.050 --> 00:27:31.230
things we have to look at.

533
00:27:31.230 --> 00:27:34.790
But Wes, our time clock is saying,
no mas, right?

534
00:27:34.790 --> 00:27:36.980
We've come to the end of an episode.

535
00:27:36.980 --> 00:27:40.540
So, it looks like we're in for
one of our wonderful multiparters.

536
00:27:40.540 --> 00:27:43.032
I know this is probably gonna
go at least one more, right?

537
00:27:43.032 --> 00:27:44.740
>> [LAUGH]
>> So join us back for that.

538
00:27:44.740 --> 00:27:47.570
See what you can do when you start
having network connectivity issues.

539
00:27:47.570 --> 00:27:50.340
There's just a multitude of
things that could be wrong.

540
00:27:50.340 --> 00:27:54.690
And like I said, we've just broken
through on what that could possibly be.

541
00:27:54.690 --> 00:27:55.540
But, that being said,

542
00:27:55.540 --> 00:27:58.460
signing off for ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

543
00:27:58.460 --> 00:28:01.356
>> And I'm Wes Bryan
>> And we'll see you next time.

544
00:28:01.356 --> 00:28:07.408
[MUSIC]

545
00:28:07.408 --> 00:28:10.509
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes troubleshoot both wired and wireless networks with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here include: Wireless Connectivity issues (proximity/frequency mismatch/standards mismatch/security settings/pass key mismatch), APIPA, failing devices, limited connectivity, ping, and IP conflicts.
episodes.title: Common Wired/Wireless Network Issues Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.310 --> 00:00:01.199
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.199 --> 00:00:02.929
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.929 --> 00:00:06.385
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.385 --> 00:00:08.343
>> [MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.343 --> 00:00:12.054
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.054 --> 00:00:13.877
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:13.877 --> 00:00:16.191
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.191 --> 00:00:20.471
I'm your host Daniel Lowry, and
in today's episode more on A+.

9
00:00:20.471 --> 00:00:23.238
That's right, always coming at you with
more of that A+ cuz it's a lot of fun.

10
00:00:23.238 --> 00:00:27.230
And joining us back in the studio to enjoy
the fun himself, our good friend Mr.

11
00:00:27.230 --> 00:00:27.847
Wes Bryan.

12
00:00:27.847 --> 00:00:29.515
Wes, glad to have you back,
sir, how's it going?

13
00:00:29.515 --> 00:00:31.583
>> Man, it's going great,
love the way you brought that in.

14
00:00:31.583 --> 00:00:34.769
He said, more on A+, right?

15
00:00:34.769 --> 00:00:35.722
>> That's right.

16
00:00:35.722 --> 00:00:36.241
>> So I'm in the right spot here.

17
00:00:36.241 --> 00:00:36.741
>> Yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

18
00:00:36.741 --> 00:00:38.142
>> That's right.

19
00:00:38.142 --> 00:00:38.800
>> Correct studio.

20
00:00:38.800 --> 00:00:39.521
[LAUGH]

21
00:00:39.521 --> 00:00:40.233
>> That's right.

22
00:00:40.233 --> 00:00:42.003
So we're going to talk a little bit more

23
00:00:42.003 --> 00:00:45.127
about some of the network
troubleshooting that you can see, right?

24
00:00:45.127 --> 00:00:47.425
There are plenty of things that they

25
00:00:47.425 --> 00:00:51.291
call out on the exam.
All good subjects, all good topics.

26
00:00:51.291 --> 00:00:52.965
In the first one we really talked about,

27
00:00:52.965 --> 00:00:56.106
well, just no connectivity.
And that could manifest itself in so

28
00:00:56.106 --> 00:00:57.190
many ways.
In fact, so

29
00:00:57.190 --> 00:00:59.110
many ways I didn't get everyone
of them in there, right?

30
00:00:59.110 --> 00:01:00.598
In fact, I was telling Dan this.

31
00:01:00.598 --> 00:01:04.669
We talked a lot about things like the
wired connections, but I didn't mention

32
00:01:04.669 --> 00:01:08.200
some of the additional things that
you could see inside a wireless.

33
00:01:08.200 --> 00:01:12.900
And more specifically, I did end on if
your proximity from the access point,

34
00:01:12.900 --> 00:01:15.270
if you're not close to
the access point at all,

35
00:01:15.270 --> 00:01:17.400
it can manifest itself
in a couple of things.

36
00:01:17.400 --> 00:01:20.544
But again,
focusing on the no connectivity,

37
00:01:20.544 --> 00:01:24.258
you just might not be close
enough to the transmitter.

38
00:01:24.258 --> 00:01:25.437
So do keep that in mind.

39
00:01:25.437 --> 00:01:29.922
The other thing that I didn't mention is,
well, there can be some certain mismatches

40
00:01:29.922 --> 00:01:33.425
that maybe your network adapter
is supporting a certain standard,

41
00:01:33.425 --> 00:01:36.514
using a certain frequency
versus what kind of encryption.

42
00:01:36.514 --> 00:01:40.050
So I've got the access points
interface pulled up that we used

43
00:01:40.050 --> 00:01:43.450
in the very first episode, or
the very first part here, and

44
00:01:43.450 --> 00:01:47.310
I wanna kind of focus in on
the wireless aspect of this, right?

45
00:01:47.310 --> 00:01:51.740
If we go to the wireless settings, that
looks like my session time down here, so

46
00:01:51.740 --> 00:01:55.200
let's go ahead and
use our super secret password out there,

47
00:01:55.200 --> 00:01:57.340
get logged back in here real quick.

48
00:01:57.340 --> 00:02:01.180
And I wanna focus again in on
the wireless portion of this too,

49
00:02:01.180 --> 00:02:05.790
because we talked mainly about wired,
the wired communication.

50
00:02:05.790 --> 00:02:06.990
But I want you to notice that,

51
00:02:06.990 --> 00:02:11.190
keep in mind that frequency
mismatches could be a problem, too.

52
00:02:11.190 --> 00:02:14.650
It's one of the reasons that
we wanna look at those 802.11

53
00:02:14.650 --> 00:02:19.320
wireless local area network standards,
because again A, B, G and,

54
00:02:19.320 --> 00:02:23.440
if you will, and AC today,
they all support different frequencies.

55
00:02:23.440 --> 00:02:24.016
And well,

56
00:02:24.016 --> 00:02:28.185
like N supports a couple of frequencies
cuz it was a dual band communication.

57
00:02:28.185 --> 00:02:31.075
But if you have some of
the older standards, all right,

58
00:02:31.075 --> 00:02:33.842
that might run into a little
bit of a problem, right,

59
00:02:33.842 --> 00:02:38.041
especially if you're supporting AC and
it doesn't have a dual band radio in it.

60
00:02:38.041 --> 00:02:42.045
Again, meaning that it can
also support 2.4 as well as 5,

61
00:02:42.045 --> 00:02:45.516
cuz remember the AC standard
is the 5 GHz frequency.

62
00:02:45.516 --> 00:02:49.339
But because manufacturers want
this interoperability and

63
00:02:49.339 --> 00:02:53.162
compatibility, sometimes they will put,
for instance,

64
00:02:53.162 --> 00:02:58.295
an M radio in there that will support
all the earlier legacy protocols, right?

65
00:02:58.295 --> 00:03:02.069
So remember the earliest protocol,
one that's kinda gone by the wayside, but

66
00:03:02.069 --> 00:03:04.787
who knows, you might still
see it out there is A, right?

67
00:03:04.787 --> 00:03:07.392
A works on the 5 GHz frequency but

68
00:03:07.392 --> 00:03:11.588
we have a lot of devices out
there that are also B and G.

69
00:03:11.588 --> 00:03:13.425
B and G, and not N.

70
00:03:13.425 --> 00:03:19.408
I say B and G only support 2.4, right,
so this could be a problem as well.

71
00:03:19.408 --> 00:03:23.274
Now the other thing I want you to keep
in mind, too, is that the networks

72
00:03:23.274 --> 00:03:27.869
here could be set to an only-based network
and it's exactly what it means, right?

73
00:03:27.869 --> 00:03:31.187
If I have a, let's say,
an N device, right, but

74
00:03:31.187 --> 00:03:35.782
I'm saying hey, I only wanna support G,
well, now have a problem.

75
00:03:35.782 --> 00:03:37.366
I'm not gonna be able to communicate.

76
00:03:37.366 --> 00:03:39.910
And even though they're
in the same frequency,

77
00:03:39.910 --> 00:03:44.003
some of the things that you certainly
don't have to worry about for this exam,

78
00:03:44.003 --> 00:03:48.471
certain technologies use something known
as direct sequence spread spectrum versus

79
00:03:48.471 --> 00:03:52.464
one that uses things like orthogonal
frequency divisional multiplexing.

80
00:03:52.464 --> 00:03:55.136
And those are, again,
you don't have to worry so

81
00:03:55.136 --> 00:03:57.564
much about the multiplexing technologies.

82
00:03:57.564 --> 00:04:01.481
It's just the fact that even though
they're operating in the same frequency,

83
00:04:01.481 --> 00:04:04.522
they might not be distributing
that information over the same

84
00:04:04.522 --> 00:04:07.400
kind of technology,
let alone if you disable it, right?

85
00:04:07.400 --> 00:04:13.370
[LAUGH] So that would cause issues, too,
might cause no connectivity likewise.

86
00:04:13.370 --> 00:04:14.510
So do keep that in mind.

87
00:04:14.510 --> 00:04:17.112
That's one of the things,
when we just talk about frequencies,

88
00:04:17.112 --> 00:04:18.355
that could cause the problem.

89
00:04:18.355 --> 00:04:23.050
The other thing that could cause the
problem, too, is your security modes here.

90
00:04:23.050 --> 00:04:27.279
So for instance, if you, well,
we really shouldn't be using WEP today,

91
00:04:27.279 --> 00:04:31.238
but if WEP is set up on here, and
again, it's even telling you, hey,

92
00:04:31.238 --> 00:04:35.163
you really don't wanna use WEP, so
I'm not even gonna turn this on.

93
00:04:35.163 --> 00:04:39.596
But if we're gonna use
something like WPA or WPA2,

94
00:04:39.596 --> 00:04:44.248
do you have things like
the right pass phrase, right?

95
00:04:44.248 --> 00:04:48.325
When we talk about personal, guys, they
love to make these technical terms, and

96
00:04:48.325 --> 00:04:50.645
in fact I know this is
one of Dan's pet peeves.

97
00:04:50.645 --> 00:04:51.938
We've talked about it before.

98
00:04:51.938 --> 00:04:54.170
They call it PSK, pre-shared key.

99
00:04:54.170 --> 00:04:55.127
They call it a phrase.

100
00:04:55.127 --> 00:04:56.057
Dan, what do you call it?

101
00:04:56.057 --> 00:04:57.027
>> I call it a password.

102
00:04:57.027 --> 00:04:58.334
[LAUGH]
>> That's exactly what it is.

103
00:04:58.334 --> 00:05:01.488
>> I think that's what 95% of
the people out there using wireless

104
00:05:01.488 --> 00:05:03.623
technologies are calling it, a password.

105
00:05:03.623 --> 00:05:08.100
Not technical people, not IT folks like
you're trying to become or are, right?

106
00:05:08.100 --> 00:05:10.508
You're gonna start saying, well,
that's the pre-shared key,

107
00:05:10.508 --> 00:05:12.970
because that's what they're
gonna drill into your head.

108
00:05:12.970 --> 00:05:15.370
But for your average everyday Joe
out there working on a computer,

109
00:05:15.370 --> 00:05:17.900
banging away at it,
password is what they're gonna call it.

110
00:05:17.900 --> 00:05:19.550
Passphrase is what they're gonna call it.

111
00:05:19.550 --> 00:05:24.180
And what's interesting is, you might have
actually put in the correct password, and

112
00:05:24.180 --> 00:05:25.090
now it's not working.

113
00:05:25.090 --> 00:05:26.350
Why is it not working?

114
00:05:26.350 --> 00:05:29.485
Your IT person may have changed
the password and you have yet

115
00:05:29.485 --> 00:05:31.249
to update what that password is.

116
00:05:31.249 --> 00:05:33.185
Hence the reason it's
telling you no connectivity.

117
00:05:33.185 --> 00:05:35.838
>> And you can see that, Dan,
and I know you've done this,

118
00:05:35.838 --> 00:05:39.785
Dan's worked in help desk many, many years
before, and why is he saying password?

119
00:05:39.785 --> 00:05:40.841
Because people understand it.

120
00:05:40.841 --> 00:05:44.636
Remember another thing, and we talk about
this in the operational procedures and

121
00:05:44.636 --> 00:05:48.596
communication, you're not doing yourself
any justice like going into somebody and

122
00:05:48.596 --> 00:05:51.960
just saying, hey, look how smart I am
by saying a whole bunch of jargon.

123
00:05:51.960 --> 00:05:53.915
Well, did you change the PSK?

124
00:05:53.915 --> 00:05:54.610
What is that?

125
00:05:54.610 --> 00:05:56.103
Did you type the right password?

126
00:05:56.103 --> 00:05:57.406
Now I know what it is.

127
00:05:57.406 --> 00:06:00.959
Okay, so understand that those terms
are synonymous with each other, right?

128
00:06:00.959 --> 00:06:03.376
And yes, you have to know the jargon for
the exam.

129
00:06:03.376 --> 00:06:06.885
But keep in mind, your jargon doesn't
a lot of times communicate when it comes

130
00:06:06.885 --> 00:06:08.062
to just basic level help.

131
00:06:08.062 --> 00:06:11.728
So encryption mismatch could
be the problem as well.

132
00:06:11.728 --> 00:06:15.718
If you happen to be using something like
WPS, where it's just a PIN that you enter,

133
00:06:15.718 --> 00:06:17.485
right, did you enter the PIN right,

134
00:06:17.485 --> 00:06:21.549
the Personal Identification Number that's
on the back of the router, if you will?

135
00:06:21.549 --> 00:06:23.350
Again that could cause a problem.

136
00:06:23.350 --> 00:06:25.524
One of the last things
I wanna say as well,

137
00:06:25.524 --> 00:06:28.643
is that you can also do things
like wireless MAC filtering.

138
00:06:28.643 --> 00:06:32.568
And this is either what's known
as a white list or a black list.

139
00:06:32.568 --> 00:06:36.015
A white list, if you will, says,
hey, anything that's on this list,

140
00:06:36.015 --> 00:06:37.553
we're gonna allow it, right?

141
00:06:37.553 --> 00:06:40.481
The black list is kind of like a, hey,
I got you in that little black book.

142
00:06:40.481 --> 00:06:41.318
We're gonna take you out.

143
00:06:41.318 --> 00:06:45.447
[LAUGH] No, the black list says no,
you're not permitted, right?

144
00:06:45.447 --> 00:06:48.021
And people can do this for
different reasons, right, or

145
00:06:48.021 --> 00:06:49.693
implement it differently, right?

146
00:06:49.693 --> 00:06:52.392
So regardless of which
side of the tracks it is,

147
00:06:52.392 --> 00:06:56.114
if it happens to be a prevent versus
a permit, are you on the list?

148
00:06:56.114 --> 00:06:58.739
And if you're on the list and
you're prevented, well,

like I have an ASUS router at my house, so

372
00:18:44.105 --> 00:18:45.482
it is a little bit different.

373
00:18:45.482 --> 00:18:49.103
But for the most part across the top of
these, a lot of times they are the same.

374
00:18:49.103 --> 00:18:50.935
So, for instance,
I have the Status option.

375
00:18:50.935 --> 00:18:55.175
And if I look at Status, one of the things
I can see is the router's information like

376
00:18:55.175 --> 00:18:57.065
its Internet MAC address.

377
00:18:57.065 --> 00:19:00.225
This is what your ISP will see
when the access point connects.

378
00:19:00.225 --> 00:19:01.995
I can see firmware version as well.

379
00:19:01.995 --> 00:19:06.325
But what I really want to know
is my Internet connection.

380
00:19:06.325 --> 00:19:08.345
We've set it to an automatic
Internet connection.

381
00:19:08.345 --> 00:19:10.938
And you can kinda see that
with the connection type here,

382
00:19:10.938 --> 00:19:13.080
Automatic Configuration-DHCP.

383
00:19:13.080 --> 00:19:16.410
But notice that I don't
have an IP address, right?

384
00:19:16.410 --> 00:19:18.420
I don't have an Internet IP address,

385
00:19:18.420 --> 00:19:22.480
I don't have an Internet-based subnet mask
or default gateway, let alone DNS servers.

386
00:19:22.480 --> 00:19:26.510
And again, that's your ISP doing the same
thing that your client does when it

387
00:19:26.510 --> 00:19:28.010
connects to the network.

388
00:19:28.010 --> 00:19:32.150
You do that outbound on the WAN side
of your communications when your access

389
00:19:32.150 --> 00:19:36.650
point goes through your modem to
connect to the ISP, it basically says,

390
00:19:36.650 --> 00:19:39.940
hey, ISP I paid you some money,
you got an ISP address for me?

391
00:19:39.940 --> 00:19:44.255
And if they're having issues or the bill
isn't paid, you're going to see this right

392
00:19:44.255 --> 00:19:49.685
here and what that does is it will
result in limited or local connectivity.

393
00:19:49.685 --> 00:19:52.665
You won't be able to communicate
outside of your network.

394
00:19:52.665 --> 00:19:56.815
Now the other thing that can
cause problems too is when

395
00:19:56.815 --> 00:19:58.875
you have IP conflicts.

396
00:19:58.875 --> 00:20:03.170
Now IP conflicts typically
are a configuration issue, if you will.

397
00:20:03.170 --> 00:20:08.100
And with the configuration issue,
sometimes here's what can happen.

398
00:20:08.100 --> 00:20:13.030
You set your computer up for
DHCP, all right?

399
00:20:13.030 --> 00:20:16.540
You set a computer up or a printer or
something like that up on your network,

400
00:20:16.540 --> 00:20:20.980
and a lot of times they like static IPs,
we talked about in TCPIP that certain

401
00:20:20.980 --> 00:20:23.770
services you never want then
to change their IP address.

402
00:20:23.770 --> 00:20:26.420
If we go back to the access point,
let me show you where you can kind of get

403
00:20:26.420 --> 00:20:30.175
yourself into trouble with this
one pretty quickly, right?

404
00:20:30.175 --> 00:20:35.000
[LAUGH] When you are setting up DHCP,
we're talking about getting

405
00:20:35.000 --> 00:20:38.570
those IP addresses pulled
down to your local machine.

406
00:20:38.570 --> 00:20:43.480
Well, if you've statically mapped an IP
address and it sits within this range,

407
00:20:43.480 --> 00:20:45.670
there is a potential for

408
00:20:45.670 --> 00:20:49.960
one of those IP addresses to be
issued out by the DHCP service.

409
00:20:49.960 --> 00:20:54.240
So let's just say theoretically, I've got
a printer within my network that I've

410
00:20:54.240 --> 00:20:59.410
statically mapped or manually configured
its IP address to 192.168.1.101,

411
00:20:59.410 --> 00:21:02.470
and my computer connects to the network.

412
00:21:02.470 --> 00:21:06.810
And it says, I need an IP address,
and DHCP says,

413
00:21:06.810 --> 00:21:10.540
well, here's the list of IPs I have here,
you can have .101.

414
00:21:10.540 --> 00:21:15.400
Now we've got two computers
on the network that,

415
00:21:15.400 --> 00:21:19.370
like the house on the same street
has identical house numbers, mail

416
00:21:19.370 --> 00:21:23.320
carrier gets there and says, wait a second
which mail box does this go to, right?

417
00:21:23.320 --> 00:21:24.800
And we have a conflict.

418
00:21:24.800 --> 00:21:27.980
So that can happen and
one of the things that you can do, I said,

419
00:21:27.980 --> 00:21:30.360
that's where you can get into trouble.

420
00:21:30.360 --> 00:21:32.950
Here's where you can kind of
alleviate that problem, well,

421
00:21:32.950 --> 00:21:35.320
you've a couple of options,
I can make sure,

422
00:21:35.320 --> 00:21:39.730
oops, that you guys take your motion
sickness pills after I get done [LAUGH].

423
00:21:39.730 --> 00:21:43.970
I can make sure that whatever the static
IP address is, it can be like .99, or

424
00:21:43.970 --> 00:21:47.720
it can be like .150,
see how it sits outside of that range?

425
00:21:47.720 --> 00:21:51.060
Or we can go even further, we can set
up what's known as a DHCP reservation.

426
00:21:51.060 --> 00:21:55.340
And when you set up a DHCP reservation,
essentially what you're saying is every

427
00:21:55.340 --> 00:22:00.690
time that computer turns on, or
a printer turns on, it says, I

428
00:22:00.690 --> 00:22:06.320
recognize that device and yes I know it's
within this list, but I've bookmarked it.

429
00:22:06.320 --> 00:22:08.220
That it's only gonna
go to this one device.

430
00:22:08.220 --> 00:22:09.800
That's why they call it a reservation,
right?

431
00:22:09.800 --> 00:22:12.455
It's like assigning
reservations at a restaurant.

432
00:22:12.455 --> 00:22:16.340
Dan, you take your wife out, I take my
wife out, if you will, to restaurant.

433
00:22:16.340 --> 00:22:18.300
We make a reservation,
what are they doing?

434
00:22:18.300 --> 00:22:22.350
They're saying this table at this
time is gonna be reserved for you.

435
00:22:22.350 --> 00:22:23.750
It's the same thing with your IP address.

436
00:22:23.750 --> 00:22:26.823
What you're saying is within that range,
I'm gonna take one of these IP addresses.

437
00:22:26.823 --> 00:22:30.172
I'm gonna bookmark it, and that's
gonna be, let's say, for that printer.

438
00:22:30.172 --> 00:22:33.678
And every time that printer turns on,
and calls out to the network,

439
00:22:33.678 --> 00:22:37.570
I'm gonna make sure I only give
that printer that IP address.

440
00:22:37.570 --> 00:22:40.960
The other thing is too, is if you're
statically mapping IP addresses,

441
00:22:40.960 --> 00:22:42.250
just map it outside of the range.

442
00:22:42.250 --> 00:22:45.210
So, couple of different things, Dan,
we can see, especially when it comes to IP

443
00:22:45.210 --> 00:22:49.000
conflicts, a lot of times IP conflicts
are just really nothing more than

444
00:22:49.000 --> 00:22:52.380
a misconfiguration of the IP
addresses on the network adapters.

445
00:22:52.380 --> 00:22:55.520
>> All right, well, Wes, I know you got
a few more little tidbits, odds and

446
00:22:55.520 --> 00:22:58.390
ends that we've got to go through when
it comes to network connectivity issues.

447
00:22:58.390 --> 00:23:00.460
But our clock is screaming
that we are out of time.

448
00:23:00.460 --> 00:23:02.580
So we'll just have to
make a short part three.

449
00:23:02.580 --> 00:23:05.340
So join us for that part three,
it'll be a lot of fun.

450
00:23:05.340 --> 00:23:07.540
As for this episode, though,
signing off for ITProTV,

451
00:23:07.540 --> 00:23:09.030
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

452
00:23:09.030 --> 00:23:09.870
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

453
00:23:09.870 --> 00:23:15.126
>> We'll see you next time.

454
00:23:15.126 --> 00:23:17.952
[MUSIC]

455
00:23:17.952 --> 00:23:21.413
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes troubleshoot both wired and wireless networks with appropriate tools. Specific topics covered here include: slow transfer speeds, low RF signal, SSID not found, hardware tools, and command line tools like tracert, netstat, and nslookup.
episodes.title: Common Wired/Wireless Network Issues Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.968 --> 00:00:08.257
Welcome to ITProTV I'm your
host Don Pezet [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:08.257 --> 00:00:11.775
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:11.775 --> 00:00:16.300
>> All right greetings everyone welcome
back to another great episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:16.300 --> 00:00:20.500
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and I hope
you're just as excited as I am because

5
00:00:20.500 --> 00:00:23.450
today we're continuing on
with more in our A+ series.

6
00:00:23.450 --> 00:00:26.690
And joining us back again to b e
as excited as we are, hopefully,

7
00:00:26.690 --> 00:00:28.550
is our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

8
00:00:28.550 --> 00:00:29.730
Wes, how's it going, man?

9
00:00:29.730 --> 00:00:30.720
>> Man, it's going great.

10
00:00:30.720 --> 00:00:34.709
Yeah, this is gonna be another good
episode in our mini-series on network

11
00:00:34.709 --> 00:00:36.240
troubleshooting, right?

12
00:00:36.240 --> 00:00:38.430
We've been talking about wired and
wireless.

13
00:00:38.430 --> 00:00:39.940
And some of the things
that you can encounter and

14
00:00:39.940 --> 00:00:42.730
there are just a handful of things
that we kinda wanna wrap up here.

15
00:00:42.730 --> 00:00:45.390
So this might not be a very
thorough episode, but

16
00:00:45.390 --> 00:00:48.710
it's definitely gonna be full of a lot
of great content regardless, so.

17
00:00:48.710 --> 00:00:49.620
>> It'll be full of something.

18
00:00:49.620 --> 00:00:51.750
>> It's gonna be full something that's for
sure, that's right.

19
00:00:51.750 --> 00:00:55.560
Let's hope it's something that you guys
wanna stick around for, that's right.

20
00:00:55.560 --> 00:00:58.680
So one of the things that
they've also talked about

21
00:00:58.680 --> 00:01:02.500
when it comes to some of the symptoms
you can get inside of wired and

22
00:01:02.500 --> 00:01:05.370
wireless networks, really,
is slow transfer speeds, right?

23
00:01:05.370 --> 00:01:08.410
When we talk about network,
remember, networks are here for

24
00:01:08.410 --> 00:01:11.250
two reasons, communication and
then sharing resources.

25
00:01:11.250 --> 00:01:14.195
And one of the things that we
do from time to time on networks

26
00:01:14.195 --> 00:01:18.920
are share things like files, we transfer
information from one computer to another.

27
00:01:18.920 --> 00:01:21.030
And sometimes those file transfers,

28
00:01:21.030 --> 00:01:24.180
if you will, or transfers in general,
slow transfer speeds can happen.

29
00:01:24.180 --> 00:01:26.880
Now there is a few things
that might cause this, right?

30
00:01:26.880 --> 00:01:29.900
The device, let's say, you've got a
network device out there, it's got a hard

31
00:01:29.900 --> 00:01:33.330
drive and that hard drive is starting to
fill up, and we're really full, right?

32
00:01:33.330 --> 00:01:36.060
Well, understand that the operating
system, whether you're

33
00:01:36.060 --> 00:01:39.940
transferring files or not, is constantly
using your hard drive, right?

34
00:01:39.940 --> 00:01:43.890
We have what are known as page file,
swap files, that we talked about in 902.

35
00:01:43.890 --> 00:01:47.890
That allow us to use portions
of our hard drive as memory and

36
00:01:47.890 --> 00:01:50.640
your operating system is
constantly using that, right?

37
00:01:50.640 --> 00:01:54.250
When you talk about things like sending
information to network-based printers.

38
00:01:54.250 --> 00:01:57.340
If the device is a printer that's
connected to another machine and

39
00:01:57.340 --> 00:02:01.450
that drive is full, you might start to see
some performance issues there as well.

40
00:02:01.450 --> 00:02:04.890
So it could be the fact
that the storage media is,

41
00:02:04.890 --> 00:02:07.370
maybe the storage media is
using old standards too.

42
00:02:07.370 --> 00:02:09.450
That could cause a problem too.

43
00:02:09.450 --> 00:02:12.120
You're cabling could be another thing,
standards, right?

44
00:02:12.120 --> 00:02:16.382
We try to shy away from CAT 3 today just
because of its limited bandwidth, right?

45
00:02:16.382 --> 00:02:20.430
You wanna, really today, you almost
wanna go with nothing less than CAT 5E.

46
00:02:20.430 --> 00:02:23.660
I know a lot of people say, well,
If I'm gonna install new cabling,

47
00:02:23.660 --> 00:02:26.980
I'm pretty much gonna go with CAT 6 or
above, and it does get expensive.

48
00:02:26.980 --> 00:02:31.640
But it could be a standards, the standard
could be causing the problem too.

49
00:02:31.640 --> 00:02:36.480
You could have limited bandwidth,
you could have a lot of devices.

50
00:02:36.480 --> 00:02:39.370
As well,
going along with that mindset is that you

51
00:02:39.370 --> 00:02:43.480
have a lot of high definition video that's
traveling your networks, and guess what?

52
00:02:43.480 --> 00:02:44.710
You need some bandwidth, right?

53
00:02:44.710 --> 00:02:48.310
That takes a lot of that
theoretical pipeline, if you will,

54
00:02:48.310 --> 00:02:50.050
to send information through it.

55
00:02:50.050 --> 00:02:53.710
And if you have a lot of devices that are
on your network all doing that at the same

56
00:02:53.710 --> 00:02:56.185
time, then you'll have
bandwidth contention, right?

57
00:02:56.185 --> 00:02:58.530
Cuz keep in mind,
when you're talking about on the network,

58
00:02:58.530 --> 00:03:00.440
it is shared bandwidth.

59
00:03:00.440 --> 00:03:04.570
And too many devices, again,
can cause a little bit of contention.

60
00:03:05.920 --> 00:03:08.930
The other thing that you could have, too,
and this is not quite as common, but

61
00:03:08.930 --> 00:03:11.650
could happen, is duplex mismatches, right?

62
00:03:11.650 --> 00:03:15.660
We have a few different types of
duplexing technologies, right?

63
00:03:15.660 --> 00:03:19.280
Duplexing is, can I send and
receive information at the same time?

64
00:03:19.280 --> 00:03:22.300
Well, if I can send and
receive information at the same time,

65
00:03:22.300 --> 00:03:23.830
that's called full duplex.

66
00:03:23.830 --> 00:03:27.310
And that's what most of your modern
networks for a long time have been,

67
00:03:27.310 --> 00:03:27.940
full duplex.

68
00:03:27.940 --> 00:03:30.620
I can send information
to Dan's computer as

69
00:03:30.620 --> 00:03:34.620
well as Dan can send information to my
computer, we can do that simultaneously.

70
00:03:34.620 --> 00:03:36.950
In the earlier days when we
were using things like hubs,

71
00:03:36.950 --> 00:03:39.140
this is another one of the reasons
you don't want hubs for

72
00:03:39.140 --> 00:03:42.240
networking devices is that
they were half duplex, right?

73
00:03:42.240 --> 00:03:45.230
Think about what we said in
their characteristics of TCP/IP

74
00:03:45.230 --> 00:03:46.270
when it comes to hubs, right?

75
00:03:46.270 --> 00:03:51.810
A hub when you send communications into
it, it basically broadcasts at all ports.

76
00:03:51.810 --> 00:03:53.700
Which means that if I'm
communicating with the hub,

77
00:03:53.700 --> 00:03:56.550
Dan's computer has to wait until I'm
done talking in order to communicate.

78
00:03:56.550 --> 00:04:01.320
That's a half duplex communication,
and it causes slow transfer speed.

79
00:04:01.320 --> 00:04:04.910
However, we usually don't have
that problem today, again,

80
00:04:04.910 --> 00:04:08.810
because the majority of the time
we are configured for full duplex.

81
00:04:08.810 --> 00:04:12.640
And a lot of times it's auto negotiated,
which means when my computer connects to

82
00:04:12.640 --> 00:04:16.810
the network, it talks to the connectivity
device and says, what are you running?

83
00:04:16.810 --> 00:04:19.920
Well, I'm running a gigabyte speed,
I'm running it full duplex and

84
00:04:19.920 --> 00:04:24.180
I'll go ahead and configure that adapter,
the operating system for you.

85
00:04:24.180 --> 00:04:27.290
Proximity of its wireless,
it could be proximity of the access point.

86
00:04:27.290 --> 00:04:30.090
Again, the farther away you get
from the range of the access point,

87
00:04:30.090 --> 00:04:31.680
the slower the performance could be.

88
00:04:31.680 --> 00:04:36.790
It could also be things like obstacles in
the way, wireless communication, while not

89
00:04:36.790 --> 00:04:41.544
really needing to be a completely
direct line of sight with Wi-Fi,

90
00:04:41.544 --> 00:04:44.800
it doesn't do too well when we talk
about walls in the way, right?

91
00:04:44.800 --> 00:04:46.320
That could affect performance too.

92
00:04:46.320 --> 00:04:49.800
It could be things like
electromagnetic interference.

93
00:04:49.800 --> 00:04:52.240
Radio frequency interference
could cause problems, right?

94
00:04:52.240 --> 00:04:56.190
And really when you talk about
electromagnetic interference,

95
00:04:56.190 --> 00:04:59.330
we're talking about effects
with wired cabling too, right?

96
00:04:59.330 --> 00:05:00.290
And what do I mean by that?

97
00:05:00.290 --> 00:05:05.760
Well, it's really easy to get a little bit
lazy when it comes to wiring your network.

98
00:05:05.760 --> 00:05:09.292
And because you already got an electrical
outlet, well, you know that that cable,

99
00:05:09.292 --> 00:05:11.345
that conduit,
it's running through the wall.

100
00:05:11.345 --> 00:05:12.761
So, let's just go ahead and

101
00:05:12.761 --> 00:05:16.725
let's put our Ethernet cable right
next to the electrical conduit.

102
00:05:16.725 --> 00:05:19.535
Well, that can cause electromagnetic
interference, right?

103
00:05:19.535 --> 00:05:23.445
That crosstalk, that bleed over
the electromagnetic energy from

104
00:05:23.445 --> 00:05:26.605
the AC source into your
network communications.

105
00:05:26.605 --> 00:05:29.335
The other thing that cause that as well
is if you're running things, like for

106
00:05:29.335 --> 00:05:31.655
instance, maybe you got some
high intensity discharge lamps.

107
00:05:31.655 --> 00:05:36.150
You've got the fluorescent bulb inside
your home, you've got a drop ceiling if

108
00:05:36.150 --> 00:05:38.060
you're in a business,
you've got all fluorescent lamps.

109
00:05:38.060 --> 00:05:44.240
Fluorescent light give off an extremely
high amount of electromagnetic energy and

110
00:05:44.240 --> 00:05:46.590
they also can affect data transmission.

111
00:05:46.590 --> 00:05:49.540
So keep in mind that could
slow things down too.

112
00:05:49.540 --> 00:05:53.460
And then notice I saved this one for last
because I think, Dan, you mentioned this

113
00:05:53.460 --> 00:05:57.500
in an earlier episode, we always want
to call this one out first, right?

114
00:05:57.500 --> 00:05:59.740
Malware, but we can over look it, right?

115
00:05:59.740 --> 00:06:01.190
Slow transfer speeds could be malware.

116
00:06:01.190 --> 00:06:04.360
You could have some kind of worm on your
network that's replicating itself across

117
00:06:04.360 --> 00:06:07.800
all of the different devices within your
network, consuming your resources, and

118
00:06:07.800 --> 00:06:09.690
really slowing things down and
causing havoc, right?

119
00:06:09.690 --> 00:06:10.870
>> Yeah, it's never a fun time.

120
00:06:10.870 --> 00:06:15.760
I've had many of help desk call
where someone says, my computer is

121
00:06:15.760 --> 00:06:18.340
running slowly, I'm like, well,
is it your computer that's running slowly?

122
00:06:18.340 --> 00:06:20.234
Is it your network connectivity
that's running slowly?

123
00:06:20.234 --> 00:06:23.876
And you come to find out that usually
it's both if it comes to malware,

124
00:06:23.876 --> 00:06:25.729
cuz it is just hogging resources and

125
00:06:25.729 --> 00:06:29.273
slamming your network home because
it's phoning home somewhere.

126
00:06:29.273 --> 00:06:30.162
>> Yeah, definitely.

127
00:06:30.162 --> 00:06:31.752
And that's what it seeks to do, right?

128
00:06:31.752 --> 00:06:34.243
Consume anything it can and
everything it can, and it will.

129
00:06:34.243 --> 00:06:34.932
>> It's the devil.

130
00:06:34.932 --> 00:06:36.280
>> [LAUGH] It really is.

131
00:06:36.280 --> 00:06:38.010
And, we've gotta watch them, right?

132
00:06:38.010 --> 00:06:42.172
Because as you'll learn when we talk about
security, a worm is a self-replicating,

133
00:06:42.172 --> 00:06:45.944
self-generated type piece of code
that's self-sufficient, if you will.

134
00:06:45.944 --> 00:06:48.671
It just needs a port of entry,
it doesn't need a host like a virus does.

135
