00:18:04.190 --> 00:18:10.140
And netstat here is network statistics,
and if I type a netstat -a,

362
00:18:10.140 --> 00:18:14.350
it'll actually show me all
of the states of TCP and

363
00:18:14.350 --> 00:18:17.550
UDP connections that I have
currently on this computer.

364
00:18:17.550 --> 00:18:21.700
Now, I do want you to understand
that UDP isnt going to see you,

365
00:18:21.700 --> 00:18:26.100
your not going to see any information
in UDP because UDP is stateless, right?

366
00:18:26.100 --> 00:18:29.481
It isnt a connection orientated service
but some of the things that I can see

367
00:18:29.481 --> 00:18:31.963
are those established
connections that we have here.

368
00:18:31.963 --> 00:18:35.473
And I can see some of them right there
going back who knows this is probably some

369
00:18:35.473 --> 00:18:38.230
type of web crawler in the background for
all we know.

370
00:18:38.230 --> 00:18:41.160
But I can see those
established connections.

371
00:18:41.160 --> 00:18:47.340
That is one of the tools that you have
inside of your Windows operating system.

372
00:18:47.340 --> 00:18:49.710
All right, couple more that
we wanna kinda talk about.

373
00:18:49.710 --> 00:18:52.300
There's another one that's more for
a legacy service today,

374
00:18:52.300 --> 00:18:54.810
than it is for a more modern service.

375
00:18:54.810 --> 00:18:57.580
And that's something called nbtstat.

376
00:18:57.580 --> 00:19:02.510
That is short for, I love this one, it's
easier to remember the shortened version.

377
00:19:02.510 --> 00:19:05.340
That's nbtstat.

378
00:19:05.340 --> 00:19:08.640
And when we needed to find out
information about NetBIOS names and

379
00:19:08.640 --> 00:19:10.940
the resolution of
the services are provided.

380
00:19:10.940 --> 00:19:15.370
We could use this type of command, right?

381
00:19:15.370 --> 00:19:18.560
You probably see there's not
a lot of information here.

382
00:19:18.560 --> 00:19:22.990
I don't know that this is going
to be too specific for us.

383
00:19:22.990 --> 00:19:27.220
In fact, let me go ahead and do a -a here.

384
00:19:27.220 --> 00:19:30.960
All right, And did I not do that right?

385
00:19:30.960 --> 00:19:34.780
Looks like we've got nbtstat -a,
and maybe,

386
00:19:34.780 --> 00:19:38.320
I don't know, maybe I put a space
in there when I shouldn't have.

387
00:19:38.320 --> 00:19:42.056
nbtstat -a.

388
00:19:42.056 --> 00:19:43.510
We will get this right eventually.

389
00:19:45.000 --> 00:19:48.780
Doesn't look like I have, it's giving
me a hard time for some reason,

390
00:19:48.780 --> 00:19:50.730
but I don't see.

391
00:19:50.730 --> 00:19:52.674
I know one of them.
>> We gotta figure out the IP address or

392
00:19:52.674 --> 00:19:53.530
remote-
>> Yeah,

393
00:19:53.530 --> 00:19:55.050
well there's another one
I'm gonna go ahead and run.

394
00:19:55.050 --> 00:19:57.152
I'm gonna run -r here.

395
00:19:57.152 --> 00:20:01.189
And -r usually will give you
some kind of information.

396
00:20:01.189 --> 00:20:05.210
It looks like my computer is
running a little bit slow here.

397
00:20:05.210 --> 00:20:09.870
Gotta love that, and I tell you what,
I almost know, bet you I know what it is,

398
00:20:09.870 --> 00:20:12.020
Windows is probably running
an update in the background and

399
00:20:12.020 --> 00:20:13.430
it loves to do that on you.

400
00:20:13.430 --> 00:20:16.610
But there is one other one that
I'm gonna run, nbtstats, and

401
00:20:16.610 --> 00:20:21.240
that is the -r, and
that gives you a little bit more output.

402
00:20:21.240 --> 00:20:24.898
It could be the fact that I don't have
any remote names in that list, so

403
00:20:24.898 --> 00:20:27.196
it's saying there's nothing to show you.

404
00:20:27.196 --> 00:20:30.529
I think one of the main things
other than remembering that

405
00:20:30.529 --> 00:20:32.967
this is specific to NetBIOS space names.

406
00:20:32.967 --> 00:20:38.140
If you see, and you've seen it quite
a few times cuz I couldn't type, right?

407
00:20:38.140 --> 00:20:42.070
The fact that I'll go ahead and
run this and let it show me the output.

408
00:20:42.070 --> 00:20:45.900
Like coulda just run a forward slash
question mark, but it will do the same.

409
00:20:45.900 --> 00:20:49.910
I think the big one Dan on this one
I want you to remember is in Windows,

410
00:20:49.910 --> 00:20:51.820
most things aren't case sensitive.

411
00:20:51.820 --> 00:20:55.700
In Nick's base system Lenox you
better get used to case sensitivity.

412
00:20:55.700 --> 00:20:57.390
It is very important.

413
00:20:57.390 --> 00:21:01.650
In Windows it isn't,
except for this command.

414
00:21:01.650 --> 00:21:05.160
Notice there's a big difference in here,
we've got a little a, lowercase a,

415
00:21:05.160 --> 00:21:07.030
we've got uppercase a.

416
00:21:07.030 --> 00:21:10.260
We've got a lowercase r which shows
me the list that I just pulled up,

417
00:21:10.260 --> 00:21:14.765
versus the uppercase r says, just go ahead
and purge that list big difference, right?

418
00:21:14.765 --> 00:21:18.545
So definitely no nbtstat
that is one that you can do.

419
00:21:18.545 --> 00:21:21.315
There's other commands out there like NET,
and I'm going to go ahead and

420
00:21:21.315 --> 00:21:24.445
run this by itself so
we can see some of the options you can do.

421
00:21:24.445 --> 00:21:30.160
We use NET like for instance NET in
combination with net use to map.

422
00:21:30.160 --> 00:21:31.360
Network drives so

423
00:21:31.360 --> 00:21:35.620
that I can connect to the shared
resources out there on our networks.

424
00:21:35.620 --> 00:21:39.999
You also have another one that's,
it's still there, netdom.

425
00:21:39.999 --> 00:21:40.591
And you know what?

426
00:21:40.591 --> 00:21:42.180
It looks like it's
actually been taken out.

427
00:21:43.225 --> 00:21:46.095
Netdom is a way, and
we can also do this with a NET command,

428
00:21:46.095 --> 00:21:49.715
netdom was a way that you could
join a Windows domain, right.

429
00:21:49.715 --> 00:21:53.915
It's in the list, again we're using
things like power shell and stuff today.

430
00:21:53.915 --> 00:21:56.965
So I do want you to be
aware that it is there.

431
00:21:56.965 --> 00:22:00.125
Know the other ones that
we've also talked about too.

432
00:22:00.125 --> 00:22:03.810
Again ping, ipconfig, ifconfig, tracert,

433
00:22:03.810 --> 00:22:09.560
nbtstat, netstat as well as netdom.

434
00:22:09.560 --> 00:22:12.230
Last one I wanna talk about when it comes

435
00:22:12.230 --> 00:22:16.580
to the software based utilities
is something known as nslookup.

436
00:22:16.580 --> 00:22:22.740
Nslookup allows you the ability to see
if your computer can do name resolution,

437
00:22:22.740 --> 00:22:24.930
remember what DNS is doing for us.

438
00:22:24.930 --> 00:22:28.900
DNS has taken a fully qualified domain
name and mapping it to an IP address.

439
00:22:28.900 --> 00:22:33.150
So if I need to figure out can
my computer do name resolution.

440
00:22:33.150 --> 00:22:34.600
I can type nslookup.

441
00:22:36.190 --> 00:22:39.258
And let's say www.google.com.

442
00:22:39.258 --> 00:22:40.880
Let's see how fast this resolves.

443
00:22:40.880 --> 00:22:44.989
Again, I think it's probably doing some
updates in the back, wasn't too bad.

444
00:22:44.989 --> 00:22:50.417
And I can see that the name www.google.com
resolves to the IPv6 Addresses and

445
00:22:50.417 --> 00:22:51.720
IPv4 Addresses.

446
00:22:51.720 --> 00:22:55.400
If that didn't happen then we
could see we'd check the TCP/IP

447
00:22:55.400 --> 00:23:00.290
properties of the network adapter and
find out if we've got a you know

448
00:23:00.290 --> 00:23:04.090
an IP address that's misconfigured
in manual configuration.

449
00:23:04.090 --> 00:23:07.280
Or maybe I don't have the default
gateway set up right and

450
00:23:07.280 --> 00:23:11.320
it's not passing the DNS information
through to the DNS server.

451
00:23:11.320 --> 00:23:14.060
>> Well, Wes,
we have a bevy of different software

452
00:23:14.060 --> 00:23:16.970
tools at our ready to
>> Be able to troubleshoot some of these

453
00:23:16.970 --> 00:23:19.270
networks to connectivity issues, but

454
00:23:19.270 --> 00:23:22.940
we also have some physical tools as
well that we might have to employ.

455
00:23:22.940 --> 00:23:25.107
>> Yeah,
defiantly they call out a few, right,

456
00:23:25.107 --> 00:23:27.509
because sometimes it's a logical issue,
right?

457
00:23:27.509 --> 00:23:30.777
And sometimes you gotta go Spock on it,
that's a logical capital,

458
00:23:30.777 --> 00:23:32.843
sometimes it's again a physical issue and

459
00:23:32.843 --> 00:23:36.410
thank goodness we got a whole plethora
of them sitting on the table here.

460
00:23:36.410 --> 00:23:40.161
So if we can take a look you can see some
of the kinds that they call out, right?

461
00:23:40.161 --> 00:23:43.952
One of the kinds that they call
out is what's known as a tone.

462
00:23:43.952 --> 00:23:47.580
They call it a tone generator and
a Tone Pro.

463
00:23:47.580 --> 00:23:49.204
Sometimes it just emits a light.

464
00:23:49.204 --> 00:23:52.010
Sometimes it does emit an audible sound.

465
00:23:52.010 --> 00:23:56.934
And what this does is essentially
you can plug this into the cable.

466
00:23:56.934 --> 00:24:02.132
And you can go over to basically
a spaghetti sized bundle of cables and

467
00:24:02.132 --> 00:24:05.190
you can touch the tone locator to it.

468
00:24:05.190 --> 00:24:10.011
And what happens is when it comes in
contact with the electrical current that

469
00:24:10.011 --> 00:24:14.091
the generator is providing,
it emits an audible tone, right?

470
00:24:14.091 --> 00:24:17.290
And that might not make sense when
you have just one or two cables.

471
00:24:17.290 --> 00:24:20.700
But literally out of the wall when
you have 400 of these CAT cables and

472
00:24:20.700 --> 00:24:22.080
it's-
>> Which one's mine?

473
00:24:22.080 --> 00:24:23.640
>> Right, exactly, which one's which?

474
00:24:23.640 --> 00:24:25.510
And it's a 300 pound bundle,

475
00:24:25.510 --> 00:24:28.390
you certainly don't wanna take the time
to go through every single one.

476
00:24:28.390 --> 00:24:31.699
So tone locators, if you will,
they call it a locater and a generator,

477
00:24:31.699 --> 00:24:33.476
it's typically one in the same unit.

478
00:24:33.476 --> 00:24:37.652
And one, it basically generates
an electrical current and

479
00:24:37.652 --> 00:24:39.580
the other one emits a tone.

480
00:24:39.580 --> 00:24:41.040
And when you touch it to the wire and

481
00:24:41.040 --> 00:24:44.140
you find the cable that's got that
electrical current going through it.

482
00:24:44.140 --> 00:24:47.000
A couple of the other things
that we have here on the table,

483
00:24:47.000 --> 00:24:49.240
we've got what's known as a cable crimper.

484
00:24:49.240 --> 00:24:50.736
And there are a couple different kinds,
too, right?

485
00:24:50.736 --> 00:24:54.617
This is one that is an RJ45 and
an RJ11 crimper,

486
00:24:54.617 --> 00:24:58.890
right, the RJ45 being the bigger one for
Ethernet.

487
00:24:58.890 --> 00:25:02.993
Next to it its older, smaller
cousin here is the RJ11, that's for

488
00:25:02.993 --> 00:25:04.845
the traditional phone lines.

489
00:25:04.845 --> 00:25:08.937
And again, what you would do is you wire
the cable according to, in this case,

490
00:25:08.937 --> 00:25:12.417
let's just take a RJ45 for
an example, or the AP8C connector.

491
00:25:12.417 --> 00:25:17.265
You would take and
you would wire it either 568A or 568B.

492
00:25:17.265 --> 00:25:19.360
You'd put it in here and
you'd crimp it down.

493
00:25:19.360 --> 00:25:21.060
Hence the name, right?

494
00:25:21.060 --> 00:25:23.020
The other thing that you have as well is,

495
00:25:23.020 --> 00:25:26.360
you could have something like
a coaxial connector here.

496
00:25:26.360 --> 00:25:28.935
And this is one where if you are using,

497
00:25:28.935 --> 00:25:32.860
like our production team here
has to use this quite a lot.

498
00:25:32.860 --> 00:25:35.210
They run some crazy cables.

499
00:25:35.210 --> 00:25:40.800
I've seen them make cables that actually
come down off of a 24 foot tall building,

500
00:25:40.800 --> 00:25:43.500
off of the roof into the back
of a soundboard, right?

501
00:25:43.500 --> 00:25:45.440
And that would be your coaxial cable.

502
00:25:45.440 --> 00:25:50.070
And you put your BNC connector here, run
the coaxial cable into the background and

503
00:25:50.070 --> 00:25:54.470
then crimp it down and
it essentially attaches the coaxial cable.

504
00:25:54.470 --> 00:25:56.686
Now they call it a couple
of different things.

505
00:25:56.686 --> 00:25:59.600
They call it wire strippers and
there's all different things.

506
00:25:59.600 --> 00:26:03.120
I kinda use these right here
cuz I like how thick they are.

507
00:26:03.120 --> 00:26:05.520
But there's also cable strippers, too.

508
00:26:05.520 --> 00:26:09.610
And this is an example of a cable stripper
that would prepare the coaxial cable.

509
00:26:09.610 --> 00:26:10.630
However, I will say,

510
00:26:10.630 --> 00:26:14.750
guys and gals out there, this one has
a cable stripper right in there, right?

511
00:26:14.750 --> 00:26:16.000
You can almost kind of see it.

512
00:26:16.000 --> 00:26:19.220
In fact, you're gonna see here,
if we can zoom down in,

513
00:26:19.220 --> 00:26:22.360
I actually used this to
kind of show you guys

514
00:26:22.360 --> 00:26:25.930
the cables here that we're going
to run the cable tester on, right?

515
00:26:25.930 --> 00:26:29.430
So another cable tester that
we have here in the studios.

516
00:26:29.430 --> 00:26:33.840
Now this cable is good and
we can tell that by plugging one end in.

517
00:26:33.840 --> 00:26:36.440
This would also work on
a coaxial implementation, too,

518
00:26:36.440 --> 00:26:39.430
if you wanted to test the single
copper conductor that runs through it.

519
00:26:39.430 --> 00:26:43.500
In this case, when I turn this on,
it's gonna send an electrical

520
00:26:43.500 --> 00:26:48.380
signal down the eight individual
conductors in the four twisted pairs.

521
00:26:48.380 --> 00:26:51.350
And it is going to be something that,

522
00:26:51.350 --> 00:26:55.030
it lets me know in this case,
hey, it's good, right?

523
00:26:55.030 --> 00:26:58.820
Reversal can happen and I've actually
done this on quite a few occasions.

524
00:26:58.820 --> 00:27:01.240
I don't know if I should admit
to that here on the show, but

525
00:27:01.240 --> 00:27:02.700
you can ask any one of the hosts.

526
00:27:02.700 --> 00:27:06.420
Sometimes I get too quick
putting that RJ45 jack in.

527
00:27:06.420 --> 00:27:09.070
Maybe I won't put the conductor

528
00:27:09.070 --> 00:27:12.660
right down onto the connector when I
crimp it down and it'll let you know.

529
00:27:12.660 --> 00:27:16.040
But sometimes you reverse it, sometimes
you can have something like this.

530
00:27:16.040 --> 00:27:18.053
Now, guys and gals out there,

531
00:27:18.053 --> 00:27:23.249
I wouldn't ever suggest doing this if
you've got one of your good connectors.

532
00:27:23.249 --> 00:27:27.210
But let's see here, let's see if I
can cause a break in one of these.

533
00:27:27.210 --> 00:27:29.580
I'm not sure, there we go.

534
00:27:29.580 --> 00:27:35.108
Notice that we've got now a pair that
don't have any lights coming on.

535
00:27:35.108 --> 00:27:35.928
>> Two pairs.

536
00:27:35.928 --> 00:27:36.456
>> Two pairs, that's right.

537
00:27:36.456 --> 00:27:40.110
We've got two pairs, so I did a pretty
good job on breaking that one, right?

538
00:27:40.110 --> 00:27:44.670
And it's letting me know now
that we don't have connectivity.

539
00:27:44.670 --> 00:27:48.560
And this also goes, I wanna go ahead and
now shout out to Jim out there in

540
00:27:48.560 --> 00:27:53.110
the chat room, he says you gotta be very,
very careful in not nicking these wires.

541
00:27:53.110 --> 00:27:58.680
Because even the slightest little
cut in the shielding itself,

542
00:27:58.680 --> 00:28:01.400
can cause an electromagnetic interference.

543
00:28:01.400 --> 00:28:05.740
And especially when you're
talking like CAT 6 and above,

544
00:28:05.740 --> 00:28:10.830
CAT 6A, and when you're going for things
like gigabit speeds, there's almost zero

545
00:28:13.470 --> 00:28:20.080
tolerance for any kind of nick in
the sheathing, let alone as drastic

546
00:28:20.080 --> 00:28:25.420
as I've done here where I've actually
cut one of the cables in the bunch.

547
00:28:25.420 --> 00:28:29.370
If we could zoom in just a little bit
farther, you guys can kind of see this.

548
00:28:29.370 --> 00:28:33.850
It lets me know what I should
be looking for when it comes to

549
00:28:34.890 --> 00:28:39.760
the actual 568A and 568B.

550
00:28:39.760 --> 00:28:41.930
It lets me know how the wiring should go.

551
00:28:41.930 --> 00:28:45.500
So if you ever needed
kind of like a guide for

552
00:28:45.500 --> 00:28:48.000
the standard,
you could always Google this, too.

553
00:28:48.000 --> 00:28:51.140
But this is kinda nice,
because it tells you what pins one and

554
00:28:51.140 --> 00:28:52.670
pins three should be.

555
00:28:52.670 --> 00:28:55.890
Right, versus pair four, pair five.

556
00:28:55.890 --> 00:29:00.580
Down here you can see what the blue pair
and the brown pair, a lot of times that's

557
00:29:00.580 --> 00:29:05.172
your ground versus your transmit and
your recipient or receive pin.

558
00:29:05.172 --> 00:29:07.260
So a couple of the different connectors,
and

559
00:29:07.260 --> 00:29:12.830
again you can see here it supports things,
like for instance your RJ45 jack, as

560
00:29:12.830 --> 00:29:17.940
well as if you're doing some kind of B and
C work as well in audio communications.

561
00:29:17.940 --> 00:29:22.590
All right, Dan, I know that we have run
the gamut when it comes to a lot of

562
00:29:22.590 --> 00:29:23.910
the different things that you can see.

563
00:29:23.910 --> 00:29:26.990
Hopefully we've shown you a good bit of
symptoms and some of the things that you

564
00:29:26.990 --> 00:29:32.290
could do to remediate, well, identify and
remediate those symptoms, as well

565
00:29:32.290 --> 00:29:36.350
as some of the logical and software-based
tools that you need to know on the exam.

566
00:29:36.350 --> 00:29:40.440
As well as some of the physical tools
that you have out there when it

567
00:29:40.440 --> 00:29:44.630
comes to maintaining those networks and
keeping them running like they should.

568
00:29:44.630 --> 00:29:48.030
>> All right, Wes, well, we do appreciate
you running us through these tools and

569
00:29:48.030 --> 00:29:51.860
symptoms that we might encounter when
network connectivity is the issue.

570
00:29:51.860 --> 00:29:54.150
That being said, looks like we're
out of time for this episode.

571
00:29:54.150 --> 00:29:55.610
We do thank you guys for watching.

572
00:29:55.610 --> 00:29:57.500
Hopefully you've enjoyed it and
learned a lot.

573
00:29:57.500 --> 00:30:00.210
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

574
00:30:00.210 --> 00:30:00.980
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

575
00:30:00.980 --> 00:30:02.016
>> And we'll see you next time.

576
00:30:02.016 --> 00:30:09.091
[MUSIC]

577
00:30:09.091 --> 00:30:16.294
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore troubleshooting and repairing common mobile device issues while adhering to appropriate procedures. Specific topics covered here includes: Field Serviceable vs. Non-Field Serviceable, display issues, sticking keys, battery not charging/power issues, ghost cursor/pointer drift, and intermittent/no wireless connectivity.
episodes.title: Common Mobile Device Issues

WEBVTT

1

2

00:22:11.560 --> 00:22:16.430
it's causing problems, you might need to
clean the screen with a lint free cloth.

451
00:22:16.430 --> 00:22:19.580
Now, I know most of us around here
pretty much have some kind of

452
00:22:19.580 --> 00:22:22.020
case around our phones right?

453
00:22:22.020 --> 00:22:25.625
I go to the extreme because
I am known to break things,

454
00:22:25.625 --> 00:22:28.200
[LAUGH] everybody else
knows that around here.

455
00:22:28.200 --> 00:22:32.748
So I've got a pretty heavy hand when
it comes to pretty much everything,

456
00:22:32.748 --> 00:22:33.720
[LAUGH] some things around here.

457
00:22:33.720 --> 00:22:37.510
So I go with an OtterBox case and
the OtterBox case that I have actually has

458
00:22:37.510 --> 00:22:41.620
the whole plastic sleeving
encases the phone.

459
00:22:41.620 --> 00:22:46.500
Well, here's the thing, when I put that
phone in my pocket and I leave it there

460
00:22:46.500 --> 00:22:51.210
and here in Florida we're not lax for
sun or hot temperatures out there.

461
00:22:51.210 --> 00:22:55.410
I start to sweat, and I get a little
bit of water in between the screen and

462
00:22:55.410 --> 00:22:58.870
the touch screen, and
the pointer drifts all over the place.

463
00:22:58.870 --> 00:23:02.130
Well, it's not really a pointer,
but it doesn't interact well,

464
00:23:02.130 --> 00:23:04.930
I start getting things that
are turning on and closing down.

465
00:23:04.930 --> 00:23:08.880
So might need to take the case off and you
might have to clean the screen as well.

466
00:23:08.880 --> 00:23:12.260
If you're one of these ones that,
like Dan and some of the other people,

467
00:23:12.260 --> 00:23:15.520
who have actually the protective
cover that's placed over and

468
00:23:15.520 --> 00:23:19.500
attaches, like it has
an adhesive to the screen.

469
00:23:19.500 --> 00:23:23.236
If you get any debris or bubbles in
between there that can cause problems and

470
00:23:23.236 --> 00:23:25.880
it can cause problems with
the interaction of the device itself.

471
00:23:26.920 --> 00:23:32.513
All right, so the other thing that they
talk about too is your numerical lock,

472
00:23:32.513 --> 00:23:37.285
numlock they call it, numeric lock,
numlock indicator lights.

473
00:23:37.285 --> 00:23:40.615
If you happen to see that those are turned
on, a lot of times that's a keyboard

474
00:23:40.615 --> 00:23:43.599
shortcut with a function key on
a laptop that you've maybe pressed.

475
00:23:43.599 --> 00:23:46.383
And now you're getting some
kinda alternate output,

476
00:23:46.383 --> 00:23:48.330
just check the function key, right?

477
00:23:48.330 --> 00:23:52.319
If it's something that you always have
to press a keyboard shortcut to happen,

478
00:23:52.319 --> 00:23:54.759
maybe you're pressing two
keys at one time, and

479
00:23:54.759 --> 00:23:57.155
again you're getting
that alternate output.

480
00:23:57.155 --> 00:24:01.055
If it's a light that is continuously on,
again, you might just have to

481
00:24:01.055 --> 00:24:05.418
press a keyboard shortcut to turn it off
to make sure that that doesn't happen.

482
00:24:05.418 --> 00:24:10.404
All right, now the next series
of things that we have are for

483
00:24:10.404 --> 00:24:14.417
instance some networking issues,
all right?

484
00:24:14.417 --> 00:24:16.880
And there are tons of networking issues.

485
00:24:16.880 --> 00:24:20.010
So keep in mind, we talked about
network troubleshooting here.

486
00:24:20.010 --> 00:24:23.010
So I'm gonna kinda brief over
some of these and go back and

487
00:24:23.010 --> 00:24:26.740
look at our networking section if you need
a little bit more information on them.

488
00:24:27.870 --> 00:24:28.780
Comes to mobile devices.

489
00:24:28.780 --> 00:24:30.780
They talk about intermittent wireless,
right?

490
00:24:30.780 --> 00:24:32.240
We talk about intermittent wireless,

491
00:24:32.240 --> 00:24:35.560
the first thing you need to check
is proximity to your access point.

492
00:24:35.560 --> 00:24:38.920
Because guess what,
if you're too far from your access point,

493
00:24:38.920 --> 00:24:41.250
you might start losing signal, right?

494
00:24:41.250 --> 00:24:46.249
You might get that intermittent signal
as you basically go out of the reach

495
00:24:46.249 --> 00:24:48.193
of the access point itself.

496
00:24:48.193 --> 00:24:50.605
It could be wireless antenna damage,
right?

497
00:24:50.605 --> 00:24:54.032
If you've dropped any device, you could
have a wireless antenna in there that has

498
00:24:54.032 --> 00:24:56.530
actually been damaged or
the card itself has been damaged.

499
00:24:56.530 --> 00:25:00.510
A lot of times in mobile devices that we
have here outside of a laptop environment

500
00:25:00.510 --> 00:25:03.690
even with the laptops,
you can't replace the wireless card.

501
00:25:03.690 --> 00:25:07.030
You'll see in our laptop section
that Dan and I did, that we did have

502
00:25:07.030 --> 00:25:10.550
a removable wireless card with
an antenna that went around the display.

503
00:25:10.550 --> 00:25:11.942
So that could be changed out.

504
00:25:11.942 --> 00:25:16.060
It could be repaired or
just completely replaced.

505
00:25:16.060 --> 00:25:20.080
However within some of your mobile
devices, you don't have that ability.

506
00:25:20.080 --> 00:25:21.740
It could be obstacles.

507
00:25:21.740 --> 00:25:26.199
Obstacles are in the way between you and
whatever the access point is, the signal.

508
00:25:26.199 --> 00:25:28.800
It could be radio frequency interference,
right?

509
00:25:28.800 --> 00:25:32.962
Microwaves, other cordless phones,
cellphones if you will, high

510
00:25:32.962 --> 00:25:37.930
intensity discharge lamps, if your access
point happens to be near one of those.

511
00:25:37.930 --> 00:25:41.900
So you might need to think about your AP,
your access point placement.

512
00:25:41.900 --> 00:25:45.280
Reposition the access point or
the antenna placement.

513
00:25:45.280 --> 00:25:47.326
I don't know Dan if you've
had to do this before, but

514
00:25:47.326 --> 00:25:49.891
I've got dipole antennas on the back
of an ASUS router that I have.

515
00:25:49.891 --> 00:25:52.458
And the connection points get loose, and

516
00:25:52.458 --> 00:25:56.283
I come in and all the antennas
are pointing down to the ground.

517
00:25:56.283 --> 00:25:58.550
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
definitely will happen from time to time.

518
00:25:58.550 --> 00:26:00.970
Just not getting quite the coverage
that you expect at that point.

519
00:26:00.970 --> 00:26:03.266
>> It's like wow,
I can't tell why I'm not getting coverage.

520
00:26:03.266 --> 00:26:05.671
Well, that's because it's
pointing behind the dresser.

521
00:26:05.671 --> 00:26:09.385
[LAUGH] All right, so,
again that something that can happen too.

522
00:26:09.385 --> 00:26:12.273
So some of the solution is that I
move closer to the access point.

523
00:26:12.273 --> 00:26:15.065
You say well, I am as close to
the access point as I can get.

524
00:26:15.065 --> 00:26:16.360
Well here's another
thing that you can get.

525
00:26:16.360 --> 00:26:19.308
It's relatively easy today to install
a wireless range extender, right?

526
00:26:19.308 --> 00:26:22.320
Then get them where you can just
plug them right into a wall outlet.

527
00:26:22.320 --> 00:26:26.000
You push a button on them and it looks for
another wireless access point and

528
00:26:26.000 --> 00:26:27.090
it seamlessly connects.

529
00:26:27.090 --> 00:26:29.975
And it makes it a lot easier,
it can extend the coverage area.

530
00:26:29.975 --> 00:26:34.122
Could start to alleviate some of
the intermittent wireless access.

531
00:26:34.122 --> 00:26:37.349
You say, well, wait a second,
I wouldn't know where in my building, or

532
00:26:37.349 --> 00:26:38.610
where in my home to put that.

533
00:26:38.610 --> 00:26:39.330
Well, that's great.

534
00:26:39.330 --> 00:26:42.921
Pull out your mobile phone, and
find applications like Wi-Fi Analyzer,

535
00:26:42.921 --> 00:26:45.657
that allow you to look at what
the signal strength is, and

536
00:26:45.657 --> 00:26:48.230
take that on your device and
walk through your house.

537
00:26:48.230 --> 00:26:51.758
And if the decibels start to decrease,
well guess what?

538
00:26:51.758 --> 00:26:53.380
That's the gain,
that's the signal strength,

539
00:26:53.380 --> 00:26:56.335
that's the area you're gonna have to
place the wireless range extender.

540
00:26:56.335 --> 00:26:58.650
So a lot of great things
that they make it easy for

541
00:26:58.650 --> 00:27:03.980
us to overcome some of these issues today,
where in

542
00:27:03.980 --> 00:27:08.590
past experience it would be very expensive
and sometimes very technical to do.

543
00:27:08.590 --> 00:27:09.790
Today they've got almost.

544
00:27:09.790 --> 00:27:12.530
And I wanna say plug and
play because we got a technology

545
00:27:12.530 --> 00:27:15.800
that is specifically plug and
play, but it's very close, right?

546
00:27:15.800 --> 00:27:16.820
Plug and enjoy if you will.

547
00:27:16.820 --> 00:27:18.178
Well, we'll make up our own terms here.

548
00:27:18.178 --> 00:27:21.205
So remove obstacles if you can.

549
00:27:21.205 --> 00:27:23.495
Is not necessarily that
you can just sit there and

550
00:27:23.495 --> 00:27:27.965
take out a load bearing wall because
you're not getting wireless access.

551
00:27:27.965 --> 00:27:29.105
But it might be something.

552
00:27:29.105 --> 00:27:31.405
Again, if it's a radio
frequency interference,

553
00:27:31.405 --> 00:27:35.847
that might be something that's suspected,
just move the access point if you can.

554
00:27:35.847 --> 00:27:38.329
All right, no wireless connectivity.

555
00:27:38.329 --> 00:27:43.340
All our basic wireless are troubleshooting
things that go on, right?

556
00:27:43.340 --> 00:27:47.580
It could be the wireless adapter itself is
disabled, it could be in airplane mode.

557
00:27:47.580 --> 00:27:51.680
You could have security settings that are
a mismatch, right, encryption mismatch.

558
00:27:51.680 --> 00:27:54.928
It could be the fact that maybe
your company or your house,

559
00:27:54.928 --> 00:27:58.791
you've got enabled things like MAC
filtering and your not allowed.

560
00:27:58.791 --> 00:28:02.434
It's like a blacklist, which means if
your on this list you can't connect.

561
00:28:02.434 --> 00:28:05.004
Or your doing white listing
which gets difficult as well,

562
00:28:05.004 --> 00:28:07.995
because you're saying anything on
this list with this media access

563
00:28:07.995 --> 00:28:09.994
control address can
connect to the network.

564
00:28:09.994 --> 00:28:13.600
And if your not on this list, sorry,
no reservations at the restaurant for you.

565
00:28:13.600 --> 00:28:15.165
You might have to disable that.

566
00:28:15.165 --> 00:28:18.230
There might be something that somebody got
in there and then like let's go ahead and

567
00:28:18.230 --> 00:28:18.890
make it secure.

568
00:28:18.890 --> 00:28:22.286
Remember, as you guys go along on
your training here at CompTIA,

569
00:28:22.286 --> 00:28:25.435
whether it's A plus, net plus,
security plus and beyond,

570
00:28:25.435 --> 00:28:27.564
we always talk about security, right?

571
00:28:27.564 --> 00:28:29.570
Yeah, I want the securest
network possible.

572
00:28:29.570 --> 00:28:33.160
Well, it's gonna be probably the most
inconvenient network as well too.

573
00:28:33.160 --> 00:28:35.540
So there's always a fine balance there.

574
00:28:35.540 --> 00:28:37.920
Hidden SSID,
remember the Service Set Identifier.

575
00:28:37.920 --> 00:28:40.910
If for security purposes you
disable the broadcasting of your

576
00:28:40.910 --> 00:28:43.430
Service Set Identifier,
a lot of times what you're doing is only

577
00:28:43.430 --> 00:28:45.930
keeping the legitimate
people out of your network.

578
00:28:45.930 --> 00:28:48.492
A lot of times you're doing
very little to stop a hacker.

579
00:28:48.492 --> 00:28:51.609
All right, and that means you'll
have to know what the SSID is,

580
00:28:51.609 --> 00:28:55.191
know that the access point is turned
on and manually configure it inside of

581
00:28:55.191 --> 00:28:58.230
the wireless adapter in whatever
device it is that connects.

582
00:28:58.230 --> 00:29:00.054
It doesn't matter if it's a laptop,

583
00:29:00.054 --> 00:29:04.500
doesn't matter if it's a work station that
has a wireless adapter installed in it.

584
00:29:04.500 --> 00:29:06.575
Standard mismatches, right?

585
00:29:06.575 --> 00:29:08.299
802.11, no wireless communications.

586
00:29:08.299 --> 00:29:11.918
Keep in mind that when we talk
about wireless communications,

587
00:29:11.918 --> 00:29:17.820
if you got an 802.11N network, right, you
could support all the protocols, right?

588
00:29:17.820 --> 00:29:22.410
But if you have an AC network,
you can support N and that's it, right?

589
00:29:22.410 --> 00:29:24.470
Unless it's got a dual band radio,
but that's for another day.

590
00:29:24.470 --> 00:29:27.510
So, that's some of
the things that can do it.

591
00:29:27.510 --> 00:29:30.020
I already mentioned airplane mode.

592
00:29:30.020 --> 00:29:35.666
Remember to enable the wireless adapter,
reconfigure security settings.

593
00:29:35.666 --> 00:29:38.799
Make sure that you have
standard compatibility,

594
00:29:38.799 --> 00:29:41.570
reposition the access
point if you need to.

595
00:29:41.570 --> 00:29:45.430
And last but not least, go ahead and
turn off airplane mode.

596
00:29:45.430 --> 00:29:48.955
Now Dan, that is a lot of information
when it comes to mobile devices.

597
00:29:48.955 --> 00:29:51.920
But I'm looking at my list buddy, and
I have just scratched the surface.

598
00:29:51.920 --> 00:29:54.140
So, I don't know if we have
enough time in this episode.

599
00:29:54.140 --> 00:29:55.509
>> Well, that's not a problem my man.

600
00:29:55.509 --> 00:29:57.433
We'll just roll into our part two for
you and

601
00:29:57.433 --> 00:29:59.740
our good folks out there
that are watching.

602
00:29:59.740 --> 00:30:01.550
So definitely join us back for that, but

603
00:30:01.550 --> 00:30:03.420
it does look like we are at
the end of this one.

604
00:30:03.420 --> 00:30:04.630
So we're gonna sign off.

605
00:30:04.630 --> 00:30:06.960
For ITPRO.TV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

606
00:30:06.960 --> 00:30:07.950
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

607
00:30:07.950 --> 00:30:09.955
>> We'll see you next time.

608
00:30:09.955 --> 00:30:16.012
[MUSIC]

609
00:30:16.012 --> 00:30:19.899
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore troubleshooting and repairing common mobile device issues while adhering to appropriate procedures. Specific topics covered here includes: Bluetooth connectivity, can't display to external monitor, non-responsive touchscreen, apps not loading, slow performance, can't decrypt email, short battery life, overheating, no sound, gps malfunction, swollen battery, and disassembly/reassembly procedures.
episodes.title: Common Mobile Device Issues Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:01.175
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.175 --> 00:00:02.712
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

3
00:00:02.712 --> 00:00:06.240
[CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:06.240 --> 00:00:08.154
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.154 --> 00:00:12.380
You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.380 --> 00:00:13.955
>> All right, greetings, everyone, and

7
00:00:13.955 --> 00:00:16.098
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.098 --> 00:00:19.447
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie and
in today's episode,

9
00:00:19.447 --> 00:00:22.480
well, we are continuing in our A+ series.

10
00:00:22.480 --> 00:00:23.760
It is that long.

11
00:00:23.760 --> 00:00:25.490
There's a lot of information for
us to cover and

12
00:00:25.490 --> 00:00:28.740
they do that intentionally cuz they
want you to have a very broad scope of

13
00:00:28.740 --> 00:00:31.170
knowledge when it comes to
being an A+ technician.

14
00:00:31.170 --> 00:00:31.820
And guess what?

15
00:00:31.820 --> 00:00:35.890
We've got someone here that's helping lead
that charge, so that we can have that

16
00:00:35.890 --> 00:00:40.160
knowledge imparted into our brains,
it is our good friend, Mr. Wes Bryan.

17
00:00:40.160 --> 00:00:41.850
Wes, we are so glad to have you again.

18
00:00:41.850 --> 00:00:42.370
How's it going, sir?

19
00:00:42.370 --> 00:00:43.260
>> Man, it's going great.

20
00:00:43.260 --> 00:00:45.888
I think it's an Aerosmith song I could
think of going on in the back of my head,

21
00:00:45.888 --> 00:00:47.112
Train Keep Rolling All Night Long.

22
00:00:47.112 --> 00:00:48.000
>> Yeah it does.
[LAUGH]

23
00:00:48.000 --> 00:00:48.984
>> It is rolling for sure.

24
00:00:48.984 --> 00:00:52.347
And that's right,
we are continuing on in mobile devices.

25
00:00:52.347 --> 00:00:55.690
And there is a laundry list of the things
that could potentially come up

26
00:00:55.690 --> 00:00:59.658
when it comes to your different mobile
devices, and really ladies and gentlemen,

27
00:00:59.658 --> 00:01:03.285
it doesn't matter if we're talking
laptops, if we're talking tablets,

28
00:01:03.285 --> 00:01:04.499
fablets, e-readers.

29
00:01:04.499 --> 00:01:09.320
All different things, cell phones,
smart phones if you will.

30
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:12.790
We kind of just rolling them
all into one big pile here

31
00:01:12.790 --> 00:01:14.550
when we talk about mobile devices.

32
00:01:14.550 --> 00:01:17.580
Keep in mind some of the other things that
we talked about in the first part, really

33
00:01:17.580 --> 00:01:22.320
the main thing that I'd like to recap is
that some devices are field serviceable or

34
00:01:22.320 --> 00:01:26.700
components within this devices
I'd say are field serviceable.

35
00:01:26.700 --> 00:01:30.060
Some are not,
some things you just can't replace, and

36
00:01:30.060 --> 00:01:33.120
keep in mind that some things
you can't upgrade either.

37
00:01:34.270 --> 00:01:37.990
For instance, NAND flash memory is
typically built into the motherboards or

38
00:01:37.990 --> 00:01:41.352
the PCBs, the printed circuit boards,
that are in these devices.

39
00:01:41.352 --> 00:01:45.710
When you talk about system on a chip where
everything's built into the circuit board

40
00:01:45.710 --> 00:01:47.530
itself, we can't replace them, right?

41
00:01:47.530 --> 00:01:51.690
If it's external storage and
you have a space, if you will, for

42
00:01:51.690 --> 00:01:55.420
things like your micro SD cards, well
then you could probably expand storage.

43
00:01:55.420 --> 00:02:00.220
So again, some things you can replace,
some things you can upgrade,

44
00:02:00.220 --> 00:02:01.810
other things are not field serviceable,

45
00:02:01.810 --> 00:02:05.440
which means if they become damaged,
you have to replace the device outright.

46
00:02:06.460 --> 00:02:09.990
All right so that being said, let's go
ahead and continue on in our list here,

47
00:02:09.990 --> 00:02:10.610
we left off and

48
00:02:10.610 --> 00:02:13.240
we were talking a little bit about
some of the networking communications.

49
00:02:13.240 --> 00:02:15.399
We talked about troubleshooting,
really wireless.

50
00:02:16.480 --> 00:02:18.680
However, when we were
talking about wireless,

51
00:02:18.680 --> 00:02:22.050
really what we were talking about
was the WiFi side of things.

52
00:02:22.050 --> 00:02:25.515
What we didn't talk about are some of
things that you can see when it comes to

53
00:02:25.515 --> 00:02:30.200
bluetooth, and I wanna mention just
briefly, cellular communications as well.

54
00:02:30.200 --> 00:02:34.590
All right, when it comes to bluetooth,
remember bluetooth is a very short range,

55
00:02:34.590 --> 00:02:38.780
very easy to configure
wireless connection.

56
00:02:38.780 --> 00:02:42.350
Operates in the 2.4 gigahertz spectrum
of the industrial, scientifical and

57
00:02:42.350 --> 00:02:44.270
medical band ISM.

58
00:02:44.270 --> 00:02:45.430
Most of your devices today,

59
00:02:45.430 --> 00:02:48.360
mobile devices,
will support some Bluetooth capabilities.

60
00:02:48.360 --> 00:02:51.160
However, as the Bluetooth has gone on,

61
00:02:51.160 --> 00:02:54.060
it's become less power hungry
than it was in the earlier days.

62
00:02:54.060 --> 00:02:58.780
In fact, if we were teaching this
five years ago or even prior to that,

63
00:02:58.780 --> 00:03:01.630
I would have been telling you, well,
if you're not using Bluetooth,

00:03:01.630 --> 00:03:03.030

00:26:24.850 --> 00:26:27.260
24 of them are in operation 24/7,

513
00:26:27.260 --> 00:26:30.950
with 3 of them on standby in case they
need to repair or service one of them.

514
00:26:30.950 --> 00:26:34.840
So the chances of that happening,
you never say never, but

515
00:26:34.840 --> 00:26:36.320
are really highly unlikely.

516
00:26:36.320 --> 00:26:37.890
So check location services.

517
00:26:37.890 --> 00:26:40.530
If you have that turned off for
any kind of security reason,

518
00:26:40.530 --> 00:26:43.830
that might be the reason your GPS
isn't tracking where you are.

519
00:26:43.830 --> 00:26:48.180
The other thing too,
is you have, what is it?

520
00:26:48.180 --> 00:26:50.730
The gyroscopes,
the accelerometers and stuff.

521
00:26:50.730 --> 00:26:53.070
And I've seen where they
give inaccurate information.

522
00:26:53.070 --> 00:26:55.397
And mine has to do this crazy thing,
where you sit there and

523
00:26:55.397 --> 00:26:57.307
do figure eights until
it can kinda figure out.

524
00:26:57.307 --> 00:27:00.318
And I always think that somebody's looking
at me sitting here doing this with

525
00:27:00.318 --> 00:27:02.160
my phone wondering,
what the heck is going?

526
00:27:02.160 --> 00:27:03.582
But it's the way it calibrates it, so.

527
00:27:03.582 --> 00:27:05.114
[LAUGH]
>> Long night at the club, Wes?

528
00:27:05.114 --> 00:27:06.183
>> [LAUGH] That's right.

529
00:27:06.183 --> 00:27:07.063
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

530
00:27:07.063 --> 00:27:08.271
you might have to calibrate them as well.

531
00:27:08.271 --> 00:27:13.690
So when it says not functioning, it could
be not functioning properly as well.

532
00:27:13.690 --> 00:27:15.330
And even though they don't call that out.

533
00:27:15.330 --> 00:27:18.740
We already mentioned swollen battery here,
guys and gals out there.

534
00:27:18.740 --> 00:27:23.420
Swollen battery basically means it's
time to get rid of that battery.

535
00:27:23.420 --> 00:27:26.852
That battery is two steps from blowing up.

536
00:27:26.852 --> 00:27:30.872
And I don't wanna mention anybody here,
any companies out here, but

537
00:27:30.872 --> 00:27:34.360
we've definitely seen some
problems in the past recently.

538
00:27:34.360 --> 00:27:38.250
With some batteries that have
caused some significant problems.

539
00:27:38.250 --> 00:27:40.530
If the battery in any way is swollen.

540
00:27:40.530 --> 00:27:44.220
If you see the device that is bigger
than what it should be in form factor,

541
00:27:44.220 --> 00:27:48.160
you need to first of all
keep it off of your body.

542
00:27:48.160 --> 00:27:51.260
Keep it in some kind of protected case.

543
00:27:51.260 --> 00:27:53.280
Honestly, I would not keep it in your car,
and

544
00:27:53.280 --> 00:27:56.542
I would take it to a field
technician right away.

545
00:27:56.542 --> 00:27:59.830
And send it back to the manufacturer,
whatever you have to do.

546
00:27:59.830 --> 00:28:03.450
If it's a carrier, and you're on CDMA,
take it to the carrier.

547
00:28:03.450 --> 00:28:06.160
They're gonna have to replace it,
refix it, or some sort.

548
00:28:06.160 --> 00:28:09.350
If it happens to be a SIM,
a GSM based phone or

549
00:28:09.350 --> 00:28:11.720
device, remember,
you can pop the SIM card out.

550
00:28:11.720 --> 00:28:12.930
You can always replace it.

551
00:28:12.930 --> 00:28:15.340
That's a field serviceable item.

552
00:28:15.340 --> 00:28:18.040
If it is something that you can open
up and you can replace the battery,

553
00:28:18.040 --> 00:28:20.530
go to your electronics store and
get a battery replacement.

554
00:28:20.530 --> 00:28:24.750
That isn't something you wanna wait on,
cuz it could be a bad day at the office.

555
00:28:24.750 --> 00:28:27.410
And it could be something that
causes some kind of bodily harm.

556
00:28:27.410 --> 00:28:29.428
And we certainly don't
want that here at ITProTV.

557
00:28:29.428 --> 00:28:32.540
We don't want any device getting hurt,
but we certainly don't want you guys and

558
00:28:32.540 --> 00:28:35.000
gals out there getting hurt, either.

559
00:28:35.000 --> 00:28:37.370
Now, one of the last things
we have to talk, Dan,

560
00:28:37.370 --> 00:28:38.990
I know we're running towards the end here.

561
00:28:38.990 --> 00:28:42.090
Is disassembling process for
proper reassembly.

562
00:28:42.090 --> 00:28:45.280
Maybe some of you guys remember when we
disassembled the laptop that was here.

563
00:28:45.280 --> 00:28:49.730
You could see how we had strategically
placed all the screws in different piles,

564
00:28:49.730 --> 00:28:54.350
and I had done other things
that you guys didn't see.

565
00:28:54.350 --> 00:28:58.340
Taking my cell phone, and taking
pictures of every step of the process.

566
00:28:58.340 --> 00:29:02.608
So that you know where the screw
locations are, you're documenting, and

567
00:29:02.608 --> 00:29:04.430
you're labeling the cables.

568
00:29:04.430 --> 00:29:06.847
And i like the pictures just for regulate.

569
00:29:06.847 --> 00:29:10.218
I don't care if i documented it properly.

570
00:29:10.218 --> 00:29:12.180
A pictures worth a thousand words.

571
00:29:12.180 --> 00:29:13.365
>> Yeah, it's a good reference.

572
00:29:13.365 --> 00:29:15.501
>> Yeah, so
I always use that a minor reference point.

573
00:29:15.501 --> 00:29:19.230
Organize your parts like we've mentioned.

574
00:29:19.230 --> 00:29:22.920
Schematics, we had one gentlemen out there
in the chat room that's talking about

575
00:29:22.920 --> 00:29:23.660
the MacBooks.

576
00:29:23.660 --> 00:29:28.280
And said, if you're gonna be taking
apart a MacBook, schematics, schematics,

577
00:29:28.280 --> 00:29:29.540
schematics, right?

578
00:29:29.540 --> 00:29:31.828
So refer to the manufacturers resources.

579
00:29:31.828 --> 00:29:35.580
And remember to use the appropriate tools,
right?

580
00:29:35.580 --> 00:29:38.500
As much as Dan and I would say,
hey, you know what?

581
00:29:38.500 --> 00:29:40.623
This is a tool [SOUND] for every job?

582
00:29:40.623 --> 00:29:43.060
Not necessarily when you're
working on mobile devices.

583
00:29:43.060 --> 00:29:46.042
Keep in mind, you have things like
iFixit kits, torque screw drivers, and

584
00:29:46.042 --> 00:29:46.753
stuff like that.

585
00:29:46.753 --> 00:29:47.360
>> Blow torches.

586
00:29:47.360 --> 00:29:48.433
>> And blow torches, right.

587
00:29:48.433 --> 00:29:50.615
Acetylene torches, and
in the end a hammer.

588
00:29:50.615 --> 00:29:52.020
>> [LAUGH]
>> No, we're just kidding guys,

589
00:29:52.020 --> 00:29:52.720
gals out there.

590
00:29:52.720 --> 00:29:54.520
Make sure that you're using
the appropriate tools.

591
00:29:54.520 --> 00:29:56.130
There's a lot of tool kits out there.

592
00:29:56.130 --> 00:29:58.670
Remember electrostatic discharge as well.

593
00:29:58.670 --> 00:30:01.290
Work on electrically
resistant mats as well.

594
00:30:01.290 --> 00:30:03.400
So that you don't have to
worry about damaging the parts

595
00:30:03.400 --> 00:30:04.805
that you're trying to replace.

596
00:30:04.805 --> 00:30:05.475
>> All right, Wes.

597
00:30:05.475 --> 00:30:09.945
Well, there's definitely a giant expanse
before us when it comes to mobile devices.

598
00:30:09.945 --> 00:30:11.585
Things that we need to know,
common issues,

599
00:30:11.585 --> 00:30:13.685
and what they might be being caused by.

600
00:30:13.685 --> 00:30:17.235
And then how we can start
to remedy that situation.

601
00:30:17.235 --> 00:30:19.525
And, of course, proper procedure
when we're taking things apart and

602
00:30:19.525 --> 00:30:20.415
putting them back together.

603
00:30:20.415 --> 00:30:21.435
You wanna follow that,

604
00:30:21.435 --> 00:30:24.605
cuz you don't wanna be [LAUGH] left
with a handful of screws and parts and

605
00:30:24.605 --> 00:30:28.105
go, here's your device, and here's
the extra bits I found inside of it.

606
00:30:28.105 --> 00:30:29.060
You're gonna love that, all right?

607
00:30:29.060 --> 00:30:33.220
[LAUGH] So you're gonna get some weird
looks from your customers if you do that.

608
00:30:33.220 --> 00:30:35.730
But Wes, we thank you for
walking us through this, and

609
00:30:35.730 --> 00:30:37.190
we thank you guys for joining us.

610
00:30:37.190 --> 00:30:39.540
But it looks like it is that time for
us to sign off.

611
00:30:39.540 --> 00:30:42.010
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

612
00:30:42.010 --> 00:30:42.910
>> And I'm Wes Bryan.

613
00:30:42.910 --> 00:30:43.820
>> And we'll see you next time.

614
00:30:43.820 --> 00:30:51.390
[MUSIC]

615
00:30:51.390 --> 00:30:54.052
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes take a look at troubleshooting printers with appropriate tools. Here they will cover specific printer symptoms like: streaks, faded prints, toner not fused to paper, creased paper, paper not feeding, paper jams, no connectivity to printer, garbled characters, vertical lines on page, backed up print queue, low memory errors, access denied errors, printer will not print or prints wrong color, unable to install printer, error codes, printing blank pages, no image on printer display, and the tools used in printer maintenance.
episodes.title: Troubleshooting Printers
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

And welcome back to another

And in today's episode,
it's all about, well more A+.

Trying to get through all that content for

If you're keeping score,
that's the 22901 for

you know what I'm talking about.

15

Joining us back in the studio,

16
00:00:33.640 --> 00:00:35.090
Wes, we're glad to have you back.

17
00:00:35.090 --> 00:00:35.850
>> How's it going today, sir?

18
00:00:35.850 --> 00:00:37.420
>> Man, it's going great.

19

We've been troubleshooting our
way through troubleshooting.

00:00:39.860 --> 00:00:40.830
That's for sure.

21
00:00:40.830 --> 00:00:41.360

22
00:00:41.360 --> 00:00:46.370
And we're gonna be talking about
the bane of just about all IT existence.

23
00:00:46.370 --> 00:00:49.070
In this episode, that's going to
be about troubleshooting printer.

24
00:00:49.070 --> 00:00:50.310
>> Dun dun dun.

25
00:00:50.310 --> 00:00:52.180
>> That's right, I can think of a movie or

26
00:00:52.180 --> 00:00:56.110
two where the baseball bat is
the maintenance tool that you use.

27
00:00:56.110 --> 00:00:56.760
It's effective.

28
00:00:56.760 --> 00:00:57.395
>> That's right.

29
00:00:57.395 --> 00:00:58.090
[LAUGH]
>> Also,

30
00:00:58.090 --> 00:01:01.230
keep in mind printers are important,
like one of our other hosts says,

31
00:01:01.230 --> 00:01:04.570
Don Pizets says the whole entire
network can fail, but if at

32
00:01:04.570 --> 00:01:07.680
least one printer is working, you can
>> Can print your resume

33
00:01:07.680 --> 00:01:09.090
out the front door?

34
00:01:09.090 --> 00:01:10.680
So keep in mind printers are important.

35
00:01:10.680 --> 00:01:11.790
And all joking aside,

36
00:01:11.790 --> 00:01:15.480
we're gonna walk through just a real
slew of problems that they can give you.

37
00:01:15.480 --> 00:01:19.550
And we'll talk about some of
the common things you can check

38
00:01:19.550 --> 00:01:24.390
to make sure that these
things can get fixed.

39
00:01:24.390 --> 00:01:25.780
So let's go ahead.

40
00:01:25.780 --> 00:01:26.890
We're gonna dive right in.

41
00:01:26.890 --> 00:01:30.130
One of the first things they
talk about are streaks.

42
00:01:30.130 --> 00:01:32.330
When we talk about streaks and

43
00:01:32.330 --> 00:01:34.740
your printed output could
be a couple of things.

44
00:01:34.740 --> 00:01:37.270
Right?
One of the things is that if it's a laser

45
00:01:37.270 --> 00:01:38.610
printer, could be the toner hopper.

46
00:01:38.610 --> 00:01:39.920
Could be a toner hopper issue.

47
00:01:39.920 --> 00:01:43.970
Remember that's where
our toner's going to be.

48
00:01:43.970 --> 00:01:46.740
Right?
It could be low toner for that matter.

49
00:01:46.740 --> 00:01:49.360
As toner starts to fade,
you also get faded images as well.

50
00:01:49.360 --> 00:01:54.390
Could be low toner or
low ink if it's an inkjet type printer.

51
00:01:54.390 --> 00:01:58.800
It could be things like, for instance,
damaged print head assemblies.

52
00:01:58.800 --> 00:02:01.950
That is something that can
also cause streaks as well.

53
00:02:01.950 --> 00:02:04.690
Some of the other things
that we have faded prints.

54
00:02:04.690 --> 00:02:05.820
We talk about faded prints.

55
00:02:05.820 --> 00:02:08.980
Well, faded prints can be just
the fact that whatever the-

56
00:02:08.980 --> 00:02:10.920
not the print media itself- but

57
00:02:10.920 --> 00:02:15.870
whatever the Compound is the component
is that it actually hits the media.

58
00:02:15.870 --> 00:02:17.290
It could be low.

59
00:02:17.290 --> 00:02:21.720
So some of these you're going to see
that they could manifest themselves in

60
00:02:21.720 --> 00:02:26.520
different types of media output
as far as the fact that hey,

61
00:02:26.520 --> 00:02:30.230
well, if we've got streaks,
could be running out of toner.

62
00:02:30.230 --> 00:02:31.460
We had a faded image?

63
00:02:31.460 --> 00:02:32.030
Well, guess what?

64
00:02:32.030 --> 00:02:33.110
It could be running out of toner.

65
00:02:33.110 --> 00:02:38.580
It could be the fact, if you had a faded
print, that it's an impact printer.

66
00:02:38.580 --> 00:02:42.430
Don't discount the fact that impact
printers are still used especially

67
00:02:42.430 --> 00:02:47.030
because they are perfect for multicopy
printing, like carbon copies and stuff.

68
00:02:47.030 --> 00:02:47.960
They're heavily used.

69
00:02:47.960 --> 00:02:51.730
You've probably seen them in last
time you went to a mechanics shop and

70
00:02:51.730 --> 00:02:54.180
they maybe changed your oil and
they printed out the bill.

71
00:02:54.180 --> 00:02:56.510
You'll see a lot of times they tear
it right out, and you sign, and

72
00:02:56.510 --> 00:02:58.420
they keep their copy and
you keep your copy.

73
00:02:58.420 --> 00:03:01.380
So it could be that fact that
you have something like a ribbon

74
00:03:01.380 --> 00:03:03.942
replacement that needs to happen.

75
00:03:03.942 --> 00:03:07.300
All right, let's go ahead and
dive into another one.

76
00:03:07.300 --> 00:03:10.950
Another one they talk about is
the toner not fused to the paper.

77
00:03:10.950 --> 00:03:14.730
I have a little diagram here that we
used inside of our print process.

78
00:03:14.730 --> 00:03:17.280
When we are talking about
our print process and

79
00:03:17.280 --> 00:03:21.240
printers in general, just looking at
the different print technologies.

80
00:03:21.240 --> 00:03:25.770
Let's go ahead and
recap that laser print process,

81
00:03:25.770 --> 00:03:28.280
I wrote it out in a couple
of different ways.

82
00:03:28.280 --> 00:03:31.070
Remember processing, cleaning,
conditioning, writing, developing,

83
00:03:31.070 --> 00:03:32.150
transferring, and fusing.

84
00:03:32.150 --> 00:03:34.750
Boy, that sounds like
Mickey Mouse Club for sure.

85
00:03:34.750 --> 00:03:38.080
But remember the last phase
of the fusing process.

86
00:03:38.080 --> 00:03:41.870
And if you remember, if not go back and
check out our printing technologies

87
00:03:41.870 --> 00:03:45.890
episode, but remember that in the fusing
process, what happens is as the toner,

88
00:03:45.890 --> 00:03:50.780
right, as the toner this EP Drum, alright.

89
00:03:50.780 --> 00:03:54.056
I tell you what we'll kind
of brief through it here so

90
00:03:54.056 --> 00:03:57.266
we can know what the trouble
is that's happening.

91
00:03:57.266 --> 00:04:02.954
Remember that the laser basically hits the
scanning assembly if you will the scanning

92
00:04:02.954 --> 00:04:08.018
mirror and that basically points
the laser down on the electrostatic drum.

93
00:04:08.018 --> 00:04:12.388
It's called an EP drum electrostatic
photographic drum I've heard Remember

94
00:04:12.388 --> 00:04:15.720
it responds to electricity and
light as well.

95
00:04:15.720 --> 00:04:18.090
Now, the laser is responsible for

96
00:04:18.090 --> 00:04:23.980
reducing the electrical charge
that is put on the drum assembly.

97
00:04:23.980 --> 00:04:25.030
Well, here's the problem.

98
00:04:25.030 --> 00:04:26.370
Here's what can happen.

99
00:04:26.370 --> 00:04:29.480
As the paper and
as the drum rotates right,

100
00:04:29.480 --> 00:04:31.590
we have this loose transfer of the toner.

101
00:04:31.590 --> 00:04:33.160
That's in the developing phase.

102
00:04:33.160 --> 00:04:37.030
The developing phase is when the toner is
actually adhered to the paper because of

103
00:04:37.030 --> 00:04:40.560
the strong positive charge
that's put on the paper.

104
00:04:41.760 --> 00:04:46.890
Now here's the thing, the last part of
the laser print process is as the paper

105
00:04:46.890 --> 00:04:51.260
travels through the fusing assembly,
it uses friction and heat, right?

106
00:04:51.260 --> 00:04:53.150
Or pressure, excuse me, and heat.

107
00:04:53.150 --> 00:04:57.310
And kind of it you're rolling out dough,
we press the dough out and

108
00:04:57.310 --> 00:04:58.150
it flattens it out.

109
00:04:58.150 --> 00:05:01.600
Well, this is usually the combination
of that pressure and heat and

110
00:05:01.600 --> 00:05:05.940
the heat what it does is it melts the
plastics that are in the toner adhering it

111
00:05:05.940 --> 00:05:07.270
to the paper right.

112
00:05:07.270 --> 00:05:08.620
That's the fusing process.

113
00:05:08.620 --> 00:05:12.270
Now, when this fails to happen,

114
00:05:12.270 --> 00:05:14.360
there's a couple of things
that could be going on here.

115
00:05:14.360 --> 00:05:18.206
All right one is the fact
that the fusing assembly.

116
00:05:18.206 --> 00:05:19.218
It's failed.

117
00:05:19.218 --> 00:05:20.757
All right, it isn't heating up.

118
00:05:20.757 --> 00:05:24.060
And because of that, right?

119
00:05:24.060 --> 00:05:28.660
What's gonna happen is as that
paper comes out in the output tray,

120
00:05:28.660 --> 00:05:31.410
you can take the toner and you can
kind of smear it a little bit right?

121
00:05:31.410 --> 00:05:33.210
Because we're not having the heat at all.

122
00:05:33.210 --> 00:05:35.900
It's not melting it and
adhering the plastics to the paper.

123
00:05:37.120 --> 00:05:39.140
The other thing that can kinda
happen too with this, and

124
00:05:39.140 --> 00:05:43.160
I'll probably mess up my slide
here a little bit is when the,

125
00:05:43.160 --> 00:05:46.960
basically what happens is
the fusing rollers get overheated.

126
00:05:46.960 --> 00:05:49.950
It happens to warp them.

127
00:05:49.950 --> 00:05:51.020
All right.
So as they turn,

128
00:05:51.020 --> 00:05:54.030
they're not turning in a perfect
circle anymore, if you will.

129

00:14:38.520 --> 00:14:41.680

board the PCP that receives the

00:14:45.370 --> 00:14:49.220

00:14:55.500 --> 00:14:59.740
That formatter board, if I could say that

00:14:59.740 --> 00:15:03.060

it receives instructions.

00:15:03.060 --> 00:15:04.950
So, let's follow the chain

00:15:04.950 --> 00:15:06.820
Operating system communicates
with the driver.

323
00:15:06.820 --> 00:15:09.390
The driver tells the formatter board

324
00:15:09.390 --> 00:15:11.760
The formatter board instructs the printer.

325
00:15:11.760 --> 00:15:15.060
On how to basically print the output.

326
00:15:15.060 --> 00:15:18.690
Any one of those chains breaks down we got
a break down in communication, guess what?

00:15:18.690 --> 00:15:20.040
We might have output problems.

00:15:20.040 --> 00:15:22.700
